https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/10/techn.snippet: Letter from John Andrew says there are Web sites that bring together job seekers and employers in snow-sports industry (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/10/techn.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Thanks for the section on Web sites of interest to skiers (''Hitting the Virtual Slopes All Year Round,'' Nov. 26). The lead article mentioned that some Web sites include ski-area jobs, but no specific sites were listed for that. **********One very helpful place that brings together job seekers and employers in the snow-sports industry is www.skiingthenet.com. **********It includes detailed descriptions of vacancies listed by resorts, ski shops, suppliers, food services and other operations, as well as copies of resumes of potential employees and interesting links to the Web sites of some employers who include information on opportunities in their organizations. **********JOHN ANDREW **********Ridgewood, N.J., Dec. 4, 1998

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/13/busin.snippet: Sun Microsystems Inc to announce overhaul of its work station business, including machines priced below $3,000, in response to competition from increasingly powerful personal computers (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/13/busin.main_headline: Responding to Rivals, Sun Plans to Revamp Work Station Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/13/busin.print_headline: Responding to Rivals, Sun Plans to Revamp Work Station Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/13/busin.body_text: **********Sun Microsystems Inc. plans to announce today an overhaul of its work station business, including machines priced below $3,000, in response to competition from increasingly powerful personal computers. **********The company, based in Mountain View, Calif., is the leading maker of work stations, desktop machines typically priced at $5,000 and up, used in computer-intensive tasks ranging from designing automobiles to creating special effects for movies. For Sun, work stations are a mainstay, generating $3.5 billion in revenue last year, according to an estimate by the International Data Corporation, a research concern. **********The entire work station business is under pressure from the recent inroads made by high-end personal computers, using the Intel Corporation's most powerful microchips and the Microsoft Corporation's industrial-strength operating system, Windows NT. **********In 1997, the sales of PC work stations running Windows NT grew 87 percent, to an estimated $6 billion, according to IDC. By contrast, sales of traditional work stations running Unix operating system, produced by companies including Sun and Hewlett-Packard, declined about 12 percent, to $9.8 billion in 1997. **********''With this announcement, Sun is responding very aggressively to the price challenge,'' said Tom Copeland, a work station analyst for IDC. **********Sun contended that its new lower-cost models, called Darwin, with prices starting at $2,995, were cheaper than comparably powered work stations made by PC makers, like Compaq. **********Sun, analysts say, is also delivering improved graphics capability in its new high-end work stations, the Ultra 60 series, at prices well below those offered by Silicon Graphics Inc., a leading supplier of machines for movie special effects and computer-generated animation. **********Sun has been able to cut the prices on its work stations while increasing their performance by revamping its product design and manufacturing in the last year, explained Ed Zander, the executive in charge of Sun's hardware business. It is now using many PC industry-standard parts in its machines, rather than design its own, while focusing time and investment on advancing its own technology -- Sun's Ultrasparc microchip and Solaris Unix operating system. **********Other work station producers, like Hewlett-Packard and I.B.M. have all decided recently to offer work stations running on Intel chips and Windows NT, as well as offering traditional Unix-based machines. **********''Sun is now the only vendor standing out against the Windows NT work station,'' said Peter Ffoulkes, an industry analyst for Dataquest, a research firm. ''And that is because Sun's management is totally committed to the concept that it is a technology company and not a reseller of other people's technology.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/26/busin.snippet: American investment banks are competing to export more of Wall Street's ways to Europe as profit expectations heighten with imminent introduction of the euro; many financial specialists are forecasting profound changes in way continental European ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/26/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: THE NEW EUROPE -- Importing the Ways of Wall St.; For Investment Firms, Euro Spells Opportunity
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/26/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: THE NEW EUROPE -- Importing the Ways of Wall St.; For Investment Firms, Euro Spells Opportunity
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/26/busin.body_text: **********It has all the trappings of a gold rush: the lure of riches, the frisson of risk, the headlong dash to stake the claims. **********The euro, Europe's single currency, makes its debut in just a week, creating a vast currency zone from the Arctic Circle to the Mediterranean. And to listen to the most optimistic of those seeking profit there, the currency's birth will unlock a mother lode of wealth that has set American investment banks competing to export more of Wall Street's ways to continental Europe. **********While these great expectations may be overblown, there is no doubt that for investors and fund managers, the euro's arrival one week from now will mean an unparalleled transformation. Trading in 11 separate currencies will disappear, creating a single financial bloc with an economic output greater than that of the United States. Many financial specialists forecast profound changes in the way continental European markets operate -- and increasing pressure on Europeans to emulate the ways of Wall Street. **********''There's this wall of money waiting to come into the market,'' said Jeremy Isaacs, head of European equity business at the Lehman Brothers office here. ''Do I think European investors are going to become more like U.S. investors? The answer is: absolutely.'' **********Of course, it is not as if continental European countries have been slouches in positioning themselves for the coming euro zone: Think only of megamergers like DaimlerChrysler, the Deutsche Bank takeover of Bankers Trust or the pharmaceutical fusion of Hoechst and Rhone-Poulenc. **********And the world's economic spiral and low growth forecasts for Europe as a whole have muted some of the more bullish voices forecasting a euro bonanza. ''I don't think you are going to have a revolution,'' Mr. Isaacs said. **********''You are going to have an evolution,'' he said. ''The question is when, not if.'' **********Euro coins and notes will not be introduced for two more years, but all transactions between banks in the 11 participating countries and all operations involving equities and bonds will be denominated in euros starting next week. With only one currency in play, European companies will increasingly be evaluated by equity investors and fund managers across a broad field of competition where pricing and performance are no longer disguised by national currencies or local scales of importance. **********The euro zone ''redefines what is a blue chip,'' said David Bowers, European equity strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company, arguing that, for instance, a company regarded as a heavyweight in one of the 11 countries would not necessarily make it into a euro index of top companies. **********In addition, 11 separate government bond markets will be replaced by a single euro debt market in which the divergent yields of the past will be replaced by far more subtle calculations of razor-thin spreads between, say, euro-denominated bonds issued by Italy and euro bonds issued by Germany. **********Cross-border acquisitions will be simplified by the euro, which will eliminate currency risk within the zone because it will have an immutable value against national currencies until they are phased out altogether in the year 2002. **********Insurance companies in the 11 euro countries alone have around $1 trillion invested in their own governments' bonds, according to Crispin Southgate, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. Pension funds have a further $350 billion in the same bonds. **********Both those amounts are set to mushroom as fund managers look for higher yields in the low-interest euro zone and strapped governments place an ever-larger part of the burden for pension provision on private citizens. **********These prospects have sharpened competition among the big American investment banks that have their European headquarters here and see themselves as best placed to deploy expertise won in the United States. That has set alarm bells ringing for big European institutions, which have been scrambling to acquire some of the same skills -- and the same reach -- as the introduction of the euro nears. **********''One of the things we have been seeing in the mergers in European banking groups is European banks trying to get the critical mass and the expertise to compete globally,'' said Madeleine Hall, a European fund manager at Schroders. **********They have not always been successful. For all its size, the giant UBS A.G., born of Union Bank of Switzerland's merger with the Swiss Bank Corporation, lost out badly in this year's meltdown of emerging and speculative markets. **********Still, big European banks such as Paribas, Deutsche Bank, ABN-Amro and Barclays are all hoping to translate strong local ties and cultural affiliations into thriving business. ''These firms are pretty powerful in their own markets,'' said Robert Morris, a managing director at Barclay Capital. While American banks would seek to expand corporate bond and other business in Europe, he added, ''it doesn't mean to say that they are quickly going to steal the market.'' **********The competition is particularly fierce in the creation of new indices for bonds denominated in euros -- a dry-sounding business redolent of number-crunching that will still play a central role both in the evaluation of fund managers' performance in a changing market-place and, more gradually, in the way businesses raise money to finance their operations. **********In the last year, American financial institutions including Morgan Stanley Capital International, Salomon Smith Barney, Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch, Bear, Stearns and J. P. Morgan have devised eurobond indices in anticipation of a new, performance driven approach to investment in the 11 euro countries. **********By contrast, only Barclays among the European banks has devised a similar index, and that one is narrowly based on government bond performance. In the last 18 months, the overall number of benchmarks has risen to 14 from two -- a proliferation some bankers view as excessive. Such has been the rush to new indices that 1998 has become known as the year of ''the battle of the benchmarks.'' **********The institutions offering benchmarks are hoping not only for the adoption of their indices as gauges for managers' performance but also for the business that comes with it. ''What distinguishes one index provider from another is the reach of services,'' said Richard Pagan of Salomon Smith Barney. **********Most of the new euro indices are now heavily weighted toward government bonds because corporate-bond issuance, though it has grown rapidly over the last year, is still only a fraction of the United States level. **********Government bonds in Lehman Brothers' United States aggregate bond index, for example, take up 47 percent of the index while corporate debt accounts for 21 percent. The same bank's euro bond index is composed of 67 percent government and 12 percent corporate debt. **********According to Anant Patel, a managing director at Bear, Stearns, the government bond market in the euro zone is currently worth some 2.25 trillion euros -- more than $2.6 trillion -- compared with a corporate bond market now valued at some 690 billion euros, roughly $800 billion. **********The expectation among fund managers is that those proportions will change radically as continental European banks re-examine corporate loans and companies wean themselves away from reliance on banks for financing. **********At present, said Merrill Lynch's Mr. Southgate, 90 percent of corporate financing in continental Europe is provided by bank loans, compared with 50 percent in the United States. By some estimates, fewer than 10 percent of continental Europe's 1,700 investment-grade companies -- many of them in Germany -- have issued public debt. That is set to change. **********''European banks are looking more closely at how much money they make,'' said David Munves, credit market strategist at Lehman Brothers. ''Corporate loans are coming under scrutiny, due to shareholder value in general.'' **********''It's a major opportunity for new index providers,'' he said. **********One indication of the likely shift toward corporate issuance is the prospect of stepped-up activity by ratings agencies -- still an unfamiliar concept to many European companies. **********Eric de Bodard, managing director for corporate finance in Europe at Moody's Investor Services, said the number of European companies to which Moody's ratings had been assigned grew by 100 to more than 300 in 1998. **********''All the signs point to at least as active a year'' in 1999, he said. ''Investors are going to be looking for more yield and are going to diversify their portfolios without foreign exchange risk.'' **********Indeed, said Mr. Patel at Bear, Stearns, with the advent of a single currency for financial transactions, the nature of portfolio management will change. **********''Traditionally in Europe, the way in which portfolio managers have been able to deliver performance is to take views on relative currency performance and the performance of spread relationships between markets,'' he said. **********With the arrival of the euro, though, ''the currency component will disappear, which was one of the biggest components,'' while interest rate spreads will shrivel. ''And now all of a sudden, you ask the question: where do I get value enhancement?'' **********The result, he said, will be ''a very new investment dynamic for Europe.'' **********Banks see their indices playing into a European transformation whose precise course is still unclear and may, indeed, face many regulatory hurdles. **********Many fund managers are hoping, for instance, that a boom in private pensions will introduce vast new sums to the market, as happened in Britain, whose pension fund industry is bigger than all of continental Europe's combined. **********Against that, continental pensions are a ticking political time bomb. Many Europeans regard a comfortable state pension as an inalienable birthright and are uncomfortable with the notion of a private pension provision familiar to an increasing number of Americans. Moreover, European private pension funds, like European mutual funds, face regulatory restrictions. **********On top of that, Russia's meltdown has dampened appetites for corporate bonds, particularly high-yield bonds. That has made some assessments more cautious. Corporate bonds, said Mr. Bowers at Merrill Lynch, will provide ''one of the most exciting challenges that the euro will bring about.'' But this year's financial problems, he said, ''have left people a little nervous about rushing into this.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/15/busin.snippet: Transmontaigne Inc to buy part of Louis Dreyfus Corp's energy division for about $161 million in cash and stock (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/15/busin.main_headline: TRANSMONTAIGNE PLANS TO ACQUIRE LOUIS DREYFUS ENERGY
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/15/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; TRANSMONTAIGNE PLANS TO ACQUIRE LOUIS DREYFUS ENERGY
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/15/busin.body_text: **********Transmontaigne Inc. agreed yesterday to buy part of the Louis Dreyfus Corporation's energy division for about $161 million in cash and stock to expand its business in the Southern and Eastern United States. Transmontaigne, based in Denver, provides transportation, storage and marketing services to oil and chemical companies. It will pay about $113 million in cash, 4.5 million shares of its common stock and an undisclosed amount of working capital for closely held the Louis Dreyfus Energy, a petroleum products subsidiary of Louis Dreyfus, based in Wilton, Conn. Louis Dreyfus Energy, based in Atlanta, operates 24 refined petroleum products terminals and storage facilities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/22/busin.snippet: Perry D Odak, new chief executive at Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc, has brought no-nonsense business attitude to countercultural ice cream maker; he has introduced new flavors, redesigned packaging and dropped some unprofitable products; Odak, who to...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/22/busin.main_headline: Getting Serious at Ben & Jerry's; Cherry Garcia and Friends Trade Funky for Functional
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/22/busin.print_headline: Getting Serious at Ben & Jerry's; Cherry Garcia and Friends Trade Funky for Functional
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/22/busin.body_text: **********First Jerry Garcia, leader of the Grateful Dead and inspiration for the popular Cherry Garcia flavor, died. Then the Peace Pop was ruled obsolete. Next, a plan to create an organic ice cream line suffered a meltdown on business principles. **********The last few years have brought change and tumult to Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc., the counterculture's contribution to the ice cream industry. Sure, Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, the co-founders, still show up at the office in cutoff blue jeans and ride motorcycles for recreation across the rapidly disappearing Burlington countryside. And the company observed its 20th birthday on May 5 the same way it always has, with a nationwide handout of free cones. **********But much of Ben & Jerry's tie-dyed approach to life has vanished, replaced by a philosophy in which balance-sheet priorities have gained the upper hand. While no one is wearing three-piece suits to work just yet, and Mr. Cohen can still be found railing against the military-industrial complex, Ben & Jerry's has undergone a transformation in which practicality rules the roost and even the social mission for which the company became so well known is much more, um, corporate. **********Those fearing a sellout, however, should ponder this: Tightening the company's business practices is not only improving the bottom line, but also seems to be promoting performance when it comes to worthy causes. **********''In the past, you could put ideas out there, and sometimes they happened and sometimes they didn't,'' said Elizabeth A. Bankowski, the company's social mission director, recalling the company's earlier, erratic efforts at doing good. ''We now meet and identify social mission objectives by function, and it's taken as seriously as every other business objective.'' **********The person responsible for most of this is Perry D. Odak, who took over as chief executive 16 months ago and is widely credited with turning the company's fortunes around. **********Mr. Odak, a towering, soft-spoken veteran of companies ranging from Color Tile to the U.S. Repeating Arms rifle makers, replaced Robert Holland, who had been selected after a highly publicized nationwide search for someone to take over the day-to-day duties from Mr. Cohen, who remains the chairman, and Mr. Greenfield, the vice chairman. Mr. Holland, a McKinsey-trained consultant whose arrival was greeted with high hopes, lasted less than two years and left for ''personal reasons.'' **********When Mr. Odak arrived in January 1997, Ben & Jerry's sales were down, and more important, morale was battered. Was the social mission, which many employees said was highly important to them, something to be abandoned in the search for profits, or was it going to continue to be a priority? ''Ben & Jerry's has suffered through a leadership crisis over the past several years,'' the 1996 annual report stated bluntly. The company, the report acknowledged, was ''at a critical point.'' **********Mr. Odak, 52, spent part of the turbulent 1960's at Cornell University but was too busy putting himself through school -- by milking a herd of Brown Swiss cows twice a day -- to participate in student protests. He concedes a certain lack of wackiness, and when asked his favorite ice cream, he replied, ''It used to be butter pecan, but now it's always our newest flavor.'' **********But maybe the company was finally ready for a different kind of leader. When he arrived, Mr. Odak set about reviving the business, filling management slots that had long been vacant, redefining jobs and paying for market research. **********Ben & Jerry's has long had great name recognition -- 78 percent of those questioned in one poll had heard of the brand -- but a lot of people (50 percent in that poll) were not buying. Some consumers were put off by the high fat content, not to mention the steep price, of the ''super premium'' ice cream. But many others were confused by the packaging, according to Mr. Odak. **********''If you didn't get the funky names,'' he said, ''you didn't know what was in the package.'' To aid shoppers who lacked the time to figure out what Chubby Hubby, say, might contain (malt-flavored ice cream with chocolate-covered peanut-butter-filled pretzels), he redesigned the carton, pushing the picture of Ben and Jerry off the lid and onto the back and toning down the graphics so that more realistic pictures of the ingredients replaced the busy hand-drawn look. A $2 million radio advertising campaign was ordered up -- a lot for Ben & Jerry's. **********Two sagging products, the Peace Pop and the Brownie Bar, were abandoned. In their place came the Phish Stick (a fish-shaped, chocolate-covered confection named for the alternative-rock band) and a series of ice creams on sticks packaged in boxes a la Haagen-Dazs. (Cherry Garcia, a melange of vanilla, chocolate and cherries, is still sold. Some defunct flavors that retain a following, like Dastardly Mash, are being recycled this year.) **********''We needed to tone down the funkiness without losing the fun,'' Mr. Odak said. As for the Peace Pop's demise, he added: ''We said to ourselves, where is the equity? It's in the Ben & Jerry's name, not in the name Peace Pop.'' **********Last month, the company announced an alliance with the actor Paul Newman, in which it will manufacture Newman's Own ice cream. While Newman's Own sends its own profits on to charity, it will pay Ben & Jerry's for manufacturing the product. The new product will also absorb some of the company's excess factory capacity and give it a contender in the slightly less expensive ''premium'' ice cream category. ''It's a win-win-win situation,'' said Kim Galle, an analyst at Adams Harkness & Hill, a Boston investment bank. **********The company earlier this year introduced a new flavor, Dilbert's World Totally Nuts, tied to the popular comic strip. Mr. Odak plans to add more ''scoop shops,'' as the company's retail outlets are known, and at least five of those are to be operated with nonprofit groups to employ homeless or otherwise needy people. The company also plans to start selling its ice cream in half-gallon containers in a bid to increase sales volume. **********Beyond that, Mr. Odak has increased Ben & Jerry's presence abroad: A single-serving package is being marketed in Japan (with flavors carrying boring names like ''Coffee,'') and the company recently acquired a small French ice cream chain based in Paris. There is a new licensing effort as well, which will initially make jackets and shirts with the Ben & Jerry's logo and could lead to additional food and apparel products. **********All this seems to be working. Mr. Galle projects 12 percent growth in sales this year, to $194.4 million,  while earnings for the first quarter  were $380,000, compared with a $1.06 million loss for the corresponding period in 1997. The company still lags behind Haagen-Dazs, the leader in the super-premium category. Haagen-Dazs had supermarket sales of $157 million for the year that ended in late March, according to Information Resources Inc., while Ben & Jerry's took in $120 million from supermarket shoppers during the period. The ice cream business as a whole grew by 11.7 percent in that period, to $3.3 billion, according to Information Resources. **********The stock of Ben & Jerry's, which  made its debut at $30.50 a share in 1992 but had traded as low as $12 in  September 1997, is now hovering around the $20 mark, a development that has also aided employee morale. [The stock closed yesterday at $19.75.] **********The company's social agenda also appears to be back on track. Mr. Odak points proudly to an environmentally friendly container, made of unbleached paper, that the company has developed and is expected to start using later this year. **********Contrast that with some of the colorful but ultimately inefficient quirks that had prevailed under Mr. Cohen and Mr. Greenfield. **********''Ben & Jerry's had a history of blurry lines between functions,'' said Ms. Bankowski, the social mission director, who is also a board member. ''Almost-meddling was an expected behavior, and decisions never seemed to be final. That was a part of the culture.'' **********Some plans really boomeranged. There was the time the company touted its environmental friendliness in arranging to use nuts from a Brazilian cooperative intended to discourage the cutting of rain forest trees. Highlighted on packages of Rainforest Crunch ice cream, the cooperative actually supplied only about 5 percent of the nuts used in the product. **********While the intentions were good, that 5 percent was judged way too low to be supporting the rain forest by the media, which took Ben & Jerry's to task over it. By last year, a spokesman said, a Peruvian cooperative was supplying most of the nuts. **********Mr. Odak ''has changed all that,'' Ms. Bankowski said. ''He holds people accountable,'' adding that performance reviews now reflect how well employees identify and meet their social mission objectives. Someone suggested cutting back on solid waste, and ''we now have a goal of reducing solid waste by 25 percent across the company.'' **********Mr. Galle, the investment analyst, said of Mr. Odak, ''This is a company that historically has not moved quickly, but he's been instrumental in getting them focused.'' **********Despite the improvement, there are still plenty of things that could give the company a jolt. One is cream prices, which were deregulated by the Federal Government in 1996. More increases could force Ben & Jerry's to raise its prices sooner than it would like, potentially putting growth on hold. **********Mr. Odak's shifts in direction have not always gone over well among old-timers. The decision to get rid of the Peace Pop, for example, left many feeling remorseful. ''There are people inside who really regretted that change,'' Ms. Bankowski said. Still, the organization that had inspired the Peace Pop name, One Percent for Peace, had itself ceased to exist. **********And the company continues to struggle to recruit and retain minority employees at all levels. Being situated in northern Vermont does not help. **********Meanwhile, a proposal to introduce a line of organic ice creams, seemingly perfect for a company like Ben & Jerry's, stumbled over the reality that no one could figure out how to sell it without losing money. ''The market indicated that people did not perceive the added value,'' Ms. Bankowski said. ''Ben is very disappointed with this decision.'' **********It all represents a coming of age for the company. When it comes to doing good deeds, not to mention selling ice cream, Ms. Bankowski added, ''Nothing is simple anymore.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/08/world.snippet: Russia's tax service to begin media blitz to prod tax-shirking Russians to file their tax returns before April 1 deadline; low level of compliance in Russia noted; last year, Russian Govt collected only about 52 percent of taxes due; last year in ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/08/world.main_headline: Russia's Tax Police Press Media Message: Pay Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/08/world.print_headline: Russia's Tax Police Press Media Message: Pay Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/08/world.body_text: **********When medieval Russian villagers savagely beat Prince Igor for trying to make them pay taxes, bad things happen: His redoubtable wife, Princess Olga, rides up to their wooden fortress with a posse of soldiers, then sets a flock of sparrows on fire and releases them to burn down the village. **********As cartoon messages go, this latest Russian television advertisement has been a bit confusing to viewers. It is not aimed at promoting animal abuse. Rather, the cartoon is a fractured slice of Russian history served up by the Russian tax service to persuade Russian children that people should pay taxes -- or else. **********Starting this month, a series of similar cartoon ads will begin flooding the airwaves of Russian state-owned television, part of a media blitz before the April 1 deadline for filing tax returns, which in tax-shirking Russia is partly a day of national mourning -- and partly a 24-hour frenzy of April Fool's trickery. Last year, the Russian Government collected only about 52 percent of the taxes due. Last year in Moscow, a city of 10 million, only 120,000 people filed their income taxes on time. **********Seventy years of Soviet culture, when the state owned everything and minimal taxes on wages were deducted directly at the workplace, is one reason Russians balk at the unfamiliar civic duty. The Byzantine and often punitive Russian tax code is another. President Boris N. Yeltsin has vowed to submit a new tax code by the middle of this year, but passage of the deeply contested bill in the Parliament is highly problematic. **********Seeking to enforce the existing tax laws, frustrated Russian tax inspectors are now aiming at the next generation. **********''We need to broaden our audience,'' Aleksandr Borisov, a spokesman for the Moscow tax service, said. ''If we want to someday create a normal government, then we need to also develop a normal sense of citizenship -- it's a long process, and it may take another generation before we get to that point.'' **********The Government's Pied Piper advertising campaign has provoked some cynicism among Russians, who doubt such cartoons will change deeply entrenched public attitudes. **********''The whole country now knows about tooth decay,'' Sergei N. Yenekolopov, a well-known Russian child psychologist, said. ''But I doubt more people are brushing their teeth in the morning.'' **********Tax evasion is a deeply rooted cultural trait, Mr. Yenekolopov said,  mythified in folk tales that glorify Russian peasants refusing to pay tribute to the Tartar invaders -- a message, he added, that the tax police's historical cartoon inadvertently reinforces. He said he did not approve of reaching out to children to get at the parents. **********''At worst, it could result in a horde of Pavlik Morozovs,'' he said, referring to a little boy who was murdered after informing on his parents to the Bolsheviks, and became a Stalinist martyr. ''Children could blackmail their parents with a call to the tax police if their parents reprimand them for bad grades in school.'' **********The Soviet tradition of encouraging citizens to inform on their neighbors, moreover, is still embedded in the tax code: People who report tax evasion to the tax police can receive a reward of up to 10 percent of the hidden income. **********Some recent high-profile efforts to install a sense of civic duty in the present generation of taxpayers have backfired: after the Russian skier Larisa Lazutina won three gold medals at the Nagano Winter Olympics and was awarded close to $1 million in bonus prize money from the Russian Olympic Committee, the Government and other sources, a senior tax service official quickly announced that she and other Olympic winners would have to hand over 35 percent of their winnings in taxes. A storm of outrage forced the Government to back down this week. **********Russian authorities are also seeking to link tax evasion to sexual impotence. In a television ad prepared by Video International, the same Russian advertising company that produced the children's cartoons, a man is shown, sitting up half-naked in bed, mournfully clicking his bedside lamp on and off, as the beautiful woman next to him turns away angrily. **********The voice-over says: ''Lost your desire? That's nerves. Pay your taxes and live peacefully.'' **********But the truth is that in Russia, tax evaders for the most part do live peacefully. Everybody cheats, and only the unlucky few get caught. The Russian tax system, created from scratch in 1992, is filled with paradoxes. The tax police have far broader license than even United States Internal Revenue Service officers to seize assets. (Last month, the Government finally issued a ruling requiring tax inspectors to obtain a court order before seizing a suspected tax evader's bank accounts.) **********On the other hand, the vast and poorly audited Russian bureaucracy makes it much easier for Russians to hide their income and assets from the Government. Companies rely on off-shore corporations and fanciful records. Individual citizens register their property in the name of obscure front companies and long-lost cousins. And like anywhere else, the rich have a far easier time hiding their real income than do small-time wage-earners. **********''If you believe their statements, bank officers earn the lowest salaries in Russia,'' Mr. Borisov said, lamenting that business executives who own dachas, luxury apartments and foreign cars get away with declaring incomes of $100 a month. So do politicians and entertainment figures. **********Last year Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin said he would set an example and release his income declaration. Mr. Chernomyrdin, former chairman of the giant monopoly Gazprom and widely believed to one of the richest men in Russia, said he earned just $8,000 in 1996. He set his net worth at $50,000. **********After Alla Pugachova, Russia's most popular pop star, was hauled into a special meeting of celebrities with tax officials, she complained that touring expenses had left her almost destitute. She pleaded for a tax amnesty and contended that she was being forced to return to work because she had not earned enough to retire. **********''I am going back to singing again, and all because of my desperate financial situation,'' she said. **********The tax laws, on the other hand, give people reason to cheat. **********Russia charges companies a 4 percent tax on their gross income. **********On top of that, the Russian corporate profit tax is 35 percent -- which is not significantly higher than the rate on American companies, except that Russian companies are not allowed to deduct business expenses. The Russian value-added tax is 20 percent, two times higher than the highest sales taxes in the United States. Similarly, the top tax bracket, on incomes of $8,000 a year or more, is 35 percent and there are no deductions allowed for charitable contributions, business expenses, medical costs or property taxes. **********And the tax service does not always inspire trust. The Russian tax police have special elite units that seize bank assets and property while clad in bullet-proof armor and black helmets and carrying automatic weapons. They look more like commandos than accountants. **********With this in mind, Mr. Borisov said the Government's humorous ad campaigns were also aimed at softening the image of the tax police. **********''We need to show we are special forces with a human face,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/07/world.snippet: Russia's financial crisis is playing itself out on wider landscape of Russian economy; looming largest of all is mountain of unpaid bills that have accumulated as companies, private and government, run out of money to pay each other, their workers...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/07/world.main_headline: Mountains of Bad Debt Stifle Russian Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/07/world.print_headline: Mountains of Bad Debt Stifle Russian Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/07/world.body_text: **********It was April when Dmitri Chernikh saw the first ripples of Russia's financial crisis lapping at the door of Galatica, one of Russia's hottest computer software companies. **********It was not the collapse of the Russian financial markets, or the dizzying leap in interest rates, or even the first uncertain steps of the country's new untested Government that worried Mr. Chernikh or his fellow directors. Like most other young Russian businesses, Galatica, with $8 million in sales last year, does not trade its shares publicly, nor has it ever sought bank loans, rates for which were prohibitive even before the latest financial panic. **********What hit Galatica last spring was something more basic, and more endemic to Russia's unfinished economic crisis: a pileup of unpaid bills, which by midsummer had topped $3 million, as the company's biggest clients -- mostly in the rich and powerful energy sector -- stopped payments on Galatica's popular management software package. **********Even after the agreement last month for a $22.6 billion package of credits and loans, Russia's financial crisis is still playing itself out on the wider landscape of the Russian economy -- if a devastated industrial base, an infant private sector and a cartel of moguls who control banking, raw materials and other key sectors can be properly called an economy. **********Like the Government, Galatica swung quickly into crisis mode. **********One option considered at the first emergency meeting was a joke: ''Change countries.'' But the company's directors -- computer whizzes from Moscow State University who founded Galatica in the early days of Soviet economic reform --were searching for a more realistic response. **********Briefly, they considered a get-tough approach. Threatening letters were sent out to clients, warning them that Galatica would cut off consulting services to companies that did not pay their bills. **********But like other attempts at breaking through the wall of Russian arrears, this bluff fell flat. **********''The response was so tough that we backed off,'' Mr. Chernikh said. ''At that point we decided that if the country is in bad shape and our clients are in bad shape, we would just have to suffer, too.'' **********Looming largest of all is the mountain of unpaid bills that have accumulated as companies, private and government, run out of money to pay each other, their workers or their taxes. **********There is even a thriving trade in debts. At the end of 1996, overdue debts constituted one third of all accounts payable to enterprises, forcing producers to rely on barter for their commercial transactions. **********As the Government moves to tighten monetary policy further, even less money is available, particularly for businesses like Galatica that offer services that many of its customers -- caught in a squeeze between newly aggressive tax collectors and angry unpaid workers -- consider low priority. **********Small companies anywhere are vulnerable to sudden financial shifts, but in Russia, the small-business sector -- much of which exists below the radar of Government data collectors -- is particularly exposed, lacking both access to credit and the protection of a well-developed system for bankruptcy and other restructuring. **********For most Russian businesses, borrowing money from local banks is not feasible, given the continuing rise in interest rates, which were already at punishing levels of about 40 percent a year for short-term loans before the crisis hit. According to one recent report, credits to the private sector in Russia amount to only 7 percent of gross domestic product, compared with 15 percent in Poland, 24 percent in Hungary or 111 percent in Germany. **********For small companies like Galatica, which employs almost 500 people in offices scattered around the former Soviet Union, seeking investors through a public offering of shares is not realistic either, particularly now with the uncertainties that cloud Russian markets. **********As the crisis deepens, many are predicting that more and more Russian companies, small and large, are going to have to scale back already pared down operations. **********''Regardless of whether people have access to bank loans, there is a single pool of capital,'' said Edwin Dolan, president of the Moscow-based American Institute of Business and Economics, which offers a master's degree in business administration. ''The tightening of monetary policy is going to affect access to working capital, which in turn tightens the nonpayment crisis.'' **********Galatica's strategy has been to look beyond its big clients in Russia's energy sector -- which have been hit hard by a drop in world energy prices -- and focus on more stable sectors, like retailing and food processing, which have more direct links to consumers. It has been helped by a recent merger with Parus, another Russian software company that built up a diverse clientele, and by its operations outside Russia, in former Soviet states like Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan. **********Coping with financial crises is not a new challenge for Galatica, which also saw payments grind to a halt in the period before the 1996 presidential elections. Then Russia's money supply dried up dramatically for several months as foreign investors, fearing a Communist victory, stayed away, and as the Russian Government drained its budget to help President Boris N. Yeltsin's re-election effort. **********''In 1996, the crisis was much bigger than now,'' Mr. Chernikh said. ''Then people stopped paying altogether. But each passing crisis is a little less alarming. It is like gunfire. The first time is frightening, the next time a little less.'' **********Two years later, after a boom year in 1997 when sales more than tripled, Galatica's directors are relatively sanguine about their ability to survive without layoffs or major restructuring. Even a devaluation of the ruble, which to most analysts would be the worst-case scenario for the Russian economy, might not so devastating. For one thing, noted Mr. Chernikh, Galatica has always set its prices in dollars, a practice that dates back to the early 1990's when the value of the ruble was being whipped by inflation. **********Since 1992, when the company developed its first program to help companies manage their resources, Galatica has geared its management programs to reflect the way their clients actually do business, not the way they should according to Western business school textbooks. **********From Soviet-style bookkeeping to  barter transactions, Mr. Chernikh says Galtica's programs have kept up with Russia's reality. **********''Western companies solve their problems very differently from Russian companies,'' he said. ''Here, for instance, a contract is not a contract  in the Western sense. It can change during implementation, which is something we have taken into account.'' **********From its beginnings as an enterprising team from Moscow State University's prestigious mechanical and mathematics department then operating on the outer edges of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's first economic reforms, the company has had the advantage of direct experience with Russia's lurching progress towards a market economy, even as it kept close ties with the wave of Russian ''computershiki'' who emigrated in the late 1980's to Silicon Valley in California. **********An important break came in 1988 when Galatica won the contract to computerize the electronic voting at the Congress of People's Deputies, an elected gathering that was to usher in political reform to the Soviet Union. But its biggest advantage was to be one of the first on what was then an empty playing field. **********''For a long time in Russia, you could do something in Russia without money,'' Mr. Chernikh said. ''Now it is already more complicated. The importance of having a name, a reputation, has much more meaning now than it did even five years ago, and that requires more money up front.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/29/busin.snippet: American gross domestic product posts 3.9 percent gain in third quarter, confounding warnings that Asian and Russian economic crises would slow US economy (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/29/busin.main_headline: Data Offer No Hint Yet Of a Slowing Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/29/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS: DIARY; Data Offer No Hint Yet Of a Slowing Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/29/busin.body_text: **********Soak it, sleep in it, leave it out in a storm: Nothing seems to shrink or even much wrinkle the American economy. **********The gross domestic product posted a healthy 3.9 percent annual growth rate in the third quarter, confounding widespread warnings that the continuing economic crisis in Asia and Russia and the resulting turmoil in financial markets would slow down the economy. Durable-goods orders slipped 1.7 percent in October, more than expected, but consumer confidence rose sharply in the November survey, personal income and spending both posted the expected modest gains in October, and existing-home sales were strong. **********Economists continue to warn that the stream of positive indicators could dry up any time; many still tentatively forecast a slowdown sometime in 1999. **********The view through the crystal ball at the holiday shopping season is none too clear,  either: On Wednesday, a news report headlined ''Poll: One-Quarter of Americans Plan to Cut Holiday Spending'' was transmitted on Associated Press news wires within two minutes of an article sent by AP's rival, Reuters, entitled ''Buoyant U.S. Consumers Set to Shop Heartily.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/24/busin.body_text: **********TRADE **********Deficit at a Record **********The nation's monthly trade deficit surged to $13 billion in March, the deepest since the Commerce Department adopted its current measurement system in 1992 and considerably more than economists had expected. The deficit in February was $12.2 billion. The new figures provided clear evidence of the impact on the United States -- both good and bad -- of Asia's mounting economic woes. Growth in the American economy, which had been threatening to overheat, was restrained. But at the same time, United States exports remained weak, hurting many manufacturers and farmers, and imports surged, a trend that does not bode well for the long term. **********INTEREST RATES **********No Increase, for Now **********The Federal Reserve's policy-setting Open Market Committee declined once again to increase short-term interest rates, apparently viewing the threat of inflation as remote and believing that any American rate increase could worsen the economic situation in Asia. Underlying the benign view of inflation are a number of recent indicators, including a 2.3 percent decline in new housing starts last month, to an annual rate of 1.538 million units. Many analysts had expected a small gain. Minutes of the Fed's March 31 meeting show that it saw a risk of inflation but decided to hold rates steady because of Asia's malaise. **********MARKETS **********Commodity Index Skids **********The Commodity Research Bureau/Bridge index of 17 commodities skidded to its lowest level in more than four years, dropping to 219.27 on Tuesday and ending the week at 219.18. Futures prices for copper, silver, oil, nickel, wheat and other commodities have been in a long-term decline that has been aggravated in recent days by Indonesia's political turmoil and -- see a pattern here? -- the Asian economic collapse. Stock and bond markets were little changed for the week. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week at 9,144.44, up 48.44. But technology stocks were battered, and the Nasdaq composite index lost 41.77, to close at 1,805, its weakest level in more than six weeks. **********TOBACCO **********A Pipe Dream? **********Anti-smoking legislation hit a potentially serious snag in the Senate, and further action was postponed until next month, sending President Clinton; Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and other Senate leaders who want to deter teen-agers' smoking back to the drafting table. Just as it appeared a consensus was forming to increase the Federal tax on cigarettes by $1.10 a pack while giving tobacco companies some protection against lawsuits, an unusual coalition of senators formed. Some want to kill the legislation, while others advocate the toughest possible anti-smoking measure. ''We are making a deal with the Devil,'' said Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, who opposes any limit on the companies' legal liability. **********SOCIAL SECURITY **********A Market-Based Proposal **********The National Commission on Retirement Policy, which includes members of Congress from both parties, proposed a sweeping overhaul of the Social Security system, calling for the establishment of personal investment accounts and a gradual increase in the retirement age, to 70, to make up for a cash shortfall expected when 77 million baby boomers become eligible for Social Security benefits. ''The goal of this is to have people more involved in their own savings,'' said Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, a leader of the group, which includes lawmakers, economists, pension-system experts and business executives. The report says the changes would keep Social Security solvent for at least 75 years without raising taxes. Some liberals, however, oppose any plan that does not offer guaranteed benefits. **********DEALS **********A Merger Epidemic **********What would once have been a big deal seems today to be business as usual. Seagram, accelerating its shift from beverages and spirits into an entertainment powerhouse, agreed to buy Polygram, one of the world's largest music companies, for $10.6 billion in cash and stock; to raise money for the acquisition, Seagram is shedding its Tropicana juice business. . . . Pearson, Britain's largest publisher, and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, a Dallas investment firm, agreed to buy most of Simon & Schuster's operations from Viacom for $4.6 billion in cash. . . . Office Depot said it would acquire Viking Office Products in a $3 billion stock swap. . . . Dillard's said it would acquire Mercantile Stores, a Midwest retailer, for $2.9 billion in cash. . . . Fortis, a Belgian-Dutch banking and insurance group, agreed to acquire Generale de Banque, Belgium's largest, for $11.1 billion. . . . Francois Pinault, the French investor who bought 29.1 percent of Christie's earlier this month, said he would buy the rest in a deal that values the international auction house at $1.2 billion. . . . Royal Ahold extended its reach into the American supermarket business with a $2.6 billion deal for Giant Food Inc. **********VIAGRA **********Worldwide Demand **********Viagra, intended to help impotent men, has yet to pass clinical tests in Taiwan, but it is already selling for $59 on the black market there. In Taipei, a nurse displayed a bag of the medication. In the United States, the Food and Drug Administration reported on Friday that Pfizer Inc. had said that six patients taking the drug had died, although it was unknown if Viagra played any role in the deaths. A spokeswoman for the F.D.A. said the agency was investigating but continued to believe the drug was safe and effective and had asked Pfizer to provide more information to patients on the proper use of the drug. Pfizer's stock fell $3.69, to $105.44.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/17/busin.snippet: All Nippon Airways Co is set to become next member of Star Alliance, world's biggest airline group, as alliance pushes to expand its reach in Asia (S)

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/17/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; All Nippon Airways May Join Star Alliance
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/17/busin.body_text: **********The All Nippon Airways Company, Japan's second-largest airline, is set to become the next member of the Star Alliance, the world's biggest airline grouping, as the alliance pushes to expand its reach in Asia.
