https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/19/busin.snippet: Cooper Cameron Corp agrees to acquire privately held Orbit Valve International Inc for about $100 million in cash (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/19/busin.main_headline: COOPER CAMERON TO BUY ORBIT VALVE FOR $100 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; COOPER CAMERON TO BUY ORBIT VALVE FOR $100 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/19/busin.body_text: **********The Cooper Cameron Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Orbit Valve International Inc. for about $100 million in cash. Orbit, based in Little Rock, Ark., manufactures  valves for the oil, gas and petrochemical industries. The company had 1997 revenues of about $85 million. Cooper Cameron, a Houston-based oil industry equipment supplier, had 1997 revenues of $1.81 billion. Shares of Cooper Cameron rose $1.75, to $51.25.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/25/busin.snippet: Norman C Payson, doctor named to take reins of Oxford Health Plans, begins to outline strategy to turn around troubled managed care company; plan includes overhauling company's systems and tightening controls; any turnaround plan hinges on success...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/25/busin.main_headline: Oxford Health Plan's Turnaround Strategy Emerging
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/25/busin.print_headline: Oxford Health Plan's Turnaround Strategy Emerging
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/25/busin.body_text: **********Norman C. Payson, the doctor named to take the reins of Oxford Health Plans, has begun to outline to employees a strategy to turn around the troubled managed care company. The plan includes overhauling the company's systems and tightening controls. **********But any turnaround plan hinges on the success of the company's effort to sell $350 million of debt over the next few months. Oxford could begin approaching investors as soon as next week about participating in a private placement of high-yield bonds, according to people who have been briefed on the company's plans. **********The debt financing, which accounts for half the $700 million in capital Oxford plans to raise, is critical to the company's future. The $350 million in equity financing from Texas Pacific Group, a private investment firm, is contingent on the company's ability to raise the debt, and Dr. Payson, who is technically serving as a consultant to the company, is to become chief executive only when the financing is completed. **********The company expects to offer a mixture of senior secured notes and unsecured high-yield bonds to large investors like insurance companies and mutual funds. Oxford has already received commitments from some investors to buy about $150 million in senior notes, according to people briefed about the financing, but must still find buyers for the remainder of the debt. **********Making the sale may not be easy, given the company's problems over the last year. In 1997, Oxford lost $291 million and is not expected to return to profitability this year. The company is expected to announce its first-quarter results soon. **********''Whenever a company is in a turnaround situation, going to the capital markets is a more complicated situation,'' said Arun Kumar, a director for Standard & Poor's, a credit-rating agency based in New York. **********Last November, just as Oxford's troubles started to appear, Standard & Poor's looked at the company's New York subsidiary, which accounts for about three-quarters of Oxford's business. Based on the information that was public at the time, S.& P. gave the outfit a B rating, a low,  noninvestment-grade rating given to groups with ''vulnerable financial security.'' **********Still, no publicly traded security of Oxford has ever been evaluated by a credit rating agency, and the deal has not yet been priced. **********''The transaction continues to move forward, and we expect to close in the second quarter,'' said Owen Blicksilver, a spokesman for Texas Pacific. **********Dr. Payson declined to be interviewed until the financing was complete. But he  has been outlining a turnaround strategy to employees and benefits consultants, according to people who have heard his plans and The Oxford Bulletin, a publication Oxford sends to consultants and others. The plan includes bringing in a new management team. **********With the exception of William Sullivan, the company's former chief executive, and Jeffrey H. Boyd, the general counsel, all the top executives who were present when Oxford first stumbled have left the company. **********In addition to hiring Marvin Rich, the managed care executive who helped with a turnaround at Kmart, to oversee Oxford's operations, Dr. Payson has named Alan Muney, a doctor who used to head medical affairs for Avanti Health Systems, as the company's chief medical officer. Additional announcements are expected, including a permanent chief financial officer. **********Dr. Payson is also trying to make peace with Oxford's doctors, many of whom are frustrated because they say that they are still unpaid after Oxford fell months behind in paying claims last year. At the end of February, the company owed about $60 million to New York doctors and hospitals in claims more than 30 days old, according to the New York Attorney General's office, which acknowledged that the company is making progress in catching up. **********Dr. Payson is also making the rounds. According to The Oxford Bulletin, he has met with leaders at more than 50 partnerships, representing some 2,000 doctors, and 8 hospitals. Oxford has also had discussions with the New York County Medical Society, the group that represents 5,000 Manhattan doctors, which is seeking to bring legal arbitration against the company. **********Oxford's success with the doctors will largely depend on whether it can clean up its old bills and pay doctors on time. Oxford has been actively negotiating with doctors and hospitals to settle claims, and the company says that it continues to pay its bills more promptly. But Dr. Payson conceded in the bulletin that the company was a long way from being able to claim success. ''Recent upgrades to our claims payment processes have improved current claim throughput,'' he said, ''but there is still much hard work ahead of us.'' **********Indeed, there are no quick fixes to the company's computer system, which Oxford executives have long blamed for the bulk of the company's problems. The company has indicated that it plans to replace its system with a new one but has not said how much such a system could cost. **********Under Dr. Payson, Oxford will also focus more on the fundamentals of managed care. ''They really want to look at how they manage medical costs,'' said Marc Gouran, a group president of Solomon-Page Group, an executive search firm. Having focused mainly on negotiating discounted fees from hospitals and doctors, Oxford intends to monitor more closely the care being delivered, questioning such things as the length of hospital stays, and review the contracts it has with its providers. **********As it begins to be more heavy- handed with its doctors and hospitals, Oxford is also looking hard at the profitability of the coverage it offers. In its core commercial business, the company is expected to raise its premiums next year for many groups and shun those groups where it believes it will lose money. **********Oxford is also trying to stem the losses from some of its government programs, leaving the Medicaid market in some states and shifting more of the risk to hospitals and doctors in some areas where it offers Medicare coverage. In New York, the company was denied a rate increase for individuals this year, but the State Insurance Department is allowing Oxford to use some of the money from a special pool to offset some of the losses the company says it has incurred by providing the coverage. **********While talking about his plans for Oxford, Dr. Payson has also emphasized that he wants to retain the flexibility and innovative thinking that has made Oxford one of the New York region's most popular managed care plans. He must now prove Oxford can be profitable doing it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/01/busin.snippet: Scott Shuger does daily analysis of articles in nation's major daily newspapers, and analysis, called Today's Papers, is sent to 20,000 subscribers of electronic magazine Slate; Michael Kinsley, editor of Slate, says Shuger hopes to educate people...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/01/busin.main_headline: An On-Line Critic Tackles the Big Papers
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/01/busin.print_headline: An On-Line Critic Tackles the Big Papers
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/01/busin.body_text: **********Scott Shuger is paid to do what most readers do free: rant about -- and at -- the nation's major daily newspapers. Every night, working from his home office in Los Angeles, he consumes the next morning's front pages, writing a report of what made news and what didn't, tweaking reporters and editors for missed details and placement of articles. **********He then dispatches his analysis, simply called ''Today's Papers,'' to the 20,000 subscribers of the electronic magazine Slate. Nonsubscribers can read it free on the magazine's home page. **********''One of the things he is supposed to do is educate people about how to read the newspaper,'' said Michael Kinsley, the editor of Slate, which is owned by the Microsoft Corporation.  ''It's always interesting that USA Today and The New York Times have different views about what's going on in the world. One will lead with a story on page one and the other will have it buried on D24. Both of those judgments can't be right.'' **********Mr. Shuger worked as a Navy intelligence officer, an editor at The Washington Monthly and a book reviewer for Amazon.com. He said his column was not about what is right or wrong: I'm not trying to preach as much as wonder what the papers are doing,'' he said. **********Here are some of his impressions: **********How he sees the newspapers (The Wall Street Journal, USA Today, The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times, The New York Times.) **********All are very good to excellent papers. The fact of the matter is you don't get everything you need from every one of them. USA Today is the least affected of the papers; it doesn't write for the people who fly business class. It doesn't have the class or money orientation. This is probably one of my most politically incorrect judgments, but I think it's an effective national newspaper. It has something that I'd love to see the other papers pick up on: the routinization of the news. The press is too crisis-oriented, the stories too breathless. **********Patterns in the way articles are displayed. **********I don't think the patterns are hard and fast. Some of the differences are clearer than others. USA Today is very good expository reporting, more of a briefing paper. It's rare you pick up a story and don't know what happened. There are many times I've read a New York Times story where sometimes they're so strong in explanation and context that you actually lose sight of what happened. It's like a wealth of information. **********That's not the same as burying its lead. The L.A. Times tends to bury its leads. I am likely to go much deeper into an L.A. Times story without knowing what the point of it is. **********Ten years ago I would have said The Washington Post was demonstrably stronger on domestic political angles. Now, The New York Times Washington bureau has gotten hip to the nuances of D.C. The L.A. Times, in political stories, isn't much behind. It weaves domestic political elements pretty effectively. **********Why he feels he is qualified to critique daily newspapers. **********I've never worked for a daily newspaper. I was on a paper in high school. I used to be in the military, an intelligence officer in the Navy. I had a good job -- I didn't get killed and I learned a lot. I served in aviation, on a carrier overseas. People say you have no idea what the pressures are on a daily reporter. I say I used to brief admirals. **********What readers say. **********As soon as I heard the idea for this column, I thought of the morning briefing prepared by the staff in the Pentagon. I knew people would want it if it was done well. There's a base motive: people like to see the media brought down. **********Readers do really feel like communicating. I've always found letters really interesting. I love knowing the readers can click on my name and send me mail. If people write me and they've not understood me, I feel this tremendous need to take the time to explain it to them. A lot of people define things left, right, liberal. I basically ignore people who are ranting at me from a very doctrinal point of view.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/16/busin.main_headline: Chief of S.E.C. Chides Funds On Information
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/16/busin.print_headline: Chief of S.E.C. Chides Funds On Information
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/16/busin.body_text: **********Mutual fund investors, blinded by stunning investment returns the last several years, are not getting enough information about how much they are paying for a fund company's services, Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today. **********In an address to the annual meeting of the Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group, Mr. Levitt called on fund companies to temper their promotion of investment performance by explaining ''clearly and unequivocally'' how fees and expenses affect small investors and what risks they face if the financial markets decline. **********Mr. Levitt's prodding of the fund industry on the issue of costs comes as the financial services business is undergoing rapid consolidation. Banks, brokerage firms, insurance companies and other financial institutions are rushing to combine their operations in the belief that greater size brings economies of scale and lower costs. **********But executives in the mutual fund industry, which has grown to its current $5 trillion in assets from $1 trillion at the beginning of the 1990's, have consistently rejected that argument, saying that the industry's growth has brought with it demands by investors for more products and services. **********Mr. Levitt said he did not intend to tell fund companies how much to charge. ''But I'm concerned that investors are ignorant about expenses and fees,'' Mr. Levitt said. ''You've got to do a better job of making sure that those who sell funds also explain the costs of investing.'' **********A recent survey conducted by the commission showed that fewer than half of mutual fund investors know that fund expenses are deducted from a fund on an continuing basis, Mr. Levitt said. And only 8 percent say they completely understand the expenses that their funds charge, he said. **********''Financial illiteracy is very troubling in an era when workers are shouldering a significant portion of their retirement planning through 401(k) plans and I.R.A.'s,'' he said. **********Mr. Levitt's suggestions for improving disclosure drew a cool reception from some fund industry executives. ''I think they are all things that the industry is already doing,'' said Don Powell, chairman of Van Kampen American Capital, a mutual fund subsidiary of Morgan Stanley, and chairman of the industry trade group. **********Fund expenses vary widely based on a fund's investment objective. According to Strategic Insight, a New York fund research company, the average annual expense ratio of equity funds range from 1 percent of assets for growth and income funds to 1.6 percent of assets for international stock funds. Generally, the expense ratio of smaller funds is higher than for larger funds, because the costs of big funds are spread over more investors. **********According to some studies, the average expense ratio has been rising the last few years. Industry executives argue that statistic is misleading, however, because it includes more small, young funds that have been started up as the industry has boomed. **********But Mr. Levitt did not stop with the issue of expenses. He also chastised fund industry executives for hesitating to follow the commission's guidelines for simplifying fund prospectuses. **********Earlier this year, the S.E.C. approved new measures intended to make fund documents more understandable to the average investor, including allowing the use of a shortened, three-  to six-page version of the more detailed prospectus to sell fund shares. A full prospectus must then be delivered to the customer with confirmation of the order. **********''A number of funds have heeded our call for better communication,'' Mr. Levitt said. **********He added, however: ''We're chagrined to hear that some of you intend to make only a few cosmetic changes and mostly leave your prospectuses as they are -- the same dense, legalistic presentations that investors don't want, don't understand and don't read. In our book, that merits a failing grade.'' **********Fund companies have not entirely rejected the S.E.C.'s proposals to simplify documents, some industry executives say. Rather, they are trying to square them with demands from many investors for more information. **********''Fund companies are struggling with how much detail should we get into,'' said Paul G. Haaga Jr., an executive vice president of Capital Research and Management, which manages the American Funds. ''I think investors get a great amount of accurate detail about fees. The question is how does an investor use that information to then make a decision.'' **********Mr. Levitt also called on mutual fund directors to be more vigilant about oversight of fund companies, questioning fees and otherwise watching out for the interest of fund shareholders. **********The commission will hold a round table on fund governance this fall, he said, to discuss the role of independent fund directors in hiring and dismissing portfolio managers, monitoring the fees that investors pay to fund managers and otherwise acting as watchdogs for fund shareholders. **********''Everyone knows that the fund director is the shareholder's representative,'' Mr. Levitt said. ''But the proper role of a fund's board has become a bit controversial lately.'' **********The commission itself has added to the controversy. Last year, the commission accused two outside directors of the Parnassus fund as well as the fund manager of securities law violations. The charges, which the Parnassus fund and the directors are contesting, contend that the directors failed to monitor the fund manager's use of benefits that should have gone to the fund.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/busin.snippet: Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announces plan to reduce its oil production by more than 1.3 million barrels a day, or nearly 5 percent, in latest attempt to push up prices; members of OPEC and other producers have been facing severe...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/busin.main_headline: OPEC Reaches New Deal to Cut Oil Production
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; OPEC Reaches New Deal to Cut Oil Production
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/busin.body_text: **********Overcoming a serious political dispute that split the Iranian delegation and threatened the final agreement, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced late today that it planned to reduce its oil production by more than 1.3 million barrels a day, or nearly 5 percent, in the latest attempt to push up prices. **********The 11 members of OPEC and other producers have been facing a severe crisis since oil prices began a sharp decline in November, falling below $12 a barrel last week to the lowest level in more than a decade. Two earlier moves to reduce production, including sharp cutbacks pledged in March, have largely failed to keep prices from dropping. **********The much-anticipated agreement was announced here at the meeting of OPEC oil ministers near the close of the commodity markets in New York today. The dispute among the Iranians had sent oil prices dropping during the day, wiping out an early rally in European markets after reports that a deal was imminent. But prices ended little changed, with crude oil for August delivery settling up 8 cents, at $14.60 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. **********The Iranian split, as well as OPEC's reputation for being unable to maintain production cutbacks, left some experts questioning how long the agreement would hold. ''It is a fragile agreement by its very nature, as it depends on the pledge of each country to cut its production,'' said Fadhil al-Chalabi, a former OPEC under secretary. He added that some countries might again be tempted to increase production if prices rise. **********The deal was nearly scuttled early this evening, shortly before it was first to have been announced, when the Iranian oil minister, Bijan Namdar-Zanganeh, who represents the moderate views of President Mohammed Khatami, engaged in a public dispute with Kazempour Ardebili, a senior figure in the Iranian leadership who tends to reflect the views of the Revolutionary Guards and other hard-liners. **********The two officials argued loudly over who had the authority to speak for Iran during the final negotiations over the production accord. Several OPEC oil ministers who attended that meeting said privately afterward that they feared the dispute would deflate any rally in oil prices the agreement might otherwise have brought. **********At one point during the session, according to several officials who were present, Nigeria's oil minister, Dan Etete, raised his walking stick in anger at the two Iranians, proclaiming, ''This is no way to do business.'' **********In the end, the Iranians and several oil ministers stormed out of the closed-door meeting, and OPEC was forced to delay the announcement of the agreement. **********''When a senior member of the Iranian delegation disagrees with his minister publicly, it poses a big question mark about what is happening there,'' a senior Arab delegate said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ''Can you imagine what it would be like if in our delegation the minister and the deputy minister argued over who speaks for the country?'' **********But other officials said there were some benefits from bringing the Iranian dispute out into the open. ''It is good that a misunderstanding has been aired here because last time when we here in March, we left with two different Iranian interpretations of a deal,'' said Nordine Ait Laoussine, Algeria's former oil minister, who is a senior adviser to his country's OPEC delegation. ''This time, we are all clear as to where Iran stands.'' **********By agreeing this time to cut their daily output by 1.3 million barrels, the 11 members of OPEC have pledged since March to remove a daily total of about 2.6 million barrels from the market. **********If OPEC, which controls about 40 percent of the world's oil production, can live up to those commitments, it could significantly reduce the excess supplies of crude oil that have sent prices plunging. But too often, oil producers both in and outside OPEC have failed to meet all their pledges. **********Late in March, for instance, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, with Mexico helping as intermediary, led a coalition of oil exporters that agreed to cut oil output by 1.7 million barrels a day. But fewer than one million barrels are estimated to have actually been taken out of production, and oil prices, which initially rallied, resumed their decline. **********Earlier this month, a number of these countries agreed to cut a further total of 740,000 barrels, starting on July 1. **********The production cutbacks announced by OPEC today will expand on the reductions planned for July 1 by more than 600,000 barrels a day. **********The biggest sacrifice in production is to come from Saudi Arabia, which plans to reduce its output by 425,000 barrels daily. Venezuela promised to cut its oil output by 325,000 barrels, and the United Arab Emirates by 100,000 barrels a day. **********After much negotiation, Iran agreed to lower its production by 65,000 barrels a day instead of OPEC's request for a 95,000-barrel cutback. Mr. Ardebili, who is an adviser to Iran's Foreign Minister and the oil minister as well as Iran's governor on the OPEC board, insisted on the smaller cut, saying this quantity was what the Government had authorized. But Mr. Namdar-Zanganeh, the Iranian oil minister, said he would agree to a larger cut. **********A senior Arab official said the differences in these Iranian positions reflected concerns over the rising production of oil by Iraq, Iran's rival and its wartime enemy in the 1980's. Over the last year, the Iraqi Government of President Saddam Hussein has raised its production of oil with United Nations permission to 2.2 million barrels a day, of which it exports 1.7 million barrels, crowding Iranian and Saudi sales. **********It does so under an oil-for-food agreement worked out with the United Nations, and if its production should continue to expand, the Iraqis might reclaim their old position as OPEC's second-largest oil producer after Saudi Arabia, passing the Iranians. **********For that reason, the hard-liners in Teheran have insisted on giving as little as possible. But President Khatami's Government, which is eager to improve ties with the rest of the world, has insisted on more cooperation. Both tendencies are represented in Iran's OPEC delegation. **********A number of non-OPEC countries that attended the meeting as observers, including representatives of Mexico, Russia, Norway and Oman, have made some production cuts themselves. **********Mexico, which reduced its output by 100,000 barrels a day at the beginning of April, plans to cut another 100,000 in July. **********But Norway, which has cut 100,000 barrels a day, has no plans for further reductions. Russia pledged reductions this year of 80,000 barrels daily, and Oman offered a 50,000- barrel-a-day cut. **********OPEC officials acknowledged that it would take a while for the market to verify that these pledges had been carried out. **********And, there is concern here that the Asian economic crisis, which has removed about one million barrels a day in demand, could grow worse, making further production cuts necessary.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/28/world.snippet: Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee of India strengthens his week-old Hindu nationalist coalition by assuring Indians that policies will not depart from those of previous governments; nationalists are expected to have trouble holding coalition together...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/28/world.main_headline: India's Confident Leader Faces a Key Vote Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/28/world.print_headline: India's Confident Leader Faces a Key Vote Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/28/world.body_text: **********Despite the inherent fragility of their 19-party coalition, a week in office has been enough for the Hindu nationalists who lead India's new Government to fend off threats of a repetition of their humiliation in 1996, when the nationalists' first bid to govern collapsed in 13 days. **********Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, the nationalists' leader, has presided over a stream of policy pronouncements aimed at reassuring Indians that there will be no radical departures from the policies of previous governments. In addition, Mr. Vajpayee's lieutenants have maneuvered to head off a repeat of the 1996 events, when the nationalists -- unable to round up support from other parties -- quit ahead of certain defeat in Parliament. **********Mr. Vajpayee, 72, has been a different man in Parliament this week  from the disconsolate figure he cut two years ago. With party tallies today showing that his Government was virtually certain to survive a crucial confidence vote in Parliament on Saturday, he used one of India's popular cricket analogies, comparing his fate in 1996 to that of a batsman who quit even before ''the umpire raised his finger'' to dismiss him. **********''But this time we have a majority, and we will prove it,'' he said. **********Opposition leaders have conceded privately that India seems set for at least a few months under the nationalists and their allies, longer if they succeed in efforts to broaden their coalition. But while many Indians are relieved that the nationalists have set aside divisive campaign pledges that had caused deep anxieties among India's Muslim minority, few believe that Mr. Vajpayee is likely to achieve the main goal he has set since taking office: providing stable government to a country that has had four Governments and five Prime Ministers in 22 months. **********This time, Mr. Vajpayee's Bharatiya Janata Party entered the parliamentary confidence debate with the opposition parties in disarray. Too deeply divided to forge a coalition of their own, the Congress Party and the United Front -- a grouping of leftist and regional parties -- appear to have reconciled themselves to remaining on the opposition benches, while hoping that personal and doctrinal differences within the Vajpayee coalition will eventually bring its collapse. **********The prospects of a quick defeat for the new Government vanished when a key component of the United Front, with 12 members of Parliament from the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, quit the front and declared itself neutral in the confidence debate. With the front split, independent tallies indicated that the Government was likely to win the confidence vote by 10 votes or more. **********Over the longer term, it seems certain that the nationalists will have trouble holding the coalition together. **********In the confidence debate, they were repeatedly chided by opposition speakers for joining with groups that have been bitter critics of the nationalists in the past, and of each other. **********Somnath Chatterjee, a leading Communist member of Parliament, recalled that one partner had called another a ''pathological liar'' in 1996, and chuckled. ''And this is what they call perfect harmony,'' he said. **********For the nationalists, the price of power has been the abandonment, at least for now, of Hindu supremacist policies they espoused during decades in India's political wilderness. But it is far from sure that they can stick to Mr. Vajpayee's pledge to offer ''genuine secularism,'' a phrase understood by most Indians to mean government that is evenhanded toward the country's many cultural, language and religious groups. **********For the moment, few Indians expect the hard-liners to follow through on threats to mount protests if Mr. Vajpayee sticks to the vow the Government has made to set aside the most controversial of the nationalists' campaign pledges, to build a Hindu temple on the site of a 16th-century mosque that was destroyed by a Hindu mob in 1992. But some Indians think the real test of Mr. Vajpayee's commitment may come in more subtle ways; one would be the fashion in which law enforcement agencies react if Hindu-Muslim frictions of the kind that have caused more than 8,000 riots since 1947 should recur. **********In its early days, the Vajpayee Government has seemed intent on emphasizing its moderation. After an initial flurry last week when the coalition partners announced that they would ''induct nuclear weapons'' into the country's military arsenal, the new defense minister, George Fernandes, has said that no decision will be made until after a full defense review. **********Even then, Mr. Fernandes has said, India may or may not choose to become a declared nuclear-weapons power.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/12/world.snippet: Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin says Russia will push to ratify second strategic arms reduction treaty in order to prepare way for Pres Clinton to visit Moscow for summit meeting by middle of year (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/12/world.main_headline: Russia Vows To Push Pact Cutting Arms
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/12/world.print_headline: Russia Vows To Push Pact Cutting Arms
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/12/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia said today that his Government would push to ratify the second strategic arms reduction treaty in order to prepare the way for President Clinton to visit Moscow for a summit meeting by the middle of the year. **********The Clinton Administration has quietly made a summit meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin conditional on Russian passage of Start II, senior Administration officials say. Start II would cut each side's existing levels of warheads by two-thirds. **********The treaty, negotiated by President Bush at the end of his term and signed by him and Mr. Yeltsin in early 1993, was approved by the Senate in January 1996. But Mr. Yeltsin has never pressed for its passage in the Russian Parliament, apparently believing that the political cost of winning would be too high. **********American critics of NATO expansion, which the Senate is expected to approve later this month, have argued that the Russian Parliament has refused to ratify Start II out of anger about NATO's move to the east. Clinton officials are eager to get the arms pact passed, in part to answer those critics and to move toward deeper cuts in a Start III agreement, which Mr. Yeltsin also favors. **********Mr. Chernomyrdin appeared with Vice President Al Gore at a joint news conference today concluding the Washington meetings of the Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission, which in semi-annual meetings over the last five years has become the main venue for some of the most difficult issues in United States-Russian relations. American officials in the audience said they were very pleased to hear Mr. Chernomyrdin himself make the connection between a summit meeting, which Mr. Yeltsin wants, and Start II approval. **********Mr. Gore also announced a new joint commission of experts to discuss and monitor the export of sensitive nuclear and missile technologies. The United States and Israel have accused Russian companies of helping Iran develop strategic missiles that could hit Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Israel. **********After originally denying such assistance, Moscow then denied an official connection to any assistance, which would break its commitments under an agreement to control missile exports. American diplomats have been pressing Moscow to stop any such aid, even from privatized companies, and the Russians recently issued a decree announcing new export controls. **********The new controls, known as ''catch-all controls,'' are designed to ban the export of goods that could be used by another country to develop weapons of mass destruction or prohibited delivery systems. **********But as Mr. Gore said today, ''Implementation is key.'' **********''By working together on export controls on weapons, weapons materials and dual-use goods,'' Mr. Gore continued, ''I believe we can -- and will -- strengthen existing international nonproliferation regimes and promote regional stability.'' **********American officials said the new team would help Washington monitor Russian compliance with its pledges and help the Russians with equipment and technology to improve their export controls. **********Administration officials are trying to dissuade the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, from putting forward a bill that would sanction Russian companies that aid Iran's missile programs by banning them from any work on the joint American-Russian international space station. The bill has already passed the House. **********During the two days of meetings with Mr. Gore, Mr. Chernomyrdin reaffirmed a 1995 Russian pledge to have no further nuclear cooperation with Iran while work continued on a Russian nuclear reactor being built, slowly and against American advice, in the city of Bushehr. The Russians have a contract to build one reactor there, and some Russian offficials indicate an interest in building more. **********American officials have tried to block that construction, convincing the Germans, who began the project in the 1970's, not to give the blueprints to the Russians and, last week, getting Ukraine to refuse to supply specialized turbines for the reactor. **********Mr. Chernomyrdin and Mr. Gore spent most of their news conference praising each other and their commission. In meetings between Cabinet secretaries, agreements have been reached on everything from energy issues to health care. **********For example, Conoco Inc. announced tentative agreement today with Russia's largest oil compnay, Lukoil, for joint development of oil reserves in the northern Arctic. The agreement, which is subject to approval by the Russian Government and Parliament, would give Conoco 40 percent of the venture and Lukoil 60 percent. It has been long stalled, and American officials pressed for the agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/12/techn.snippet: John Nagamichi Cho's new book, Spam-ku: Tranquil Reflections on Luncheon Loaf, contains 162 haikus culled from Spam Haiku Archive, a Web site he launched as a lark in June 1995; site has received about 11,000 entries from 1,500 on-line poets; Haik...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/12/techn.main_headline: To a Haiku Writer, Spam Is Poetry in a Can
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/12/techn.print_headline: To a Haiku Writer, Spam Is Poetry in a Can
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/12/techn.body_text: **********FOR the moment, anyway, John Nagamichi Cho's new book has a category unto itself at the Library of Congress. His Internet-derived collection of haiku-like verse inspired by Spam, the popular processed-pork product, is the sole listing under the subject heading ''Canned meat -- poetry.'' **********With the deaths last year of the Beat poets Allen Ginsberg and William S. Burroughs, Mr. Cho crowed, ''I'm the first in a generation of 'meat poets.' '' **********For ''Spam-ku: Tranquil Reflections on Luncheon Loaf'' (88 pp., HarperCollins, $7.95), Mr. Cho sliced 162 prime examples of porcine poetry out of the Spam Haiku Archive (pemtropics.mit.edu/jcho/spam), a Web site he launched as a lark in June 1995. To date, about 1,500 on-line poets have submitted more than 11,000 entries to the site. All refer in some manner to the rosy-toned Hormel Foods product, and most follow the three-line, 5-7-5 pattern of syllables that schoolchildren learn is the classic haiku form. The Spam-ku range from earnest, often ham-fisted efforts at evoking a mood, such as Mr. Cho's ''The first time we kissed:/ Your cheeks flushed a deep Spam pink,/ Your lips soft, hungry'' to such swinishly punny entries as Chris Fishel's ''Descartes on pig parts/ Says: I'm pink, therefore I'm Spam/ Deep philosophy.'' **********Mr. Cho, a 34-year-old research scientist at M.I.T., attributes part of Spam-ku's popularity to the simple fact that it is a short, silly-sounding word. ''It's hard to compose haiku about Vienna sausage or Canadian bacon,'' Mr. Cho said. ''They take up too many syllables. He said that contributors liked to play with the tension between the nostalgia invoked by Spam's rich history -- introduced in 1937, it was a staple of many wartime diets -- and its anachronistic status today as processed pork in a fresh-meat era. **********More than anything, though, Spam-ku are easy to compose, an appealing ingredient for those taking advantage of the Web's self-publishing capabilities. Mr. Cho's site also contains an area for haiku about news events, and earlier this year the Salon (www.salonmagazine.com), the on-line magazine, held a competition for haiku error messages. **********''American poetry in the 20th Century has become pretty intimidating,'' Mr. Cho said. ''Both rhyme and meter have gone out of fashion, and people find it hard to understand what poetry is and how to write it. Here, you have a very simple structure that anyone can follow -- although you'd be surprised how many entries I get that miss the syllable count.'' **********Francis Heaney has written about 230 Spam-ku for the archive. ''They're not all gems,'' Mr. Heaney conceded. His favorite -- ''Moon rises,/ White as two slices of bread,/ Sunset pink as Spam within'' -- did not make it into Mr. Cho's book. **********Although he has since abandoned the form, Mr. Heaney, a 28-year-old puzzle writer and editor in Manhattan, said, ''I do my best writing under constraints, so the constraint of a haiku, plus the fact that it has to be about Spam, is very limiting. To do things within that is fun.'' **********Because haiku almost always involves nature, Mr. Heaney sought to incorporate that element into his poems. Would that requirement be fulfilled by a reference to Spam alone? ''It's made out of pigs,'' Mr. Heaney replied. ''I guess pigs are natural.'' **********Another entry that did not make it into the book was this candidate from Alex Dunne: ''Spam's own irony/ Is that its haiku's never/ Worse than Spam itself.'' **********Haiku experts are skeptical about the new form. ''It's technically not poetry,'' said Lee Gurga, a dentist from Lincoln, Ill., who recently served as president of the Haiku Society of America (www.octet. com/hsa/). ''Spam haiku makes statements; statements are not the same as images.'' **********Despite Mr. Cho's claims to the contrary, Dr. Gurga said, the archive entries are not ''senryu'' either. ''Senryu have to do with human nature, and they can be very funny, but they tend to have a little more resonance than Spam.'' Ultimately, Dr. Gurga said, Spam-ku ''doesn't bother me in the least,'' adding, ''I like it when people have fun.'' **********And Dr. Gurga said he hoped that the archive would lead visitors to more serious haiku sites on the Internet. Well-regarded examples include Dhugal J. Lindsay's Haiku Universe (www2.ori.u-tokyo.ac.jp/dhugal/haikuhome.html) and the Shiki Internet Haiku Salon (cc.matsuyama-u.ac.jp/shiki). **********Mr. Cho's slim volume represents a burgeoning breed of books that were sired in cyberspace. Jeremie Ruby-Strauss, who edited ''Spam-ku'' for HarperCollins and has published a compendium of martini recipes siphoned from a Web site, approached Mr. Cho after stumbling upon his archive. **********Mr. Ruby-Strauss, who uses an unopened can of Spam as a paperweight, said he had seen Spam-ku swapped with gusto elsewhere on the Net. ''Here's a product that's been marketed,'' Mr. Ruby-Strauss said of Spam, but there was no literary product. ''So let's make a product.'' **********At his publisher's insistence, Mr. Cho sent his selections to Hormel at its headquarters in Austin, Minn., for approval. He omitted those he feared might raise objections. **********For the most part, Mr. Cho said, ''They just wanted all the capitalizations right and for some strange reason, they said no possessives.'' **********The book's illustrations received the toughest inspection. One that showed a mouse sniffing at a tin of Spam was rejected by the company. **********''They said, 'Please, no rodents associated with Spam,' '' Mr. Cho recalled. ''We just decided to can that one.'' **********Hormel officials declined to comment, but the company does maintain a tongue-in-cheek Web site for its product (www.spam.com). **********In addition to offering a Spam mouse pad for sale, the site contains a dissertation that strives to distance the company from ''spam,'' Internet slang for unsolicited E-mail. The term was derived from a Monty Python comedy routine in which the word is repeated ad nauseum. **********A few weeks ago, at the bidding of a friend's daughter who enjoyed the book and wanted to sample its salty, spicy subject, Mr. Cho consumed Spam for the first time in nearly 20 years. Despite his seven-syllable description of the sensation -- an ''elastic, rubbery feel'' -- he said the experience had not prompted him to compose a haiku about the moment. After penning 200 entries for the on-line archive, Mr. Cho lost his appetite for the verse form in early 1996. **********''It was like an addiction,'' he recalled. ''When it was over, it was completely over. I went cold turkey.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/07/world.snippet: Analysis: it is not clear whether Cambodia's election advanced cause of democracy that outside world worked hard to implant there since start of decade; some political experts cite reports of electoral manipulation and campaign of fear at local le...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/07/world.body_text: **********Cambodia's election nearly two weeks ago may, for a while at least, produce the political stability that people here yearn for. But it is not clear whether it has advanced the cause of democracy that the outside world has worked hard to implant here since the start of the decade. **********Emerging reports of electoral manipulation and a campaign of fear at the local level have led some political experts to suggest that for many Cambodians, the lesson of this election is that the will of the people must still bow to the raw power of their leaders. **********The quick stamp of approval by international observers, followed by their quick departure from Cambodia, has left many people here feeling abandoned and bewildered. The trade-off -- political stability -- is not quite here yet. And given this nation's history of political turmoil and the mutual animosities of its leaders, a stable Cambodia in the long term would be a surprise. **********On Wednesday, the national election committee announced that the incumbent leader, Hun Sen, had won a majority of the 122 seats in Parliament, but not the two-thirds needed to form a government without forming a coalition with his rivals. Opposition parties are challenging the count and threatening to paralyze the opening of Parliament six weeks from now with a boycott. **********And reports continued to accumulate today of a sort of political cleansing in villages around the country where threats of reprisals are forcing supporters of opposition parties to flee. **********But most political experts predict that after a period of political theater, threats and horse-trading -- and even a possible constitutional crisis --that could last well into the fall, the second-place finisher, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, is likely to join Mr. Hun Sen in some form of coalition. **********''If nothing else, he will be under intense pressure from his party to take a share of the spoils of government,'' a senior aid worker said. ''What's in it for them to stay out in the cold?'' **********That outcome carries its share of irony. After muscling his way into a coalition leadership with Prince Ranariddh after the Prince won the last election, in 1993, Mr. Hun Sen pushed Prince overboard in a coup one year ago and declared, ''I am the only captain of the ship.'' **********The clear domination of Mr. Hun Sen's party this time around, and the weakening of military forces loyal to Prince Ranariddh, may, through force of arms and politics, create a more stable situation than under the dual premiership of the previous Government. **********After the coup last year, Mr. Hun Sen's supporters systematically killed about 100 members of the opposition, monopolized the broadcast media, took control of the mechanisms of the political campaign, intimidated the voters and then invited the Prince to return from exile and take part in a free election. **********Election day, July 26, was an uplifting demonstration of the desire of Cambodians to exercise their mandate, as more than 90 percent of eligible voters crowded into polling places. Foreign election monitors were thrilled. Some called the spectacle ''a miracle.'' **********But many diplomats and aid workers who live here were incensed at this quick-draw assessment. **********''This country has been perpetually in turmoil for the last 30 years,'' a diplomat said. ''It's going to take more than one Sunday of relative peace and quiet to change that. It is incredibly disingenuous and intellectually dishonest as well as possibly immoral for the international community to come in here and say, 'O.K., you have democracy,' when the reality on the ground is much different.'' **********It is impossible to quantify the effects of any threats or manipulation by the governing party. But the picture of voting day that has emerged in reports from Cambodian and foreign observers suggests that a good deal more was going on than was apparent on the surface. **********Voters had already been given the message in the previous weeks and months that there was a right and wrong way to vote. Mr. Hun Sen's party members, who virtually monopolize local and provincial government, had thumb-printed voters, had collected and held their voting cards and had selectively threatened, attacked and sometimes killed villagers who opposed them. **********On voting day, it was those same party functionaries who ran the polling stations, sending a signal that, as one foreign monitor put it, ''we'll still be here tomorrow, and you're still going to have to live with us.'' **********A variety of ballot manipulation was used at the polling stations, said the election monitor, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. With a population that is more than 60 percent illiterate, polling station staff marked ballots for many people, the election monitor said. **********They sometimes engaged in a system of ''telegraph'' voting, in which premarked ballots were substituted for clean ones. Once the count was under way, a disproportionate number of opposition ballots were ruled invalid. **********There are unconfirmed allegations of larger-scale manipulation that may have involved the switching of ballot boxes and the massaging of vote totals. **********''I have heard people say that next time they won't vote -- it makes no difference anyway,'' a European diplomat said. ''A lot of people see this election not as a democratic exercise but as a tool by Hun Sen to perpetuate his power. They feel used.'' **********For two years leading up to the 1993 election, the United Nations employed 20,000 foreign aid workers here and spent more than $2 billion in an effort to plant the seeds of democracy in one of the world's most battered and suffering countries. **********The years since then have been a struggle between Cambodia's violent past and the small but growing corps of people who have embraced the United Nations' democratic ideals. The country has a wildly free press -- though journalists are sometimes killed -- and a vigorous sector of private groups focusing on human rights, the rights of women and children, legal reforms, environmental protection and the alleviation of poverty. **********They are the real opposition to Mr. Hun Sen's monopoly of power. **********Now that representatives of other countries have returned briefly, pronounced themselves satisfied and left again, Mr. Hun Sen may feel himself under less pressure to permit this range of democratic activity, said Thomas Hammarberg, the human rights envoy to Cambodia from the United Nations. **********''The nature of the international community is that interest moves from country to country,'' he said. ''Cambodia is now in danger of being forgotten.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/28/busin.print_headline: S.E.C. and Firm Settle Municipal Bond Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/28/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission announced a settlement today in a civil case against O'Brien Partners Inc., which it accused of breaching its fiduciary duty to municipal bond clients by not informing them of commissions it received from brokers who invested revenues from the municipal issues. **********Without admitting or denying the findings, O'Brien, a financial adviser to municipal issuers, agreed to a commission finding that it failed to adequately disclose to four clients that it received brokerage commissions in connection with the clients' investments of certain bond proceeds. **********According to the commission, O'Brien received about $450,000 of commissions, either directly or through an affiliated broker-dealer, in 10 payments from 1991 through 1993. The payments, from investment brokers, represented a split of commissions earned by those brokers on investments of bond proceeds from O'Brien's clients. **********The four municipal issuers named in the S.E.C.'s civil suit were Wisconsin Public Power Inc., the Calleguas Municipal Water District, the Southern California Public Power Authority and the City of Anaheim, Calif. **********''As financial adviser and investment adviser, O'Brien Partners owed these municipal clients a fiduciary duty to disclose all actual or potential conflicts of interest,'' the commission said in a statement. **********As part of the settlement, O'Brien agreed to a cease and desist order and to pay a $250,000 civil penalty.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/26/busin.snippet: Carl G Sontheimer, creative electronics engineer and successful entrepreneur who was known as man who brought Cuisinart to US, dies at age 83; photo (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/26/busin.main_headline: C. G. Sontheimer, Cuisinart Backer, Dies at 83
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/26/busin.print_headline: C. G. Sontheimer, Cuisinart Backer, Dies at 83
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/26/busin.body_text: **********Carl G. Sontheimer, a creative electronics engineer and successful entrepreneur who made his most visible contribution to the American economy -- and American kitchens -- after his retirement, died on Monday at a hospital near his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 83 and known as the man who revolutionized American cooking by bringing the Cuisinart to the United States. **********His family said the cause was respiratory failure. **********It's a shudder to think what would have happened -- or not happened -- to American cooking if Mr. Sontheimer had taken up golf. **********There he was in 1971, a 57-year-old Massachusetts Institute of Technology graduate who had invented an array of technical devices, including a microwave direction finder that went to the moon, and started and sold two electronics companies, giving him the wherewithal to enjoy a well-deserved life of leisure. And he was bored. **********So bored, in fact, that almost as soon as he had sold his last company, Anzac Electronics, in 1966, and completed a three-year consulting contract with the new owner, he had begun casting around for a new venture, among other things considering and rejecting a flier in home security systems. **********Then, drawing on a lifelong passion for French food and French cooking, he decided to try to combine business with pleasure by finding French products suitable for an American franchising operation. **********So Mr. Sontheimer, a native New Yorker who had grown up in France, where his father represented an American company, headed back to France in 1971 with his wife, Shirley, on a scouting trip. **********It was there, at a French cookery show, that he spotted it, an ungainly but versatile machine designed to process food for restaurants. A sort of glorified blender whose multiple attachments allowed it to cut, slice, knead, chop, dice, grate, grind or even blend, it had been manufactured by a French restaurant supply giant, Robot-Coupe, for eight years, but Mr. Sontheimer immediately saw its possibilities for the home kitchen, specifically his. **********As he told his wife, the machine would be ideal for making quenelles, those French delicacies whose meat or fish bases had to be chopped to a fare-thee-well, then laboriously forced through a sieve to achieve the proper consistency. **********Moving swiftly, Mr. Sontheimer and his wife concluded an agreement to distribute a modified version of the commercial machine in the United States, then came up with the name that would soon become a household word. **********''He always thought of French cooking as an art and he wanted it to be based on the word, 'cuisine,' '' his wife said yesterday in explaining how they had come up with Cuisinart. **********It was not until January 1973 that the Cuisinart was introduced at a show in Chicago, and for all its French lineage, the product had more than just an American touch. No wonder. Mr. Sontheimer had spent more than a year modifying virtually every component. **********But then Mr. Sontheimer was never one to leave well enough alone, especially when it came to food. There was the time, for example, when he suffered such cuisine shock eating the food at his M.I.T. fraternity after years of fine dining in France that he went into the kitchen to help put things right. **********He continued his interest in cooking throughout his varied career, which included stints with RCA and Maguire Industries before he founded the forerunner of Trak Electronics in 1947 and then, after selling his Trak stake in 1960, establishing Anzac to develop and manufacture precision microwave systems. **********Along the way he studied French cooking in New York and became friends with James Beard, the enormous cooking master he only occasionally resembled. At a bit more than 6 feet tall, Mr. Sontheimer would periodically trim down to portly. **********For all the Sontheimer improvements, the expensive Cuisinart sold sluggishly until 1975 when a rave review in Gourmet magazine and endorsements from Mr. Beard and others touched off a stampede of sales and created a new industry. **********As Cuisinart sales soared, a host of competitors offered similar food processors, but although the clones were generally much less expensive, Cuisinart's acknowleded edge in quality, a Sontheimer obsession, led to a marketing anomaly in which the most expensive machine was the biggest seller. **********The road to Cuisinart success was not always smooth. After winning permission from Robot-Coupe to use other suppliers, for example, Mr. Sontheimer created an improved model and had it manufactured in Japan, a move that led Robot-Coupe to market its own model in the United States, but without success. **********There was also his battle with Zabar's, the Manhattan specialty food store, which sold Cuisinarts at such a deep discount that Mr. Sontheimer cut off the store's supply until his efforts ran afoul of Federal and state laws, leading to a $250,000 fine. **********Partly because of fresh competition from Sunbeam's Oskar and other cheap, miniature processors, Cuisinart's sales declined in the 1980's, but when he and his wife sold the company to an investment group in 1987 the price was $42 million. The company is now owned by Conair. **********After that, Mr. Sontheimer did not seek any more bold new ventures, but the man who never played golf didn't exactly retire. He continued to maintain an office in Greenwich to manage his real estate and other investments and he helped produce two cookbooks, ''Classic Cakes and Other Great Cuisinart Desserts,'' and ''The Pleasure of Cooking Fruits and Vegetables,'' both based on recipes from his acclaimed magazine, The Pleasure of Cooking. **********And, of course, he continued to cook. **********Shortly before he entered the hospital two weeks ago, his wife recalled yesterday, he had turned out a delicious rack of lamb. **********In addition to his wife, he is survived by four children from a previous marriage, Peter and Henry, of Gettysburg, Pa., Katherine Rovine of Elkins Park, Md., and Barbara Young of Monroe, Conn.; a sister, Eleanor Tichner of New Canaan, Conn.; 10 grandchildren, and 3 great-granchildren.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/27/busin.body_text: **********Talks Between Oil Giants Reflect Global Realities **********The talks between Exxon and Mobil on a possible combination show how global competition and advancing technology have made what were once seen as unthinkable deals practical and even necessary. **********Even industry giants have been forced to seek ways to cut costs on huge, expensive international projects. In addition, oil companies have decided that they will not be rescued soon by a rebound in oil prices.   [Page A1.] **********Health Insurance Costs to Rise **********Many working Americans will have increases of 8 percent to 20 percent or more on health insurance premiums next year in the sharpest price increases since the early 1990's.   [A1.] **********OPEC Won't Cut Production **********Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, deeply divided over the best strategy for propping up sagging crude oil prices, took no action on making further production cuts, delaying any decision until March.   [C3.] **********Default Expected on Soviet Debt **********Russia has told Western bankers that it will renege on the terms of repaying $28 billion in Soviet-era debt to creditors, effectively paving the way for a default on interest payments next month, bankers in London said.   [C3.] **********Markets Gain in Asia and Europe **********Stock markets in Asia and Europe advanced, as Japanese investors awaited economic stimulus measures and the European markets percolated with rumors of a big oil merger. Tokyo's main index, the 225-issue Nikkei, gained 134.30 points, or 0.89 percent, closing at 15,207.77. The index rebounded from a drop of 91.17 points on Wednesday.   [C2.] **********Honors for Leo Burnett **********Leo Burnett, the adman behind the Marlboro Man, was selected one of the 20 most influential business leaders of the 20th century. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/25/world.snippet: Top Clinton foreign policy advisers meet to weigh military and political strategies against Iraq, including sustained attack on suspected biological and chemical weapons sites that Pres Saddam Hussein has hidden from UN inspectors; National Securi...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/25/world.main_headline: U.S. LISTS OPTIONS ON USE OF FORCE IN IRAQ STANDOFF
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/25/world.print_headline: U.S. LISTS OPTIONS ON USE OF FORCE IN IRAQ STANDOFF
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/25/world.body_text: **********President Clinton's top foreign policy advisers met today to weigh military and political strategies against Iraq, among them a sustained attack on suspected biological and chemical weapons sites that Saddam Hussein has hidden from United Nations inspectors, White House officials said. **********''There'll be one final round of diplomacy, and then an ultimatum, and then we act,'' a National Security Council official said. **********White House officials said a countdown to a military strike could begin as soon as Ramadan, the Muslim holy month of fasting, ends on Friday. A senior Administration official said of the prospect of military action, ''We're focused more on weeks than months or days.'' **********Members of Mr. Clinton's national security team briefed the President later today on their discussion. **********The participants in the meeting included Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright; Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen; the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger; the Director of Central Intelligence, George Tenet, and the chief delegate to the United Nations, Bill Richardson. They left the White House without deciding on their ultimate course, an Administration spokesman said. **********The White House meeting came as a consensus emerged in the President's national security staff that Iraq would never comply with the United Nations inspectors, and that smart bombs and cruise missiles may be needed to destroy President Hussein's hidden potential to build crude weapons of mass destruction. **********With the White House enveloped in a miasma of sexual and legal scandals, Administration officials said they were painfully aware that they might be accused of using an attack on Iraq as a diversion to sustain political and popular support for an embattled President. But they took pains to point out that the military plans they are weighing were drawn up two months ago, in November, during the last standoff with Iraq over the United Nations inspections. **********The Administration plans to devote next week to convincing skeptical American allies and members of Congress that military action is the only way to stop Iraq from building a biological and chemical arsenal. **********''We have never put the question directly: 'We're going in. Are you with us or not?' '' the National Security Council official said. **********So far, only Britain is clearly supporting a hard line. Seven years after it came together to drive the Iraqi Army out of Kuwait, the international coalition that fought the Persian Gulf war under the United Nations banner has splintered. **********Two United States battle groups in the gulf -- including warships, fighter jets, hundreds of cruise missiles and precision-guided bombs -- will soon be joined by a British battle group. Together they will form the largest military deployment in the region since the gulf war. **********But no other allies are likely to join. Washington is in a poor position to rebuild the worldwide coalition  that it assembled to fight Iraq in 1991. The United States has been politically weakened at the United Nations by its failure to pay its dues, and Russia, France, China and some Arab allies are unlikely to openly support a military attack on Iraq. **********Nonetheless, the momentum propelling the United States toward bombing Iraq appears inexorable. **********Iraq continues to defy the United Nations inspectors who are charged with identifying and helping to eliminate Baghdad's ability to build nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. A senior United Nations official, Richard Spertzel, said on Friday that there was ''tantalizing information'' that Iraq is operating a secret biological weapons plant despite United Nations inspections and in defiance of an international ban. **********The chief of the inspection team, Richard Butler, told the Security Council on Friday that Iraq was continuing to mislead the inspectors. **********Diplomacy, jawboning and continuing economic sanctions have not moved President Hussein. **********Mr. Clinton warned on Wednesday that diplomacy might be approaching a dead end. ''Something is going to have to give here,'' he said. Administration officials strongly suggested that after going an extra mile down this diplomatic route in the coming week, military action might lie at the end of the road. **********The military plans drawn up in November were originally aimed at compelling Baghdad to comply with United Nations' attempts to rid Iraq of its ability to build weapons of mass destruction. But diplomacy and threats have failed to persuade President Hussein to cooperate. **********Now a crucial question for the United States is whether Washington can or should destroy his suspected weapons plants with bombs and missiles -- and whether force will change his behavior, a strategy that has not worked well in the past. **********The commander of United States forces in the Persian Gulf, Gen. Anthony Zinni of the Marines, said two months ago that if called to battle, he would attack ''the things that mean most to Saddam.'' **********The general defined those targets as the forces that ''enable him to inflict the kind of pain he does on his own people and on others in the region.'' He said those forces include the ''Republican Guard units that keep him in power, his own infrastructure and command and control systems,'' and his ability to build and use biological and chemical weapons. That ability is thought to be concealed in dozens of sites, including presidential palaces. **********''The intent is to deny him the capability to continue to threaten his neighbors and his own people and to threaten the world with his capability,'' General Zinni said. **********Three new teams of United Nations technical experts are scheduled to begin a series of meetings in Baghdad on Feb. 1 to weigh Iraq's compliance on missile warhead, germ warfare and chemical weapons issues. The meetings are expected to continue throughout February; it is unclear whether the United States can attack while the teams meet in the Iraqi capital. **********A United States attack on Iraq, Administration officials said, will create more questions: whether to forbid Iraq from flying any planes within its borders and whether to force Iraq to open the suspected weapons sites -- assuming such sites are still standing after what may become the biggest bombing campaign against Iraq since the war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/16/busin.main_headline: A Long-Horizon Mantra, With a Chorus of 'Diversify'
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/16/busin.print_headline: STORM CLOUDS OVER WALL STREET: THE INVESTORS; A Long-Horizon Mantra, With a Chorus of 'Diversify'
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/16/busin.body_text: **********In light of the market's recent declines,  The New York Times interviewed three families with differing investment philosophies to see what, if any, adjustments they were making. The Times also asked certified financial planners to review the portfolios and, if needed, make recommendations. The results suggest that investors have convinced themselves that sticking with stocks is the conservative thing to do. **********Close to Their Goal, Regardless **********Alan and Vicki Schechter of Dix Hills, N.Y., were vacationing in Lake Louise, Alberta, when the Dow swooned 299 points on Aug. 4. Hearing the news, Mr. Schechter, 51, chief financial officer at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn, called in to check his accounts. **********''He got aggravated,'' said Ms. Schechter, 49, a librarian at Frank P. Long Intermediate School in Bellport, N.Y. **********''It just lasted for a second,'' her husband responded. ''The scenery was too pretty.'' **********Nothing could have mellowed Mr. Schechter during the market meltdown 11 years ago. Though he preaches the gospel of buying on dips, his reaction to the October 1987 crash was to sell -- a lot. ''I really regretted doing it,'' he recalled. **********So despite the latest downturn, which was much less severe, the Schechters are not changing their investment mix, which they call conservative. **********Each has an employer-sponsored retirement plan, invested mainly in Fidelity Investment funds like Fidelity Fund, Equity-Income II and Growth and Income. They also have a brokerage account with about nine stocks, including Microsoft, I.B.M. and Pfizer; index funds, and a tax-exempt money-market fund. **********Mr. Schechter said he might use some of those cash reserves to buy more shares of stocks he owns that are off their highs. **********With their two children finished with school, the couple's main objective is financial independence. Given their aggressive saving -- the two have contributed 10 percent of their annual salaries over the last 30 years to their retirement plans -- and the market's great run, Mr. Schechter thinks they are close to their goal, regardless what the market does in the short term. **********Reviewing the Schechters' portfolio, George Toth, a certified financial planner at Chestnut Investment Advisory in Erdenheim, Pa., said the couple did a ''great job'' of accumulating assets through disciplined investing. But he was concerned that they might have too much money in large stocks and large-stock mutual funds, both of which track the market and put them at more risk than they might realize. For diversification, he suggested putting about 15 percent of their retirement money in a convertible bond fund -- at least temporarily. **********Mr. Toth also said the Schechters needed to figure out their downside risk and set price targets for their stocks and funds -- and to get out if those targets were hit. **********Mr. Schechter dismissed the recommendation to diversify (''The economy was built on these large, well-capitalized companies'') and added that he didn't need to set price floors because he's a long-term holder. ''Over a 5-to-10-year period, I think they're all going to rise.''   DAWN GILBERTSON

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/08/busin.snippet: Viewpoint comment by Peter L Venetis points out that smaller banks can find new customers among small- and medium-sized businesses that are no longer customers of interest to huge financial institutions (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/08/busin.main_headline: VIEWPOINT; In Banking, a Happy Medium
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/08/busin.print_headline: VIEWPOINT; In Banking, a Happy Medium
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/08/busin.body_text: **********THE last year has seen great changes in the banking industry, as a flurry of big mergers, like those of First Union and Corestates and of Chemical and Chase Manhattan, has altered the financial landscape. **********A legacy of these megamarriages has been the creation of a homeless generation of small- and medium-sized businesses -- refugees from newly consolidated giants that no longer have the time or the inclination to serve them well. Mergers can result in fewer bank branches and fewer bank employees to help smaller businesses. **********But the growing number of these disenfranchised customers represents an opportunity for smaller banks that can offer sophisticated products in combination with caring, personal service. These customers often rely heavily on relationships with specific bank employees who can resolve problems and provide prompt answers. **********For business customers, a good bank means several things: a useful line of products and services at a reasonable cost; prompt responses to loan requests; timely financial solutions and capital, and access to bankers with decision-making power. **********These are the exact qualities that can be  overlooked during and after a bank merger -- especially when the focus and culture of  the merging institutions are different. And that is when smaller business customers can become lost in the shuffle. **********In a recent survey, the Opinion Research Corporation asked senior executives at 225 small- and medium-size companies -- those with revenues of $5 million to $15 million -- to rate their primary bank on how well it  understood their needs. While half of the executives said they were satisfied with their banks' problem-solving ability and convenience, only 38 percent gave the bank high marks as a trusted source of financial advice. In addition, only 46 percent of the executives were extremely satisfied or very satisfied with the attention they had received from their primary bank. **********Many companies just don't feel that they are getting good value in their banking relationships. Midsize banks -- those with $1 billion to $5 billion in assets -- have traditionally been considered too small to offer technically sophisticated products and too  large to provide personal and efficient service. But the new availability and affordability of technology is giving smaller banks a way to offer such products while still providing access to senior managers. **********Consolidation among the bigger players also lets midsize banks contribute more meaningfully to economic growth in their communities. In the New York area, where many new jobs are being created by small-  and middle-market businesses, the flexibility of smaller banks puts them in an ideal  position to supply the capital and services to support growth and neighborhood renewal -- particularly in commercial transactions of $1 million to $10 million. **********Midsize banks are nimbler than larger banks, and can leverage their close-to-the-customer style to introduce new products quickly. They are also adaptable enough to examine opportunities case by case. **********In one instance, my bank uncovered an opportunity to provide financing for properties that were a mix of residential and commercial uses. The need was initially seen by a branch manager who was trying to help a customer finance an unusual property. It didn't fit with our existing menu of financial products, so we created a new one -- a combination residential mortgage and commercial real estate loan -- and got it into the field quickly. **********We applied the same logic in a new portfolio of private banking and investment services that would otherwise be out of the reach of smaller commercial customers. **********The spigot-on, spigot-off approach that many of our bigger competitors apply to  commercial lending has made smaller customers less likely to rely on them for financing. The small size and complex nature of many deals in today's market simply do not whet the appetite of large banks. **********Midsize banks, on the other hand, can be willing and able to fill the widening service gap for small and midsize businesses that are lost in the merger chaos.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/04/busin.snippet: Orange County, California, says Fuji Securities has agreed to settle lawsuit for at least $7.9 million, in connection with county's 1994 bankruptcy (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/04/busin.body_text: **********Orange County, Calif., said today that Fuji Securities Inc. had agreed to settle a lawsuit against it for at least $7.9 million in connection with the county's 1994 collapse in the biggest municipal bankruptcy in United States history. **********Orange County said Fuji had agreed to make an immediate payment of $7.9 million and would pay up to $8.6 million more if a court overturned a decision made in favor of Fuji, the United States investment banking arm of Fuji Bank Ltd. of Japan, when it is appealed by the county next year. **********The settlement is the latest between Orange County and securities firms stemming from the county's collapse after losing $1.69 billion in derivatives trades during the plunge in the bond market in 1994. The county has recovered almost $800 million to date, including the Fuji settlement and another settlement for $10 million by the Minneapolis-based Dain Rauscher Corporation, which was also announced today. **********''While Fuji Securities continues to believe that it acted properly in all of its dealings with the county, the settlement relieves it of the continuing burden and expense of litigating the county's remaining claims,'' said a statement by Dean Jeske, a lawyer for the Chicago law firm of Foley & Lardner, which represented Fuji. **********The strategy of the former Orange County Treasurer, Robert Citron, of borrowing short-term money with repos to buy longer-term maturity derivative securities made money in 1992 and 1993 as interest rates dropped. It fell apart in 1994 when bonds fell and rates soared, and the county filed for bankruptcy protection. **********Earlier this year, Merrill Lynch & Company agreed to pay $400 million to settle allegations it contributed to Orange County's trading problems.
