https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/22/busin.snippet: Johnson & Johnson agrees to buy DePuy Inc, successful maker of orthopedic devices, for $3.5 billion in cash; Roche Holding AG, which bought 84 percent of DePuy 14 months ago, will collect about $2.9 billion; Roche got DePuy shares as part of $10.2...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/22/busin.main_headline: Johnson & Johnson to Buy Medical Device Maker
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/22/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Johnson & Johnson to Buy Medical Device Maker
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/22/busin.body_text: **********Johnson & Johnson, the big diversified health care manufacturer, agreed yesterday to buy DePuy Inc., a successful maker of orthopedic devices, for $3.5 billion in cash. After the purchase, Johnson & Johnson would be one of the largest makers of artificial joints and other devices that replace or strengthen body parts. **********Analysts said Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., was seeking to regain momentum after disappointing losses of market share in sales of another type of medical device, coronary stents, which prop open clogged arteries. DePuy makes hip and knee replacements and titanium mesh implants that are used increasingly often in lower back operations. **********Johnson & Johnson, which makes Tylenol and Band-Aids as well as prescription drugs and hospital supplies, said it would offer $35 each for outstanding shares of DePuy, a century-old company based in Warsaw, Ind. Roche Holding A.G. of Switzerland, which bought 84 percent of DePuy 14 months ago, would collect about $2.9 billion. **********Roche got the DePuy shares as part of a $10.2 billion purchase of Corange Ltd., a Bermuda-based holding company that also included Boehringer Mannheim G.m.b.H., a big German maker of drugs and diagnostic products. **********''This was definitely a good deal for Roche,'' said Sergio Traversa, an analyst at Mehta Partners, a health care research firm, ''Roche wants the cash because it gets almost one-third of its income from managing its financial investments.'' **********Roche is also expected to reduce debt it assumed in the Corange deal, while retaining business in pharmaceuticals, diagnostics, vitamins, fine chemicals, and flavors and fragrances, said Arvind Desai, an analyst at Orbimed Advisors, a health care research firm. Roche is the world's 11th-largest maker of drugs and and is first in sales of diagnostic products. **********Ralph S. Larsen, chairman of Johnson & Johnson, said the combination with DePuy could create ''the leading company in the $9 billion orthopedic products market.'' Johnson & Johnson had $630 million in orthopedic sales last year; DePuy had $770 million. **********James A. Lent, chairman of DePuy, will head the combined orthopedic products unit, which will be based in Warsaw. **********Some Wall Street analysts had predicted that Johnson & Johnson would buy a cardiovascular device company to bolster its share of the market for coronary stents after agile competitors like the Guidant Corporation and Arterial Vascular Engineering Inc. seized chunks of the market for the tiny titanium tubes. **********Johnson & Johnson's United States sales of stents in the United States have declined 50 percent so far this year, compared with sales in 1997, Mr. Desai said. **********Kurt Kruger, an analyst in San Francisco with Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities, said that even after the DePuy deal, the company still might purchase a cardiovascular device company. ''Johnson & Johnson needs more,'' he said. **********A spokesman for Johnson & Johnson declined to comment on further acquisition plans but noted that the company is testing a number of stents. Robert V. Andrews, the spokesman, said the new products might include stents with radioactive or anticoagulant coatings and miniature stents for smaller arteries. **********Johnson & Johnson has retained its big but relatively slow-growing hospital and surgical supply businesses at a time when other drug makers like Eli Lilly & Company and Pfizer Inc. have been selling these divisions so that they can concentrate on high-growth pharmaceuticals. **********Mr. Traversa said the Johnson & Johnson units might be valued higher by investors if they were spun off as separate companies. **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Johnson & Johnson shares declined 87.5 cents, to $76.25, and DePuy gained $3.0625, to $34.5625. Roche American depository receipts rose $2, to $105.50.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/02/busin.snippet: Article on confusion that can result when companies merge and top executives reach power-sharing agreements; some executives believe it is not possible for such relationships to succeed; photos (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/02/busin.main_headline: Co-Chief Executives: Can Two Be a Crowd?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/02/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT; Co-Chief Executives: Can Two Be a Crowd?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/02/busin.body_text: **********IT is hard enough for investors to tell whether many of the recent corporate mergers make sense. But figuring out whether the power-sharing agreements made by top executives of the merged companies will work is nearly impossible. **********Even the executives who negotiate these arrangements can find them confusing. Charles R. Lee, chairman of GTE, stumbled  last week while trying to explain his arrangement with Ivan G. Seidenberg, chief executive of Bell Atlantic. **********''I will be chairman and chief executive officer of the merged company,'' he said at a news conference, ''and Ivan will be president and co-chief executive officer of the company. I'm a co-chief executive, he's a 'co' -- I think I goofed that up. We're partners, we're two 'co's.' '' **********Mr. Lee can be forgiven his tied tongue.  After all, such marriages of convenience are still a bit new for corporate America. Among the biggest merger deals, hostile takeovers are giving way to so-called mergers of equals, in which the chief executives of the merged companies must, by definition, maintain equal status after their deal. **********Never mind that old-fashioned command-and-control hierarchies still drive the action  at corporate headquarters. These days, sharing is a fashionable term, and chief executives besides Mr. Lee and Mr. Seidenberg are using it often. **********John R. Stafford, chief executive of American Home Products, and Robert B. Shapiro, chief executive of Monsanto, for example, announced such an arrangement in June. And Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Travelers Group, and John S. Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, agreed to share power in their new company, Citigroup. **********But what are the chances that these modern marriages will work? **********Consider, as a baseline, that close to half of all real marriages end in divorce -- and most of them do not start off as marriages of convenience. In corporate weddings of chief executives, the power-sharing agreements are typically just a side effect of getting the deal done, not a result of two executives' seeking each other out because their strengths are complementary. **********EXECUTIVES may have any number of reasons to want to retain the title of chief executive in the new company: protecting their lieutenants in the merged company, making more money or avoiding being seen as a loser in a power struggle. **********''They're trying to solve a social problem,'' said Herbert M. Sandler, the co-chief executive of the Golden West Financial Corporation, the Oakland, Calif.-based parent of World Savings Bank. ''They're not saying, 'That's a guy I'd really like to team up with.' '' **********Mr. Sandler can speak with some authority on the subject. He has shared the title of chief executive with his wife, Marion O. Sandler, since they bought Golden West in 1963. **********Mr. Sandler said that for co-chief arrangements to work, the executives must trust and respect each other, and, most important, have no hidden agendas. ''If it's being driven by other factors, then you're making real compromises, and then there is a high risk that it's not going to work,'' he added. **********Some executives have said they do not think such relationships can work, period. When CUC International merged with HFS Inc. last December, CUC's chairman, Walter A. Forbes, entered into an unusual agreement with Henry R. Silverman, the HFS chairman. Until the year 2000, Mr. Forbes would be chairman of the merged company, the Cendant Corporation, and Mr. Silverman would be chief executive; after that they would switch jobs. Although Mr. Forbes resigned this week over accounting irregularities at the company, he said in an interview earlier this month that they chose the job-trading structure because it would have been unwieldy to have two chief executives making decisions at the same time. **********''We just felt that co-anything is difficult,'' Mr. Forbes said. **********Mr. Lee of GTE and Mr. Seidenberg declined to be interviewed. But Dennis C. Carey, vice chairman for the United States practice of Spencer Stuart, an executive search firm that has often worked for GTE, said he believed Mr. Lee and Mr. Seidenberg would develop a productive relationship. Mr. Lee, he said, has long made a habit of sharing decision-making with his top managers at GTE. **********''I have no doubt that Chuck will find this power-sharing arrangement very comfortable,'' Mr. Carey said. ''It's part of his approach to conducting business.'' **********And Mr. Seidenberg, who will become the sole chief executive of the merged company in July 2002 and will replace Mr. Lee as chairman two years later, has already shown that he can wait patiently. He was chairman of Nynex when it merged with Bell Atlantic and agreed then to take a back seat until Raymond W. Smith, the chairman of Bell Atlantic, stepped aside. **********''This is not a radical departure from what Ivan had already adapted to,'' Mr. Carey said. **********Sometimes, marriages of convenience do work out. Robin H. H. Wilson and Glenn R. Zander were co-chief executives of Trans World Airlines during most of 1993, as it was working its way out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. They were thrown together because they represented two important parties in the bankruptcy -- Mr. Wilson the airline's employees, and Mr. Zander the  creditors. **********As it turned out, their skills fit together nicely: Mr. Wilson had expertise in airline operations and Mr. Zander in finance. **********''In this particular circumstance, this was the right solution,'' Mr. Wilson, who is now managing director of SH & E Inc., a consulting firm, said last week. ''But it does create some particular pressures on individuals to acquire a certain compatibility.'' **********As successful as the executives were in helping T.W.A. emerge from bankruptcy, Mr. Wilson said he would probably not have chosen a co-chief role if he had the chance to do it all over again. **********''A more traditional model would be preferable,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/27/busin.snippet: Dataquest, market research firm, says that Microsoft Office has 93 percent of world market for collections of business software known as suites; Lotus Smartsuite has 4 percent of market, and Corel Wordperfect Suite has 3 percent; part of states' l...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/27/busin.main_headline: Microsoft Has A Stronghold In Office Suites
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/27/busin.print_headline: Microsoft Has A Stronghold In Office Suites
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/27/busin.body_text: **********When employees of the New York Attorney General's office sat down last week to prepare the final draft of the multistate lawsuit  accusing the Microsoft Corporation of monopolistic, anticompetitive behavior, they typed the document using Microsoft Word, the word processor installed on the office's computers as part of a group of business programs known as Office. **********''We have Windows 95 and the Microsoft Office suite,'' Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco acknowledged with a rueful chuckle. **********So does virtually every other office in America, which is one of the reasons that Mr. Vacco and 19 other state Attorneys General have targeted Office in their lawsuit. **********Dataquest, a market research firm, said that Microsoft Office now has 93 percent of the world market for the collections of business software known as suites. The other 7 percent is divided between two other suites built around former industry heavyweights. Lotus Smartsuite, has 4 percent of the market, and Corel Wordperfect Suite has 3 percent. **********In addition to Word, Microsoft Office includes the Excel spreadsheet program for financial analysis and management, and Outlook, a personal information manager for keeping schedules and contact directories. Microsoft offers Office in three versions -- standard, professional and small-business editions. Various versions also include Powerpoint presentation software for developing slide shows on a computer screen; Access, a data-base management tool for finding and analyzing information stored in large computer filing cabinets, or Streets, a mapping and directions program. **********The part of the states' lawsuit dealing with Office accuses Microsoft of using predatory pricing strategies to gain dominance in the market for office suites. **********The Justice Department argues that Microsoft's pricing policy for Office leaves computer manufacturers the practical choice of installing Microsoft's suite on all the computers they make or on none of them. The result, the suit says, is that competition ''is threatened to be curtailed and foreclosed.'' **********But some experts in the industry argue that the states are mounting a battle that may already be lost, since  Microsoft Office already enjoys the same level of monopolistic dominance held by the company's Windows operating system. **********Just three years ago, Wordperfect was the world's best-selling word processor, with more than half the market. Lotus 1-2-3, the venerable spreadsheet program, had a similar market share. **********No one argues that Microsoft's pricing strategies alone are responsible for the sharp decline of these competing suites. **********Most analysts say that Microsoft gained its monopoly position in part by figuring out more quickly than others that most people want programs bundled in a suite and designed to work with and look like one another. The company also produced updates that took advantage of technological advances far more quickly than competitors did. **********As an example, Dennis Tevlin, Microsoft's director of marketing for the desktop applications division, said that when Windows 95 was released, ''Lotus and Wordperfect had ample time to develop updates. But they just didn't do it. So we were already on to our second generation when they were just shipping product.'' **********Corel assigns blame for Wordperfect's decline largely to its previous owner, Novell Inc. And a senior Lotus Development executive, who, under company policy declined to be identified, said that the many shifts in the industry the last five years, including the move to suites, brought the downfall of Lotus 1-2-3. Neither company placed primary emphasis on the pricing policy described in the states' lawsuit. **********Whatever happened in the past, said Chris Le Tocq, an analyst for Dataquest who follows this industry, ''it's very tough to see a way anyone could come in with a word processor or a spreadsheet and turn this around'' in the future. **********And Lewis E. Platt, chairman of the Hewlett-Packard Company, said: ''By now, it's over in that business. Most people find it more difficult to switch applications programs than to even switch operating systems.'' **********Even Attorney General Vacco, when told of the latest sales figures, said: ''Wow! Perhaps it has gone too far, but only the marketplace can provide an answer. Given a more level playing field, can another player compete? I don't know.'' **********A senior Government official involved with the state and Federal lawsuits said, ''When a market tips as decisively as this, there's a real question whether or not it makes sense to try to generate competition.'' **********Microsoft, the state lawsuit said, offered computer manufacturers -- known in the industry as an O.E.M., for original equipment manufacturer -- two choices when buying the office suite. They can buy individual copies of the program for installation on some computers at a price of roughly $170 to $190. Or, they can buy the program at a far lower price, roughly $125, if they purchase it for installation on every computer in a company line -- the Dimension series of Dell computers, for example. **********This is called a ''per system'' license, and the suit says: ''It is impractical in an economic sense for an O.E.M. to install a competing office productivity suite on a computer subject to a per-system license. In order to do so, the O.E.M. would have to pay for both Office and the competing product, and likewise would be required to pass along to the customer the cost of offering both Office and the competing product.'' **********But Mr. Tevlin said that Microsoft's pricing was set in this manner because retailers would complain if manufacturers could buy single copies at a cost far below theirs. **********Executives of the Corel Corporation, the Canadian company that owns Wordperfect, said sales may have been hurt by this -- but not very much. ''The fact is, sales to O.E.M.s are not really a big money maker for us; the retail market is more important,'' said Cindy McGann, Corel's corporate counsel. Mr. Tevlin of Microsoft said manufacturers accounted for only about 6 percent of the Office market. **********Still, Don Sylvester, a senior vice president at Corel, argued that Microsoft's pricing ''absolutely harms everyone in the market, and nobody wants to wake up six months from now and find that Micorosoft is the only one standing in the word processing and suite market.'' **********As it is, Corel has changed its marketing strategy. ''It's clear to us that Microsoft isn't our competition anymore,'' he said. ''They are our environment, and we need to deal with that fact by making our product completely compatible with Microsoft Office so users can move files back and forth between their programs and ours.'' **********The senior Lotus executive agreed that compatibility was essential for survival. And both companies are now selling their products at a fraction of the cost of Microsoft Office. This leaves Microsoft officials wondering aloud what all the fuss is about, since predatory pricing typically means selling a product for far less than a competitor. Corel sells Wordperfect Suite to manufacturers for about $15, and the retail price for the program is only $99. Lotus is owned by I.B.M., and its suite is bundled free on most I.B.M. personal computers. The retail price of Microsoft Office is $399. **********Even with rock-bottom prices, both companies said they believed they could survive and both have large bases of customers who buy updated versions of the programs. A survey early this year of about 300 companies by the Olsten Corporation, a temporary worker company, found that 21 percent of the offices surveyed still used Wordperfect, and 27 percent still used Lotus 1-2-3.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/20/busin.snippet: Pete McCarthy, scuba-diving entrepreneur, receives patent for new type of swimming fin that he says will require less exertion on part of divers; Joanne Marie DeAngeles gets patent for swimming goggles with built-in ear protectors; Martin C Metro ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/20/busin.main_headline: Patents; What's new at the pool: A new design for fins, protection for the ears and a float for baby.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/20/busin.print_headline: Patents; What's new at the pool: A new design for fins, protection for the ears and a float for baby.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/20/busin.body_text: **********THE last big innovation in swimming fins -- those rubber appendages that give scuba divers and snorkelers more leg power -- came in 1965, with the introduction of vents. The vents, by allowing water to pass through the fin, reduced drag and made kicking less laborious. **********Pete McCarthy, a 32-year-old scuba-diving entrepreneur, had not even been born when the vented fins first appeared. But Mr. McCarthy has just patented a new type of fin that he says will require a lot less exertion on the part of divers. **********In anthropomorphic terms, Mr. McCarthy's fin more resembles the tail of a tuna than the webbed foot of a duck. ''It's split into two slender wings that are kind of V-shaped,'' Mr. McCarthy said. ''It acts like a fish tail.'' **********The fins rotate somewhat like the propeller blades on a boat, he said. ''Only they don't go all the way around.'' **********Mr. McCarthy -- who said he came up with the design through trial and error after experimenting with about 200 handmade prototypes -- quit his job as a software salesman in 1996 to work full time on his idea. **********The fins allow a diver to go faster than he would wearing conventional fins, Mr. McCarthy contends. Using an underwater speedometer that he also invented, Mr. McCarthy said he had clocked divers going about 30 percent faster with his fins. **********But that is a bit like claiming that a new car can go 150 miles an hour. Impressive, but not particularly relevant if it is used for commuting and running errands. **********A more meaningful measurement, said Jon Hardy, who runs a scuba-products testing company called Scuba Lab on Catalina Island, Calif., is the consumption of oxygen. **********Mr. Hardy, whom Mr. McCarthy paid to test his fins, said the split fins did reduce divers' air consumption. ''The fins are from 20 to 40 percent more efficient than conventional fins,'' Mr. Hardy said. Mr. McCarthy said divers wearing his fins just perform a small flutter kick, rather than the big bent-knee kick that is most effective with traditional fins. ''No knees at all,'' he said. ''You just roll your ankles.'' **********Apollo Sports, a Japanese company that distributes diving equipment in the United States, has licensed Mr. McCarthy's patent and will be coming out with its version of the split fin this summer. **********Mr. McCarthy, who has a company called Nature's Wing, in Newport Beach, Calif., said he had also licensed patent 5,746,631 to other companies that will be developing their own versions of the fin. **********Swim Goggles With Ear Protectors **********Joanne Marie DeAngelis's daughter is grown now. But she remembers how difficult it can be to coax a child prone to ear infections to put in earplugs before swimming. **********So she has invented a pair of goggles with built-in ear protectors. **********The ear protectors are not inserted. Instead, they are essentially wide bands made of a rubberized waterproof material that molds tightly around the outside of the ears. The bands, which attach at the back with a Velcro-type fastener, also serve to hold the goggles in place. **********Ms. DeAngelis, an administrative assistant at a brokerage firm in Brooklyn, said she was hoping to license her patent, No. 5,713,078. **********An Exercise In Baby-Sitting **********Since small children must constantly be supervised around the pool, parents of young families often find it impossible to squeeze in a few laps for exercise. **********Martin C. Metro and Naomi R. Fine, of Oakland, Calif., have come up with a way for parents to watch their children while doing the backstroke. **********It is a flotation device that a child sits inside. The baby float features a canopy to keep the sun out and a bar in front with small toys attached. **********To use it as a kick board, a parent grasps it at one end. To use it as an arm strengthener, the parent does the backstroke while squeezing the sides of the chair between his thighs. **********Mr. Metro and Ms. Fine received patent 5,766,052. **********Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/17/techn.snippet: Letter from Michael Taglieri comments on Dec 10 article on E-mail etiquette (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/17/techn.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Your article on E-mail etiquette (''Tracking the Evolution of E-Mail Etiquette,'' Dec. 10) omitted what for me is the most important use of the blind carbon copy function: sending my own E-mail to myself. I have E-mail access both at home and at work, with no ability to get access to one account from the other location. **********If I want to save an E-mail message received on one account, I can Bcc it to my other account. That keeps my recipients from wondering what kind of screwball would send himself copies of his own E-mail. **********MICHAEL TAGLIERI **********New York, Dec. 10, 1998

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.snippet: Former Zambian Pres Kenneth D Kaunda is under house arrest while police try to build case that he was behind three-hour coup attempt on Oct 28; his lawyers are fighting to have him released, since prosecutors have presented no evidence, other than...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.main_headline: Zambia Gazes at the Power Elite's Dirty Laundry
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.print_headline: Zambia Gazes at the Power Elite's Dirty Laundry
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.body_text: **********When former President Kenneth D. Kaunda arrives at court each morning, up to 100 soldiers surround him and not only shove photographers back with rifle butts, but also jump like basketball forwards trying to block his face. **********Inside, when a political ally of his asks for a glass of water, a lawyer for Mr. Kaunda makes the court clerk taste it first. **********Suspicion runs deep in Zambian politics these days. **********In the last two years, Zambia has had a bomb blast outside the President's house, a roundup of opposition leaders, a flawed election, the shooting of two opposition candidates, a lawsuit asserting that the President is secretly a foreigner, threats of invasion, riots in the capital, a coup attempt, a roundup of 90 coup suspects, torture allegations and, on Christmas Day, the arrest of Mr. Kaunda. **********And yet, life goes rather normally.  The country, some say, would probably be much the same if none of this had happened. This nation of nine million people on the divide between relatively stable southern Africa and chaotic central Africa is stumbling along: Once relatively wealthy, now poor; once staunchly socialist, now aggressively free-market; never wholly democratic nor wholly despotic, Zambia is still giving the donor nations that support it a combination of hope and the heebie-jeebies. **********A state of emergency is in effect.  But there is no curfew, airports are open and rush-hour traffic jams the business district. As a police sergeant in the northern city of Kitwe said, ''The state of emergency is only for the political elite in Lusaka.'' **********Under the emergency's broad detention laws, Mr. Kaunda is under house arrest while the police try to build a case that he was behind the three-hour coup attempt on Oct. 28. **********His lawyers are fighting to have him released, since the prosecutors have presented no evidence, other than an unsubstantiated statement that he agreed to give the coup leaders money and jobs. But Zambia's courts are so slow that a habeas corpus hearing, normally urgent, has dragged on for a month. The Government says Mr. Kaunda exploits the hearings to make speeches, and the court has barred all press contact with him. **********Many Zambians and outside experts believe that the coup attempt had nothing to do with Mr. Kaunda, but was a foray by a few captains and majors who had been drinking and were bitter about their low pay and their generals' handsome lifestyles. **********One of the two accused coup leaders, Capt. Jackson Chiti, testified on  Jan. 15 that the police had tortured him, demanding that he implicate Mr. Kaunda. But he denied that the former President was involved and tearfully apologized to him in court. **********But there are other theories too:  one put about by some American officials and South African military experts is that Zambia overreacted to a feeble coup attempt because it is terrified that Angola is plotting against it. **********Supply flights to the Unita rebels in eastern Angola have originated in western Zambia, prompting threats of invasion by the Angolan Government. Since Angolan troops helped overthrow Presidents Mobutu Sese Seko in the former Zaire and Pascal Lissouba in the Congo Republic last year because Unita had bases in those countries, Zambia is nervous. **********But Eric Silwamba, the President's chief of staff and a special envoy to Angola, said Zambia closed the airstrips and expelled the South African company running the supply flights, Meteor-Ex. Its relations with Angola are cordial again, he said. **********Nonetheless, a South African military expert said western Zambia's airspace is still largely unwatched by radar and the Zambian Army is spread thin in border areas west of the Zambezi River. **********Mr. Silwamba denied that the demoted Defense Minister and other party insiders had enriched themselves by helping Unita, which still controls diamond areas. **********The most common outlook on the repeated crises of the last two years is that they all spring from a deep hatred between two very touchy men: Mr. Kaunda, a schoolteacher who led Zambia to independence from Britain in 1964 and ruled it for 27 years, and President Frederick J. T. Chiluba, a trade unionist who formed the coalition that ousted Mr. Kaunda in a democratic election in 1991 and then fractured in squabbles. **********Mr. Chiluba ''tried to destroy Dr. Kaunda's reputation, calling him a dictator who ruined the country,'' said the Rev. Nevers Mumba, a clergyman building his own political party. ''That touched Dr. Kaunda's ego and pride. That's what made him come back into politics.'' **********The two could hardly be more different. Mr. Kaunda is tall and solid, wears Nehru suits and affects a large white handkerchief into which he alternately storms and weeps; as a liberation leader he combed his hair like Don King's, but now, at 73,  he has a gray beard and lives on raw vegetables. **********Mr. Chiluba, 54, is tiny and efficient, a fundamentalist Christian who wears natty suits and does without a scurrying entourage. In his rapid-delivery speeches, he quickly lapses into tart scorn, doing imitations while telling folksy stories deriding Mr. Kaunda, African and Western leaders and other critics. **********''I think he's driven by a fear of appearing weak,'' said Jim Polhemus, an American consultant studying democracy here. ''The people around him are telling him not to let Mandela or Mugabe or the donor nations push him around.'' **********Asked about the series of crises,  Mr. Kaunda's party says Mr. Chiluba changed the Constitution to bar him from running again in 1996, planted small bombs as an excuse to claim the existence of a ''Black Mamba gang'' and jail his party leadership until the 1996 race was over, rigged the election, secretly ordered the police to fire into Mr. Kaunda's car during a 1997 party meeting, grazing him and seriously wounding an ally, framed him on the coup charges and hopes for another chance to kill him. **********Mr. Chiluba's aides say Mr. Kaunda ignored the people's will by running again, produced false witnesses saying Mr. Chiluba is Zairian, faked his own shooting, provoked the 1997 riot in which the downtown  market was burned and arranged the coup attempt. **********Almost every one of these charges has led to court; almost all have petered out inconclusively. The Black Mamba bombing charges were dropped for lack of evidence.  The Supreme Court ruled that Mr.  Chiluba did not have to take a DNA test to prove his identity. It still has not ruled on the 1996 election. The wounding of Mr. Kaunda has yet to be officially investigated. **********Acknowledging that it looked as if the Government trumped up the  Black Mamba case, Mr. Silwamba says the police botched it by being hasty. They do not want to repeat that mistake over the coup, he said.  He denied that the Government was persecuting Mr. Kaunda. **********Many Zambians view these fights as confined to the political elite. **********''The average Zambian is marginalized completely, and the playing ground is being left to the politicians,'' said Ngande Mwanajiti, who ran the Clean Campaign Committee in 1996. As a defender of civil liberties, though, he feels threatened.  ''The police can come and take me away at any time.'' **********Most Zambians, however, are just trying to get by. The standard of living today is about half what it was in 1964, when copper prices were high. Mr. Kaunda's socialism unraveled the economy, and Mr. Chiluba's bold privatization efforts have forced thousands of layoffs. **********The foreign investment he hopes to attract is slow in arriving, and the budget is propped up with foreign aid. Mr. Silwamba calls that ''the pity of being a poor country -- they give the money, so they want you to play the tune.'' **********Mr. Chiluba's Government resents the fuss foreigners are suddenly making over Mr. Kaunda. They recall that Mr. Kaunda muzzled the press, jailed hundreds of political opponents and made children leave school to line the roads and wave whenever his motorcade went by.  Many Zambians remember waiting all night for cooking oil or sugar, which inevitably ran out, leaving soldiers to whip angry shoppers away. **********''Now,'' a museum guard said, ''it is the opposite. There is food on the shelves -- but no money to buy it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/17/busin.body_text: **********Astra International, Indonesia's biggest car maker, said yesterday that it had reduced its work force by 20 percent, or 25,000 workers, in the last several months to reduce costs. The cuts, which began last year, have come as Indonesia's first recession in 30 years has battered Astra's ability to repay $2 billion in debt. **********The job cuts, including 20,000 contract workers and 5,000 staff members, show Astra is determined to survive the slowdown, said Yulian Warman, a spokesman. Astra continues to employ about 100,000 contract and full-time workers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/11/busin.snippet: Article on current upturn in value of balanced mutual funds which, for years, have lagged behind pure equity funds; chart (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/11/busin.main_headline: A Happy (or Not So Sad) Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/11/busin.print_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; A Happy (or Not So Sad) Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/11/busin.body_text: **********AFTER years of lagging behind pure equity funds, balanced mutual funds are suddenly looking a lot more attractive. **********Balanced funds, which hold a mixture of stocks and bonds, tend to underperform pure stock funds during bull markets, but their bond holdings can salvage some returns when equities head south. Think of them as a good hedge against an overheated stock market or a global recession. **********''Any time risk is that high in equities, it's always a good idea to look at less risky alternatives, and balanced funds fall into that category,'' said Norman G. Fosback, editor of the Mutual Fund Forecaster, a newsletter in Deerfield Beach, Fla. ''Balanced funds, as a class, are extremely attractive.'' **********The average balanced fund lost 6.7 percent in the third quarter -- a return not as good as the 1.8 percent gain for the average bond fund but far better than the 13.4 percent slide of the average stock fund, according to Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago. **********The class, however, includes a lot of individual differences. Some balanced funds are split between two managers -- one for the stock assets, one for the bonds. The funds can also have a fixed or variable asset split and enormously different objectives. **********Investors should be aware that scores of balanced funds have been rolled out recently by firms eager to fill out their product lines for the 401(k) market, said Amy Arnott, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds. Nearly half of the balanced funds tracked by Morningstar have assets of less than $30 million and thus do not appear in the mutual fund tables of The New York Times. **********It may behoove investors to either select big, established balanced funds, said Ms. Arnott, or to pay extra-close attention to the style a fund uses. ''Be more cautious,'' she said. ''Especially if it's going to have a newer manager.'' **********In fact, some balanced funds are not very balanced. Portfolio managers may make big bets on the stock market, or even on certain types of stocks. Avondale Total Return, for example, has almost 86 percent of its assets in stocks and just 9 percent in bonds. The Berger Balanced fund, by contrast, has 50 percent of its assets in stocks, 18 percent in bonds and the rest in cash. In a down market, such differences between funds can produce a vast gulf in results. For the year through Sept. 30, Avondale's 1.7 percent return was far below Berger's 13.7 percent. **********The types of stocks in a balanced fund can also throw performance out of kilter. Consider the Smith Barney Security and Growth fund, which has a nearly 50-50 split between stocks and bonds. The fund may look evenly balanced, but the majority of its stock holdings are in small companies, which are getting hammered in this market -- as is the fund, down 9.4 percent through the third quarter of this year. **********While balanced funds as a group are known for their stability, certain funds still change the weightings in their portfolios radically and quickly. Provident Investment Counsel Pinnacle Balanced, for example, has cut its stock holdings to about 62 percent, from 74 percent in July, according to Jeffrey Miller, managing director of the fund. It has returned 12.7 percent this year through Sept. 30. **********Alliance Growth Investors is another balanced fund that has unloaded stocks. Nicholas D. Carn, the portfolio manager, recently cut his equity holdings to 55 percent, from 68 percent in July and 82 percent in January. ''Obviously, the high stock exposure is one of the things that has helped our performance'' in the bull market, he said. The fund returned 5 percent in the first three quarters. Investors looking for a less risky balanced fund, he said, can put their money in Alliance Conservative Investors, which has only about 23 percent of its holdings in stocks and returned 6.8 percent in the period. **********While bonds give these funds more stability, they have their own risks. In general, the longer the bonds' maturities, the higher the interest-rate risk. Long-term bonds usually pay higher interest rates than short-term bonds, but if rates rise, a fund dominated by long-term bonds is locked in at a lower rate of return. **********Balanced funds can hold many different types of bonds -- corporate and municipal, as well as Treasury -- with varying maturities. The Mainstay Total Return B fund, for example, is holding bonds with an average maturity of 13.2 years, while Avondale Total Return is holding short-term debt with an average maturity of two years. For the first three quarters, Mainstay's 7.8 percent gain beat Avondale's return by more than 6 percentage points. **********''Balanced funds are usually sold as conservative investments, but if you've got a fund that is concentrated in small stocks and long-term bonds, you don't have a conservative product,'' said Steve M. Lipper, senior vice president at Lipper Analytical Services, the research firm in Summit, N.J. **********Mutual fund experts caution investors to read the current and past semiannual reports to see what kind of securities a fund is holding and the changes the portfolio has made. **********An investor's tax bracket will also influence her choice of balanced mutual funds. One option for investors in the top brackets is USAA Growth and Tax Strategy, a fund with about 51 percent of its assets in tax-free bonds and 49 percent in growth stocks. It returned 2.8 percent in the first three quarters. **********Then, of course, there is always another option. Sheldon Jacobs, editor of the No Load Fund Investor, a newsletter, recommends that investors do their own portfolio balancing by buying separate stock and bond funds. That, he said, gives them more control over the amount and types of stocks they are holding and lets them plan tax gains and losses more effectively.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/08/world.snippet: Turkish feminists demand resignation of Isilay Saygin, Cabinet minister in charge of women's affairs, after she defends traditional practice of subjecting women to virginity tests (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/08/world.main_headline: Turks Clash Over Defense of Virginity Tests
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/08/world.print_headline: Turks Clash Over Defense of Virginity Tests
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/08/world.body_text: **********Outraged Turkish feminists are demanding the resignation of the Cabinet minister in charge of women's affairs after she defended the traditional practice of subjecting women to virginity tests. **********In rural areas and urban neighborhoods populated by migrants from the countryside, parents and future husbands often take young women to be tested before their marriage, and sometimes if they are suspected of having had premarital relations. **********The minister, Isilay Saygin, has often seemed proud of her anti-feminist stance, asserting at various times that ''women don't want to take part in politics'' and that ''three women don't equal one man.'' Her appointment to Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz's Cabinet in June provoked some protests, but the campaign for her removal began in earnest after the publication last week of an interview she gave to an Istanbul newspaper. **********Asked what she thought of virginity testing, she replied: ''It doesn't bother me. I do whatever Turkish tradition and customs require of the family.'' **********''Educating children is the duty of the father and mother,'' she asserted. ''The state is the father.'' **********Reminded that some young women have committed suicide rather than face the results of virginity tests, Ms. Saygin said: ''Girls who committed suicide because they were forced to take a virginity test would have committed suicide anyway. I don't think this is really important. Five or three girls, it doesn't matter.'' **********These and other comments infuriated feminists. **********''To be able to say that three or five women might die is not something out of the blue,'' said Halime Guner, co-founder of a women's group called Flying Broom. ''She has always been like that.'' **********Even one of Ms. Saygin's senior aides, Selma Acuner, disavowed her comments. ''Virginity tests are a violation of individual rights,'' Ms. Acuner said. ''Reactions are pouring in to our ministry.'' **********The case may prove a boon to the small but growing women's movement in Turkey. It has brought feminist groups together with more mainstream organizations such as the Republican Women's Association, which is dedicated to promoting the sexual equality that Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, founder of the Turkish Republic, decreed in the 1920's. **********''Women are not reluctant to participate in politics,'' the chairman of the association, Senal Saruhan, said after Ms. Saygin's interview was published. ''They have been treated as second-class citizens.'' **********Turkish law makes no reference to the practice of virginity tests, but many parents consider them a reasonable way to control daughters. **********''Sometimes headmasters of schools bring girls in for tests, and if it is found that the girls are not virgins, they can be expelled,'' said Sahika Yuksel, an Istanbul doctor who is among those calling for Ms. Saygin's resignation. ''Police often bring women in for tests if they are found in a flirtatious or romantic situation,'' she said. ''If they are not virgins they can be charged with practicing prostitution or brought back to their families, where they often face serious problems.'' **********''No one should have an interest in whether an adult woman is a virgin or not,'' Dr. Yuksel said. ''Unfortunately, in certain countries, including Turkey, virginity is considered an important sign of honor.'' **********Ms. Saygin has declined to comment on the dispute, and Government spokesmen today also declined.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/07/busin.snippet: Rufus Griscom, editor in chief on the on-line magazine Nerve (www.nerve.com) says with onset of holiday season his magazine has moved into market for provocative gifts like silk pajamas, aromatherapy candles, stories and essays by established auth...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/07/busin.main_headline: Compressed Data; An Attempt at 'Literate Smut' In a Time When Outrage Died
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/07/busin.print_headline: Compressed Data; An Attempt at 'Literate Smut' In a Time When Outrage Died
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/07/busin.body_text: **********What with matters Lewinsky and the Viagra sensation, 1998 has been a watershed year for sex, in the view of Rufus Griscom, editor in chief of the on-line magazine Nerve (www.nerve.com). Previously unutterable topics have infiltrated public discourse, and this can only be good news to someone in the business of offering readers ''literate smut.'' **********''When Tom Brokaw says 'erectile dysfunction' on the air, when puritanism is pushed back, it's permanent,'' Mr. Griscom said. **********For this reason, at the onset of a holiday season that many have proclaimed an ''e-Christmas,'' Mr. Griscom feels that his magazine's foray into electronic commerce is well timed. As with its stories and essays, which have been contributed by established authors like Erica Jong, Nerve's on-line store leaves much to the imagination. **********''Everyone asks us, 'Are you selling lotions and sex toys?' '' Mr. Griscom said. ''We clearly, very intentionally, decided not to do that.'' Instead, there are provocative gifts like silk pajamas and candles. **********''Perhaps it should come as no surprise that apple pie is the scent American males find most arousing. If you're not the sort to bake your man a pie (or whisk your woman off to an ocean bluff), put our aromatherapy candles to work for you,'' reads the promotional copy for the ''Nerve Boutique: Supplies for the Thoughtful Hedonist.'' **********But pushing for a renaissance of the game Twister -- ''people should get their limbs entwined with other people's limbs as often as possible'' -- is just one facet of Mr. Griscom's efforts to extend the 18-month-old Nerve brand. **********In raising money and signing deals, Mr. Griscom (who has a scholarly demeanor and an Ivy League degree) has learned that perhaps even more than love, sex is vastly misunderstood -- particularly when the word ''intelligent'' is used to describe it. **********''Our goal is not to turn people on but to make people think about it,'' he said. ''Erotica tends to follow the arc of the sexual act and is more about arousal, whereas what we tend to publish is more thoughtful and might make people feel decidedly unaroused.'' **********In this paradox, Mr. Griscom finds an intriguing challenge for the new millennium, a time in which E-mail and chat rooms factor increasingly into the romantic lives of a great number of people. To accommodate the shift, the site will soon allow the creation of personal home pages, the better to swap personal data and one's own erotic writings. **********A television show is also possible, and a book -- ''Nerve: Literate Smut'' -- is already on the stands.   LISA NAPOLI

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/busin.snippet: Executive with Cyberspace Research was confronted several months ago by Federal law enforcement officials investigating whether company was commissioned by subsidiary of Reuters Holdings PLC to steal information electronically from rival, Bloomber...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/busin.main_headline: Investigators in Reuters Case Met With Computer Consultant Months Ago
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/busin.print_headline: Investigators in Reuters Case Met With Computer Consultant Months Ago
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/busin.body_text: **********An executive with a Manhattan computer company was confronted several months ago by Federal law enforcement officials investigating whether the company was commissioned by a subsidiary of Reuters Holdings P.L.C. to steal information electronically from a rival, Bloomberg L.P., people briefed on the case said yesterday. **********The contact between the Government and the executive of Cyberspace Research suggests that at least some people working with the small company could have been cooperating with the Federal investigation of the subsidiary, Reuters Analytics Inc., before it was disclosed last week. **********Telephone calls to Cyberspace Research have gone unanswered for several days. A number for David Schwartz, a former Bloomberg employee who runs Cyberspace Research, could not be obtained. **********Prosecutors have been investigating for as long as a year to determine whether Reuters took part in a scheme to steal proprietary information maintained in Bloomberg's central computers. They are examining whether that information was later improperly incorporated into products like the Reuters 3000, which has been widely viewed in the financial data industry as the product most likely to compete with the Bloomberg terminal. **********In the week since Reuters announced that a Manhattan grand jury was investigating whether it improperly obtained and used Bloomberg's information, the company has said little about the nature and scope of the inquiry. **********But yesterday, Reuters released its first comprehensive statement on the case, describing information that it has learned since first being made aware of the Federal inquiry earlier this month. **********In the statement, Reuters said that investigators were examining whether the company induced a consultant it did not identify to gain access to proprietary data maintained in Bloomberg's central computers. That consultant is Cyberspace Research, according to people briefed on the case. But, Reuters said, the access under investigation did not involve hacking, in which Bloomberg's central systems would be penetrated by an outside computer. **********Rather, Reuters said, the activities under investigation involve direct access to the information in the computer systems through a Bloomberg terminal. Cyberspace Research subscribed to Bloomberg's service. Reuters did not, and indeed, companies in this industry do not allow competitors to have access to their computer systems. **********People who have been briefed on the case said prosecutors thought that Cyberspace Research had obtained thousands of screens of Bloomberg data, the fundamental product of the computer system. Prosecutors think that the information was then turned over to Reuters executives, these people said. The investigation is examining whether that information was then used directly in some Reuters products. **********The prosecutors are also examining whether the company used such information to reconstruct analysis programs used by Bloomberg through a process known as reverse engineering, in which a final product is broken down to find out how it works. While this would give Reuters the ability to duplicate some Bloomberg analytical functions, it did not require or involve access to the system's operating code, people who have been briefed on the case said. **********In its statement, Reuters said that the investigation was examining ''whether Bloomberg data obtained by the consultant was improperly incorporated into Reuters products and whether Bloomberg information was used by Reuters Analytics for any improper 'reverse engineering' of certain analytics,'' the statement said. **********The investigation involves information relating to fixed-income investments, the statement said, and ''to some extent'' to equity investments, too. **********Reuters said that it did not think the company would have to withdraw any products because of the investigation. But it said that if it discovered proprietary information belonging to Bloomberg in its products, ''it intends to take remedial action.'' **********At this point, Reuters said, the principal focus of the investigation is on Reuters Analytics and employees with that unit. But the investigation also involves ''an examination of the activities of other individuals and entities outside of Reuters Analytics,'' the company said. **********Investors reacted positively. In London, Reuters shares rose 40.5 pence, to 560.5 pence. The stock remains down about 5 percent from its level before the market learned about the investigation. The company's American depository receipts -- each representing six shares -- also rose, closing up $4.4375 yesterday, to $55.125. **********Reuters did not identify any of the employees whose activities might be under investigation. To date, it has placed three executives on paid leave, including Hubert Holmes, the unit's director. Mr. Holmes, who has declined to comment, reported directly to senior executives at the parent company in London. **********Michael Bloomberg, the chairman and chief executive of Bloomberg, declined to comment on the unfolding investigation at a press conference yesterday announcing a strategic partnership with CNET, an Internet publisher and television production company in San Francisco. **********''It's between the Justice Department and Reuters,'' he told reporters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.snippet: Benjamin Bowden, industrial designer who created futuristic bicycle that became expensive collector's item, dies at age 91 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.main_headline: Benjamin Bowden, 91, Auto and Bicycle Designer
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.print_headline: Benjamin Bowden, 91, Auto and Bicycle Designer
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.body_text: **********Benjamin Bowden, an industrial designer who created a futuristic bicycle that became an expensive collector's item, died on March 6 in Lake Worth, Fla. He was 91. **********Mr. Bowden was born in London and studied at the Regent Street Polytechnic school, a daughter, Gina Bowden-Pierce, said. He began working in the automobile industry in Britain in 1925 as a designer but also had an interest in bicycles. **********Only a few hundred examples of his streamlined, fiberglass-construction Bowden Spacelander bike were built. It was one of a handful of creations selected from hundreds of entries in 1946 by the British Council of Industrial Design for a London exhibition, Britain Can Make It. **********The original model included an electric motor that gathered energy on downhill and flat terrain and helped the rider climb hills. A number of bicycle manufacturers rejected the Spacelander as too exotic for mass marketing. But in recent years, collectors have paid as much as $15,000 for an example in good condition. **********The automobile designs he worked on included the Healey sports car, a forerunner of the Austin-Healey, and an armored car used by Winston Churchill and King George VI in World War II. **********In 1952, he moved to Windsor, Ontario, where he had a hand in making the Ford Thunderbird perform smoothly, his daughter said. ''His fingerprints are on a ton of things,'' she said. His design work also extended to objects like bathroom fixtures and gasoline station pumps. **********His last job was coordinating designs for military tanks at General Dynamics, his daughter said. He was 79 when he retired and moved to Florida in 1986. **********Survivors include his wife, Mary, of Lake Worth; two sons, Robin, of Cognac, France, and Derek, of Ludlow, England; two daughters, Patricia Sundgaard of Dallas and Ms. Bowden-Pierce, of Orlando, Fla.; a stepdaughter, Judy Patterson of Brooksville, Fla., and two stepsons, Mark Connolly of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Dennis Connolly of Lake Worth.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/busin.snippet: Japanese yen's sudden rise against US dollar threatens to take momentum out of Japan's exports by making it more costly for America and other foreign markets to buy Japanese products; economists say if yen's strength lasts, it could even prolong J...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/busin.main_headline: Yen's Rise Against Dollar Is Threatening Japanese Exports
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Yen's Rise Against Dollar Is Threatening Japanese Exports
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/busin.body_text: **********The yen's sudden jump against the dollar this past week threatens to take the momentum out of Japan's exports by making it more costly for America and other foreign markets to buy Japanese products. **********If the yen's new-found strength lasts, economists say, it could even prolong Japan's worst postwar recession. **********Big corporate exporters such as the Sony Corporation, the Honda Motor Company, the Fuji Photo Film Company and the NEC Corporation have been caught off-guard by the yen's abrupt about-face. The yen's higher exchange value makes their products more expensive abroad and lowers the value of their foreign earnings when converted back into yen. **********''If the high yen trend continues, we will see the influence on our sales and profits within several months,'' Tamotsu Iba, vice president of Sony, said in a statement. ''The current rapid rise in the yen does not reflect the fundamentals of the Japanese economy.'' **********Up until this week, the yen had been weakening for months, a reflection of the litany of economic problems confronting Japan: debt-laden banks, rising bankruptcies, falling domestic sales, plummeting business confidence and a stock market that has continued to flirt with 12-year lows. Asia's economic crisis put further downward pressure on the yen. **********But the yen's weakness has also been regarded as a benefit to Japan because it has helped stimulate exports, the one area of Japan's economy that has continued to maintain relative health. **********Now, the abrupt change to a stronger yen, combined with signs of economic weakness appearing in Japan's most important market, the United States, has raised doubts about Japanese exporters as well. **********Share prices of companies heavily dependent on exports have been falling recently. Many of those companies are the bluest of Japan's blue chips, the industrial elite of the nation. **********Honda shares, for example, fell 470 yen yesterday, to close at 2,900 yen, while Sony's shares declined 380, to 7,770 yen. Honda is now trading at about 9 times earnings, while Sony trades at 16 times earnings. In comparison, shares of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, which is less dependent on exports to the United States than Honda and Sony, trade at 27 times earnings. **********''It's hard to say in any definitive way what the exact impact could be without knowing each company's hedging ratios, the final demand for their products and where they are produced,'' said Kathy Matsui, chief strategist at Goldman Sachs (Japan) Ltd. ''But I still think that, net-net, it's hard to say it's positive for the exporters.'' **********Some companies did offer rudimentary snapshots of the potential impact of the yen's swing. **********A one yen move in the dollar-yen exchange rate makes a 5-billion-yen difference in Sony's profits. Thus, the recent seesaw of the rate from 135.35 yen to the dollar when trading opened this week to 116.95 yen in late New York trading today caused a slide of more than $780 million in potential earnings from Sony's operating profits. The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest car company, sees a 10-billion-yen swing in operating profits every time the dollar-yen exchange rate fluctuates by one yen. **********The yen's rise is not necessarily viewed as a bad development elsewhere in Asia -- in fact, other weakened Asian economies could benefit from a rising yen because it would make their exports more competitive. Stock markets in Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea and Thailand rose today because of that prospect. **********But Japan has been counting on its mighty car and electronics manufacturers with their vast global sales networks to generate the cash needed to keep its gross domestic product from slumping further than the 1.8 percent decline the Government has projected. With much of Asia still stuck in an economic rut and the domestic market in a funk, the Japanese exporters are regarded as increasingly important to Japan's still- elusive recovery. **********If the United States economy slows further, as many believe it will, and the yen maintains its current strength, corporate Japan will face an unprecedented jump in excess capacity and inventories, which are already at levels that are pressuring prices. While the long-term impact of the drop in the dollar could become moot overnight should sentiment turn again, sudden swings in the exchange rate can hurt day-to-day corporate decision-making. **********''The movement affects short-term business conditions, too, in terms of competitiveness,'' said Aston J. Bridgman, a spokesman for NEC, the world's second-largest semiconductor manufacturer. ''If we're bidding on projects, we can quickly become uncompetitive when exchange rates swing like they have today and yesterday.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/27/busin.body_text: **********Q. I am part of a small team that creates product marketing materials for our manufacturing company. One member of our team chews up much more than her share of our group budget, overpaying for necessities and wasting money on frills. Should the rest of us keep pinching pennies, even though the quality of the work suffers, or should we spend what we think we need, knowing that it will call down the wrath of the bean counters on the whole team? **********A. Without a doubt, your best option is C: Neither of the above. (Isn't that always the case?) Both courses you mention aren't really plans at all; rather, they are ways to avoid dealing with your team's problem. And you do have a problem. **********It is essential for everyone in a group to recognize that each member is responsible for the performance of the whole, says Jon R. Katzenbach, a director with McKinsey & Company, the consultants, and an author of ''The Wisdom of Teams'' (HarperBusiness). ''All members should be mutually accountable to one another for their expenditures or the budget or whatever,'' he said. ''Otherwise, you don't have a real team.'' **********For a work group to function effectively -- and profitably -- the members must address internal crises like a spendthrift's  breaking of the budget. They shouldn't wait for an outsider to instill order. ''The team should confront the person,'' Mr. Katzenbach advised. ''Say: 'Look, we're all accountable for this. We have to collectively be comfortable that this spending is going to help us achieve our purpose.' '' **********David Schafer, a vice president at the Enron Corporation who has worked closely with self-directed teams, said, ''One characteristic of teams that really should have appeal is the self-policing nature of the group.'' **********Of course, it can take time for a team to learn how to handle conflicts itself, rather than relying on a supervisor. ''It's certainly not automatic,'' Mr. Schafer said. ''One of the things I would tell my teams is that there's safety in numbers. You've got to be careful not to look like you're ganging up on someone, but whoever confronts the person can say: 'This isn't just my take on the issue. This is the way the group sees it.' '' **********Ron Burnaska, a consultant at the General Electric Company on personnel and team issues, offered a four-step approach: *********** Designate a team member to confront the offender about the group's concerns. *********** Ask the offender the reasons for his behavior. (There may be a good explanation.) *********** If the explanation isn't convincing,  work with the person on a corrective plan. *********** Arrange a follow-up meeting with the person to review the situation and determine if progress is being made. **********No one likes confrontations with co-workers. But if the problem festers, Mr. Schafer warned, ''frustration levels on the team rise and suck the energy out of the group.'' **********Besides, your team's only alternative is to wait for a higher-up to step in and handle your management responsibilities for you. And that wouldn't look good on your year-end performance evaluations. **********Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she will respond to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.
