https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/07/busin.main_headline: Dow Slides by 92.92 as Uncertainty Surrounds Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/07/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; Dow Slides by 92.92 as Uncertainty Surrounds Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/07/busin.body_text: **********The stock market fell sharply again yesterday, continuing a recent volatile trading pattern that reflects the uncertainty of the outlook after a rally that has pushed the market to repeated new highs this year. **********In the last 11 trading days, the Dow Jones industrial average has plunged 267 points in four trading days, shot up 275 points to a new high in five, and fallen 138 points in two, including yesterday's 92.92-point, or 1 percent, decline to 9,054.65. **********Nearly 60 points of the decline yesterday came at the end of the day, after Alice Rivlin, the vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, said on CNBC that she ''sees cause for concern about the values in the stock market.'' **********Although she added, ''That doesn't necessarily mean it's a bubble,'' such a comment from an official at her level at a time of uncertainty can make investors jittery. **********''When the market is overbought and a cautionary comment comes out, the market can tumble,'' said Richard McCabe, the chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch. **********The uncertainty for investors is being created by the outlook for both earnings and economic growth. First-quarter earnings have been relatively weak. Although forecasters expect them to rebound, investors will have to wait to see if that will happen. **********In addition, although many forecasters are expecting economic growth to slow down, there are no firm signs of that yet, and the expected drag from Asia has not shown up as quickly as expected. **********The current stronger-than-expected growth has lead to a reported shift at the Federal Reserve to a bias toward raising interest rates. Forecasters are not betting that the Fed will act soon -- its next policy meeting is May 19 -- but the threat led to the big selloff on April 27 and it is still overhanging the market. **********Also, the riots in Indonesia are shifting some attention back to Asia, with investors realizing that the recovery from last year's currency devaluations is still a long way off. **********''The market has run very hard without much support from lower interest rates or stronger earnings,'' said Douglas R. Cliggott, the United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities. **********If interest rates fall further, he said, that could help. But he does not expect that to happen because the economy is not yet slowing down as forecast. And if earnings improve, that could help. **********But he does not expect a real bounce-back until next year, in part because of the drag from Asia. ''I don't think it's a long-term earnings problem, but we have a few weak quarters ahead of us,'' he said. **********This view has lead him to cut his asset allocation for equities by 10 percentage points, to 60 percent. He put half of this into bonds, raising that portion to 35 percent, and the rest into cash, raising its share to 15 percent. ''We are in for a pause, but not an end to the bull market,'' he said. **********The market was led down yesterday by American Express, off 2 15/16,  to 99 1/2 Walt Disney Company, off 2 1/2 to 124 3/16; Pfizer, down 2 15/16, to 108 13/16, and Microsoft, off 1 3/8, to 86 3/8. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 10.58 points, to 1,104.92, while the Nasdaq index dropped 8.23 points, to 1,856.68.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/17/busin.snippet: Two-day Wall Street conference organized by Rev Jesse Jackson and his Rainbow/PUSH coalition is held at World Trade Center, where leaders of Wall Street community attempt to address issue of race; meeting--with its star-studded cast that includes ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/17/busin.main_headline: Congeniality And Unease As Wall St. Addresses Race
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/17/busin.print_headline: Congeniality And Unease As Wall St. Addresses Race
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/17/busin.body_text: **********There was something for everyone at this week's Wall Street conference organized by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and his Rainbow/PUSH coalition. **********The meeting -- with its star-studded cast that included President Clinton and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve -- offered Mr. Jackson and his organization an opportunity to generate headlines again while raising tough questions about why black Americans and other minorities have had so little access to investment capital, financial training and well-paying jobs. **********And with affirmative action under increasing assault in the political arena and in the courts, business may actually be a friendlier forum these days for Mr. Jackson to practice his patented blend of uplift and agitation. Hobnobbing with the country's financial titans did not hurt Mr. Jackson's image, either. **********''You raised my stock, thank you very much,'' Mr. Jackson half-jokingly told Mr.  Greenspan after the Fed chairman addressed the conference. He did more than that. The meeting also provided Mr. Jackson and Rainbow/PUSH with an opportunity to raise tens of thousands of dollars from Wall Street's bulging pockets. **********Mr. Jackson would not say exactly how much money had been raised by this week's event, although he said that the event's sponsors, which included big Wall Street firms like Merrill Lynch and the Salomon Smith Barney subsidiary of Travelers Group, had provided $400,000 ''in round figures'' to help cover the cost. **********Rainbow/PUSH also held a fund-raiser Thursday night on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, with about 450 guests paying $500 each for dinner and entertainment by the singer Roberta Flack. Mr. Jackson declined to say how much that event had raised, explaining that not all the costs had been calculated. He also raised money yesterday at a $350-a-head luncheon. **********But beyond the coffers filled, is anything likely to change as a result of the sessions, which combined 1960's-style consciousness-raising with a hardheaded 1990's focus on the bottom line? **********For the middle-aged white men who run most Wall Street firms, the two-day gathering at the World Trade Center in downtown Manhattan that ended late yesterday offered an opportunity to pay lip service to minority hiring and to wear their hearts on their sleeves before a basically sympathetic audience. **********After all, critics said, Wall Street has plenty of explaining to do: Blacks now account for no more than 600 of the country's 90,000 brokers, according to Tony Chapelle, publisher of Securities Pro newsletter, which reports on blacks on Wall Street. The percentage of employees in the securities industry who are black has dropped from 10.6 percent in 1990 to 8.4 percent in 1996. And nearly three out of five blacks on Wall Street are employed as office and clerical workers, according to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. **********The conference exposed a clear divide on Wall Street. In general, firms with lots of ordinary customers seemed to take the conference more seriously. Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover both contributed to the event, officials said, and senior executives from each firm attended. **********But firms that deal little with the investing public, like Lehman Brothers, seemed less involved. William Ahearn, a Lehman spokesman, said this week that the firm had ''at least one person attending,'' but was not supporting the event with a donation  or providing speakers for any of the industry panels. **********Asked what he had achieved at the conference, Mr. Jackson gave a discursive answer, setting out the grim economic history of the country's black population. ''For 250 years blacks were listed as commodities,'' he said. **********''There are these definable, quantifiable gaps in our economy,'' he said, adding that the conference had helped to draw attention to ''the investment gap, the education gap and the trade gap in our economy.'' **********''Wall Street stands to gain if it closes the gap,'' he said. **********In interviews, Mr. Jackson and his staff insisted yesterday that they would continue to keep a close eye on Wall Street, and that their newfound closeness with the securities industry would be characterized by ''tough love,'' combining friendship and criticism. **********At some firms, Mr. Jackson's carrot approach appears to be having some effect. James Dimon, the chairman and chief executive of Salomon Smith Barney, has told managers for the last two years that they will be rewarded financially if they succeed in hiring good minority and women candidates, according to Gordon McAndrew, a spokesman for the firm. **********But the stick may prove even more effective. Smith Barney settled a class action suit brought by women and minority employees in part by pledging to do more to safeguard their rights. A resolution to a similar suit brought against Merrill Lynch is currently being negotiated. **********Mr. Jackson, when asked about the cases, replied with a broad statement offering few specific suggestions. **********As for the black business leaders among the 650 people in attendance, the meeting was a chance to do more than exchange business cards. ''It's bringing people together to focus on the task at hand,'' said Kenneth I. Tatum of Mitchell & Titus L.L.P., an accounting and consulting firm. That task, he said, is to ''insure that minorities get to share opportunities'' in fast-growth sectors of the economy like finance, software and high technology.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/30/world.snippet: Reporter's Notebook offers vignettes of Pres Clinton's visit to Botswana; photo; map (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/30/world.main_headline: Reporter's Notebook; Africa Presents Clinton With a Raft of Distractions
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/30/world.print_headline: Reporter's Notebook; Africa Presents Clinton With a Raft of Distractions
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/30/world.body_text: **********President Clinton seemed to have every reason to fear that his embarrassing troubles back home -- ''the current situation,'' as some White House officials delicately refer to it -- would trail him to Africa, during the 12-day trip that brought him here today for two days of relaxing among the big game of the Kalahari Desert. **********Last Monday morning, as the President prepared to disembark from Air Force One in Accra, Ghana, for his first moments on African soil, Kwesi Koomson, a Ghanaian reporter for the Business Chronicle in Accra, stood musing over who would emerge next. **********''Let's see if it's Monica or Kathleen,'' he said softly, with only the slightest of grins. Turning to an American colleague, Mr. Koomson proceeded to display an intricate knowledge not only about Monica S. Lewinsky and Kathleen Willey, but also about other members of the ensemble in the running White House follies. **********''Ken Starr,'' Mr. Koomson said, referring to the independent counsel. ''Do you think he is getting frustrated with his job?'' **********And so it went, from country to country: shouted questions about legal maneuverings from White House reporters and lewd editorial cartoons in the local newspapers. President Clinton was in town, a popular radio host warned in Cape Town on Thursday, and added, ''Lock up your daughters!'' **********The presence in Mr. Clinton's delegation of Bruce Lindsey, the deputy White House counsel, and Betty Currie, the President's personal secretary, served as reminders to those on the road of the troubles back home. Both have testified to the grand jury. **********Mrs. Currie's testimony is believed to have differed in a critical way from a sworn deposition by Mr. Clinton, though she has seemed happy and relaxed when glimpsed on this trip. ''Wonderful!'' she exclaimed on Thursday, when asked what she thought of Mr. Clinton's speech to the South African Parliament. **********As the week wore on, and as somber matters like the 1994 genocide in Rwanda took center stage, ''the current situation'' receded farther into the background. At a news conference on Friday, Mr. Clinton was not asked about Ms. Lewinsky. Granted, Nelson Mandela was standing beside him, and Mr. Clinton took only four questions. But even an extra question shouted by an American reporter at the President's retreating back was about gun control, not executive privilege. **********By Friday evening in Cape Town, Mr. Clinton evidently felt relaxed enough to wander within easy questioning range of reporters. ''I like your hat,'' he told one of them. Surprised, she replied, ''Oh, really?'' **********''I noticed it earlier today,'' Mr. Clinton said. No, despite initial reports to the contrary, the hat was not a beret. It was brown, and had a brim. **********At Church, Two Sermons **********This morning, before he left South Africa, Mr. Clinton -- or at least some reporters traveling with him -- received a jolting reminder at a church service in Soweto of the charges back in Washington. **********In the Regina Mundi Catholic Church, a refuge for black activists during the apartheid fight, the pastor performed a Lenten reading that happens to be about an adulterous woman. ''If there is one of you who has not sinned, let him be the first to throw a stone at her,'' he read. **********In his remarks later to the enthusiastic congregation of 1,000, Mr. Clinton did not allude to the reading. Speaking about the hard work ahead for South Africa, he offered a snippet of Scripture that he called ''one of the very most important to me.'' **********''When you are discouraged, when you are frustrated, when you are angry, when you wonder whether you can make the most of your freedom for these children,'' Mr. Clinton said, ''remember what St. Paul said to the Galatians: 'Let us not grow weary in doing good. For in due season, we shall reap if we do not lose heart.' '' **********The Local Delicacy, Worm **********Africa has presented the White House, which has been known to go to great lengths to divert reporters from the President's woes, with plenty of potential diversions. Today, the President's press secretary ate a worm. **********Presented with a local delicacy -- a Mopane worm boiled in salt water and dried in the sun -- Michael D. McCurry popped it into his mouth. Then, at the request of journalists, he ate another one for the cameras. ''Tastes like a dead worm,'' he reported, ''fried in oil.'' **********What Happened at the Gate **********Not that the White House has been happy with all of the coverage of this trip. Administration officials have been aggravated with reporters for focusing on the President's contrite comments about past American actions here. **********Some were furious about television reports that showed Mr. Clinton in Ghana shouting for a crowd to move back after he had approached to shake hands. The pictures, they said, played into the worst stereotypes about Africans and implied that Mr. Clinton was fearful when he was actually trying to protect two women pressed against the steel barricades. **********''The subtheme of that was savagery, out-of-control violence,'' said the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, the President's special envoy to Africa. He said the crowd was actually engaged in a ''love surge.'' **********Ready to Rest **********A further reason that the charges regarding Ms. Lewinsky have slipped into the background may be sheer exhaustion, because of the sleepless schedule set by the White House. The President himself is tired and suffering from a cold, aides said. He seemed to be in a hurry today to get some rest. **********Mr. Clinton did not have much business to do in Botswana, a democracy of 1.5 million people that is so successful, thanks to its diamond and tourism industries, that it no longer merits American development money. The last Peace Corps volunteers left in December. Perhaps as a result, the reception given Mr. Clinton today on the lawn of the state house mingled elements of starchy ceremony with gentle comedy. **********Lieut. Gen. Mompati S. Merafhe, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, introduced three speakers in a row today in stentorian tones. Each time, he began his remarks by running through greetings to precisely the same lengthy list of dignitaries, including the two Presidents as well as ''your excellencies, heads of diplomatic missions and international organizations and your dear spouses'' and ''honorable members of Parliament and your dear spouses.'' The third time through, titters swept the crowd of 2,000 or so. **********When he stepped up to the lectern, Mr. Clinton greeted the people on the podium and ''all the other people who have previously been recognized by a previous speaker.'' The crowd cracked up. **********The President went on to speak for less than six minutes, without ever removing his sunglasses. After he finished, the military band, which had played a Sousa march and the two national anthems, broke into Michael Jackson's ''Thriller.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/03/busin.snippet: Carrefour SA, France's largest food retailer, says it is in talks to buy 50 percent it does not own of Mexican supermarket chain from its partner in venture, Grupo Gigante SA (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/03/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; French Retailer In Mexican Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/03/busin.body_text: **********Carrefour S.A., France's largest food retailer, said today that it was in talks to buy the 50 percent it did not already own of a Mexican supermarket venture. **********Carrefour plans to buy the stake in Grandes Superficies de Mexico from Grupo Gigante S.A., its partner in the venture since its inception in 1993. Gigante is one of Mexico's leading retail companies. **********Carrefour and Gigante first talked about a potential end to their venture in mid-1996, when Carrefour announced plans to open 10 new stores each year in Mexico. **********That meant that Carrefour and Gigante, which operates 189 stores in Mexico, would have to invest about $100 million each to open that many stores in 1997. Gigante, acknowledging that it was unable to keep up such a pace because of cash shortages, let Carrefour open new stores under a fully owned subsidiary. **********Carrefour opened only four new stores last year, but maintains a goal of rapid expansion in 1998. It said that by ending the partnership, it could better focus on its core business and fully owned outlets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/12/world.snippet: Paraguay's governing Colorado Party sweeps presidential elections, defeating coalition of opposition parties to maintain its half-century-long hold on power (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/12/world.main_headline: Ruling Party in Paraguay Maintains Its Long Grip on Presidency
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/12/world.print_headline: Ruling Party in Paraguay Maintains Its Long Grip on Presidency
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/12/world.body_text: **********Overcoming bitter divisions within its own ranks, the Colorado Party appeared today to have swept presidential elections here on Sunday, defeating a coalition of opposition parties to maintain its half-century-long hold on power. **********According to partial results issued early today, Raul Cubas Grau, a 54-year-old engineer and former Government minister, won 53.4 percent of the vote. Domingo Laino, 62, leader of the Alliance parties, won 43.1 percent. Mr. Laino, a career politician and human rights activist, has made two previous unsuccessful bids for the presidency. The results were released by Saka, a respected civic organization. Official tallies will not be available for several days. **********Though public opinion surveys had shown the Colorado and the Alliance parties in a dead tie, the Colorado also appeared to have won majorities in Congress, taking 24 seats in the Senate to the opposition's 21, and 43 of 80 seats in the lower house. **********The Colorado, which has become a potent fusion of political party, patronage machine, cultural tradition and state during its many years in power, had been riven by internal schisms that led to repeated calls for the postponement of elections. The Colorado was also the party of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, whose 35-year dictatorship was the last to end in South America, in 1989. **********Though the Colorado party was euphoric with its election victory,  which supporters began celebrating even before exit polls were announced, party leaders turned their attention today to settling internal differences to produce a government program. **********Uppermost in the public debate was the fate of Lino Oviedo, an Army general who precipitated the political crisis here when he defied a presidential order to retire two years ago in what was generally seen as an attempt to seize power from President Juan Carlos Wasmosy. **********Though Mr. Cubas won the vote, the triumph was General Oviedo's. Mr. Cubas had started as the general's vice presidential running mate in party primaries last September. After he unexpectedly won the primary, General Oviedo was arrested  and sentenced to 10 years for insubordination for his actions two years previously. At rallies and victory celebrations yesterday, supporters called out the general's name, not that of the newly elected President. **********Today, Mr. Cubas, who had campaigned on the slogan, ''Cubas in government, Oviedo in power,'' left his options open when asked about General Oviedo's future. ''We're going to try to see that justice is done with him, and afterwards we'll see what he would like or can do,'' Mr. Cubas said. **********Experts here said Mr. Cubas's most urgent task will be getting Paraguay's financial house in order. Its economy has been stagnant for 15 years, and has shrunk for the last 2 years. The country is a center for arms and drug smuggling and most of the economy is underground. **********It also remains a bastion of old-style Government spending, with the state owning the telecommunications, energy, ports and other key industries. Workers in those sectors represent the support base of the Colorado party. **********As of this afternoon the electoral tribunal had made no further declarations concerning allegations of fraud in early election returns. Official results from the actual vote, however, corroborated a sizable Colorado victory.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/busin.snippet: Report by Cerulli Associates on hedge funds shows that they have soared in popularity this decade; report also highlights growing interest in these funds by institutional investors and offers some insight into characteristics of these highly secre...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/busin.main_headline: Survey Shows Big Growth In Hedge Fund Popularity
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/busin.print_headline: Survey Shows Big Growth In Hedge Fund Popularity
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/busin.body_text: **********A new report on hedge funds, the private investment funds aimed at wealthy individuals and institutions, shows that they have soared in popularity this decade. **********The report by Cerulli Associates, a Boston consulting and research firm, also highlights the growing interest in these funds by institutional investors and offers some insight into the characteristics of these highly secretive funds. The report is expected to be released next week. **********While hard and fast numbers are impossible to come by, Cerulli estimates that total assets under the hedge funds' management, referred to as investors' capital, have increased roughly sixfold since 1990 to some $300 billion at the end of 1997. The figures do not reflect borrowing by the funds, which significantly increases the amount they can invest and the impact that they have on markets. About half of the money invested is from foreign investors, using off-shore funds. The number of funds has more than doubled to roughly 4,500. **********Despite the recent debacle involving Long-Term Capital Management, Cerulli believes investors will continue to clamor to put their money in hedge funds and estimates that assets will continue to climb by at least 15 percent annually over the next 5 to 10 years. ''I still believe the industry is very alive and positioned for growth,'' said Jeff Benjamin, a consultant with Cerulli who was the lead author of the report. **********Once the domain of wealthy investors, hedge funds are now attracting pension funds, endowments, foundations and investment managers who invest in a group of hedge funds. These institutions, which accounted for only 5 percent of the hedge funds' assets five years ago, now account for about 80 percent of assets. The involvement of such big institutions should help push hedge funds, which frequently refuse to let their investors know exactly what they are doing, to disclose more about their strategies and what they own. **********On the basis of a data base of about 1,100 funds, Cerulli also offers a glimpse into the makeup of these funds. While George Soros and Julian H. Robertson Jr. get the lion's share of attention, most of the funds are much smaller entities. About a quarter of them have assets of less than $10 million, and only about 5 percent have assets of more than $500 million. **********''They operate like little entrepreneurs, in one-to-two-person offices,'' Mr. Benjamin said. **********While Cerulli did not examine the strategies of these funds in any detail, the report does show that about 81 percent of the funds use borrowings to leverage their returns. Mr. Benjamin estimates that the majority of funds do not use the extraordinarily high leverage that Long-Term Capital employed, but typically keep their borrowings to less than five times their assets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/15/busin.snippet: Article describes contents of briefcase of author Stephen R Covey; photos (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/15/busin.body_text: **********Stephen R. Covey, author of the best-selling book ''The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People'' (Fireside/Simon & Schuster), keeps spare briefcases under his desk just in case the one he carries falls apart or gets left behind in an airport lounge. As he tours the country promoting his books and lecturing to clients, Dr. Covey carries a heavy load of reading material. A devout Mormon, he is never without a Bible, and he has lately added a Sunday School manual for a course he is teaching on the Old Testament. **********When he emptied his briefcase recently, out came copies of U.S. News & World Report and The Economist; the books ''Leading Minds'' by Howard Gardner, about historical figures like Gandhi and Eleanor Roosevelt, and ''The Power of Character,'' a collection of essays on one of his favorite subjects, and the manuscript of his work-in-progress, ''Living the Seven Habits.'' **********The original book's habit No. 3, ''Put first things first,'' requires him to tote his Franklin Planner, a calendar system that allows Mr. Covey to mark events years ahead. As a father of 9 and grandfather of 28, he consults the planner often. Holidays, school plays, birthdays and graduations are sacred, he says, and he has also penciled in a family trip to Israel for spring 2000. **********When flying, Dr. Covey likes to nap or read without interruption. So he carries a sleeping mask and a baseball cap, to cover his bald head and reduce the odds of being recognized.   JULIA LAWLOR

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/14/busin.main_headline: 3 MacArthur Fellows Are Adding Value to the World of Money
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/14/busin.print_headline: EARNING IT; 3 MacArthur Fellows Are Adding Value to the World of Money
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/14/busin.body_text: **********EVERY year since 1981, it has been a cross between a Pulitzer and a lottery: the fellowship program of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, which awards sizable, no-strings-attached grants to a diverse group of creative thinkers. **********To choose recipients, the foundation uses a confidential group of nominators and a selection committee. Earlier this month, the foundation announced 29 such fellows -- distributing grants, to be paid over five years, that ranged from $220,000 to $375,000, depending on the recipient's age. **********Among the winners were three whose work involves innovative perspectives on money matters: a rancher who has taken steps to preserve his Southwestern way of life; a geographer who studies how labor and political issues help mold a cultural landscape, and an economist who aims to apply the ideals of feminism and the left to calculations of productivity. **********Don Mitchell **********'People's Geography Of the United States' **********''Mansfield Park,'' by Jane Austen, contains a passage of special significance to Don Mitchell, 36, a cultural geographer at Syracuse University who has just won a $235,000 grant for his work on how human activity influences the natural landscape. **********In the book, when Mr. Rushworth vows to improve his home at Southerton Court but wonders who will help, Miss Bertram chimes in: ''Your best friend upon such an occasion would be Mr. Repton, I imagine.'' **********Mr. Repton was Humphrey Repton, a famous English landscape gardener who lived at the turn of the 18th century and laid out the gardens and parks surrounding many great country houses. **********''Repton is a fascinating figure who illustrates how human aesthetic sense and wealth can be part of the process of constructing the space we live in,'' Mr. Mitchell said last week in a phone conversation from Scotland where he was visiting the parents of his wife, Susan Millar, who is also a geography professor. **********Mr. Mitchell's specialty is the influence of political conflict on the landscape. In ''The Lie of the Land: Migrant Workers and the Californian Landscape'' (University of Minnesota Press, 1996), he explored how the endless struggles between big farming interests and migrant workers shaped the state's agricultural landscape. **********''The way the land looks today is the result of these debates and arguments,'' he said in the phone interview. **********As an example, he pointed to the labor camps built for migrant workers in California's central valley after the strikes of 1933 and 1934 because authorities feared a social explosion if the farmers failed to improve conditions for their help. ''You only find decent living and washing facilities where the workers were militant,'' he said. **********As other examples of the way social or political conflicts can shape a landscape, Mr. Mitchell cites Tompkins Square Park in Manhattan's East Village and the People's Park near the campus of the University of California at Berkeley. **********Both parks, he said, are products of long political battles among various interests, including city and university bureaucrats, local residents, environmentalists and advocates of the rights of homeless people. **********In New York, a result has been a space that now serves the needs of local residents, while in Berkeley the university constructed a park where it had originally planned to build dormitories. **********Mr. Mitchell, born in Walnut Creek, Calif., came to Syracuse University in 1997 from the University of Colorado in Boulder, where he had taught since gaining a doctorate in geography from Rutgers University in 1992. **********He said he had no firm idea yet how he would spend his award: ''I'm not an entrepreneur. I like teaching.'' **********But he would like to assemble a team of geographers and historians to write what he calls ''a people's geography of the United States,'' which would chart the development of Americans' ''social relationship with their landscape.''   PAUL LEWIS

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/03/busin.main_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS; How to Sidestep Those 'No Vacancy' Signs
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/03/busin.print_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS; How to Sidestep Those 'No Vacancy' Signs
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/03/busin.body_text: **********THE nation's hottest mutual fund companies have an important message for new investors: Go away. **********Since the start of 1998, an astonishing number of funds -- 18 -- have shut their doors to new investors. That is a record pace, according to Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago. Among the latest to close are Lord Abbett Research Small-Cap, with $677 million in assets; Janus Overseas, $4.2 billion, and Vanguard Primecap, $10.2 billion. **********If the market stays strong, more funds are likely to follow suit, particularly among the ranks of top-performing small-  and mid-cap stock funds that often have trouble putting sudden, large amounts of new cash to work. But would-be investors should take heart: There are often ways to slither into such closed funds, even as companies tighten the loopholes. **********In past years, many closings were announced well in advance -- a sort of last call for outside investors to plunk down their money before the fund rolled up the welcome mat. But fund companies have become less hospitable since the infamous 1991 closing of the Janus Venture fund, which offered new investors a three-month grace period to get in. It was swamped with new money and suffered from the bloat for years. **********By contrast, Vanguard announced the immediate closing of its Primecap fund after the close of business on April 21. What's more, it now limits existing shareholders to a maximum additional investment of $25,000 a year. **********Fund managers often turn off the investment spigot for the best of reasons -- to protect returns for existing investors -- but the announcements often cause new shareholders to rush in before the deadline. **********''Everyone wants what they can't have,'' said Stephen Janachowski, partner in Brouwer & Janachowski, an investment firm in Tiburon, Calif., that specializes in placing client money in no-load mutual funds. ''When a fund closes, there's definitely an allure. For better or for worse, people want to get in.'' **********How does the determined investor storm the ramparts of such a fund? There are several ways. **********Friends and family may provide the easiest point of entry to a closed fund. For example, family members of any Janus fund shareholder are welcomed into any of the firm's funds, including the just-closed Janus Overseas, provided they have the same home address as the shareholder. Similar accommodations may be offered by other fund companies; investors can check the fund prospectus for details. **********Fund companies do not advertise the fact, but it is simple for an investor to transfer shares of his or her stock to family members, or even to strangers. One- or two-page transfer-of-ownership forms, available from fund companies, are used most often to transfer shares within a family --  from a parent to a child, for example, or, for married couples, to change from single to joint ownership. **********Many fund companies once allowed transfers as small as a single share, but no longer. At Vanguard, for example, there is a $3,000 minimum. And if you are the seller who is helping someone in from the cold, remember that the current price for a share of your fund, expressed as net asset value, is only part of the real cost, because of likely capital gains upon which you'll be taxed. **********FOR buyers, the main problem can be finding a shareholder who is willing to sell. That's where the Internet can help. ''On line gets you out there fastest,'' says Daniel Wiener, editor of the Independent Adviser for Vanguard Investors. **********Prospective buyers, for example, can post a bulletin-board message at  Web sites like www.morningstar.net or on Sage Online, available only to subscribers of America Online, offering to pay above net asset value for a particular fund. Sellers can then use transfer-of-ownership forms to make the deal. **********The discount broker Jack White & Company runs a service called Connect that matches mutual fund buyers and sellers. The service was started in 1990 as a way to match buyers and sellers of load funds, allowing buyers to sidestep the sales charge. While Connect is not widely known, it can also help you gain entry to a fund that is technically closed to new money. Buyers pay a flat $200 fee, which is split between the seller and the brokerage firm. **********Here is how the service works: The investor opens a brokerage account at Jack White ($500 minimum in cash or securities), and informs  the broker that he is interested in buying into a specific mutual fund. Then he waits until a seller appears -- and the vigil may be long. **********''There are some funds we've never found a match for,'' warned Peter Mangan, executive vice president at Jack White. ''Others have a long list of interested buyers. We match orders by size, and serve them on a first-come, first-served basis.'' Among the funds in highest demand are T. Rowe Price New Horizons and FPA Capital. **********Another tactic is to hire a financial adviser. When most big funds close the door on new retail investors, they also do so on registered financial advisers, who manage accounts for their individual customers. But with some fund companies, especially smaller ones, there is often some leeway for an investor to wiggle in.  Skyline Asset Management of Chicago, for example, closed its Skyline Special Equities Portfolio to new investors last year. But advisers with a minimum $250,000 investment in the fund as of Jan 30, 1997, are grandfathered in, and may continue to place new clients in the fund, a small-cap value offering with $561 million in assets. **********''It's a courtesy to advisers who believed in us early and put significant assets with us,'' says Michele  Brennan, director of marketing. ''They put a lot of time and effort into choosing funds. When one closes, it can cause a lot of problems for them.'' **********Of course, to pursue this option, investors must be willing to turn over their money to a professional manager. If one is in the market for professional advice anyway, this route makes sense. **********IS it wise to spend the time and effort to seek out such funds? The short answer: It depends. The Sequoia Fund closed to new investors in December 1982. It has returned 19.9 percent annually since then, compared with 15.5 percent for the average large-value peer fund, according to Morningstar. That certainly seems worth the trouble. **********But the desire to gain access to such forbidden fruit is not always well-founded. ''A fund closes because a manager feels the fund's performance is threatened,'' said Susan Belden, editor of No-Load Fund Analyst, an investment guide published in Orinda, Calif. ''There are so many funds out there to choose from,'' she said, that it is hardly worth the time to pursue one that has closed. **********On the other hand, the No-Load Fund Analyst includes three closed funds -- Strong Common Stock, N/I Growth, and Harbor International -- in its ''model portfolio'' of 20 recommended offerings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/06/busin.snippet: Penguin Putnam sends two unknown authors, Iain Pears (An Instance of the Fingerpost) and Janice Graham (Firebird), on tour of cities across the country five months before their books arrive so that they can meet with booksellers, journalists and b...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/06/busin.main_headline: Unknown Authors Beat Their Books to the Stores
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/06/busin.print_headline: Unknown Authors Beat Their Books to the Stores
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/06/busin.body_text: **********Each new book likes to lay claim to at least one iota of originality, but ''it's rare you get a chance to be original'' when marketing it, says Phyllis Grann, chief executive of Pearson P.L.C.'s Penguin Putnam unit. Publishers nevertheless hunt for the new marketing angle that might provide, if not originality, at least an edge. **********And so with the campaigns for two very different books, the company has tried to turn the institution of the author tour on its head. One title is ''An Instance of the Fingerpost,'' a British literary thriller by Iain Pears, just published in the United States under the Riverhead imprint. The other is ''Firebird,'' a romantic first novel by Janice Graham to be published under the Putnam imprint in July. **********In both cases, rather than planning  the authors' bookstore and media appearances around publication date, as is customary, Putnam sent Mr. Pears to 13 cities, and Ms.Graham to 20 cities, five months in advance, when signings and interviews were nowhere on the horizon. But it was at the times when retailers were deciding how many copies of each book they would initially stock. **********In each city, the author met 8 or 10 independent and chain booksellers, journalists and book club leaders over a group meal. Then came the follow-up: from October, when Mr. Pears's tour took place, until publication in March, a different coordinated mailing piece arrived on booksellers' desks every month. A similar campaign will ensue for Ms. Graham, who conducted her meet-and-eat tour in February and early March. **********''It's a clear sign of the lengths to which a publisher now goes to make a case for an unknown author,'' said Jeff Seroy, vice president for publicity at a competitor, the Farrar, Straus unit of Holtzbrinck. **********Other publishers could recall only one other occasion when something similar was tried, albeit on a much smaller scale. In January 1996, Henry Holt, another Holtzbrinck unit, took the English novelist John Lanchester on a six-city ''eating tour'' for ''The Debt to Pleasure'' three months before publication. According to Holt executives, the ploy worked beautifully, capturing attention for this first novel, which went on to sell more than 50,000 copies. **********Now Putnam is gambling that this expensive ''quality time'' and intensive, carefully designed follow-up will influence retailers' orders and ''better position our authors,'' says Marilyn Ducksworth, the senior vice president who devised the plan. **********Although another competitor, Random House, has not tried Ms. Ducksworth's particular gambit, Carol Schneider, a Random House associate publisher said she understood the impulse. ''Everyone is aware of the need to get a buzz started as early as possible,'' Ms. Schneider said, ''partly because the bookstore chains make their buying decisions so early and partly because the marketplace seems so much more competitive.'' **********These days, even presidents of some publishing houses are taking to the road to introduce important titles to accounts, as Morgan Entrekin did last year to introduce booksellers to Charles Frazier's first novel, ''Cold Mountain,'' which became a best seller and literary award winner. **********Publishers reserve such efforts for books with best-seller potential that have usually cost them a large royalty advance. Ms. Graham's book was bought as the first in a three-book, world-rights deal for $1 million, a sum Putnam has already recouped through foreign rights sales. Industry executives say that Putnam paid a substantial six-figure sum for Mr. Pears's book. **********Although Mr. Pears is the author of several mysteries, and ''An Instance of the Fingerpost'' was a best seller after its publication in Britain last September, his is not a household name and British success does not necessarily translate into American sales. Moreover, the shy, scholarly Mr. Pears ''wouldn't fare well on the show circuit,'' his editor, Julie Grau, conceded. The book itself requires a fair degree of intellectual gymnastics, costs $27, and, at 700 pages risks ''landing with a thud'' on reviewers' desks, Ms. Grau said. **********Lise Friedman, the events coordinator at Dutton's bookstore in Los Angeles, recalled eating breakfast with Mr. Pears. ''We ordered 35 copies because we could see how important the book was to the publisher,'' she said. ''We probably would have ordered five without the tour and follow-up.'' **********Another who met with Mr. Pears was Steve Wasserman, editor of The Los Angeles Times Book Review, which featured the book on its front page the week of publication. **********Compared with the introverted Mr. Pears, Ms. Graham is outgoing and vivacious. But she posed a separate set of marketing challenges. ''At publication it would be very difficult to get consumers into the stores for signings with someone they'd never heard of,'' Ms. Ducksworth said. Indeed, an author talking to rows of empty chairs is an embarrassing commonplace event on the signing circuit these days. **********Thus far, the advance introductions seem to be paying off handsomely. Mr. Pears's book made its debut at No. 11 on yesterday's New York Times best-seller list. Costco, the warehouse club chain, has decided to make Ms. Graham's novel the debut selection for its new book club. **********Familiarity may breed contentment. Leslie Graham, head buyer at a San Francisco bookstore called a Clean, Well Lighted Place, met with Ms. Graham (no relation) and recalled, ''Many of us don't normally read romantic fiction; but because we were breakfasting with her, every bookseller had read the entire novel.'' **********That impressed Ms. Graham. ''I was told touring would be incredibly stressful, but I found this tour to be a writer's dream,'' she said. ''What better than actually to come in contact with people who've read your book?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/22/busin.snippet: Dresdner Bank AG, Germany's third-largest bank, and Allianz AG, Europe's second-largest insurer, to form asset management venture in effort to cut costs (S)

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/22/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; German Bank Forming Venture With Insurer
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/22/busin.body_text: **********Dresdner Bank A.G., Germany's third-largest bank, and Allianz A.G., Europe's second-largest insurer, said yesterday that they would form an asset management venture in an effort to cut costs. By combining the maintenance and development of their information technology systems and sharing investment costs abroad, Dresdner and Allianz said they each expected to save at least 10 million marks ($6 million) a year. **********The two German companies already have cross-distribution agreements for life insurance and mortgage products, and they own stakes in one another: Allianz holds 22 percent of Dresdner, which owns 10 percent of Allianz. The venture stops well short of combining the companies' asset management activities, a move some analysts had expected.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/05/techn.snippet: Karen Wickre assesses on-line magazine Word; photo (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/05/techn.print_headline: LIBRARY; Animation And Audio Enliven Text
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/05/techn.body_text: **********WWW.WORD.COM **********THE most self-consciously artistic of the four, Word uses multimedia throughout its extensive pages in sections on topics like Work, Habit, Pay, Machine, Place, Desire. **********Each one is home to personal essays and fiction that marry graphics to text in an art-for-art's-sake style. You can call up short animated clips and audio bits to see what is de rigueur. **********The editor, Marisa Bowe, lends a down-home tone and a rather self-absorbed stream of consciousness to the Word-fest with her letters and diary excerpts. Her predilection toward the personal, a common (detractors would say all too common) characteristic of most Web writing, runs through many of the contributions on Word's crowded pages, which tend to tackle personal ennui more than the latest on Monica Lewinsky or Iraq. **********Part art journal, part Gen-X journal, Word is where text and image meet, commingle and mostly do not know when to stop. **********Like a celebrity autobiography, it appears to cry out for an incisive editor -- and a great deal of indulgence to visit on more than a few occasions. **********But Word does exploit the freshness and innovation found on the Web.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/28/busin.snippet: America Online chooses Real Networks Inc's streaming technology, which delivers audio and video over Internet, as main way for users to play streaming media on new version of its on-line service; Real Networks chairman, Rob Glaser, says his recent...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/28/busin.main_headline: Compressed Data; Real Networks in Pact With America Online
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/28/busin.print_headline: Compressed Data; Real Networks in Pact With America Online
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/28/busin.body_text: **********It seemed a risky step when Rob Glaser, chairman of Real Networks Inc., appeared before the Senate Judiciary Committee in July, joining a chorus of Microsoft bashers. He complained that some of the Microsoft Corporation's latest software refused to work properly with his company's so-called streaming programs, which deliver audio and video over the Internet. **********Mr. Glaser is no garden-variety Microsoft adversary. He is himself a former Microsoft executive, and Microsoft holds a 10 percent stake in his fast-growing Seattle company. **********Yet his public dispute with Microsoft has certainly not hurt Mr. Glaser's business so far. There are no signs of retaliation from his giant neighbor, former employer and investor in Redmond, Wash. Meanwhile, people in increasing numbers -- now more than 30 million -- are using his software. **********And today, Real Networks plans to announce that America Online Inc., the on-line leader, has chosen its technology as the main way for users to play streaming media on the new version of the service, AOL 4.0. **********That word comes as America Online begins its own marketing drive today for AOL 4.0 -- not only an upgrade for its 13 million current subscribers, but also an effort to lure the millions of other people who will be sent America Online disks in the mail. **********The America Online agreement is  a marketing coup for Real Networks. ''It is piggybacking on AOL's powerful distribution network,'' said Jae Kim of Paul Kagan & Associates, a research firm. **********The Internet, in Mr. Glaser's view, is on its way to becoming a mainstream mass medium for receiving the recorded voice and television-style videos. Already, 85 percent of the Web sites that offer streaming media make use of the technology from Real Networks. **********And if anything, he says, the spat with Microsoft over his Senate testimony seemed to help, with the volume of daily downloads from the company's site (www.real.com) rising by nearly 20 percent immediately afterwards. **********''People heard and read about streaming media,'' Mr. Glaser said, ''and wanted to see what all the hubbub was about.''   STEVE LOHR

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/24/busin.snippet: Lazard Freres & Co agrees to settle accusations that in early 1990's it grossly overcharged municipal agency in Los Angeles in bond transaction; details of civil suit settlement is not disclosed; if deal holds, it will mark first time prominent Wa...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/24/busin.main_headline: Lazard Is Said To Settle Suit On Bond Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/24/busin.print_headline: Lazard Is Said To Settle Suit On Bond Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/24/busin.body_text: **********Lazard Freres & Company has agreed to settle accusations that in the early 1990's, the brokerage firm grossly overcharged a municipal agency in Los Angeles in a bond transaction, attorneys close to the case said yesterday. **********Details of the civil suit settlement reached Tuesday were not disclosed, and it still needs the final approval of officials in Los Angeles. **********But if the deal holds, it would mark the first time a prominent Wall Street firm has settled what Federal investigators call ''yield burning.'' **********For the past few years, Federal regulators have been probing allegations of yield burning, said to have occurred in the early 1990's when Wall Street firms sold grossly marked-up Government bonds to public agencies. Earlier this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission brought its first case, against Rauscher Pierce Refsnes, and won its first settlement, against Meridian Securities, now part of the Corestates Financial Corporation. Rauscher, now part of Dain Rauscher, is still fighting the S.E.C. **********Lazard, a premier Wall Street firm, made a name for itself under the leadership of the investment banker Felix Rohatyn, who helped bail New York City out of its financial mess in the 1970's. **********Lawyers for Los Angeles County would only say that discussions were held Tuesday. Lawyers for Lazard refused comment yesterday. **********But lawyers familiar with the agreement said the Los Angeles County officials would take the agreement to a vote on Monday. **********Los Angeles County officials had claimed in their lawsuit that they had lost several million dollars as a result of the price markups, and that the losses further depressed an already ailing public agency, which has been attempting to build a large subway system in Los Angeles. Lawyers for Lazard had argued they had simply made a ''healthy profit'' on the transaction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/18/world.snippet: Cuban schools continue to teach that United States is evil and threatening enemy even though most Cuban families have relatives in US and Government lets dollars sent by relatives or spent by American tourists circulate freely; hearing one message...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/18/world.main_headline: Havana Journal; Divided Loyalties Tugging at Cuba's Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/18/world.print_headline: Havana Journal; Divided Loyalties Tugging at Cuba's Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/18/world.body_text: **********More than eight years after the cold war melted in the rubble of the Berlin wall, the children of Cuba continue to dive under desks in schools all over the island. **********The drills serve to reinforce the most pervasive ideological lesson in Cuba's schools: that the United States is evil and that Cubans must always be ready to defend themselves. **********That old message, fashioned after the Bay of Pigs invasion and the missile crisis in the early 1960's, is fed constantly to children here even when there are no tensions between the United States and any other country, as there are with Iraq now. **********But it is an especially poignant message today when most families in Cuba have relatives in the United States and when, faced with enormous economic difficulties, the Cuban Government has allowed dollars to circulate freely on the island. **********Nowadays, when children come home from the war drills, they slip on shoes bought with dollars sent by their grandparents in Miami or, in some cases, they work odd jobs catering to American tourists to earn dollars themselves. **********In the mornings, William Jose Diaz, a 12-year-old Pioneer who is in eighth grade, swears to defend the Cuban flag against ''los Americanos.'' In the evenings, he rushes to open the doors of tourists cars. He works outside Pain de Paris, an expensive bakery in Vedado. Most nights, he makes at least $2. When someone handed him $1 recently, the boy rushed home to buy bananas for dinner. **********Years ago, it was easier for parents to keep their children blissfully unaware of both their true political feelings and the hardships they went through. But now, with the country's economy in chaos, even young children know that once they turn 7 they lose the right to buy milk. **********They know that the Government issues only two school uniforms during elementary school -- one in kindergarten and the other in fifth grade. And that they are no longer able to buy toys because the Government did away with the yearly ritual of selling toys to children on the 26th of July, the anniversary of the beginning of Fidel Castro's armed uprising in 1953. **********The contradictions of their young lives -- hearing one message in school and another, radically different, at home -- confuses some children. Their teachers want them to fight the Americans; their parents want to join them or, at least, to get some of their dollars. **********''Mom,'' a 7-year-old girl recently asked her mother, ''if William Clinton is so bad, why do we want to go live with him?'' **********Trusting their children and thinking them ready to absorb contrasting messages, many parents openly discuss their beliefs in front of them and even mock the revolutionary slogans and songs they bring home. But then they ask their children to keep it to themselves. **********Some parents fear that their children will be ostracized if their teachers know that they live in a non-revolutionary home. Parents who make a living in what the Government considers illegal activities -- renting a room or selling cigars without a license -- also fear that, if their children talk, the Government may confiscate their goods, fine them or, in some cases, jail them. **********The burden of living in two distinct realities affects some children in psychological and physical ways. Teresita, a 14-year-old ninth grader who lives in Old Havana, said she had never told her best friend that her parents desperately want to leave the country. **********She has also never told anyone that, when the doors are locked, her mother rants against President Castro, blaming his Government for the scarcities in their home. Two months ago, Teresita began to shed the hairs of her arms and legs. The doctors told her that she lacked some essential vitamins in her diet; the mother thinks it is a result of stress. **********A 52-year-old writer who insisted on being identified only by his first name, Angel, cannot stand a song praising the revolution that his 9-year-old daughter has been singing lately. He tells her to stop and his daughter obeys. The mother, worried about her daughter, intercedes. **********''You want your children to be a full member of the family, to know how you feel about everything,'' said the mother, a member of the Communist Party who long ago grew disenchanted with the revolution but outside the home pretends to be as enthusiastic as ever. ''But I worry sometimes how all this is going to affect her and how much contradiction she can really absorb in her young mind.'' **********Yet the girl's mother, in a fit of anger, recently ripped to pieces her red Communist Party ID and threw it out the window. It was her daughter who ran three flights downstairs in a panic to retrieve the picture from the sidewalk so that no one would ever know what her mother had done. **********While Angel helps his daughter with her homework, he systematically deconstructs everything she has been taught at school. She is now learning about Jose Marti, a 19th-century patriot who fought to free Cuba from Spanish colonialism. In Cuba today, Marti is also regarded as the intellectual precursor of the revolution. Angel tells his daughter that Marti would never have supported Mr. Castro's Government. The little girl giggles and rolls her eyes. **********But there is very little that parents  can do to shape their children's education. In a country with no private schools and compulsory education until ninth grade, parents are forced to send their children to state-run schools. They also have no say about the curriculum and, more and more these days, very little about their children's extracurricular activities. **********Some parents try to exert control by taking their children late to school  to avoid the morning ritual where students salute the flag, sing the national anthem and repeat revolutionary slogans. Others are turning to religion, hoping that lessons in catechism will open their children's minds to other points of view. **********The Roman Catholic Church is taking full advantage of it. To make the shift easier for the children, it is incorporating some of the messages children hear in school into Sunday sermons. It is not unusual for priests now to somehow link Cuba's patriots to religion. **********At a recent Mass here, Jaime Cardinal Ortega Alamino drew cheers from his mostly young listeners when he reminded them that the full name of Antonio Maceo, one of Cuba's most revered martyrs, was Antonio de la Caridad, a clear reference to Cuba's patriot saint, Our Lady of Charity. **********Priests in some churches are also enticing children to attend Mass and catechism classes through a system of bonuses and rewards. Children receive bonuses for every Mass and catechism class they attend. Once a week, they can exchange the bonuses for gifts like gum, clothing, pencils and toys, all donated from churches abroad. **********''They get things they want and need and we get an opportunity to show them the church's way,'' said the Rev. Jesus Maria Lusarreta, a priest at La Milagrosa, where more than 400 children attend catechism weekly. **********During his five-day visit to Cuba in January, Pope John Paul II referred to Cuba's youth in two of the four Masses he held. At the first, in Santa Clara, some parents nodded in silence when the Pope said, ''Parents must be acknowledged as the first and foremost educators of their children.'' **********But it is difficult for parents to heed the Pope's words. Elementary school children go to school here from 8 A.M. to 4:20 P.M. On Saturdays, they often return to school for sports or political events. Sometimes they sleep over in the school to await so-called Domingos de Defensa, Sundays of Defense, days in which the children practice what it is like to be under attack and receive their lessons in a bunker. **********Marta Perez Herrera, deputy director of Pepito Tey, an elementary school in Old Havana, said that, beginning in third grade, children are  trained by members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces, who teach them everything from patriotic symbols to military moves. At a recent practice session in a park, uniformed men were training young children to march as one. **********While the children marched, a 16-year-old girl in tight pink shorts stood in a corner a few blocks away eyeing foreigners. The girl, Yanel Noa, said she dropped out of school because she did not want to work in the fields, a requirement for all students in high school. **********Had she continued in school, she would have become a dancer, she said. For now, she lives off the charity of a special friend: a 32-year-old married American man who often travels to Cuba loaded with cash.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/12/busin.snippet: Ordinary investors are fleeing to other currencies as yen falls to new lows against dollar, heightening concern that fundamental shift in sentiment is under way against yen; among factors mentioned by currency traders as immediate causes of yen's ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/12/busin.main_headline: As the Yen Falls, Markets Fear Japanese Savers Will Look Elsewhere
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/12/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; As the Yen Falls, Markets Fear Japanese Savers Will Look Elsewhere
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/12/busin.body_text: **********As the yen falls to new lows against the dollar, ordinary investors are fleeing to other currencies, heightening concern that a fundamental shift in sentiment is under way against the yen. **********Among the factors mentioned by currency traders as immediate causes of the yen's fall are the faltering stock market, doubts about the new Government's commitment to dealing with problems in the banking sector and the possibility that China might devalue its currency. **********Such concerns pushed the yen down to a rate of 147.63 to the dollar in London trading early today, an eight-year low, and to 147.35 in New York later. The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell for a seventh consecutive trading day, closing down 219.40 points, or 1.4 percent, at 15,406.99. In Hong Kong, the main stock index fell 3.6 percent, to 6,779.95. Most other Asian markets were also lower. **********The biggest worry among currency traders is that the yen is reaching a level where Japanese housewives, who control the family purse strings and thus a vast pool of savings, are swapping their yen for dollars, German marks and pounds sterling. **********''That's the main worry for me,'' said Steven Barrow, a currency strategist at Bear Stearns International in London. ''The key here is what's happening to Japanese savings and the fear that ordinary Japanese are looking to send their cash abroad in droves.'' **********The yen's slow erosion over the last few months has contributed to a surge in the Government's already large surplus in the current account, which measures the difference between income from foreign sources and foreign obligations payable, excluding net capital investment. **********Few have been paying attention, however, to the even larger outflows from capital and investment accounts since last spring, a strong indication that Japanese households are beginning to seek higher returns and less volatility in other currencies. **********Mr. Barrow noted that while the current account surplus has been running at one trillion to 1.5 trillion yen a month, according to Government figures issued in July, Japan's capital and investment accounts are running deficits of 2 to 2.5 trillion yen a month, reflecting a net outflow of money. **********''While they're earning more foreign currency from trade, it seems they're only too willing to see even greater sums flowing back out to take advantage of higher yields elsewhere,'' he said. **********One of the biggest factors in the decision last month by Moody's Investors Service, the credit-rating agency, to put Japan's triple-A rating on review for a possible downgrading was concern that the household sector had joined the flight to other currencies. **********''Of particular concern is the potential for volatile portfolio shifts into foreign currency assets by Japanese residents in the post-Big Bang environment,'' Moody's said in its news release, referring to sweeping financial reform measures that went into effect on April 1. **********And traders worry that the Government statistics fail to fully capture the flight from yen to dollars or other currencies. A shift of individual savings out of yen and into other currencies may not show up in the Government numbers because the money may never leave the country. Instead, it may sit in a foreign currency account at the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, Citibank, Sumitomo Bank and other banks that offer such accounts. **********It is difficult to get a read on how big that shift is, however, since most banks refuse to disclose breakdowns of foreign-currency deposit accounts and yen deposit accounts. **********Japanese bank officials contend that April's financial reform measures did not really enhance the ability of Japanese depositors to shift their savings into dollars and other currencies, but they do concede a marked uptick in demand for foreign-currency accounts since then. **********Until this spring, the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi was almost the only Japanese bank to promote foreign-currency accounts aggressively. Katsumi Tsuiji, a Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi spokesman, said the demand for those accounts had accelerated since April, although the increase was somewhat modest because the bank already had a significant part of the foreign-currency deposit market. **********Mr. Tsuiji declined, however, to disclose the amount in foreign-currency deposits, as did a spokesman for Citibank. **********Sumitomo Bank began offering foreign-currency deposit accounts in five different currencies last year, in advance of the financial reforms. A spokesman said that from March until the end of July, the amount of deposits held in foreign-currency accounts had increased 150 percent. **********Few believe the Government is prepared to step in and try to stem that tide. In the past, intervention has taken place only in advance of a significant policy development, and there is no new policy in sight. **********Indeed, various senior officials of the ruling party have expressed dissatisfaction with the yen's direction in recent days, but to no avail. Today, Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa hinted obliquely that the Government might move to prop up the yen, and Eisuke Sakakibara, Vice Minister of Finance for international affairs, suggested that the Group of Seven industrial nations would join in support of the Japanese currency. **********Mr. Miyazawa, noting the negative impact that the slide in the yen is having on other Asian currencies, said, ''I couldn't speak of specific levels, but it is necessary to intervene if the market is not moving in an orderly fashion.'' **********The markets assume that as the yen weakens, Japanese exports become more competitive with those of other Asian countries, and concern is mounting that the Chinese will be forced to devalue their currency, the yuan, in spite of pledges not to do so. **********A report today in The Financial Times said the Chinese Government was selling yen, in a major shift in its foreign-currency portfolio. **********''The next key point is 150'' yen to the dollar, said Hiroshi Sakuma, a foreign-exchange trader at Barclays Bank in Tokyo. ''That's the target point for a lot of investors and speculators because that's the point that many think the Chinese will have to devalue.'' **********Some economists and strategists suggest that allowing the yen to weaken is, in fact, the Government's newest plan to reinvigorate the deteriorating Japanese economy, in spite of the stern tone of disapproval emanating from the Ministry of Finance. **********Economists like Paul Krugman have argued that Japan should deliberately unleash inflation, which would encourage consumers and companies to spend rather than save in fear that their purchasing power would be diluted in the future. **********Craig Chudler, chief strategist at Salomon Smith Barney in Tokyo. said: ''This could be the economic policy they're after. If they allow the currency to depreciate, it should be inflationary by making imports more expensive, and many economists believe Japan desperately needs inflation to get the economy going again.''
