https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/05/techn.snippet: Letter by Jeffrey F Friedman questions whether weekly Circuts section caters to an illiterate subset of Times readers by virtue of type of software (CD-ROM) it reviews
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/05/techn.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********My heart sank again today on opening my Thursday New York Times with its weekly Circuits section. **********We are in the midst of a transformation as great as the use of movable type, and you are reviewing wedding planners (''The Computer as Wedding Consultant,'' Oct. 15). **********Every week it seems the Circuits section reviews some other piece of mass-market software, with never a look at the truly interesting products hitting the market. **********Do you think that the audience for Circuits is an illiterate subset of Times readers, or are you unaware of topics like the rare books being reproduced by Octavo Press, the collection of all of the Callas Juilliard master classes on one CD-ROM, efforts to put all of English poetry on four CD-ROM's, and dozens of other Web-published collections of literature, historical documents and scientific information? **********Instead, you're reviewing 10 zillion recipes no one wants to eat and the wino's guide to great vintages on CD-ROM. Just because software stores carry mostly games and this type of bilge, there is no reason to limit Times coverage in this way. **********Unless, of course, Circuits is nothing more than another way to sell ads. **********JEFFREY F. FRIEDMAN **********New York, Oct. 15, 1998 **********Circuits welcomes letters from readers. Letters must include the writer's name, address and telephone number.  Letters can be sent by E-mail to circuits@nytimes.com or by postal mail to Letters, Circuits, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036-3959. Letters selected may be abridged.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/29/world.snippet: Boris G Fyodorov, chief Russian tax collector and top economic policy maker, is ousted from post, leaving policy in hands of unlikely coalition of Communists, regional leaders and Boris Yeltsin Administraiton holdovers; dismissal follows other res...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/29/world.main_headline: Kremlin Ousts Its Most Outspoken Reformer
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/29/world.print_headline: Kremlin Ousts Its Most Outspoken Reformer
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/29/world.body_text: **********The Russian Government's most outspoken reformer was ousted from his post today, leaving policy in the hands of a unlikely coalition of Communists, regional leaders and Yeltsin holdovers. **********The reformer, Boris G. Fyodorov, who was chief tax collector and top economic policy maker, was removed from both positions, the Kremlin said. **********His dismissal follows other resignations that have made a shambles of Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov's promise to assemble a well-oiled professional team. **********''The formation of the Government is going very badly,'' said Grigory A. Yavlinsky, head of the liberal Yabloko Party who promoted Mr. Primakov for Prime Minister. ''These people cannot work together.'' **********In many respects this does not seem to be the most auspicious moment to discharge an official who symbolizes a tough-minded approach to collecting taxes and has credibility with the West. Russia is desperate for revenue. Tax receipts are plummeting along with the ruble. Recent efforts at privatization have been a bust. The sale of state property has raised 16 percent of the goal for January to August. **********Russia also badly needs a clear economic plan. International Monetary Fund officials who recently met with Mr. Primakov and his aides said they left without a coherent idea of the economic program beyond printing money. **********The Government is not entirely devoid of liberals. Mikhail M. Zadornov, recently appointed as Finance Minister, is a free-market advocate. And Aleksandr Y. Livshits, a former Finance Minister, appears to be angling for a high job. **********But they are just a part of a coalition that includes a Communist central banker, a Communist aide for economic policy and a left-leaning Agriculture Minister. **********Still the story of Mr. Fyodorov is an especially vivid case study in the  Government's inability to chart an economic course, put the right person in charge and stick with the plan and the person. **********Western economists were heartened in May when Mr. Fyodorov was tapped as head of the State Tax Service. A wealthy investment banker and former Finance Minister, Mr. Fyodorov was brash, self-assured and avidly pro-capitalist. **********No sooner was he in office than he instructed his aides to compile a list of the 1,000 richest citizens. He put himself on the list and ordered Government audits of everybody on it. **********He started a campaign to collect back taxes from Gazprom, the natural gas monopoly that has long enjoyed cozy ties at the highest level of the Government. Mr. Fyodorov joined police officers in publicity-making raids of tax deadbeats. **********After the ruble collapsed and Mr. Yeltsin discharged Sergei M. Kiriyenko as Prime Minister last month, Mr. Fyodorov rode out the storm. For a brief moment he emerged as the point man for the Government's effort to pull itself out of the crisis. **********The worldly Mr. Fyodorov met the I.M.F. over the billions of dollars that  Russia hopes to receive in loans.  He also promoted the ''currency board'' approach, in which the ruble  exchange rate would be fixed, pegged to a hard currency like the dollar. Domingo F. Cavallo, the former Argentine Economics Minister who conquered soaring inflation in his country, described Mr. Fyodorov as a veritable soulmate on a visit here. **********But it was downhill from there.  After Mr. Primakov became Prime Minister, he began to reach out to the Communists, and they had a score to settle with Mr. Fyodorov. **********To placate the left, Viktor S. Gerashenko, the former central bank chairman who presided over the ruble devaluation in 1994, was reappointed to the post. Yury Maslyukov, a Communist, was made First Deputy Prime Minister with responsibility for economic matters. **********But the Communists continued to bray for Mr. Fyodorov's head. ''The Communists and the Agrarians said that they could not possibly have him in the Government,'' said Tom Adshead, codirector of research at the United Financial Group, an investment company that Mr. Fyodorov founded. **********Still, Mr. Fyodorov seemed determined to soldier on. When rumors  circulated this month that he was out of a job, he issued a defiant statement insisting that he was not leaving. Even tonight a spokesman for Mr. Fyodorov voiced the hope that he would land another Government job. **********Mr. Fyodorov's is just the latest casualty in the political wars. On Friday Aleksandr Shohkin, a centrist and ally of former Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, resigned after  10 days in office. He said he was leaving to protest the reappointment of Mr. Zadornov, who was Finance Minister when Russia devalued the ruble in August. Mr. Primakov fired back, castigating Mr. Shohkin as unstatesmanlike. **********The pro-reform head of the Securities Commission, Dmitry Vasilev, also quit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/23/world.snippet: People in Kaluga, Russia, were poised for worst when value of ruble fell after Russian Government's sudden shift in economic policy; four days after crisis hit, early signs of panic had subsided; when currency offices reopened on Aug 19, ruble was...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/23/world.main_headline: Ruble Down, Prices Up: A Russian City Flinches
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/23/world.print_headline: Ruble Down, Prices Up: A Russian City Flinches
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/23/world.body_text: **********It has been a long time since anyone in this pretty but forlorn city on the Oka River in central Russia heard any good economic news. Local industrial and agricultural production has dropped 22 percent in the last four years. Doctors, teachers and most factory workers have not been paid in months and their salaries, when they get them, are on the average a paltry $110 a month. **********Bad news, on the other hand, arrives regularly. And this week, while the ruble tumbled, it was coming in by the truckful as shipments of imported goods pulled up to Kaluga's crowded street market with prices on Turkish jackets, Polish boots and Korean blankets already as much as 10 percent higher. **********In the circumstances, what is a Kaluga street vendor to do? **********''We have raised our prices a little, but there is so much competition we can't raise them too high,'' said Oleg, 34, who left his job at a local military plant four years ago to try his hand at selling shoes. ''If you raise them too high,'' added Oleg, who would not give his last name, ''people won't buy because they just don't have the money.'' **********As the value of the ruble fell after the Russian Government's sudden shift in economic policy, people here in Kaluga, 100 miles south of Moscow, were poised for the worst. Many flocked to the local offices of Russia's Government-backed savings bank, some to withdraw funds, others to switch their accounts from rubles to dollars, which, to their relief, they discovered they could do. Still others found refuge in jewelry shops. Only a few managed to exchange rubles to dollars before local currency offices were shut down early Monday afternoon. **********Four days after the crisis hit, early signs of panic had subsided. When the currency offices reopened on Wednesday, the ruble was trading at roughly 7.9 to the dollar, a drop of 15 percent from last week's levels, but less than the 30 percent plunge some had feared. **********Prices were going up, but in a country where everyone, including the the Government and the banks, is running out of money, that does not necessarily mean inflation; it just means people are going to have to do with even less than the little they have. **********''In Russia, it is just a matter of survival,'' said Lena Petrukhina, 27, who sells shoes in a tent next to Oleg. ''Right now, things are very tense. I don't see how it will get any better, if it ever does get better. '' **********For most people in Kaluga, this week has been just another chapter in a crisis that dates from 1991, to the collapse of Communism and of a way of life that was, if nothing else, secure. Since then, they have lived through worse: the soaring inflation of the early 1990's utterly wiped out people's Soviet-era savings. This time, their savings accounts have remained secure -- at least for now. **********What has made this week's events so painful, and so bitter, was the reminder that the seven-year crisis is not over, not by a long shot. A year ago, the Kaluga regional government thought that by 1999 the region would be on the threshold of economic growth. Last week, its expectations, already lowered, were that the economy next year would stay at 1998 levels. By the end of this week, Maksim Akimov, deputy director of the region's economic department, was predicting things would only get worse. **********Mr. Akimov, 28, is not so worried about inflation, or the value of the ruble, which he, like many others, now believes will be held at more or less its current level by the Central Bank. His worries are about the freeze on capital investment, domestic and foreign, that this region of 1.1 million sorely needs to pull itself out of its economic mess. **********''The main problem is how debt crisis affects investments,'' he said. ''The reaction of capital markets will be, 'Better not to even touch Russia,' and who can blame them? If I were an investor, I would take my money and run.'' **********Like so much of Russia, the Kaluga region was heavily dependent on the military-industrial complex,  which here, as elsewhere, has sunk into terminal depression. Factories that once employed 14,000 now employ 4,000 and those that still have jobs have seen paychecks buried in a mountain of backed-up debt, starting with $34 million that the Russian Defense Ministry still owes the region for unpaid orders. **********''I can name you 10 factories in the whole region that pay their workers on time,'' said Yuri Rastorguyev, business manager at the local government newspaper Vest. ''So you can understand, if people haven't gotten their salaries in six months, and they raise prices, where does that leave them? Basically, the system is in total collapse.'' **********Yet people do survive, or as Denis Skyanik, a 25-year-old violinist, noted, ''Nobody is going to die of hunger.'' In his case, he supplements his 300-ruble monthly salary from the Kaluga Orchestra by playing on a street corner, weather permitting. He also plays at parties. ''Russians like to drink and have fun,'' he said. ''So that business will always be there.'' **********To make ends meet, Igor Babichev, editor of a private financial newspaper that by his own admission makes no money, sold shoes, imported Spanish wine and dabbled in real estate before settling on a side business of campaign consulting. ''Everybody here has a hobby,'' he said almost cheerily, ''and no one will tell you how much they earn.'' **********Getting a handle on Kaluga's economy is one the lcoal government's next orders of business. According to Mr. Akimov, traders on the Kaluga street markets will soon be required to install cash registers, to issue sales slips and to pay a single simplified tax. **********''For some people, it will make life easier,'' he said, ''but there is no doubt it will be a lot harder for those who aren't paying any taxes, and they are many.'' **********The drop in the value of the ruble could prove a boon for local industries that produce consumer products, from building materials to food processing, Mr. Akimov said. But such industries account for only 13 percent of local production, another harsh legacy from the Soviet era, and many of those have done little to adapt to a market economy. **********As it is, Kaluga gets 40 percent of its food and 70 percent of its consumer goods from abroad, a fact that many see as an example of their economic humiliation. **********''Before, in Soviet times, people had money, but they had nothing to buy,'' said Aleksei Slabov, a political commentator for the newspaper Vest. ''Now they can buy anything they want, but they have no money. Basically, it comes to the same thing. Nothing has changed.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/23/busin.print_headline: Fed by the Hand That Bites
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/23/busin.body_text: **********FIFTY years ago, Lou Witzeman watched as a neighbor's house in an unincorporated area of Phoenix burned to the ground. A reporter at the time, Mr. Witzeman wrote the story for The Arizona Times, but he found a personal angle. He discovered that he, too, had no fire protection. **********After unsuccessful attempts to find a municipal fire company that could provide service, ''I realized I had to do it myself or forget it,'' he said. While continuing to work as a reporter, he formed a one-engine, four-person fire department that sold subscriptions for service to his neighbors. **********In 1969, his company, Rural-Metro Corporation, began operating an ambulance service separate from the fire company. The service has grown into a company with annual revenues of $476 million and has shifted its focus to developing public-private partnerships. **********In recent years, many more entrepreneurs are finding that  the government is not simply the enemy and has more to offer than red tape. Multimillion dollar companies now do everything from operate prisons to deliver mail to American troops overseas. And small-business owners like Ben Farmer, a respiratory therapist, have taken over less weighty assignments. Mr. Farmer, for example, has been operating the paddle-boat rides for the last five years on the Downtown Canal in Indianapolis, where municipal services have been privatized extensively through competitive bidding. **********''There is a whole market now of firms whose primary business is contract services for the government,'' said Adrian Moore, a director at the Reason Public Policy Institute, a nonprofit center in Los Angeles that focuses on privatization. ''It's been around for a long time in the simplified form of janitorial services or purchasing contracts, but in the last 5 to 10 years it's gotten a lot more complex.'' **********In many cases, what started as small entrepreneurial efforts have grown into huge corporations. The Corrections Corporation of America, started by a business executive, a lawyer and a corrections official in Tennessee, is a good model. **********C.C.A., as it is known, was founded in 1983 in Nashville and got off the ground by operating a juvenile center in Memphis. It is now a business  responsible for 78 prison-related ventures that encompass 63,308 beds,  about 3.5 percent of the more than 1.8 million jail and prison beds in the United States. **********''The private sector looks at the Federal Government as a new market,'' said Robert L. Raasch, the  chairman of the Coalition for Taxpayer Value. ''If the Federal Government looks at ways to save money, it's going to look to private sector bidders or entrepreneurs.'' **********The coalition is spearheading the push for legislation that would result in privatization of what are considered commercial jobs in the Federal Government. The measure would push Federal agencies to decide whether to turn these commercial activities over to private companies. **********Mr. Raasch said that his goal goes beyond privatization. He wants the Federal Government to stop taking business away from the private sector. As examples he used the Veterans Administration's hospitals competing for laundry contracts. **********''Our official position is that anything that is not inherently governmental, like providing advice to the President or national security, should be done privately,'' Mr. Raasch said. **********Organizations representing Federal workers, however, have opposed the measure, saying that it is based on a faulty assumption -- that making a government function private always saves money. **********Opponents note that there are plenty of cases where privatization or extensive outside contracting has led to shoddy work and higher costs. In the private prison industry, cases of brutality, neglect and insufficient services have raised questions about  prisons being a bottom-line business. **********Companies handling government business is not new, but in recent years the relationships have become more entwined. For example, when United States troops went into Bosnia in 1995, a private Houston company did the troops' laundry, provided their meals and helped establish base camps. **********The company, Brown & Root Services, won a five-year contract in 1992 to provide logistical services to forces deployed overseas because the military, after downsizing, began farming out support services. The contract has also taken the company to Somalia, Zaire and Haiti. **********''They've done mail delivery, run shuttle services, provided potable water and taken care of solid waste,'' said Joan Kibler, the public-affairs officer for the Trans-Atlantic Program Center of the Army Corps of Engineers, which ran the service. **********Representatives of small businesses complain that the  the opportunities for them are more limited. ''Larger businesses are more likely to do government contracting,'' said Dan Danner, a vice president of Federal Government relations with the National Federation of Independent Business. For what he called the ''smallest of the small,'' local and Federal governments are still more of a problem -- think regulations and taxes -- than a benefit. **********But Mr. Witzeman, who has retired but remains on the board of Rural-Metro, says that he still sees plenty of room for entrepreneurs to explore business relationships with all government levels. **********''I didn't expect it to be this at the beginning,'' he said, considering how his company has grown into a major corporation by working with local governments. ''But as I saw the trend developing I got less and less surprised. I wish I could be here 50 years from now to see where it's going. I think we'll have a very happy and cost-effective existence.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/31/techn.body_text: **********Crazed turkeys attack, aliens abduct cows, and robots slaughter the townspeople. No, it's not another Year 2000 prediction; it's the next chapter in a different pop culture phenomenon. **********South Park, the politically incorrect, animated cable television show that features a gaggle of foul-mouthed kids, will soon be a shoot-'em-up computer game. **********The game is priced at $39.95 and is due out in January from Acclaim Entertainment Inc. The story line is that a mysterious comet is heading toward South Park, causing all manner of mayhem, like inspiring the poultry to go postal. **********It falls on the townspeople, controlled by the game's player, to save the day. The characters are armed with a variety of weapons and a whole lot of creative compound expletives. **********''It's definitely for mature audiences,'' said Michelle Seebach, a spokeswoman for Acclaim, based in New York. She said there would be warning labels all over the package. ''It's very reflective of the show,'' she added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/14/busin.main_headline: Tenneco Said To Halt Talks On ITT Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/14/busin.print_headline: Tenneco Said To Halt Talks On ITT Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/14/busin.body_text: **********Tenneco Inc., a leading maker of car mufflers and shock absorbers, has halted talks to buy the European brakes division of ITT Industries Inc., a person close to the company said late yesterday. **********Two other bidders, including the German tire maker Continental A.G. and the Ford Motor Company's Visteon Automotive Systems are still interested in the concern and may make an announcement some time this week. **********Late yesterday afternoon, Tenneco's board met to discuss the acquisition of ITT Automotive Europe, which is based in Frankfurt. But after the meeting ended, ''the deal was dead,'' the person close to the company said. Tenneco had been expected to make an announcement early today that it was aquiring the division for around $2 billion, this person said. Several people close to the companies who were reached for comment expressed surprise that the transaction was not completed. **********''There is no deal with ITT,'' Barbara Posner, the vice president of communications for Tenneco, said last night. ''We are not acquiring their brake and chassis unit as rumored.'' She declined to comment further. **********Executives at the companies had been in talks for more than a month. **********ITT Industries, based in White Plains, designs and manufactures automobile products, including brake and chassis systems and electronics for the military market. The European automotive division has been on the auction block since March. It is estimated that the division employs 16,700 people and has annual sales of about $2.2 billion. **********In early June, several companies were said to be interested in buying all or part of the European operations, including Delphi Automotive Systems, Visteon Automotive Systems, Siemens A.G. and Tenneco. Several companies took plant tours to inspect the operations then. **********The unit would have been a significant addition to Tenneco's automotive line. Tenneco entered the auto parts business with the acquisition of Walker Manufacturing, a muffler maker, in 1967. The Tenneco Automotive division, which is based in Lake Forest, Ill., had 1997 sales of $3.2 billion. It not only sells mufflers, but Monroe brand shock absorbers, too.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/24/techn.snippet: Article on advantages and disadvantages of grocery shopping on World Wide Web; drawing (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/24/techn.main_headline: Web Shopping? Not for the Picky
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/24/techn.print_headline: USER'S GUIDE; Web Shopping? Not for the Picky
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/24/techn.body_text: **********ON days when life is under control in our household, either my husband or I will take the baby to shop at a friendly family-owned grocery. We all benefit from such leisurely outings. Clementine always gets a cookie (iced) from the owner, who also remembers to ask us how our older daughters are liking school so far this year. We bask in the amazing luxury of checkout  clerks who cheerfully insist on bagging all the groceries. **********But more often, our household suffers shopping emergencies. Alerted by the baby sitter that the premises are devoid of some absolutely vital item, I will jump up from my desk to rush out to buy, say, diapers. **********In theory, that pattern should make me an ideal candidate for on-line shopping -- at least for mundane, nonperishable provisions. After all, I could conveniently arrange for the delivery of whole truckloads of diapers -- and avoid unduly interrupting my work or appearing in public in my lucky writing sweatpants (paint-spattered on one leg). **********But in reality, I am as reluctant as the next shopper to tinker with my habits. That's because shopping isn't really about shopping. It's about defining ourselves through the acquisition of goods, the items that tell the rest of the world about our wants, needs and tastes, including our willingness to eat generic-brand corn niblets. **********So as I browsed through on-line shopping sites recently, I realized that I would need an incentive to make an actual purchase, some prize or reward. Something like---- hey, a chance to earn free movie tickets. **********I had arrived at www.freeride.com, one of a growing number of marketing Web sites that award prizes to on-line shoppers. The more you buy from Freeride partners like www.netgrocer.com, www.books.com or www.magmall.com, the more points you earn. Freeride users who accumulate enough points can redeem them for a $20 gift certificate at Tower Records (1,000 points), a $5 gift certificate at Red Lobster (275 points) or even a Playboy T-shirt (800 points). Me? I opened a Freeride account with the relatively modest goal of getting a free ticket for ''There's Something About Mary''(460 points) before it left town. **********There is nothing new about Freeride's brand of marketing, of course. Today's on-line techniques borrow heavily from the same marketing efforts that led to the trading stamp craze that began throughout the United States and Canada at the turn of the century, according to David Monot, a historian and author of ''Store Wars: Shopkeepers and the Culture of Mass Marketing 1890-1939'' (University of Toronto Press, 1996).  In those days, the tedium of routine shopping was replaced by the excitement of earning stamps for purchases, then pasting them into books. Full books could be redeemed for prizes. The trading stamp era ended in scandal after some unscrupulous stamp companies didn't pony up the rewards they had promised shoppers. **********But after I called Freeride's founder, Jordan Stanley, I was confident that Freeride was a legitimate business -- and not just because I learned, coincidentally, that Mr. Stanley lived in the same town I do. And not because every time I go to the Little League fields, I practically drive by his house, which would make it really convenient to knock on his door to complain if free movie passes failed to arrive promptly in the mail. No, what endeared Mr. Stanley to me was that he gave me tips for earning Freeride points without actually buying anything. **********How I love to beat the system. By filling out surveys Mr. Stanley told me about, I earned 55 points. By clicking on any of thedesignated shopping sites promoted on the Freeride site, I could earn 5 more points. **********Mr. Stanley even told me how to set up a second Freeride account to get around paying a $4.99 shipping fee that Netgrocer wanted to charge me to get six cases of 48 diapers delivered to my door by Federal Express. ''We just started a new promotion --  it waives the shipping,'' Mr. Stanley said. ''Go to www.att.net, click on the Freeride ad that rotates on that site, then set up a new Freeride account in your husband's name and go to Netgrocer,'' he said. **********But even with the head start given me by Mr. Stanley, I wavered. The real problem was one of choice: On the day I shopped, Netgrocer's best value in the category of diapers was 48 Pampers Baby Dry Stretch Size 4, packaged in a green bag, for $13.49: about what I would pay at the store (once the shipping was waived). But our regular brand is Huggies Ultratrim Girls Size 4, in a pink bag, which would cost $14.58 for the same number of diapers, a dollar more than I would pay at the store. **********I felt paralyzed by indecision: Should I get the price I want or the diapers I want? I phoned Daniel Miller, a British anthropologist, for guidance, and he made me feel much better. ''Shopping isn't just about defining yourself,'' Dr. Miller said. ''It's really about defining your relationships to the people closest to you, in this case, your infant.'' **********Dr. Miller, who spent a year studying the shopping habits of North London families for his new book, ''A Theory of Shopping'' (Cornell University Press), was confident that my crisis was a common case of ''infant obsession.'' That syndrome is characterized by the creation of a largely fictitious list of the infant's likes and dislikes. **********''Parents develop strong views about the particular nature of their infants,'' Dr. Miller explained. ''That comes out with items of clothing -- what an infant supposedly likes to wear or doesn't like to wear -- and with particular foodstuffs.'' In case I might have thought that Dr. Miller was being too critical of obsessed parents, he added, ''It's a way of expressing love.'' **********He was right, of course. Anyone can see that my baby is the sort who likes to wear diapers that come in a pink bag, not green, and it makes more sense to buy them at the store than over the Internet, at least for now. With that problem solved, I logged off, never earning the points I needed for a movie ticket. But we continue to reap the rewards of off-line shopping. Both Clementine and her father came home from the store yesterday licking icing off their fingers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/25/busin.main_headline: Dow Edges Higher as Curtain Drops on a Troubled Week
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/25/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; Dow Edges Higher as Curtain Drops on a Troubled Week
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/25/busin.body_text: **********Stocks seesawed yesterday to finish mixed, closing out the worst week for the market since January on investor concern that corporate profit growth is faltering. **********Gateway led a decline in computer stocks after reporting unexpectedly weak earnings, while Pepsico gained after saying Thursday that it might  spin off some bottling operations. Companies with steady earnings growth like General Electric and Merck helped prop up the market. **********''People seem to be making a bet that the economy is slowing and that growth stocks are safe bets,'' said David Baker, chief of program trading at Deutsche Bank Securities. **********The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.38 points, to 8,937.36, after swinging up as much as 69 points and down 65 points. For the week, the Dow lost 400.61 points, or 4.3 percent, from last Friday's record, though it is still up 13 percent for the year. **********Toward the end of the day, the market retreated on news of gunfire in the Capitol building but recovered somewhat when it became clear that no political figures had been shot. **********The broad market ended lower. Nine stocks fell for every five that rose on the New York Stock Exchange. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.05, to 1,140.80. The Nasdaq composite index fell 4.23, to 1,930.99. **********DuPont, Silicon Graphics, Callaway Golf and Hewlett-Packard  were among the companies that warned this week about deteriorating profits. Quarterly earnings rose just 2.6 percent among the S.& P. companies that reported results, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks earnings. Profits rose 8.1 percent in the corresponding quarter a year ago. **********Earnings concerns are evident in share prices. The S.& P. 500 and Nasdaq both lost 3.9 percent since records reached last Friday, the worst weekly losses since Jan. 5-9. But the S.& P. 500 is up nearly 18 percent for the year, and the Nasdaq is up 23 percent. **********Paul Hennessey, head of trading at Boston Partners Asset Management L.P., said investors are worried that profits will deteriorate in the second half of 1998. ''Maybe we've seen all the gains in stocks for the year,'' said Mr. Hennessey, whose firm oversees $18 billion. **********Gateway, the second-largest direct seller of personal computers, fell 6 1/8, to 52 5/8, after reporting second-quarter earnings of 38 cents, 6 cents below forecasts. Gateway, formerly Gateway 2000, was hurt by weak demand and increased expenses. Its stock was downgraded by Lehman Brothers. **********Silicon Graphics slumped 2 5/8, to 11 1/2, after the maker of computer work stations reported a larger-than-expected fourth-quarter loss on weak sales in Asia. **********Pepsico gained 2 3/16 , to 39 3/4, after the No. 2 soft-drink maker said it might sell a stake in its bottling operations to the public, a move that could help it compete more effectively against Coca-Cola. **********Shares of Oxford Health Plans fell 1 7/16 , to 9 1/8, and touched a 52-week low of 8 3/4 during the day on increased concern about its coming quarterly earnings report. Earlier this week, the once high-flying managed care company told doctors it might have to cut their fees and raise premiums to make money. **********American depository receipts of Nokia soared 9, to 92, after the world's No. 2 mobile phone maker's earnings, helped by strong demand for its networks, beat analyst forecasts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/13/busin.main_headline: I.B.M. and Realnetworks in Joint Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/13/busin.print_headline: I.B.M. and Realnetworks in Joint Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/13/busin.body_text: **********The International Business Machines Corporation and Realnetworks Inc. announced a venture to integrate audio and video into E-mail and other Internet software as I.B.M. tries to gain an edge on the Microsoft Corporation. **********The companies will combine I.B.M.'s Lotus Notes and Domino products, software that allows people in different locations to work together on projects and conduct meetings, with Realnetworks' Realsystem G2 audio and video technology. **********The resulting products are expected to be used by companies for presentations and training. **********Lotus Development, a division of I.B.M., and Microsoft are battling for dominance of sales of software that allows workers to collaborate on line, the so-called groupware market. The International Data Corporation recently reported that Microsoft had overtaken Lotus in sales for the first time in the first half of this year, though Lotus still has more users. It said Microsoft sold 5.6 million packages of its Exchange product while Lotus sold 5.3 million copies of Lotus Notes. **********I.B.M. will include products of Seattle-based Realnetworks in the next version of Lotus Notes 4.6 and Lotus 5 in the first quarter of next year, Lotus said. **********Microsoft, which owns a minority stake in Realnetworks, has no plans to announce a similar agreement, according to Realnetworks. **********Shares of I.B.M. rose $3.5625 to $130.875. Shares in Realnetworks rose $7.875 to $34.875.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/06/busin.snippet: Roundup of questions inspired by recent advertising, marketing and media oddities (M)4
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/06/busin.main_headline: What kind of coupon expiration date is April 31? Also, thanking customers who shop at Target.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/06/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; What kind of coupon expiration date is April 31? Also, thanking customers who shop at Target.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/06/busin.body_text: **********IT'S time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media. ***********Is the ''it'' referred to in advertising for the Gatorade sports beverage sold by the Quaker Oats Company that asks ''Is it in you?'' the same ''it'' referred to by the Seagram Company in advertising for Chivas Regal Scotch whisky that asserts ''You either have it or you don't''? ***********Is it a sly inside joke when a woman in a commercial for the Salon Selectives line of hair care products sold by Unilever proclaims that her appearance gives her ''the power to conquer the world . . . or maybe just Cincinnati'' -- home of the Procter & Gamble Company, the principal rival of Unilever in such competitive fields as hair care? ***********How many history teachers complained to CBS about a promotional commercial for a special program, ''People of the Century,'' in which Dan Rather quoted Theodore Roosevelt's saying as ''Walk softly and carry a big stick''? ***********Wouldn't the corporate world be less insufferable if more executives had a sense of humor like those at the Target retail unit of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, who saluted shoppers' affectionate references to ''Target'' stores by running ads carrying the theme ''C'est Target''? ***********Couldn't someone at the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee have proofread a direct-mail solicitation letter that sought opinions from New Yorkers on significant issues so their responses could be shared with ''Senator Daniel Patrick Moyni''? ***********Was it an accident that one recent morning on the cable television system serving the Upper West Side of Manhattan, three infomericals for compact disk collections were playing in progressive sequence, so that Channel 50 peddled a collection of music from the 1950's, Channel 51 the 1970's and Channel 52 the 1980's? ***********Will the move by the Sunshine Biscuits unit of the Keebler Foods Company to stop embossing the word ''sugar'' on its Vienna Fingers sandwich cookies help millions of noshers turn trim? ***********Did anyone at People magazine notice that an ad on page 91 of the July 6 issue, showing a woman standing behind an X-ray machine to promote the calcium content of the Total line of cereal sold by General Mills, was nearly identical to an ad that appeared 12 pages later, showing a boy standing behind an X-ray machine to promote the calcium content of the Sunny Delight juice drink sold by Procter & Gamble? ***********Now that the Brown & Williamson Tobacco unit of BAT Industries promotes redesigned packages of Kool cigarettes with ads carrying the headline ''NU look,'' will Northwestern University become popular with smokers? ***********When Hoechst A.G. decided to run an ad about its research on Alzheimer's disease, which carried the headline ''Imagine being in your 90's and still able to recite every word Springsteen ever wrote,'' did someone remember to ask Bruce Springsteen about it? ***********Wasn't it a marvelous moment of media convergence coincidence when the Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications sponsored a newspaper ad supplement as part of a trade campaign carrying the theme ''The accent is on content'' just as Steven Brill was bringing out the first issue of Brill's Content magazine? ***********As ''road rage'' continues to concern motorists, is it smart for the General Motors Corporation to promote the Chevrolet Monte Carlo Z34 by showing Taz, the Tasmanian devil cartoon character, in ads carrying the headline ''Inside every Monte Carlo driver is a wild side''? ***********Now that Procter & Gamble has run newspaper ads in which the company acknowledges that Crest Multicare toothpaste does not help reduce and prevent gingivitis and reduce plaque while a competitive brand, Colgate Total, does, can consumers look forward to subsequent ads that are as scrupulously honest about the shortcomings of other products? ***********After The Wall Street Journal advised readers to visit ''the legendary Nat King Cole bar'' at the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan, how many showed up and asked the pianist to play ''Unforgettable''? ***********Are the Marlboro cigarette billboards in the Richmond area carrying the headline ''You get a lot to like'' -- a line from one of the brand's early jingles -- a precursor of a retro-chic national campaign from the Philip Morris Companies that would include a concert tour by Julie London, who sang the jingles? ***********Is a coupon for the Soft Scrub line of cleansers sold by the Clorox Company that expires on ''April 31, 1998'' actually good forever? ***********If George Steinbrenner ever moves the New York Yankees from Yankee Stadium, could disgruntled fans insist that the Lipton Brisk tea commercial set there, which features him along with Babe Ruth, Reggie Jackson, Mickey Mantle and Billy Martin, be re-edited to show the rest of them clobbering him with their bats? ***********Wasn't it classy of the Clairol unit of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company to pay a posthumous tribute to Shirley Polykoff, who created the line ''Does she or doesn't she?'' for Clairol hair dyes? ***********When executives of the U.S. Tobacco unit of the UST Corporation decided to promote Copenhagen Long Cut snuff with the slogan ''It satisfies,'' wasn't there anyone there to remind them that Chesterfield cigarettes were once sold with the slogan ''They satisfy''? ***********Will Marlon Brando, Gary Cooper, Marilyn Monroe and the other Hollywood stars featured in a Levi's jeans campaign carrying the theme ''Our models can beat up their models'' next start to threaten an advertising columnist by warning him, ''You ask a lot of questions for someone from Brooklyn''?

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/27/busin.snippet: Peco Energy Co says it will cut its dividend from 45 cents a share to 25 cents a share effective with first-quarter dividend (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/27/busin.main_headline: PECO ENERGY TO REDUCE DIVIDEND BY 20 CENTS A SHARE
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; PECO ENERGY TO REDUCE DIVIDEND BY 20 CENTS A SHARE
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/27/busin.body_text: **********The Peco Energy Company, a utility that serves Philadelphia and southeastern Pennsylvania, said yesterday that it would cut its dividend from 45 cents a share to 25 cents a share effective with the first-quarter dividend, payable on March 31. Corbin A. McNeill Jr., the chairman and chief executive, said the cut was being made because of an order by the Pennsylvania Public Utilities Commission to open the state to competition. He said the order would lead to a substantial loss in value of Peco's assets because it would not allow the utility to recover the decline in value of its generating plants. Shares of Peco closed yesterday at $22.50, down 18.75 cents.

Both companies are based in Worcester, Mass. Shares of Citizens, a property and casualty insurer, closed at $29.50, up $1.9375. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/04/busin.body_text: **********Chrysler Posts 20% Rise For Sales in October **********Chrysler reported that its car and truck sales rose 20 percent in October compared with figures from the month a year earlier, indicating another strong month for industry vehicle sales despite waning consumer confidence. **********Other auto makers also reported excellent sales. Toyota Motor Sales reported its best-ever October sales for its Toyota and Lexus divisions. And American Honda reported its Honda and Acura sales increased 10 percent for its best October. [Page C3.] **********Stocks Mixed in Sluggish Trading **********Stocks were narrowly mixed in fairly sluggish trading as investors resisted pushing prices, which are now at levels not seen in nearly three months, any higher. The Dow Jones industrial average finished unchanged at 8,706.15, while the S.& P. 500 and Nasdaq declined slightly. [C11.] **********Bond prices rose for the first time in three sessions as the yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.21 percent, from 5.25 percent. [C2.] **********Single Currency Already a Force **********While the advent of the euro, Europe's single currency, is still weeks away, it is already a financial force, both in currency trading and in European capital markets, where it has begun to alter the ways in which governments do business. Market Place. Shares of Equitable, which is controlled by AXA of France, fell $1.125, to $47.75. Signs were posted on doors of ABC's offices and studios in five cities announcing a lockout of workers. [D9.] **********Los Angeles Times to Cut Jobs **********The Los Angeles Times said it would cut its 6,400-person work force by 250 people, or nearly 4 percent. [C6.]

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/24/world.snippet: Pres Clinton says agreement between Sec Gen Kofi Annan and Pres Saddam Hussein will allow United Nations weapons inspectors immediate and unconditional access throughout Iraq if fully implemented; warns details and procedures must be clarified and...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/24/world.main_headline: CLINTON SAYS IRAQ IS PROMISING UNCONDITIONAL ACCESS TO SITES
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/24/world.print_headline: THE DEAL ON IRAQ: THE OVERVIEW; CLINTON SAYS IRAQ IS PROMISING UNCONDITIONAL ACCESS TO SITES
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/24/world.body_text: **********President Clinton said today that Iraq had agreed to allow United Nations weapons inspectors immediate and unconditional access throughout the country, and he began to seek British, French and Russian support for a Security Council resolution that would warn Saddam Hussein of serious consequences if the deal is violated. **********In a news conference today, Mr. Clinton indicated that the agreement, reached by Secretary General Kofi Annan and President Hussein, would restore free and unfettered inspections by the United Nations Special Commission, known by its acronym, Unscom. **********Mr. Clinton said, ''If fully implemented, and that is the big 'if,' this commitment will allow Unscom to fulfill its mission.'' [Transcript, page A10.] **********But Mr. Clinton also warned that the details and procedures of the agreement need to be clarified by Mr. Annan. Most importantly, he said, Iraq's promise would have to be tested before the crisis could be considered over. **********If Iraq reneges this time, Mr. Clinton said, ''everyone would understand that then the United States and hopefully all of our allies would have the unilateral right to respond at a time, place and manner of our own choosing.'' In other words, although he did not say it directly, he made clear that the United States reserved the right to respond with military force. **********Washington's plan is for the American aircraft carriers and troops to stay in the Persian Gulf region, perhaps for months. ''At this point it would be premature to declare peace and start bringing the troops home,'' an official said today. **********Some of the gaps in the agreement, which consists of two pages and an annex, were larger than the President implied, officials said. **********The agreement is vague in several areas, including exactly how presidential sites, properties that Iraq has declared off-limits, would be inspected and what would be the precise  role of Richard Butler, the chairman of the special commission. [Text of the agreement, Page A10.] **********The officials were also unhappy that the agreement commits the weapons inspectors to respect Iraq's national security, sovereignty and dignity. If the clause is linked to the special procedures yet to be established, the Iraqis may refuse inspections on the grounds of ''national security.'' **********A senior American official acknowledged the problem, but said: ''What matters more than the clarifications is the testing. You can't know if the words are a problem until the implementation is tested.'' **********But a senior French official agreed that Mr. Hussein had made ''a clear commitment to grant unconditional access for inspectors, an agreement that is strong and in writing,'' that violation of the agreement ''will mean military action,'' and that ''everyone in the Security Council agrees we don't want to be in a new Iraqi crisis every six weeks.'' **********For the first time since the Persian Gulf war ended in 1991, Mr. Clinton said, Mr. Hussein has acknowledged that he must keep his commitment to allow weapons inspectors working for the special commission into any site without time limits. **********''But the proof is in the testing,'' Mr. Clinton said, and if Mr. Hussein reneges again on his commitments, ''there will be serious consequences.'' **********American officials said that ''serious consequences'' is a diplomatic term that is understood to mean military action. Senior American and Western officials said that a new United Nations Security Council resolution was being drafted, to be put forward this week, that it would codify the agreement and warn Mr. Hussein of the consequences. **********While the Americans do not expect France or Russia to sign a blank check, officials of both countries said today that there is no confusion about the military ramifications of the resolution. **********Mr. Clinton spoke today with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, President Jacques Chirac of France and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to discuss Mr. Annan's agreement and a subsequent resolution. **********''If Saddam were to violate this thing now, even the Russians would not stand up for him,'' a senior Administration official said. **********Another senior official said, ''We've made clear, and the French and Russians accept, that they won't be able to hold back military action, and they recognize that, and they are prepared to join us in issuing a stiff warning to the Iraqis.'' **********French officials said they expected American troops to remain on station in the gulf for two or three months while the agreement is tested, but American officials said they expected to be able to test it ''sooner rather than later.'' **********Mr. Annan is expected to try to clarify these gaps and other points when he briefs the Security Council on Tuesday, upon his return after a stop in Paris. Knowledgeable French officials said tonight that some ''oral agreements'' were clear but were not easily put into writing. **********Among them, an official said, was the French suggestion that the inspection of the eight presidential sites be carried out by a new, sixth subcommittee of Unscom headed by someone appointed by Mr. Annan, but who would report to Mr. Butler, preserving Unscom's authority. **********''It seems what Annan got from Saddam includes this,'' the official said. ''But we want to hear it from him directly.'' **********The agreement now states simply that the special groups will include experts drawn from Unscom and the International Atomic Energy Agency, which inspects nuclear matters, and would include diplomats appointed by the Secretary General. Numbers and procedures are not delineated, and the text speaks only of ''specific, detailed procedures which will be developed given the special nature of the presidential sites.'' **********Mr. Annan went to Baghdad with instructions to delineate presidential residences within the eight presidential sites, which include many other buildings. It was unclear in the text, officials said, if he had succeeded, or whether these ''special procedures'' had to apply to the larger sites and not merely the palaces or residences. **********But the text of the agreement, after standard references to the sovereignty and dignity of Iraq, does say that ''the Government of Iraq reconfirms its acceptance of all relevant resolutions of the Security Council,'' and that ''the Government of Iraq undertakes to accord Unscom and the I.A.E.A. immediate, unconditional and unrestricted access in conformity with the resolutions.'' **********Toward the end, the text also says, as Iraq wanted, that the lifting of tough economic sanctions imposed after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990 is ''obviously of paramount importance.'' **********But criticism of the deal was quick to come, with some Republicans saying Mr. Clinton had abdicated the making of foreign policy to the United Nations and could once again be snookered by Mr. Hussein. **********The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, voiced concern that the Administration had ''subcontracted'' its foreign policy to Mr. Annan. **********''I was worried that this initiative by Annan was going to put the President in a box, and that's exactly what's happened,'' Mr. Lott said. ''He's in a very difficult position now to say, 'Oh, no, this is not good enough.' '' **********The House Speaker, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, said he had no qualms with the United Nations acting as a mediator. ''I think as long as the Secretary General is operating within a framework established by the American President, we have nothing to fear,'' he said. **********With Congress just returning from a 10-day recess, Democrats and Republicans gave guarded comments  before having examined the details of the agreement. ''We can only judge those details when we see them,'' said Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut. **********''I have grave misgivings about this,'' Mr. Lieberman continued.  ''But if in fact there is an agreement in writing that provides for unlimited access by U.N. inspectors to all of the sites in Iraq, then I think it's going to be very hard for us to do anything but to let that agreement go into effect.'' **********Other senators complained that Mr. Hussein had badly outmaneuvered the United States. ''From the outset, the U.S. believed this was a military contest, and Saddam Hussein believed it was a political fight,'' Senator Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat who just returned from a visit to Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Oman, said in an interview. ''In retrospect, he was probably right. It may be incredible for most Americans to accept, but Saddam Hussein actually won the public relations battle.'' **********Senator John F. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat, spoke for many of his colleagues when he listed questions about unresolved issues: **********''What is the long-term policy, and where do we go in the long run here? What will the force deployment level be? How will we guarantee compliance? What happens if he doesn't comply down the road? How do we avoid this ratcheting up on an annual basis and sort of continual tweaking that Saddam Hussein seems to enjoy putting the United States to?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/26/busin.snippet: Edward Wyatt column on faltering of some US companies as result of Asian financial crisis; Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan again warns that bad bank loans could hamper US employment and income; graph (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/26/busin.main_headline: You, Too, Can Own A Bad Bank Loan
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/26/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH; You, Too, Can Own A Bad Bank Loan
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/26/busin.body_text: **********Wall Street saw a darker strain of trickle-down economics last week as several companies with little to no direct exposure to the Asian malaise warned that their businesses were beginning to suffer. **********Exhibit A was Computer Associates. A mere 5 percent of the software company's revenues come from Asian customers. But big multinational clients are not ordering as much of Computer Associates' mainframe software, apparently because the Asian decline is hurting their operations. **********It is not hard to imagine the trend continuing, funneling down to outfits that depend on Computer Associates or on the spending of its employees -- the company that cleans its office buildings, for instance, or the guys that fix the copy machines, or even the corner coffee bar where employees stop in the morning. **********Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, apparently agrees. ''We have yet to see the full effects of the crisis in East Asia on U.S. employment and income,'' he told Congress last week. **********Tucked into Mr. Greenspan's comments was a reprise of a recent Fed warning to banks that the loans they have eagerly been  making to businesses could come back to haunt them if the economy slows, whatever the cause. **********That problem could funnel down, too. Many banks have shrugged off the Fed's warning because they have unloaded one-quarter or more of their lower-quality loans onto ''loan participation funds.'' Generally, those loans are considered below investment grade, meaning that they have been made to companies whose prospects raise doubts about their ability to repay. Moreover, the loans themselves are illiquid and cannot be resold easily. **********But the funds, also known as ''floating rate'' or ''prime rate'' funds, have been snapped up by individuals seeking higher yields than those offered by short-term Treasuries or money market funds. **********Last month, in the biggest such offering in a decade, Van Kampen American Capital raised $1.6 billion for a new fund that invests almost solely in floating-rate loans -- and, moreover, borrows money to leverage its bets. Most of the big mutual fund companies, like Franklin Templeton, Merrill Lynch, Eaton Vance and Aim, offer similar funds; others, including Fidelity Investments, are considering joining the fray. **********The amount of loans held by these funds grew fivefold over the last three years, to $26 billion at the end of the first quarter, according to the Loan Pricing Corporation. Over the same period, the assets in equity mutual funds merely doubled, and the assets in bond funds rose just 25 percent. **********Because the funds are not able to turn the loans quickly into cash when investors want to redeem their shares, most of the funds allow investors to withdraw money only periodically, generally once a quarter. In doing so, the funds offer to repurchase a certain number of shares -- say, 5 percent of the fund's total. If more investors want to cash out, too bad; each shareholder gets only a portion of his shares redeemed. **********Making illiquid loans to companies with questionable ability to repay is not necessarily the best business to be in when a crisis hits. If the Asian malaise spreads more broadly in the United States, many of the loans held by these funds could turn sour. Panicky investors could have a difficult time getting their money out. And the pain will have trickled all the way down.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/29/world.snippet: Indonesia begins withdrawing 1,000 combat troops from East Timor, but critics and residents remain skeptical about the more than 11,000 troops and police officers who will continue to patrol territory; photo; map (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/29/world.main_headline: Indonesia Cuts Timor Force But Islanders Are Skeptical
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/29/world.print_headline: Indonesia Cuts Timor Force But Islanders Are Skeptical
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/29/world.body_text: **********Indonesia began withdrawing 1,000 combat troops from East Timor today, but critics and residents remained skeptical about the more than 11,000 troops and police officers who will continue to patrol the territory. **********The highly publicized withdrawal is an attempt to demonstrate Jakarta's commitment to a peaceful resolution of the fate of the former Portuguese colony, which Indonesia invaded in 1975 and annexed the following year. Since then the disputed territory has been the scene of fierce fighting between security forces and separatists, that along with disease and starvation, has left an estimated 200,000 people dead. During the period since annexation, the Indonesian military has been accused of repeated human rights abuses against the people of East Timor. Today 398 departing troops, representing the elite Special Forces and the Strategic Reserves Command, boarded a vessel docked in the harbor here in the  capital while several hundred residents watched from behind an iron fence. **********''We are removing the combat troops because the number of rebels in the jungle is getting smaller,'' said the military's information officer, Capt. Tri Yoga Budi, who estimated the current number of rebels at fewer than 200. **********While the threat from rebels seeking independence for the area may have been reduced, the decision to pull out the combat troops is believed to have more to do with the talks between Indonesia and Portugal planned for Aug. 4 and 5 in New York under the auspices of the United Nations Secretary General. **********Requests for demilitarization have also come from Jamsheed Marker, the United Nations special envoy for East Timor who recently visited the territory, and from the Roman Catholic Bishop for the territory, Carlos Ximenes Belo, who has repeatedly called for freedom of movement on the island, which is 1,300 miles east of Jakarta. **********''As long as there are soldiers there will be threats,'' said Manuel Carrascalao, a founding member of the broad-based Movement for the Reconciliation and Unity of the East Timorese People, a new group that favors a referndum to determine the future of the territory. **********Residents and activists said that security officials were still stopping East Timorese at random and that the military retained a presence in each of the villages. **********''The soldiers are repressive as usual,'' said Anis Neves of the local Rights Foundation. **********He questioned the need to keep on so many troops if so few rebels remained to pose a threat. **********The official answer is that the troops will be employed in the territory's ''development.'' **********''The soldiers help the farmers with planting, some help teach and others are involved with development activities,'' said Lieut. Col. Saragi, who like many Indonesians uses only one name. **********Mr. Carrascalao said only a complete withdrawal of troops would lead to peace in East Timor, where 85 percent of the population is Catholic. Indonesia is mostly Muslim. **********''The East Timorese don't have a problem with religious differences or with the Indonesians,'' he said. **********Mr. Carrascalao called the troop withdrawal a ''charade'' staged for the outside world at a time when the new administration under President B. J. Habibie has offered the territory a degree of autonomy in return for international recognition of East Timor as a part of Indonesia. **********The United Nations still recognizes Lisbon as the administrative authority over the territory. **********Jakarta's officials have ruled out the possibility of a referendum on East Timor's fate. **********''There have never been any problems solved by referendum,'' said Gov. Abilio Soares of East Timor. **********''We prefer dialogue as a means of bringing about a better future for the people of East Timor,' he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/08/busin.body_text: **********On-line banking functions in some versions of Intuit Inc.'s Quicken personal finance software may stumble when the Year 2000 arrives, but this is no basis for suing Intuit now, said a New York State judge who dismissed three class action lawsuits against the company last week. **********Judge Ira Gammerman's ruling that software companies cannot be sued for Year 2000 problems before actual damage has occurred echoed the conclusions reached in August by a Santa Clara County judge in California in the first such suit against Intuit. Judge Gammerman also said software companies cannot be sued before being given a chance to fix Year 2000 problems. **********Intuit has announced that Quicken upgrades curing the Year 2000 problems will be available without charge by next June. **********The cases have been closely watched by lawyers, who say similar suits could generate $1 trillion in damages and fees if the Year 2000 date transition creates widespread computer problems as has been widely predicted.

Money That Binds, a primer on the euro; after decades of dreams, diplomacy and delays, euro is suddenly real; on Dec 31, 11 European countries are to lock their exchange rates to euro, now worth about $1.17, and ced...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/30/world.main_headline: THE NEW EUROPE: Money That Binds; Primer on Euro: From Birth To Growth as Unifying Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/30/world.print_headline: THE NEW EUROPE: Money That Binds; Primer on Euro: From Birth To Growth as Unifying Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/30/world.body_text: **********This border city in Alsace-Lorraine has been French and then German and now French again, depending on who won the last war. But today it is a placid outpost in a more unified Europe: a home for the European Parliament, and a mecca for cross-border shoppers. **********So it is not surprising that the European single currency, the euro, arrived here well before its official introduction this Friday. At the Cora supermarket, everything from bananas to televisions have been priced in euros (as well as in French francs) for months. At upscale restaurants like Roma, euro-pricing on menus is a fashion must. **********And residents like Michel Raymond, who shops for Grand Marnier in France but for port wine in Germany, are opening euro checking accounts right after the New Year. ''It will make things simpler for everybody,'' said Mr. Raymond, a retired French businessman. ''Some things are cheaper here and others are cheaper on the German side. This will make the payments easier.'' **********After decades of dreams, diplomacy and delays, the euro is suddenly real. On Thursday 11 European countries are to lock their exchange rates to the euro, now worth about $1.17, and cede to the new European Central Bank the power to set interest rates and monetary policy. **********On the street it may look as if little has happened. But currency conversion represents the most important step in Europe's long quest for political unity. In getting to this point, the 11 euro nations for the first time have adopted a common economic policy that has reined in public spending, reduced debt and tamed inflation. **********This achievement has seriously altered the political debate; indeed, governments in Germany, France and Italy have fallen in large part because of the spending cutbacks required to create the euro. Business strategy has been transformed, and more residents and visitors are thinking of Europe as a single place instead of a jigsaw of nationalities and a hodge-podge of currencies and laws. **********Today's German marks, French francs, Italian lire and eight other currencies may be used for three and a half years more. (Euro notes and coins arrive on Jan. 1, 2002.) Local currencies are to be removed from circulation by July 1, 2002. **********European stock and bond trades will be denominated entirely in euros, starting on Monday. All transactions between banks, which is frequently how Europeans pay their bills, will be in euros, even within the same country. Bank customers can write checks in euros, and many credit-card purchases will be calculated in euros. Euro travelers checks are coming. **********Though Americans are largely bystanders, the euro will affect them, too. Travelers will be spared the necessity of changing dollars into different currencies, and currency risks will be reduced for money managers. That alone is expected to yield substantial savings. **********While the euro was once viewed as a weakling because of doubts that Spain and Italy would have the discipline to get into fiscal trim, all signs now suggest that the euro will start off strong and may come to rival the dollar as a reserve currency held by central banks around the world. If that happens, economists say, it could push up American interest rates slightly. It could also make European goods more expensive for Americans. **********The new currency may also be a means for Europe to compete more strongly with the United States: The move to a unified market and a single currency has forced the transformation of Europe's biggest industries. Many are merging with rivals to cut costs; others are selling businesses to refocus on their strengths. And quite a few, like DaimlerChrysler A.G., have been doing both. **********One major country that is not party to the euro is Britain, which has always viewed itself as separate from Europe. It is taking a wait-and-see attitude because of public fears that using the euro would erode Britain's independence. **********British businesses definitely favor the currency, however, and worry that they will suffer a disadvantage by holding on to the pound. **********But Prime Minister Tony Blair insists that Britain will consider using the euro after the next round of national elections, which are likely by 2002, and only after a national referendum. **********The Origins **********Postwar Dreams, Post-Cold-War Fact **********Why did the 11 other nations go to all the trouble? **********The idea of a single currency dates back to the 1950's, when postwar diplomats like Jean Monnet, president of a precursor to the European Union, sketched out sweeping visions for economic and political unification. The idea was that the more each nation relied on the others for economic and political security, the more reluctant they would be to send their armies into battle. **********But the real impetus came with the fall of the Berlin wall in 1989. The prospect of a reunited German powerhouse alarmed many Western European governments, and Francois Mitterrand, then the President of France, pressed his German counterpart, Helmut Kohl: France would support the reunification if Mr. Kohl would commit his Government to replacing the mark with a single currency administered by an independent central bank. **********''After reunification, a lot of the neighbors around Germany were afraid that it might become politically and economically too strong,'' said Peter Wolf-Koppen, who oversees euro projects at Commerzbank in Frankfurt. ''They first tried to make a political union, but they failed. A monetary union was the best they could do.'' **********Mr. Kohl quickly became the euro's strongest champion, driven in part by memories of World War II. **********''I have often been told that the euro was a technocratic idea, invented by finance ministers,'' remarked Christian Noyer, vice president of the European Central Bank. ''That is clearly not the case. They had the simple idea that the money, the currency that people use every day, was a way to foster integration.'' **********Two years after the fall of the wall, in the Dutch city of Maastricht, European leaders reached a basic accord, with a strongly German imprint. Countries would have to meet strict limits on deficits and would have to bring inflation down to Germany's level, about 3 percent. **********But the Bundesbank, the influential German central bank, would take a back seat to an independent European Central Bank, which would focus on fighting inflation. **********The euro's proponents argue that it will make Europe more efficient and competitive because pricing differences will stand out. Trade will be enhanced because foreign-exchange risks will be minimal. (Europe abolished most tariffs and other trade restrictions six years ago.) **********But more important, supporters predict that the greater attention to prices will force cost-cutting by manufacturers. And while that may contribute to Europe's high unemployment, it may also initiate much-needed changes in costly regulations that hinder competitiveness today. **********''This can work like a reform program for Europe, and be very good for the competitiveness of Europe,'' said Jurgen Stark, vice president of the Bundesbank. ''On the one hand it is a great political challenge. But on the other it is a great opportunity for Europe to combine sound monetary and fiscal policy with more flexibility.'' **********The Change-Over **********Banks and Stores Do the Arithmetic **********In many respects, the euro will seem at first like a phantom currency because notes and coins will not circulate until Jan. 1, 2002, to give buyers and merchants time to adjust. And while euros will be usable beginning Monday in the ether of electronic payments, nobody can be forced to accept them before 2002. **********Many bankers argue that the long transition period makes the process needlessly costly and complicated. Instead of just converting to a new currency, banks have to change first to a system of dual currencies that will become obsolete in 2002. **********Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest bank, says it will spend more than $200 million on the conversion during the next four years. ''The dual currency makes it much more expensive,'' said Peter Wolf-Koppen, at Commerzbank in Frankfurt. **********But merchants are reaching very different conclusions about how soon to price goods in euros. **********In France, supermarkets like Le Clerc and Caro are already posting all prices in euros. In Germany, where many are still hostile to trading in their solid marks for untested euros, big retailers are moving more slowly; most plan to post dual prices on some items right away, but they are reluctant to make a full conversion in 1999. **********For the moment, managers at the Cora hypermarket simply steer attention away from the euro price. A big sign promoting a widescreen television announces a price in French francs: FF 7,990.00. The euro price -- e 1,206.97 -- is printed in only small letters on the price tag. **********In part because of marketing uncertainties, some consumer-product companies are delaying the switch. **********''We're going to let someone else find out the answers on how to teach consumers about the euro,'' said Peter Csandi, a spokesman for Adidas, the sportswear company. ''We don't intend to be pioneers.'' **********But a growing number of Europe's biggest industrial companies are converting rapidly, convinced they can quickly recoup the cost by saving money on foreign-exchange dealings. DaimlerChrysler and Siemens plan to convert all their business systems early next year. They are also pressing suppliers to bill in euros, which is likely to speed up acceptance. **********The Future **********Not by Euros Alone Do Economies Live **********The euro has confounded naysayers ever since European leaders laid down the timetable in the early 1990's. As recently as four years ago, many were convinced that few countries would overcome national pride to abandon their currencies. **********When it became increasingly clear that monetary union would occur, most assumed that it would be limited to about eight ''core'' countries, led by Germany and France. But Europe's poorer and shakier countries -- Italy, Spain and Portugal -- started clamoring to join the club. And to the amazement of many, they brought their budget deficits and inflation rates down enough. **********But there could be some nasty surprises. Economic growth is uneven. There are inflation risks in fast-growing countries like Spain and Ireland; at the same time, growth is slowing in countries like Germany and France, where unemployment rates remain above 10 percent. **********The challenge for the new central bank is to set uniform interest rates that will foster growth everywhere. **********The political landscape has also changed profoundly. Some leading politicians who pushed for the euro are out of power now, casualties of voters' objections to relentless budget cutting, especially on social programs. New governments in Germany, Italy and France are not so beholden to the rules set out to create the euro. **********After Mr. Kohl and his center-right coalition were defeated last September by Gerhard Schroder and the left-of-center Social Democratic Party, the new Finance Minister, Oskar Lafontaine, quickly became a vocal critic of both the Bundesbank and the European Central Bank. He argued that tight-money policies brought about by the euro were the real reason that European unemployment mostly remains high. **********Under the Maastricht Treaty, political leaders have no authority over the European Central Bank, which is led by a former Dutch central banker, Wim Duisenberg. And a separate treaty calls for huge fines on governments whose spending generates deficits of more than 3 percent of gross domestic product. The rules also say that once a nation enters the euro union, it cannot withdraw. **********In practice, many experts are skeptical that European leaders would impose such punishments. **********''Countries have to realize that the misbehaviors of one country can damage all the others,'' said Mr. Stark, the Bundesbank official. ''If a big country runs a high deficit, it is pretty clear the European Central Bank will have to react with a rate increase.''
