https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/27/busin.main_headline: Milken Settles S.E.C. Complaint for $47 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/27/busin.print_headline: Milken Settles S.E.C. Complaint for $47 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/27/busin.body_text: **********Michael R. Milken, the financier who used a huge junk bond empire in the 1980's to make or break a swath of big American companies, agreed yesterday to pay $47 million to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission complaint that he had violated a 1991 order barring him from the securities industry for life. **********At the same time, in an apparently related deal, Federal prosecutors said they would not recommend new criminal charges against Mr. Milken for violating terms of his probation stemming from a criminal securities fraud conviction in 1990. **********In agreeing to settle with the S.E.C., Mr. Milken neither admitted nor denied its allegations that he had violated the 1991 order by offering advice to such financiers as Rupert Murdoch and Ronald O. Perelman on several transactions in recent years. And, with a net worth estimated to be in the hundreds of millions of dollars, Mr. Milken can easily pay $47 million, a sum that represents fees received for his consulting work. **********During the years that Mr. Milken was advising Mr. Perelman and Mr. Murdoch, he was also on probation as part of the sentence for his conviction on the criminal charges. Prosecutors were investigating whether Mr. Milken had violated his probation after his release from prison in 1993 by continuing to provide securities advice, and as a result they successfully sought to extend his probation on several occasions. **********Prosecutors' continuing investigation into his activities threatened to put Mr. Milken back in prison for violation of probation. That probation will now apparently end. But he would still be unable to return to the securities industry. **********The settlement of the S.E.C. complaint was agreed on by lawyers for the S.E.C. and for Mr. Milken before Judge Milton Pollack in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday morning. **********Then, late yesterday, Mark F. Pomerantz, chief of the criminal division at the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, sent a letter to Judge Kimba M. Wood, who sentenced Mr. Milken in 1990 and has been overseeing his probation, saying that his office had decided not to recommend proceedings against Mr. Milken for violation of probation. The letter said that the United States Attorney's office ''concluded that the initiation of probation violation proceedings in this matter is not warranted by the existing evidence and by the law.'' **********Judge Wood sentenced Mr. Milken to 10 years in prison after he pleaded guilty to six counts of securities fraud, involving manipulation of the prices of securities and other illegal financial practices. He committed those crimes during his years at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a securities firm that Mr. Milken built into the dominant force in the junk bond market but that went bankrupt in 1990. Mr. Milken, however, served 22 months of that sentence, after Judge Wood reduced it. **********But Mr. Milken has remained on probation, and the United States Attorney's requests for several extensions of that probation over the last few years had raised the prospect that the Government might seek to return Mr. Milken to jail. The 51-year-old financier, who is suffering from prostate cancer that his advisers said yesterday was in remission, particularly feared returning to jail, associates say. **********Judge Wood's clerks forwarded copies of Mr. Pomerantz's letter to reporters, but did not say whether the judge might take further action. Stephen E. Kaufman, one of Mr. Milken's lawyers, declined to comment on the letter. **********The S.E.C. said in its complaint that Mr. Milken, and his company, the MC Group, had in two cases ''introduced companies, suggested business arrangements between them, participated in negotiations regarding the structure of such transactions, and securities issued in connection with these transactions, and received transaction-based compensation of $42 million.'' Such actions, the S.E.C. said, breached the commission's 1991 order barring Mr. Milken from associating with a securities broker. **********In a statement, Mr. Milken's lawyer, Richard V. Sandler, said Mr. Milken ''had taken legal advice before engaging in any consulting activities.'' **********''Mr. Milken,'' he added, ''is battling prostate cancer and has decided not to contest the S.E.C. allegations to determine who is right and who is wrong. Therefore, without admitting such allegations, or denying them, and without any findings of wrongdoing, Mr. Milken is returning the fees that he received with respect to the two transactions that are the subject of this action.'' **********The $47 million will go to the Treasury. It is not a fine but represents fees that Mr. Milken and his company earned for two transactions: In the first, they received $27 million for advising Bert C. Roberts Jr., the chairman of the MCI Communications Corporation, and Mr. Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, on a 1995 accord in which MCI agreed to invest $1 billion to $2 billion in the News Corporation. In the second, they were paid $15 million for advising Ronald O. Perelman, who controls Revlon Inc. and other businesses, on his acquisition of New World Communications, a television station and production company, from the News Corporation in 1996. The other $5 million  represents interest on these fees. **********Such fees are high, but not atypical, on Wall Street, where investment banks are paid for their advice calculated as small percentages of multibillion-dollar deals. Mr. Milken and his MC Group were ''integrally involved in the transaction between MCI and News Corp.,'' the S.E.C. said in its complaint. **********Though Mr. Milken can easily pay the $47 million, Dennis J. Block, a senior partner at the law firm of Weil, Gotschal & Manges, who was not involved in the case, said, ''It's quite an extraordinary amount of money and probably reflects his concern that he might have had his probation revoked.'' **********The regulatory action against Mr. Milken and his company made no mention of consulting by Mr. Milken regarding a third corporate deal that had attracted the attention of Government investigators in recent years: Time Warner's acquisition of Turner Broadcasting for $7.5 billion in 1996. There was apparently insufficient evidence to back S.E.C. allegations about this deal, in which Mr. Milken received a $50 million fee. **********''This is a guy who has been the subject of Government investigation for years,'' said Jeffrey B. Sklaroff, a partner at Greenberg, Traurig, a New York law firm, who was not involved in the case. ''At a certain point the Government believes that it has gotten more than a pound of flesh. Milken's also served jail time previously. It's hard for the Government to maintain an aggressive stance. At a certain point, human interest flags and you move on.'' **********Some of these sentiments were echoed yesterday by people close to the Government investigation. They indicated that they were wary of a courtroom fight with an uncertain outcome, particularly when Mr. Milken suffered from cancer. **********Government officials defended the settlement, pointing out that most complex securities cases end in negotiated settlements. ''This was a tough case; we believe that the settlement is a fair outcome for the Government,'' said William McLucas, the head of the S.E.C.'s enforcement division.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/22/busin.snippet: United States trade deficit unexpectedly narrows in November, to $8.037 billion from revised $9.091 billion in October, as both exports and imports decline; despite declines in deficits with Japan and China, gaps with those countries over first 11...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/22/busin.main_headline: U.S. Trade Deficit Narrowed In November in Surprise Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/22/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; U.S. Trade Deficit Narrowed In November in Surprise Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/22/busin.body_text: **********The United States trade deficit unexpectedly narrowed in November, though analysts said it was likely to be only a brief respite before the Asian economic crisis leads to larger deficits this year. **********The trade deficit shrank to $8.037 billion in November from a revised $9.091 billion in October, as both exports and imports declined, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Many economists had expected the deficit to rise. **********The deficits with China, Japan and most Pacific Rim countries also narrowed in November, countering expectations that currency devaluations in Asia would increase United States imports by reducing the cost of foreign-made goods. **********Still, despite the declines in the deficits with Japan and China in November, the gaps with those countries over the first 11 months of last year were up 16.7 percent and 24 percent, respectively. **********And today, the Japanese Government reported further indications of the trend toward a rising imbalance in trade between the United States and that country. Japan's merchandise trade surplus rose in December by 40.9 percent from a year earlier, and the surplus with the United States rose by 25.4 percent. **********For all of 1997, Japan's overall trade surplus expanded by 48.5 percent, the first annual rise in five years, the Ministry of Finance reported. **********In a separate report yesterday, the Federal Reserve said that economic ripples from the Asian turmoil were felt in most regions of the United States in recent weeks. ''Manufacturers and agricultural firms report weaker exports to Asia, and there was some evidence of increased competition from Asian products in U.S. markets,'' the Fed said in its regional survey, known as the beige book. **********That has helped keep inflation absent from the American economy, the Fed said, noting that ''prices were generally flat'' in the period covered by the survey. **********Analysts said the narrowing of the United States trade gap could be accounted for in part by problems with the way the Commerce Department computes the figures. **********''We have been arguing for some time that the Government's seasonal adjustment procedure for the fourth quarter produces a narrowing of the deficit,'' said Anne Mills, an economist at Lehman Brothers in New York. ''Today's numbers are a reflection of the seasonal adjustment, not the underlying data.'' **********Lee Price, Acting Under Secretary for Economic Affairs, acknowledged that there were problems with the adjustment process, but added that the pattern did not show up consistently in every trade category and that Government economists were reluctant to force a general adjustment on the numbers only to try to correct the trend. **********The trade figures could give a lift to the fourth quarter's gross domestic product, which economists had been forecasting to grow at about a 3.5 percent annual rate. **********Economists said that the trade numbers for January or February should better reflect the actual trade situation and begin to show the effects of the Asian crisis. ''It's the calm before the storm,'' Ms. Mills said. **********The trade deficit for all of 1997 is on target to total $111 billion, matching last year's total, which was the largest since a $115 billion deficit in 1988. **********''There isn't any doubt in anyone's mind where the trend is going on trade,'' said James Glassman, chief domestic economist at Chase Securities in New York. ''It would defy logic for it to go the other way.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/27/world.snippet: Informal Government proposal for severing Canada's ties to Queen Elizabeth II is widely assailed, and its backers are now backpeddling (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/27/world.main_headline: Canadians Riled at Plan To Cut Ties To Queen
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/27/world.print_headline: Canadians Riled at Plan To Cut Ties To Queen
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/27/world.body_text: **********Canada has its Queen and, as some politicians are discovering, God save those who would try to sever the country from its monarch. **********Senior advisers to Prime Minister Jean Chretien, along with some unidentified leaders of the governing Liberal Party, are still smarting from the sharp response they received to a recent informal proposal to mark Canada's entrance into the new millennium by finally cutting all the country's ties to Her Majesty. **********After the unidentified leaders passed along the idea to a friendly reporter and the trial balloon was sent up in a prominent article, crowds of loyalists came out to shoot it down. **********''A bauble on the national Christmas tree that these people think they can pluck off in 1999,'' was what John L. Aimers thought of the Liberal idea. Mr. Aimers had been through this fight before, which was why he helped found the Monarchist League of Canada, based in Toronto, more than 20 years ago. **********''This is a naive, fanciful project of some gutless wonders in Ottawa who don't want to attach their names to this,'' Mr. Aimers said. ''They should be more careful of what they let slip.'' **********There was a significant amount of backpedaling in the halls of Parliament after the first reports of the dump-the-Queen plan were released. Although the Prime Minister's office had made it clear that Mr. Chretien was anxious to hear what Canadians thought of the idea, in a year-end interview with the Canadian news magazine Maclean's, Mr. Chretien said that abolishing the monarchy was not a priority. **********''I have enough problems with the separatists in Quebec,'' Mr. Chretien said, ''I don't want to have problems with the monarchists in Ontario.'' **********And Sophie Galarneau, a spokeswoman for Mr. Chretien, said, ''While it's certainly true that the Prime Minister would like to know what Canadians think about it, this is not a Government project at this point.'' Although some officials, like Industry Minister John Manley, have openly espoused a republican Canada, Deputy Prime Minister Herb Gray went on television to play down the idea. The Premier of the province of Prince Edward Island then said he would be the first to cast the one veto it would take from the provinces to block any such amendment. **********Columnists at some of Canada's largest newspapers gleefully took shots at the plan. Dan Gardner, writing in the Ottawa Citizen -- the newspaper that broke the story -- noted that the plan was billed as a visionary project to mark the year 2000. But, he wondered, ''Can't we just build a giant dome or something?'' **********In The Montreal Gazette, Tommy Schnurmacher, a columnist, called the idea of throwing out the Queen ''impertinent.'' **********Canada's relationship to the Queen is a complex one, similar to that of Australia, another member of the British Commonwealth seeking to come out from Britain's shadow. For several years, the Australians have engaged in a debate over whether to remove the Queen as head of state. **********Feelings toward the royal family are warmer in Canada than they are in Australia, said Mr. Aimers of the Monarchist League, at least in English-speaking Canada. While most Quebecers are cool to the crown, royal visits to the Maple Kingdom, as the Monarchists call it, almost always attract big crowds, and members of the royal family often vacation in Canada. **********While vowing allegiance to the Queen is considered by some Canadians to show a lack of independence, Mr. Aimers points out that under the Canadian Constitution, Queen Elizabeth is actually Canada's own monarch, quite separate and apart from being Queen of England or Queen of Australia, titles she also holds. And the Queen's role as head of state, he adds, ''is first and foremost the most significant distinction between Canada and the United States.'' **********On its Internet site (www.monarchist.ca), the Monarchist League sells stickers with pictures of the Queen that it suggests can be attached to letters to the Government to show support for the Maple Crown, and bumper stickers that say ''My Canada Includes the Monarchy.'' **********The Canadian writer Robertson Davies once called the crown ''the consecrated spirit of Canada.'' Despite changing times, monarchists want the Queen's profile to remain on all Canadian coins, and they insist the Queen is still a central figure in Canadian life. **********That much was proved quite smartly, Mr. Aimers said, when the country's immigration service retained the mention of the sovereign in the Canadian oath of citizenship that was recently updated. The oath, repeated by all immigrants who become Canadian citizens, still says, ''I pledge my loyalty and allegiance to Canada and Her Majesty, Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Canada.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/21/busin.snippet: Stock prices of major international drug companies soared Tuesday in anticipation of a new round of takeover activity after SmithKline Beecham PLC said it was discussing a possible merger with American Home Products Corp..The combination, if compl...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/21/busin.main_headline: SmithKline and American Home Discuss Creating an Industry Giant : Merger Talk Propels Drug Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/21/busin.print_headline: SmithKline and American Home Discuss Creating an Industry Giant : Merger Talk Propels Drug Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/21/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices of major international drug companies soared Tuesday in anticipation of a new round of takeover activity after SmithKline Beecham PLC said it was discussing a possible merger with American Home Products Corp. **********The combination, if completed, would create the world's largest pharmaceutical company and underscore the intensifying pressure for economies of scale in the industry. **********In 1996, the two companies sold a combined $14.4 billion of prescription drugs, compared with $13.5 billion for the market leader, Glaxo Wellcome PLC, itself the product of a 1995 acquisition by Glaxo PLC. Just behind are Merck & Co. of the United States and Novartis AG of Switzerland, formed by the merger in 1996 of Sandoz AG and Ciba-Geigy AG. **********The announcement will "make everyone think twice" about possible mergers in the drugs industry, said Stephen Putnam of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson. **********Globalization has been a leading factor in a surge of merger activity, which soared 50 percent in 1997 to a record $1 trillion in the United States alone, and the trend is felt acutely in the pharmaceutical business. **********With the cost of developing a prescription drug escalating into the hundreds of millions of dollars, companies are eager to combine their research-and-development efforts and sales activities to cut costs and increase the prospects of discovering a top-selling drug. Novartis executives said the company was on track to save 2 billion Swiss francs ($1.33 billion) by the end of 1999 **********Mr. Putnam said the savings for SmithKline and American Home Products would be particularly large because they operated in similar product lines but had little overlap in specific drug categories. He estimated the potential savings at as much as £1 billion ($1.64 billion) a year, or 10 percent of costs in common business areas. **********SmithKline shares rose as high as 815 pence on the news before retreating to close at 748, up 5. In late trading in New York, American Home Products was up $11.3125, at $92 **********[At that price, American Home would be worth about $52 billion, The Associated Press reported, which would make such a merger the largest one yet, eclipsing the $37 billion in stock that WorldCom Inc. is paying for MCI Communications Corp.] **********The London Stock Exchange prompted SmithKline to make the announcement after its stock rose more than 20 percent, from 626 pence Jan. 12. **********Although American Home is slightly larger, with an estimated 3.5 percent of the global market for prescription drugs against 2.8 percent for SmithKline, analysts said it was more vulnerable because its sales growth was slower and the company had fewer drugs under development. American Home's biggest drug is Premarin, a hormone-therapy drug for post-menopausal women. It also sells the over-the-counter pain reliever Advil. **********SmithKline's leading products include the anti-depressant Paxil and the antibiotic Augmentin. **********Prospects for a deal could be clouded by potential legal liabilities stemming from Pondimin and Redux, diet pills that American Home pulled from sale in the United States last year because of a risk of heart-valve damage. Antitrust regulators also might press for divestment of vaccine lines, the one area where the companies have significant product overlap. **********Other takeover speculation centered on such drugmakers as Zeneca Group PLC, a cancer therapy leader that is vulnerable because of its relatively small size, and Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., which is seen as having slower growth prospects. Zeneca shares jumped 92 pence to 2,377, and Bristol-Myers Squibb rose $2.125 to $95.5625. Among other drug stocks, Glaxo Wellcome rose 38 pence to 1,677, and Novartis rose 34 Swiss francs to 2,440 ($1,628).

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/13/techn.print_headline: Q & A; Where Sites Go to Die
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/13/techn.body_text: **********Q. What happens to abandoned Web sites? Do they stay on the Web? **********A. Orphaned sites are a sad thing, indeed. Ignored by its creator for whatever reason, a stranded page will just sit there until someone (or some program) deletes it from the host Web server. **********In some cases, the company that is the host of a particular site will pull the plug if the site's creator neglects to pay the bills or to update the site over a certain period of time. A once-popular page might be voluntarily shut down as its creator moves on to other things, leaving a dead end from another page that links to it. **********The Internet Archive is an organization that is trying to find, record and store a copy of every public document on the Web, dead or alive (www.archive.org). The group's own site offers a link to a free program called Alexa, which runs with your browser.  If a dead page is in the archive, Alexa can show you what it looked like. **********For a humorous look at pages that once burned brightly and then flickered out, visit Ghost Sites (www.disobey.com/ghostsites), an active page that chronicles inactive ones and is updated monthly.   J. D. BIERSDORFER **********Circuits invites questions about computer-based technology, by postal mail to Questions, Circuits, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036-3959 or by E-mail to QandA@nytimes.com. This column will answer questions of general interest, but letters cannot be answered individually.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/09/busin.snippet: Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Arthur Levitt Jr says Richard H Walker, general counsel at SEC, will become commission's top enforcement officer; Walker takes over for William R McLucas, who is leaving; photo (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/09/busin.main_headline: Enforcement Chief Named At the S.E.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/09/busin.print_headline: Enforcement Chief Named At the S.E.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/09/busin.body_text: **********Richard H. Walker, general counsel at the Securities and Exchange Commission, will become the commission's top enforcement officer, Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman, announced yesterday. **********Mr. Walker takes over for William R. McLucas, who is leaving the commission after eight years in the position. Mr. McLucas said yesterday that he had been hired by the prominent Washington law firm of Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering, which has been aggressively courting former Federal regulators for its securities practice. **********The job of enforcement director, the person in charge of investigating wrongdoing in the nation's securities markets, is widely considered to be the second most important post at the S.E.C., after that of chairman. **********Mr. Walker, 47, said yesterday that he intended to continue the commission's crackdown on insider trading, swindles by brokers selling low-priced stocks, abuses in the issuance of municipal securities and accounting fraud. ''Those in the bucket shops, boiler rooms and other fraudulent enterprises which are capitalizing on this bull market ought to think about some other line of business,'' he said. **********The S.E.C. has recently lost many lawyers to private law firms, which can pay the regulators many times their Government salaries. Colleen P. Mahoney, the enforcement division's No. 2 official, said last month that she was also leaving to pursue a job with a private firm. Concerned about the turnover, Mr. Levitt has asked Congress to approve a $7 million package of bonuses for several hundred lawyers and staff members at the commission. **********Wilmer, Cutler has long been wooing Federal regulators to its securities practice. Mr. McLucas will join six other former S.E.C. lawyers there, including former top officials in the commission's divisions of enforcement, corporate finance, investment management and market regulation. **********''There is almost a shadow S.E.C. at Wilmer, Cutler,'' said Joseph A. Grundfest, a professor of law and business at Stanford University and a former S.E.C. commissioner. ''It's a unique phenomenon in American law.'' **********Robert B. McCaw, a partner at Wilmer, Cutler, said that the firm's hiring of Mr. McLucas ''is putting a crown jewel'' on the firm's longtime strategy of hiring former regulators from divisions throughout the S.E.C. **********''Dozens of law firms would have loved to make McLucas a partner,'' Mr. McCaw said. **********''Our practice is now nearly perfectly positioned for the corporate crisis,'' he added. ''We have the ability to service a problem from A to Z.'' **********Mr. McLucas will become co-chairman of the firm's securities practice, along with Mr. McCaw. **********Mr. McLucas said in an interview yesterday that he realized his new job might include defending some companies that he might have been prosecuting if he were still at the S.E.C. But he said he believed that much of his work would include ''prevention and making sure companies do things the right way.'' **********''I think you can do this work aggressively and still sleep well,'' he said. **********Mr. McLucas and his successor at the S.E.C. went to law school together at Temple University, and he and Mr. Walker have long been close friends. Lawyers at the commission say that both men are highly regarded by Mr. Levitt. **********Before becoming the commission's general counsel in 1995, Mr. Walker was director of the S.E.C.'s Northeast regional office in New York, where he supervised such prominent fraud cases as those the Government brought against the Towers Financial Corporation, the Foundation for New Era Philanthropy and the Bennett Funding Group. **********Last year, as the commission's general counsel, he helped coordinate the Government's strategy in a Supreme Court case that affirmed a broad definition of insider trading. **********The case involved James H. O'Hagan, a Minneapolis lawyer who bought shares and options in the Pillsbury Company after he learned that another company his law firm represented planned a hostile takeover bid for Pillsbury, driving up the share price. Mr. O'Hagan ultimately made a $4.3 million profit but contended that he was not an insider; the Supreme Court disagreed. **********Mr. Walker, who grew up in Delaware, said he considered himself a New Yorker. Before joining the S.E.C. in 1991, he was a partner in the New York office of the law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. He owns a weekend house in Connecticut, where he keeps a small boat that he takes out on Long Island Sound.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/15/busin.snippet: Stryker Corp to buy Pfizer Inc's Howmedica orthopedics unit for $1.9 billion (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/15/busin.main_headline: Stryker to Buy Orthopedics Unit From Pfizer for $1.9 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/15/busin.print_headline: Stryker to Buy Orthopedics Unit From Pfizer for $1.9 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/15/busin.body_text: **********The Stryker Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy Pfizer Inc.'s Howmed ica orthopedics unit for $1.9 billion, expanding its line of products to repair injured joints and bones. **********Shares of Stryker fell 14 percent because the costs of the acquisition would slow the company's growth. **********Stryker said it would have about 15 percent of the orthopedic market worldwide following the acquisition. Pfizer is selling its medical-technology businesses to focus on its more profitable pharmaceuticals, including the impotence pill Viagra. **********Stryker will add to its line of hip- , knee-  and shoulder-repair products, as well as products used to hold together broken bones. **********The acquisition will almost double Stryker's size, making it a more formidable competitor in the orthopedics industry, where an aging population is increasing demand. **********''Baby boomers are doing Rollerblades and they're staying active longer,'' said Tom Gunderson, an analyst at Piper Jaffray Inc. ''Stryker clearly said they wanted to be one of the big players.'' **********The transaction, reported today in The Wall Street Journal, was announced less than a month after a rival company, Johnson & Johnson, agreed to buy DePuy Inc. for $3.5 billion to expand its own orthopedic business. **********As a result of the acquisition, Stryker told analysts that earnings growth would slow to 5 percent in 1999, although the company expects to return to 20 percent growth the following year. **********Robert Faulkner, an analyst at Hambrecht & Quist, said: ''Stryker has been 20 percent earnings growth come hell or high water. Those bets are off now.'' **********Stryker's shares fell $5.75, to $36, on the New York Stock Exchange today. Pfizer fell 81.25 cents, to $101.1875. **********Stryker will take a $400 million pretax charge for the acquisition in the fourth quarter. It will also amortize about $1 billion in good will over 30 years. **********Howmedica had $821 million in 1997 sales. Stryker had sales of more than $980 million last year, with $740 million of that from orthopedic surgical products.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/04/techn.snippet: Suzanne MacNeille reviews destination CD-ROM on France, Spain and Italy; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/04/techn.print_headline: LIBRARY/DESTINATION CD-ROM'S; 3 Countries Frozen in Time
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/04/techn.body_text: **********COUNTRIES OF ROMANCE **********(E.M.M.E. Interactive; $38.99; Windows 3.1 and 95.) **********LIKE a lushly illustrated coffee table book, Countries of Romance is pretty to look at but lacks much detailed information. The France, Spain and Italy we find in this set of three CD-ROM's are the idealized versions, presented in broad strokes and caught in centuries past. **********Perhaps the viewer who will get the most out of this collection -- which is a perennial in stores -- is the art-history student planning a first trip to Europe. Produced by E.M.M.E. Interactive, the Paris-based company that has also published CD-ROM's on the Louvre, the Vatican and the Sistine Chapel, Countries of Romance is most informative and innovative when it deals with art and historic architecture. **********In Spain, three of the five main menu items focus solely on architecture, including Roman, Islamic, Baroque and Renaissance styles. A photographic sequence devoted to Antonio Gaudi's surrealistic Barcelona buildings is especially appealing. **********In each of the CD-ROM's, at least one section is devoted to that country's major artists, like Monet in France, Goya in Spain and Piero della Francesca in Italy. Biographical texts and lists of major works and their museum locations are given for each entry, as is a selection of five or six paintings that the viewer can magnify and examine. **********Photographs, graphics (including lovely but not particularly useful maps), lots of period music and extensive narration make up most of the format used here. There is some written text, but not much. If you search for them, you will find short video clips on bullfighting, flamenco, the Palio horse race in Siena, Florentine football and, surprisingly, the May 1968 student riots in Paris, the only nod at recent history in the collection. **********One of the best features in the entire set is the beautiful and remarkably detailed graphic of the Grand Canal in Venice. You can move along the right or left banks and click on a highlighted building, like the Church of the Scalzi or the Doge's Palace, and get a close-up photograph of the building accompanied by a brief narrated history. **********The seemingly arbitrary selections of cities and subjects for each country might make you wonder about what was left out. In Voyage Through the Wonders of Italy you will find Venice, Rome, Siena and Florence (albeit of several centuries ago), but you will have to resort to your Baedeker or Michelin if you are looking for anything on Milan, Bologna, Naples or the Tuscan countryside. Similarly, Voyage in Spain has  nothing about Cadiz, Valencia or the lovely white towns of Andalusia, and the France CD-ROM offers virtually nothing on French cuisine or wine. **********Another element that has been ignored is the late 20th century. Madrid is a sprawling, largely modern city, but one sees little beyond the Prado or a nearly empty Plaza Mayor. And is it possible that I never encountered a single car in traffic-ensnared Rome?

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/28/busin.snippet: Federal Trade Commission says Merck & Co reduced competition in pharmaceuticals market for time after it bought Medco Containment Services, managed-care drug sales company, in 1993; Merck announced it has agreed to antitrust safeguards requested b...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/28/busin.main_headline: F.T.C. Says Merck Deal Cut Competition
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/28/busin.print_headline: F.T.C. Says Merck Deal Cut Competition
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/28/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that Merck & Company had reduced competition in the pharmaceuticals market for a time after it bought Medco Containment Services, a managed-care drug sales company, in 1993. Merck announced on Wednesday that it had agreed to antitrust safeguards requested by the commission. **********The commission said the new agreement, which would replace the terms Merck accepted three years ago in settling a civil suit in California, would insure that Merck and Medco did not revert to earlier practices. Government regulators said such practices had threatened to undermine competition. The California settlement expired earlier this year. **********Under the new agreement, Medco must offer a wide range of products by all drug makers, on lists selected by independent committees of doctors and pharmacists. Merck must maintain a fire wall denying it access to marketing information that Medco gathers about competing  products. **********Managed-care units like Medco and similar divisions of Eli Lilly and SmithKline Beecham buy drugs at discount prices and push doctors to prescribe them for members of health plans. **********Merck said the new agreement merely formalized policies that it had followed since it bought Medco. A Merck spokesman said the only change from the 1995 agreement was a provision that the selection committees would ''give no preference to the products of Merck'' except on ''objective criteria.'' **********William J. Baer, director of the commission's Bureau of Competition, said the new agreement committed Merck and Medco to maintain the safeguards and barred any return to the favorable treatment that the commission said Medco had given to Merck drugs on preferred drug lists called formularies. **********Mr. Baer noted that Merck adopted the earlier safeguards in February 1995 in settling a civil suit brought by the Bacon-Normandi Corporation on behalf of pharmacies that objected to the Merck-Medco merger. The three-year agreement ''was a little bit porous,'' he said. **********Kevin Colgan, a spokesman for Medco, said that only 38 of the 533 brand-name drugs on the preferred list had been made by Merck. Of these, 40 were recommended for substitution as lower priced and as effective or better than other products. He said only four such drugs were made by Merck: Zocor, a cholesterol-lowering drug; Prinivil and Prinzide for cardiovascular problems, and Timoptic XE for glaucoma. **********The commission's agreement binds Merck to provisions similar to those accepted by Eli Lilly after it bought PCS Health Systems from the McKesson Corporation. The Merck agreement would be for seven years after formal approval by the F.T.C. SmithKline Beecham has a smaller market share and is not considered a threat to competition, antitrust experts said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/17/world.snippet: South Korea and other Asian countries are moving closer to an American-style free-market economy and away from the kind of capitalism they have been pursuing, which emphasizes Government planning and long-term relationships and is widely blamed fo...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/17/world.main_headline: Crisis Pushing Asian Capitalism Closer to U.S.-Style Free Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/17/world.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Crisis Pushing Asian Capitalism Closer to U.S.-Style Free Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/17/world.body_text: **********Sitting in his office just off the factory floor, a week's stubble on his face and weariness in his eyes, Kim Jung Ju watches his workers carefully, figuring out whom he might lay off next. **********''Now the bottom line is everything,'' Mr. Kim says mournfully, and he complains that the relationships that were the underpinning of Korean-style capitalism are dying quickly. ''Before, companies that had done business with us for a decade would help us out in times of trouble. But no more.'' **********So the customers of Mr. Kim's clothing factory are breaking the rules of the game by squeezing him and curbing orders. And he reacts by breaking the rules again and laying off one-third of his 130 employees. **********That is the harsh reality of free-market capitalism, and it might be unremarkable in the United States. But this is Asia, where in the past some nations followed a different economic model, emphasizing not markets but rather Government planning and long-term relationships. **********That version of capitalism, particularly the variety developed by Japan and adopted by South Korea, is now widely regarded as a problem rather than a solution. For the present at least, the Asian financial crisis is driving Governments and businesses alike toward a more open, market-oriented, laissez-faire version of capitalism, the kind championed by the United States. **********While many aspects of East Asia's community ethos will remain, Asian officials and scholars suggest that the region's economies may emerge from the financial crisis looking a bit more like the American economy. In other words, they would be more open to imports and foreign investment, less curtailed by strict regulations, less dominated by Government planning and more ruthless about laying off workers. **********''Everybody has been liberating markets to take advantage of globalization and the world economy,'' said Jusuf Wanandi, chairman of a policy research center in Jakarta, Indonesia. ''So we are all moving more to the American model.'' **********Still, as Mr. Wanandi noted, this does not mean that Asian countries will adopt the free model outright. Many Asians are still not on friendly terms with the market forces that over the last few months have demolished their economies, and they worry that an excess of markets will threaten a way of life and community ethos. **********While the changes under way seem breathtaking to a laid-off Korean worker, they still leave the region looking -- to Western eyes -- far more Asian than American. Western commentators have been saying for generations that Asians are becoming ''more like us,'' and while in one sense they were right, that does not mean that convergence lies ahead. **********In any case, the change in the mood in Asia is striking because Japanese-style capitalism was perhaps the most formidable rival to neoclassical free-market capitalism as a model for other countries. Japanese officials vigorously urged other Asian nations to adopt the Japanese approach to capitalism, even sponsoring a 1993 World Bank report that was supposed to give the Japanese methods the seal of legitimacy. The report did not quite do that, but it was not as critical of state intervention as an earlier World Bank report. **********To be sure, Asia as a whole never adopted a single economic model. Hong Kong was traditionally a paragon of laissez-faire capitalism. On the other hand, Japan and South Korea relied on a very similar system of industrial planning, huge inter-linked conglomerates, lifetime jobs in big companies, export assistance and protected domestic industries. **********Taiwan, Singapore, Indonesia and Malaysia were somewhere in-between, but all borrowed in part from the Japanese development model. Bureaucrats in all those countries sometimes seemed to think that they were better at allocating capital and goods than markets were. **********''How can you go hunting without a target?'' Naohiro Amaya, the late former top Japanese trade official and leading theorist of the Japanese model, was quoted as saying in 1988. ''When you go hunting, you have to shoot at a target. But your neoclassical school of economics says you can fire in all directions at once, and the 'market' will insure you hit the target. Well, we don't accept that line of reasoning, and our economic model will probably be stronger in the future, and have a greater demonstration effect for developing countries, than either the American model, which has become weak and less relevant, or the Soviet central-command model.'' **********The wheel may turn again, but for now there are no more boasts about the superiority of the Japanese-Korean model. **********''Other Asian markets should take note and move their economies more in the direction of free market logic and away from government and bureaucratic intervention and centralized monopolistic industrial power blocs,'' warned the Chosun Ilbo, South Korea's leading newspaper. ''If Asians have been arrogant, soaked in snobbish and boastful attitudes, then now is the time to realize their limitations and show a degree of humility and repentance.'' **********These days, both Japan and Korea are trying to dismantle regulations and bureaucratic controls over the economy. ''Economies are all going the American way, and that's a major trend today,'' Makoto Kuroda, a former top Japanese trade official and managing director of Mitsubishi Corporation, said. **********Some Trends Under Way in Past **********Still, Mr. Kuroda noted that there are countercurrents as well, and in any case the trend away from bureaucratic intervention is not a completely new one. **********In Japan, the Government has been losing its ability to manipulate the economy, and layoffs have become more common in the last few years. Regulation is diminishing, and imports have risen, and those trends have been visible in South Korea and other Asian countries. **********The Asian financial crisis has dramatically accelerated this process. While Asia has had crises in the past, like the oil crisis of 1973-74, that were in some ways more severe than the present one, those were external shocks. In contrast, this crisis seems more of a collapse from within, especially with Japan's long stagnation since 1990, and the problems raise fundamental questions about whether a new strategy is necessary. **********''The model is now clear,'' said Lee Hong Koo, a member of the South Korean National Assembly and a former Prime Minister. ''It's not Japan. It's the West.'' **********''The current crisis has convinced almost all people that that the old style doesn't work,'' Mr. Lee added. ''We will adjust ourselves rapidly to the new requirements, which means we will fashion ourselves more like the West, like the U.S. and European model.'' **********Mr. Lee and others emphasize that they do not see the collapse of their development strategy as a defeat for Asia. On the contrary, they hope that freer markets may give the region a new dynamism. **********''If we faithfully implement the reforms we agreed on with the I.M.F., we will emerge with a stronger economic foundation, and we will be poised to overtake Japan,'' said You Jong Keun, a top economic adviser to President-elect Kim Dae Jung of South Korea. **********Several Changes Are Predicted **********In the real world, a shift to a new model is never quite so clear-cut as it sounds, but in general the changes that diplomats and business executives are talking about are these: ***********Governments may control economies less than before. The Finance Ministry in Korea no longer tells the banks whom to lend to, and the Finance Ministry in Japan has lost its capacity to determine the fate of banks and securities houses. As a result, despite official Japanese assurances that no big bank would be allowed to fail, one did in the fall. ***********Labor markets may become a bit more flexible, and unemployment rates will rise. Lifetime employment and rigid seniority will tend to be less important, and layoffs will increase. This has been happening for years but will accelerate. South Korea's unemployment rate is expected to quadruple this year to 10 percent. ***********Relationships in general may tend to become less important. The huge families of linked companies -- called keiretsu in Japan and chaebol in South Korea, where the ship-building arm buys its cars from the linked auto company and its beer from the linked brewery -- is gradually giving way to a more open system in which business is allocated not by loyalty but by price. Already, business groups in both countries are for the first time allowing affiliates to collapse, and Asia's great home-grown champion of relationship finance, Peregrine Securities in Hong Kong, collapsed this month. ***********Companies may make less effort to build market share and more effort to make money. Japanese banks and South Korean chaebol alike are being ordered to disclose more accurate and useful financial information, and everyone is paying more attention to credit-worthiness. **********Transition Apparent In Seoul Already **********These changes are matters of degree, and even modest change will take time. But in Chung Youn Goo's small clothing factory in Seoul, the transition is already apparent. Mr. Chung has laid off a third of his work force, rather than keep them on in hopes for a rebound, as he would have done in the old days, and he is now scrutinizing data as much as cultivating relationships. **********''Our methods of doing business have changed a lot,'' Mr. Chung said as he sat at a small table near the factory floor. ''We put a lot more emphasis on making sure that we have confidence in the companies we deal with. For companies listed on the stock exchange, for example, we conduct a thorough review of their financial standing, because now even the big companies can go belly up very quickly.'' **********The crisis is so recent that the changes in the way of doing business are tentative, and many still have not fully taken effect. But in South Korea, the chaebol have been forced to accept substantial changes by the markets and by President-elect Kim, who unlike other recent presidents owes the chaebol nothing. **********On Thursday, the chaebol jointly promised to adopt Western accounting standards, to bring outsiders into their boards of directors and to reduce the cross-guarantees that subsidiaries make to honor one another's debts. They also pledged to reduce their debt-equity ratios to bring them closer to Western standards. **********These measures are important because the top 30 chaebol account for nearly two-thirds of South Korea's economic output. That was the result of preferential treatment -- the Government ordered banks to lend to the chaebol, for instance -- and the ratio is expected to drop as South Korea becomes more market-oriented. **********To be sure, while executives find themselves forced to embrace the market, that is not to say they find it a pretty sight. Dong Hwa International, a trading company, did some deals with the United States a few years ago, and its executives were angered when the American company promptly cut costs by dispensing with Dong Hwa and contacting the Korean end company directly. **********That was shrewd but unethical, Dong Hwa executives say. Still, they see such moves as the way of the future. **********''I think the Korean economy will look more like America's, because all parties here are trying to cut costs, cutting out third parties, cutting out middlemen,'' lamented Kim Jin Hyung, an executive of Dong Hwa. **********Resembling America Only a Bit More **********Yet Asia is not suddenly going to look like America. One way of looking at it is that young Japanese, Taiwanese, Koreans, Chinese and Thais already wear Western clothes, eat American hamburgers, watch American movies and listen to American music. Within a few years, they are much more likely also to face the risk of layoffs, and to change jobs with American-style casualness. **********All this will make Asia's labor markets, finance and industry resemble America's a bit more, but  Americans do not become more group-oriented or respectful of their parents when they put on a Sony Walkman. **********Japan is still the country that is most hesitant about rapid change toward a more market-driven system, with Japanese wary of the brutality of market mechanisms. The old system protected a way of life that is often inefficient -- with the tiny rice shops and futon-makers that charge ludicrous prices -- but that is also central to the ethos of Japan. A more efficient, market-driven system may mean better prices and more supermarkets, but the fear is that it will also lead to alienation, crime and an end to the civility that is the most outstanding feature of daily Japanese life. **********The result is a profound ambivalence that has Japan tip-toeing toward a freer market system but still aghast at the layoffs and turbulence that a radical economic restructuring will require. **********''Markets are riddled with defects,'' the Yomiuri Shimbun, the largest circulation newspaper in Japan, complained in an editorial. ''Markets widen the rich-poor gap and raise unemployment, putting the nation's entire social fabric at risk.'' **********Yet the newspaper acknowledged, just a bit sadly, that ''the move toward markets has reached the point of no return.''

Carematrix, based in Needham, Mass., will also assume $50 million of debt. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/09/busin.body_text: **********The United States and France announced an agreement yesterday to expand access to each other's aviation markets, a move that could drive down fares as competition increases for trans-Atlantic flights. **********United States carriers will be able to add nine daily flights to the current limit of 21, while French airlines can increase flights by the same amount under the agreement, which will take effect this summer. The agreement allows unrestricted access after five years. The agreement highlights French confidence that Air France can withstand greater competition before the Government sale of a minority stake this year. It could make the carrier, whose American partners are Delta Air Lines Inc. and Continental Airlines Inc., more attractive to prospective investors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/22/busin.snippet: Texas Instruments Inc reports greater-than-expected decline in second-quarter profit, attributing it to weak prices for memory chips; net income fell to $43 million, down from $249 million in year-earlier period; revenue declind about 15 percent, ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/22/busin.print_headline: COMPANY REPORTS; Profit Down For Texas Instruments
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/22/busin.body_text: **********Texas Instruments Inc., the leading maker of semiconductors for mobile phones, reported a greater-than-expected decline in second-quarter profit yesterday, attributing it to weak prices for memory chips. **********The Dallas-based company's net income fell to $43 million, or 11 cents a share, down from $249 million or 65 cents, in the period a year earlier. Texas Instruments' earnings before charges fell to $142 million, or 35 cents a diluted share, from $213 million, or 54 cents, before charges and gains in the period a year ago. **********Analysts had expected earnings before the charges of 37 cents a share, according to a survey by the First Call Corporation. **********Revenues declined about 15 percent, to $2.17 billion from $2.56 billion. **********The semiconductor industry is ailing because of a global oversupply of chips, falling prices and the economic turmoil in Asia. Earnings were also hurt by flat sales of digital signal processors, the chips used in cellular phones and disk drives. Sales of the specialized chips were unchanged from the first quarter, although up from the corresponding period a year earlier. **********Texas Instruments said it expected prices to remain depressed in the third quarter. **********Prices for the dynamic random-access memory chips used in personal computers fell about 30 percent from the previous quarter and about 70 percent from the period a year ago, the company said. **********Texas Instruments agreed last  month to sell its memory-chip operations to the rival Micron Technology Inc. for $641 million in stock plus $190 million in debt. **********Shares of Texas Instruments rose $2, to $60.9375, in Nasdaq trading. **********Texas Instruments set aside $233 million before taxes in the second  quarter to pay for a revamping that included the sale of its memory chip business to Micron and the elimination of 3,500 employees through layoffs and attrition. The company also reported a gain of $83 million from the sale of its joint venture with the Acer Corporation to Acer. **********Drew Peck, an analyst with Cowen & Company, said demand for digital signal processors should pick up next year, driven by an expected recovery in disk drive sales, as well as the introduction of new products that incorporate the chips, such as motor controllers for refrigerators and air conditioners. **********William Aylesworth, Texas Instruments' chief financial officer, said the unusual sluggishness in the digital signal processor market was largely a result of economic woes in Asia, which had been one of the fastest-growing markets for the chips. **********''Certainly in the third quarter, there is going to be continued pressure on margins because of the weak orders from the second quarter,'' Mr. Aylesworth said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/07/busin.main_headline: Autumn Rally Taking Stocks Back to Highs
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/07/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; Autumn Rally Taking Stocks Back to Highs
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/07/busin.body_text: **********The stock market has spoken. Its tidings: Happy days are here again. **********As of yesterday's close, most broad market measures were either close to their summer highs or at them. The Dow Jones industrial average closed the week at 8,975.46, up 59.99 points for the day and 4.46 percent for the week. That places the Dow only 3.8 percent below its July 17 peak and up 19 percent from its Aug. 31 low. For the year, the Dow is up a respectable 13.49 percent. **********Big-capitalization stocks that make up the Dow average are not the only ones moving up. The Wilshire 5000 index, the best approximation for the entire United States stock market, has shown an even better performance. It has jumped 21 percent from its Oct. 8 low, and is up 12.4 percent for the year. Yesterday, the Wilshire had a value of $11.5 trillion. In about one month, the value of the index has risen more than $2 trillion. **********As of yesterday, the market has gone eight sessions without a down day, its second example of such durability in less than one month. But extended moves like these are unusual: to find a third example of such staying power requires a trip back to 1997. **********What's fueling this move? Traders and strategists point to several disparate factors. **********Most significant, perhaps, is a sea change in monetary policy not just domestically but around the world. Central banks, beginning with the Federal Reserve back in September and extending to Britain, Latin America and parts of Asia, have been reducing interest rates fairly aggressively. According to Jeffrey Applegate, chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers, since the September rate cut by the Fed, 27 central banks have done the same. **********''In the last month and a half, the global policy outlook has improved,'' Mr. Applegate said. ''Then this week we had a slew of data that was stock-market friendly. I think the fear trade is out of the market.'' **********Lower interest rates are almost always a tonic for stock prices largely because they mean reduced borrowing costs -- offering the potential for higher profit margins -- for corporations. So it is not surprising that a cut in the discount rate -- the Fed's rate on loans made to banks -- has historically been followed by an average 12-month increase of 18 percent in the Standard & Poor's 500 index. **********Stocks have been getting an additional lift from a giant increase in the money supply. According to Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y., the broadest measure of money supply, known as M-2, which includes currency in circulation, savings accounts and money market mutual funds, has grown by 2.5 percent in the last two months. The annualized rate for the last three months is 9.3 percent, the fastest annual expansion since 1987. ''This tells me that there isn't a credit crunch,'' Mr. Shepherdson said. ''And all this liquidity sloshing around has got to go somewhere.'' **********An increase in the money supply comes basically from the Fed's providing reserves to the banking system, which banks  use to lend. ''New lending and investing power is created as money turnover speeds,'' said Robert H. Parks, an economist and investment consultant in Scarborough, N.Y. ''It brings increased spending power that can go into stocks.'' **********Another supply of money coming into stocks is from investors selling Treasury holdings in recent days. When Russia effectively defaulted in August, Treasuries became the darling of investors. **********No more. The price of the 30-year bond has tumbled this week. Its yield, which rises as the price falls, ended at 5.38 percent, up from 5.15 percent a week earlier. **********An interesting, if somewhat obscure, reason for the advance in equities may be the decline in stock volatility recently. Volatility -- basically the range from high to low in stocks during the trading day -- peaked on Oct. 15. Mr. Applegate notes that since 1948, the S.& P. 500 has risen an average 12 percent in the 12-month period after a peak in volatility. **********''As long as the policy outlook continues to look good, then risk aversion should come down, volatility should come down and returns should come up,'' he said. **********The jubliant stock market is, however, choosing to shrug off some troubling indicators. Corporate earnings, for example. While all the third-quarter announcements are not quite in, the period was a disappointment. **********Even though many analysts have focused on the positive announcements, those were a distinct minority. John L. Manley Jr., equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, said that of 428 companies that have reported third-quarter results, fewer than 36 percent recorded a positive surprise. He defines a positive surprise as a company that reports a result greater than the consensus estimate on Wall Street one month before the quarter ended. **********Neither do stocks seem to care that it is becoming increasingly likely that the Fed's policy-making committee will not cut rates when it meets on Nov. 17. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, said on Thursday that investors and lenders appeared to be less fearful than they had been. If the deep freeze in the credit markets is indeed beginning to thaw, as Mr. Greenspan seems to believe, another quick rate cut becomes less likely. **********Some investors are calling this the John Glenn rally. After all, since Mr. Glenn blasted off from Cape Canaveral, the market has rallied nearly 10 percent. As long as he has been in orbit, so has the stock market. **********Mr. Glenn returns to earth today. Investors clearly hope the stock market does not follow suit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/06/world.main_headline: Anti-Apartheid Champion Standing Trial on Fraud Charges
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/06/world.print_headline: Anti-Apartheid Champion Standing Trial on Fraud Charges
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/06/world.body_text: **********All Allan A. Boesak says he is guilty of is ''struggle bookkeeping.'' **********But in Courtroom 19 in the new wing of Cape Town's High Court, a judge is going to decide whether ''struggle bookkeeping'' was really fraud and theft, crimes serious enough to send one of the liberation struggle's heroes to jail. **********Since August, the court has heard from a string of witnesses that Mr. Boesak used welfare projects to raise cash for a life of luxury, flashy cars and overseas holidays. And for a while, it seemed, the prosecution might breeze to victory. **********But last month, one of the prosecution's principle witnesses, Mr. Boesak's bookkeeper, crumpled under cross-examination and admitted that he had implicated Mr. Boesak only to cover up his own thieving. With tears in his eyes, the bookkeeper, Freddie Steenkamp, who is already serving a six-year sentence for theft, asked for Mr. Boesak's forgiveness. **********Just how big a blow to the prosecution this was remains to be seen. Prosecutors are scrambling to line up other last-minute witnesses, including the singer Paul Simon, who contributed more than $100,000 to Mr. Boesak's Foundation for Peace and Justice. **********But the case has gripped this country both because it has offered a window into Mr. Boesak's indulgent living and because President Nelson Mandela has several times swooped in to help him, in ways some critics find deeply objectionable. **********When Mr. Boesak returned from a year in California to face charges last year, Mr. Mandela sent his Justice Minister to greet him at the airport, and in recent weeks Mr. Mandela has openly raised funds for his defense and derided the quality of the prosecution's case, triggering outrage in legal circles. He later apologized for those remarks. **********In his heyday, Mr. Boesak was a clergyman in the forefront of the anti-apartheid movement, defying the authorities and landing more than once in solitary confinement. He was a founder of the United Democratic Front, the political group aligned with the outlawed African National Congress and a man with a certain gift for rallying a crowd. **********''The time has come,'' he told the crowds when the United Democratic Front was officially launched in 1983, ''for white people in this country to realize that their destiny is inextricably bound with our destiny and that they shall never be free until we are free.'' **********But in the years that followed, prosecutors say, Mr. Boesak began using the funds that poured in from foreign donors to support his Foundation for Peace and Justice for his own needs -- sports cars, an expensive home and, after his divorce, the debts of his new, young wife. **********At one point, auditors testified, more money was spent on first-class travel for Mr. Boesak and his family than for any other project the foundation was involved in. **********The accusations of misappropriation of funds surfaced in 1994, when lawyers for DanChurch Aid, a Danish charity, said that money it had sent to help victims of apartheid had been used to pay for Mr. Boesak's house. But it took more than two years before the case wound its way through various bureaucracies and formal charges were made. **********Mr. Boesak faces 32 counts of fraud and theft involving nearly $1.5 million, $195,000 of which he is accused of taking for himself. Much of the money had been donated by Scandinavian charities, but some was donated by Mr. Simon after his Graceland tour of South Africa and some was from the charitable arm of Coca-Cola. The prosecution says Mr. Boesak deliberately raised money from Coca-Cola saying it was for a poverty project, when he had every intention of using the money to invest in a hotel. **********Even after Mr. Boesak's return to South Africa, the case was delayed for more than a year as he battled to have the country's Legal Aid system pay for his legal bills. Eventually, an anonymous donor coughed up more than $150,000 for his defense. **********When Mr. Boesak ran out of funds last month, he appealed directly to Mr. Mandela, who then publicly solicited more money for him. Within 24 hours another anonymous donor gave another $150,000. **********On most days, Mr. Boesak has come to court accompanied by his wife. He has shown little emotion during the proceedings. Some witnesses have been former board members of Mr. Boesak's foundation who described being kept in the dark about almost all of the foundation's financial transactions. Some had even resigned because of the lack of accounting procedures. **********But some witnesses have clearly been reluctant to speak against a man they admire. During Thursday's testimony, the prosecutor battled with an auditor who had trouble remembering much of anything, including which years he audited the foundation's books. Finally, the prosecutor made him read the notes from the margins of his work sheets. **********''A good system of internal checks does not exist,'' the notes said. **********Most days, a small group of Mr. Boesak's supporters sit in the back of the room. But Mr. Boesak says he feels abandoned by almost everyone  but Mr. Mandela. **********At times, he says he has regretted ''ever leading one single march.'' He says the charges are not about fraud or theft but about politics and people getting revenge for the success he had. **********He says that administering the accounts of the foundation was not his work and that he paid little attention to it. ''My job was to work for the downfall of apartheid,'' Mr. Boesak said, brushing aside the notion that perhaps he should have been more aware. ''I should like to think that that was a job not badly done.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/06/busin.snippet: Readers share anecdotes about playing sports with colleagues and superiors at work; cartoons (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/06/busin.main_headline: It's Only a Game. Or So You Thought.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/06/busin.print_headline: EARNING IT: ON THE JOB; It's Only a Game. Or So You Thought.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/06/busin.body_text: **********The Duke of Wellington supposedly said that the battle of Waterloo was won ''on the playing fields of Eton.'' Indeed, many a valuable lesson is learned in games -- and that goes for business just as much as war. Some lessons may sting, but as these anecdotes demonstrate, they linger in the memory. **********In the summer of 1966, Barry Augenbraun, now of St. Petersburg, Fla., was a newly minted associate attending his first summer outing at a major Wall Street law firm. Asked to choose a sport, he picked tennis; around 6:30 that evening, he phoned his wife, Janet, and told her he had some good news and some bad news. **********''Oh,'' she said, her concern evident in her voice. **********''Yes,'' he replied. ''I came in second in the firm doubles tournament.'' **********''Great!'' his wife said. **********''No,'' Mr. Augenbraun said. ''That was the bad news.'' He had been teamed with one of the firm's partners, who was also a nationally ranked tennis player, and that ''this is the first firm championship he has lost in six years.'' **********''What's the good news?'' Mr. Augenbraun's wife asked. **********The partner, he replied, ''offered to buy me golf lessons before next year's outing.'' **********Meet Bill Byrne of San Francisco, a member of the winning team in an unusual race. **********At a company picnic where food and beer were in ample supply, a new executive, having decided that team-building games would provide a good way to observe organizational culture, set into motion an odd variation on the three-legged race: **********Each team had 10 players, and each player was given a short piece of rope. The first two players, assuming the usual three-legged stance, tied legs together with the rope; then they walked 50 yards to a hula hoop. The first player stepped into the hoop with his free leg, picked it up by hand and passed it over his head. Then both players lifted their common leg, passed the hoop through to the second player's free leg so that he could then pass the hoop over his head and place it on the ground. **********Having completed the drill, the team returned to the starting line, tied on another person and repeated the procedure. The goal was to sequentially tie together all 10 team members, pass the hula hoop and return to the starting line. **********Given the presence of the beer, coordination was not prevalent, and several participants were so drunk with competitive spirit that they failed to notice their bleeding, rope-burned ankles. **********Mr. Byrne writes, ''The new executive awarded first place to my team, for having the intelligence to quit soon into the game.'' **********After surviving hours of round-robin play, Brian Brown of Manhattan and his doubles partner reached  the finals of the hotly contested tennis tournament at their company's annual sales conference. **********Mr. Brown, who no longer works for the company, writes that their opponents in the finals included a man ''who fancied himself a tennis pro and happened to be a director of our publishing firm.'' **********Volleying with gusto and covering the net with tenacity, Mr. Brown and his partner sensed an impending victory, made all the sweeter by the presence of a crowd of their peers. **********The partners were on the verge of serving out the match when one of their more senior colleagues, who had been watching from the sidelines, called time out and walked across the court to the baseline, where Mr. Brown was standing. **********He cupped his hands to Mr. Brown's ear and whispered: ''Are you out of your mind? The purpose of this exercise is not to lose your job.'' **********Mr. Brown discussed this situation with his partner. **********''Now, with our priorities in proper perspective,'' Mr. Brown writes, ''we managed to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory.'' **********Of course, there is always a bright side to losing. **********Jack Economou of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., recalls the Type A lawyer who lost his tennis match to an easygoing stockbroker by a score of 6-1, 6-2, 6-0. **********As they left the court, the Type A told his opponent, ''Could have gone either way.'' **********School Days For Workers **********Students of all ages are heading back to school this month. But in the workplace, a return to the classroom can come at any time of year, in the form of corporate training sessions. Whether it's learning about the new computer, the corporate culture, or how to unleash the salesman within, such classes can leave teacher and student alike wondering just how quick a study the other is. Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.
