https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/12/busin.snippet: Nearly 6,000 workers go on strike at General Motors factory in Flint, Mich, joining walkout at nearby plant in increasingly bitter fight that could close down virtually all of GM's North American production within days; photos; company has already...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/12/busin.main_headline: 6,000 G.M. WORKERS AT MICHIGAN PLANT JOIN AUTO STRIKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/12/busin.print_headline: 6,000 G.M. WORKERS AT MICHIGAN PLANT JOIN AUTO STRIKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/12/busin.body_text: **********Nearly 6,000 workers went on strike this evening at a General Motors factory in Flint, Mich., joining fellow strikers at a nearby G.M. plant in an increasingly bitter fight that could close virtually all of the company's North American assembly plants within days. **********G.M., the world's largest auto maker, had already closed seven of those assembly plants and temporarily laid off 18,600 workers for lack of parts from the initial strike last Friday at a metal-stamping plant in Flint. Most of G.M.'s 22 other assembly plants in the United States, Canada and Mexico are expected to quickly run out of the spark plugs, speedometers and other parts made by the giant factory where workers walked out this evening. **********With some parts factories also likely to close, G.M. could be forced to temporarily lay off up to 200,000 more workers. **********The workers struck over G.M. efforts to move production tasks to other factories, both inside and outside the country where costs are lower, a move they regard as a threat to job security. Hundreds of strikers shouting ''U.A.W.!'' and toting placards identifying their union locals mobbed the parts factory's gates. They were joined by workers from the metal-stamping factory. **********Scattered among the picketers were members of the United Automobile Workers from across Michigan and even Ohio and Illinois who had come to show their anger at G.M., which has contended with steadily worsening labor relations in trying to make its factories run as efficiently as those of its rivals. **********''We're going to fight, and we're going to keep fighting,'' Richard Shoemaker, the U.A.W.'s vice president for G.M. issues, said this evening. **********Diane Young, a parts worker for 22 years who went on strike tonight, said the action was a regrettable necessity. ''It's a frustrating situation for both sides, but it's the only way to have a future,'' she said. **********G.M. said in a terse statement that it was disappointed by the broadening of the strike. ''We have committed, talented people, and we encourage the union to join management leadership at both facilities to urgently reach settlements that help us effectively work with them to improve G.M.'s competitive position in the marketplace,'' the company said. **********The spark plug factory workers have been increasingly alarmed in recent years as G.M. has bought more basic auto parts from outside companies, including some in Mexico, while selling its own factories or cutting back employment. **********The metal-stamping factory workers have been worried that G.M. management is assigning to other G.M. factories considerable work on vehicles not yet in production, possibly signaling their plant's obsolescence. The strikers have also been infuriated by G.M.'s decision to remove, over the Memorial Day weekend, many of the stamping dies needed to produce hoods and other parts for G.M.'s new full-size pickup trucks. The dies are used like enormous molds to press sheet metal into auto parts. **********As in eight other local strikes over the last three years, G.M. executives have vowed to proceed with their longstanding plans to cut costs. But senior U.A.W. officials have increasingly come to see this confrontation as an emotional struggle, perceiving a threat to the union's long-term survival in G.M.'s willingness to remove equipment from plants where workers are about to strike. **********Negotiators stopped talking after the strike was called but planned to resume talks on Friday morning. With the broadening of the strike to a second factory, the overall walkout could last until the end of June. That is when union leaders will face increased pressure to settle so that U.A.W. members can collect full pay during the industry's annual summer vacation in early July. **********National U.A.W. leaders almost never visited the picket lines during the strikes over the last three years. But they have been doing so daily this week. While senior U.A.W. and G.M. officials refrained from criticizing each other in public during the previous strikes, both sides have been doing so this time. **********Even people close to the U.A.W. concede that the metal-stamping workers in Flint have had one of the most generous deals in the auto industry. Its provisions allowed some workers to draw a full day's pay for half a day's work. Workers agreed two years ago to give up many of these provisions in exchange for further G.M. investment in Flint. The union now contends that the investment has not been forthcoming, an accusation G.M. denies. **********The truck parts metal-stamping equipment was transferred by G.M. to a parts factory in Ohio. G.M. has been planning to build the pickups initially in Oshawa, Ontario. **********But Basil E. Hargrove, the president of the Canadian Auto Workers union, warned in a telephone interview this morning that G.M. should not count on Canadian workers' willingness to accept parts produced by equipment taken out of the Flint factory. The Canadian workers were angry that G.M. managers had made such a presumption. **********''We're not noted much for strike breaking,'' Mr. Hargrove said. ''If anybody says they're moving those dies and that's your livelihood, logic no longer plays any part of it, it's emotion.'' **********Mr. Shoemaker said this evening that G.M. had agreed in negotiations to return the dies to Flint at the end of the strike. He also said that he had learned from G.M. that the dies had accidentally been damaged by nonunion workers during their removal from Flint and consequently had not been used. **********G.M. officials said earlier today that the dies had been moved successfully and were producing new parts. The officials declined to comment on Mr. Shoemaker's remarks tonight. **********G.M. executives have said repeatedly this year that to stay more competitive the company must become more efficient, meaning that each worker must produce more cars and components. While Ford and Chrysler now derive most of their automotive sales and profits from pickups, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles, with relatively little competition from foreign brands, G.M. still sells mostly cars and faces heavy pressure from imports and from nonunion factories in the United States. **********That pressure has only increased as the dollar's value has soared in global foreign-exchange markets this year, which makes it even cheaper for foreign auto makers to sell their cars in this country with generous discounts. **********G.M.'s stamping operations are particularly inefficient compared with those of rivals. The company gloated last summer that its cost for producing new dies was only twice that of its most efficient competitor -- but used to be eight times higher. **********The stamping factory in Flint is among the least efficient of all and has been under great pressure from G.M. to improve its results or face closing. ''They have 14 stamping facilities, and they probably need 9 or 10,'' said David Bradley, an analyst at J. P. Morgan and Company. **********A successful introduction of the new pickup is considered vital to G.M., which earns up to half its worldwide profits just from sales in North America of full-size pickups and the Suburban, Yukon and Tahoe sport utility vehicles, which share the same underbodies. G.M. plans to introduce new versions of the sport utility vehicles a year after the new pickups.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/02/world.snippet: New York and California outline sanctions against Credit Suisse and UBS after talks collapse over how much money Swiss banks and Swiss Government will return to Holocaust survivors and heirs; Treas Matt Fong, defying State Department, says Califor...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/02/world.main_headline: Two States Outline Sanctions on Swiss Banks in Holocaust Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/02/world.print_headline: Two States Outline Sanctions on Swiss Banks in Holocaust Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/02/world.body_text: **********New York and California outlined  sanctions yesterday against two Swiss banks, after negotiations collapsed over how much money the banks and Swiss Government will return to Holocaust survivors and heirs. **********Despite State Department objections, Treasurer Matt Fong of California said his state would not do any more business with two banks, Credit Suisse and UBS. **********The New York State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, and the New York City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, said they would outline this morning a series of sanctions that would begin taking effect in 45 to 60 days unless a settlement was reached. **********The decisions were made after all sides of the dispute had spent a day before a committee of state and local finance officials who had until now recommended holding off sanctions, because the talks had appeared headed toward a settlement. **********In New York the first step is most likely to be the rejection of bids for overnight deposits of surplus Government money, followed by banning the banks from underwriting Government bonds. Ultimately the state and city pension funds could sell their shares of Swiss companies. The funds are the second and third largest public employees' pension funds in the country, with combined assets of $188 billion. **********The three officials, as well as others from Pennsylvania and Delaware, said at City Hall in Manhattan they would recommend to 800 other state and local finance officials that they begin applying sanctions to prod the Swiss Government into joining new negotiations. **********''My impression is that the sides are not that far apart and that the problem is with the Swiss Government,'' Mr. Hevesi said. **********Credit Suisse and UBS proposed last month to put $600 million in a ''rough justice fund'' to help Holocaust survivors, in addition to paying whatever sums a commission led by Paul A. Volcker determined were due based on bank records. **********The plaintiffs proposed last week to settle for $1.5 billion, provided that the Swiss Government and the Swiss National Bank joined in the agreement, Mel Weiss, a lawyer from New York who represents the Simon Wiesenthal Center, said outside the closed session. **********The $1.5 billion is far less than lawyers for survivors and heirs, and for charities designated to represent those who died heirless, have been seeking. Those people were engaged in a two-step process in which a settlement would first be made with the commercial banks and then the talks would to the Swiss Government. **********The banks and Government said that sanctions were not warranted and that imposing them would make it more difficult to settle the case. **********''We will review all of our options,'' Roger Witten, a lawyer from Washington who is the lead negotiator for the banks, said. ''But a gun at our head is not conducive to progress in these negotiations.'' **********''State and local sanctions in this matter are wrong both in principle and practice,'' Under Secretary of State Stuart E. Eizenstat said in a statement to the officials. Mr. Eizenstat later said he hoped that ''the parties will resume their talks as soon as possible in a noncoercive atmosphere.'' **********Mr. Hevesi said the impasse ''gives us no choice'' but to begin taking business from the banks to prod them and the Government to settle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/12/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; China Loosens Controls Over Foreign Banks
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/12/busin.body_text: **********China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, announced yesterday that it would allow foreign banks to start yuan operations in Shenzhen for the first time and that it would license more foreign banks to take deposits in yuan and lend out yuan in Shanghai's Pudong district. The central bank also said it planned to increase the limit on yuan-denominated working capital allowed for foreign banks to 100 million yuan ($12 million) from 30 million yuan, to ease controls on interbank borrowing and to allow foreign banks to engage in yuan-based consortium lending. **********The new measures, analysts said, are a sign that China's Government recognizes the benefits that foreign competition can bring to the financial industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/techn.main_headline: Mild Cleaners Are Best For a Computer Screen
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/techn.print_headline: Q & A; Mild Cleaners Are Best For a Computer Screen
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/techn.body_text: **********Q. I've been reluctant to wipe off my computer screen when it gets dusty, fearing that I might damage sensitive equipment. What can I use to clean it? **********A. Many computer monitors have an antiglare coating on the glass surface of the screen. Strong cleaning fluids, mildly abrasive cloths or excessive rubbing -- while great for removing sticky fingerprints -- can scratch or dissolve the protective coating. **********Most computer stores sell pads, sprays and fluids designed for use on video-display screens. Some products, while a little pricier, include both a prepackaged wet pad (soaked in a combination cleaning and anti static solution) and a lint-free dry pad (to remove stubborn spots and leave the screen free of streaks). **********In a pinch (financial or otherwise), you can clean your monitor's screen with a soft, lint-free cloth moistened with water or a mild glass cleaner. Paper towels may leave lint all over the glass, so avoid using them. If you use a spray bottle, spray the liquid onto the cloth, not directly onto the screen. Gently wipe the screen until it is dry and then enjoy the view.   J. D. BIERSDORFER **********Circuits invites questions about computer-based technology, by E-mail to QandA@nytimes.com or postal mail to Questions, Circuits, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036-3959. This column will answer questions of general interest, but letters cannot be answered individually.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/08/busin.snippet: Analysis of Commerce Department proposal to turn management of Internet domain names, and thus management of Internet itself, over to private not-for-profit international corporation that would represent various Internet interests; proposal disapp...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/08/busin.body_text: **********The Clinton Administration called it ''A Proposal to Improve the Technical Management of Internet Names and Addresses.'' **********But the report released on Friday by the Commerce Department was much more than that. It had been long awaited by the Internet community -- which these days means everyone from multinational corporations to sandals-and-socks computer programmers to grandmothers on America Online -- as the Government's first real attempt to specify a system of governance for the informally organized global computer network born in Federal laboratories nearly three decades ago. **********But after a year of intense study, peering into issues of technology, trademark law, international politics and competition, the Government turned to the Internet community and said -- Here, you do it. **********The Government said it had decided to turn the management of Internet domain names -- and thus the management of the Internet itself -- over to an as-yet-unformed private corporation, representing various Internet interests. That organization will be responsible for fixing the escalating problem of assigning Internet domain names -- the chaotic scramble for coveted cyberspace addresses that was the impetus for the review in the first place. **********Domain names and addresses are the computer network equivalent of phone numbers, street addresses and trademarks, all rolled in one. Each of the millions of computers connected to the Internet requires a unique address, which enables electronic mail to get to its intended destination and World Wide Web pages to be found in what is rapidly becoming the world's main library. Each computer's formal address is expressed as a series of numbers, for example, 199.181.172.241. But to make the addresses easier to use, companies and individuals can ask to assign a name to the numbers, like nytimes.com. **********The ''.com'' part of the address is called a top-level domain, and it is roughly the equivalent of a telephone area code. The current top-level domain system -- seven generic top-level domains like .com and .org and .edu, plus a couple of hundred two-letter country codes -- was created when there were just a few hundred computers connected to the Net. Nobody anticipated the phenomenal growth of the Internet as a global network used by millions for electronic commerce, communications and entertainment. Today, the domain set aside for commercial activity -- .com -- is the largest and fastest growing. **********With more than 100,000 new commercial domain-name registrations being added each month, the Internet is headed toward a traffic jam that makes the overcrowding of phone area codes look benign. **********Rather than try to fix the problem  by adding more top-level domains, which it proposed doing in an earlier, much-criticized draft of the report, the Administration called for creation of a private not-for-profit international corporation whose job it would be to find a solution to the domain-name problem. If all went according to plan, the new corporation would assemble an international board of 15 directors from the private sector (the report did not even specify how the board would be chosen, leaving even that matter to the Internet community) and would begin tackling the most fundamental questions about the future of the global network by October. **********People hoping for more immediate action were left unsatisfied. **********''If they were going to do that, they could have done it a year ago,'' said Carl Oppedahl, a patent and trademark lawyer in Colorado, who has been a critic of the current system, which has no formal structure for resolving domain-name trademark disputes. ''I feel badly about the time delay. The Internet has not benefited from having all these months go by.'' **********The Government reserved the right to overrule whatever choices the private sector makes. And, while repeatedly professing its desire to get out of the Internet oversight business, the Government left open the possibility that it might retain that option until well into 2000. **********The Government's proposal was bad news for those looking for relief from domain congestion or seeking  some improvement of the current trademark dispute morass, and for dozens of domain name registry businesses that had hoped to become rich selling names in proposed new domains like .web, .inc, or .sex. **********But the Government's network solution was good news for Network Solutions Inc., the Virginia company that five years ago was awarded an exclusive Government contract to administer the .com, .org and .net domains. When Network Solutions got the contract, there was no fee to register names. Soon after, it got permission to begin charging $50 for each name (recently reduced to $35). **********Network Solutions' contract is supposed to expire on Sept. 30, but the new report opens the possibility that the company will continue to have a monopoly on the lucrative ''.com''  franchise until the new corporation comes up with an alternative -- something that everyone agrees will be no easy task. As a result, Network Solutions' stock soared on Friday, up $6.75, to $39.25. **********Viewed one way, the Administration's decision to not make any decisions was a vote of support for the Internet's old guard, which has long argued that the Internet is capable of regulating itself without government interference. **********''I have to read it as a victory for self-governance, a victory for the Internet and a demonstration that the Government has developed a profound understanding of the way the Internet works,'' said Don Heath, president of the Internet Society, a trade association. **********Viewed another way, the Government looked at all the hulking issues now pressing in on the Internet and punted. Critics say that by essentially freezing the domain-name situation in its current form for an indeterminate time, the problems facing the new board will be even tougher when it convenes. **********Time was rarely a concern as the Internet grew organically from its origins in the 1960's and 1970's. Keeping track of all the new computers on the network, and all of the technical issues of the emerging medium, was largely a volunteer effort. But in the early 1990's, when restrictions against commercial uses of the Internet were relaxed, the environment changed. **********Today, millions of companies are investing billions of dollars in Internet-related ventures. Millions of E-mail messages cross the network every day, and it is rapidly becoming a conduit for much of the world's telephone calls. Universities, grade school students, farmers, scientists, lonely singles, traveling salesmen, busy families, small businesses and giant corporations have come to depend on it. **********Husbands and wives battle over domain names in divorce court, companies pay six-figure amounts for rights to ''business.com'' and ''internet.com'' and million-dollar legal fees are increasingly common in domain-name trademark disputes. **********With such large issues at stake, many people want a more defined structure for the Internet -- not just an ad hoc group of volunteers, albeit very diligent ones, running the show, as is currently the case. **********The domain name issue is just one of many decisions that need to be made quickly. Others include: Who is responsible for making decisions?  What parts of the structure are best left to the marketplace, and what parts are best left to government interests? In the latter case, whose government? Trademark law is based on geography, while the Internet is the antithesis of geography. How to reconcile? **********These are among the questions that the Clinton Administration expects a new, unformed, untested, international corporation of indeterminate composition to answer as quickly as possible. **********''The process is going to have to be accelerated because the demand for domain names is astronomical,'' said Ken Stubbs, chairman of the executive council of CORE, the Council of Registrars, a group of more than 80 companies that handle domain-name registrations for businesses and individuals worldwide -- and that all must funnel registrations to Network Solutions. ''If domain names were ''800'' numbers or cell phone numbers, and someone announced that there would be no more phone numbers issued for 12 to 18 months, there would be concern.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/11/busin.snippet: Mutual fund investors seeking safety sometimes face unexpected risks as managers of conservative-sounding funds maximize holdings in relatively volatile types of securities to boost yields; managers are under pressure because majority of funds hav...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/11/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds Report; In Search Of A Foothold In Rocky Times
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/11/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds Report; In Search Of A Foothold In Rocky Times
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/11/busin.body_text: **********AS stock and bond markets around the world became more volatile last year, mutual fund investors sought safety. But they did not always get it. **********Some of the very mutual fund managers whose conservative-sounding funds were most in demand reached aggressively for yield, pushing their holdings of relatively volatile types of securities to the limit. **********Consider the CGM Fixed Income fund, a long-term bond fund. Most such funds perform well when long-term interest rates fall rapidly. But in spite of a decline in rates in the fourth quarter, the CGM fund lost 5 percent of its value as the price of one security cratered. The only bond funds that did worse were invested in Asian emerging markets. CGM declined to identify the problem holding, but it recently pushed its junk bond allocation to a third of its portfolio, the fund's self-imposed limit. **********Investors should brace for more blowups in bond funds, said Burton J. Greenwald, who provides advice to mutual funds from his firm in Philadelphia. ''I think you may already have some managers who have been tempted to overreach,'' he said. And stock funds may hold some surprises. ''It seems that after three years of such incredible ebullience in the marketplace, some funds might be further out on a limb than investors realize,'' he said. **********If so, it comes at an inopportune time. At the end of last year, investors made a clear shift to more conservative funds. Government bond funds attracted more money than they lost in the fourth quarter -- the first time they had done so in four years. Growth-and-income funds, the most conservative class of general equity funds, took in nearly half of the money coming into American stock funds, the most since 1989. And investors, unnerved by the tumult in Asian and domestic markets, put a bigger portion of their new fund dollars into money market funds. **********But fund managers have a far different view of the world. Even as they have posted solid gains, their frustrations have grown because they have found it more difficult to keep up with low-cost unmanaged portfolios, like those that track the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. For the fourth year in a row in 1997, the average stock fund failed to beat the index. **********Most bond funds had trouble keeping up with their benchmark, too. As long-term interest rates fell below 6 percent, to their lowest point in two years, the average taxable bond fund produced a total return of 8.85 percent for the year, according to Morningstar Inc., below the 9.6 percent return of the Lehman Brothers Aggregate bond index. **********There were a few bright spots. Funds that specialize in financial services, the best-performing sector of the last five years, continued their torrid pace in 1997, gaining 46 percent. And in the final three months of the year, utility funds, one of the worst-performing groups over the last five years, topped the performance lists. **********Still, the majority of funds had disappointing returns when compared with their indexes. Is it any wonder that some of their managers reached for higher returns in some surprising ways? **********Consider the Oppenheimer Global Growth and Income fund. The manager's midyear report practically screamed ''stability,'' stating in all capital letters that the fund is intended for people ''who need to reduce the effect of short-term market fluctuations.'' **********So what were shareholders to think when they opened the most recent report? They found that nearly one-fifth of their assets were invested in some of the most volatile securities around -- zero-coupon Treasury strips, a form of a long-term Treasury bond that reacts sharply to changes in interest rates. By last week, moreover, the portfolio manager, Frank Jennings, had doubled that bet, placing 40 percent of the fund in zero-coupon Treasuries. **********So far, the gambit has worked. Declining long-term rates helped the fund to a gain of 28.3 percent last year, and it has gained more than 20 percent in each of the last three years. Yet that performance only put the fund in the middle of the pack of 3,000 equity funds that are tracked by Morningstar and that have been around for three years or more. **********After Mr. Jennings took over the portfolio in October 1995, the fund started to adopt some riskier strategies, first by investing more in stocks of small companies and in emerging markets, then, in the last half of 1996, by creeping into zero-coupon bonds. **********The fund made a full-fledged bet on the direction of interest rates last fall. As of last week, two-fifths of the fund's $300 million in assets were invested in long-term zero-coupon Treasury bonds -- long-term Treasuries that have the interest coupon stripped away, leaving just the principal. **********''They do roughly twice as well as the long bond'' when bond prices rise and interest rates fall, Mr. Jennings said of the zeros. ''They are equivalent to 50-year Treasury bonds.'' **********Of course, their value also falls more sharply and more quickly when interest rates rise. **********A glance back to 1992 and 1994 shows what can happen when rates rise. The average taxable bond fund lost nearly 4 percent in 1994, according to Morningstar, and a few imploded. In 1992, a European currency crisis produced big losses for shareholders in many short-term world bond funds, which aimed to invest in what were then thought to be ''safe'' government securities. The category has since largely disappeared. **********Mr. Jennings bristles at the notion his strategy is speculative. ''I'm sensitive to being portrayed as a guy who's just a gunslinger,'' he said. Zero-coupon Treasuries ''are less risky than most junk bonds and most telephone company bonds. And they are less risky than Microsoft stock or a lot of stuff that is in most stock indexes.'' **********Some fund managers disagree. ''If a manager's philosophy is primarily to add value by trying to time interest rates, that is as dangerous as an equity manager who tries to time the equity market,'' said Kevin McClintock, head of taxable fixed-income funds at Dreyfus. **********The interest-rate bet seems particularly odd for a fund with a growth-and-income name. Indeed, after the fund made its regular report on its holdings last month, Morningstar moved it into the international hybrid category from the growth-and-income stock category because of its big bet on interest rates. Even Mr. Jennings acknowledges that his strategy is a bit controversial, saying ''I've gotten a certain amount of heat on the subject.'' **********STILL, Mr. Jennings points out that only about one-quarter of last year's returns came from his bond positions, and that astute stock picks -- including Nintendo, the electronic game company in Japan, and Dairy Farm International, the supermarket chain listed in Singapore -- accounted for the rest. **********Mr. Jennings said his current strategy assumed that the economy could fall into recession, leading to a bear market in stocks and ''a massive bond market rally.'' **********''I don't think the average investor appreciates that risk,'' he said, referring to recessionary prospects. **********Investors in the CGM Fixed Income fund might not have appreciated the risks they faced, either. The fund, one in a stable overseen by G. Kenneth Heebner, has been the best-performing general bond fund tracked by Lipper Analytical Services over the last three and five years -- a fact that CGM has trumpeted in advertisements. **********But the once-steady performer lost 5.1 percent of its value last quarter, even as long-term interest rates fell and the prices of long-term bonds rose. The average long-term bond fund gained 2.8 percent in the same period, according to Morningstar. **********What hurt the CMG Fixed Income portfolio? No one at Capital Growth Management, the Boston company headed by Mr. Heebner, agreed to talk about it. **********The fund's most recent portfolio, dated June 30 in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed that at least 35 percent of its $44 million in assets consisted of bonds below investment grade -- that is, high-risk junk bonds. Those bonds pay high interest rates, and their value moves more in sync with stock prices than with long-term bonds. **********A highly concentrated portfolio is characteristic of the way Mr. Heebner runs his funds. It can lead to significant outperformance when events go the fund's way. But it also means that one holding can cause a portfolio to implode. **********A call to CGM's toll-free shareholder information line produced an operator who, while declining to give her name, said ''a particular holding'' in the fund's portfolio dragged down the fund's performance last quarter. She said that she could not name the holding, but that ''the portfolio has since been restructured, about three weeks ago.'' **********The bond market is not the only place where portfolio managers have been tempted to stretch for a performance edge. A stock fund that has done so by reaching down into the tiniest of stocks, known as microcaps, and by betting big is Safeco Growth. **********One of the best performers among all diversified American stock funds for the last five years, Safeco Growth gained 50 percent last year, making it fifth best among the diversified stock funds tracked by Morningstar. Assets have exploded, with up to $20 million a day coming into the fund, helping it to triple in size over the last year, to $600 million. **********That rapid growth has led the fund to assume increasingly large positions in its favorite stocks. At the end of June, 27 percent of the fund's assets were in companies in which the fund owned more than 5 percent. Less than two years ago, such investments accounted for less than 5 percent of the fund's portfolio. **********Some of the fund's positions amount to several times the number of shares that normally trade each day. At the end of September, the Safeco fund owned more than 522,000 shares of Lifeline Systems, which markets an electronic system for summoning emergency medical assistance. That stake amounted to more than 9 percent of Lifeline's total shares, near the 10 percent limit for the fund. Other Safeco funds and employee pension plans owned 6 percent more of Lifeline. Given that a mere 13,500 Lifeline shares trade each day, it would take nearly 60 days for all the Safeco-related funds to sell all that Lifeline stock. **********And Lifeline is but one of a dozen companies in which the Safeco Growth fund has stakes of 5 to 10 percent. **********''If I believe in a stock, I think it's in the best interest of shareholders not to worry about how to get out of it,'' said Thomas M. Maguire, the Safeco fund's manager. ''This is a diversified portfolio. When I hit a home run with a stock, I'm going to make 300 or 400 percent. I'm not going to hit home runs every time, but the most I can lose in any one stock is 100 percent. The ones I'm right about will more than make up for the ones I'm wrong on.'' **********So far, at least, they have. But sometimes an entire sector falls so far that few individual securities escape unscathed. **********For an example, just look at the recent activity in the Asian stock and bond markets. When Southeast Asian currencies went into a tailspin last year, so did stocks in most emerging markets, as well as some bonds and notes issued by Asian Government agencies and banks. **********SOME American money market funds held Korean bank debt when those economies began their slump. IBC Financial Data, which tracks money market funds, said the Alliance Money Market Prime portfolio and the Alliance Capital Reserves fund had the biggest exposures last year. **********At the end of May, the most recent data filed with the S.E.C. showed that more than 5 percent of each portfolio was invested in bonds issued by the Industrial Bank of Korea and the Korean Development Bank. A spokesman for Alliance said that those funds no longer held Korean securities, adding that the ones in the portfolio early last year matured at full value in October. **********The Strong Heritage Money fund, one of last year's best performers among money market funds, also held some Korean securities at the end of August, the date of its last  report. A spokeswoman for Strong said that after those securities matured at full value, the fund did not buy any more Korean securities. **********While these money market funds escaped harm this time, other funds could get caught leaning the wrong way, especially if interest rates reverse their downward spiral of recent days.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/26/busin.snippet: Profile of Bruce A Lehman, who has announced that he will step down as Commissioner of US Patent and Trademark Office; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/26/busin.main_headline: Patents; The Commissioner quits, after focusing attention on intellectual property and making enemies.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/26/busin.print_headline: Patents; The Commissioner quits, after focusing attention on intellectual property and making enemies.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/26/busin.body_text: **********BRUCE A. LEHMAN, who announced Friday that he would step down as Commissioner of the United States Patent and Trademark Office, is not a man many people feel lukewarm about. His loyalists defend him as a visionary who has served the public admirably. His critics dismiss him as an intemperate despot who does the bidding of big business. **********But defenders and detractors tend to agree on one point: That Mr. Lehman has raised the visibility of intellectual property by transforming what was formerly a bench-warming position into a prominent perch. **********''He has been savvy about making important people understand why patents matter,'' said Robert Merges, professor of law at the University of California at Berkeley. ''He essentially has made Washington understand that patent issues are important to overall economic strategy.'' **********Mr. Lehman, who was appointed in 1993 by President Clinton, said he would resign by the end of the year because he had accomplished his goals as Commissioner. But there has been speculation for nearly a year that Secretary of Commerce William M. Daley, who is Mr. Lehman's boss, was pushing him to leave, after Mr. Lehman became embroiled in a bitter feud with his assistant commissioners. **********''Good riddance,'' said Jamie Love, director of the Consumer Project on Technology, which is based in Washington. ''He was terrible on the issue of making patents accessible to everyone on the Internet. And whatever Hollywood or the biotechnology industry wanted, he would do. His responsibility should have been to the public.'' **********Mr. Lehman, whose background was in copyrights rather than patents, fashioned himself an intellectual-property czar. **********And clearly, he would most like to be remembered for his contributions in the copyright arena. He helped, for example, to negotiate the World Intellectual Property Organization copyright agreements, which were recently approved by Congress. **********Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah and chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said the agreements were Mr. Lehman's main achievements. ''He foresaw the need to adapt copyright law to the needs of the digital age,'' Mr. Hatch said. **********Some others agreed. ''From a software industry perspective, the legacy he leaves goes well into the new millennium,'' said Robert Holleyman, president of the Business Software Alliance, a trade association. ''I couldn't overemphasize the importance of that treaty, which he was so instrumental in negotiating.'' **********Mr. Lehman championed a broad array of copyright changes, in what he hoped would be a precedent-setting White Paper on Intellectual Property and the National Information Infrastructure. But most of those proposals have been rejected, according to James Boyle, now a visiting professor at Yale University law school. **********Among the ideas, since abandoned, that were set forth in the 1995 white paper: a proposal that Internet providers be responsible for the copyright violations of subscribers. **********Professor Boyle helped persuade 100 law professors to sign a letter criticizing the white paper. ''You couldn't get 100 law professors to sign a letter agreeing that the sun will rise tomorrow,'' he said. ''But they signed this letter.'' **********Mr. Lehman was instrumental in trying to harmonize American patent laws with those of other countries. He was a driving force behind a 1995 law -- long sought by industry and other countries -- which changed the term of a patent. **********Before the new law, the life of a patent extended 17 years from the date it was issued. Now, a patent lasts for 20 years from the date of the application -- regardless of how quickly or slowly it was granted. **********The purpose of the change was to discourage so-called submarine patents, which popped up after having been submerged at the Patent Office for years or decades, often because of delaying tactics by inventors who wanted to wait for a particular technology to become widespread so as to receive maximum royalties. **********But Mr. Lehman's efforts drew the ire of independent inventors, whose cause was taken up by such unlikely allies as Phyllis Schlafly, the right-wing opponent of abortion rights; Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire and sometime Presidential candidate, and Francis Modigliani, a Nobel Prize-winning economist. **********The organized resistance of independent inventors is the main reason that other so-called harmonization legislation that was favored by Mr. Lehman has lingered on Capitol Hill for several years without becoming law. **********As the first openly gay man to be confirmed by the Senate for a Presidential appointment, Mr. Lehman entered his post with the stated goal of transforming the Patent Office into an agency that celebrated diversity. **********Indeed, two of his top officials were black men, Lawrence J. Goffney and Philip G. Hampton. But at some point, Mr. Lehman's relationship with his lieutenants went awry. Last fall, the three met with Secretary Daley in an effort to settle their differences. **********By March of this year, Mr. Goffney and Mr. Lehman had become embroiled in a bitter, public dispute. Mr. Lehman accused Mr. Goffney of incompetence, while Mr. Goffney accused Mr. Lehman of cronyism and racism. Both Mr. Hampton and Mr. Goffney have subsequently left the Patent Office for private business. **********Mr. Lehman's departure means that soon, four of the top five positions in the agency will be vacant. **********Staff members representing Vice President Al Gore have privately sought out potential nominees to succeed Mr. Lehman. An obvious candidate is Q. Todd Dickinson, a Philadelphia patent lawyer who earlier this year was appointed Deputy Commissioner. **********But the real question is not so much who will be on the Clinton Administration's short list but rather will anyone really want the job. **********The new commissioner will have little time to focus on grand policy initiatives. Instead, his time will be consumed by the mundane logistics of moving a 5,500-person agency into new office space and in shoring up the agency's trouble-ridden, billion-dollar effort to update its technological structure. **********And there is no assurance that the new commissioner would have a great deal of time to take care of even this business: if a Republican wins the Presidency in 2000, a Democratic-appointed commissioner would probably be replaced. **********Mr. Lehman ''is a very smart guy, a very aggressive guy, and he couldn't get past some of these issues,''  Professor Merges said. ''It's bound to scare off the next person. **********''In Silicon Valley, there's a term for this,'' he said. ''It's called an insurmountable opportunity.'' **********Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/25/busin.snippet: Family-controlled companies that have ruled South Korea face end of era with country's economy in crisis; that era began in 1960's, when South Korea's military rulers chose the companies, called chaebols, to industrialize nation and favored them w...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/25/busin.body_text: **********With South Korea's economy in crisis, the family-controlled companies that have been its rulers are facing the end of an era. **********That era began in the 1960's, when South Korea's military rulers chose the companies, called chaebols, to industrialize the nation and favored them with loans from a banking sector controlled by the Government. **********Under the new rules imposed by the International Monetary Fund as the price for a bailout, economic growth will slow and interest rates will climb, possibly driving more chaebols into bankruptcy. **********Market-oriented changes mandated by the I.M.F. or proposed by President-elect Kim Dae Jung -- never a fan of the chaebols in his long years as a populist dissident -- will expose the companies to fiercer competition in their previously protected home market. Financial changes will make the accounting systems used by the chaebols more transparent. It will become more difficult, for example, to have one subsidiary guarantee another's loans. **********''The I.M.F. will accelerate the process of exposing the chaebols to international market forces, and international market forces will dismember them,'' said Stephen E. Marvin, head of research for the Ssangyong Investment and Securities Company. ''The corporate restructuring will be vicious.'' **********Still, he says, the politically powerful chaebol families will not go down without a fight. ''If they get one nostril above water, they will go back to the old way in a minute,'' he said. **********For now, though, the chaebols are drowning in debts and cutting back sharply on capital investment, selling off real estate and subsidiaries, freezing or trimming wages and even eliminating jobs despite a tradition of lifetime employment. **********For many analysts and economists, change is long overdue. ''An advanced economy and chaebols cannot go together,'' said Cho Song Dung, a professor of corporate strategy at Seoul National University. **********Professor Cho said the chaebols served a role in the early development of the nation by allowing a few individuals to obtain a critical mass of scarce capital. But he said the chaebols have now each diversified into dozens of businesses, too many to manage well. The top 30 chaebols account for 40 percent of the nation's total sales, 44 percent of assets and 18 percent of employees, according to 1995 figures, the latest available from the Fair Trade Commission. **********Capital is allocated on the basis of family ties and Government connections -- sometimes oiled by bribery. Nor do chaebols use capital wisely, but instead follow one another lemming-like, resulting in overcapacity. **********''In a free market, Samsung would never get the capital to build a car factory,'' said Richard Samuelson, head of research at SBC Warburg Dillon Read in Seoul. ''The banks would say, 'Are you crazy?' '' **********But Samsung, whose chairman, Lee Kun Hee, loves cars, will start selling vehicles this spring despite a huge production glut that has forced the bankruptcy of Kia Motors and the sale of Ssangyong Motors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/13/busin.snippet: British Telecommunications PLC announces agreement to acquire MCI Communications Corp's 24.9 percent stake in companies' international joint venture for $1 billion in cash; with British Telecom's agreement to buy stake in Concert, as venture is kn...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/13/busin.main_headline: British Telecom to Acquire MCI's Stake in Joint Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/13/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; British Telecom to Acquire MCI's Stake in Joint Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/13/busin.body_text: **********Pulling one of the final threads from its tattered relationship with the MCI Communications Corporation, British Telecommunications P.L.C. announced an agreement yesterday to acquire MCI's 24.9 percent stake in the companies' international joint venture for $1 billion in cash. **********Yesterday's deal was the denouement in a five-year relationship that began with high hopes for a global telecommunications partnership, blossomed into plans for a merger and then fell apart amid a fight over money. **********With British Telecom's agreement to buy the stake in Concert, as the venture is known, the British communications giant will be free to move forward with plans to form a $10 billion joint venture with MCI's rival, the AT&T Corporation. **********Neither MCI nor British Telecom would make any executives available yesterday to discuss the deal. **********Concert, which British Telecom formed in 1994, is meant to be a vehicle for serving the global communications needs of multinational corporations. With service in 52 nations, Concert tries to allow its customers to use a seamless network that functions identically in New York or New Zealand. **********After buying MCI's portion of Concert, British Telecom will own the entire venture. The British company expects Concert to generate about $1 billion in revenue and to become profitable this year. Financial analysts are unlikely to balk at the implicit value of $4 billion that yesterday's deal placed on the operation. **********British Telecom's American depository receipts, which trade on the New York Stock Exchange, rose $2 yesterday, to $133.375. MCI rose $1.625, to $61.75, on Nasdaq. **********MCI, the No. 2 long-distance carrier in the United States, began its dealings with British Telecom in 1993, when B.T. bought 20 percent of the American company for $4.3 billion. The companies formed Concert the next year. **********In 1996, they announced that British Telecom had agreed to acquire the 80 percent of MCI it did not already own for $24 billion, forming a trans-Atlantic communications giant called Concert P.L.C. **********But the relationship soured last summer. Both companies' shareholders had already approved the deal and the companies were seeking regulatory approvals when MCI said in July that it could lose as much as $800 million in its nascent local phone operation. **********British Telecom reacted to the announcement by essentially forcing MCI to accept a $5 billion reduction in the value of their deal, making it worth $19 billion. **********That opened the door for other communications carriers to bid for MCI, which was not entirely pleased with the latest turn in its relationship with British Telecom. **********Worldcom Inc., led by Bernard J. Ebbers, offered $30 billion in stock for all of MCI early last October. Two weeks later, GTE jumped into the competition with a $28 billion cash bid. **********British Telecom did not make a serious attempt to hold on to MCI. After a flurry of negotiations between MCI, Worldcom and GTE, MCI agreed to be acquired by Worldcom for $37 billion in stock. **********That deal will probably be completed in the next month. For its 20 percent stake in MCI, British Telecom will receive $7 billion in cash. As for Concert, AT&T will become British Telecom's main partner as soon as the British company finishes buying out MCI.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/10/world.snippet: International commission set up 52 years ago to return gold that Nazi Germany seized from central banks of countries it occupied closes its books and disbands after returning most of last six tons to original claimants; Tripartite Gold Commission ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/10/world.main_headline: International Panel Closes Books on Gold Seized by Nazis in War
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/10/world.print_headline: International Panel Closes Books on Gold Seized by Nazis in War
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/10/world.body_text: **********An international commission set up 52 years ago to return gold that Nazi Germany seized from central banks of countries it occupied closed its books and disbanded today after returning most of the last six tons to the original claimants. **********In early 1997 the Tripartite Gold Commission delayed distribution of the gold, then valued at $68 million, amid disagreements about going ahead despite the possibility that money, jewelry and tooth fillings of Holocaust victims might have become mixed up with it. **********After some hesitation, France joined the United States and Britain -- the other members of the commission -- in pledging money to a relief fund for individual victims who might have claims on the monetary gold. **********About $60 million has so far been promised to the fund by 14 countries, including the three members of the tripartite commission and most of the countries that recently received the last of the gold. The total will probably rise to about $70 million, Stuart E. Eizenstat, the United States Under Secretary of State for Economic, Business and Agricultural Affairs, said today after a ceremony at the French Foreign Ministry to mark the milestone. **********''The mystery of how much victim gold was in this may never be known,'' Mr. Eizenstat said later. ''We came up with an estimate of $4 million, but it could be much higher.'' **********The French Foreign Ministry, which has opened the Tripartite Gold Commission archives to the public, said France would contribute $3.45 million to the relief fund. The United States has pledged $25 million, and Britain $1.7 million. **********Of the original 370 tons of foreign monetary gold reserves that the World War II Allies recovered from Germany in 1945, only $300,000 worth belonging to Yugoslavia has not been returned. That gold will remain on deposit in the Bank of England, officials said, until Yugoslavia's successor states can agree on its disposal. **********The actual amount of gold the Nazis seized from occupied countries' banks and from victims of the Holocaust was much higher than the amount the Tripartite Gold Commission recovered. **********Some is thought to have gone to Switzerland, which has been in an uproar for most of the last two years over charges by Jewish groups that Swiss authorities knowingly sold gold belonging to Holocaust victims for the Germans, and that Swiss banks held onto assets of the Nazis' victims instead of trying to restore them to their heirs. **********France decided only last year to renew efforts to find the owners of hundreds of artworks seized by German occupation authorities or their French collaborators during the war, and is trying to produce an inventory from files that had lain untouched for most of the past 50 years. **********Insurance companies that failed to pay claims to survivors of Holocaust victims and German companies that employed slave laborers during the war are the latest to face class action lawsuits. **********The United States has organized a conference in Washington in late November to discuss guidelines for museums, art dealers and galleries on dealing with problems of disputed ownership. **********Austria said today that after years of refusing to allow artworks to be shipped out of the country to claimants living abroad, it would now agree to restore to their rightful owners hundreds of art objects confiscated by the Nazis. **********''We want to document that at the end of the historically burdened 20th century we want to clear things up once and for all,'' Elisabeth Gehrer, the Minister for Education and Cultural Affairs, said in Vienna. **********Two paintings by the Expressionist Egon Schiele lent by the Leopold Foundation in Austria to the Museum of Modern Art in New York City have been held there since last January because of a pending ownership claim by surviving members of a Jewish family that lived in Austria when the Nazis took over.
