https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/24/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 2 Big Assignments For Messner Vetere
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/24/busin.body_text: **********Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York has been awarded two assignments that together have combined billings estimated at $60 million to $80 million. **********Volvo Cars of North America has expanded its relationship with Messner Vetere, its lead agency, by naming the shop to handle consolidated national dealer advertising, with billings estimated at $30 million to $40 million. Those duties had been handled by various agencies including Messner Vetere, which creates campaigns for dealers in such markets as metropolitan New York. **********Bob Austin, director for marketing communications at Volvo Cars in Rockleigh, N.J., confirmed reports of the assignment this week in Advertising Age and Adweek. The decision came without a review, he said, adding that Messner Vetere, which is owned by Havas Advertising, would create a spinoff agency, to be named Fuel North America, dedicated to dealer ads. **********The opening of Fuel is part of a trend as agencies open stand-alone units to handle duties for important automotive clients. TBWA/Chiat/ Day, for instance, part of Omnicom Group, plans to start a spinoff named Blacktop Advertising to handle the retail advertising part of its Nissan Motor Corporation account. **********The other new assignment for Messner Vetere comes from the Universal Studios Recreation Group, part of the Seagram Company, which named the agency to handle creative duties for its revamped theme park in Orlando, Fla., Universal Studios Escape. **********The account, with billings estimated at $30 million to $40 million, had been handled by Foote, Cone & Belding in New York, part of True North Communications. **********Elayne Garofolo, executive vice president for worldwide marketing at the recreation group in Hollywood, confirmed a report of the assignment this week in Adweek. **********Messner Vetere was awarded the account, she said, after a three-month review that also included TBWA/Chiat/Day in Playa del Rey, Calif. DDB Needham New York, which is also owned by Omnicom, handles media buying for the account. The Los Angeles office of Foote, Cone continues to handle advertising for Universal Studios.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/15/busin.snippet: Profile of and interview with Joseph M Juran, 93, world's pre-eminent living expert on quality of products and organizations that produce them; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/15/busin.main_headline: The Guru of Doing It Right Still Sees Much Work to Do
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/15/busin.print_headline: TALKING QUALITY WITH -- JOSEPH M. JURAN; The Guru of Doing It Right Still Sees Much Work to Do
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/15/busin.body_text: **********IT is hard to believe that Joseph M. Juran is 93 years old. **********His hazel eyes still alternately twinkle and pierce, his smile fluctuates between gracious and sardonic, his wit is keen and sharp. And never mind that he has spent two days holding court in a conference room at the Warwick Hotel in New York, patiently doing one-on-ones with reporters wanting to hear his take on whether American industry finally has its problems with quality under control. He looks rested and positively dapper in his dark suit and bow tie, fielding yet another stream of queries. **********But then, novelty tends to perk up anyone. And for Dr. Juran, arguably the world's pre-eminent living expert on quality in products and the organizations that produce them (W. Edwards Deming, after all, died in 1993), sitting still for interviews is novel indeed. Then again, he is writing his memoirs, so maybe this is a dry run for a book tour. **********Whatever his reasons for opening up, when Dr. Juran talks quality, people listen. **********A native of Romania who emigrated to Minneapolis with his family at the age of 8, Dr. Juran graduated from the University of Minnesota with an electrical engineering degree in 1924 and has been stumping the campaign trail for quality ever since. He earned a law degree from Loyola of Chicago in 1936, in case he needed something to fall back on during the Depression, but he never found law as compelling as management. **********Indeed, decades before re-engineering became a management buzzword, Dr. Juran was applying his then-radical concepts of empowered worker teams and continuous quality improvement to reduce defects at Western Electric's Chicago Hawthorne Works. During World War II, he and his techniques helped  cut the time it took to process military supply orders from the front to 36 hours from 99 days. **********His ''Quality Control Handbook,'' published in 1951, and ''Managerial Breakthrough,'' in 1964, have been hailed by management gurus like Peter Drucker as springboards from which American manufacturers could launch their sporadic leaps into quality. In fact, such praise has been heaped on various speeches and white papers and consulting projects that his Juran Foundation has churned out since he founded it in 1979. **********NOT surprisingly, Dr. Juran does not mince words when he talks about how Japanese companies from carmakers to electronics whizzes have cleaned corporate America's clock on quality issues. He refuses to name today's offenders -- ''it would be unethical for me to point to companies that just can't get their quality right,'' he said -- but he readily condemns companies for quality sins of the past. **********''The Japanese started their quality revolution right after World War II, and it took them until 1975 before they caught up with the West in quality,'' he said. ''Our companies didn't start fighting back until 1980, and even then, most of their initiatives failed.'' **********Why the poor record? In Dr. Juran's mind, the buck stops squarely at the top. **********''C.E.O's have always left quality to chance or to committees, never to people high-level enough to make decisions,'' he said. ''So the workers would use statistical tools to quantify costs and defects, and they'd set goals and monitor progress toward them.'' **********Why is that so bad? He explained: ''Say there's always been a chronic scrap problem that could be solved, but that the workers just think is inevitable and gets built into the goal. It's a problem, but it's treated like a fate.'' **********Dr. Juran has no patience with talk about motivating workers to produce higher-quality products. ''Companies like General Motors would post big slogans like 'Do it right the first time' on every plant wall,'' he said.  ''Well, that sounds great on the transmitting end, but considering that operator mistakes and oversights cause maybe 15 percent of quality problems, it's pretty insulting on the receiving end.'' **********BUT he is no cranky pessimist. He reckons that swelling numbers of companies are finally getting it right on quality -- raising service and customer-satisfaction levels as costs, defects and product-development cycles plummet. **********They are the companies that have learned to do triage on their problems with quality. They let line workers deal with the ''trivial many,'' the hundreds of little glitches from a screw that needs oiling to an inefficient mail delivery schedule -- minor quality problems that nonetheless can add up. But these companies do not hesitate to devote plenty of high-level resources to the ''vital few'' -- the materials or procedures or people that cause the most problems. **********Consider the case of the auto company and the leaky cabs. By Mr. Juran's recollection, anyone driving that company's trucks in the rain got wet. But not all the truck cabs leaked in the same places, so the design errors were not easy to ferret out. Rather than let workers keep plugging isolated leaks, the company asked a team to diagram exactly where the leaks were occurring in a host of cabs. They found that three locations accounted for 90 percent of the leaks. **********''They redesigned just those spots,'' Dr. Juran recalled. ''Now, instead of an average of three leaky spots in every cab, they have an average of just one leak in every three cabs.'' **********The solutions are not always so predictable, leading Dr. Juran to  point out another attribute of companies that know how to tackle quality: ''They are prepared to turn over a rock and deal with some pretty strange stuff underneath.'' **********A case in point: A few years ago, another auto maker, realizing that too many of its cars were going out with unbalanced wheels, formed a team to figure out why. The trouble turned out to be not in the wheels but rather in the testing equipment: It gave inconsistent results, and the readouts were too small for plant workers to see without hunkering close. **********So what started as a project to overhaul wheel making turned into a joint project with the supplier of the testing machine to calibrate the equipment better and provide it with a bright digital readout. Once the new gear was in use, ''fewer cars needed servicing because of imbalanced wheels, and as a bonus, the company could actually cut its field service staff,'' Dr. Juran recalled. **********THE ability to dissect a problem into chewable chunks is another characteristic of a quality-savvy company, Dr. Juran said. The example he cites is, of all things, a Hawaiian-themed resort with a troupe of hula dancers who were not dancing up to par. Hotel managers told them to solve their problem or else. So they trained a video camera on themselves and analyzed the tapes, spotting which dancers made which missteps at which points in the show. **********''Some steps every dancer had trouble with, so they changed the choreography,'' Mr. Duran recalled. ''Good dancers that got a few steps wrong got better training. Dancers that made lots of mistakes on lots of steps just got canned.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/02/world.snippet: Kenya's wild animals are threatened by country's farmers, who for 20 years have been encroaching on lands that were once wild and who now regard wild animals as pests; the 8 percent of Kenya's land that is set for wild animals cannot accommodate t...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/02/world.main_headline: It's Kenya's Farmers vs. Wildlife, and the Animals Are Losing
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/02/world.print_headline: It's Kenya's Farmers vs. Wildlife, and the Animals Are Losing
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/02/world.body_text: **********On a clear day, Agnes Patita can see the tourists in vans inching along dirt roads, searching the plains for antelope, zebra, giraffe and, if they are lucky, an elusive pride of lions. **********But the majestic cats the tourists pay to see are dangerous pests to Mrs. Patita. Lions have killed more than 20 cattle here in the last two months. On a recent night, two lions broke into the Patitas' corral and killed 10 goats and sheep. **********''The problem is they kill the livestock we depend on for school fees, for food, for everything,'' Mrs. Patita said. ''The tourists don't understand. They travel in cars. They don't live the way we live.'' **********The clash between farmers and lions in Kitengela reflects a growing conflict between people and wild animals in this East African country that conservationists say poses a serious threat to the survival of wildlife. During the last 20 years, aerial surveys show, Kenya's wildlife has been disappearing steadily as the country's human population expands and farmers encroach on lands that were once wild, biologists say. At the same time, small-scale poaching for meat by Kenya's impoverished rural people has also increased, conservationists say. **********Although Kenya sets aside 8 percent of its land for national parks, the protected areas are not large enough to accommodate the animals' migration. At any given time, most of the animals are not within the parks, and so they trespass on increasingly crowded farmland. **********Since 1977, when hunting was made illegal here, at least 40 percent of the range animals have disappeared from Kenya's savannahs -- a drop of at least 412,000 animals --  and they are continuing to disappear at a rate of 2 percent to 3 percent a year, according to an analysis of government surveys. **********For some species -- the Thomson's gazelle, the waterbuck, the greater kudu, the oryx and the elephant -- the declines have been steeper, far above 50 percent. **********Kenya's creeping ecological debacle has set off a strenuous debate among ranchers, scientists, conservationists and small farmers over how to reverse the trend. **********One camp, led by the current director of the Kenya Wildlife Service, David Western, wants to find ways to make wildlife profitable for local people and give them a reason to  protect the animals. **********Another, led by the former head of the wildlife service, Richard Leakey, argues that Kenya should instead fence off wild lands, more strictly enforce anti-poaching laws and, in essence, give up on trying to stop the decline of wildlife elsewhere. **********Ranchers, meanwhile, argue that they have the right to use the wildlife on their lands, so they will have a financial interest in maintaining them. Under current Kenyan law, the state owns all wildlife, and it is illegal to sell or hunt them without a permit. Giving landowners custody would open the door to profitable ventures like sport hunting and exporting animals to zoos and game reserves. **********For Kenya the stakes in the debate are extremely high. The country's beauty and picturesque wildlife are among its few natural resources.  Along with beaches and coral reefs on the coast, the African wildlife attracts tourists who spend about $400 million a year, the largest single earner of foreign exchange. **********But now most of those earnings never find their way into the pockets of small farmers and herders who must put up with the destruction wild animals cause on their lands. **********Conservationists like Mr. Western are encouraging farmers and ranchers to pool their lands, open private game parks and get into the tourist business themselves. These projects are already operating in a half-dozen Kenyan communities, and plans have been drawn up for 30 more. **********''If you want to preserve the wildlife, you have to find a way to make money on it,'' said Nicholas Georgiadis, an ecologist who heads the private Mpala Research Center in Laikipia. ''Can you create a balance where the wildlife creates enough income so that people want to maintain it?'' **********Lots of People, Not Much Farmland **********The projects that have succeeded, like the Il Ngwezi Sanctuary in Samburu district, have done so because a small number of families have shared in the profits and because they have received financial help and training from international conservation organizations. **********In other places, though, the slim revenues from the sanctuaries have been either spread too thinly among the owners of the land or skimmed off by corrupt local officials. Some of the sanctuaries also lack trained managers able to run a successful tourist resort. **********''Patience will run out unless these newly introduced forms of land use can see tangible benefits,'' said Nehemiah K. Rotich, chairman of the East Africa Wildlife Society. ''They would like to see wildlife making money.'' **********But Mr. Leakey argues that such projects will never succeed on a scale large enough to save wildlife. He and other conservationists maintain that it is a pipe dream to think such schemes can reverse the underlying causes of the decline. Not only is there a human population explosion coupled with little arable land, but Kenya also has no comprehensive land-use plan that would zone land for wildlife, agriculture and cattle. **********''We have to deal with the fact that we have islands of wildlife,'' Mr. Leakey said. ''What we need is the political leadership to say we need these parks intact. The antagonism to wildlife can be dealt with as the antagonism to tax collectors is dealt with.'' **********In 1946 when the first park, Nairobi National Park, was established, there were only five million people living in Kenya. **********Now there are 30 million trying to eke out a living on the same land, and only about a fifth of the country receives enough rainfall to raise cash crops. **********In the last 20 years, tens of thousands of people have migrated into lands not suitable for farming. These farmers have plowed under and overgrazed buffer zones around parks and reserves that the animals must use as dispersal areas during wet seasons, wildlife officials say. Wild lands in Kenya have been disappearing at a rate of 2 percent a year, they said. **********Impoverished people, many facing extreme hunger because they are trying to farm in arid regions not suitable for crops, have poached thousands of animals for food. **********While the Government's anti-poaching efforts, begun in the late 1980's, dramatically slowed down the wholesale slaughter of elephants and rhinoceroses in the last eight years, the local police have done little or nothing to stop a burgeoning underground trade in bush-meat, conservationists say. **********''It's totally illegal but everyone's doing it,'' said Rob Barnett, of Traffic, an environmental organization that has just completed a study showing the trade in bush-meat is thriving in Kenya. ''The law-enforcement people aren't enforcing the laws.'' **********Perhaps the most extensive clash between man and beast has taken place in the Taita Hills, a range of mountains sandwiched like a peninsula of humanity between the western and eastern halves of the Tsavo park. **********Competition for land during the last 25 years has forced tens of thousands of Taita people, who in the past lived on the fertile slopes of the mountains, to move down onto the rangelands below, an arid savannah that was carved up into large communal ranches for cattle grazing in the 1960's. These migrants have splintered much of the ranchland into smaller farms, and they have run into constant battles with elephants, lions and buffaloes. **********At the park headquarters near the town of Voi, Crisant Mueme is a ranger whose job is smoothing out the park's ruffled relations with farmers. **********He and his colleagues keep a dog-eared log book that reads like a police blotter in a big city, except the criminals are all animals. One night a lion takes 10 goats. On another an elephant tramples a man coming home from a bar. Nine people are injured chasing buffaloes from their fields. There are pages and pages of entries about zebras, elephants and buffaloes destroying crops. **********In 1997 alone, there were 87 reports of elephants trampling crops and two people were killed by the mammoth animals. Rangers were forced to kill three rogue elephants during the same period. **********''We are trying to educate the community about the importance of wildlife and how we can benefit from it,'' Mr. Mueme said. ''They are listening to us, but it takes time.'' **********One place where animals have wreaked havoc is the Mramba Group Ranch, a 30,000-acre piece of land right on the border of the western half of Tsavo park. **********Last year, two people were trampled to death by elephants in Mramba, Mr. Mueme said. Farmers there report constant problems, mostly lions killing cattle and elephants eating crops. An electric fence has been erected around the parts of the ranch under cultivation. But the animals are already finding ways around it, local officials say. **********Despite these problems, the governors of Mramba ranch have asked permission from the wildlife service to set up a game sanctuary, hoping to cash in on the tourists visiting Tsavo park and a second private sanctuary in Taita run by Hilton Hotels. **********Living With Wildlife: The Practical Value **********''We have lived along with the wildlife but we haven't benefited from it,'' said Richard Mwambili, a member of the governing committee of the ranch. Mr. Mwambili said the ranch does not yet have the resources to build roads and lodges needed to attract tourists. Though 15 camp scouts have been trained by the wildlife service, they remain idle, he said. **********The delay has frustrated many residents. To overtake what the ranch can now make from cattle, Mr. Mwambili said the sanctuary would have to make more than $300,000 a year from tourism, and it will take several years to build up a steady stream of tourists. **********''I'm going to be the manager,'' he said. ''But I'm not managing anything at the moment.'' **********Still, many farmers in Mramba say they are willing to give the sanctuary a chance, despite their long-running war with wildlife. **********Tourism or Farming: That's the Choice **********''The animals are not good and they are not bad,'' Mr. Mwikamba said. ''If the game sanctuary is put up at Mramba some of my own children might be employed there. If the tourists come, the money from tourism might help sending our children to school.'' **********Unfortunately for park officials, only 3 of the 28 community ranches in Taita have accepted the notion of tourism as an alternative to agriculture, wildlife officials say. **********More than half are considering parceling out lands to families for farms, despite the constant threat of  drought there. It is a formula wildlife officials maintain would mean losing more vital dispersal areas and migratory paths for animals. **********In all, 58 percent of the animal population of Tsavo, some 106,600 individuals, vanished between 1973 and 1993, said Mohammed Dhidha, the regional biodiversity coordinator in Tsavo. **********''Nothing short of a land-use policy by the Government will stop this,'' said James Ndungu, a wildlife official in charge of community coordination.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/busin.snippet: A pathbreaking meeting of government officials and business executives at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development agreed Wednesday that government's role should be to create environments in which business can flourish rather than...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/busin.main_headline: OECD Talks Urge State to Help Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/busin.print_headline: OECD Talks Urge State to Help Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/busin.body_text: **********A pathbreaking meeting of government officials and business executives at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development agreed Wednesday that government's role should be to create environments in which business can flourish rather than to try to tell business what it should do. **********The meeting was the first-ever international gathering of industrial ministers and the first OECD meeting to invite executives to participate and provide their input to the formulation of policy. **********Speaking positively of the result, John Bulloch, a Canadian executive, said, "At least the politicians are now all singing from the same hymnal." **********That was the emphasis put on the result by the meeting's chairman, Margaret Beckett, president of the Board of Trade in Britain. **********Acknowledging that not all 29 organization member countries hold identical views on the role of government in business, Ms. Beckett said: "There are differing degrees of opinion. But what is extraordinary is that everyone agrees about the direction policy has to take." **********One of the concrete results of the meeting was a mandate for the organization to expand its comparative evaluation of government policies aimed at supporting industry so that benchmarks of best practices could be established. **********"Seeking the input of businessmen is a major change," David Aaron, the U.S. undersecretary of commerce, said in an interview. "It does make a difference having real businessmen talking about business." **********He said the meeting showed "strong support for private-sector, market-driven solutions to problems — that's a big change" and one that is "likely to lead to a lighter hand" of regulation. **********The thrust of the meeting was twofold: that small and midsize companies are the major creators of jobs and that the industrial paradigm is changing from a focus on physical production and output to a knowledge-based economy where intangibles such as quality and service are of growing importance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/14/techn.snippet: Ericsson AB, Swedish-based telephone company, to introduce in United States later this year its smallest mobile telephone, which includes such things as voice mail and caller ID device; phone is 4 inches tall and weighs 4.7 ounces; photo (S)

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/14/techn.body_text: **********Small is good, or at least that's what the designers at Ericsson, the Swedish-based telecommunications giant, are betting as the company introduces its smallest mobile telephone-and-more to the United States. **********The phone, 4 inches tall and 4.7 ounces, is called the Ericsson CF 788 and comes with features that appear primed to drive gadget gurus ga-ga. Besides being small enough to slip easily into a purse or shirt pocket, the phone -- which bears a striking resemblance to Captain Kirk's retro-futuristic flip-top communicator -- can accept short E-mail messages. It will probably cost around $200 and will also have voice mail, phone-to-phone text messaging and caller ID. **********''There are a lot of things you can do with your mobile phone these days,'' said Mike Sullivan, the director of channel management at Ericsson, talking about the CF 788. **********Introduced in the New York area earlier this year, the telephone is expected to roll out over the rest of the United States this month, Mr. Sullivan said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/20/world.snippet: Many experts say one factor behind economic crisis that is reverberating around world is fantastic increase in pool of capital that is moved from one country to next and one currency to next in search of safety and profit; the sums are so gargantu...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/20/world.main_headline: Experts Question Roving Flow of Global Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/20/world.print_headline: Experts Question Roving Flow of Global Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/20/world.body_text: **********They were the world's richest and shrewdest investors, and they rode a wave of globalization to buy bonds in a promising developing country. When the country defaulted, they were livid. **********''There should be lunatic asylums for nations as well as individuals,'' one investor wrote in The Morning Post of London, denouncing the defaulting country as ''a nation with whom no contracts can be made.'' **********It all sounds a bit familiar, but the year was 1842 and the developing country was the United States. After defaults by Maryland, Pennsylvania, Mississippi and Louisiana, the entire United States was blacklisted and scorned on global markets, with Americans barred from the best London clubs and the Rothschilds warning bitterly that America would be unable to ''borrow a dollar, not a dollar.'' **********Globalization, in other words, may not be quite as fresh as it sometimes seems. Since at least the 13th century, when Florentine merchants lent money to the English to pay for King Edward I's wars, international capital has roamed the world in search of high returns. (The start was inauspicious: England defaulted, causing the collapse of two Florentine banks.) **********What has changed, economists say, is the scale of the capital flows and their ability to capsize small nations -- or even large ones. Many experts say that one factor behind the economic crisis that has devastated Asia and Russia, wobbled South America, and now come knocking on America's own door is the fantastic increase in the pool of capital that sloshes from one country to the next in search of safety and profit. **********The sums are so gargantuan -- far greater than the amounts that governments can wield -- that a growing number of economists are calling for new steps to control these capital flows or at least soften their impact. Some say that the Bretton Woods economic system, which has governed the global economy for half a century, has been eclipsed by these vast pools of capital, and there are calls to design a new ''architecture'' for the global economic order. **********The topic is expected to be widely discussed at next month's special meeting of finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven industrialized countries, summoned by President Clinton to discuss the global crisis. Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, has already discussed measures to ease the volatility of capital flows with Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and with his British counterpart, Gordon Brown. **********The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, weighed in this week with a denunciation of rigid capital controls but a call to confront the problem by tightening supervision over banks that engage in international finance. All of a sudden, a vigorous debate is under way, and it may shape the global economy for decades to come. **********''We'll have to rethink the system in a big way,'' said Jagdish Bhagwati, a prominent scholar of international economics at Columbia University. ''The President has called this conference, and it should be the start of that process.'' **********Professor Bhagwati urged that the new architecture should ''give up the notion that the optimal world is one characterized by free capital flows, by capital account convertability, where you just press a button and take out a billion.'' **********The Clinton Administration has led a global push to free the flow of capital around the world, and any new impediments to capital flows would be an abrupt step back for its campaign. As recently as last March, the International Monetary Fund newsletter carried a front-page headline cheerily declaring capital liberalization to be ''an irreversible trend.'' **********These days, it looks more reversible. Some economists believe that despite a wealth of scholarly research showing the need for caution, the United States pushed too hard for capital liberalization. The result, they say, was that tides of investment flooded into ill-prepared developing countries and created speculative bubbles, and then surged out, leaving behind shattered nations and a global financial crisis. **********''I actually think the I.M.F. was too pushy in going around the accepted wisdom and encouraging countries to liberalize their capital accounts too soon,'' said Ronald I. McKinnon, an economist at Stanford University and author of a book on capital liberalization. ''And not the least of the reasons behind this was arm-twisting by the United States Treasury, which always wants American banks and Wall Street people to be in there, competing freely.'' **********Still, there is no question that freer capital flows have brought tremendous benefits to the global economy, as well as perils. Some places, like Hong Kong, have opened themselves to capital flows without restriction and are examples of the prosperity that free movements of capital can reap. Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, likens the flows to jet planes, observing that jets bring enormous efficiencies and benefits to the world -- but that the crashes are more spectacular than ever. **********What are these capital flows? **********They are not some sinister force, but simply the result of ordinary people's cash roaming in search of a good return. When an American deposits money at the corner bank, some of that may end up being lent to a Brazilian company, and the same person's pension fund may dabble in the Hong Kong stock market. **********In the United States, trading in foreign securities amounted to 2 percent of gross national product in 1975 and 213 percent last year, according to data from the Bank for International Settlements. **********Paradoxically, historians sometimes attribute the modern boom in international capital, beyond the easy reach of any regulator, to the Communists. In the 1950's, China and Russia kept their dollars out of the United States, for fear Washington would freeze their accounts, and instead deposited the dollars in Europe. **********One result was the ''Eurodollar'' market and a growing investment pool that flitted from country to country and currency to currency in pursuit of higher interest rates. The amount of foreign currency bank deposits around the world reached $1 billion only in 1961 and now is almost $1.5 trillion. **********One problem, though, is that a lot of this is ''hot money,'' or short-term flows that are particularly volatile. **********Even in the 19th century, sailing ships used to carry gold to distant countries in pursuit of higher interest rates. In 1849, England raised its interest rate by 2 percentage points, prompting an early demonstration of the volatility of capital flows: ships that were already at sea, headed for America with their gold, turned around and sailed to England to get the higher rate. **********Most governments imposed capital controls early in this century and then lifted them in the 1970's and 80's, and limitations on changing money came to be seen as quaint. Paradoxically, it is the holdouts with capital controls, like China and India, that have weathered the financial crisis much better than others, because they were not vulnerable to a sudden exodus of capital. **********''I've been told, 'China seems to be coming out of the crisis well because it has capital controls, so what's wrong with reimposing controls?' '' said Linda Tsao Yang, the American envoy to the Asian Development Bank. **********Ms. Yang and other American officials are wary of capital controls, however, particularly the rigid kind imposed by Malaysia that ban most investments from being taken out of the country within the first year. Scholars say that such capital controls offer short-term benefits but tend to discourage investment in the long run and often get mired in corruption and inefficiency. **********''There is a significant risk that over the next three or four quarters short-term results from Malaysia will be seen as beneficial,'' said William R. Cline, the chief economist of the Institute of International Finance in Washington. ''An illusory temporary success could tempt other countries to follow suit.'' **********The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development this week backed the right of countries to adopt emergency capital controls like Malaysia's. Even the Far Eastern Economic Review, a conservative Hong Kong-based magazine owned by Dow Jones & Company, declared its sympathy for capital controls in a recent editorial. **********''As we look to Malaysia's unorthodoxy,'' it said, ''we hold our nose and cross our fingers.'' **********While Western economists are mostly unimpressed by Malaysia's controls, many speak highly of a quasi tax that Chile has imposed on short-term borrowings from abroad. With that measure, which the country is in the process of dismantling, Chile has been able to attract foreign capital, but has been less vulnerable to a sudden exodus. **********The specific proposals that G-7 finance ministers might discuss to deal with capital flows are unclear. But there is vague talk of increasing supervision over borrowing banks and of establishing funds that could be used to insure depositors or counteract speculative attacks. **********''Outright controls on the flow of funds are virtually impossible in this modern, integrated world,'' said Yuji Tsushima, a finance expert in Japan's Parliament. ''But we should have some device through which if the volatility of the market gets too disturbing, it could be mitigated.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/busin.snippet: Gretchen Morgenson column on impact on bond market over issue of whether Federal Reserve's interest-rate cuts will forestall US economic recession and improve credit availability; graph (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH; Oh, Those Yawning Spreads
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/busin.body_text: **********True or false: The Federal Reserve's recent interest-rate cuts, and those expected forthwith, will forestall an economic recession in the United States and lower the risk that credit will dry up across the economy. **********True, said the stock market as it meandered upward last week. In one of the calm est five-day trading stretches in months, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 8,452.29, up four-tenths of 1 percent. **********The bond market, however, isn't sure that all is well yet. Smoke signals from much of the non-Treasury bond markets say a recession remains a possibility. Moreover, while it is unclear whether banks have stopped lending to good customers, the bond markets are still gripped by catalepsy. And so a credit crisis might start there. **********Because movements of various fixed-income instruments, like mortgage-backed securities and high-yield bonds, aren't as easily tracked as stocks, what the bond market is saying isn't immediately evident. But one sign of continued fear among these investors is the difference between the yields they demand on junk bonds and those paid by Treasury securities with like maturities. This difference is known as the spread. **********When investors embrace risk, as they did last spring, spreads between Treasury issues and more speculative debt are narrow. As investors rush into riskier bonds, their prices rise and yields decline. When investors shun risk, as they are now, spreads widen. **********Despite the Fed's latest reduction in interest rates, on Oct. 15, spreads remain wide by historical standards. The estimated yield on Salomon Smith Barney's index of high-yield bonds exceeds that on Treasuries by 6.82 percentage points, compared with a 5.3-point spread before the rate cut. **********''This spread is reflecting a great concern that the economic environment is not very healthy and that, if anything, surprises will be on the downside,'' said Ned Riley, chief investment officer of the BankBoston Corporation. Mr. Riley agrees with the market and expects corporate earnings to be chronically disappointing for six to nine months. **********The hefty spread on junk bonds is also a sign that the huge market for these corporate bonds is still frozen. As a result, the credit squeeze that the Fed fretted about when it lowered rates remains a possibility. **********According to Mr. Riley, credit contractions can happen for two reasons. One is a result of restrictive moves by bank regulators. The other is more emotional, with lenders pulling back from loans more out of fear of default than its reality. ''It's the emotional action we have to worry about now,'' Mr. Riley said. ''As lenders become gun-shy, they can create a credit squeeze even without monetary authorities being a catalyst.'' **********Hence the interest in credit spreads. If they narrow, it will mean that lenders are becoming more optimistic about their customers' prospects. If they stay wide, a credit contraction is likely. **********Both stock and bond investors think the Fed's recent rate cuts, though welcome, are not enough. Indeed, many are hoping for a one-half-point slash in the Federal funds rate at the next Federal Open Market Committee meeting in November. **********These hopes could be dashed. Late last week, several Fed members started telegraphing that further rate cuts were not necessarily a given. In a speech on Thursday, J. Alfred Broaddus, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, said said the risk that the economy's growth rate could accelerate -- a k a inflation -- hadn't vanished. And, he said, the Fed cannot ''be held hostage'' to the markets on interest-rate policy. **********The stock market has shrugged this off. So far.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/11/world.snippet: Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin visits Pope John Paul II at Vatican; they exchange gifts and discuss year 2000 celebrations; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/11/world.main_headline: Pope and Yeltsin Chat of Much, Including the Millennium
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/11/world.print_headline: Pope and Yeltsin Chat of Much, Including the Millennium
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/11/world.body_text: **********As they exchanged gifts in the august splendor of the Vatican's Apostolic Palace, Pope John Paul II turned to President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia this evening with a wish that holds special meaning for both. **********''Let us hope we will go together toward the third millennium,'' the Pope said in a voice barely heard over the sound of whirring cameras as he gave an affectionate pat to the hand of Mr. Yeltsin's wife, Naina. **********John Paul, the first Polish Pope in history, and the Russian leader, a former Communist who became his country's first elected leader, had just emerged from 50 minutes of private conversation in which they had discussed, among other things, the celebrations for the year 2000. **********For the Pope, 77, that year will be a jubilee year, when he hopes to lead  the Roman Catholic Church into the next millennium. For Mr. Yeltsin, 67, it will mark the end of his second mandate, with no certain indication of what will follow. For both men, whose failing health is a subject of persistent speculation, it is a date packed with personal and public significance. **********According to their spokesmen, today's meeting, which continued long after its scheduled conclusion, was cordial and warm. ''More than one of the world's burning issues were discussed,'' said Sergei Yastrzhembsky, Mr. Yeltsin's spokesman. **********After 45 minutes, their conversation, conducted through interpreters,  was interrupted by a Vatican official who went into the papal library to remind them that the Russian President had other appointments to keep. The Pope, starting to rise, was stopped by Mr. Yeltsin, who said, ''Your Holiness, we haven't finished yet.'' **********One subject the two did not discuss was a papal trip to Moscow, which despite invitations first from the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1989, and then from Mr. Yeltsin on  his last Vatican visit, in 1991, remains blocked by objections from the Russian Orthodox Church. **********Twice in recent years, meetings between Pope John Paul and Patriarch Aleksy II have been called off because of continuing bitterness felt by the Orthodox Church over the division of church properties in western Ukraine, where the Greek Catholic Church, which is bound to Rome,  re-emerged in the post-Soviet period. **********In fact, the bitterness between the Roman Catholic and Orthodox churches dates back to the original schism of 1054. It flared up again last year when the Vatican joined protests over a new Russian law that sought to limit the activities of religions other than those considered traditional to Russia. **********The Vatican spokesman, Dr. Joaquin Navarro-Valls, said tonight that Mr. Yeltsin had explained that he had taken the Pope's letter objecting to the law into consideration when he vetoed its first draft. But the amended version still troubles the small Catholic Church in Russia, which says it is open to abuse on the local level. **********On Monday, Mr. Yastrzhembsky noted that the relations between the two churches were not an appropriate subject for the meeting between Mr. Yeltsin and the Pope. **********''It is a sphere in which the state, including the President, does not interfere,'' he said. ''Let us hope that the two leading branches of the Christian Church will find the wisdom, patience and good will in the near future to remove, and perhaps extinguish, their problems.'' **********As Mr. Yeltsin and Pope John Paul were conversing, Msgr. Jean-Louis Tauran, the Vatican's Foreign Minister, and Russia's Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, also held a meeting, at which they expressed their shared concerns about the crisis in Iraq. **********Pope John Paul has repeatedly urged a peaceful solution to the crisis and warned against the military option now considered by the United States. Mr. Yeltsin, at a joint news conference with Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy today, said the use of military force against Iraq would lead to a ''big conflagration.'' **********Mr. Yeltsin, here on his first foreign trip since a long convalescence, was more at ease at the Vatican than he had been at the morning news conference, where he appeared tense and confused as he tried to clarify earlier statements about the Iraqi crisis. **********At the public gift-giving ceremony, Mr. Yeltsin presented two volumes of the Pope's poetry translated into Russian in a specially printed edition, together with two gold goblets encrusted with multicolored enamel. The Pope gave Mr. Yeltsin a two-foot-high bronze medallion depicting the Virgin Mary holding the Christ child. **********Joined by his wife and several dozen members of his official delegation for the ceremonial part of his Vatican visit, Mr. Yeltsin beamed when the Pope, greeting his daughter Tatyana, who serves as Mr. Yeltsin's  personal consultant, said to her in Russian, ''molodets,'' a word that means ''good for you.'' **********And to Mrs. Yeltsin, the Pope added, ''I am very happy to see your husband in good form.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.snippet: Key to Indonesia's future lies increasingly in hands of its powerful military, as nation suffers its worst crisis in 30 years, its capital seething with rage and Pres Suharto struggling to keep control; the one institution with an efficient nation...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.main_headline: Role of Military: A Potential Unifier Split by Conflicting Goals
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.print_headline: UNREST IN INDONESIA: THE GENERALS; Role of Military: A Potential Unifier Split by Conflicting Goals
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.body_text: **********As Indonesia suffers its worst crisis in 30 years, its capital seething with rage and its President struggling to keep control, the key to the nation's future lies increasingly in the hands of its powerful military. **********The one institution with an efficient nationwide organization, and the one institution that enjoys broad support among most Indonesians, may ultimately decide whether it is time for President Suharto to heed widespread calls to step aside after 32 years in power. **********A former general himself, Mr. Suharto has worked hard to insure the loyalty of the military, appointing his supporters -- in many cases his personal aides -- to all its top positions. Whatever its internal disputes, the armed forces has been seen as firmly behind the President. **********But it also takes seriously its mission as the nation's unifying force, as well as its constitutionally mandated responsibility to insure national stability. **********''I think the present leadership is very loyal to Suharto and it would only be in extreme circumstances that they would consider taking action against him,'' Harold Crouch, an Australian political scientist who is an expert on the Indonesian military, said earlier this year. **********''But in a sense, we are approaching those extreme circumstances,'' he said. ''Let's say rioting broke out: there would be a point where they would say, 'Something has to be done.' '' **********Now the riots have come, ripping away any hope that Indonesia could weather its political and economic crisis in peace. Since the region's economic downturn hit Indonesia hard at the start of this year, with rising prices, food shortages, unemployment and bankruptcies, the specter of social unrest has kept the nation on edge. **********The current turmoil in Jakarta, and the shooting deaths of several student demonstrators this week, approach the worst-case scenario that political analysts and foreign diplomats had feared. **********And with Mr. Suharto continuing to take an inflexible stance, brushing aside calls for political reform, elements of the military may already be saying something must be done. Indeed, some officers have publicly voiced sympathy with the calls of student demonstrators for reforms. **********This would seem to put them at odds with Mr. Suharto, who made a show of ignoring the nation's economic and political crisis in March by proceeding with a scripted re-anointment to a new six-year term, then packing his new Cabinet with relatives and cronies. **********''There is only one question now: What is the military going to do?'' said Kwik Kian Gie, a leading economist. ''And the next question is, who is the military?'' **********Is it hard-line Suharto loyalists, thought to be represented by the President's son-in-law, General Prabowo, whom he recently named to head the special forces? Or is it pragmatic professionals like Gen. Wiranto, a former aide-de-camp, whom the President recently named to the dual posts of Defense Minister and armed forces chief? **********Will they face the question posed last week by Amien Rais, an outspoken Muslim leader, of whether to ''support the President'' or ''support the nation''? **********The Indonesian armed forces enjoy widespread respect as the agent of liberation a half century ago from Dutch colonialism, and play a constitutionally prescribed political-military role known as ''dwifungsi,'' or dual function. **********From the highest levels of government to the lowest bureaucratic echelons, the military permeates the nation's administrative structure. Seventy-five seats in the 500-member Parliament are reserved for the armed forces. Half of provincial governorships are held by military men. Many Cabinet ministers, senior civil servants, ambassadors and directors of state corporations are soldiers. These civilian duties occupy fully two-thirds of the 300,000-member military. **********''In the last 10 or 15 years, it's been in a major sense the backbone of the Government and ultimately, in a crisis, the army is what will hold the nation together,'' Mr. Crouch said. **********As the crisis here has grown, many Indonesians have become fascinated by the experience of the Philippines a decade ago in which mass demonstrations of ''people power'' stopped the tanks of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos and persuaded soldiers to disobey his orders to shoot. **********The dynamics of Indonesia's crisis differ in many ways from those of the Philippines. For one thing, the violence here has already far surpassed that of the Philippines in 1986. But in both cases, the soldiers sent to quell the disturbances share the hardships and the sentiments of many of the demonstrators. **********''These soldiers are the next generation,'' said Ali Sadikin, a political scientist. ''We know they are also suffering.'' **********At a campus rally today, Harinan Siregar, a doctor who took part in student demonstrations a generation ago, said that -- as in the Philippines -- some demonstrators were hoping to win over the soldiers who were guarding them. **********''Some people think that with the support of the military they could topple the Government,'' he said. ''So they try to convince the army to come over to their side.'' **********And in a scene that is as common here as it might be unusual in many another country, the arrival of a contingent of soldiers at the University of Indonesia campus today -- wearing red berets and carrying long riot-control sticks -- was greeted by students with cheers and applause. **********The soldiers responded by waving their sticks in greeting, and soon the young men -- soldiers and students -- were mingling and embracing like friends.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/18/busin.snippet: Chase Manhattan Corp to lay off about 2,250 employees, or 3 percent of its work force, as it consolidates administrative and business functions; about half of the layoffs, or 1,125 jobs, will be in New York metropolitan region and New York State; ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/18/busin.main_headline: 2,250 Layoffs Set at Chase, Or 3% of Staff
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/18/busin.print_headline: 2,250 Layoffs Set at Chase, Or 3% of Staff
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/18/busin.body_text: **********The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's largest bank, said yesterday that it planned to lay off about 2,250 employees, or about 3 percent of its work force, as it consolidates administrative and business functions. **********About half of the layoffs, or 1,125 jobs, will be in the New York metropolitan region and New York State. The cuts are part of a plan to eliminate about 4,500 of the bank's 69,033 positions over the next 18 months by laying off workers and by not replacing others who depart. **********When Chase and the Chemical Banking Corporation agreed to merge in 1995, the two banks employed about 75,000 people. The completion of the merger in 1996 brought the elimination of about 12,000 jobs. But the number of employees subsequently grew, in part because of smaller acquisitions Chase pursued, such as last year's purchase of the credit card business of the Bank of New York Corporation. **********Chase employees have been aware for some time that layoffs were on the way and a climate of uncertainty has pervaded the bank -- an uncertainty that will now be prolonged as Chase carries out the layoffs. **********An internal memo circulated to employees in January indicated that layoffs were coming. At the time, Chase said it was freezing hiring in its corporate and business-support units. Chase also said it planned to trim $70 million a year from its budget by declaring a ''moratorium on the use of all management consultants,'' reducing its sponsorship of events and other measures. Chase said yesterday that many of the cuts would affect the company's back-office operations, though it said the rest would be proportionally shared among the bank's other operations. **********''The uncertainty is nothing new,'' said one employee who insisted on anonymity. ''Now we just know what the exact numbers will be.'' **********Chase said it would take an after-tax charge of $320 million against its earnings for the first quarter, related to the layoffs and administrative consolidation. No further layoffs are envisioned for the immediate future, the bank said. **********Chase's president, Thomas Labrecque, said that the broad outlines of the layoffs were decided only this week and that he had consulted Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani about them. Mr. Labrecque said annual savings from the moves would be about $460 million. **********''It's a meaningful chunk of change that will make investors feel better about the company's earnings outlook,'' said Diane Glossman, an analyst at Lehman Brothers. **********The bank plans to reinvest the savings in highly profitable businesses like cash management, high-yield debt, advising on mergers and acquisitions, stock research and underwriting, originating and servicing mortgages and credit cards. **********Mr. Labrecque said the moves would assure that revenue growth would rise to 10 percent annually in the next two years from current rates of 8 percent. He also said the cutbacks would help achieve a goal of an 18 percent return on equity -- a key measure of profitability. **********''Where we're really looking for the push is not that the expense base will go down, it's that the revenues will rise,'' Mr. Labrecque said. **********As part of the reorganization, Mr. Labrecque also said that Chase would create a unit, Chase Business Services, that would perform functions common to all of the bank's businesses, like marketing, benefits administration and property management. **********Chase also announced that it would raise its quarterly dividend to 72 cents from 62 cents and that it planned a 2-for-1 stock split, pending shareholder approval. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Chase shares rose $6.4375, to $134.75. **********Despite the reaction of the market, some analysts said that yesterday's announcement failed to allay some of their concerns about Chase, such as its continued exposure to economic uncertainty in Southeast Asia and the soundness of some of the bank's loans. **********''This was a very narrow restructuring announcement and didn't get to some of the more meaningful issues like credit quality,'' said Judah Kraushaar, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/06/busin.main_headline: Telephone Ethics: A Matter of Priorities
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/06/busin.print_headline: Telephone Ethics: A Matter of Priorities
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/06/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********I was surprised by the suggestion of Ian Alterman that ''many secretaries are discomfited by having to lie'' about their bosses' availability to take telephone calls (Letters, Nov. 18). **********I'm sure that most of the people calling the executive I assist know that at least some of the time he's not really ''in a meeting.'' But I doubt that many of them question his, or my, professional ethics as discussed in the article ''You're Asked to Cheat. What to Do?'' (Oct. 11). **********My responsibilities include helping my executive prioritize assignments -- and that means some calls are more important than others. No one really wants to hear me say, ''There's a bigger name on Line 2.'' **********I hardly consider it an ''infraction.'' **********After all, it's not as if my boss is asking me to shred documents that are under Congressional subpoena. **********ANN FARTHING **********Los Angeles, Nov. 12

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/04/busin.body_text: **********Baker Hughes Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the assets of the Western Rock Bit Company, a privately held Canadian bit distributor, for $30.8 million. Baker Hughes, based in Houston, provides products and services for the oil, gas and process industries. Western Rock, based in Calgary, Alberta, has been the exclusive licensee and Canadian bit distributor for Baker Hughes's Hughes Christensen unit. Western Rock will be operated as a separate division of the Hughes Christensen Company, which supplies roller cone and drill bits, Baker Hughes said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/world.snippet: Senior ministers of Austrian Govt send draft law on restitution of art confiscated by Nazis to Parliament and say they expect that some paintings, furniture and other objects will be returned to their rightful owners by end of year (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/world.main_headline: Austria Moves Toward Returning Artworks Confiscated by Nazis
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/world.print_headline: Austria Moves Toward Returning Artworks Confiscated by Nazis
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/world.body_text: **********Senior ministers of the Austrian Government today sent a draft law on the restitution of art confiscated by the Nazis to Parliament and said they expected that some paintings, furniture and other objects would be returned to their rightful owners by the end of the year. **********Passage of the law would mean that several major museums in Vienna would have to give up works, from paintings to tapestry to armor, that have been on display for decades. **********The Culture Minister, Elisabeth Gehrer, said before a meeting of the  ministers today that the Government wanted to correct the wrongs of the past. **********The Nazis stripped Austrian Jews of valuable art just before the start of World War II. After the war, the  Austrian authorities refused to allow Jewish families who had fled into exile to retrieve their artworks and take them abroad. **********''It is our will to clear up after 50 years what has not been done before,'' Mrs. Gehrer said. ''We cannot make wrongdoings right, but we can make justice possible.'' **********The Austrian branch of the Rothschilds is among the Jewish families whose extensive art holdings were taken by the Nazis and subsequently held by art museums here, including the Kunsthistorische and the Belvedere. Baroness Bettina de Rothschild, who lives in southern Austria, said she had been told today that her family could expect to recover its heritage, including two portraits by Franz Hals, ''before the end of the year.'' **********The Baroness, 73, fled into exile as a young girl days before the Germans marched into Austria, and later married an American diplomat, Matthew Looram. She praised Mrs. Gehrer for her perseverance. **********''I give her enormous credit,'' the Baroness said. ''She has shown great guts. I don't think it's very popular.'' **********The leader of Austria's far-right Freedom Party, Jorg Haider, said on Wednesday that the Government's effort to return the confiscated art was too great a favor to Jews. **********The move to return the art began  after an uproar last winter over the disputed ownership of two Egon Schiele paintings lent by an Austrian foundation for a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art in New York.  Claims by descendants of the works' prewar owners were outlined in articles in The New York Times. **********A spokeswoman for Mrs. Gehrer  said the Government expected Parliament to approve the law in October. Ownership claims would then have to be reviewed by a new six-member commission. **********The review is considered a formality in the case of works belonging to the Rothschild, Lederer and Bloch-Bauer families, who left Austria and have formally made claims since the war. Those family collections and 400 to 500 other items, mainly coins and armor, have been fully investigated and their rightful ownership affirmed, said Mrs. Gehrer's spokeswoman, Heidi Marie Gluck. **********Mrs. Gehrer said art stolen by the Nazis and held in Austria fell into three categories. The first covers art taken by the Nazis and never returned to its owners because the Austrian Government refused to allow it to be taken out of the country. Those works were generally donated or dedicated to national museums and galleries. **********Among them are 10 paintings that  the Kunsthistorische acquired in 1946. They include such prized 17th-century Dutch works as a ''Portrait of a Man'' and ''Portrait of a Woman'' by Frans Hals and paintings by Meindert Hobbema, Aelbert Cuyp, Jan Wynants and Frans van Mieris. **********The Baroness said she and her family were looking forward to seeing the paintings, carpets and tapestries that are now in the Museum of Applied Arts and a host of other artworks in their home. **********A second category of art established in the draft law covers works  that were acquired on the open market but are now believed to have a ''shady'' provenance, Mrs. Gehrer said. **********A third category covers works that could not be returned to their rightful owners despite restitution efforts after the war and that reverted to the state as ''ownerless.'' Those are to be handed over to a national fund that  will decide what to do with them.
