https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/01/busin.snippet: Business in advertising industry is so good that it is hard to find, and to keep, good workers; some of workers who lost their jobs during recession of late 1980's and early 1990's became freelancers and are happy on their own; as economy has impr...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/01/busin.main_headline: How good is business? It's so good that good workers are very hard to find, and to keep.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/01/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; How good is business? It's so good that good workers are very hard to find, and to keep.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/01/busin.body_text: **********EXECUTIVES at Sicola Martin, an agency in Austin, Tex., have two problems: Business is booming. And their high-technology clients' business is booming, too. **********How is that a problem? Just try finding and then holding onto talented workers, they say, echoing a lament heard throughout the advertising industry. **********''We're often training people only to lose them,'' complained Barbara Matijevich, a spokeswoman at the $53 million agency. ''We lose a lot of people to the high-tech companies themselves.'' **********Sicola Martin -- facing fierce competition for workers from computer companies as well as within the advertising industry -- may be having a particularly tough time. But executives around the country say recruiting good people has been more difficult in the last year to two years. **********Many blame the industry itself, in part at least, for the crunch. During the recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's, agencies stopped hiring and laid off the middle managers they now need, said O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York. **********''We're now paying the penalty for that,'' he said. ''We sort of lost a whole generation of new people.'' **********Some of those lost workers became freelancers and are now quite happy on their own, thank you, said Anne Melanson, director of human resources at the Bates Worldwide unit of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C., a $6 billion agency based in New York. About 10 percent of the people her agency would like to hire are freelancing, she said. **********As the economy has improved, others have jumped to lucrative jobs at consulting firms and in corporate marketing departments, leaving lagging agency salaries behind, Mr. Drake and others said. **********Camille Weas, human resources manager at Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis, an $863 million agency that is majority-owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, said Campbell Mithun stopped shopping for young M.B.A.'s in the late 80's because advertising salaries were no longer competitive. **********New York agencies complain about a shortage of talent, but those in Minneapolis and elsewhere in the Midwest are particularly frantic. **********''There are certain areas that people don't necessarily want to go to,'' explained Judy Wald, chairwoman of Judy Wald Partners, an executive search firm in Manhattan that specializes in advertising positions. **********Campbell Mithun opened a 15-employee satellite office in New York last year for finicky creative types who are hard to lure to Minneapolis, Ms. Weas said. **********In Los Angeles, Brian Morris, president of Dailey & Associates, another unit of Interpublic, said area agencies had found recruiting tough because of ''the riots and earthquakes and floods and everything else.'' Then, as the agencies started to recover, he added, they found themselves in a boom-time scramble for employees. **********Agencies all over are adding perquisites to attract employees and offering incentives to those already on staff who bring in new hires. **********D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications in New York, the flagship of MacManus Group, doubled its new-worker bounty to $1,000 last year, said Leslie Engel, human resources director. D.M.B.& B. has also added tuition reimbursement and health-related programs, along with referrals for child care and care for the elderly, in an attempt to woo Generation X'ers, she said. **********Still, Ms. Engel said, it takes perhaps twice as long to fill a vacancy as it once did, and account supervisors are especially hard to find (an assessment echoed at several other agencies). **********All this would seem to be good news for recruiting firms at least -- except for one thing. Robert Herman, of the Robert Herman Company in New York, said he lost about $200,000 in fees last year as prospective hires were lured back by their old agencies. **********Ms. Wald, who has experienced the same setback, said: ''It shows how hard they try to hold onto their valued people. They know how hard it is to find a replacement.'' **********Even when a hiring appears to be successful, it may not last long-term. Sicola Martin, the Texas agency, spent a year looking for one account director, only to have him leave within six months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/18/busin.snippet: Apple Computer Inc sets aside 17 million shares, or 13 percent of its total shares outstanding, to be awarded to executives in effort to prevent loss of top talent (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/18/busin.body_text: **********Apple Computer Inc. has set aside 17 million shares, or 13 percent of its total shares outstanding, to be awarded to executives in an effort to prevent the loss of top talent. **********The shares will be given to senior executives, including the chairman, chief operating officer and other ''key employees.'' The new plan, outlined in Apple's proxy filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday, expands the number of shares that may be awarded and the types of stock-based performance awards that may be granted. **********Apple has floundered as almost every top executive, with the exception of the interim chief executive, Steve Jobs, and the chief financial officer, Fred Anderson, has left the company in the last two years. In that time, the company reported losses of $1.86 billion as it had struggled to stem sliding market share. **********In addition to the ousting of the chief executive officer, Gil Amelio, in July, many other executives have also left.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/busin.snippet: AT&T Corp chief executive C Michael Armstrong and Tele-Communications Inc chairman John C Malone will pursue starkly different career goals when AT&T Corp acquires Tele-Communications Inc; Armstrong will throw all his energies into integrating AT&...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/busin.main_headline: One Partnership, Starkly Different Career Goals
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/busin.print_headline: COMMUNICATIONS GIANT: THE CHIEFS; One Partnership, Starkly Different Career Goals
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/busin.body_text: **********C. Michael Armstrong and John C. Malone have arranged a very modern marriage. In the proposed $31.8 billion merger of the AT&T Corporation, the nation's biggest long-distance phone company, and Tele-Communications Inc., the second-largest cable-television company, theirs will be a partnership of equals pursuing starkly different career goals. **********Mr. Armstrong, AT&T's chief executive since last November, will throw all his energies into integrating AT&T's telephone services with TCI's cable wires in a drive to offer local phone service to consumers. **********Mr. Malone, who built TCI from a scrappy West Coast cable company into an industry behemoth, will hardly be a passive partner in that endeavor. Indeed, he will become one of AT&T's biggest individual shareholders and will sit on its board. **********But he will spend most of his time doing what he enjoys most -- cable deals. By retaining control over Liberty Media, TCI's separately traded programming unit with stakes in such properties as QVC Inc., Home Shopping Network, TV Guide, the Discovery Channel, Encore Media and Liberty Fox Sports, Mr. Malone will in effect have his own sandbox to play in. **********All the while, both men stand to make a lot of money from the deal. Mr. Armstrong could get rich and Mr. Malone a lot richer than his current $2.4 billion net worth. **********At a joint news conference yesterday, the 58-year-old Mr. Malone said he thought his ownership of some 25 million TCI shares was worth about $1.2 billion, though he added that he was so optimistic about the ramifications of the merger that earlier in the day he had bought another $240 million in TCI stock at market prices -- or roughly five million shares. **********The rest of his wealth is mostly tied up in Liberty and a third company, TCI Ventures, that will be folded into Liberty. He will ultimately be able to swap the TCI stock for AT&T shares, tax-free. **********''I don't have John's problem,'' Mr. Armstrong joked yesterday, referring to Mr. Malone's wealth and his seeming uncertainty about its value. **********Perhaps not, but he isn't doing too badly. According to an AT&T proxy filed in March, he received a $14.9 million stock package when he left the Hughes Electronics Corporation to join the phone company. He also got a $1.4 million salary, a comparable bonus and performance-related stock designed to match his salary this year and next. **********If Mr. Armstrong can make this merger work, of course, he is likely to benefit from huge option grants that could push his long-term compensation into the stratosphere. **********Unlike Ted Turner, Time Warner vice chairman, who sold his Turner Broadcasting System to Time Warner and did not retain a separate power base, Mr. Malone will continue to run his own fief at Liberty Media. **********He has always been an avid deal maker, and in overseeing Liberty, which will have relatively little debt, he will have ample opportunity to buy and sell and negotiate. ''He wants to build asset value,'' said Christopher Dixon, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. **********That role should suit Mr. Malone's impatient personality well. Since Liberty is generally a minority investor or partner in cable-programming holdings, he will not be required to get involved in day-to-day operating duties, a task that has never particularly interested him. **********Given the complexity of the deal, however, it is not yet clear just what the final structure of AT&T will be. Mr. Armstrong and Mr. Malone said yesterday that while the first step was for AT&T to acquire TCI, a second step was to spin off AT&T's residential long-distance and cellular businesses together with TCI's cable systems into an AT&T ''tracking stock.'' Tracking stocks represent ownership in certain, specific assets of publicly held companies and rise or fall with the fortunes of those assets. Investors in such stocks have no voting rights, however. **********The advantages of a tracking stock for the issuing company are twofold: It retains full control of the underlying assets, and it is subject to fewer tax consequences. **********Mr. Malone is already taking advantage of the tracking-stock structure to sell back shares of AT&T that TCI received when it sold a stake in Teleport, a company that provides local phone and data services to businesses, thereby pumping up Liberty's cash reserves. TCI will also sell its shares in At Home, an Internet access and information services company that operates over cable networks, to AT&T for cash. Those shares are held by Liberty and TCI Ventures, respectively, both of which are themselves tracking companies of TCI. **********Mr. Malone sees the new Liberty as a sort of GE Capital Corporation, he said yesterday, because it will have the capital to make leasing investments in such technologies as digital cable set-top boxes, which could help AT&T grow. **********But before any of that can happen, Liberty said yesterday that it would merge with TCI Ventures, which has a wide range of holdings in Internet telephone and foreign cable ventures, in a stock deal with Liberty offering 0.52 share for each share of TCI Ventures. **********The merged Liberty-TCI Ventures -- which will retain the Liberty name -- will be an unusual form of tracking stock because AT&T, though it will swap a new class of its shares for the Liberty shares, will not have a direct financial interest in Liberty. Liberty will be owned by Mr. Malone, other TCI and Liberty executives, and the public.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/busin.snippet: Small biotechnology stocks stage rally; catalyst is Entremed Inc; its shares skyrocket on news that company has two compounds in development that in combination could eradicate human tumors in laboratory mice (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/busin.main_headline: Smaller Biotechnology Stocks Stage a Spirited Catch-Up Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS; Smaller Biotechnology Stocks Stage a Spirited Catch-Up Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/busin.body_text: **********Some small biotechnology companies that have watched the big drug stocks soar over the last year had their turn yesterday as hopes grew for a new cancer treatment. **********The catalyst was Entremed Inc.;  its shares skyrocketed on news that the company had two compounds in development that in combination could eradicate human tumors in laboratory mice. An article on the findings appeared in The New York Times on Sunday. **********Stock analysts sought to remind  investors yesterday that other drugs successful in the laboratory had failed in humans and that the progression of even the most successful biotechnology drug from discovery to market was rarely a straight line. **********Entremed has found that the two substances -- angiostatin and endostatin, which are naturally occurring in humans -- together interfere with the blood supply to tumors, make the tumors shrink and disappear, and prevent their return. The compounds were discovered by Dr. Judah Folkman, a cancer researcher at Children's Hospital in Boston. **********The drugs are in a class of molecules known as anti-angiogenesis compounds, a research area that has been pursued by large pharmaceutical and small biotechnology companies for several years. While Entremed is a year away from starting clinical trials in people, some anti-angiogenesis drugs are further along. A related class of drugs, known as matrix metalloproteinase inhibitors, which disable an enzyme that tumors use to invade surrounding tissues, is also advancing. **********Stocks of many small companies involved with these drugs shared in the euphoria surrounding Entremed, which closed yesterday at $51.81, more than four times its $12.06 closing price on Friday. The most neglected companies of recent months showed the greatest percentage gains. Immunogen closed at $2.31, up 78 cents, or 51 percent; Boston Life Sciences finished at $7.59, up $5.47, or 257 percent; Repligen was at $3, up $1.53, or 104 percent; Sugen closed at $16.44, up $2.81, or 20 percent; Imclone Systemsended trading at $10, up $1.25, or 14 percent, and Magainin was at $8.19, up $2.25, or 38 percent. **********Companies with drugs in the later stages of development got less of a boost. Genentech fell 44 cents, to $68.50, despite having one of the broadest pipelines of cancer drugs, including an anti-angiogenesis compound. Agouron Pharmaceuticals, which is testing a matrix metalloproteinase inhibitor, closed at $34.38, up $1, while British Biotech, which has a similar drug in clinical trials, closed at $13.50, up $2. **********''The Entremed thing was overdone, but this is going to be an important area,'' said Jim McCamant, editor of Medical Technology Stock Letter. The biotechnology company with the broadest effort in anti-angiogenesis, he said, is Imclone Systems, a New York company that is pursuing three approaches. **********Mr. McCamant cautioned that animal data give no guarantee of success. ''Immunogen announced superior mouse data back in April 1997,'' he said. ''Genentech announced encouraging data in this area 15 years ago, using tumor necrosis factor in mice. Unfortunately, in large quantities, it proved toxic to humans.'' **********Anti-angiogenesis is by no means the exclusive province of the smaller companies. Entremed is a partner with Bristol-Myers Squibb, the dominant player in cancer chemotherapy drugs, to develop angiostatin, and is seeking a partner for endostatin. Bristol-Myers has its own internal development program in such drugs, as do Zeneca, Takeida and other big pharmaceutical companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/06/world.snippet: Serbian police and paramilitary units unleash helicopter gunships and armored personnel carriers against armed Albanian separatists in Kosovo Province, forcing dozens of Serbian families and Albanian women and children to leave and cordoning off s...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/06/world.main_headline: Gun Battles in Serbia Raise Fear of 'Another Bosnia'
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/06/world.print_headline: Gun Battles in Serbia Raise Fear of 'Another Bosnia'
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/06/world.body_text: **********Serbian police and paramilitary units today unleashed helicopter gunships and armored personnel carriers against armed Albanian separatists in Kosovo Province, forcing dozens of Serbian families and Albanian women and children to leave and cordoning off scores of villages to keep outsiders away. **********Twenty Albanians and two Serbian policemen were killed, the Serbian interior ministry said. **********A spokesman for Kosovo's Albanian political leader, Ibrahim Rugova, said there were houses burning and ''massacres being carried out.'' It was impossible to confirm such accusations because no access was allowed to areas where fighting was going on. **********''Today's attack proves the unprecedented brutality of the Belgrade regime,'' said the spokesman, Mustafa Xhemaje. **********Serbian police officials said they began the attack in the Drenica area, 25 miles west of Pristina, the provincial capital, after Albanian separatists attacked a police station at dawn, wounding two officers. **********People attempting to enter the area were turned away by police officers in flak jackets and armored personnel carriers. Helicopter gunships whirred overhead, and there were reports that detonations could be heard in the hillsides around Prekaz. **********The villages under siege today were the same ones where at least 24 Albanians were reportedly tortured and executed by Serbian police and paramilitary units last weekend, apparently in retaliation for the deaths of four Serbian police officers. **********Many Serbs here say state security forces have been distributing automatic assault rifles to Serbian men in the province, and Western diplomats express fear that the attacks could broaden into the kind of rampages that characterized the behavior of the Serbian forces in Bosnia during the war there. The black-uniformed special paramilitary units from the ministry of interior that are now deployed in Kosovo served in Bosnia. **********The people, too, say they fear something more ominous, and those who can are fleeing on their own, especially the Serbs. They account for less than 10 percent of the two million inhabitants of this once autonomous province, including 25,000 who were resettled here after being expelled from other parts of the former Yugoslavia. **********Life seems particularly bleak for the refugee Serbs. **********In a dank, stuffy gymnasium, Zdravko Olovic sat peeling four potatoes for his dinner tonight. The battles, raging just a few miles from his refugee center and its 400 residents, brought back troubling memories of his life as a Serb in Croatia at the start of the war for independence from Yugoslavia there in 1991. **********''Perhaps, given what has happened in the rest of the former Yugoslavia, it was just a question of time before this occurred in Kosovo,'' he said. **********The Serbs here live in small ghettos and towns where they have little contact with the Albanians. The Albanians, most of them Muslims, boycott all state institutions, often do not speak Serbo-Croatian and view the Serbian police and military as an army of occupation. **********The Albanians in Kosovo have their own parallel government -- which levies taxes -- and shadow institutions including a school system operated from private homes. **********The distance between the two communities is so wide that it is difficult to see how it can be bridged. The Serbian Government seems deaf to pleas that it grant the Albanians the political rights it revoked in 1989 when it abolished Kosovo's status as an autonomous province. **********Today's assault was apparently aimed at wiping out an outlawed guerrilla organization, the Kosovo Liberation Army, which is seeking independence for the province. The attack was viewed as open defiance by the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, to international calls for restraint and dialogue. (Serbia and Montenegro are the last republics left in Yugoslavia.) **********The British Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, representing the European Union, met in Belgrade with Mr. Milosevic today and urged him to negotiate with the Albanian separatists. He also warned President Milosevic that he faces increased international isolation if he continues to use force to smother the unrest, European diplomats said. **********The foreign ministers of the United States, Russia, Britain, France, Germany and Italy are to meet Monday in London to discuss Kosovo. **********''The fear among the Serbs is escalating,'' said Bosko Drobnjak, the chief of information for the Serbs in Kosovo. **********''These terrorists used to target state bodies and their representatives, first of all the police. They then started to murder prominent Serbs and ethnic Albanians who remained loyal to the state. Now they are killing ordinary Serb civilians. **********''The state must protect its citizens. It must provide security. If we do not, people will lose confidence.'' **********The Kosovo Liberation Army has promised revenge attacks against Serbian police officers for the recent spate of killings. **********Over the past few weeks, gunmen from the Kosovo Liberation Army have opened fire at night on apartments where police officers live and on centers for Serbian refugees. Separatists have killed at least 50 people, including many police officers, in the past year. **********Serbs planning to leave the province, especially many of the refugees, said they believed the violence would continue to mount. **********''No one wants to go to Serbia,'' said Tanja Strbac, 24, a Serb who works in the Pristina electric company and who was expelled from Croatia with her family. ''We are not given Serbian citizenship as refugees. We are denied employment in state companies. Only in Kosovo can Serbian refugees find work and equal treatment. The pressure, however, has become too much. It is unbearable. I live in an old hotel with 450 refugees and every few days another room is empty.'' **********Ljubisa Radenkovic, 22, is in the police reserve and works as a waiter in a small restaurant where only Serbs dine. His brother is a police commander who, he says, has been in four armed confrontations with the separatists. **********''There are stories that 500 terrorists have infiltrated from Albania to fight,'' he said. ''My family is from here, but 90 percent of my cousins have left. We have only three or four close relatives still in Kosovo, and most of them want to get out.'' **********Vera Raden, 36, a Serb, said, ''We have seen enough of violence and terror.'' Ms. Raden, who was resettled against her will in Kosovo after she fled her home in Croatia two years ago, added: ''I know the warning signs. I saw them before. It is time to leave.'' **********--------------------        U.S. Reinstates Sanctions **********WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The Administration responded today to reports of Serbian massacres of Albanians in Kosovo by reimposing sanctions on Yugoslavia. **********A State Department spokesman, James Foley, denounced ''the excessive use of force'' by Serbian police and announced the reversal of recent decisions to let Yugoslavia open a consulate in the United States, land planes from its national airline here and expand the Yugoslav diplomatic mission to the United Nations. **********The sanctions had been eased after President Slobodan Milosevic supported a moderate new government in the Serbian republic in Bosnia and Herzegovina. **********The State Department says that the Albanians are entitled to greater self-government within Yugoslavia, but that United States policy does not support independence. Mr. Foley said Belgrade's failure to address the Albanians' ''fundamental political rights and grievances'' is the ultimate source of the violence. **********At the Pentagon the spokesman, Kenneth H. Bacon, said today that he knows of no plan for the United States or NATO to send troops to Kosovo. The Administration is ''focusing on diplomacy'' and urging restraint on all sides, he said. **********But Mr. Foley reiterated that violence in the province ''can have an impact beyond Kosovo.'' He urged the Albanians, as well as Serbs, to exercise restraint and said, ''We condemn all terrorist actions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/busin.snippet: AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney met with top government officials and business chiefs at annual World Economic Forum, Davos, Switzerland; Sweeney is only union official ever to come from US in forum's 27 years; Sweeney said global economy and fre...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/busin.main_headline: Rare Bird in Davos: Labor Chief Makes His Points
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Rare Bird in Davos: Labor Chief Makes His Points
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/busin.body_text: **********The chief executives lunching with John J. Sweeney, the American labor leader, seemed almost to be seeking his blessing. A Frenchman tried to get him to criticize the French Government's plan to shorten the workweek. A Canadian sought his approval of bonuses and profit sharing for workers, rather than wage increases. And an American tried to get Mr. Sweeney's consent to the proposition that Mexican wages will rise. **********Like a water buffalo at a gathering of elephants, Mr. Sweeney, the president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, was an unusual sight at the annual World Economic Forum, which ended today. This is a gathering of several heads of state and hundreds of top government officials, corporate chiefs, financiers, academics and bankers who network, lobby, make deals and talk over the ills of the global economy. Until recently, union leaders were seldom invited and this time only six were present, the five others from Europe. Mr. Sweeney, who first attended last year, is the only union official ever to come from the United States in the forum's 27 years. **********Like everyone else, he wandered the crowded halls of the conference center, greeting people like Donald V. Fites, chairman of Caterpillar Inc., as if that company had never gone through a horrendous, still unresolved union battle. Or he agreed to have a cup of coffee with a chief executive in a hotel coffee shop, a short walk or shuttle bus ride along the snowy main street of Davos. **********''In this atmosphere,'' Mr. Sweeney said, ''you can chat with chief executives and world leaders so easily in ways that I cannot do back home.'' **********His message was short, focused, direct and repeated, like a politician's stump speech. The global economy and free trade are here, a fait accompli, acknowledged by labor, Mr. Sweeney said. Job-shifting across borders to lower-wage labor cannot be entirely stopped. Nor can damage to workers from crises like the current one in Asia. But national labor movements must come together to insist on minimum international labor standards and a seat at the table when the International Monetary Fund negotiates bailout agreements that fall hardest on workers. **********''We will demand coordinated efforts to stimulate growth, to regulate currency and capital speculation, to extend labor and democratic rights as part of the response to the Asian collapse,'' Mr. Sweeney declared. **********He made this case from a podium that he shared with Fernando Henrique Cardoso, Brazil's President, and George Soros, the financier. The audience of several hundred responded with warm applause to the presentations of Mr. Cardoso and Mr. Soros. Their view generally was that strong economic growth would raise worker incomes. Mr. Sweeney, taking a different tack, drew no applause. ''I got good feedback later,'' he said. ''People here don't want to publicly applaud labor.'' **********Representative Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, made Mr. Sweeney a target in one of his presentations, charging that he was out of date, a throwback to labor movement thinking in the 1930's, including opposition to agreements that promote free trade. ''He just does not get it,'' Mr. Sweeney said. ''We are not opposed to trade agreements, but they have to be done properly, and not leave out workers.'' **********Whatever the frictions, the World Economic Forum's organizers say they will add more labor leaders next year. ''I had made an attempt before to invite more labor leaders,'' said Klaus Schwab, the forum's president. ''But unlike business leaders, you did not find many labor leaders who thought globally. And I did not want Davos misused as a forum for national disputes.'' **********Mr. Schwab is also responding to another concern of the business executives and government officials who are the backbone of these annual conferences. A frequently expressed worry at the forum was the potential for strikes, demonstrations and violence, particularly in Indonesia, as workers react to the damage from the Asian crisis. **********''I think everyone is very concerned with the second wave of the Asian crisis,'' Mr. Schwab said. ''The first was financial and the second is going to be social and political.'' **********At a luncheon on Monday given by the labor leaders, the half-dozen executives at Mr. Sweeney's table  sought his sympathy or at least his informal counsel for their labor problems back home. Roger Cukierman, chairman of the Compagnie Financiere Edmond de Rothschild Banque, in Paris, asked Mr. Sweeney if he favored the French plan to cut the workweek to 35 hours from 39, with no cut in pay. **********Mr. Sweeney said he did, to Mr. Cukierman's disappointment, but on a softer note, he agreed with the banker that the shorter week would not prompt French employers to hire more workers, which is the goal. Instead, they will probably fill the extra hours on overtime, the two men agreed. **********Predictably, Mexico and the North American Free Trade Agreement  came up. ''What people in Mexico tell us is that as productivity rises, they will pay higher wages,'' said Steven C. Kletjian, chairman of the Unicco Service Company in the United States, which takes over operations that corporations outsource. **********Mr. Kletjian's comment brought a standard Sweeney reaction. ''From the data we have now,'' he said, ''we know that while Nafta created some jobs in the United States, they are mostly low wage. In Mexico, the new jobs are the lowest of the low.'' **********Brian R. D. Smith got the answer he sought. He is chairman of the British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority, a government-owned electric power utility, with 6,000 unionized employees. He is trying to persuade his workers that they should accept profit-sharing and bonuses, rather than fixed wage increases. **********''That is happening more and more,'' Mr. Sweeney said, ''not only profit-sharing but stock distribution.'' **********And Mr. Smith beamed. Will he quote Mr. Sweeney in his continuing  conversations with his workers? ''Definitely,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/19/busin.snippet: Vornado Realty Trust to spin off to shareholders new Vornado Operating Co, $100 million unit that will hold its non-real estate businesses (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/19/busin.main_headline: VORNADO REALTY TO SPIN OFF $100 MILLION UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; VORNADO REALTY TO SPIN OFF $100 MILLION UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/19/busin.body_text: **********Vornado Realty Trust said yesterday that it would spin off a $100 million unit that will hold its non-real estate businesses on Oct. 16 to shareholders of record on Oct. 9. The unit, called the Vornado Operating Company, will be responsible for managing Vornado's cold storage business, trade show operations and its Hotel Pennsylvania in New York. The spinoff was necessary for Vornado to comply with rules governing real estate investment trusts. As a REIT, Vornado is exempt from corporate income taxes if it distributes at least 95 percent of net income to shareholders as a dividend. It must also generate at least 75 percent of its revenue from rents and mortgage interest. Shareholders of Vornado, based in Saddle Brook, N.J., will receive one share in the new company for every 20 shares owned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; Slide in Shares Moderates While Earnings Jitters Persist
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/busin.body_text: **********Stocks fell yesterday amid concern that earnings growth was not keeping up with stock prices. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which lost nearly 100 points on Tuesday and 400 points last week, fell only 19.82 points yesterday, to 8,914.96, led by Wal-Mart Stores, which dropped 2 9/16, to 60 7/8. The Standard & Poor's 500 index of 500 stocks declined 5.03, to 1,125.21. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index dropped 15.04, to 1,881.49. **********''Earnings are growing, but at a slower pace,'' said John Niedenberger, a money manager with Advanced Investment Management in Pittsburgh, which oversees $3 billion. ''I haven't done much buying lately. I'm not selling either. I'm just holding.'' **********Losses would have been greater if not for I.B.M., which was up 2 5/16, to 127 3/4, on optimism that a new line of mainframe machines will bolster the company's sales. Steven Milunovich, a Merrill Lynch analyst, increased his 1999 earnings forecast for the company. **********Profits for the 407 S.& P. 500 companies that have reported earnings so far are up just 3 percent, on average, down from 11 percent a year earlier, according to First Call. **********Wal-Mart, whose stock is up 55 percent this year, is expected to report a 25 percent increase in fiscal first-quarter earnings on Aug. 12, based on the average forecast from analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International. Yet the nation's No. 1 merchant led a broad retreat in retailing issues. **********Nor did investors find relief in small companies. The small-cap barometer, the Russell 2000 index, fell for a ninth day, down 0.3 percent. It is now off 2.5 percent this year, compared with a 16 percent gain for the large-company S.& P. 500. **********General Motors declined  1/8, to 74 1/8, after workers voted to settle strikes that had cost the auto maker an estimated $3 billion in profit. The settlement lets G.M. trim fewer jobs than it had wanted and restricts its ability to close unprofitable plants. G.M. had risen 5.3 percent in the previous three days as optimism for a settlement grew. **********Telecomunicacoes Brasileiras surged after Brazil's Government sold its controlling stake in the national telephone network for almost $19 billion. Telebras holder shares, up 5 11/16, to 119, were created by Merrill Lynch to let foreign investors trade the 12 companies spawned in the Telebras breakup as a single security. About 4.9 million shares changed hands after the stock opened for trading. **********Cendant rose 1 3/8, to 18 3/8, after the chairman, Walter A. Forbes, and eight other board members resigned. Investors had been calling for Mr. Forbes to step down since the marketer and franchiser said it would restate earnings for the last three years because of accounting irregularities at its CUC International unit. CUC, which was headed by Mr. Forbes, merged with HFS Inc. to form Cendant last year. **********--------------------        Treasuries End Lower **********(By Reuters) **********Treasury prices ended lower yesterday, pressured in part by corporate supply. **********The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 13/32, to 105 2/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.76 percent, from 5.74 percent on Tuesday. **********''The long end is being held down primarily because of deals,'' said Astrid Adolfson, first vice president and senior economist at MCM Moneywatch. **********Analysts expect $9 billion of debt to be issued by the end of the week. While few corporate deals were priced yesterday, positioning ahead of the the new supply led to some selling of Treasuries, traders said. **********Caution ahead of today's report on second-quarter employment costs also weighed on trading yesterday. But there was good demand at the Treasury's auction of $15 billion in two-year notes. Following are the results of the auction: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********High Price . . .   99.813        High Yield . . .   5.475%        Low Yield . . .   5.400%        Median Yield . . .   5.464%        Accepted at low price . . .   55%        Total applied for . . .   $40,794,637        Accepted . . .   $18,642,381        Noncompetitive . . .   $1,587,631        Interest set at . . .   5 3/8 **********The two-year notes mature on July 31, 2000

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/17/world.snippet: UN weapons inspectors conclude Iraq could be hiding two to five times more deadly germ agents than it has admitted making, as well as warheads to deliver them; say Government's systematic refusal to cooperate in recent weeks deepened suspicions, w...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/17/world.main_headline: Iraq Said to Hide Deadly Germ Agents
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/17/world.print_headline: ATTACK ON IRAQ: THE ARMS MONITORS; Iraq Said to Hide Deadly Germ Agents
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/17/world.body_text: **********United Nations weapons inspectors have concluded that Iraq could be hiding two to five times more deadly germ agents than it had admitted to making, as well as the warheads to deliver them, United Nations officials said today. **********In interviews, the inspectors said Iraq's systematic refusal to cooperate in recent weeks had deepened their suspicions, which stem from evidence they have gathered since the end of the 1991 gulf war. **********The inspectors disclosed that Iraq had failed to turn over a key log book of purchases by its germ program, which would account for, among other things, the amount of media, or special food for germs, it had bought. **********Iraq also refused to open buildings for routine inspections and only belatedly made available the Iraqi experts who could help resolve key discrepancies about Baghdad's production of germ weapons. **********In his speech last night, President Clinton said he had ordered the attack on Iraq to help contain Saddam Hussein and his weapons of mass destruction. Mr. Clinton listed some of the obstacles and harassment that inspectors faced. But the inspectors said the problems went far beyond the President's statements. **********The scope of Iraq's germ program remains cloaked in mystery, the experts agreed, with indications that Baghdad had backtracked during this round of inspection on even its previous minimal cooperation.  ''Clearly, they weren't going to cooperate and were going out of their way to cause problems,'' one official who returned from Baghdad said. **********Iraq has already confessed to making enough deadly microbes to kill all the people on earth several times over. After the gulf war, Baghdad admitted to having loaded botulinum toxin (which causes muscular paralysis resulting in death) into 16 warheads, anthrax (which causes high fever and is usually fatal within two weeks) into five warheads, and aflotoxin (which causes liver cancer) into four warheads. **********It also acknowledged having filled 157 bombs with the same deadly agents, and having conducted research on tricothecene micotoxins (which cause nausea, vomiting and diarrhea), wheat cover smut (which ruins food grains), hemorrhagic conjunctivitis (which causes extreme pain and temporary blindness), rotavirus (which causes acute diarrhea that can lead to death) and camel pox (a camel version of small pox). **********But the inspectors now believe that Iraq could well have gone even further, based on discrepancies between what Iraq has declared having imported, consumed and destroyed. Inspectors said that the biological teams were denied at least three key documents, at least one of which was key to reconciling Iraq's reporting record. **********According to two inspectors, the United Nations team asked the Iraqis on the morning of the first day of meetings for a ''log book'' that described purchases and imports for the germ program, which several of them had seen in 1995 but had failed to grasp its significance. Among the log book's entries were imported shipments of the special foods used for growing germs. **********At the first meeting, the Iraqis promised to produce the log book. But each day they offered another excuse. The inspectors said the book was critical to estimating the amount of germ agents that Baghdad could have produced and turned into weapons. **********At first, the Iraqi team said they couldn't find the log book, two inspectors said. Then the Iraqis said that the book should be retrievable, but that they would need the approval of Tarik Aziz, Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, to release it. On the last day of the meetings, the Iraqis indicated they were still looking for the  book. An inspector said, ''This was less cooperation than we had seen six months ago.'' **********In other cases, the Iraqis refused to provide documents they acknowledged existed. One was a list of imported food to grow germs from the customs department, which was also requested on the meetings' first day. The Iraqis said they couldn't find them, an inspector said. Another missing document was an inventory of germ food that had been stored at Al Hakam, Iraq's major germ production center. **********An inspector said that if Baghdad had used the germ food to grow deadly agents, especially anthrax in either liquid or dry form, the microbes could still be used in weapons. **********On Dec. 4, Diane Seaman, an American inspector, tried to lead a large, experienced biological team into a site inspectors considered routine. While she was permitted to go the building, the Iraqis refused to open the office she sought to enter, telling her that she would have to  ''break down'' the locked doors.. **********''It was a holy day,'' one inspector conceded. ''But there can be no exempt days or the inspection system wouldn't work.'' **********The Iraqis also delayed making available key officials from the biological program. ''We had asked for six,'' one inspector said, ''but they only produced three of the people we wanted at the early meetings.'' By the last meeting, when their usefulness was marginal, Iraq finally produced the full contingent of experts. **********The Iraqis told inspectors that two top scientists in the germ program were out of the country. One of them was said to be in Britain; London  denied it. **********The inspectors said that Iraq was aware of the stakes in this round of test inspections and monitoring.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/busin.main_headline: Olde Discount And Officials Pay Big Fine
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/busin.print_headline: Olde Discount And Officials Pay Big Fine
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/busin.body_text: **********A discount brokerage firm and three of its executives, including its founder and chairman, agreed yesterday to pay $7 million in fines to settle Federal allegations of fraudulent sales practices and use of misleading advertising and promotional literature. **********As part of a coordinated settlement of charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the National Association of Securities Dealers, the Olde Discount Corporation, a Detroit-based brokerage firm, agreed to pay a $4 million civil penalty to the S.E.C. to settle allegations that the firm's compensation, production, hiring and training practices encouraged brokers to lie to customers, as well as to engage in unauthorized and unsuitable trading in customer accounts. **********Ernest J. Olde, the firm's former president and chairman, was fined an additional $1 million by the S.E.C., which accused him of failure to supervise. Stanley A. Snider, Olde's former director of national sales, was ordered to pay $100,000, and Daniel D. Katzman, a former Olde regional manager, was ordered to pay $50,000. They were accused of playing roles  in inducing and causing the violations. **********The case is the first in which the S.E.C. has held a brokerage firm directly liable for its brokers' fraudulent sales practices, said Richard P. Murphy, a senior trial counsel with the commission's Atlanta office. **********In settling the charges, the firm, Mr. Olde, Mr. Snider and Mr. Katzman neither admitted nor denied the charges. Lawyers for the firm, Mr. Olde and Mr. Katzman were said by others at their firms to be unavailable for comment. Mr. Snider's lawyer, Bruce Hiler, a partner at O'Melveny & Myers in Washington, declined to comment. **********Under the settlement, Mr. Snider and Mr. Katzman are barred from association with any broker, dealer, municipal securities dealer, investment adviser or investment company for five years. Mr. Olde faces a one-year suspension. **********The brokerage firm was also fined $1.35 million by NASD Regulation Inc., the regulatory arm of the N.A.S.D., which accused it of using and distributing improper advertising. Mr. Olde was fined $500,000 and suspended from the securities industry for 18 months. **********Olde issued a statement saying the settlement built on a series of initiatives it began on its own more than three years ago. Those actions include changes in management, compensation structure, enhanced sales and supervisory systems and expanded broker and supervisory training programs, Randal J. Mudge, Olde's managing director, said in a news release. The company said it planned to employ an independent consultant to review its policies and procedures. **********According to the S.E.C. complaint, brokers routinely used high-pressure sales practices, and earned substantially higher commissions for selling stocks in which Olde made a market. Many of those stocks were speculative and unsuitable for elderly, retired investors, Mr. Murphy said. **********The firm advertised commission-free services to investors, failing to tell them that the firm made money on many of the stocks that brokers were pushing. **********''The firm created a situation that channeled their brokers' efforts to selling a narrow slice of the investment products'' that Olde offered and ''resulted in the brokers' illegal conduct,'' Mr. Murphy said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/21/techn.snippet: Review of Web sites for preteen-age and teen-age girls, including A Girl's World; photo (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/21/techn.main_headline: LIBRARY/WEB SITES FOR GIRLS; Offering Curious Girls Room for Exploration
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/21/techn.print_headline: LIBRARY/WEB SITES FOR GIRLS; Offering Curious Girls Room for Exploration
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/21/techn.body_text: **********AS the mother of a 5-year-old girl, I have high hopes that my daughter will achieve Internet literacy. At the same time, I know how tough it can be to find great Web sites where a girl can safely hang out and have fun. Try typing in ''girl'' on a search engine, and you will see what I mean. There is a plethora of Las Vegas-style entertainment, but not much to comfort a parent. **********Fortunately, there are a few wonderful sites that present utterly absorbing, enjoyable and comparatively safe places for preteen-age and teen-age girls. In fact, I'm convinced that, taken together, Web sites like the ones reviewed here -- Girl Tech,  Purple Moon and A Girl's World --  may just be the ''killer app'' for girls. The traffic tells the story: these sassy sites gather 1.5 million to 2 million hits a month, making them as attractive as, say, www.Disney.com. They employ a magic formula, a successful combination of things many young girls love to do in their free time. **********One of these ingredients is the power to create and develop fantasy worlds over which girls can exert a degree of control. When I was a kid, I loved sharing gifts and secrets with my friends. I liked to write long stories and leave them in my best friend's locker. I liked pretending I was someone else. I had penpals in Europe and Africa. On these sites, a girl can do all the things I loved to do. **********Of course, the Internet can be a creepy place for kids. It is too easy for young Web surfers to be caught in a wave of messages from predators who ask them inappropriate questions about their age, their sex and where they live. So as a nervous parent, I am particularly heartened by the safety precautions taken at these sites. A girl can spend hours on the Web without getting into much more trouble than attends a she-hurt-my-feelings spat with an on-line acquaintance she has never met. The sites' Webmasters -- or Webmistresses -- all go beyond posting lengthy warning messages to parents and rules for girls. **********Purple Moon, for instance, monitors all incoming and outgoing messages and requires a parent to register, too, when her or his daughter signs on to the site. A Girl's World tracks messages and E-mail and reports any suspicious messages to the F.B.I. (The site's founder, Karen Willson, says she has seen only four such messages in the site's two-year history.) Girl Tech circumvents any communication hazards by posting all messages in supervised forums. **********The most important contribution these sites make is that they give girls a place to enjoy themselves and one another without being passive consumers. While they are having fun, they are learning to feel they have a place in the world of computer technology. For my money, that beats anything television can offer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/10/busin.snippet: Patriot American Hospitality Inc, which has $1.2 billion in loans due by 2000, agrees to sell hotels and equity interests in two separate deals for $206.5 million; Patriot to sell seven hotels in Interstate Hotel Management Inc to Paine Webber Rea...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/10/busin.body_text: **********Patriot American Hospitality Inc., which has $1.2 billion in loans due by 2000, agreed today to sell hotels and equity interests in two separate deals for $206.5 million. **********In one transaction, Patriot agreed to sell seven hotels totaling 1,982 rooms and its controlling stake in Interstate Hotel Management Inc. to Paine Webber Real Estate Securities Inc. for $165 million. **********In the other deal, Patriot agreed to sell 100 percent equity interests in the Courtyard by Marriott in Westborough, Mass., and the Residence Inn by Marriott in Pittsburgh, as well as 50 percent equity interests in the Courtyard by Marriott in Orange, Calif., and the Courtyard by Marriott in St. Louis, to Milton D. Fine, a director of Patriot American Hospitality, for a total of $41.5 million. Patriot, based in Dallas, is the nation's second-largest hotel real estate investment trust, with 486 hotels and resorts with more than 105,000 rooms. **********The company disclosed today that settling three equity contracts would either reduce its cash reserves or dilute its common stock. It also said it had delayed indefinitely an $850 million bond offering, originally scheduled for the fourth quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/news/.main_headline: Luxury Fiber Shows Lots of Versatility : Cashmere Shakes Off Its Stuffy Image
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/news/.print_headline: Luxury Fiber Shows Lots of Versatility : Cashmere Shakes Off Its Stuffy Image
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/news/.body_text: **********PARIS—                     Today's fashionable woman lives her life in a cashmere cocoon, preferably four-ply. In the morning she throws off her Malo cashmere-covered hot water bottle, slips on a Lucien Pellat-Finet cashmere tank with a pair of Fake London cashmere bondage pants, eases her feet into her Manolo Blahnik cashmere stilettos and kisses the baby — wrapped in cashmere swaddling — good-bye. **********Cashmere has emerged as the quintessential fiber of the late 1990s, embodying all the relevant fashion values of now. It resonates luxury, sensuality, elitism, heritage and a heady dose of mystique (just how many wearers realize cashmere comes from combing herds of hairy goats roaming Inner Mongolia?). **********"It combines the notion of comfort and exclusivity," says the French cashmere designer Lucien Pellat-Finet, "And, most importantly, it is an exclusivity that is worn for oneself, rather than, say, a fur coat, which is about exclusivity worn for others." **********Right now the consumer longing for cashmere is on a high. In Britain, cashmere brand Brora announced its September sales 100 percent up on the previous year, while in Paris this week Pellat-Finet launches his childrenswear with a spring/summer collection of mini tops and cardigans destined for precious offspring aged two to 14. He is set to add homewear in January with a new line of throws, blankets, cushions and kimono-shaped dressing gowns — all in cashmere. **********Still in Paris, Frederique Hood is also working exclusively in cashmere, designing what she describes as "body accessories" that include ankle and wrist warmers, shoulder warmers (a narrow shawl attached to the upper arms) and a cool abbreviated cape in magenta four-ply cashmere knit. **********And in Milan, the knitwear brand hLam is exploring cashmere's spring/summer potential with their newest yarn, a single-ply cashmere that has been knitted off-gauge to create what they call "cashmere air." **********"It's a super, super light knit and it feels almost like lingerie," explains the designer Gunn Johannson. "We've used it for tiny pieces like T-shirts and camisoles." **********A few years back, cashmere was confined to golf clubs and London's genteel shopping arcades; now it's featured on every runway in town. So what is behind the substantial increase in fashion profile? For a start, designers have realized its potential is a whole lot more exciting than sugary twin-sets. **********"Cashmere is so resilient, so tough, you can do things with it you couldn't possibly do to wool," says Desiree Mejer, of Fake London, who is at the forefront of injecting sex appeal into what was once a prudish yarn. "You can press it, boil it, knot it and it always comes back." **********For spring/summer '99, Mejer has button-fly jeans and bondage pants made from woven cashmere, while for sweaters she has indeed slashed, boiled, safety-pinned, printed and tie-dyed cashmere to get a raw and urban look. **********"Cashmere has always been so stuffy," says Mejer. **********"I wanted to do something more subversive. Although it is a symbol of quality and it is classic and conservative, it is also a question of not being intimidated by all that, but instead repossessing cashmere and doing something different." **********And certainly cashmere's fashion moment is being driven by consumer demand for something different. **********About six years ago, Victoria Stapleton started her mail-order cashmere business Brora in the United Kingdom with the intention, she says, of "supplying your bog-standard cashmere jumper at the same quality as shops, but at cheaper prices because of lesser overheads." **********- **********SO she started with the standard issue of "V-neck navy blue gents jumper," but soon realized that, in fact, what people were craving was, as she puts it: "cashmere in groovy styles. Cashmere has always been so badly designed, so traditional and so basic, I realized just by taking it that one step further and giving it a bit of an edge, it highlighted us from other people." **********Brora styles tend to stay the safe side of fashionable, so although Stapleton has kept a core of basic sweaters, she also offers cashmere hooded tops, slouchy pants, cropped and skinny-rib styles and for next spring/summer she is experimenting with a lacy filigree cashmere with lurex sparkly detail. In six years, Brora sales have grown tenfold, she has opened a retail store on King's Road in London and has just launched a capsule baby Brora cashmere collection. **********The fact that cashmere as a raw material is currently widely available also explains its high fashion profile and accounts for its recent presence on the high street. **********"Normally cashmere is in short supply and is an expensive fiber," says Brian Walbank, sales and marketing director for Todd & Duncan, a Scottish cashmere spinning mill. "But at the moment, due to an accumulation of raw material over a couple of seasons, it is in plentiful supply and every man and his dog wants cashmere selling on his counter." **********Dubbed the democratization of cashmere, it means it is currently being sold at a whole range of price levels and differing qualities with cashmere sweaters available at the French supermarket Monoprix for 490 francs ($88) or Britain's Marks & Spencer from £90 ($150). **********"Cashmere is a word generically known as a luxury fiber," says Walbank. "The big problem is how to differentiate between all the different qualities out there." **********Walbank predicts the current cycle for cashmere at all price levels will last at most a further two years, before returning to being an exclusively prestige fiber. And finally in the rise of cashmere, there is the power of air-conditioning. Thanks to an increasingly temperature-controlled environment, designers and mills alike are betting the future of cashmere is no longer confined to the traditional autumn/winter season, but is reaching out into spring/summer territory. **********- **********TODD & Duncan are working on a fine-weight single ply summer yarn suited to T-shirts and tiny cardigans, while Lucien Pellat-Finet, who has a line of two-ply sweaters and tops insists, "You go somewhere like the States in summer and you go to the supermarket and there is air-conditioning on full blast, or out to a restaurant at night and there's air-conditioning on full blast. If you wore just a T-shirt, you would die." **********Unless that is, it happens to be a cashmere T-shirt, preferably two ply. **********ALICIA DRAKE is a fashion and style writer based in Paris.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/02/news/.main_headline: American Topics : Not All Hippie Communes Have Succumbed to Reality
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/02/news/.print_headline: American Topics : Not All Hippie Communes Have Succumbed to Reality
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/02/news/.body_text: **********In the spring of 1976, a group of long-haired young dreamers bought 304 acres of rolling woodlands near the small town of Harrodsburg, Indiana, and moved into canvas teepees. They slept on dirt floors, cooked over campfires, raised chickens and goats and tended an organic garden. Their dream: to build a Utopian community. **********"In those days you were young and it was all an adventure," recalled Sara Steffey, 47, one of the original members of May Creek Farm. "We were all really happy. It was like retiring in your 20s." **********Such dreams, of course, tend to encounter harsh reality — cold winters, leaky roofs, the need, like it or not, for money. And so hundreds of the communes like May Creek Farm that sprang up in the '60s and '70s disbanded or dissolved. But others remain. A directory produced by a group called the Fellowship for Intentional Community lists 540 North American communes. **********Outside Harrodsburg, the community that started in teepees thrives, though it has evolved. May Creek Farm Inc., now part nature preserve, part housing subdivision, is home to 10 families with 30 members, living in houses, not teepees. Each family owns its own plot of land; together the "creekers," as they call themselves, own 200 acres of surrounding woodlands, which they protect from poachers in search of ginseng, goldenseal and the mushrooms that sprout after rain. **********The group's goal of self-sufficiency has had to be revised. While two families survive through artistic endeavors, several members go into nearby Bloomington to work: as a nurse, a school teacher, a dance instructor. **********There have been differences within the community — some members are Buddhists, others Protestants or followers of American Indian religions. And neighbors have finally overcome their fears of orgies or debauchery in the commune. May Creek survives, largely thanks to its members' love of a simpler country life. "If I had to live in town again," said Heather Jones, 32, "I don't think I could stand it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.snippet: United States urges most of nearly 11,000 Americans living in Indonesia to leave country immediately, citing worst political violence there in more than three decades; Clinton Adm also joins European nations in delaying $1.4 billion emergency aid ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.main_headline: As Strife Grips Indonesia, U.S. Asks Citizens to Leave and Delays Aid Payment
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.print_headline: UNREST IN INDONESIA: THE POLICY; As Strife Grips Indonesia, U.S. Asks Citizens to Leave and Delays Aid Payment
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.body_text: **********The United States today urged most of the nearly 11,000 Americans living in Indonesia to leave the country immediately, citing the worst political violence there in more than three decades. **********The warning to American residents of Indonesia's two largest cities -- Jakarta and Surabaya, which are home to about 6,000 Americans -- was one of several moves announced by the Clinton Administration to deal with the fast-deteriorating situation in Indonesia, where thousands of people have taken to the streets in protest against the 32-year rule of President Suharto. **********The Administration also today joined European nations in delaying a $1.4 billion emergency aid payment and ordered the evacuation of all nonessential employees of the United States Embassy in Jakarta, the Indonesia capital and the scene of the worst violence this week. It also called off a planned mission to Indonesia by a high-ranking American military delegation. **********Violent demonstrations have also been reported in recent weeks in Surabaya, which like Jakarta is on the central Indonesian island of Java. **********In its warning to Americans living in Jakarta and Surabaya, the State Department said that they ''should depart the country as soon as possible'' given that ''widespread protests have increasingly been accompanied by violent confrontations with security forces.'' **********''Live ammunition has been fired at protesters, and several deaths have occurred,'' the department statement said. ''American citizens in other parts of Indonesia may also wish to consider departure at this time. In the meantime, American citizens should avoid large crowds and demonstrations.'' **********If Americans in the two cities follow the State Department's guidance, it will amount to one of the largest evacuations of American citizens from a foreign nation in recent years. **********Today's moves by the Clinton Administration reflected a view now widely held within the United States Government that President Suharto's rule over the world's fourth most populous nation may be coming to a quick, violent end. **********The $1.4 billion payment was supposed to be approved today, the latest installment in a $43 billion Western-led rescue package for Indonesia. But European nations urged a delay in the payment by the Asian Development Bank. The United States agreed, despite promises earlier this week that the Western aid package for Indonesia would not be affected by the rioting in Jakarta. **********The objective of the aid package was to restore the confidence of the markets and bring investors back into the country. Now, many in Washington are arguing that there is little use in continuing to pump money into an economy that was nearing collapse because of the growing political turmoil. **********Clinton Administration officials said the visit to Jakarta by the military delegation led by Adm. Joseph W. Prueher, the commander of all American military forces in the Pacific, was called off at virtually the last minute when it became clear that the roads into Jakarta from the international airport were so insecure that the admiral could not travel on the ground in safety. **********''Given the deterioration today in the situation in Jakarta, including the fact that the road to the airport is closed, there was a literal question of getting into the country and then the question of who do you meet with when you get there,'' said Stanley O. Roth, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs. **********Officials said that Admiral Prueher, the commander in chief of the United States Pacific Command in Honolulu, had been scheduled to meet with his counterparts in the Indonesian military to demand that they end the use of violence against anti-Government demonstrators.  More than two dozen people, most of them civilians, have been reported killed in the rioting this week. **********In testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Mr. Roth said that the State Department had begun planning for the evacuation of American citizens from Indonesia. **********''Given that the situation in Jakarta has become very dicey, with a lot of rioting, we can't guarantee the security of American citizens there, and neither can the Indonesian authorities,'' he said. ''This is not panic, but we all take very seriously our obligations to protect American lives.'' **********The State Department said that it had ordered all ''nonessential'' employees of the United States Embassy to leave the country immediately and warned American citizens not to travel there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/29/techn.snippet: Jason Heckel of Salem, Ore, is sued on charges of violating Washington's law against misleading commercial E-mail, or spam (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/29/techn.main_headline: Lawsuit Against a Spammer Is Filed Under a Oregon Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/29/techn.print_headline: NEWS WATCH; Lawsuit Against a Spammer Is Filed Under a Oregon Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/29/techn.body_text: **********In what is believed to be the first lawsuit brought by a state against a spammer, Jason Heckel of Salem, Ore., has been sued on charges of violating Washington's law against misleading commercial E-mail. Mr. Heckel, 24, has admitted sending between 100,000 and one million pieces of E-mail per week to solicit interest in a get-rich-quick scheme, said Paula Selis, senior counsel in the consumer protection division of the State Attorney General's office. A trial date has been set for March 2000. **********The Washington law, which took effect on June 11, prohibits sending unsolicited commercial messages -- spam -- to any E-mail account identifiable as belonging to a Washington resident if the messages have misleading subject lines, use a third party's domain name without permission or misrepresent the message's point of origin. Mr. Heckel's E-mail included a subject line that said, ''Did I get the right E-mail address?'' -- the kind of subject line that might appear on E-mail from a college friend. The law includes a fine of $2,000 per piece of illegal mail sent. ''People get angry about spam,'' Ms. Selis said. ''They don't like receiving it, especially if it has misrepresentations in it. Having a law like this on the books gives consumers and the Attorney General's office a tool to protect consumers.''   TINA KELLEY

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/17/news/.main_headline: Morse Code Sinks Without an SOS
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/17/news/.print_headline: Morse Code Sinks Without an SOS
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/17/news/.body_text: **********PARIS—                     As the inventor Samuel Morse might have said: **********.. - / .-.. - - - - - - -.- ... / .-.. .. -.- . / SOS / ..-. - - - .-. / - .... . / - - - - - .-. ... . / -.-. - - - -.. . **********It looks like ... --- ... for the Morse Code. **********The communications code made famous by a thousand war movies and tapped out as the Titanic slipped beneath the waves is fast giving way to computers and satellites. **********Within six months, use of the Morse Code will be abolished on all oceangoing passenger ships and cargo vessels above 300 gross tons. It will have been 100 years since the first maritime distress signal was sent in Morse by a lightship in the English Channel, reporting the grounding of the steamship Elbe. **********"There is a wonderful romantic image of the radio operator tapping out a final radio message as the ship sinks beneath him," said Roger Kohn, a spokesman for the International Maritime Organization in London. "But the question is, does anyone survive?" **********The sinking of the Titanic in 1912 with the loss of some 1,500 lives prompted the first international Safety of Life at Sea conference, which called for vessels carrying more than 50 passengers to be equipped with a radio-telegraphic apparatus. **********During the 1990s, most vessels have been upgraded to conform to the global maritime distress and safety system adopted by the International Maritime Organization 10 years ago, and which become universally mandatory next year. The system relies on satellites and a network of ground-based radio stations. **********A ship in distress today no longer has to worry whether an emergency signal is received by other vessels in the vicinity. Mr. Kohn said the message would be picked up by a radio station somewhere in the world, which would coordinate a rescue action using all the resources in the region. **********Take the Achille Lauro, which caught fire and sank in the Indian Ocean in December 1994. Its SOS was received by a ground station in Norway, which quickly directed a flotilla of ships to the scene, enabling all but two of the 979 passengers and crew to be rescued. If the Titanic had had the same kind of radio and satellite equipment, Mr. Kohn said, all aboard could have been saved. **********The combination of wireless and Morse enabled the code to be used as a universal means of communicating at sea, with dots and dashes, or long tones and short, standing for the letters of the alphabet. It may come back into vogue if the world's electronic sinews collapse one day or are knocked out by enemy attack — in fact, the Pentagon still trains Morse operators for such an emergency. But Mr. Kohn said its defects include limited range, slowness, tendency to be disrupted by atmospheric conditions and the difficulty of training operators.
