https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/04/busin.snippet: New York Stock Exchange board votes to no longer require industry arbitration of job-discrimination claims, deciding that it will hear such claims only when they are submitted and after dispute has arisen (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/04/busin.main_headline: Big Board Votes to Abandon Mandatory Job-Bias Arbitration
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/04/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS; Big Board Votes to Abandon Mandatory Job-Bias Arbitration
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/04/busin.body_text: **********The board of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to no longer require industry arbitration of job-discrimination claims, deciding that it will hear such claims only when they are submitted and after a dispute has arisen, according to executives at the exchange. **********The decision, which affects the whole brokerage industry as it covers stockbrokers and other members of the exchange, will be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the next few days, and after a period for public comment, it is expected to lead to a change in the exchange's rules, said James E. Buck, senior vice president and corporate secretary of the exchange. **********The brokerage industry's practice of mandatorily referring employment disputes to industry arbitration -- as many brokerage employees agree to do when they sign their work contracts -- has gradually been eroded. Critics of mandatory arbitration have maintained that it gives unfair advantage to brokerage firms, and denies employees their civil rights by preventing them from getting access to courts. The proponents of mandatory arbitration say it is quicker, cheaper and more efficient than resorting to the courts. **********The change by the Big Board follows Federal court decisions in Massachusetts and California, which held that brokerage firm employees could take discrimination claims to court and did not have to submit to industry arbitration. It also follows a recent decision by the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the Nasdaq market. That body recently ruled that the matter of mandatory arbitration in these cases was one for individual securities firms to decide for themselves. **********George Nicolau, a past president of the National Academy of Arbitrators and now a spokesmen on such issues, called the decision ''a progressive step toward fairness.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/26/busin.snippet: Most of 800 publishers, editors, subscription agents, advertising directors and investment bankers who gathered at conference sponsored by Magazine Publishers of America in Orlando, Fla, express concern about potential for sluggish advertising sal...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/26/busin.body_text: **********It is safe to say that the mood of the conference sponsored by the Magazine Publishers of America in Orlando, Fla., last week, was one of caution. **********Most of the 800 publishers, editors, subscription agents, advertising directors and investment bankers who gathered at the conference expressed trepidation about the potential for sluggish advertising sales in 1999; they were concerned about the European and Asian economies and how the downturn of those economies will affect marketers' budgets; they sweated over newsstand consolidation, which is making distribution more difficult. **********''People are generally feeling scared to pessimistic about next year,'' said Michael Lafavore, the editor in chief of Men's Health, which is published by Rodale Press. **********But it was hard to be too gloomy in a world where most people wear mouse ears and there's a 60-foot-high plaster swan perched atop the neighboring hotel. Disney World, the Walt Disney Company flagship where the conference was held, does not provide the most serious environment for thought-provoking, chin-in-hand discourse. **********So while Kofi Annan, the Secretary General of the United Nations, spoke gravely about the economy (''the global economy is rooted in deep political imbalances,'' was one phrase), some found it difficult to regard him as soberly as they would have had he been speaking from a U.N. podium. He was, after all, at the Disney Yacht and Beach Resort, and remember, this is central Florida -- with no places to anchor a genuine yacht and no beaches, save for the Disney-manufactured ones, upon which to sun. **********Attendees could watch Steven Brill, the editor of Brill's Content, and Norman Pearlstine, editor in chief of Time Inc., debate the issues raised by the CNN Tailwind controversy, typical enough fare for a magazine convention. **********But this conference also featured a unique combination: the chance to speculate about the economy, and the chance to watch an animated cartoon in a screening room in the base of an enormous, fake baobab tree at Animal Kingdom. While Michael Clinton, senior vice president and chief marketing officer for Hearst Magazines, shared his concerns with other publishers on a panel, he also got to ride Space Mountain for the first time. **********Mr. Clinton said that 1997 and 1998 were such stellar years for the magazine industry that it was natural for publishers to wonder how long the good times would last, especially after the recent fluctuations in the stock market. It has been a good decade, over all. In 1997, magazine advertisers spent more than $12.7 billion in the publications tracked by the Publishers Information Bureau; in 1990, they spent only $6.7 billion. In 1997, magazine advertising pages topped 231,000, according to the Publishers Information Bureau -- up 35 percent from 1990. **********''We are all asking ourselves, 'How high is high?' '' Mr. Clinton said. ''So as we look around at all the global markets, it keeps us very concerned about next year. Certainly, I think that the market in the last week or two has been encouraging.'' **********The real tell-tale sign will be retail sales this Christmas season, he said, ''because that's a great barometer of consumer confidence, and when consumers are spending, marketers will feel more comfortable about increasing their spending.'' **********Mr. Lafavore expressed concern about the 12 international editions of his magazine. **********''I used to worry about only one economy,'' he said. ''Now I have to worry about a whole bunch of them. Certainly, in Russia we launched less than a year ago and we came in late to a booming market.'' **********Mr. Lafavore said that he was also concerned about the editions his company publishes in Peru, Colombia and Mexico. ''And we were talking about starting up in Brazil, but things have taken a turn for the worse there,'' he said. **********William F. Reilly, chairman and chief executive of Primedia, which is controlled by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the buyout firm, shocked some guests by saying in the conference's closing speech that he welcomed a recession because it might allow him to snatch up some new properties. **********Reed Phillips 3d, an investment banker with Da Silva & Phillips, suggested another benefit of downturns. ''A recession tends to lead to a shake-out,'' he said. ''There are probably too many magazines, and after a recession you would have fewer magazines. In some markets, you might have eight competitors where you should only have four or five.'' When those extra magazines close, he said, they stop diluting the ad market for the survivors. **********Perhaps Michael Kelly, the editor of National Journal, summed up the conference's surreality most eloquently, if half-jokingly. Mr. Kelly said that holding the publishers' conference at Disney World was ''akin to that sensation you get when you're standing at the edge of a vast ocean, and people always say that kind of moment puts your life in perspective. You realize you're one small mortal. **********''There's a Disney effect like that,'' he continued. ''All these people are going to panels and earnestly discussing the magazine industry and brilliant launches and how to conduct research, but at the same time you're surrounded by this endless Disney world that goes on forever all around you. And you begin to get this feeling. What does all of this matter? In five years, Disney will just own us anyway. We'll all just be another subsidiary.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/11/busin.snippet: Compaq Computer will start selling personal computers directly by telephone and over Internet at prices lower than those charged by local dealers; company is taking step to fend off potent rival, Dell Computer, which has always marketed its machin...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/11/busin.main_headline: Compaq to Sell PC's Directly to Consumers
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/11/busin.print_headline: Compaq to Sell PC's Directly to Consumers
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/11/busin.body_text: **********Compaq Computer, the largest manufacturer of personal computers, will start selling its machines directly by telephone and over the Internet at prices lower than those now charged by local dealers, people close to the company's strategic planning said yesterday. **********While the plan, scheduled to be announced today in New York, is expected to anger some local dealers who sell the vast majority of Compaq's computers, the company is taking the step to fend off a potent rival, Dell Computer, which has always marketed its machines directly and now threatens Compaq's market lead. **********In an unusual attempt to mollify its dealers, Compaq is offering to pay them a referral fee of 6 percent to 7 percent of the purchase price on orders they send to Compaq's direct-sales unit. Dealers would also be allowed to sell the new lower-priced computers themselves, but under less attractive terms. **********A Compaq spokesman declined to confirm the report. **********Antony A. Ibarguen, president of Tech Data Corporation, one of the largest computer wholesalers, said:  ''There are dealers who tend to be paranoid'' about a company that adopts a direct-marketing strategy. ''They may not choose to sell that manufacturer's products.'' **********Other manufacturers saw an opportunity in Compaq's move. **********Jim McDonnell, the marketing manager for Hewlett-Packard's personal computer products, said, ''We hope that what Compaq is doing will drive some resellers into our camp.'' **********Still, many analysts praised Compaq's move as essential. **********''Compaq has no choice but to do something,'' said Robert P. Anastasi, a computer stock analyst with Robinson Humphrey in Atlanta. ''Dell has been so successful it has conditioned customers to ask to buy direct. You can only say no for so long.'' **********Compaq has been losing market share to Dell, now No. 3, which has  grown faster and been more profitable because of the efficiency of its direct-sales model. **********The International Business Machines Corporation, the No. 2 personal computer seller, has also been moving to sell more machines directly, although it has mainly focused on its traditional base of large companies. **********''We will have the capacity to sell to all our customers directly,'' said David M. Thomas, the senior vice president of I.B.M. in charge of its PC group. ''For small businesses, our focus is on the small resellers' channel. We will focus our direct efforts on the large enterprise market.'' **********Compaq's new effort is aimed mainly at small to medium-sized businesses, a market that until now has bought fewer computers from direct sellers than either big businesses or consumers have. **********''The small and midsized business market is growing rapidly, but until now it has been very fragmented,'' said Andy Bose, the president of Access Media International-USA. The majority of small-business owners, he said, buy what the industry calls ''white box'' computers, machines assembled by local dealers. He said there was a huge opportunity for direct sales to small businesses because many companies were no longer buying their first computer. Companies are more secure and need less help when replacing machines. **********Over all, small business will account for about 9 million of the 36 million computers that will be sold this year, Mr. Bose said. **********Long recognizing the threat from Dell, Compaq has spent years improving its manufacturing efficiency and reducing inventory, a costly hot potato in a market in which computer prices often fall by 1 percent to 2 percent a week. **********Two years ago, Compaq introduced a direct-to-consumer sales effort via toll-free telephone calls. But the results have been tepid, mainly because Compaq kept its prices high to avoid angering dealers. **********''For nearly five years, we've been hearing that Compaq was going to get more efficient to compete with the likes of Dell, Gateway and Micron,'' said Joel Kocher, chief executive of Micron Computer, a direct sales company that focuses on small business. ''To date, their efforts have been less than successful.'' **********Compaq's plan to build a ''hybrid'' model that combines direct sales with dealer sales is fraught with peril, analysts say. **********''You cannot be all things to all people in all places in all industries,'' said Tony Amico, an analyst with International Data. ''You need resellers that know about specific industries and who can reach out to America beyond the big cities.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/08/techn.snippet: Josh Gabriel, musician and computer programmer, helps form Mixman Technologies, San Francisco, which last year released software package, Mixman Studio, for PC's that creates self-contained recording studio and real-time mixer; software makes comp...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/08/techn.main_headline: Music Made Easier; It's All In the Mix
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/08/techn.print_headline: Music Made Easier; It's All In the Mix
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/08/techn.body_text: **********FOR years Josh Gabriel, a musician and computer programmer, had looked for a way to make composing and recording music as simple for the average person as desktop publishing had made producing newsletters. **********Traditionally, anyone wanting to make music had to play an instrument or have a pleasing singing voice. And even becoming a rapper required some talent and practice and a deejay, someone who mixed music on increasingly expensive and complicated equipment. **********''I just wanted to let people actually get their own hands on music,'' Mr. Gabriel said. **********Four years ago he helped to form Mixman Technologies in San Francisco and began building just such an enabling technology. The result was Mixman Studio, released last Christmas. It is a software package for PC's that creates a self-contained recording studio and a real-time mixer. (A Mac version is due in December.) **********The latest version of the mixer, which is the heart of the application, has a sound-effects studio and editing capacity and is to go on sale next month. The mixer resembles a three-dimensional view of a deejay's dual turntables. Any WAV file, the common means of storing sound in PC's, can be used with Mixman. **********Mr. Gabriel's company also sells enhanced music CD's that are packed with hundreds of prerecorded samples, or clips, of music. Mr. Gabriel, who is vice president and creative director of Mixman Technologies, added that his company buys the rights to the musical samples, some from well-known artists like George Clinton and Naughty by Nature. That makes the sound clips royalty-free. **********Once these clips -- short loops of musical phrases like bass lines, synthesizer chords, vocal tracks, percussion and sound effects -- are placed with a mouse click into Mixman, they become represented on the mixer by a letter or number. Hold down the 'I' key, for instance, and as long as it is depressed the sound of a drum playing is heard. Each of the 16 keys call up musical sounds, each synchronized to play together in key and tempo. But Mixman has its limitations. Creating music with complex harmonic structures is practically impossible. Mr. Gabriel acknowledged that Mixman is best suited for creating highly rhythmic music that tends to depend heavily on repetitious elements. **********While some musicians have rejected the idea of inviting listeners to remix their finished work, others, Mr. Gabriel said, have welcomed it. ''They understand that there is something to having a fan appreciate in a deeper way what the artist is doing by letting them into the work,'' he said. **********A limited version of Mixman Studio can be downloaded free at www.mixman.com. The retail version costs $49.95; the deluxe model, Mixman Studio Pro, with sound effects and editing additions, is due in stores in November for about $119.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/12/busin.body_text: **********Vanguard Cellular Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its cellular telephone operations in North and South Carolina for $190 million. Its operations in Myrtle Beach, S.C., serving a population of 250,000, will go to Triton PCS Inc. for $160 million. The company's 48 percent stake in the cellular operations of Wilmington and Jacksonville, N.C., serving 170,000 people, will be sold for $30 million to the United States Cellular Corporation. Vanguard, based in Greensboro, N.C., will use the proceeds to reduce long-term debt and to finance an extended stock repurchase program. Its stock rose $1 a share, to $17.125. United States Cellular's shares rose 56.25 cents, to $31.875.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/12/world.body_text: **********EUROPE **********BRITAIN: PINOCHET'S DEFENSE -- A British law that provides immunity to former heads of state would have protected even Adolf Hitler from arrest and prosecution in Britain, lawyers for Gen. Augusto Pinochet told Britain's highest court. General Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator, is resisting extradition to Spain, which wants him to face trial in connection with crimes allegedly committed during his rule.   Sarah Lyall (NYT) **********RUSSIA: JAPAN'S PREMIER ARRIVES -- Prime Minister Keizo  Obuchi of Japan arrived in Moscow on the first official visit by a Japanese leader in 25 years. Relations have been cool for decades because Japan wants Russia to return four small islands in the Kuriles that Soviet troops seized in 1945.   (Reuters) **********GREECE: NAZIS' 'LOAN' -- Foreign Minister Theodoros Pangalos of Greece said the new German Government should repay $3.5 billion that Nazi occupation forces forcibly borrowed from the Bank of Greece during World War II. Bank and Government officials have said that applying a minimum 3 percent interest lifted the total amount owed today to $13 billion.   (Reuters) **********ASIA **********CHINA: CLINTON-DALAI LAMA TALK IRKS BEIJING -- China has strongly protested President Clinton's meeting on Tuesday with the Dalai Lama as well as the visit to Taiwan by Energy Secretary Bill Richardson, calling their actions interference in China's internal affairs.   Erik Eckholm (NYT) **********CHINA: BLOCK ON FOREIGN CURRENCY -- Chinese state banks have begun blocking most foreign-currency transfers within the country as part of a crackdown on illegal money trading, bank officials said. Chinese individuals and companies have been buying dollars out of concern the yuan would be devalued.   (AP) **********CHINA: SOUTH KOREAN LEADER'S VISIT -- President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea and more than 250 officials and corporate executives arrived in Beijing for a five-day visit. China and South Korea have become major trade partners, although China remains a rare diplomatic ally of North Korea.   Erik Eckholm (NYT) **********INDIA: HARSH WORDS FOR PAKISTAN -- Raising the level of acrimony in the contentious talks between India and Pakistan, India's Home Minister, Lal Krishna Advani, said, ''As far as we are concerned, Pakistan is a terrorist state.'' Mr. Advani, a powerful figure in the governing Hindu nationalist party, labeled India's rival as an international outlaw for allegedly giving material support to Muslim militants in the disputed Kashmir.   Barry Bearak (NYT) **********JAPAN: DEAL FOR VOUCHER PROGRAM -- The governing  Liberal Democratic Party of Japan has agreed to an opposition party's demands to issue gift vouchers in an effort to stimulate domestic economic demand. The vouchers, amounting to $5.7 billion, will be distributed to elderly pensioners with low incomes, the disabled and families with children. The plan has been criticized by  other politicians, business executives and economists as a gimmick.   Stephanie Strom (NYT) **********IRAN: REWARDING A WINNING GOAL -- An Iranian soccer player, Mehdi Mahdavi-Kia, has been exempted from military service in gratitude for the winning goal he scored in a World Cup match against the United States in June, the Iranian newspaper Etelaat reported.   (Agence France-Presse) **********MIDDLE EAST **********ISRAEL: RELIGIOUS PARTY'S GAIN -- Religious parties won nearly half the seats in Jerusalem's city council, preliminary results showed, a development that will give rigorously Orthodox parties a big say in the future of the disputed city. Rigorously Orthodox Jews make up about one-third of Jerusalem's population of 600,000.   (AP) **********CYPRUS: STATEMENT ON ISRAELIS' ROLE -- Trying to dispel persistent rumors, Israel's Foreign Ministry said that two Israelis arrested in Cyprus last week as suspected spies were not working for Turkey, but did not say who had employed them. The arrests have strained relations between Israel and Cyprus, which is suspicious of Israel's military pact with Turkey.   (AP) **********AFRICA **********NIGERIA: INDUSTRIES GOING PRIVATE -- Nigeria has started to privatize key state-controlled industries as part of a move toward economic reform, the country's military ruler, Gen. Abdulsalami Abubakar said. State-controlled agencies to be fully or partially sold off include the country's telecommunications, mining and energy industries.   (AP) **********SOUTH AFRICA: DE KLERK'S REQUEST DENIED -- President Nelson Mandela has rejected an application from his predecessor F. W. de Klerk, for state funds to cover legal fees incurred in his attempt to stop the Truth and Reconciliation Commission from implicating him in human rights violations during the apartheid era.   (NYT) **********THE AMERICAS **********CHILE: U.N. WITHDRAWS PINOCHET OFFICER -- A Chilean general linked by human rights groups to unlawful executions during the era of Gen. Augusto Pinochet is being withdrawn from United Nations peacekeeping duty in Kashmir. The Secretary General's spokesman, Fred Eckhard, said that Chile had promoted the officer, Brig. Gen. Sergio Espinoza Davies, to major general and was appointing him inspector general of the Chilean Army.   Barbara Crossette (NYT) **********CHILE: LEADER BEGINS PRETORIA TRIP -- President Eduardo Frei flew to South Africa to begin a nine-day international trade mission, putting aside concerns that domestic political dissent could escalate if a panel of the British House of Lords rules that Gen. Augusto Pinochet can be extradited to Spain to stand trial.   Clifford Krauss (NYT) **********Compiled by Christopher S. Wren

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/06/busin.snippet: Daniel Akst column on trend toward casual dress in workplace discusses demise of necktie as emblem of masculine propriety; drawing (M)/
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/06/busin.main_headline: Foulard and Rep, Rest in Peace? Not So Fast!
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/06/busin.print_headline: THE CULTURE OF MONEY; Foulard and Rep, Rest in Peace? Not So Fast!
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/06/busin.body_text: **********WOMEN everywhere this holiday season are out buying neckties for the men in their lives. They might just as well be gift-wrapping spittoons. **********December 1998 finds the American workplace more casual than ever: Four out of five workers get to dress down at least one day a week, according to Peter Simon of NPD Group, a market research firm. And a recent survey of hiring executives by Management Recruiters International found that 42 percent believe the suit and tie will ultimately disappear. (Most of these doomsayers think it will happen in the next 10 years.) **********Consider the situation at the Pro Player sports licensing unit of Fruit of the Loom in Hudson, N.H. A company spokesman described the place as so actively hostile to neckwear that it bans ties from the premises. Until recently, the company had a rack in the lobby where guests could park these primitive totems; the rack was removed recently because no one ever turns up in a tie anymore. **********Times certainly have changed. In the days of afternoon baseball and snap-brim hats, of hair oil and smoker's coughs, men who pretended to any sort of social class wore neckties to ball games and apologized for being in public without a suit coat. The necktie was the emblem of masculine propriety. As Monica Lewinsky put it, in grand jury testimony that must have rung bittersweet with haberdashers everywhere, ''Ties were a big issue with us.'' **********If neckties are an endangered species, it should not be too surprising. They are the ultimate Freudian accouterment in an increasingly gender-neutral workplace. In that sense, the old four-in-hand can seem as Neanderthal as pinup calendars and secretary-chasing. **********Neckwear is also associated with a more formal era, when people worked in downtown offices and did business face to face. These days, more of us do at least some of our work at home, or in suburban office parks far from the public gaze. **********And in an age when everyone is cool and confession is valued over concealment, neckties can seem awfully buttoned up, their wearers secretive, rigid and constrained. On sitcoms, a high-school student in a tie is usually a geek, the sort of social climber who intends to run for student council president. He may be liked, as Biff says in ''Death of a Salesman,'' but he isn't well liked. **********So why do women (who account for half of all necktie purchases) keep buying them for men? Dr. Joyce Brothers has weighed in on the subject. ''It is a gift of manhood,'' she said, citing an ''implied intimacy'' that prevents women from giving ties to just any casual acquaintance or co-worker. A cigar may be just a cigar, but Ms. Lewinsky knew that a necktie is something else again, which is why she made presents of them to the Commander in Chief. **********There's no equivalent to the tie in women's wardrobes. They once tried floppy bow ties but soon abandoned them for a less derivative brand of business attire. And in men's wardrobes, there is no substitute: Without neckties to channel decorative instincts, men are left to flounder uncertainly in a sea of corduroys, khakis and ''dressy casuals.'' **********Chesterton once said, ''When man ceases to believe in God, he does not believe in nothing. He believes in anything.'' Post-necktie, we may be in for the sartorial equivalent. **********Besides, a necktie implies a certain maturity in a man, the way long pants once did. Should we really be wearing T-shirts and flip-flops to the office when we're past the age of reason? Haven't school districts across the country, in adopting dress codes and uniforms, acted on the belief that disdainful clothing and disdainful behavior are connected? **********There are signs of a backlash against the untie-ing of adult America as well. The Douglas County, Neb., Register of Deeds has adopted an employee dress code, including ties for male managers, and sent a copy to private firms whose employees often visit the office, in the hope that they, too, will comply. **********And the necktie on America's most influential office worker, Dilbert, always points upward, an inextinguishable symbol of hope in the office-cubicle wasteland. Either that, or it badly needs ironing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/30/world.snippet: US will pledge hundreds of millions of dollars in aid to Palestinians and is pressing other wealthy nations to dramatically increase economic assistance to encourage them to stick to peace process with Israel; aid package, to be announced at inter...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/30/world.main_headline: U.S. to Increase Package Of Aid to Palestinians
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/30/world.print_headline: U.S. to Increase Package Of Aid to Palestinians
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/30/world.body_text: **********The United States will pledge hundreds of millions of dollars in aid to the Palestinians this week and is pressing other wealthy nations to dramatically increase economic assistance to encourage the Palestinians to stick to the peace process with Israel, senior Clinton Administration officials said. **********The new American aid package, to be announced on Monday at a one-day international donors' conference here, could total as much as $900 million over the next five years, officials said. In all, they hope the conference will raise $2.3 billion for the Palestinians, the amount pledged at the last major donors' conference in October 1993, shortly after the Oslo peace accords. **********''I'm not going to tell you precisely what we'll pledge because we're still in consultations with Congress,'' a senior State Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said last week. ''But I can tell you that we do plan to substantially increase the amount of assistance that we will provide for this next five-year period.'' **********Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright will be the host for the conference, which will be attended by President Clinton; Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and the Foreign Ministers of Saudi Arabia, Egypt and other Arab nations. **********''We'd like to see if we can do better'' than in 1993, the State Department official said. ''One way to underpin peace and to build a constituency of peace is to make certain that people are better off.'' **********The Israeli Foreign Minister, Ariel Sharon, will not attend the conference because of what American officials described as domestic political turmoil. The Israeli team will be led by the Director General of the Foreign Ministry, Eytan Bentsur. **********Mr. Arafat arrived in Washington on Saturday and had lunch today with Secretary of Commerce William M. Daley and a group of 15 American business leaders. He also met groups of Arab Americans. **********In past years, much of the American aid money for the Palestinians has been used for infrastructure, including the paving of more than 400 miles of roads that knit together scattered towns and villages in the West Bank and Gaza. **********American aid to the Palestinians is expected to increase, in part because of promises that President Clinton made to Mr. Arafat's Palestinian Authority and to Israel that Washington would pick up much of the bill for the land-for-security plan that was hammered out in negotiations last month in Wye, Md. **********The Israelis are expected to seek up to $1.2 billion in additional aid as a result of the Wye agreement, while Palestinian officials have suggested that they will solicit as much as $400 million in new aid. **********The United States also hopes that an expanded aid package to the Palestinians will allow Mr. Arafat to blunt the influence of the radical Islamic militant organization Hamas, which has built public support by sponsoring medical clinics, schools and sport clubs. **********State Department officials said  only two Arab nations -- Syria and Lebanon -- turned down invitations to the meeting on Monday, just as they did when invited to the 1993 conference. Syria and the Syrian-controlled Government of Lebanon have been harsh critics of the Israeli-Palestinian peace process. **********Even as they spoke optimistically about the chances of increasing aid to the Palestinians, State Department officials acknowledged that they had effectively suspended plans to open a Middle East development bank, an institution that they had once billed as a symbol of economic cooperation among Israel, the Palestinians and their neighbors. **********Plans for the Middle East and North Africa Development Bank were announced in 1994. The bank, with the United States as its largest shareholder, was supposed to encourage Israelis and Arabs to work together with private investors on regional development projects. **********But the United States was unable to get the main Middle East partners in the project -- Israel, Egypt, Jordan and the Palestinians -- to agree on a charter for the bank. And without their support, State Department officials said, Congress refused to make a contribution to capitalize the bank.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/31/world.snippet: Government investigation into disappearance of scores of people in northern Mexico is thrown into turmoil by discovery that narcotics traffickers infiltrated unit carrying out probe; discovery follows January 18 gangland-style execution of Hector ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/31/world.main_headline: Drug Lords Infiltrated a Mexico Inquiry Into Disappearances
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/31/world.print_headline: Drug Lords Infiltrated a Mexico Inquiry Into Disappearances
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/31/world.body_text: **********A Government investigation into the disappearance of scores of people in northern Mexico has been thrown into turmoil by the discovery that narcotics traffickers infiltrated one of their agents into the unit carrying out the inquiry. **********Attorney General Jorge Madrazo Cuellar said in an interview that he had been stunned to learn that a federal police officer with ties to traffickers had been assigned to take part in one of the country's most sensitive investigations. **********''I lost all confidence in the group,'' Mr. Madrazo said on Monday. ''I had to wonder how many more corrupt agents like him were in that unit. What had they done to this inquiry?'' He said he intended to appoint new prosecutors and detectives to carry out the investigation. **********Mr. Madrazo said he and his aides first detected the infiltration after hearing of the gangland-style execution in Ciudad Juarez on Jan. 18 of Hector Mario Varela, a federal police commander, and learning that Mr. Varela had weeks earlier been assigned to work with the unit. **********Mr. Varela's assassins shouted ''This is to teach you to keep your word!'' as they fired 20 bullets into his body, Mr. Madrazo said. The style of the execution, as well as a review of intelligence files, convinced Mr. Madrazo that Mr. Varela was a corrupt officer who had been infiltrated into the investigation. Authorities are trying to determine who engineered Mr. Varela's assignment, Mr. Madrazo said. **********''It's absolutely clear that he was a narco-policeman,'' he said. **********The inquiry has centered on Ciudad Juarez, a gritty border city across from El Paso that is a crossroads in a multibillion-dollar drug trade and where at least 90 people, including several Americans, have vanished since early 1994. Most have had peripheral ties to the narcotics underworld, and many have vanished after being detained by men with police uniforms or credentials. **********Recently the Government inquiry has focused on a review of the way Chihuahua State handled dozens of missing-persons investigations, which federal prosecutors have said were sloppy and perhaps criminally negligent. Mr. Madrazo recently issued a subpoena to a senior Chihuahua police commander, saying he intended to ask about why the investigative files were in such chaos. **********The prosecutors also plan to question the commander about reports that he led families of the disappeared to believe that their relatives were being held secretly by the United States Government, a notion the prosecutors, as well as two United States officials, have ridiculed. **********Mr. Madrazo said he intended to take statements from the commander, Francisco Minjares, who heads Chihuahua's anti-kidnapping squad, and perhaps from other officials, as soon as he assembles his new team. Mr. Madrazo said he had pledges of cooperation from Gov. Francisco Barrio Terrazas of Chihuahua.  ''There are signs that the state investigations into the disappeared in Chihuahua were carried out in a very deficient and irregular fashion,'' Mr. Madrazo said. ''In some cases it appears that after people reported the disappearances, nothing was investigated. I told the Governor that we're going to have to formally question several public servants.'' **********In an interview on Thursday, Arturo Chavez Chavez, Chihuahua's attorney general, defended Mr. Minjares as an honest official but said his state's law enforcement authorities may have responded poorly as scores of people disappeared. **********''Perhaps some of our investigations were not well done,'' Mr. Chavez said. ''Maybe they should have been done better.'' On the other hand, he said, federal officials should not direct suspicions exclusively at Chihuahua police officials, since many relatives of vanished persons have accused federal officers of detaining the victims before they disappeared. **********Last year people from both sides of the border formed an Association of Relatives of Disappeared Persons to pressure authorities for a full accounting. The group's leaders have complained that investigations by both federal and state authorities have appeared chaotic or corrupt. **********With public awareness of the disappearances growing last year, Mr. Madrazo formed the 20-man unit and ordered its coordinator, Jorge Castaneda Espinoza de los Monteros, to review all investigations and to clarify responsibilities. Mr. Castaneda said in a recent interview that he had studied thousands of pages of case files and taken statements from more than 100 people in Juarez. **********Mr. Castaneda said several relatives of vanished people had told him under oath that during investigations Mr. Minjares's, the leader of the anti-kidnap squad, had urged them not to speak out because their relatives were in the United States in a witness protection program. **********''Minjares would say, 'Look, don't make waves about this, your relative is being taken care of,' '' Mr. Castaneda said. **********Lourdes Rayos Jaquez, an El Paso resident whose two brothers disappeared in Juarez after their detention by federal agents in November 1995, has testified that Mr. Minjares told her that one of her brothers, Francisco, was being held by American authorities in Houston. **********''Personally, I don't believe these people are being held in the United States,'' Mr. Castaneda said. ''I think that's an infantile accusation.'' **********In a Jan. 11 meeting in Juarez with families of the disappeared, James Ward, the United States Consul there, said he had consulted with many American law enforcement officials, and, ''I have never encountered anything that would lead me to believe that any of these people are part of the witness protection program.'' **********Mr. Madrazo said that last year he asked the American Government whether the United States is holding any of the disappeared and is still waiting for an answer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/12/world.snippet: Jyoti Basu, West Bengal's Chief Minister and India's pre-eminent Communist leader, remains hugely popular despite Communists' failures; Basu, whose investment-friendly policies have put him at odds with hard-line Communists, has agreed to head coa...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/12/world.body_text: **********When Jyoti Basu arrived for an election rally in this town on the southern fringes of Calcutta, a crowd of about 25,000 people greeted him with shouts of ''Lal Salaam!'' meaning ''Red Salute!'' The podium was draped with red bunting and a hammer-and-sickle insignia. Mr. Basu's first words were in similar vein. ''Comrades,'' he said, ''I bring you fraternal greetings!'' **********In an India increasingly enamored of American-style capitalism, Mr. Basu might be taken for a man out of his time. At 83, he is the pre-eminent figure in India's fractured Communist Party. For 20 years, he has been Chief Minister of West Bengal, a state with 75 million people. His base is Calcutta, a city of 12 million people with dying industries and festering slums that is an archetype of problems that accumulated in the decades when India took the Soviet Union for its economic model. **********Despite the Communists' failures, Mr. Basu remains hugely popular. ''I love Comrade Jyoti and everything he stands for,'' said Vishwanath Mitra, a skinny stubble-bearded man who sat in the crowd clutching a red banner. Mr. Mitra, 42, said he had worked for years as a painter for 3.50 rupees an hour, barely 30 cents in the 1970's, before Communist reforms increased his daily pay to 60 rupees, now about $1.30. ''All I have achieved in life, I have achieved through this flag,'' Mr. Mitra said. **********But as Indians prepare for a general election that will culminate in a final round of voting on March 7, Communists across India are having to do some fresh thinking. For several years now, Mr. Basu's government has been hailed by Western businessmen as one of the most investment-friendly among India's 25 states, to the point that some Indians question whether Mr. Basu's faction of the party, the Communist Party of India (Marxist), remains Communist in anything but name. **********Now, another ideological somersault seems to be imminent, forced by the political arithmetic of the election. Only 20 months ago, after a  1996 general election that produced the most splintered Parliament in India's history, Mr. Basu was invited to become Prime Minister in a coalition Government of 13 regional and leftist parties. Under pressure from Communist hard-liners, Mr. Basu refused, saying the party did not wish to compromise its principles by heading a Government that it could not fully control. **********Mr. Basu later described the decision as a ''historic blunder.'' But by then the coalition Government, under two lackluster Prime Ministers from center-left parties, was stumbling toward political oblivion, finally collapsing in December 1997. This led to the current election, and polls that have established a further rise in popularity of the Bharatiya Janata Party, or B.J.P., the right-wing Hindu nationalist group whose specter forced the accommodations between squabbling groups that produced the coalition Government in 1996. **********This time, Mr. Basu and the Communist Party of India (Marxist) have said they will join a coalition and will agree to Mr. Basu's heading it, if the opportunity arises. The reasons for the change of heart were made clear in Mr. Basu's speech at the rally here, in which he said that the B.J.P.'s rise had confronted Indians with a choice as crucial as any since independence in 1947. **********Although the B.J.P. has never been closer to winning an election, it has chosen not to play down elements in its creed that have prompted critics to say it favors a ''Muslim bashing'' India in which 700 million Hindus would suppress the rights of 120 million Muslims. In its election manifesto, the party has advocated a raft of policies that are anathema to Muslims, including plans to build a Hindu temple on the site of a 16th-century mosque, in the northern city of Ayodhya, that was destroyed by a Hindu mob on Dec. 6, 1992. **********To Mr. Basu, an atheist raised in a Hindu family, the B.J.P.'s plans amount to an assault on the foundations of Indian democracy, as laid down by Mohandas K. Gandhi and others in the independence generation. ''The choice before us has never been more clear, or more crucial,'' the Communist leader said. ''This is the 50th year of our independence, and the 50th year after the assassination of Mahatma Gandhi, and it is time to think of what kind of nation we have become.'' **********He added: ''After 5,000 years of civilization, do we want an India where political power will rest with people who destroy mosques? Do we want to be ruled by barbarians who will attempt to divide us on communal lines? Or do you want an India where all people are treated equally, whatever their religion, their caste or ethnic group? I say to all of you, this is a dangerous moment in our history, so you must think very carefully before you vote.'' **********For Communists, the B.J.P.'s rise  has required a shift in attitudes toward the Congress Party, which ruled in New Delhi for most of the country's first 40 years as an independent nation. For much of that time, Congress was anathema to the Communists. But recently Mr. Basu and other pragmatists have argued that Communists must identify ''the main enemy'' -- the Hindu nationalists -- and bury old differences with Congress. **********The logic has become compelling in the wake of the resurgence of the Congress Party under Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born widow of Rajiv Gandhi, the Congress Party leader assassinated in the final days of campaigning for the 1991 election. Drawing vast crowds across the country, Mrs. Gandhi has raised hopes among Congress supporters that the party, in a slump for years, may revive enough to emerge from the election  with enough seats to lead a coalition. **********Recent polls have suggested that Mrs. Gandhi's campaign is making inroads into the B.J.P.'s earlier lead, perhaps enough to make a non-B.J.P. Government possible. Outlook magazine, a widely respected weekly, reported in its current edition that its latest poll, among 16,300 voters across the country in the last week of January, showed the B.J.P. and Congress neck and neck in popular support, with slightly less than 30 percent backing for the parties and groups allied to them. The poll showed 23 percent support for the United Front, an alliance of parties that formed or supported the departing Government, including Mr. Basu's Communists. The remaining 17 percent supported other splinter parties, or were undecided. **********One of Mr. Basu's trickiest tasks has been to respond to Mrs. Gandhi's emergence as a potential Prime Minister, a prospect that privately concerns many veteran political leaders who may be forced to join in a Congress-led coalition or, like Mr. Basu,  are considered prime ministerial candidates themselves. **********At Sonarpur, Mr. Basu described Mrs. Gandhi as ''a housewife,'' a term also used by B.J.P. leaders. But the Communist leader sought to differentiate his remark from that of the B.J.P. leaders, who have lost no opportunity to belittle Mrs. Gandhi. **********''By calling her a housewife, I mean only honor to her, and in any case I am not wrong,'' he said. ''I am simply pointing out that she has spent much of her life as many Indian women do, nurturing her children and running her home.'' **********As chuckles rippled through the crowd, the Communist leader added an afterthought, as if to preserve his ideological rectitude, and perhaps his hopes of becoming Prime Minister. **********''Some say Sonia is Italian, that she has no right,'' he said. ''But this is nonsense; she is an Indian citizen, and has as much right to enter politics as the rest of us. In any event, the issue has been overstated. The Congress Party is rotten to the core, and even if the Son of God were to appear in India, he could not save it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/27/busin.snippet: Young & Rubicam Inc, world's fifth-largest advertising agency, says it has filed registration statement with Securities and Exchange Commission for initial public offering of its stock; offering is projected to raise $350 million (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/27/busin.main_headline: After years of anticipation, Young & Rubicam is finally preparing for a public stock offering.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/27/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; After years of anticipation, Young & Rubicam is finally preparing for a public stock offering.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/27/busin.body_text: **********THE long anticipated foray of Young & Rubicam Inc. onto Wall Street is at last under way. **********Y.& R., the world's fifth-largest agency company, with billings estimated at $12 billion, said yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of its stock. The I.P.O., which had been expected for almost two years, is projected to raise $350 million. **********''It's big,'' said Alan J. Gottesman, who follows the agency industry as managing director of West End Communications/Consulting in New York, the largest ''since the Ark.'' **********The shares to be sold will be offered by Y.& R., which was founded in New York in 1923; top executives of Y.& R. who own stock in the company, and Hellman & Friedman Capital Partners III L. P., a unit of Hellman & Friedman, a private investment firm in San Francisco. **********The number of shares to be sold in the offering and their price will be disclosed in a subsequent filing. **********The offering is the brainchild of top executives at Y.& R., led by Peter A. Georgescu, the charismatic chairman and chief executive who has quietly transformed a somewhat somnolent operation into a powerhouse capable of handling huge accounts on a worldwide basis in realms ranging from traditional advertising to newer frontiers like interactive marketing. **********Mr. Georgescu has recognized that in the prevailing wisdom of Wall Street, which has favored the stocks of large, publicly held agency companies, Y.& R. has been operating at a disadvantage. The stock offering is meant to rectify that. **********The offering ''is very prudent'' for top managers of Y.& R., Mr. Gottesman said. ''It will not only raise cash to benefit their balance sheet; it gives them a new currency with which to make acquisitions. **********''When you do stock-for-stock acquisitions,'' he continued, ''they can be tax free or tax deferred to the seller.'' That has been a puissant argument in favor of large, publicly traded rivals of Y.& R. like the Interpublic Group of Companies and Omnicom Group, which have used their highly valued stocks to snap up scores of independent agencies. **********Y.& R. plans to use the proceeds from the I.P.O. to repay a portion of bank debt, according to the filing. **********The acquisition by Hellman & Friedman in August 1996 of a significant minority stake in Y.& R., believed to have been 20 percent, came as part of a recapitalization of the agency company. That sale was the first step in the lengthy road that Y.& R. would travel to join Interpublic, Omnicom and WPP Group as publicly traded companies. Hellman & Friedman, known for its role in arranging leveraged buyouts, was the first outside investor in the history of Y.& R. **********Y.& R. has reorganized its top management several times in recent months, also in prelude to the offering. **********According to the filing, Y.& R. -- which offers services that in addition to advertising include public relations, direct marketing and sales promotion -- had a net loss of $23.9 million last year on revenue of $1.38 billion. That compared with a net loss of $238.3 million in 1996 on revenue of $1.22 billion, which stemmed in part from special charges. **********Based on the valuations of Interpublic and Omnicom, about two times revenue, Y.& R.'s total value  could be $2.5 billion, Mr. Gottesman said. That price would include a so-called I.P.O. discount, which takes into account the company's lack of a track record as publicly held entity. **********Agency brands under the Y.& R. umbrella include Young & Rubicam Advertising, the public relations agency Burson-Marsteller, the direct marketing agency Wunderman Cato Johnson and Landor Associates, a corporate and brand identity consulting company. **********The client list of Y.& R. reads very much like a who's who of blue-chip marketers, including Citicorp; the Colgate-Palmolive Company; the Ford Motor Company; Pepsico Inc.; the Philip Morris Companies, and Sears, Roebuck & Company. The agency company has been particularly successful in landing giant consolidated accounts of global behemoths like the Citibank unit of Citicorp and Colgate-Palmolive. **********The co-lead underwriters for the offering are the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation and Bear, Stearns & Company, both of New York. The co-managers, also based in New York, are Furman Selz L.L.C.; Goldman, Sachs & Company, and Salomon Smith Barney. **********Y.& R. plans for its shares to trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol YNR. **********You were expecting maybe ADS?

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/world.snippet: British troops will stop patrolling Belfast area this weekend and some paramilitary prisoners will be released in next few days (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/world.main_headline: In a New Sign of Peace in Ulster, Troops Will Halt Belfast Patrols
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/world.print_headline: In a New Sign of Peace in Ulster, Troops Will Halt Belfast Patrols
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/world.body_text: **********British troops will stop patrolling the Belfast area this weekend and some paramilitary prisoners will be released in the next few days, officials said today. **********The decisions, which indicate significant progress in the Northern Ireland peace effort, came as the head of the Protestant Unionist Party, David Trimble, and the political leader of the Irish Republican Army, Gerry Adams, held private talks for the first time. They met for 45 minutes on the issues that still divide them, mainly the timing of disarmament by the I.R.A. **********On Monday the two men addressed each other briefly for the first time at a meeting of leaders of the new Northern Ireland Assembly, which is to enact the political reforms of the peace agreement reached last spring. Mr. Trimble is the First Minister of the Assembly and Mr. Adams is a member of it. **********At today's meeting, the two men, until recently openly bitter enemies, went into a second-floor room at the Parliament Buildings and talked by themselves. **********''It was the first time ever that a leader of Irish republicanism sat down face to face with a leader of Ulster unionism,'' said Richard McAuley, an assistant to Mr. Adams. **********Monica McWilliams, a member of the Assembly representing the Women's Coalition, said, ''After the painful summer we've had, we deserve one of these days.'' **********''This is a good message to put out -- that the heads of unionism and republicanism are sitting down together,'' she added. **********Of the negotiations to come on details of the peace agreement, which are supposed to give Roman Catholics more political power, Ms. McWilliams said: ''There are still enemies. There are still people who hate each other. But still this is an important day, a historic day.'' **********The withdrawal of British troops to their barracks this weekend was announced by Ronnie Flanagan, the Police Chief of the predominantly Protestant British province, who controls the movements of all security forces. **********He said the withdrawal was possible because ''we currently have a reduced terrorist threat.'' He said it was a ''distinct possibility'' that some of the 17,500 British troops in Northern Ireland would return to the mainland soon. **********A reduced British military presence on the streets is seen as a concession to demands by Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., that the province must be ''demilitarized'' before the I.R.A. can be expected to disarm. **********Officials said that as many as 12 paramilitary prisoners, Catholic and Protestant, would probably be released in the next few days before the expiration of their terms. The early release of prisoners is a principal demand of both Catholic and Protestant groups.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/01/busin.snippet: Profile of Ann Livermore, who has been promoted to head of new Enterprise Computing Solutions Organization at Hewlett-Packard; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/01/busin.print_headline: PRIVATE SECTOR; Trailblazer in the Silicon Jungle
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/01/busin.body_text: **********IN her first year at Stanford University's business school, Ann Livermore submitted the winning plan to manage the student snack bar. Soon she was persuading corporate recruiters to buy doughnuts from her to serve at presentations. The companies thought nothing of paying 50 cents for doughnuts that cost her a nickel. **********Following tradition, she was allowed to keep her profits. Breaking tradition, she made a small fortune -- enough, in fact, to pay for her entire M.B.A. education. The next year, the administration took the business back for itself. **********Mrs. Livermore has always set her sights high, and now she is suddenly in a position to scale the peaks of one of the most male-dominated industries in America. Two weeks ago, she was named to head the new Enterprise Computing Solutions Organization at the Hewlett-Packard Company, the world's second-largest computer maker. **********The promotion thrust her into the company of America's most powerful women executives. Enterprise Computing Solutions, which markets all of Hewlett-Packard's computers except for desktops, has 44,000 employees and estimated annual sales of $15 billion. ''Only a handful of women, including Carly Fiorina at Lucent, Jill Barad at Mattel, Andrea Jung at Avon and Lois Juliber at Colgate, have assumed operating roles of this size, scale and complexity,'' said Caroline W. Nahas, managing director for Southern California of Korn Ferry International, the executive search firm. ''It's a significant announcement.'' **********Her new job has made her a contender to succeed Lewis E. Platt, Hewlett's chief executive, when he reaches the company's retirement age of 60 three years from now. But Mrs. Livermore, who is 40, played down the significance of her sudden proximity to the throne. **********''Right now, what I'm worrying about is how I'm going to learn 17,000 new names,'' she said with a laugh. Turning serious, she added, ''I have never in my H.P. career thought about what my next job is going to be.'' **********That may not be spin. The secret of her success seems to be the intensity of purpose she gives to whatever task is at hand. Until she got her new assignment, she was vice president and general manager of the company's software and services group, which handles everything from Internet commerce and consulting to telephone support. There, she set a goal for her businesses to grow at twice the industry average. And for each of the last four years, they expanded by 20 percent or more, meeting or exceeding her target. **********She has also earned a reputation as an iron-willed manager, and considers herself a disciple of Jim Arthur, a now-retired Hewlett-Packard executive whose intimidating manner has made him something of a company legend. Yet Mrs. Livermore has a gracious manner that has made her one of the most popular bosses at Hewlett-Packard. She remembers a colleague once telling her that she was ''one of the few people who can tell you to go to hell and you'd look forward to the ride.'' **********Whether she is really material for the top job remains an open question, of course. A 16-year veteran at Hewlett-Packard, she is not a technology buff. Even so, those who work with her say she is a quick study on almost any topic. ''Ann can take a complex business situation and really understand the implications,'' said Joe Beyers, a Hewlett-Packard executive who worked for her in starting several Internet businesses. **********She views customer satisfaction as the key to growth. She breaks down the concept into three components, to which she gives equal weight: customers' pure satisfaction with a product; the likelihood that they will buy it again, and the likelihood that they will recommend it to someone else. **********Mrs. Livermore -- nee Martinelli -- grew up in Greensboro, N.C. When she was 8 or 9, her father, an insurance company executive, showed her some ''big old I.B.M. mainframes'' in his office and explained how they worked. She was so taken with them that she became a volunteer key punch operator, entering data for him. **********''At the time I didn't realize I was cheap labor,'' she said. ''But I'd sit down with pages and pages of stuff that had to be key-punched, thinking that this was the greatest thing in the world.'' **********Still, it wasn't love of computers that brought her to Silicon Valley. As a senior at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, she made trips to both Harvard and Stanford to decide where to go to graduate school. It was no contest. **********''In March, I visited Harvard and it was wet, cold, snowy, ugly,'' she said. ''I came to Stanford and people were sitting out by the swimming pool looking at their accounting books.'' **********Even before her recent promotion, her stature had grown. Last year, she became a member of the board of United Parcel Service. **********She likes nothing more than spending the day alone with her husband, Tom, an executive at a Bay Area packaging company, and their 9-year-old daughter, Emily. An avid skier and a fledgling golfer, she says she can still unplug more completely than some of her associates when she is away from work. More than most companies, Hewlett-Packard operates on voice mail -- but she says it hasn't taken over her life. **********''When I'm on vacation,'' she says, ''I don't listen to voice-mail messages.''
