https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/13/busin.snippet: American Bankruptcy Institute study finds only 3 percent of those filing for Chapter 7 bankruptcy can repay even small part of their credit card debts; study is sure to affect debate when Congress again takes up bankruptcy legislation next year (S...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/13/busin.main_headline: Whose Numbers to Use On Credit Card Debt?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/13/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; Whose Numbers to Use On Credit Card Debt?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/13/busin.body_text: **********Earlier this year, when the credit card industry lobbied Congress to toughen bankruptcy laws for individuals, Visa USA and Mastercard International commissioned a study that said 10 percent of debtors could repay some card debt. **********Legislation, passed by the House but not taken up in the Senate, would have required a single person making $17,900 or more, or a family of four making $51,000 or more, to repay 30 percent of credit card debts in bankruptcy. If the debtor failed, he risked being pursued for the rest of his life for the full debt and penalties. **********Now comes a study that rebuts the finding. According to the American Bankruptcy Institute, a nonpartisan, nonprofit research group in Washington, only 3 percent of those filing for Chapter 7 bankruptcy can repay even a small part of their credit card debts. Chapter 7, under which virtually all debts are erased, is used for 70 percent of all personal bankruptcies. **********The study is sure to affect the debate when Congress again takes up bankruptcy legislation next year. The institute's study was based on people making at least a third more in annual income than those in the industry study. That suggests that at the income levels the industry reviewed, it would have found almost no one able to repay a portion of their credit card debts. **********Philip Corwin, the industry's chief lobbyist, said he was ''skeptical of the study findings,'' adding that there was ample evidence that many people understated income in bankruptcy filings. **********DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/busin.snippet: Economic Scene column on collapse of Long-Term Capital Management says Federal Reserve did not orchestrate a bailout, created no moral hazard and set no bad precedent; holds there was no bailout because Federal Reserve turned over no taxpayer mone...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Long-Term Capital didn't get a bailout and didn't warrant one.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Long-Term Capital didn't get a bailout and didn't warrant one.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/busin.body_text: **********JUDGING from the volume of criticism, William J. McDonough, president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, made a dreadful mistake when he orchestrated a ''bailout'' of Long-Term Capital Management, the multibillion-dollar investment fund that bought most of its assets with borrowed money. **********Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, wonders out loud why the Government needed to rescue private investors. Jeff Faux, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute, spoke for many on the political left when he questioned the fairness of rescuing millionaire speculators when the Government turns its back on bankrupt companies that employ low-paid workers. **********Other critics ask whether the Fed's action creates a destructive incentive, known as a moral hazard, for banks and securities firms to lend recklessly to investment funds, assured by last week's action that the Government would not let their investments go belly up. **********Good questions all. But the Fed has even better answers. The truth is that it orchestrated no bailout, created no moral hazard and set no bad precedent. **********First, let's clean up some language. There was no bailout because the Fed turned over no taxpayer money to the fund. **********Long-Term Capital is a hedge fund, a type of investment fund that caters only to investors who are rich and sophisticated. The investors raised a few billion dollars of their own and borrowed tens of billions more from banks and securities firms like Merrill Lynch. For three years its investment strategy worked brilliantly, but its investments soured this year. Because the firm had borrowed to the hilt, losses turned to disaster when creditors demanded their money. **********That, says Prof. George Benston of Emory University, ''sets up a classic free-rider problem.''  Each creditor grabs for its money while there is still money to grab. But if all the creditors grab at once, the fund will be forced to sell assets hastily, guaranteeing stupendous losses. A fire sale of securities would put the fund in about the same position as a family forced to sell its suburban mansion in 24 hours. **********''What Mr. McDonough appears to have done,'' Mr. Benston suggests, ''is to use the credibility of the Fed to bring the creditors together for their mutual benefit.'' Working together, they can keep the fund alive at least long enough to sell off its assets in an orderly, patient and perhaps even profitable manner. **********A bailout for the rich? For all the prattle, the fact is that the partners come away nearly empty-handed. The creditors, a consortium of banks and securities firms, have pledged to put up $3.6 billion in exchange for 90 percent ownership. Moral hazard? The deal nearly wipes out the misbehaving speculators and forces inattentive creditors to fork over money and take over the wreckage they indirectly sponsored. This deal hardly offers comfort for repeat offenders. **********There has also been talk that the deal smacks of hypocrisy. The United States lectures the Japanese to let the market weed out bankrupt banks and companies. But it is a stretch to connect the dots between last week's deal and Japan's neglectful bank regulators or its ''convoy'' system, under which strong companies prop up the weak. Last week's deal puts creditors in charge of a mop-up exercise. There is nothing to suggest they will keep the fund in business longer than it takes them to get back the best value for its assets -- unless they decide it can generate long-term profit. **********The Fed-brokered deal raises the larger question of when the Government should rescue bankrupt companies. Bailing out nonfinancial companies rarely makes sense because a government that protects losers will attract losers galore. But politicians sometimes cannot resist bailing out the likes of Chrysler and Lockheed -- huge corporations whose demise threatens thousands of workers -- even though research shows that few if any jobs are truly saved. **********Banks, however, are special. Burton Malkiel, an economics professor at Princeton University, argues that bailing out banks makes sense ''because taxpayers are already on the hook for the federally insured deposits.'' And the Government needs to protect the nation's money supply. **********Most economists are unwilling to extend the safety blanket beyond banks even though the failure of hedge funds, securities firms and other financial concerns could in theory touch off cascading defaults that could infect banks because their loans would go unpaid or the value of their other assets would plummet. But it is easy to exaggerate the threat and, besides, the Fed can pump up an economy temporarily dragged down by sluggish credit markets. **********So where does that leave the debate over Long-Term Capital? It is not a bank, nor does its collapse appear to threaten the solvency of banks. It does not, then, warrant a bailout. It didn't get one. Mr. McDonough merely helped creditors take over the firm and spare themselves needless losses. Score one for Mr. McDonough's good sense.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/02/world.main_headline: Life's Ups and Downs: Charting Extinctions
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/02/world.print_headline: Life's Ups and Downs: Charting Extinctions
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/02/world.body_text: **********Extinction is a steady process, exacting a continuous toll of species even in the best of times. Biologists believe this is a device that continually opens niches for new species, thereby fueling the engine of natural selection and the growth of biological diversity, which has grown, if unsteadily, ever since the first explosion of large animal life in the Cambrian era 540 million years ago. **********The line that begins below traces the changing levels of diversity, as measured by fossils of marine organisms classified by families. The fossil record shows five major devastating pulses of extinction, not counting the present mass extinction caused by human activity (which some scientists believe will be the most severe of all). During these extinctions entire families and even orders of organisms were exterminated, radically redirecting the course of evolution. The human race evolved within the order of mammals, for example, but if the dinosaurs had not been wiped out, humanoid creatures might have evolved from dinosaurs instead. Dr. Dale Russell, a paleontologist at Ottawa's National Museum of Natural Sciences, has speculated that one dinosaur in particular, Stenonychosaurus, which had a large brain, walked on two legs, had thumbs and possessed binocular vision, might have become an evolutionary ancester of human-like creatures, but for the extinction of dinosaurs. **********Explanations for these mass dyings are almost as numerous (and conflicting) as the scientists who speculate on them. **********The most famous of the mass extinctions is the most recent: the one at the end of the Cretaceous period, when the dinosaurs died out (unless, as some scientists believe, some dinosaurs evolved into birds). The Cretaceous extinction, more than any other, has prompted bitter controversy. **********Many scientists assert that it was caused by the atmospheric effects of an asteroid impact -- possibly the one believed to have created a huge underwater crater on the Yucatan coast of Mexico. But other proposed explanations for the dinosaurs' demise include loss of habitat, climate change, the spread of diseases, a massive volcanic event in India, periodic fallout of cosmic dust, and many other possibilities. **********The Permian extinction of 250 million years ago is especially puzzling, partly because it was by far the worst in earth's history; estimates suggest that up to 95 percent of all the species alive before the extinction event (including all the trilobites and many other flourishing animal groups) were killed off. A change in the composition of the earth's atmosphere, volcanoes in Siberia and other causes have been suggested, but no one knows for sure.   MALCOM W. BROWNE

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/09/busin.snippet: Immense summer wildfires across central Florida are resulting in scaling back of homeowners insurance by limiting most payments to 120 percent of insured value rather than full replacement cost; photos (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/09/busin.main_headline: In Florida's Fires, A Test for a New Insurance Policy
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/09/busin.print_headline: SPENDING IT; In Florida's Fires, A Test for a New Insurance Policy
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/09/busin.body_text: **********THE wildfires that swept through the piney woods here this summer provided a test, of sorts, of a new kind of home insurance that is being introduced gradually across the country. **********Instead of paying whatever it takes to replace a destroyed home, as had been the case for years, the leading insurers are now selling policies that limit most payments to 120 percent of the insured amount. **********And that has posed a powerful question:  Would the scaled-back coverage be enough for people to start over? Would there be huge gaps between the cost of a new house and the insurance payment? **********The answer, based on evidence accumulating here, is that the lesser coverage seems to suffice. Both the insurers and Florida regulators say there have been no complaints and, in nearly a dozen interviews, people who lost their homes had nothing but praise for their companies. **********''We couldn't ask for better treatment,'' said Aida Meltzer, an Allstate customer who lost her three-bedroom home here in central Florida, near the Atlantic coast. **********Many fire victims have collected more than they expected, and those who have come up short say they have only themselves to blame because they consciously underinsured their homes, taking what they thought was a reasonable gamble that disaster was unlikely. **********The key to making the restricted policies work, consumer advocates and insurers say, is in accurately calculating the cost of rebuilding a home and then adjusting each year for inflation and improvements. **********''This approach requires much more vigilance,'' said J. Robert Hunter, director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America. But handled correctly, he said, it seems fair to both customers and insurers. **********While State Farm and Allstate, the two biggest home insurers, limit their payments to 120 percent in most states, Allstate has a ceiling of 150 percent in California and 125 percent in New York, Arkansas and North Carolina. Industry experts say the higher limits may attract more customers, but that with careful evaluations, the 120 percent margin should work anywhere. **********The industry's new approach, which requires regulatory approval state by state, has yet to be tested in the aftermath of a big hurricane or earthquake, when laws of supply and demand -- as well as profiteering -- can push rebuilding costs off the charts. In the Florida fires, the number of homes lost was not enormous, and prices for building materials seem to have changed little. **********Insurers also say they do not foresee problems in areas where real estate values are skyrocketing, because coverage is based on the cost of rebuilding rather than on a house's market value. A big part of a house's sale price often reflects the value of the land on which it was built. But homeowner's insurance covers the house, not the site. **********Insurance companies introduced unlimited policies in the early 1980's as a way to increase sales. They soon became the industry standard, so no insurer had an edge -- just a lot more liability. **********Hurricane Andrew cost the industry $16 billion in 1992, and State Farm took the first step toward retrenchment the next spring, refusing to sell unlimited policies in Florida. **********Instead, it instituted the 120 percent provision. Judith K. Mintel, a lawyer for State Farm, says the intent is to insure accurately the cost of replacing a house. State Farm allows for a 10 percent margin of error in its estimate system, she said, and throws in another 10 percent for good measure. **********SATISFIED that the concept was workable, the company began putting it into effect nationally in 1996, as state regulators approved it. And the competition has followed. The policies, which cost about the same as their predecessors, are now being sold in more than 30 states. Allstate is selling them in New York and New Jersey, but State Farm is still awaiting regulatory approval in those states; both companies await approval in Connecticut. **********The companies say that they sent notices to customers about the changes and that they instructed agents to spread the word, but details of the coverage apparently were lost on many people. Fire victims here said they did not realize -- until claims adjusters told them -- that they could get up to 20 percent more than what their policies specified. For that matter, they also couldn't recall a time when they had unlimited coverage; they believed that if they were insured for $100,000, they could expect $100,000 -- no more, no less. **********They were also happy to learn that they would receive several thousand dollars, in most cases, to remove the remains of their homes and for new landscaping. **********By spreading money around immediately, the insurers won many friends in Palm Coast, which has a population of about 30,000, scattered over hundreds of acres of thick woods a few miles from the beach. Within hours of the fires in July, the insurers were handing out thousands of dollars for living expenses; within a few days, many people had received checks for the face value of their policies. **********When Rhon Dixon, the owner of a window-blind and kitchen-cabinet company, drove up to the knee-high mound of ash that had been his two-story, three-bedroom frame house, he found a State Farm claims adjuster sitting in his driveway. **********''He said, 'Do you need some living expenses?' '' Mr. Dixon recalled. ''I said, 'Probably.' And he said, 'What do you need, $5,000, $10,000?' I said $10,000 would be fine. Then, about three minutes later, he said: 'You're going to need a deposit for where you're living. Why don't I just give you $15,000?' And I said, 'That's even better.' '' **********Mr. Dixon, 42, said he had never expected to use his insurance, had guessed at what might be enough coverage and didn't aim high. He never read his policy and doesn't recall hearing about the 20 percent cushion or other beneficial provisions. **********''You think your property is worth a lot, but when you talk with the tax people and the insurance company, you try to claim it's not worth anything,'' he said. ''Until something like this happens, it just seems like you just keep paying, and never get anything back.'' **********NOW Mr. Dixon has been talking with contractors about rebuilding. Their calculations show his coverage was low. His policy was for $108,900; rebuilding will cost about $150,000. ''It's my fault,'' he  said. ''I didn't have it insured for enough.'' **********The gap, though, is not going to be as wide as he first thought. State Farm has already given him $21,700 more -- the 20 percent -- plus $1,300 for things like replacing his driveway, sidewalk and a patio. And he expects State Farm to supply an additional $5,000 to bulldoze and cart away his ruins and about $5,400 more for new landscaping. Changes in building codes have increased some building costs, and State Farm routinely pays a percentage of those expenses. **********A more litigious person might argue that Mr. Dixon's State Farm agent should have made an effort to see that the insured value of the house was closer to the mark. Executives at State Farm headquarters in Bloomington, Ill., said that their policy is for agents, armed with the latest costs of building materials and a computer, to estimate as precisely as possible how much it will take to replace each house they insure. Mr. Dixon said the only estimate he knew of came out of his head. **********James I. Jones, 62, who got out of his house just as his trees were catching fire, was also underinsured. He thought his agent's estimate of $100,000 of coverage was low, but didn't argue: he did not want to pay higher premiums. Now that concrete block walls are all that remain of his three-bedroom home, he also blames himself, not State Farm. Mr. Jones says two contractors have estimated the cost of replacing his home at $135,000. **********Many of the Florida fire victims said their biggest insurance mistake was underestimating the value of their furniture, clothes and the other contents of their homes. An Allstate homeowner's policy automatically provides the equivalent of half the face value for the home's contents; on a $100,000 policy, the contents are covered for an additional $50,000. State Farm's automatic allocation is 75 percent. **********Aida and David Meltzer, retirees from Baltimore, were among those whose insurance coverage worked out just right. They did not cut corners and fastidiously updated their coverage. When they added a room to their beige-and-brown ranch house in mid-May, Mrs. Meltzer increased their Allstate coverage by $10,000, to about $80,000. **********After the fire, the Meltzers found it would cost about $85,000 to rebuild, well within the 20 percent margin. And they have decided to add a few frills out of their own pockets. ''I'm very well satisfied with the insurance company and all the people we've had to deal with,'' Mr. Meltzer said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/busin.snippet: Hoke Simpson, former dean at Columbia University Graduate School of Business, dies at age 83 (M)9
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/busin.main_headline: Hoke Simpson, 83, Former Dean At Columbia's Business School
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/busin.print_headline: Hoke Simpson, 83, Former Dean At Columbia's Business School
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/busin.body_text: **********Hoke S. Simpson, a former associate dean at the Graduate School of Business at Columbia University, died on Sept. 26 at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. Mr. Simpson, a resident of Rye, N.Y., was 83. **********The cause of death was lung disease, said his daughter, Drayton Jenkins Gerety. **********Mr. Simpson joined the business school as the director of executive programs in 1954 and was promoted to associate dean for executive education in 1967. The executive education program, which is part of the business school, is a series of one-  to four-week nondegree courses for executives, including those in management, finance, leadership and marketing. Courses are sometimes custom-designed for private companies, too. **********When Mr. Simpson joined the business school, its executive education division was just starting. He helped develop a wide range of business courses, and during his tenure the school had programs in New York, France, Spain and South America. He retired in 1985. **********After he graduated from the Georgia Institute of Technology in 1935 with a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering and industrial management, Mr. Simpson went to work as a salesman for the General Foods Corporation. During a 16-year career at General Foods, except for a six-year stint with the Naval Reserve, Mr. Simpson worked in the marketing, personnel and labor relations divisions. Before joining Columbia University, Mr. Simpson worked for the Vick Chemical Company as director of personnel and public relations. **********Mr. Simpson is survived by his wife, Suzanne, of Rye; his daughter, Drayton Jenkins Gerety of Mamaroneck, N.Y.; two sons, Hoke Jr., of San Diego, and Willis W., of Asheville, N.C.; seven grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/30/world.snippet: Collapse of ruble sets off boom in survival strategies among Russians, affecting everyone, from ordinary citizens to small business owners; many shops have raised prices or simply closed while citizens struggle to withdraw money from banks; many w...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/30/world.main_headline: Ruble's Crash Sets Off Boom in Survival Strategies
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/30/world.print_headline: TURMOIL IN RUSSIA: IN MOSCOW; Ruble's Crash Sets Off Boom in Survival Strategies
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/30/world.body_text: **********By Monday this week, the owner of Shury-Mury, a popular downtown Moscow restaurant that offers a country atmosphere and Russian cuisine, had made his decision: his prices would have to go up. **********By the time he changed the menus yesterday, the cost of his baked sturgeon and blinis filled with red caviar had shot up by 30 percent. **********''Already for a week, we had been working at a loss,'' said Vadim Nikitin, 29, who in these times of trouble, has taken to watching two hours of television news every night, anxiously scanning the airwaves for information that will help him figure out which way his country is going, and what its currency is worth. **********Two weeks ago, before the de facto devaluation of the ruble and the subsequent reshuffling of the Russian Government, one dollar equaled 6.2 rubles. Today, it is worth pretty much what anybody says -- from 10 rubles at some currency exchange booths, to 20 rubles on an incipient black market, to 11, the rate set after Friday after brief trading on an electronic inter-bank exchange. **********Mr. Nikitin's problem -- shared by virtually all restaurateurs who have built business on Moscow's bubble economy -- is that much of the food he feeds his customers comes not from the Russian countryside but from abroad. And while he was hesitating about how much to charge for his dishes, his suppliers were not. **********''Sturgeon was 50 to 60 rubles a kilo last week, today it is 100 rubles, and that is the wholesale price,'' Mr. Nikitin said. **********A bigger problem was his deliveries of imported alcohol, which ground to a halt last week as wholesalers sat on their cases, waiting to figure out their value in Russia's fast-evaporating currency. Even though he pays his employees in rubles, their salaries -- like his rent -- are pegged to the dollar, a hangover from the turbulent days of Russia's triple-digit inflation in the early 1990's, a habit that lingered on long after the ruble reached stable levels in the last few years. **********Larissa, as an employee at the Moscow office of a multinational company, also earns dollars. That's good news, given the way the ruble has been going this week. The bad news is that she cannot draw dollars from the debit card her employer uses to pay employees' salaries. **********In fact, Larissa, who asked not to be identified by her last name, has not even gone near her bank all week, not after a colleague showed up late at work one day, with a tale of woe heard all across this dollar-infected city. **********The young woman had gone to her bank at 6 A.M., where she was the 41st person to sign up on the day's waiting list. At noon, the bank manager appeared to tell the crowd that there would be no dollars, only rubles at the fictitious rate of 7.8, an official level that has remained on the books since Moscow's interbank currency exchange shut down for business last Wednesday morning. **********''Some people are taking rubles in small quantities, some managed to take out their dollars before this whole thing began,'' Larissa said. ''I have decided to wait and see what happens.'' She said the company has said that on Monday, it will pay salaries in rubles -- at 9.5 to the dollar. **********These are dizzy days for Moscow's yuppies, who have grown used to big salaries, often paid in dollars, from the banks, foreign firms, real estate companies and other businesses that rode the wave of the capital's recent boom years. Many of these people are so young that they have known nothing but well-paid, white-collar jobs. Aleksei Smirnov, a 19-year-old real estate broker, stood in line at a currency office Friday with a fistful of dollars, which he wanted to trade at a rate of 12 rubles to the dollar. **********His first reaction when the ruble collapsed was to go the country. **********''We don't have any money in the bank, so we avoided that problem,'' he said, as he waited in line with his girlfriend Natasha Kolucheva, 18. ''We have our money under the mattresses. Natasha has several thousand, I have a bit less.'' **********But as luck would have it, when their turn came to go into the bank, the teller had run out of rubles, and the couple went looking for other ways to get enough rubles to get through the coming week. **********By mid-week, Moscow was in a mad spending spree. ''People were buying everything,'' said Aras Agalarov, president of Crocus International, which owns a chain of 70 stores across the city, from a giant household store on the outskirts to chic boutiques scattered around the center. **********Many of his competitors in the luxury goods business simply shut their doors this week, hanging out signs that said things like ''closed for technical reasons,'' or ''closed for inventory,'' which as excuses go, were not too far off the mark: they were in fact waiting to see which way the ruble will jump, whether to raise their prices by 10, 20 or 30 percent. **********Mr. Agalarov, who is also vice president of the Moscow International Business Association, chose another route. He stayed open, and sold at his old prices -- which brought a wave of customers, buying at twice their normal rate. **********''It was like having a big sale,'' Mr. Agalarov said. ''It was the end of the season anyway, so we already had marked goods down by 30 percent. The Government just went and added another 50 or 70 percent to the discount, that's all.'' **********Cars, real estate, washing machines, jewelry, stereos -- everything was getting swept by splurge spenders looking for ways to park their money before the ruble goes down any further. The giant AvtoVaz  factory in Togliatti, in southern Russia, reported it had emptied its inventory of the latest model of Zhiguli, the Fiat-lookalike that had been the staple of the Russian car market, before the recent flood of imports. **********Real estate brokers in Moscow reported a rush of buyers, looking to snap up new apartments and small dachas, or country houses, at something approaching old prices. In fact, according to newspaper reports, real estate prices have already edged upward 25 percent in Russian ruble terms, and where they will land at the time buyers sign their contracts is anybody's guess. ''Few people have enough money in their mattresses to buy an apartment,'' noted the newspaper Moskovsky Komsolets, adding that without access to bank accounts, it will be awhile before anybody has the cash to conclude any deals made over the past chaotic week. **********Like other retailers, Aleksandr Silvanovich, the 29-year-old director of ''Everything for the Home,'' a small household goods store in central Moscow, has been told repeatedly by his suppliers to forget bank transfers. With the Russian banking system now in gridlock, everybody now wants cash up front, he said. **********''Right now we are only buying domestic goods,'' he said, in between calls on his mobile phone. ''The prices on them have gone up 10 to 15 percent, but we are trying to hold down our prices, which means our profits are dropping 10 to 15 percent. Everyone is in shock. So are we.'' **********Mr. Silvanovich had been planning a renovation of the store, on the first floor of an old building. Now he has put it off. **********Mr. Nikitin is also finding that price rises are complicating his plans to open a second restaurant. ''Now we can't buy some of the necessary appliances we need,'' Mr. Nikitin said. ''I made calls on Monday, but no one is selling, or they are selling at 15 to the dollar.'' **********For Alik Guseinov, a 36-year-old flower vendor from Azerbaijan, the problem is that his roses, some imported from Holland, some grown locally, do not last more than three days. So people, out searching for more durable goods, are walking right past his stand outside a subway stop, even though he is now selling the roses at their wholesale price. **********''People are buying less,'' he said. ''They don't complain about the prices since we haven't raised them. But we know it's hard for people. They aren't getting paid, or they can't get their money from bank. If we raise our prices, no one will buy.'' **********Lyudmila Kazmina, 72, lives mainly off the pensions she receives as a  formerly high-placed administrator in the Soviet state film commission. **********But every day, she sets up a table on the sidewalk, selling a hodgepodge of items from romance novels to Orthodox church calendars to help out her daughter, Lena Orfani, 42, who lost a job as an editor in the documentary film division. **********This week, they were celebrating Lena's birthday but the dishes on their table this year were modest. **********''I invited my friends of course, but I have to say that every year it is more humble,'' Mrs. Orfani said. ''Now everything is more expensive.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/12/world.snippet: 35-year-old Sergei Kiriyenko, Pres Boris Yeltsin's besieged nominee for Prime Minister, has shown himself to be adept politician in brief period on national stage; his liabilities, mainly his youth and limited Government experience, are also his p...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/12/world.main_headline: Yeltsin's Nominee, Besieged, Is Not Without Allies
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/12/world.print_headline: Yeltsin's Nominee, Besieged, Is Not Without Allies
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/12/world.body_text: **********As workers took to the streets this week to demonstrate against the Government's chronic inability to pay back wages, a young Kremlin official huddled with labor leaders to defuse the protest. **********Even though Moscow has repeatedly failed to make good on its promises to pay the wages, the labor leaders agreed to give it yet another chance. ''Kiriyenko has given us hope,'' said Aleksei Surikov, the deputy head of the National Federation of Independent Trade Unions. **********In the two weeks since President Boris N. Yeltsin stunned the nation by dismissing his Cabinet and nominating the 35-year-old Sergei N. Kiriyenko for Prime Minister, Mr. Kiriyenko has run into a buzz saw of criticism. **********The Communist opposition has portrayed the Government shake-up as a grave political crisis. Some Western analysts have questioned whether Mr. Yeltsin is mentally competent to govern. **********But in the brief period that Mr. Kiriyenko has been on the national stage, he has shown himself to be an adept politician. **********To be sure, the appointment is an enormous gamble. Mr. Kiriyenko's  government experience is limited to 11 months at Russia's Energy Ministry. But his liabilities -- his youth and limited Government experience -- are also his potential strengths. **********Russia has a surfeit of holdovers from the Soviet era, like former Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, who talk about change but are mired in the old ways. **********It has bold reformers, like Anatoly B. Chubais, a former Kremlin aide  whose every move seemed to stir up opposition from Communists and powerful financial interests. **********But Mr. Kiriyenko is different. Unlike Mr. Chernomyrdin, he has made his mark as a young man in the brash new world of Russian capitalism. Unlike Mr. Chubais, he has not been in Government long enough to make a lot of enemies, and he eschews ideological battles. **********In short, Mr. Kiriyenko may be a leader who can quietly hammer away at changing the tax system, tightening controls over powerful monopolies and pursing other market-economy measures without the debilitating ideological battles that hobbled some of his predecessors. **********His appointment will be all the more important if, as Mr. Yeltsin has suggested, it signals a generational shift that propels other young politicians to the top echelons of power. **********The lower house of Parliament, as expected, rejected Mr. Kiriyenko's nomination. But that was just part of the horse-trading between Mr. Yeltsin and the Communist-dominated opposition, which wants to demonstrate that it is still an important political force and obtain a few posts in the new line-up. **********Mr. Yeltsin resubmitted the nomination, and most analysts expect the process to end in Mr. Kiriyenko's approval as Prime Minister. But he could be handicapped if the price of the Parliament's consent is too high and the new Government is seeded with members of the opposition. **********So far Mr. Kiriyenko has been his own best advocate. He has not boasted about Government accomplishments, has patiently stroked his critics and has even appropriated some of their sound bites. **********The newspaper Nezavisimaya Gazeta described his initial program, which he outlined Tuesday, as ''truly apolitical'' and devoid of an ''ideological lining,'' a rarity in Russia's superheated political scene. **********Regional leaders have been heartened by Mr. Kiriyenko's talk about reapportioning tax revenues so the provinces get more. **********Mr. Kiriyenko has tried to placate the Communists by emphasizing the need to struggle against poverty. Unlike other Yeltsin aides, he has not gone around boasting that Russia is  firmly embarked on the path of economic growth. **********Vladimir V. Semago, a senior Communist member of Parliament, said in a interview that he had met with Mr. Kiriyenko and considered him to be a politician in the tradition of Western European social democrats. ''I could see it in his eyes,'' said Mr. Semago, who added that he planned to support him. **********But economic reformers, like Mr. Chubais and Yegor T. Gaidar, consider Mr. Kiriyenko to be one of their own. And a review of Mr. Kiriyenko's career suggests that he has internalized the principles of the market economy. **********Born in the Black Sea town of Sukhumi, Mr. Kiriyenko, who married his childhood sweetheart, Maria, and has two children, got his start in the Volga River city of Nizhny Novgorod, which was called Gorky in Soviet times. His father was Jewish, but he adopted his mother's Ukrainian name, an effort to deal with the anti-Semitism of Soviet times. **********As a young man, he was studious and punched all the right tickets. He studied in the department of shipbuilding at the Gorky Institute of Water Transport Engineers, where his father headed the Department of Scientific Communism. After military service, he worked as a foreman at the Krasnoye Sormovo shipyard. **********He also joined the Komsomol, the  Communist youth organization, and from 1990 to 1992 was second secretary of the its regional branch. Mr. Kiriyenko has kept his Communist Party membership card as a kind of memento of those times, as have many Russians who are reluctant to write off years of their life as a waste. **********But unlike today's Communists, Mr. Kiriyenko was quick to take advantage of Russia's lurch toward the market. After a course on finance in Moscow, he served as chairman of a Nizhny Novgorod bank. He later became president of the Norsi oil refinery, one of the largest in Russia. **********His colleagues in Nizhny Novgorod dubbed him ''the little computer'' because of his organizational skills and attention to detail. One of his hobbies, however, is martial arts. **********''He had a reputation as a good manager and took a systematic approach,'' said Dmitry I. Bednyakov, a Nizhny Novgorod lawyer. ''Like every person he has drawbacks. His main one is his age and lack of experience.'' **********[Dressed in blue jeans and a sweater vest, Mr. Kiriyenko made an informal appearance, with his wife and two children, on an interview program broadcast Saturday night on NTV, Russia's private television channel. **********[As he described his working style and his hobbies, he came across as a cool-headed, tough-minded, ideologically neutral manager, a type increasingly familiar in Russia these days. In his case, he said, he felt no tug for the luxury goods that are often the mark of Russia's new rich. ''I like what I like,'' he said, pulling at the collar of his plaid shirt. ''I don't pay any attention to the label.''] **********While Mr. Kiriyenko has not been in Government long, his experience is hardly trivial. **********After Boris Y. Nemtsov left his governor's post in the Nizhny Novgorod region to work as a top Kremlin aide, Mr. Kiriyenko was also invited to work in Moscow. **********He was appointed First Deputy Minister of Energy in May 1997. (Mr. Nemtsov initially served as minister, in addition to other tasks.) **********In a nation rich in oil and natural energy, the ministry is a powerful agency. And as Mr. Nemtsov was preoccupied with giving interviews to the press and tackling social issues like housing reform, Mr. Kiriyenko was the de facto minister. **********In November, Mr. Kiriyenko was officially appointed Minister of Fuel and Energy. He helped set the terms of the coming auction of the Rosneft state oil company and negotiated with Americans on oil projects in Russia, among other complex issues. **********If Mr. Yeltsin dies in office, the Prime Minister becomes President for three months while an election is organized. **********Some people blanch at the prospect of a neophyte's finger on the nuclear button, but in shaking up his Government Mr. Yeltsin left his national security team intact, retaining his Foreign Minister, Defense Minister and national security adviser. **********Mr. Kiriyenko, who so far is not giving interviews to Western reporters, has said he made enough money as a businessman that he can afford to serve in government. He has a reputation for independence and is not believed to be the tool of any of Russia's business interests. **********Not that the Russian bankers and financiers have not tried. **********''I have already come across it,'' Mr. Kiriyenko told the Russian press. ''A careful offer of 'help' comes from somewhere. I ignore it. Then the next day some newspaper changes its tone.'' **********Certainly, Boris A. Berezovsky, the powerful tycoon, does not control him. The terms of the Rosneft auction that Mr. Kiriyenko shaped were decidedly not in Mr. Berezovksy's favor. **********Mr. Berezovksy recently began a media campaign against Mr. Yeltsin's Government shake-up and is backing the ousted Mr. Chernomyrdin, who has declared himself a candidate for the 2000 presidential election. **********Some of Mr. Kiriyenko's critics question whether he has the strength to be his own man. They say he may turn out to be nothing more than a caretaker while the real decisions are made by Mr. Yeltsin, his daughter Tatyana Dyachenko and whatever group of financiers happens to be in favor at the moment. Before he was named Prime Minister he had met with Mr. Yeltsin only twice. **********''He isn't a political person,'' complained Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the head of the liberal Yabloko party. ''He doesn't represent any political forces. He is the technical executor of whatever the President orders him to do.'' **********Others say that the new Government may turn out to be too much of a hodgepodge to accomplish much. **********''It will have representatives from very different political powers, financial powers, elite groups and clans,'' said Nikolai Petrov of the Carnegie Endowment. ''So to expect from it some realistic serious steps in the realm of economics will not be realistic.'' **********But many reformers inside and outside of the Government believe that they may have found a new standard-bearer who may make headway as long as speaks quietly in  nonconfrontational tones. **********''The public understands what must be done,'' Mr. Kiriyenko said this week in a perfect example of his understated call to arms. ''The problem is how to do it, what mechanisms and instruments.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/22/busin.snippet: Karl E Prindle, industrial chemist who helped transform cellophane into mass-market wrapping, died on Oct 13 at age 95 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/22/busin.main_headline: Karl E. Prindle Dies at 95; Made Cellophane Marketable
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/22/busin.print_headline: Karl E. Prindle Dies at 95; Made Cellophane Marketable
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/22/busin.body_text: **********Karl E. Prindle, an industrial chemist who helped transform cellophane into a mass-market wrapping, then devised a way for the masses to unwrap it without breaking their fingernails, died on Oct. 13 at a hospital in Willoughby, Ohio. **********He was 95 and was recalled as an inventor of both moisture-proof cellophane and the zip-tape strip used to open billions of cellophane-wrapped cigarette and chewing gum packages and other tightly sealed products. **********In a career in which he was always looking for an encore, Mr. Prindle made his most significant contribution to commercial science as a 24-year-old research assistant for the old DuPont Cellophane Company, which was based in Buffalo. **********Never mind that what people still persist in calling cellophane is rarely anything of the biodegradable, cellulose sort, but a petroleum-based product known as polypropylene. **********For the better part of half a century, cellophane was among the most ubiquitous and profitable products. But until Mr. Prindle came along, it was known primarily as an attractive, elegant and highly expensive wrapping for high-ticket items like perfumes. Because it was porous, it was unsuitable for wrapping cigarettes, candy and other products that required protection from moisture. **********By helping to develop a complex, four-component coating that increased cellophane's moisture resistance, Mr. Prindle helped lay the groundwork for a commercial bonanza that gave DuPont a virtual monopoly on a product that was not its own. **********Considering its long and close identification with E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, it is easy to forget that unlike, say, nylon, and other signature products, cellophane was not a DuPont invention. **********Indeed it had been developed in France in the early 1900's as the accidental discovery of a Swiss scientist looking for a coating to protect restaurant tablecloths from wine stains. **********By the time DuPont secured an American license to make cellophane in 1923, it seemed to have little mass-market potential. **********That is where Mr. Prindle came in. A native of Charlotte (pronounced shar-LOT), Vt., whose father operated a lumberyard and whose mother sold insurance to put her two children through college, Mr. Prindle joined DuPont soon after he graduated from Oberlin College in 1925. **********Within a year he had helped develop a moisture-proof version of cellophane that not only all but displaced the original, but gave DuPont a lucrative, second-generation patent that allowed it to dominate the cellophane market. **********Mr. Prindle was given full credit for the invention and had his name on the patent, along with that of his young boss, William Hale Charch. But it was DuPont, which had spent $15,000 on the research, including Mr. Prindle's salary, that reaped the millions in profits. **********Mr. Charch, who died in 1958, went on to a legendary career as a DuPont research chief. Mr. Prindle went on to another company and another cellophane milestone. **********Joining the old Dobeckmum Company, which was based in Cleveland, in 1932, Mr. Prindle turned his attention to another cellophane problem: the difficulty of opening anything sealed in it. **********While his invention will seem rather more crucial to anyone who has tried, say, to open the wrong end of a pack of cigarettes, his solution was as simple as it was ingenious: he put a stickum on a thin strip of cellophane and adhered it to the inside of the cellophane wrapper with a protruding tab that could be pulled to cut cleanly through the wrapper. **********It took some doing to get the stickum just right, but Mr. Prindle was a perfectionist if nothing else, and it is a tribute to his ingenuity that similar strips are still used on packages made of polypropylene. **********During his years with Dobeckmun, which was bought by the Dow Chemical Company in 1957, Mr. Prindle developed Lurex, a synthetic metallic thread widely used to give fashions affordable glitter, and scores of other products, but none that quite rivaled cellophane. **********He may not have shared in the millions his inventions made for their corporate owners, but Mr. Prindle managed to do quite well for himself. After his retirement in 1968 he concentrated on his hobby, investing, and made millions in the stock market. **********Mr. Prindle's wife Mary, to whom he was married for 66 years, is deceased. He is survived by two daughters, Janet of Manhattan and Anne Johnson of Dayton; a sister, Eleanor Benning of Charlotte; three grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. **********He had the satisfaction of outliving his own product. The last American manufacturer of cellophane went bankrupt last year, and cellophane is no longer made in the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/27/world.snippet: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, in report wrapping up two years of hearings into human-rights abuses during apartheid era, is expected to lay overwhelming blame on Government, but will also implicate African National Congress; ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/27/world.main_headline: South Africa Braces Itself For Report by Truth Panel
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/27/world.print_headline: South Africa Braces Itself For Report by Truth Panel
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/27/world.body_text: **********The Truth and Reconciliation Commission, in a report wrapping up two years of hearings into human-rights abuses in South Africa during the apartheid era, is expected to lay overwhelming blame on the government, but also to implicate members of the liberation struggle in atrocities, according to parts of the document that have been leaked. **********The 3,500-page report is to be released on Thursday, and past and present political leaders are scrambling to minimize the damage to their reputations. **********The state-owned television and radio today quoted a small portion of the report as saying that the African National Congress party of President Nelson Mandela would be found responsible for torturing and killing suspected traitors and for using bombs and mines in incidents that hurt or killed innocent civilians. The report also found that the congress had engaged in killing political opponents, including members of the Inkatha Freedom Party. **********In addition, it said the A.N.C. had to accept responsibility for the actions of President Mandela's former wife, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, who was convicted in 1991 of assault and kidnapping after the death of a young activist. **********During the commission's hearings on Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela's conduct in the early 1980's, when she was the liberation movement's most visible leader, the panel heard testimony suggesting that she and her bodyguards were also linked to dozens of other assaults and deaths. **********Some 200 people have been notified that the report will contain negative findings specifically about them. They include two former Presidents, F. W. de Klerk and P. W. Botha, several current A.N.C. cabinet members  and the leader of the Inkatha party, Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi. **********Mr. de Klerk said today that he would go to court to block the report, which apparently accuses him of being an ''accessory after the fact'' in the bombing of a church headquarters in Pretoria in 1986. Although the report says that he did not order the bombing, it says that he subsequently came to know about the roles of others involved and failed to report the information to the police. This could open him up to prosecution. **********In a statement, Mr. de Klerk, who has often done battle with the commission, said he regretted having to go to the courts, but had exhausted all other alternatives and had to defend himself against ''unfounded attacks.'' **********But there are plenty of jitters on the other side too. Unhappy congress officials tried the back door recently, seeking to meet with commission officials to express their concerns. But that request was turned down. **********Some political analysts say the leaked portion of the report that dealt with the congress was probably a result of a calculated effort to defuse the impact of the negative findings when the report is officially released. But some say the reverse. The leader of the conservative Freedom Front party, Constand Viljoen, said the leaks were an attempt to give the commission credibility. **********The spokesman for the congress, Thabo Masebe, denied that his party was responsible for the leak and said that the A.N.C. would not comment on the report until it was made public. An advance copy of the findings were given to Mr. Mandela today, his office said, so that he could make a statement when he officially receives the report on Thursday. **********The creation of the commission was part of the negotiated settlement that enabled South Africa's peaceful transition in 1994 from a white supremacist government to a multiracial democracy. With the power to offer amnesty and to subpoena witnesses, the commission is easily the biggest and most powerful panel of its kind to be established anywhere.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/20/your-.snippet: HAWAII'S BUSINESS environment is stifling these days, but there is at least one company that investors might find worth some analysis. It is Cyanotech Corp., one of the few companies that successfully leverages its location in Hawaii to compete in...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/20/your-.main_headline: With Algae Products, Cyanotech Profits From Hawaii's Marine Habitat : The Value of Reaping the Sea's Riches
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/20/your-.print_headline: With Algae Products, Cyanotech Profits From Hawaii's Marine Habitat : The Value of Reaping the Sea's Riches
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/20/your-.body_text: **********HAWAII'S BUSINESS environment is stifling these days, but there is at least one company that investors might find worth some analysis. It is Cyanotech Corp., one of the few companies that successfully leverages its location in Hawaii to compete internationally. **********Cyanotech makes use of the island's gifts in mass farming microalgae, a marine biological organism whose extracts are used to make a range of natural products. **********Its flagship product is called Spirulina Pacifica, a nutritional supplement meant to provide increased energy and natural anti-oxidants. **********While Spirulina is produced by other manufacturers, "Cyanotech is head and shoulders above others" in producing the substance, said Colin Watanabe, branch manager of National Securities Corp. in Honolulu. **********Walter Ramsley, portfolio manager at Walrus Partners, which is based in Holliston, Massachusetts, concurred. **********This is born out, he said, by anecdotal evidence from consumers and the more tangible proof that Cyanotech can charge more per bottle than its competitors. **********The company's geographic location in Hawaii accords it several unique advantages in producing algae-derived materials such as Spirulina, Mr. Watanabe said. **********The tropical climate gives the Hawaiian producer a consistent, year-round growing season. Hawaii also provides a pristine environment for the cultivation of microalgae. **********Value investors take note: The company's stock tumbled from $4.375 in April to the current price of $3.50 after its direct-marketing distributor in China, where Cyanotech had approximately 50 percent of its business, practically became unable to operate under a new local regulation. **********Until then, Cyanotech's profit margin was a whopping "40 cents to the dollar," Mr. Ramsley said. **********That is "the level it could return to," if the company is successful in its attempts to acquire new customers inside and outside of China, he added. **********The company also is betting on a newly commercialized product called astaxanthin. The material is a red pigment used primarily in the aquaculture industry to impart color to the flesh of pen-raised fish such as salmon and shrimp, raising the commercial value of the marine animals significantly. These fish acquire the red pigment naturally when growing wild but come out paler when raised in artificial environments. **********An artificial version of astaxanthin is already successfully commercialized by Roche Holding AG, the Swiss pharmaceutical producer, which monopolizes what is estimated to be a $150 million-a-year market. **********Mr. Watanabe said the natural astaxanthin could potentially replace the synthetic version because it poses no health hazards and is absorbed more quickly by fish than the artificial one. **********About 30 customers recently conducted field trials and all reported favorable results, Mr. Ramsley said. **********Analysts said that Cyanotech stands to benefit enormously if the market opens in a country like Japan, where the aquaculture industry is expanding rapidly and where approval for natural astaxanthin from the health authorities is awaited. **********CYANOTECH'S Web site is www.cyanotech.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/world.snippet: Diplomats tracking human rights abuses in Kosovo say they are unable to learn fate of more than 20,000 civilians who fled from Yugoslav Government counteroffensive against ethnic Albanian rebels; foreign monitors and aid workers say their movement...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/world.main_headline: Harried Monitors Still Searching for 20,000 Kosovo Refugees
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/world.print_headline: Harried Monitors Still Searching for 20,000 Kosovo Refugees
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/world.body_text: **********Diplomats tracking human rights abuses in Kosovo say they have been unable to learn the fate of more than 20,000 civilians who fled on Tuesday from a Yugoslav Government counteroffensive against ethnic Albanian rebels. **********As the Government attacks continue and fears of rights violations grow, foreign monitors and aid workers say their movements are being restricted by Serbian authorities. **********The United States and other Western countries accused the Yugoslav Government of brutality against civilians in past offensives, and after being threatened with military action by NATO, Yugoslav officials agreed to protect civilians and to allow foreign observers to monitor the Yugoslav military and police forces. **********But with the foreign observer mission badly understaffed and with access restricted, monitors have lost track of more than 20,000 refugees who fled Tuesday from Malisevo when the town came under attack from Government troops. **********''We assume they are in great difficulty,'' said a European diplomat. ''They must be scattered in the countryside in many places, but we don't know. There are many children and many elderly among them. Who knows what condition they are in.'' **********Despite these fears, diplomats also said they saw the possibility of negotiations between Yugoslavia and the ethnic Albanians on autonomy for Kosovo. **********On Saturday the Government forces began their largest offensive against ethnic Albanian rebels in Kosovo province, where ethnic Albanians are about 90 percent of the population. In the last six months, an organization called the Kosovo Liberation Army has grown from a small group of insurgents to a broadly based movement demanding independence for the province. **********The refugees from Malisevo are among an unknown number of people who are fleeing the fighting. ''One has to hold the Government responsible for creating these refugees,'' a senior Western diplomat said. **********He and other diplomats said they did not have enough information to decide if Government forces had been so brutal that NATO action was needed. ''I don't want to say we haven't crossed the line and then tomorrow morning find there are 1,000 people dead in a field somewhere,'' the senior diplomat said. **********Foreign diplomats said there is no exact test for recommending NATO military action or further sanctions against Yugoslavia, which now has only two republics, Serbia and Montenegro. Rather it is ''a kind of consensus by all of us and our governments that would be reached if events became too terrible to countenance,'' one European said. ''But for the moment we are not learning what the truth is about conditions in the field.'' **********The foreign observers, diplomats and military experts, from the United States, Russia and European countries, were turned back by Yugoslav authorities in several combat areas today, they said. Near one town they were barred from, Junik, they reported hearing the sounds of heavy combat. **********Ethnic Albanian political parties say 20 people were executed Tuesday by Yugoslav forces in Junik. A senior Western diplomat said today that he had raised that report with top Yugoslav officials but had received no satisfactory answer. **********Foreign diplomats and monitors said that in many areas where they were permitted, villages had been shelled and many homes burned. **********''From what we could see, it looked as if there was an attempt to take territory and move the civilian population out,'' one monitor said.  ''It looks as if the Yugoslav Army is trying to keep its own casualties low by laying back and using artillery and tanks. That can be very hard on civilians.'' **********Some foreign journalists, traveling in a group organized by Government officials, visited Malisevo, which until the counteroffensive had been a rebel stronghold. They reported it to be deserted except for three families and an elderly man who said he had stayed to care for his cows. **********In Malisevo and area villages there were an estimated 10,000 to 15,000 ethnic Albanians until last week, when about 20,000 refugees arrived after Government forces recaptured the city of Orahovac. **********United Nations relief officials who were able to reach Malisevo last Thursday described conditions as desperate. Today they said that they did not know what had happened to the people there and that access for relief workers in most of the province was blocked either by fighting or by Government authorities. **********A Western diplomat said most refugees were probably in areas controlled by the rebels and would not go back to Malisevo or Orahovac even if the Government offensive ended. ''I think the Albanian public is terrorized by the security forces and not prepared to return unless there is a new security situation,'' he said. **********But diplomats also said they are close to arranging an alliance of ethnic Albanian groups that could negotiate with the Yugoslav Government for some kind of autonomy for Kosovo. This may be difficult because, while Western governments say they do not want Kosovo to be independent, most ethnic Albanians say they will accept nothing less. **********The diplomats say the Albanian political leaders have agreed in principle to form a negotiating team, though they have not decided on the team's membership or who will lead it. The Kosovo Liberation Army was officially invited to join the alliance only today, but it did not immediately respond, diplomats said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/13/world.snippet: Japan's governing Liberal Democratic party released draft plan to bolster economy, but financial markets and analysts are skeptical, saying package is hodgepodge of measures that will have little effect (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/13/world.main_headline: Japan Drafts Economic Plan and It Is Met With Skepticism
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/13/world.print_headline: Japan Drafts Economic Plan and It Is Met With Skepticism
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/13/world.body_text: **********The governing Liberal Democratic Party released a draft plan today to bolster the economy, but the financial markets greeted it skeptically and analysts described it as a hodgepodge of measures that would have little effect. **********This new stimulus package could end up being worth about $165 billion, surpassing the last stimulus plan, which was itself a record. But no official figure was disclosed today, and in any case its size and implementation will depend on political developments. **********The draft, which is expected to be formally endorsed by the Government Monday, aims to create one million jobs and to stimulate consumer spending with less expensive  housing loans, about $57 billion in long-term tax cuts and the distribution of $5.7 billion in merchandise coupons. One proposal, a rollback of last year's increase in the consumption tax, was not mentioned in today's outline. **********Today's draft plan is clouded by uncertainty and could still be redrawn, depending on a process of courtship underway among Japan's political parties and factions. After a stinging election defeat over the summer, the Liberal Democrats have been struggling to maintain the upper hand, and have been forced to take up measures demanded by opposition groups. **********That is why today's plan includes a shopping voucher program, a demand from the small Komei Party. **********In addition, the Liberal Democrats  have also entered intense discussions to form a possible coalition with the Liberal Party, an opposition group run by Ichiro Ozawa, who stormed out of the Liberal Democratic Party in 1993, offending key members. On Monday, Mr. Ozawa plans to meet Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, who returns from a trip to Russia that day, and if an agreement is struck, then today's economic draft plan would be rewritten to include some form of rollback in the controversial consumption tax. **********''If we reach agreement on a coalition, then today's package means nothing,'' said Yoshio Suzuki, policy planning chairman for the Liberal Party. **********The Liberal Party has called for a complete repeal of the five percent consumption tax for at least one year, after which the tax would be gradually stepped up again as permanent income-tax cuts are phased in. But some senior Liberal Democrats have resisted such a step, partly because it would be a big embarrassment for the party, which sent the economy into recession by raising the tax to five percent from three percent in April 1997. **********All this political jockeying has produced a package that economists say may prevent the bottom from falling out from under the economy, but that they also doubt will do much to nurture a genuine recovery. ''It's understandable how the package came together, for it seems a patchwork quilt that parlays to different interests,'' said Christopher J. Calderwood, chief economist at Jardine Fleming Securities Ltd., in Tokyo. ''It lacks coherence or a theme, other than keeping things the same.'' **********Still, there are some elements of the plan that are likely to remain even if a coalition among the parties is reached. In one notable move, the plan suggested that the Government will take on a greater role as banker to alleviate the liquidity shortage that is afflicting cash-strapped companies across the country. Though the Parliament recently enacted two sets of banking laws aimed at easing the credit squeeze, new private lending by the weakly capitalized banks is unlikely to flow into the economy in large amounts any time soon. **********Under the Liberal Democrat's plan, the Government would issue tens of billions in credit guarantees to help midsize firms take out loans.  Moreover, in a two-year program, it plans to also make available as much as $40 billion in taxpayer's postal savings deposits to the Japan Development Bank, which would extend the funds to corporate borrowers who need to repay bonds and have been turned away by their bankers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/26/world.snippet: North Korea warns US that it is prepared to launch another medium-range missile; Clinton Administration has warned the North that such a step would jeopardize international aid it was promised in exchange for freezing its nuclear weapons program (...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/26/world.main_headline: North Korea Warns U.S. That It Can Launch Another Missile
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/26/world.print_headline: North Korea Warns U.S. That It Can Launch Another Missile
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/26/world.body_text: **********North Korea today warned the United States that it was prepared to launch another medium-range missile. The Clinton Administration had privately told the North that such a step would jeopardize international aid it was promised in exchange for freezing its nuclear weapons program. **********The latest warning, published by the official Korean Central News Agency today, said it was ''foolish for the U.S. to expect any change in our attitude.'' But American officials have said in recent weeks that they have seen no activity to suggest that a launching was imminent. **********When North Korea launched a three-stage missile over Japan on Aug. 31, it took the American intelligence community by surprise. Until then, American officials did not believe that the North possessed the technology for a three-stage ballistic missile, which gives the country the ability to reach all of the major American military bases in South Korea and Japan. **********North Korea maintains that the launching was intended to propel a small satellite into low earth orbit. While North Korean news agencies say the satellite now is broadcasting patriotic North Korea songs, American officials say their review of the evidence suggests the satellite either failed to get into orbit, or dropped out of orbit within hours of the launching. **********''We haven't heard a thing,'' one senior Administration official said last week, ''because it's not up there anymore.'' **********The political significance of a second launching would likely be far greater than any marginal technological achievement it might represent for the North. **********The Administration has been trying to rescue a 1994 accord under which North Korea agreed to freeze its nuclear weapons program in exchange for fuel oil and the construction of two civilian nuclear power plants. The United States committed itself to paying for the fuel oil; Japan, South Korea and other nations are paying for the nuclear plants. **********But the discovery earlier this year of a huge dig under a mountain, which the United States suspects is intended for nuclear weapons development, and the missile launchings have cast doubt on the accord. This month the North dropped a demand that it be paid in return for allowing international inspectors to see the new site; instead, it suggested that it would be willing to allow inspectors in if the United States provided more food aid. Some aid has already been sent to alleviate starvation in the country. **********A second launching would probably derail any chance that Congress would approve further participation in the nuclear accord, Administration officials fear. **********It could also derail Japan's contributions to the program. But missile launches themselves are not a violation of the nuclear agreement. **********The North said in its statement today that ''We will never be frightened by the U.S. warning,'' about further launchings. ''The U.S. still knows little'' about the North, a statement few American officials would dispute. **********The administration announced in October that former Defense Secretary William Perry would oversee a complete review of policy on North Korea. Mr. Perry then traveled to South Korea, Japan and China to assess the North's capability. Outside experts say predictions about the North's behavior are becoming more problematic as starvation spreads and pressure on the Communist Government increases.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/world.snippet: Pres Boris Yeltsin will ask Western leaders to help defend Russian rubble, even as Russian financial markets steady slightly after record plunge; Yeltsin will ask Pres Clinton and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to support Russia as it plans new rou...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/world.main_headline: Yeltsin to Ask Western Help for Ruble as Markets Steady
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/world.print_headline: Yeltsin to Ask Western Help for Ruble as Markets Steady
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/world.body_text: **********As Russian financial markets steadied slightly after this week's record plunge, President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that he would call on Western leaders to help defend Russia's embattled ruble. **********His appeal was later echoed by a top finance official who said Russia would need a hefty rescue package from the West -- more generous than a $700 million loan already expected from the International Monetary Fund -- if it is to stem the panic that has threatened Russia's economic and political stability. **********Speaking at a televised meeting of Government officials hastily summoned to his country house, Mr. Yeltsin said he would call foreign leaders, including President Clinton and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, asking them to support Russia as it proceeds with a plan for a new round of spending cuts and more vigorous tax collecting measures. **********''Foreign investors should feel confident there will be no collapse of financial markets in Russia,'' Mr. Yeltsin said, tapping the table for emphasis. ''The Central Bank and Finance Ministry today possess enough reserve funds to stay afloat. That's what is important.'' **********For now, the Yeltsin strategy seemed to work. The ruble was stable for the second consecutive day, and Moscow stock indexes rose. **********According to the latest report from the Russian Central Bank, Russia's gold and currency reserves now stand at $14.5 billion -- down from the $23 billion levels declared in October. Maintaining the stability of the ruble has been a key achievement of Mr. Yeltsin's reform-minded Government over the last few years, and as its desperate actions this week demonstrated, a stable ruble remains its top priority for keeping the shaky Russian economy on track. **********The arrival in Moscow tonight of a top emissary from the International Monetary Fund is seen here as a sign that some help is already on the way. John Odling-Smee, the fund's official in charge of Russia and the former Soviet Union, is expected to confirm approval of a $700 million installment of a $10 billion loan to Russia, delivering a seal of approval that has been closely watched by financial markets here and abroad. **********Meanwhile, Anatoly B. Chubais, a former top Kremlin aide and the head of Russia's electrical monopoly, was headed for Washington. Mr. Chubais maintains close ties to Mr. Yeltsin, and it is believed that he will consult with American officials about possible economic help for Russia. **********Sergei Vasilyev, a senior Kremlin aide, was also on the trip. The Kremlin declined comment about it. **********At a news conference held today in Kazakhstan, Michel Camdessus, managing director of the fund, said Russia's latest efforts had convinced the I.M.F that it was serious about tackling its budget deficit. ''These are important enough that we believe we can release the next tranche of support,'' he told reporters, adding that an announcement would come in the ''in the next few days.'' **********But Deputy Finance Minister Oleg V. Vyugin said today that Russia needed the psychological boost of more foreign credits -- even if those credits turn out to be unnecessary. **********''Judging from the current situation, I can tell you that in principle there is a chance that we can resolve this situation without additional assistance,'' he said. But he added that  further credits ''would play a psychological role because panic is a psychological phenomenon.'' The amount Russia seeks, he said, would be ''a different order of figure.'' **********''Such a credit would show everybody that there are considerable resources and that there won't be problems in the future,'' he said. ''I don't see how such a decision would hurt.'' **********Financial analysts here said today that Western institutions and banks were unlikely to come forward with a currency-stabilization package for Russia anytime soon, preferring to see if financial markets will be convinced by the endorsements given Russia's fiscal program this week by the I.M.F. and Western governments, including Washington. **********In trading today on the Moscow stock exchange, the benchmark Russian RTS index rose 6.2 percent, winning back most of Wednesday's losses. The ruble, which was pegged at 6.17 to the dollar on Wednesday, rose slightly to 6.14. **********The fiscal crisis, which has dominated the news for days now, has for the most part floated over the heads of most Russians, who are more preoccupied with making ends meet than with the values of currencies and stocks. **********A key test of the markets' response will come Wednesday at a regular auction of Russia's Government-backed bonds, known as G.K.O.'s. The bonds will carry an interest rate of 150 percent as rates were tripled on Wednesday to save lure investors to hold bonds and the ruble. **********''Supportive statements by the I.M.F. and the U.S. Treasury are useful to show the markets that the support is there,'' said Christopher Granville, chief strategist at Fleming UCB, a London-based investment group. ''For the moment, the panic seems to have stopped. Then, the bluff will be called.'' **********Russian finance officials are exploring the possibility of a sovereign syndicated loan, which would be pulled together by Western banks, financial analysts said today. ''If they did get the money, the thing to do would be to restructure their loans, and buy back the G.K.O.'s, and cut their domestic debt,'' said Mr. Granville. **********At the emergency meeting held this morning, Mr. Yeltsin called on Prime Minister Sergei V. Kiriyenko to focus efforts on shoring up the ruble. Mr. Yeltsin said he would press Russia's tax authorities to improve their dismal tax collection record, an indicator that has been under close scrutiny by Western advisers. **********''Heads will roll,'' Mr. Yeltsin said, noting that he will meet on Friday with the law enforcement and fiscal authorities. ''They have been working poorly. They must be stricter.'' **********Mr. Kiriyenko said later that Mr. Yeltsin would sign a decree authorizing the tax police to confiscate property belonging to tax dodgers, with a list of major delinquents now being drawn up. Other measures under consideration would call for the forced bankruptcy of companies that have not paid their tax bills, and court proceedings against the managers of delinquent state-owned companies. **********At a Cabinet meeting today, Mr. Kiriyenko said the principal cause of the Russian crisis was that ''we have not learned to live within our means,'' a failure that he said had cost the Russian Government credibility here and abroad. **********Mr. Kiriyenko, 35, who became Prime Minister just a month ago, also met on Wednesday last night with four influential Russian bankers at their request. According to reports, the bankers were reassured by his pledge to stick to the Government's announced austerity plan. **********In public statements, several top Russian finance officials have blamed foreign investors -- who hold $20 billion in Russian Government securities -- for triggering the panic on the markets this week. **********''The market was rocked by a small circle of market players,'' Mr. Vyugin said today. ''We know them. We know about their operations. Judging from these operations, we can say with certainty that their purpose was to push the prices down.'' **********At a news conference on Wednesday Mark Mobius, president of the Templeton Russia Fund, outlined the difference between the Asian and Russian financial crises. **********''In the case of Russia, the crisis is a Government debt crisis, a Government cash-flow crisis,'' he said. ''In the case of Asia, the government was rich, and the private sector was in debt. In the case of Russia, the Government is in trouble, and the private sector is very rich. In both cases, the capital markets, stock markets, bond markets have become extremely volatile.''
