https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/15/world.main_headline: China Keeps Murdoch And His TV On Hiatus
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/15/world.print_headline: China Keeps Murdoch And His TV On Hiatus
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/15/world.body_text: **********One of the paradoxes of Rupert Murdoch's bend-over-backward efforts to keep good relations with China is that he has been so badly frustrated here. **********China's media market is still so tightly closed to foreign companies, and the authorities are so suspicious of international media companies like Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation, that 10 years of wooing and genuflection has yielded almost nothing so far. **********The recent embarrassment to the News Corporation's book unit, HarperCollins -- which apologized to the former Hong Kong Governor, Chris Patten, after dropping his book for its anti-China content -- might have an economic rationale if there was a heavy payoff in China's market to compensate. Yet media executives and consultants say profitability in China is so far in the future that no one can predict when it will come. **********Mr. Murdoch has put well over $1 billion into a satellite television network called Star TV, which broadcasts in several Asian countries and is intended to be the News Corporation's route into China, where more than 300 million homes have television sets, the world's largest potential market. **********But winning approval to broadcast, collecting subscription fees selling advertising are proving so difficult that media executives measure progress in tiny increments. China's entertainment industry is coming alive, yet business opportunities remain maddeningly elusive to foreign operations. **********News Corporation executives argue that they are taking the long view and that with a small toe in the door, they are ahead of their competitors. ''It's all about position, position, position,'' said Bruce Dover, the company's chief representative in Beijing. ''Our strategy is to be ready for the day when the door opens.'' **********Mr. Dover pointed to Star TV's partial ownership of a Hong Kong company, the Phoenix Satellite Television Company, as an important if modest sign of progress. The Phoenix channel, with Chinese-language programming, broadcasts decidely cheerful dramatic shows that consultants say will have difficulty winning cable viewers with 40 channels to choose from. **********Limited mostly to viewers in international hotels and to a cable network in a single Chinese city, Guangzhou, Phoenix reaches a tiny segment of China's viewers. Star TV claims that 35 million homes have access to Phoenix, though independent consultants say that is probably optimistic. **********Even worse, Phoenix broadcasts are still technically illegal, since the Ministry of Radio, Film and Television has yet to grant formal approval. Officials are clearly aware of Phoenix's broadcasts, and they are essentially reserving the right to block them at any time. The same is true for Star TV's four channels, which carry music videos, sports, movies and English programs. **********The brightest aspect of Phoenix, consultants say, is that Star TV shares ownership with a Singapore company called Today's Asia and a Hong Kong company called China Wise, which have their own connections to China's television industry. Star TV and Today's Asia each own 45 percent; China Wise owns the remaining 10 percent. **********''China is so tightly controlled that a joint venture like that is quite an achievement,'' said John Wong, of the Boston Consulting Group, who advises media companies in China. **********Mr. Dover said Star TV, which Mr. Murdoch bought for $900 million in 1993, had lost perhaps $100 million a year until last year, when its loss was reduced to $40 million. It will break even in 12 to 18 months, he estimated. **********Advertising revenue for Phoenix, Mr. Dover said, grew to $34 million last year. ''We're quite happy with that,'' he said. **********Although Mr. Murdoch has visited China many times, assiduously courting Chinese leaders, he attracted the most notice here in 1993 when he said in a speech in London that technological advances like satellite TV were ''an unambiguous threat to totalitarian regimes everywhere.'' **********Alarmed, China's leadership promptly banned individuals from buying satellite dishes. **********Mr. Murdoch's efforts to repair ties to Beijing -- by yanking the BBC news service from Star TV's broadcasts, by authorizing a $1 million book contract at HarperCollins for the daughter of Deng Xiaoping, and by reaching a minor Internet deal with The People's Daily -- have yet to win back much encouragement. **********The News Corporation's only other China venture, a television studio in Tianjin, has also been a disappointment, a Star TV executive said. ''It's a waiting game,'' the executive conceded, referring to Mr. Murdoch's plans in China. ''He realizes it's going to be be a long, long trip.'' **********Mr. Dover, the News Corporation executive, said: ''That problem of control still worries them. But there's an insatiable appetite they have to meet. They need to be more forward-looking.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/15/busin.snippet: Credit-card companies have appeared to awaken to reality that second only to plastic, the Internet is best thing that ever happened to the industry; at end of November, typical E-commerce site can send up to 2.5 percent of its revenue to credit-ca...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/15/busin.main_headline: The real winners in electronic commerce are turning out to be the credit-card companies.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/15/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; The real winners in electronic commerce are turning out to be the credit-card companies.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/15/busin.body_text: **********IN many an Internet start-up company's dreams, there's a fragment of hope that its Web site, device or software will somehow stand at the tollbooth of the electronic commerce universe and collect a share of every transaction made in cyberspace. **********That device has already arrived. It's called the credit card. **********In recent weeks, credit-card companies have appeared to awaken to the reality that second only to plastic, the Internet is the best thing that ever happened to the industry. Thus this season has seen the television advertising campaign for Visa and the Internet toy merchant Etoys, Seagram's Universal Studios on-line promotion with the Morgan Stanley  Dean Witter Discover card, and last week's deal between the Internet service provider Earth Link Network and the credit-card monolith MBNA Corporation, which issues Visa and Mastercard cards. **********If the purveyors of revolving debt suddenly look like the Internet's latest, best pal, there's good reason. Most of the deals were conceived months ago, when it became clear that electronic commerce meant a no-cash, no-check bazaar where consumers would use their cards more than ever. **********''I've been running around the office rallying the troops, saying 'We've been waiting 40 years for an opportunity like this,' '' said Joseph Vause, vice president of electronic commerce for Visa USA. **********As the E-commerce pie expands, so, too, grows the wealth of the credit-card industry. At month's end, a typical E-commerce site can send up to 2.5 percent of its revenue to the credit-card companies to cover transaction fees. Given estimated Internet sales of roughly $40 billion this year, credit-card companies expect to reap hundreds of millions of dollars in transaction fees. **********And, of course, that number is expected to skyrocket as an ever-greater percentage of consumers turn to on-line shopping. Visa, for one, estimates that it will process a total of $13 billion in Internet charges this year, or about 1 percent of its total charge activity. But by 2003, those umbers are expected to reach $100 billion and 11 percent, respectively. **********Given the math, ''credit-card companies are going to find that the investments they've made are very wise ones indeed,'' said Ken Cassar, an E-commerce analyst at the New York Internet research firm of Jupiter Communications. Noting that consumers now make 80 percent of purchases with cash, Mr. Cassar said, ''If credit-card companies can move that number 5 percent'' via on-line purchases, ''that's huge.'' **********So far, analysts say, the credit- card company doing the most to promote Internet spending is Visa, which holds the biggest market share on line and off. While Visa USA, the umbrella organization for the 21,000 financial institutions that issue the card, was already one of the leading on-line advertisers in 1997, it has taken the message to the mainstream in 1998 with the Etoys holiday promotion on television. **********The $8 million to $10 million ad campaign, for which Etoys paid nothing, has done so well that Etoys canceled its own ad campaigns lest it be overwhelmed by demand, Visa's Mr. Vause said. He added, ''It's the first time we could feature a merchant everybody could go to.'' **********But even the organization's $25 million 1998 advertising budget pales in comparison with what is being spent by some of the Visa-affiliated financial institutions. In late October, for instance, First USA, a Visa and Mastercard issuer, announced a five-year, $90 million deal to advertise its credit cards on Microsoft's MSN.com site -- and that was just one of several marketing deals it has made with major Web sites. **********Mastercard was actually the first to bring the topic of Internet spending into prime time, with an ad that was on the ''Seinfeld'' finale in May promoting Excite's shopping channel. Mastercard has also spent heavily on its Shop Smart program, in which it endorses Internet retailers, and it is about to start another Internet-oriented television ad. **********The Discover card, meanwhile, is capitalizing on shoppers who make on-line purchases only when they find bargains. At Discover's Shop Center, consumers get rebates and discounts from selected merchants when they buy with the card. **********Curiously, analysts say that American Express has been relatively less active on line, which Mr. Cassar of Jupiter Communications characterized as ''a huge, colossal mistake.'' **********''It's just a ton of potential opportunity that Amex will basically be giving up to other credit-card associations,'' Mr. Cassar said. **********Emily Porter, director for public affairs at American Express, said the company ''is doing special offers on line'' -- promoting last-minute travel bargains on its site, for example. However, its mass media Web commerce promotion has been limited to a recent one-day radio media tour that she conducted, ''where on-line shopping was talked about in practically every interview, so we are seeking to spread the word.'' **********Perhaps not enough. According to a recent Jupiter survey of consumers who used credit cards to make Web purchases this year, 55 percent used Visa, 26 percent used Mastercard, and 11 percent used American Express. Off line, American Express has 16.7 percent of the market, according to Credit Card Management magazine, while Mastercard has 27.4 percent and Visa 48 percent. **********For Web merchants, having the credit-card companies' support is a boon. While off-line ads promote the medium, on-line advertising dollars help rich sites get richer, proven sites get rich and start-ups get by. **********Preview Travel, which earns 25 percent of its revenue from banners that advertisers buy on its Web site, struck its biggest ad deal this summer with Mastercard, which paid an undisclosed amount for the right to be the ''preferred'' card at the site. For that, Mastercard gets its logo placed throughout the site -- but in no location more important than at the point where the customer selects a credit card to book a reservation. Moreover, while the order form's selection box includes other credit cards, only Mastercard is highlighted. **********''That's the trick of the game,'' said Paul Johnson, an on-line commerce analyst with the International Data Corporation, an Internet research firm in Framingham, Mass. ''I'm anxious to see how successful that is.'' **********Mastercard says its Internet partnerships are quite successful. ''We've seen market-share shifts of 30 percent with some sites,'' said Debra Coughlin, senior vice president of global advertising for Mastercard International. **********Ad dollars notwithstanding, not all sites are convinced of the value of such partnerships. **********''We get a lot of offers, but nobody's come up with a compelling enough reason for us to offer this to our customers,'' said Robert Olson, chief operating officer of Virtual Vineyards, a wine retailer. **********Meanwhile, Fingerhut, a catalogue  company and Web retailer with more than $1.5 billion in annual sales and its own proprietary credit card, is trying to circumvent the credit- card companies altogether. Andy Johnson, Fingerhut's senior vice president for market development, said that starting next year the company would begin issuing proprietary credit cards for its E-commerce sites, like Andy's Garage, just as Macy's does with its in-house credit cards. **********''We're looking for ways to take costs out of the process,'' Mr. Johnson said. ''Right now, customers are paying for the fees the credit-card companies charge us.'' **********Ultimately, it may not matter which credit-card company gets the customer's money. What matters is that the emerging symbiotic relationship between silicon chips and plastic cards is nurturing electronic commerce and bringing consumers a step closer the day when cash is no longer king.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/20/busin.snippet: East Tennessee Technology Park in Oak Ridge--one of three major sites of original Manhattan Project that was used until 1988 to enrich bomb-grade uranium--is now being decontaminated so it can be reused or demolished; many companies are cleaning u...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/20/busin.main_headline: Nuclear Arms to Plowshares; Cleaning Up Financially by Cleaning Up Oak Ridge
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/20/busin.print_headline: Nuclear Arms to Plowshares; Cleaning Up Financially by Cleaning Up Oak Ridge
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/20/busin.body_text: **********When the Energy Department looks around Oak Ridge, its huge weapons enclave some 20 miles outside Knoxville, Tenn., it sees a truly daunting cleanup problem. There are centrifuges, reactors, pumps, hundreds of acres of buildings and soil, all bearing troublesome radioactive memories of the roles they played in building nuclear bombs. **********BNFL Inc. looks at the same stuff and sees $50 million worth of metals it can sell as scrap. The East Tennessee Materials and Energy Corporation sees a place to set up a waste-treatment center without fouling anyone's back yard. Blue Ridge Development sees a place where it can set up shop at a dirt-cheap rent. Bioneutrics Inc. sees a way to treat brain cancer. **********''It seemed a crime to bury something that could be used for a purpose like this,'' said George F. Dilworth, president of Bioneutrics, which is building a cancer treatment center around a small nuclear reactor that the Government estimates would cost $8.5 million to dismantle, decontaminate and bury. **********Apparently, lots of people agree. The disparate visions of Oak Ridge are melding, as a growing reindustrialization program lets companies clean up financially by cleaning up Oak Ridge. **********Although each arrangement is different, in essence companies like Bioneutrics are bartering their services in return for materials or space. Typically, the companies agree to decontaminate a specified portion of Oak Ridge. They return cleaned-up classified equipment to the Energy Department for disposal. But they get to keep the nonclassified materials and equipment on their site, and they get to occupy the space at a deeply discounted rent. **********''This program has moved up the decontamination and re-use of these buildings by at least two generations,'' said Robert Brown, Oak Ridge's operations asset manager. **********It is also saving the Government hundreds of millions of dollars in cleanup costs and creating jobs in an area that seemed poised for economic devastation. **********Not that everyone is delighted. The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers union, which represents many Oak Ridge workers, has tried, so far unsuccessfully, to force companies to give its laid-off workers first crack at new jobs. And while environmental officials in Washington say they have not paid close attention to the project, Environmental Protection Agency officials in Atlanta have expressed worries that the Energy Department will divert funds from cleanup to marketing. **********Still, advocates seem to far outnumber critics. ''It's win-win all around,'' said Joe W. Anderson, chairman of East Tennessee Materials. The company is cleaning up and re-using some 85,000 square feet of space, at a $2 million saving to the Energy Department, and is employing some 200 displaced Oak Ridge workers to boot. ''The community gets jobs, the D.O.E. gets free cleanup, we get to resell whatever material we can salvage, and we get a place to set up shop,'' Mr. Anderson said. **********If Oak Ridge were a private facility, industry would probably run the other way. It is a quintessential ''brownfields'' property -- land or buildings with a legacy of hazardous contamination. Companies often shy away from such facilities, fearing they will be held liable if the actual culprit in the contamination goes out of business, or otherwise escapes culpability for future harm. **********Those are unlikely scenarios at Oak Ridge, a vast complex that was carved out of farmland during World War II, provided enriched uranium for the first atom bomb, and turned out components for nuclear weapons for years afterward. ''The isotopes we used are unique to us, and there's no way 20 years from now that we could or would shift responsibility to anyone else,'' Mr. Brown said. **********Oak Ridge probably could not afford to clean up on its own. Its budget, $3.2 billion in 1993, is now $1.9 billion and falling. The work force, 19,300 strong in 1993, is down to 14,500, and heading for no more than 7,500 within a few years. And Oak Ridge faces a domino effect: less money means fewer people means more shuttered facilities means more idle plants in need of cleaning up. **********Other Energy Department weapons plants face similar budget cuts. Those that must remain open -- Sandia, in Santa Fe, N.M., which must maintain existing weapons stockpiles, is a notable example -- are bringing in extra money by letting companies use their people and facilities for industrial research. Those with particularly severe contamination -- like Rocky Flats, near Denver -- are cleaning up and shutting down. And a few facilities are experimenting with what Robert W. DeGrasse Jr., an Energy Department director, calls ''the perpetual motion approach'' -- they clean up some space, lease it out, and use the lease revenue to clean up other space. **********But only Oak Ridge seems suited to a huge clean-it-and-keep-it approach. The gaseous diffusion process that it used to enrich uranium yields a lot of residual nickel, which has a high value on the scrap metal market. And uranium presents a less formidable health hazard and decontamination problem than do plutonium, tritium or other elements used in weapons. **********''Sometimes, you can decontaminate an entire machine with simple solvent, hand-wipe, and good old elbow grease,'' said Joel W. Garber, vice president of American Technologies Inc., a $20 million engineering services company that is decontaminating 125,000 square feet and 200 machines at Oak Ridge. **********In many ways, Oak Ridge is wiping away its history with similar ease. It recently changed the name of its old K-25 uranium enrichment facility, a 706-acre complex with 118 buildings, to the East Tennessee Technology Park. Its goal is to turn it into a self-sustaining industrial park by 2010. **********The first lease was signed in May 1996, and 45 percent of the space is already in the hands of the private sector. One reason for the speed: with Congress's blessing, Oak Ridge circumvented the mountains of red tape that would normally accompany any industry-government deal by handling all transactions through the Community Re-use Organization of East Tennessee, or Croet, a nonprofit private-sector group set up expressly as Oak Ridge's real estate marketing arm. **********''It would take the D.O.E. two years to do what we can do in a few months,'' said Lawrence Young, president of Croet (pronounced CROW-ette). **********Start-up companies can get going even more quickly. Blue Ridge Development, a local real estate developer, has taken 54,000 square feet of already clean space, and is subdividing it to use as an incubator for fledgling companies. **********Dan Barnett, a Blue Ridge partner, says the leases can be approved in weeks. ''Someone who just needs a few hundred square feet doesn't want to wait for all kinds of negotiations and approvals,'' he said. ''Let's face it, the private sector just knows how to move quicker.'' **********In lieu of cleanup responsibilities, Blue Ridge gave Croet a check for $250,000 in advance rent. It will also share some of its rental revenues with Croet after two years. **********Oak Ridge is not by any means getting away scot-free on its cleanup bill. In by far the biggest contract signed so far, it has agreed to pay BNFL Inc., a subsidiary of British Nuclear Fuels Ltd., $238 million over six years to clean up three contaminated buildings, comprising five million square feet of floor space. **********BNFL, which has dismantled gaseous diffusion plants in England -- and which, in fact, has been decontaminating waste for commercial nuclear plants in the United States for three years -- calculates that there are at least 130,000 tons of copper, nickel and other metals it can salvage. It also figures it can resell a few electrical transformers and other pieces of equipment, particularly in developing countries. **********John R. Smith, senior vice president of BNFL, which is based in Fairfax, Va., estimates that the company can get $50 million for the cleaned-up materials, bringing its total take to $288 million. That's about a quarter of what the Energy Department estimates it would cost to do the cleanup itself -- but then, Mr. Smith notes, that estimate builds in the cost of government bureaucracy and inefficiency. **********''Their mind-set is making weapons, not decommissioning them,'' he said. ''We have the experience, and at $288 million we can make a modest, sensible profit.'' **********BNFL will hire some 300 former Oak Ridge workers to help with the cleanup and will turn the decontaminated space back to Croet to lease to companies without cleanup skills. That, in turn, will create a rental revenue stream that Croet can use to pay for even more cleanup. **********While BNFL is plumbing the lion's share of metallic riches, smaller companies are being dazzled as well. American Technologies originally leased some 45,000 square feet in a relatively uncontaminated maintenance shop at Oak Ridge, with the idea of turning decontaminated metal scrap into containers for low-level radioactive waste. But soon after it moved in, it realized that the huge machine tool shop next door presented more lucrative opportunities. **********So it stopped fabricating boxes -- ''We realized we couldn't compete in price with cold rolled steel anyway,'' Mr. Garber recalled -- and agreed to decontaminate the whole area. In return, it will pocket anything it gets for the tools. The Energy Department estimates that the equipment is worth as much as $1.5 million, and Mr. Garber, who has arranged to auction it off in June, says he can get even more. **********Already, the new Oak Ridge tenants are learning to use one another to maximize their profits. BNFL and American Technologies are joining forces to look for used-equipment markets in Southeast Asia. And Materials and Chemistry Laboratory Inc., an environmental testing company, is looking for a partner to help it clean up an underused Oak Ridge laboratory that it wants to use. The company wants no part of cleanup responsibilities, so it is looking to barter free laboratory testing services to a company that will do the cleanup. **********''We'd pay maybe $2.35 for space that's worth $5 or $6 a square foot, so trading for the cleanup gives us a real bargain,'' said Barry A. Stephenson, the company's president. **********Such side deals are just fine with Oak Ridge and Croet. Indeed, anything that gets Oak Ridge cleaned up more quickly sits well with them. Croet just leased clean space to Dynamic Tooling Systems, a tool-and-die company that will employ 30 local people, but that did not want to clean space itself. And Mr. Young is planning to build a conventional industrial park on 1,000 acres of uncontaminated farmland nearby. **********''This area needs jobs,'' Mr. Young said. ''And cleanup and jobs are inextricably linked.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/04/busin.body_text: **********It is early morning on a recent Tuesday, and Gary Parr is hard at work. Since arriving four hours earlier at his 35th-floor office overlooking Times Square, Mr. Parr, the co-head of Morgan Stanley's global mergers-and-acquisitions group, has dispatched a banker to Asia to counsel a client on a corporate restructuring, weighed in on a bid for an insurance company and mapped out a London trip to meet a chief executive who wants to sell the company he runs. **********Four floors down, the activity is just as frenzied. Two of Mr. Parr's associates, Derek Kirkland and Douglas L. Brown, are huddling in Mr. Brown's office, poring over a list of insurance companies Morgan is advising. Within 30 minutes, they have doled out eight assignments to 20 Morgan bankers, including missions to Asia, Europe and Latin America as well as New York. **********''We're busier than we've ever been,'' says Mr. Parr, the 18-hour days wearing on his voice. ''And it doesn't look like it will slow down.'' **********Investment bankers have always logged long hours, but those like Messrs. Parr, Brown and Kirkland are finding themselves busier than most. That is because the insurance industry -- their specialty -- is among the busiest domestic sectors for mergers this year. **********Amid the continuing merger boom, insurance is just one of several areas that are expected to be especially active, with the forces driving consolidation varying by industry. Pharmaceutical companies, for example, are scrambling to find partners to help underwrite the huge cost of developing the next blockbuster drug, and marketing their products to five continents. Utility companies and banks, by contrast, want to grow to meet the challenges of deregulation. **********So far this year, the financial services industry -- including banks, investment firms and insurance companies -- is leading the mergers pack with 119 announced bids worth $24.9 billion, according to the Securities Data Company of Newark. Telecommunications companies are not far behind, with 31 proposed transactions valued at $23.5 billion, followed by the business-services sector, where a $8.4 billion hostile bid by Computer Associates for the Computer Sciences Corporation drove the total up to $13.5 billion. **********Similarly, the Halliburton Company's agreement last week to acquire Dresser Industries for $7.7 billion skewed the figures for the machinery industry, thrusting it to No. 4,  even though machinery is not expected to be hot this year. **********But there is plenty of business for everyone; over all, 1998 is shaping up as the most hectic mergers-and-acquisition season on record, and the momentum seems unstoppable. **********Through Feb. 26, 1,506 domestic transactions valued at $142.2 billion have been announced, according to Securities Data, surpassing the previous record of 1,548 deals worth $128 billion in the similar period last year. And volume for all of 1997 set a record for the fourth year in a row. ''The merger train is still on track and gaining speed,'' said Richard Peterson, a spokesman for Securities Data. **********Think back to last October when the stock market dropped 1,017 points, or 12.4 percent, in less than three weeks. Bankers lamented then that the good old days were over and that it was time to find a ''real'' job. **********They were wrong. Many analysts now predict the mergers boom will continue no matter what the stock market does. They look at all the elements of the global market -- financial deregulation at home, the crisis in Asia, market liberalization in Europe and, everywhere, low interest rates and inflation -- and conclude more companies will decide the only way to prosper in such an environment is to become bigger fast by joining forces with a competitor. **********''There is pressure on younger companies to keep up with the giants,'' said Eff Martin, a managing director at Goldman, Sachs's high-technology group. ''They have to have the critical mass to compete.'' **********Plus, you cannot forget the strong economy. With stock prices so high, some chief excutives figure that now is a good time to sell. Acquisition-minded companies do not mind paying a premium because a good partner will give earnings a boost. But some studies suggest that while initial enthusiasm raises a stock's price, mergers only sporadically deliver as promised in the long run. **********Still everywhere, activist investors like the mutual-fund manager Michael Price are badgering poor performers to cut costs and improve profits. ''That pressure will force companies to pursue strategies to keep the price of their stock up,'' said Rick Escherich, an analyst in the mergers-and-acquisitions department of J. P. Morgan Securities. **********The danger, of course, is that investors' expectations will be raised to unrealistic levels. Only last month, Donald J. Trump caught many people on Wall Street off guard by hiring two investment banks to help him sell some or all of his debt-laden Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts for what they viewed as a far-fetched price of $1.1 billion, or about $29 a share -- almost triple its current market price. **********Even a market crash would probably do little to cure merger fever, industry watchers say. If the Dow tumbles, says Robert Friedman, a partner at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, ''acquisition targets will look a lot more attractive to leveraged buyout firms.'' Buyout firms have been stockpiling cash and are set to pounce on vulnerable companies.  Witness Texas Pacific Group's injecting $350 million, for instance, to help bail out battered Oxford Health Plans when the health care giant's stock fell to the midteens. **********Another twist investors can expect is an increase in the number of deals abroad. Last year, 45 percent of the $1.58 trillion of worldwide mergers and acquisitions were outside North America, according to J. P. Morgan. And this year, Europe is expected to be even livelier, in part because of the privatization of government-owned concerns and the deregulation of telecommunications and financial institutions. Recently, for example, Allianz, the German insurer, announced a bid to acquire AGF, a French rival, for more than $10 billion. If completed, it would be the largest-ever foreign takeover of a French company. **********And once the smoke from Asia's financial crisis starts to clear, two trends are likely to emerge. Already, cash-poor Asian companies are seeking buyers for subsidiaries to raise money quickly. And American companies that want a presence in Japan or South Korea will finally be able to buy it. ''For the first time, you can afford to raid a Korean company,'' said Steven Koch, a co-head of the mergers group at Credit Suisse First Boston. ''Two months ago, you couldn't do that.'' **********In the United States, investors can expect consolidation in the financial sector to lead the merger wave. ''You have a blurring of the lines between banks, insurance companies, securities firms and other financial services,'' said Ken Wilson, head of the financial-institutions group at Lazard Freres. Banks are selling for three to five times stated book value -- the worth of a company's assets at their original acquisition prices minus any depreciation. That is the highest level since they rebounded from their early slump of the 1990's. **********Why are suitors willing to pay so much? Economy of scale is a big factor; the most successful mergers are expected to slash costs by 25 to 55 percent. But the main impetus is that size is seen as a key to survival. Banks want to solidify their presence at home and expand into new markets. Nationsbank, the fast-growing banking conglomerate based in Charlotte, N.C., for example, lacks a large presence in California. It has long desired to complete a transaction with BankAmerica, based in San Francisco, but it is interested in First Chicago NBD, too, bank advisers say. **********Investment banks that are rumored to be on the block include J. P. Morgan, which has transformed itself from a commercial bank, and Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, a unit of Deutsche Bank. Both have underperformed their rivals. **********One fly in the ointment is the year 2000 software problem, which some analysts say could slow bank merger activity next year if it is not overcome soon. **********In insurance, the consolidation of the overcrowded life insurance business is fueling the boom. The United States has more than 100 active life insurance groups, according to Michael Blumstein, a Morgan Stanley analyst. ''Compare that to Japan, which has about 30,'' he said. Aetna, for example, has reportedly put its life insurance unit up for sale even as it seeks to develop a bigger health insurance business. **********For sellers like Aetna, the timing is right. Insurance companies in general are now selling for between two and two and a half times stated book value, the highest in recent memory. Unlike banks, though, insurance companies will expand more rapidly abroad, said Rodgin Cohen, an lawyer at Sullivan & Cromwell, one of the leading law firms in mergers and acquisitions. Bankers speculate that smaller insurance companies, like Life USA Holdings or ARM Financial Group, could be targets. **********And the decision of more and more mutual insurance companies to go public could set off another wave of activity, analysts say. **********Pharmaceutical companies are playing the mating game, too, but for different reasons. Unlike insurers or banks, said Jay Flaherty, head of Merrill Lynch's global health care group, they ''don't have the external pressure to do something because they are in pretty good shape.'' **********Their goal is to combine their research and development to come up with new products more cheaply and only in rare cases to shore up a balance sheet or replenish a drug pipeline. Analysts say American Home Products, which was dropped in January by SmithKline Beecham, is on the prowl for a partner, as is SmithKline, which last week broke off talks with Glaxo Wellcome and is rumored to be a hostile target. **********Patrick McMullan of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette warns that if the stock market declines the next few months, small biotechnology companies that are looking for capital could find themselves in the arms of larger companies -- either through alliances or outright acquisitions. **********Telecommunications and computer companies are among the most widely discussed candidates. Analysts expect regional telephone companies to expand into new markets and computer concerns to buy networking or Internet companies to round out their product lines. **********Utilities are the latest industry caught up in deregulation. Gregg Polle, a banker at Salomon Smith Barney who specializes in the sector, said merger activity was happening at two levels. ''Some companies say the way to make money is to become retail companies and offer a suite of products,'' he said. ''Others say the way to make money is to deliver electricity to the house.'' **********Companies near each other will be the quickest to marry. Candidates include FPL Group in Juno Beach, Fla., the Southern Company in Atlanta and Dominion Resources in Richmond. **********One obstacle is that regulators have not figured out how far deregulation should go. American Electric Power of Columbus, Ohio, and the Central and South West Corporation of Dallas announced their intention to combine last December, but the transaction is being reviewed by regulators. **********''If regulators let the deal go through, it will open up more activity,'' Mr. Polle said. ''If they knock it down, mergers could slow.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/07/busin.snippet: Motorola Inc reports that it has managed to match Wall Street's diminished expectations for its first-quarter earnings, but any likelihood that investors in technology companies will take that as good news is dashed when company warns that its sec...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/07/busin.main_headline: COMPANY REPORTS: THE MARKETS -- Market Place; Motorola issues some relatively good news, then some bad.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/07/busin.print_headline: COMPANY REPORTS: THE MARKETS -- Market Place; Motorola issues some relatively good news, then some bad.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/07/busin.body_text: **********MOTOROLA Inc. reported late yesterday that it had managed to match Wall Street's diminished expectations for its first-quarter earnings, but any likelihood that investors in technology companies would take that as good news was dashed when the company warned that its second quarter was shaping up much more poorly than projected. **********''This doesn't look good,'' said John Lazlo, who follows technology stocks for Paine Webber in San Francisco. ''Most people felt that the first quarter would be the trough.'' **********Motorola, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., said that it earned $180 million, or 30 cents a share on a diluted basis, in the first quarter, down 45 percent from $325 million, or 53 cents a share a year earlier. Revenues were $6.9 billion, up 4 percent from a year earlier. **********Excluding $54 million from asset sales and other one-time gains, the telecommunications and semiconductor giant had operating earnings of $142 million, or 23 cents a share, right in line with what analysts had projected after being warned a month ago to reduce their estimates. **********Last month's warning had focused attention on the problems Motorola and other major technology companies were facing as a result of Asian currency declines and the resulting economic woes in several key Asian countries. Motorola had issued its bad news on the heels of a warning from the Intel Corporation, another technology bellwether, that its earnings would be below projections. But at the time Motorola had also injected a note of hope when it said that it had seen signs that Asia's economic problems were abating. **********Yesterday, though, Christopher Galvin, Motorola's chief executive, said that problems in Asia might continue for ''several more quarters.'' The company also said that it was being hurt by weakening demand for pagers and analog cellular telephones in the United States. **********''Second-quarter sales are expected to be below those of a year ago,'' Mr. Galvin said. ''Second-quarter earnings are expected to be well below current investment community expectations and could be equal to or less than 1998 first-quarter earnings.'' **********The earnings and disappointing forecast were released after trading had ended on the New York Stock Exchange, where Motorola's share price fell 31.25 cents, to $59.875. Analysts were awaiting the chance to question the company in a conference call scheduled for early today. **********Motorola has long been among the most widely held of technology stocks, but its usefulness as a barometer for the sector has been questionable for some time. Analysts say that many of its problems, especially in the wireless communications business, result from poor execution rather than industrywide pressures. **********Motorola's largest business, the  cellular phone group, increased sales to $2.81 billion in the first quarter as demand grew for the company's new digital products, but overall orders were flat and operating profits dropped as sales of its older, analog products fell sharply. The semiconductor business, which sells many of its products to the cellular group and other Motorola operations as well as externally, had a 4 percent decline in orders, although sales edged up 1 percent, to $1.83 billion. **********Motorola's radio sector had a 27 percent increase in sales, to $1.24 billion; increased profits, and a 2  percent growth in new orders. But that was partly offset by the messaging sector, which includes paging products, where sales tumbled 25 percent, to $693 million, orders fell 21 percent and Motorola lost money. Motorola said that the paging decline reflected efforts by retailers to reduce inventory and that sales to consumers in the key North American and Chinese markets appeared to still be growing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/techn.snippet: Consumers are being given growing array of options for meeting their escalating need to fax, phone, send E-mail and go out on Internet; many newer transmission options are expensive, with higher service costs and extra charges for special modems, ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/techn.main_headline: Phone Lines, and Lines and Lines, Keeping Their Appeal
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/techn.print_headline: Phone Lines, and Lines and Lines, Keeping Their Appeal
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/techn.body_text: **********CALL it phone-line meltdown, if you will; consumers know it well. It's that angina-inducing moment when an avalanche of both voice and data transmission needs threaten to turn your single, humble phone line, as well as your patience, into a pile of ashes. **********Trying to stay in touch with the office -- 20 calls a day -- as well as surf the Net? Good luck. Plain-vanilla phone lines can do only so much. **********In the past year in particular, consumers have been given a growing array of options for meeting their escalating need to fax, phone, send E-mail and go out on the Internet. As a result, they no longer have to rely on just a phone line or two. **********But many of these newer transmission options, like cable Internet connections and A.D.S.L. (asymmetrical digital subscriber lines), are currently available only in certain parts of the country. And while their prices are dropping, they are, for the most part, still expensive, with not just higher service costs but also extra charges for special modems, installation and even Internet service providers. Even then, technical support for the services is often less than encouraging. **********Given the constraints of newer technologies, many consumers are sticking with the tried and true. That usually means simply increasing the number of regular phone lines, from one or two to three or four -- or more. By all accounts, sales of regular phone lines are booming. An extra line is usually no more than $20 a month, with installation starting around $75. **********In California, for example, Pacific Bell has installed a record number of telephone access lines in the past three financial quarters, and almost all of those installations have been standard phone lines, which use analog technology. Pacific Bell now offers its customers 17.7 million access lines. But it still has only about 170,000 customers for its I.S.D.N. (integrated services digital network) service. The company is now introducing A.D.S.L. service as well. **********At Bell Atlantic, sales of extra analog lines are also brisk. The number of sales first surged in 1994 and is now growing by 15 percent a year, said Debra Swann, executive director for consumer local and toll services at Bell Atlantic. **********Families with talk-happy teen-agers, as well as home offices, account for a good chunk of the interest, of course. At Pacific Bell, for example, about one-sixth of the requests for extra phone lines are now coming from families that plan to give the lines to teen-agers, said John Britton, a company spokesman. **********Still, heavy Internet use seems to be the factor that eventually drives most consumers to pile up dial tones. For example, in a survey of 7,800 households last fall, Ziff-Davis Marketing Intelligence found that 51 percent of those that used the Internet 16 hours or more a week had two or more lines, while 8 percent had three or more. **********At Byte Sized Computing, a home-office consulting business in Rye, N.Y., Dominick Curatola, the owner, said he was asked about the need for second lines ''almost every day.'' So far, he added, consumers seem to be sticking with analog technology. ''I think there's interest in newer technologies on a theoretical level, but the small office or home hasn't really begun to push it,'' Mr. Curatola said. That's because most people are buying computers that have modems that use traditional analog phone lines already built into them. **********''Quite honestly, consumers are having enough time with regular modems and services, let alone the fancier technologies,'' said Jim Mulcahy, who owns another computer consulting service, Computer Tutor @PCI  in Bronxville, N.Y. **********But many consumers may simply not yet need the lightning-fast transmission speeds of newer technologies like A.D.S.L. At its fastest, A.D.S.L. can pummel data along 250 times faster than a traditional 28.8-Kbps (kilobits per second) modem. **********''The killer application for the Internet is still E-mail,'' said Doug Michelman, another spokesman for Pacific Bell. ''More often than not, consumers are accessing the Internet for E-mail.'' **********Cost, however, may be an equally strong motivator. Take the McCalmont family of Cincinnati. The McCalmonts already have three phone lines. Yet until recently, they found themselves juggling those lines constantly to meet their considerable voice and data needs. Both Mr. McCalmont and his wife, Alyce, for example, work from home as professional organizers; as such, they not only need to maintain a semblance of order at home regarding communications but also need to rely on open phone lines for business calls and the Internet. **********But the McCalmonts' daughter, Laura, 16, is on the phone constantly. And their son, Drew, 14, spends so much time on the Internet -- up to 12 hours a day in the summer -- that he now has his own phone line. **********Earlier this year, the McCalmonts realized that they needed to expand their phone line capacity fast. But they were already paying almost $200 a month for their three lines, an Internet service provider and three car phones. As a result, I.S.D.N. service was never an option. In the Cincinnati area, it costs $110 a month for service alone, while installation, an I.S.D.N. modem and Internet service cost extra. **********Of course, the McCalmonts could have installed a fourth phone line, at a service cost of about $20 a month. Three months ago, however, they opted for an even cheaper, as well as simpler, solution: an Internet call manager service from Cincinnati Bell.  For $7 a month, the service lets them answer or transfer an incoming call while they are using the Internet on their business line.  They can also flash callers a message to let them know they will return the call. **********Jon Kiphart is also staying true to his analog phone lines. As a freelance programmer who, among other things, automates theme park rides, Mr. Kiphart often finds himself connecting to the Internet from phones in far-flung locales like Malaysia that are not equipped to send and receive data on line and that also have limited access to digital phone technology. **********For times like these, Mr. Kiphart carries his own acoustical modem, a coupling device designed for phones. At home, in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., he makes do with two analog phone lines, even though he often has to download large files chock full of graphics. **********''I've heard that I.S.D.N. modems are very difficult to set up,'' he said. ''And what I need is ease of use, durability and reliability, as well as the ability to tap into my computer from exotic locations.'' **********Cost, however, is also a sticking point for Mr. Kiphart. ''If the local cable service were able to deliver Internet service for $20 a month, I'd go for it,'' he said. ''I'd also be willing to pay $30 a month for unlimited I.S.D.N. access. But right now I'm already spending between $200 and $300 a month for two analog lines, Internet service, a cell phone and a pager.'' **********Digital technologies are becoming more affordable. For example, computer manufacturers are expected to roll out products that have A.D.S.L. modems built into them as early as next year. Meanwhile, A.D.S.L. technology, unlike I.S.D.N., carries the advantage of not being metered, so consumers can usually get unlimited service for between $70 and $90 a month. That fee, however, doesn't cover A.D.S.L.'s hefty installation and modem costs, which can chalk up an extra $600 or more. **********Phone companies are trying to keep connection costs down as well. For example, when Bell Atlantic begins rolling out A.D.S.L. service next month, start-up fees will be held to less than $200 for an introductory promotional period. That fee will include a $99 connection fee and an A.D.S.L. modem for less than $100. Bell Atlantic says  it will also waive fees for any home wiring work that may be necessary and any setup help that customers may need to reconfigure their computers for the new technology. **********Peter Castleton, director of data products for Bell Atlantic, says consumer interest in the company's A.D.S.L. service has been overwhelming so far. ''There seems to be pent-up demand for it,'' he added. **********Still, for now, many consumers seem to be sticking with the technology that gives them the fewest number of headaches. One example is Beth Rowan, a public relations and marketing consultant who lives in Bronxville, N.Y. **********Ms. Rowan works from her home and has two teen-agers, ages 13 and 16. Not surprisingly, she likes ''to have things simple and straightforward, rather than the latest technology on the block.'' As a result, when she needed more phone capacity last summer, she simply installed a third phone line. **********Ms. Rowan may move to a faster transmission technology yet: she says she is tired of the ''antiquated'' phone system in her county that allows her to surf the Net at a speed of only about 28 Kbps, even though she has a 56-Kbps modem. For now, though, sheis sticking with the simplest solution possible. **********So is Elizabeth Wise, a psychology student in Bronxville. Ms. Wise does a lot of Web surfing, and her husband, a financial analyst, often has to use one of the family's two phone lines to transmit lengthy reports to the computer at his office in Manhattan. **********Even though Ms. Wise's home was wired for I.S.D.N. technology in a recent renovation, she is sticking with analog phone lines for now because of cost and because she knows that newer transmission technologies, like cable and satellite, will be coming along. **********''I'm waiting to see how these other technologies are going to shake down,'' she said. ''I want what is simplest, as well as most economical, for the home user. And when I get it, I'll stick with it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/busin.snippet: Republic Security Financial Corp to acquire First Palm Beach Bancorp for $279.3 million in stock (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/busin.main_headline: REPUBLIC SECURITY TO BUY FIRST PALM BEACH
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; REPUBLIC SECURITY TO BUY FIRST PALM BEACH
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/busin.body_text: **********The Republic Security Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire a crosstown bank, First Palm Beach Bancorp, for $279.3 million in stock. Republic Security will issue 4.194 shares for each First Palm Beach shares, valued at $55.05 a share based on its closing price on Wednesday. Adding First Palm Beach, the parent of First Bank of Florida, will give Republic Security $2.8 billion in assets and 83 branches in five south Florida counties. Republic Security, the parent of Republic Security Bank, which is based in West Palm Beach, has $1 billion in assets and 32 branches. First Palm Beach, also in West Palm Beach, has $1.8 billion in assets and 51 branches. First Palm Beach's shares rose $7.75, or 21 percent, to $44.25, and Republic Security fell $1.625, to $12.625.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/12/techn.snippet: Dulcie Leimbach reviews Art Dabbler, children's art software from Metacreations; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/12/techn.print_headline: LIBRARY/CHILDREN'S ART SOFTWARE; Tutorials and Realistic Tools
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/12/techn.body_text: **********ART DABBLER **********(Metacreations; $49; Windows 95 and 98 and Macintosh 7.5 or later.) **********DABBLER is a well-stocked, serious art studio, with tools and graphics that simulate those you would find in a genuine studio. The Dabbler tools, which can create effects and styles ranging from pointillism to Impressionism, allow children to produce works that look authentic. **********For artists, this is challenging and satisfying; for nonartists, Dabbler is like taking an introductory course at a good art school. Children from age 4 to about 7 will probably need constant assistance; older children should be able to solo after a few tries with an adult. **********An abbreviated printed guide comes with the package; a longer tutorial, on the CD-ROM, requires Adobe Acrobat 3.01, which can be downloaded free on the Web. **********In Dabbler, the art tools and colors are in virtual drawers at the top of the screen; there is also a standard Windows menu. A white drawing pad appears, accompanied by rock music. (You can turn off the sound.) You can also experiment with background textures like cotton paper and fabric. **********You can then click on the color wheel, where a huge array of tints is presented. Tools are next: you can choose a pen or chalk (which ends up resembling pastels on paper) or ink, among many others. You can also determine how thick you want the tools' impressions to be. You are the artist, after all. **********Drawing with chalk against a dark background (this is the most useful background for seeing how tools behave) reveals a backdrop's texture. If you switch to the crayon tool, it makes a denser mark; if you change the texture, you can achieve a rubbing effect with the crayon. A water-drop effect turns the graphics into a watercolor, resulting in a beautiful, sophisticated artwork. (Not all the tools react with the paper texture.) Dabbler's canny ability to simulate a tactile experience and blend one tool with another becomes more evident the more you experiment. **********The ''flipbook'' animation feature allows children to make short cartoons and is very entertaining. Its tutorial is helpful, and verbal instructions serve as a patient, clear teacher, so you really can't feel lost. **********When you open Goo, a catalogue of human faces pops up. Goo was tried out on Halloween, putting the notion of a Frankenstein's monster close at hand.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/29/world.snippet: Stanford University colleagues say Hua Di, top Chinese missile scientist who has lived in United States since 1989, was arrested in Jan on his first trip home and awaits trial for allegedly revealing state secrets; he had been assured by Chinese s...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/29/world.main_headline: China Expert On Missiles Is Arrested On Return
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/29/world.print_headline: China Expert On Missiles Is Arrested On Return
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/29/world.body_text: **********A top Chinese missile scientist who has lived in the United States since 1989 is in prison here awaiting trial on a charge of revealing state secrets, say colleagues at Stanford University, where he was a research associate. **********The scientist, Hua Di, 62, was arrested in January during his first trip home in nine years. **********Earlier this decade, he was charged in absentia with divulging secrets in some of his writings in the United States on Chinese military issues. But in a meeting in Hong Kong last October, Chinese security officials assured him that if he visited China he would not face arrest, Mr. Hua told friends before he left for Beijing on Dec. 31. **********On Jan. 6 he was arrested, and in February he was charged with divulging state secrets. **********The American Embassy here said today that it had raised the issue with China on behalf of Mr. Hua, who is a permanent resident of the United States and is seeking citizenship but remains a Chinese citizen. **********Stanford officials have also argued on Mr. Hua's behalf in letters to President Jiang Zemin. Colleagues at the university's Center for International Security and Cooperation, where Mr. Hua worked, say they are deeply concerned about his health. Shortly before leaving for Beijing he had surgery for a rare form of male breast cancer, and he was to receive chemotherapy on his return to California last winter. **********The Chinese Government has not commented publicly on the case. Until recently not even relatives were allowed to see him, and family members who have since had contact are not speaking to the press. He has a lawyer, who has also declined to speak to the press. Some people familiar with the case expect it to go to trial in the coming weeks. **********Officials at Stanford pressed his case quietly in hopes that he would be released. But this week, newspapers in Hong Kong and Taiwan reported on his arrest. **********A child of China's Communist elite, Mr. Hua was educated in Moscow, spent decades as a leading military scientist and in 1978 was given a national prize for his contributions to China's ballistic missile and satellite programs. **********To an unusual degree, Mr. Hua was allowed to maintain contacts with experts abroad, and in 1980 and 1981 he spent more than a year in the United States at the University of Washington and then at Stanford. **********In 1986, senior Chinese officials authorized Mr. Hua to provide advice to an American researcher on Chinese defense, John W. Lewis, who was writing books on China's nuclear and missile programs, Mr. Lewis said in an interview today. **********Mr. Lewis is the former director of the Center for International Security and Cooperation and has worked closely with Mr. Hua for the last nine years. The center has often served as an unofficial conduit for sharing information between the Chinese and American militaries. **********In this shadowy world of trading in not always reliable defense information, Mr. Hua became a player, often saying he had special contacts and information on Chinese programs, American defense experts said. **********In June 1989, during China's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square, Mr. Hua was at a conference in the Soviet Union. He decided not to return to China -- he later said he had played a role in the democracy movement and feared arrest -- and moved to California when offered a position at the Stanford research center. **********In the early 1990's at Stanford, Mr. Hua wrote or was co-author of articles on the development of China's missiles and other sensitive topics. He collaborated with Mr. Lewis, for example, on an unusually detailed account of China's submarine nuclear missile program, said to be one of the items now held against him. **********Mr. Lewis said today that Mr. Hua had never provided vital information that was not already in the public domain or that he had not been previously authorized to share. **********At two international conferences in 1993, Mr. Hua had friendly meetings with top officials from China's military industries, Mr. Lewis said. ''There was no sense that he'd done anything wrong,'' he said. **********For personal reasons, Mr. Hua wanted to return home, and late last year he sought the October meeting in Hong Kong with Chinese officials to see what his prospects were. He returned to Stanford confident that he would have no problem, say friends who spoke with him before his departure for Beijing. **********Mr. Hua's arrest comes at a time when the Chinese military establishment is in some turmoil, with President Jiang forcing out formerly powerful officers and attacking high-level corruption and outside business activities. It could be, speculated one American defense expert who spoke on condition of anonymity, that Mr. Hua's former contacts or protectors in the military or defense industry here have lost power.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/09/world.snippet: Illegal workers from Indonesia were welcomed by Malaysia when its economy was booming, but now they are being rounded up, locked in detention camps and sent back home on daily shiploads; even as they are sent back across Strait of Malacca, many mo...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/09/world.main_headline: As Boom Fails, Malaysia Sends Migrants Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/09/world.print_headline: As Boom Fails, Malaysia Sends Migrants Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/09/world.body_text: **********They leave as empty-handed as they came, their heads shaved like those of prisoners, bowing and smiling deferentially as police officers in cherry-red helmets herd them into the holds of cargo ships. **********Victims of Malaysia's ''Operation Get Out,'' they are illegal workers from Indonesia who were welcomed here when the economy was booming but are now being rounded up, locked in detention camps, and sent back home on daily shiploads. **********''If we must grow calluses on our hearts, so be it,'' said an editorial in The Straits Times of Singapore, where the Government is using floggings and jail terms to deter migrants. **********But even as they are sent back across the Strait of Malacca, many more migrants are coming, driven by the growing poverty and joblessness of neighboring Indonesia. Officials say as many as 300 or more people are landing every day in Malaysia alone. **********This is Asia's new fear: a tide of desperate economic refugees who could begin to swamp the shores of their neighbors in what some are already calling a new wave of boat people. **********As much as the empty office buildings and shuttered factories of Southeast Asia's shrinking ''tiger'' economies, these crisscrossing streams of jobless workers are a new emblem of the region's hardships. **********''It is potentially explosive,'' said Razak Baginda, a Malaysian political scientist, ''and in terms of magnitude it could be worse than Vietnam, both because of the numbers and the proximity of the nations.'' **********It was only in 1996 that Malaysia and other Southeast Asian countries finally sent home the last stragglers from among the Vietnamese boat people, more than 20 years after the end of the Vietnam War. **********Now the worry is Indonesia, just a few miles across the water, where experts predict that 8 million to 10 million people could be unemployed this year, out of a population of 200 million and a work force of 90 million. **********Hundreds of thousands -- or even millions -- of returnees from other countries will only add to Indonesia's hardships. **********The potential for violent disorders in Malaysia was clear two weeks ago when some illegal migrants rioted at a detention camp near Kuala Lumpur, the capital. Eight detainees and a police officer were killed, and scores were wounded. **********The first fears of an influx were expressed in Australia early this year. Indonesians angered by rising prices were turning against the ethnic Chinese minority that controls much of Indonesia's commerce. An outbreak of anti-Chinese riots raised memories of mass killings in 1965, when the Chinese were one of the targets. Many wealthy Chinese in Indonesia have already moved their families to Australia, Singapore or elsewhere. **********But for the present, officials here say, ethnic Chinese make up few of the new migrants. Instead, they come from the same poor class of Indonesians who for years have been welcomed as cheap labor. **********For more than a decade, migrant labor formed one of the engines of Asia's economic boom. Malaysia in particular, with a population of just 21 million, has relied on foreign workers in the last decade as it binged on huge construction projects. **********Foreign laborers now make up as much as a fifth of Malaysia's work force, including an estimated 1.2 million Indonesians, 800,000 of whom are here illegally. Some 25,000 Indonesians did most of the work in building a just-completed international airport. They are now being sent home. **********Ubiquitous in Kuala Lumpur but little noticed, small Indonesian ''villages'' are evidence of this large population of workers, with their lively Indonesian music, their rows of bird cages and the sweet smell of clove cigarettes. **********''There is no more work here, and we are ready to go home,'' said Mion Rakit, 27, who has worked here for 10 years but now spends his days playing cards with his friends. ''But times are tough at home, too.'' **********The situation is similar in Thailand, which is home to about a million illegal workers, most of them from neighboring Myanmar, the former Burma. With unemployment in Thailand forecast nearly to double, to more than two million, the Thais say they will expel some 300,000 foreign workers this year. **********''We don't have enough jobs for our own people,'' said Foreign Minister Surin Pitsuwan. ''How can we be expected to care for foreigners?'' **********Singapore is a smaller country with equally large fears of inundation by migrants. Its population is only three million, and its shores are only a two-hour boat ride from Indonesia. **********''We are literally a nation besieged,'' said the prosecutor in a trial last month at which 117 illegal migrants were sentenced to up to six weeks in jail and four to six strokes of the cane. **********That is the sentiment in Malaysia as well, where Foreign Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi said: ''It is dangerous to have too many people unemployed. It can cause instability in Malaysia socially and even politically. We have to take care of our own people first; charity must begin at home.'' **********In addition to chasing down illegal migrants, Malaysia has announced that it will not renew the work permits of as many as 850,000 legal foreign workers when they expire in August. **********This raises the prospect of expulsions on a daunting scale. ''If we want to send back even half the illegal workers, how are we going to transport 400,000 people?'' said Mr. Baginda, the political scientist. **********At the same time, Malaysia has mounted an aggressive defense against new arrivals, including a small flotilla of naval vessels, a new radar system and posses of villagers who patrol their shores like wartime vigilantes. **********In the last three weeks of February alone, the police reported that 332 boats had brought 3,971 illegal migrants -- three-fourths of the total number of landings in all of 1997, when 444 boats brought 5,432 people. **********''I have every sympathy for Indonesians looking for work,'' said Rahim Noor, a political commentator. ''I'm extremely sympathetic. But to be swamped by them would be to have a breakdown of the infrastructure. It's bad for us too. Our economy is getting worse too.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/28/world.snippet: Brazilian Congress defers vote on bill to give nine-year old environmental agency power to enforce environmental protection laws; environmentalist charge bill has become too diluted in political bargaining (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/28/world.main_headline: World News Briefs; Brazil Delays Vote On Environmental Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/28/world.print_headline: World News Briefs; Brazil Delays Vote On Environmental Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/28/world.body_text: **********The Congress put off voting today on a bill that would have given Brazil's environmental agency power to enforce environmental protection laws nine years after the agency came into being. **********The bill, which has languished in the Congress for seven years, was originally hailed by ecologists as a model for the 21st century. But today they sought to have the vote postponed after the bill was substantially weakened in recent days, under pressure from industrial and agricultural business interests. **********Joao Paulo Capobianco, secretary general of the Socio-Environmental Institute, a nonprofit group based in Sao Paulo, said the bill had become diluted in political bargaining. ''It's not even worth passing the law in this form,'' he said. **********The recent changes would remove some of the law's tougher provisions, including those barring polluters from receiving Government loans, and allowing the Government to hold industrial polluters personally liable for the damage they cause.
