https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/09/busin.print_headline: 2 Internet Access Services Discuss Joining Forces
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/09/busin.body_text: **********The At Home Corporation is in talks with Road Runner, a unit of Time Warner Inc., about combining their high-speed Internet access services to strengthen their competition with local phone companies in the race to link millions of homes to the Internet. **********''We've been talking to them for a while,'' an At Home spokesman, Matt Wolfrom, said Friday. But, he added, ''no deal is imminent.'' **********At Home's talks with Road Runner, first reported in Broadcasting and Cable magazine, come as cable television operators rush to improve their existing lines and roll out digital set-top boxes to offer home Internet service. **********The cable companies must compete with phone companies, like the regional Bells, which also are working to deliver faster on-line access to consumers. **********At Home's majority shareholder is Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator. Road Runner provides Internet access over Time Warner's cable lines. **********Time Warner declined to comment on the talks. **********Industry analysts estimate that the market for Internet access in homes could reach $10 billion a year. **********Last month, Compaq Computer,  Intel, Microsoft and the nation's six largest local phone companies teamed to establish standards for digital subscriber lines to send information at higher speeds over existing phone lines. **********Digital lines give computer users faster data services like Internet access and faxing, while leaving the lines open for regular phone calls. The Compaq-led group wants to offer  the service by year's end. **********At Home provides Internet access over cable lines in Baltimore, Chicago and elsewhere. **********The company said that it expected to spend up to $40 million a year in the next several years to bring its service to new cities in the United States and abroad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/26/busin.body_text: **********Microsoft's Trial Thesis: Big, Yes, but Not a Bully **********The Microsoft Corporation's defense in the antitrust trial that began last week boils down to one question: Where's the harm? **********John Warden, Microsoft's lead lawyer, posed the question in hundreds of ways as he cross-examined the Government's lead witness, James Barksdale, the president and chief executive of Netscape Communications. Mr. Warden sought to establish that while Microsoft is assuredly aggressive and powerful, there is scant evidence that its behavior raises prices or restricts output so that consumers suffer. News Analysis. [Page C4.] **********Some low-technology highlights have emerged in a high-technology trial. [C4.] **********A consortium including Microsoft, Compaq and Intel has won preliminary approval of its technical standard for the high-speed transmission of Internet data over phone lines. [C4.] **********Politics Is Out, Astrology Is In **********Bonnie Fuller, the editor of Conde Nast's Glamour, has decided to cancel the magazine's column about women in politics, one of the hallmarks of the longtime editor Ruth Whitney, whom Ms. Fuller replaced in September. And Ms. Fuller -- who attracted readers by injecting an energetic sexuality into the pages of Cosmopolitan -- has also decided to add an astrology column, which will make its debut in the January issue. [C7.] **********Talent Agency Shifts Executives **********In a step in the evolution of one of the largest and more unusual talent agencies in Hollywood, International Creative Management has announced a shift in its executive ranks with the naming of two co-presidents and a more forward-looking strategy after a decade of focusing on reducing debt. [C2.] **********G.M. Executive Resigns in Europe **********One of General Motors' top European executives has resigned because of disagreements over how the car maker is being run. [C2.] **********Latest Turn in a Radio Mystery **********When Art Bell, a late-night radio talk show host, signed off on Oct. 13 by saying that a life-threatening event meant it was his last broadcast, it set off a two-week whirl of conspiracy theories and countertheories. Mr. Bell has said he will return to the air on Wednesday but has declined to elaborate on the crisis. [C8.] **********Going Off Line for Publicity **********The Mining Company, an Internet search service that offers personal guides to Web sites, and other high-technology companies have recently undertaken national advertising blitzes -- broadcast, cable TV, outdoor and print -- intended to make their brands household names. The measures include the Mining Company's giant mural on a building in Manhattan. Prospectus. [C4.] **********Anxiety Builds in Magazine World **********Most of the 800 publishers, editors, subscription agents and advertising directors who gathered at the Magazine Publishers of America conference expressed trepidation about the potential for sluggish advertising sales in 1999 and other economic concerns. [C7.] **********A Renewed Call for Diversity **********The governing board of the American Society of Newspaper Editors agreed last week that ''the nation's newsrooms must reflect the racial diversity of American society by 2025 or sooner.'' In addition, the board agreed to include women in its annual newsroom census to monitor any ''glass ceiling.'' [C8.]

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/18/busin.snippet: Bell Sports Corp reports great public and investor interest in its new skiing and snowboarding helmets, following deaths of Michael Kennedy and Sonny Bono in skiiing accidents; graph showing gains for company stock; bicycle helmets are still expec...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/18/busin.main_headline: Good News From Bad for Ski Helmets
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/18/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT; Good News From Bad for Ski Helmets
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/18/busin.body_text: **********SHORTLY after Sonny Bono became the second celebrity in a week to die in a skiing accident, the phones at the Bell Sports Corporation began ringing off the hook. Bell, best known as a manufacturer of bicycle helmets, had introduced its first skiing and snowboarding helmets just a few weeks before Michael L. Kennedy, and then Mr. Bono, suffered fatal head injuries on the slopes. **********''We've received more phone calls since those accidents than at any other time I can recall,'' said Terry G. Lee, Bell's chief executive. **********Investors seem interested, too. Shares in Bell, the only publicly traded maker of ski helmets, jumped from $8.44 on Dec. 31 to a close of $10.0625 on Jan. 7 before settling back to $9.4375 on Friday. And there are signs that this attention is more than a blip. Mr. Lee says demand for this protective headgear started rising even before the recent deaths. **********''Last year we saw helmets used in ski schools for the first time,'' he said. ''The market is pretty small, but it's been growing.'' About 80,000 ski helmets were sold last year, a 22 percent increase over 1996. **********Bell's entry into this arena -- it began making plans in late 1996 -- is a small element of a large turnaround effort. The company, which makes bicycle and auto-racing helmets and accessories under the Bell, Giro, Rhode Gear and other brand names, grew fast in the early 1990's as bicycle-helmet laws spurred demand. But in 1995 the rush of new laws slowed and Bell, saddled with some recent acquisitions, saw its earnings and stock price fall. **********So last year Bell, a 45-year-old company based in San Jose, Calif., spun off several underperforming divisions and cut costs. The effect was immediate. Excluding one-time charges related to the spinoffs, Bell earned 37 cents a share in the 12 months ended last June, up from 1 cent a share in the previous 12 months. In the quarter ended in September, it earned 5 cents a share, up from the break-even point in the quarter a year earlier. **********Investors noticed the improvements, and the stock went from around $6 a share to a 52-week closing high of $10.875 last fall. But whether the stock is a good value is unclear; analysts have not yet adjusted the stock's price-earnings ratio for the recent spinoffs. **********''The company has been through some tough times, but it has a very good balance sheet and a wonderful brand name,'' said Lee H. Allen, a stock analyst with Allen Financial Advisors in Boston. **********This year, bicycle helmets are expected to furnish most of the revenue growth for Bell, which had sales of $215 million for the year ended last June, excluding those of the spun-off divisions. Mr. Lee says there are still pockets of high demand for the bike helmets, especially in overseas markets, which now account for only 25 percent of Bell's sales. Longer term, analysts say, much will hinge on Bell's ability to keep leveraging its strong brand names. **********Those names may play a central role in the ski-helmet market, where Bell must compete with Boeri and Briko, the two European brands that are the market's biggest. **********As for demand for the helmets, Mr. Lee is hopeful. ''We're getting a tremendous amount of inquiries from sports-equipment dealers, and we've even had consumers walking into our headquarters off the street,'' he said. **********Indeed, because fewer than 10 percent of skiers are wearing helmets, there is plenty of room for growth. And at least one state legislator, Representative Robert Bacon of Colorado, is considering whether to include skiing in a pending bill that would mandate helmets for in-line skating and bicycling for children. **********On the other hand, some people question the effectiveness of ski helmets. With respect to the two celebrities, for instance, ''It's just not clear that either would have survived if they were wearing helmets,'' said Dr. John C. Nelson, a spokesman for the American Medical Association. **********Moreover, the A.M.A. estimates that from 1981 to 1997, only 2.6 percent of skiing accidents resulted in head injuries, and fewer than 1 percent of those were fatal. Generally, skiing is safer than sports like bicycling and swimming, according to the National Safety Council. **********''The average recreational skier probably doesn't need a helmet,'' Dr. Nelson said, ''as long as he knows the terrain and he uses common sense.'' **********All told, and without more evidence of rising demand, potential Bell investors should not hang their hopes solely on the ski-helmet market. ''I think the strength of the Bell and Giro names will give the company a leg up, and that ski helmets will be a possible incremental source of profit growth,'' said Stephen Schoene, a bond analyst at Miller Tabak Hirsch & Company in New York. ''But the potential for this company in the bike-helmet market is probably much greater.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/05/busin.body_text: **********Recycling Industries, a metals recycling company with about $360 million in annual revenue, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Jefferson Iron and Metal Brokerage Inc. for an undisclosed price. Jefferson, based in Birmingham, Ala., has annual revenue of $170 million. The deal will allow Recycling Industries, based in Englewood, Colo., to market its products through Jefferson, which sells more than 1.5 million tons of recycled materials a year to customers including steel mini-mills and foundries. Recycling Industries produced about two million tons of ferrous materials last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/19/busin.body_text: **********Economy Remains Strong, Fed Says in 'Beige Book' **********The economy in all regions of the United States remains strong, despite a decline in export sales to Asia -- yet inflation seems ''eerily calm,'' the Federal Reserve said in its ''beige book'' survey of regional economic conditions. **********''Industrial activity is on the rise in most parts of the country,'' it said, and demand for labor is strong. Retail sales are strong, the Fed added, but auto sales are down. [Page D4.] **********Stock Market Topples Records **********All major stock market indexes reached new highs, with the Dow industrials climbing 25.41 points, to 8,775.40. [D8.] **********Joblessness Strains French System **********Although the French economy is expected to grow a healthy 3 percent this year, unemployment continues to strain the country's vaunted welfare system. [A1.] **********Japanese Household Savings Fall **********Japan's average household savings fell 1.3 percent, to an average of $125,769 in 1997. The drop, the first in four years, signaled that the nation's slump had spread to one of the pillars of the economy. [D5.] **********Optimistic Signs in Thailand **********Investment has begun flowing into Thai companies for the first time since the financial system started to crumble eight months ago, raising hopes that foreign investors are starting to acquire assets made cheap by severe currency and market losses. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/27/busin.snippet: Toy industry joins computer age, making big push into Internet retailing; hope is that stores-without-walls will attract parents with modems, people too busy or too impatient to deal with big chain stores' huge, warehouse-like retail outlets; on-l...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/27/busin.main_headline: Shopping for Toys Without the Kids; Virtual Stores Give the Big Retailers A Foothold Against On-Line Upstarts
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/27/busin.print_headline: Shopping for Toys Without the Kids; Virtual Stores Give the Big Retailers A Foothold Against On-Line Upstarts
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/27/busin.body_text: **********First virtual toys, now virtual toy stores. **********With toy makers and sellers catching up with the computer age and making a big push into Internet retailing, shoppers can now buy everything on line -- from Tamagotchi virtual pets to Teletubbies plush dolls. The hope is that these stores-without-walls will attract parents with modems and motivation, people either too busy or too impatient to deal with the big chain stores' huge, warehouse-like retail outlets. **********So, well ahead of the 1998 critical year-end selling season, toy companies are racing to become the Amazon.com of their industry. Some of the on-line players include Noodle Kidoodle Inc., Toys ''R'' Us and the leading upstart company, Etoys, a unit of Idealab. Some manufacturers, including Mattel Inc., which has a Barbie Web site, www.barbie.com, are also experimenting with on-line marketing. **********Having had one of its best years in a decade last year, thanks to a healthy economy, and hoping for a repeat performance this year, the toy industry is in an expansive, experimental mood. Though on-line retailing still accounts for only $13 million of the $22 billion annual United States toy market, the virtual toy shop is the industry's attempt to find new or additional sales among the households that are most likely to value time-saving efficiency and to have the discretionary income to pay a premium for such convenience. Nearly 20 million Americans now shop on line, according to the Web measurement company Media Metrix Inc. **********But the industry's move on line is not without risk. The big retailers face the same sort of internal conflicts that the bookseller Barnes & Noble does in trying to counter Amazon.com -- how to respond to the on-line upstarts without cannibalizing the brick-and-mortar franchise. **********Toy makers must venture carefully into cyberspace, lest their direct-sales activities rankle the retailers they rely upon to move their merchandise. **********For their part, the on-line upstarts, despite the cost advantages of not having to invest in stores, warehouses and big inventories, may find themselves struggling to match the marketing muscle of big established retail brand names. **********Then there is the question of whether the touch and the texture of toy shopping can translate as readily to the digital realm as some other consumer activities that have taken hold on line, like booking airline seats or trading shares of stock. **********''One of the big strengths of toy retailing is the in-store excitement, merchandising and the personal touch,'' said Frank Reysen Jr., editor of Playthings, a toy industry publication. ''There is a danger of that getting lost in the web of technology. The initiatives, attitude and approach have to be a virtual representation of the store itself, and that's not an easy thing to do.'' **********The toy merchants are undaunted, though. **********The large retailers say they will win the Internet game because their well-regarded names and vast resources give them an in with consumers that should spill over into on-line selling. For customers, the companies say, those strengths will translate into low prices, quick response to orders and a better chance of finding limited-edition items -- like Mattel's popular Share a Smile Becky doll, a wheelchair-bound friend of Barbie -- that smaller toy sellers may have trouble obtaining in large volume. **********But the small, niche operators say they have the upper hand because they offer many of the must-have items and also specialty products -- like Schylling's make-your-own chewing gum kit -- that tend to sell in such small numbers that the big guys find them not worth stocking. **********And whether large or small, the companies say they can offer on-line consumers the advantage of not having to traipse around in search of the last Beanie Baby in town. **********Longer term, toy merchants envision that this type of retailing will become the modern equivalent of that more traditional form of direct-to-consumer marketing -- catalogue shopping. Like catalogue sales, which rely on mailing lists assembled from consumers' past buy-by-mail habits, the data bases created by electronic commerce would enable toy makers to observe the shopping habits of computerized households and use discounts and other enticements to keep them coming back for more. It is a way for merchants to get to know their customers' preferences to an extent not possible when a person goes into a store and pays cash for a Sing and Snore Ernie. **********All of the industry's behind-the-scenes strategizing for her money and loyalty is just fine by Chana Wilson, a housewife and mother of two boys, ages 3 and 12, who was in the market recently for an ant farm for her out-of-state nephew. ''I knew I had to buy a toy, wrap it up and ship it to Houston,'' said Mrs. Wilson, who lives in Beckley, W.Va., and ranks shopping at toy stores right up there with visiting the dentist. **********Trying to avoid ''all that rigamarole,'' Mrs. Wilson, whose husband, Derric, is a supervisor at a prison, went on line and found Etoys, where she bought an Uncle Milton ant farm for $19.95 plus $4 for shipping and $3 for gift wrapping. **********''That saved me time and money and a major headache with my 3-year-old,'' Mrs. Wilson said. ''You just don't want to take a 3-year-old shopping for other kids' toys.'' **********It is just this sort of shopper that the big conventional retailers are going after. Toys ''R'' Us, the nation's largest toy retailer, started a Web site last month that it intends to heavily advertise on the Internet as well as on television and through home delivery circulars later this year. So far, the site has about 2,000 items, compared with about 15,000 stocked in Toys ''R'' Us stores. Tens of thousands of Internet users have already visited the site, though the company declined to say how many had bought anything. **********Visitors to www.toysrus.com, are assured that shopping is ''fun and fast.'' Say, for instance, someone is clueless as to what to buy an 8-year-old girl. The shopper need only choose a category, like dolls, click on the child's age and the target price. Seconds later a suggested list of merchandise appears, including Baby Pick Me Up, which sells for $14.97 plus shipping and handling. **********Just like a theater operator who tries to drum up concession sales by piping in the smell of freshly popped corn, Toys ''R'' Us is using its personalized suggestion feature also to get shoppers to consider buying items they may not have intended to. Those looking for dolls, for instance, are also shown a Barbie Disc Girl CD Player for $16.99. Call it an electronic hard sell. **********Prices are typically the same for toys bought on line or in stores. But the convenience of Internet shopping does mean having to pay shipping rates, which are about $5 for a $25 order and around $9 for a $100 purchase. The companies insist, though, that the cost is more than worth the convenience. **********''People are more strapped for time, and they are looking for new ways of shopping,'' said Joel Anderson, vice president of Toys ''R'' Us Direct. ''There is a new medium out there that is emerging, and it is an area we need to be in.'' **********The toy maker Hasbro Inc. is feeling the same need. The company, which has been dabbling in on-line product marketing for more than a year, recently hired a specialist in Internet commerce to develop a plan to advertise further and sell selected items like collectibles directly to the consumer (www.hasbro.com). The executive, Wendy Riches, had managed the interactive advertising unit of WPP Group's Ogilvy & Mather agency, as part of her role as chairman and chief executive of the Ogilvy One North America division. **********One potential problem is that Hasbro sells mainly to retailers, some of whom may frown on any form of added competition. This sort of conflict has also been a problem for computer makers, like Compaq, which has a well-established network of distributors who have been wary of the company's plan to expand into on-line direct sales. **********Already, some toy retailers are raising concern about Hasbro's intentions. ''This is the manufacturer cutting out the middle man,'' said Shane Igoe, new media manager at F.A.O. Schwarz, which was one of the first toy sellers to go on line when it started www.faoschwarz.com nearly two years ago. **********Toys ''R'' Us is less concerned, saying Hasbro's Internet appeal will be limited because it will offer only its own brands and not Barbie, Beanie Babies and other popular toys made by its competitors. For its part, Hasbro says its on-line selling efforts are not meant to put it in competition with Toys ''R'' Us or any other retailer. Rather, the company says, it is seeking to augment what retailers are already doing, even listing store locations where shoppers can find certain items. **********''We look at this as a partnership with the retail trade,'' said Adam Klein, Hasbro's head of global marketing. ''Each one of our key retailers is going at this thing a different way. We have to have our own in-house expertise to both work with them and, where there are gaps, to be able to recognize them and go after these opportunities.'' **********Hasbro also says that, at least initially, it will limit its toy selling to items not available in retail stores. The company, which has not determined when it will begin selling on line beyond the interactive products like the Yahtzee CD-ROM it already offers, was fuzzy on whether consumers would have to pay retail prices for toys bought directly from the manufacturer. Mr. Klein said only that ''the idea is not to compete with the retail trade, and this is part of everything we are going to be looking at.'' **********With Hasbro and other industry giants edging in on its domain, Etoys, a year-old company based in Santa Monica, Calif., that has about 3,000 items listed for sale on its site, www.toys.com, may need a Star Wars laser to fend them off. But the company says its strength is in the range of playthings it provides. **********''What we do is have the popular products and also have a lot of cool products like kits to make your own chewing gum, products you never see in Toys 'R' Us,'' said Toby Lenk, chief executive of Etoys. ''A big retail buyer can't buy six of something. It's too inefficient for them so they buy in bulk and can't test on a smaller scale.'' **********Etoys also knows it will have to rev up its marketing machine to avoid getting overshadowed by the competition. Without discussing precise amounts, the company said it planned to triple its multimillion-dollar marketing budget for the next six months. **********If people like Mrs. Wilson, the mother in West Virginia, are any indication, the on-line toy market is up for grabs to anyone who can make toy shopping effortless without significantly adding cost. But won't she miss an intrinsic part of the toy-buying experience by buying a lovable baby doll without first giving it a squeeze or without reading product information on a box of building blocks? **********''Heavens, no,'' Mrs. Wilson said. ''I could care less. I already know what a box of Legos looks like. I wish I'd found this before last Christmas.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/08/busin.snippet: Article on recent entrance of mutual fund companies into hedge-fund business; drawing; graph (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/08/busin.main_headline: Should You Bristle at These Hedges?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/08/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; Should You Bristle at These Hedges?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/08/busin.body_text: **********IT'S not the sort of thing they are likely to trumpet in newspaper ads or in 30-second television spots, but increasingly, mutual fund companies are muscling into the hedge-fund business. **********''Over the last few years, we have seen mutual fund companies launch an increasing number of hedge funds or hedge funds of funds,'' said Lois Peltz, managing editor of Managed Account Reports, a hedge fund newsletter. **********Indeed, hedge funds are now being run by well-known mutual fund companies like Franklin Templeton, Gabelli and Strong Capital Management, as well as Wellington Management, which runs several of the Vanguard Group's mutual funds. **********Hedge funds, investment vehicles for wealthy individuals and institutions, have the flexibility to sell securities short, betting that they will decline, or to borrow money, in order to magnify returns; they can also use a variety of other tactics not widely available to most mutual funds. Many hedge funds are based offshore and are not available to American investors. **********Should mutual fund investors worry if their fund companies introduce hedge funds? There are some sticky issues. **********A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J., said mutual fund directors and investors should keep a close eye on a mutual fund's performance if the manager is also running a hedge fund. The issue is whether the manager will do as good a job with the mutual fund when he can make more money from the hedge fund; if the mutual fund's performance declines, he added, ''the directors should refocus the manager back on the mutual fund.'' **********There are other issues, too. Independent hedge funds can sell their holdings in a stock all at once, but if a hedge fund is part of a mutual fund company, it generally must sell pari passu -- at an equal pace -- with the company's mutual funds that hold the same stock, constraining flexibility. **********And what if a company's hedge and mutual funds invest in the same stocks and those stocks drop? Mutual fund investors, who can withdraw money at any time, are likely to yank their cash first. So, as the mutual fund jettisons a stock to meet redemptions, the value of the stock may drop further, damaging the hedge fund's holdings. **********Hedge-fund investors, meanwhile, are generally locked in for at least six months.  According to one investor in the Robertson Stephens Orphans Hedge fund, which holds illiquid stocks, its value has fallen over the last 18 months as investors in the Robertson Stephens Contrarian mutual fund, which holds similar stocks, have been bailing. A spokeswoman for the funds was unavailable for comment. **********Despite these complexities, and the headline-grabbing troubles of Long Term Capital Management and other hedge funds, mutual fund companies are likely to keep introducing hedge funds as they seek to increase fee income and economies of scale, and try to hold onto sought-after managers. **********Rolling out hedge funds lets fund companies employ their core strengths without much extra overhead. Fund managers on staff are usually all too happy to run a hedge fund on the side, as the pay, often based on the total fees, can be lucrative. ''The reason they're doing this is to keep their best managers in house,'' Ms. Peltz said. **********Typically, hedge funds get 1 percent of assets as well as 20 percent of gains above their previous highs. By contrast, the median fee on general equity mutual funds is 1.3 percent of assets, according to Lipper. **********Just last August, State Street Research rolled out a hedge fund, Small Cap Energy, whose managers, Dan Rice and Tom Moore, also run the State Street Research Global Resources mutual fund. So far, the hedge fund has under $11.5 million in assets, compared with $164 million in the mutual fund. **********The prime difference, according to Robin Tice, a State Street spokeswoman, is the mutual fund's broader portfolio, which is wont to include gold and other kinds of companies. ''We started it because we have expertise in managing energy and natural resources investments,'' she said. **********If hedge funds are picking many of the same stocks held by mutual funds, why pay the higher fees? One hedge-fund expert said that if an investor believes in a manager, that investor may be willing to take the hedge fund's additional risks of greater leverage, or portfolio concentration, to get higher returns. And hedge funds can invest in often-lucrative private partnerships. **********Alliance Capital is the biggest mutual fund newcomer in the hedge-fund business. Since 1994, it has rolled out 13 hedge funds, six domestic and seven offshore. **********Alliance executives are reluctant to talk about them. ''Hedge funds are basically partnerships, and the S.E.C. does not permit funds to advertise,'' said Charles Schaffran, who oversees Alliance's hedge funds. Newspaper interviews, he said, ''might be viewed as advertising.'' **********SOME mutual fund companies say the experience of running hedge funds can yield good investment ideas that are cross-fertilized with their mutual funds. **********Mario Gabelli, whose Gabelli & Company manages 27 mutual funds, has run risk-arbitrage hedge funds since 1985 and now runs a number of other hedge funds. ''To the degree that our analyst Laura Lanahan makes a comment about the Pulitzer merger with Hearst-Argyle, the arbitrageurs would hitch on,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/06/busin.body_text: **********Q. I'm a part-time contractor at a high-technology company. Recently, my supervisor asked if I would be interested in a full-time job, at less pay per hour but with stock options and other benefits. The truth is that I'm not interested -- I like the freedom and my current pay -- but I worry that if I reject his offer, he'll replace me with someone committed to the long haul. Any negotiating suggestions? **********A. Freedom or security: It's a stark choice -- and one that your employer may not realize is a tough call for you. Because the company wants you full time, it clearly likes your work. Nevertheless, before deciding on a bargaining approach, talk with your boss about exactly why he made the offer. **********''It may be that the company is looking to cut expenses or reduce its number of consultants,'' said Bob Deissig, president of recruiting services for the Ayers Group, a human resources consulting firm in New York. If so, you should seek ways to maximize your value -- like increasing your work load but not your fee -- that would make the company more willing to keep you on your terms. **********Alternatively, your boss may simply be dazzled by your technical prowess and is afraid of losing you. Employers are often much more worried about your taking off than you are about being replaced -- particularly in this tight job market, said Robin Ryan, a Seattle-based career counselor and author of ''Winning Resumes'' (John Wiley & Sons, 1997). **********In either case, the operative word is tact. By turning down a full-time gig, you are saying, in essence: ''I really like you guys, but not enough to commit.'' Think about how that line played in your last personal relationship. Employers tend to take rejection about as well as insecure girlfriends or boyfriends, so when breaking the news to your supervisor, let him down easy. **********Blame it on the money, Ms. Ryan advised: ''Go to your employer and say, 'I just can't take a salary cut at this time.' '' This puts your rejection in practical, hard-dollar terms that most business types can grasp. After all, stock options are a nice perk, but they can't pay the rent, and they often have no value until you have been with a company for 3, 5 or 10 years. **********But no matter how practical your reasons, you need to make your rejection as flattering as possible, Mr. Deissig said. ''Tell your supervisor how honored you are by the offer,'' he said, ''and stress how terrific you think the organization is.'' Emphasize that you have no intention of abandoning the firm. ''Assure them that the offer makes you even more committed to the organization,'' he added, ''and ask what you can do to make everyone more comfortable with your consultant status.'' **********If you do plan to stay, Mr. Deissig said, consider negotiating a long-term contract. **********Of course, if your employer is desperate to hire you, he may counter with a second offer at your current pay -- or higher. At that point, you'll have to re-evaluate just how much you want to stay footloose and freelance. **********Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she will respond to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/29/busin.snippet: Peter Orszag letter disputes November 1 article on Social Security reforms (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/29/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********''Save Social Security? From What? (Seniority, Nov. 1) perpetuated several myths about Social Security reform. **********First, though high rates of economic growth would partially address the Social Security problem, achieving them would be more difficult  than the column suggested. The column implied that future economic growth of 1.75 percent a year -- half the historical average -- is eminently achievable. But employment growth is expected to slow markedly in the future, since we are unlikely to repeat events like the baby boom and the dramatic entry of women into the work force. **********Second, even if such growth were achievable, it would not insure that the Social Security system would be just fine. Instead, it would reduce the system's long-term actuarial gap by only one-quarter, leaving a large imbalance. **********Finally, despite the article's implications, reform will be less painful if we address it now rather than later. Starting earlier will let us spread the adjustment over many generations, rather than forcing one to bear a disproportionate burden. No one's crystal ball is perfect, but your column seemed unduly rosy on this issue. **********PETER ORSZAG **********Belmont, Calif., Nov. 1 **********The author is president of Sebago Associates, a public policy consulting firm.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/01/busin.body_text: **********Credit Suisse Group said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the reinsurance business of its Winterthur Insurance Company unit to the Bermuda-based Partnerre Ltd. for 1.125 billion Swiss francs ($750 million).  Credit Suisse said that the sale was another step in the strategy of having Winterthur concentrate on its core insurance business, and that proceeds from the deal would be reinvested in Winterthur's primary insurance operations in Western and Eastern Europe and in Asia. **********Winterthur Re generated 1.26 billion francs ($840 billion) in premium income in 1997, or about 4.7 percent of Winterthur's total premium income of 26.8 billion francs. Edward Taber, head of the brokerage's asset management unit, said the firm, which he declined to name, had ''well over'' $1 billion in assets under management. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/20/busin.snippet: Commerce Dept reports nation's trade deficit expanded to $12 billion in January from $10.9 billion in December, as financial crises in Asia depress demand for American goods in that part of world; deficit in goods alone rose to $18.8 billion, high...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/20/busin.main_headline: January Trade Deficit Soared, as the Asia Crisis Hit Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/20/busin.print_headline: January Trade Deficit Soared, as the Asia Crisis Hit Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/20/busin.body_text: **********The nation's trade deficit surged in January to its highest level in a decade as the financial crises in Asia depressed demand for American goods in that part of the world, the Commerce Department reported today. **********It said the deficit in the trade of goods and services expanded to $12 billion in January from $10.9 billion in December. This was the widest gap since the department began using its current monthly measurement system in 1992 and was last exceeded late in 1987 under a system that measured trade on a quarterly basis. **********The deficit in goods alone rose to $18.8 billion, the highest level on record, from $17.7 billion in December. **********Economists have predicted for months that Asia's woes would begin slowing the robust American economy, and today's figures provided the first clear evidence that the process was under way. **********''This is the beginning of Asia kicking in, and it is the harbinger of wider deficits to come,'' said Joel L. Naroff, an economist at the First Union Bank in Philadelphia. **********With American exporters feeling the bite, the Clinton Administration stepped up efforts today to press Japan into reviving its moribund economy to help pull Asia out of its crisis. For the first time, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers specified how much the United States wanted Japan to increase public spending and cut taxes: 2 percent of the country's gross domestic product. That is roughly equivalent to $77 billion. **********Mr. Summers acknowledged that Japanese officials were becoming increasingly angry at American criticism of how their economy was being managed. But, he said, ''Just as our Japanese and European friends appropriately criticized U.S. budget deficits, we think it is appropriate'' to specify how Japan should stimulate its economy for the good of its trading partners. **********Analysts said they expected widening trade deficits in coming months to exert more of a drag on growth in the United States. **********But they said it remained unclear whether the otherwise strong economy would slow sufficiently to avoid inflation pressures that would lead the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates -- or whether the economy might slow so much that an interest-rate cut would be justified. **********Inflation statistics released today provided few clues to which way the economy might tip. The Labor Department said the Consumer Price Index for February rose one-tenth of 1 percent, held down by falling oil prices, leaving the inflation rate for the last year at 1.4 percent. Excluding food and energy, the Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent, its biggest jump since last April. Most of the rise, though, came from one-time increases in items like cigarette prices and rent, rather than broad-based price increases. **********Falling oil prices also made the trade deficit look smaller, since the value of energy imports would otherwise have been much higher. As it was, the trade figures showed how the difficulties among some of the nation's fastest-growing export markets were being felt at home. **********The most compelling evidence was in the figures for trade with the four original ''Asian tiger'' economies. The combined deficit in those markets -- South Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan -- jumped to $2.2 billion for the month, up from $841 million in December and $783 million a year earlier. **********The deficit just with South Korea, one of the nations hit hardest by financial crisis, rose to $856 million from $341 million. In January 1997, the United States had a trade surplus with South Korea of $181 million. **********The deficit with Japan, one of the most politically sensitive indicators of American trade performance, narrowed to $4.4 billion, from $5.1 billion in December, when the gap was particularly high. **********The deficit with China, which now rivals that of Japan in economic and political significance, rose in January to $3.7 billion from $2.7 billion. **********While considerable attention has been focused on how Asian financial problems are hurting trade, economists said the overall impact on the United States was mixed. The currency devaluations across Asia have made imports from there into the United States less expensive, dampening inflation and forcing domestic competitors to hold down prices. **********Low inflation and a flood of investment from Asia into United States Treasury bonds have pushed down interest rates, reducing borrowing costs for American businesses and consumers and setting off mortgage refinancing that has left more money in the pockets of many people. **********While the slowing of exports to Asia could significantly cut growth in this country, the slowdown will be partly offset by the reduction in interest rates and by low oil prices, analysts said. While many economists still expect growth to slow from its 3.9 percent pace in the fourth quarter, few predict that it will slow in the current quarter to what has been considered a sustainable pace of 2.5 percent or less. **********''The domestic part of the economy is really on fire,'' said Stuart G. Hoffman of the PNC Corporation. ''If the trade deficit held at its current level through February and March, it could knock one and a quarter percentage points off the growth rate, but that would leave real G.D.P. growth at 3 or 3.5 percent.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/05/world.snippet: British soldiers ring the Drumcree neighborhood of Portadown, Northern Ireland, in effort to prevent sectarian violence on July 5, when Orange Order says it will try to march down down a Catholic street to celebrate 1690 Battle of the Boyne; photo...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/05/world.main_headline: Troops Occupy Ulster Town on Eve of Protestant March
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/05/world.print_headline: Troops Occupy Ulster Town on Eve of Protestant March
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/05/world.body_text: **********In an effort to prevent sectarian violence on Sunday, hundreds of British soldiers ringed the small Portadown neighborhood called Drumcree today and installed thousands of yards of four-foot-high barbed wire in the surrounding fields. **********The soldiers, armed with automatic rifles and in full combat uniform, seemed to be everywhere for several miles around. **********They and hundreds of armed police officers blocked roads with huge slabs of cement and forced residents of this town 35 miles west of Belfast to show identification as they neared the small steepled Church of Ireland Protestant church. **********''There's more Brits at Drumcree than there were at Dunkirk,'' a taxi dispatcher said. **********For the fourth consecutive year, Drumcree is the focal point of anger, and some hatred, between Roman Catholics and the Protestants of the Orange Order. The order holds 3,000 parades each summer to celebrate the victory at the 1690 Battle of the Boyne by the Protestant William of Orange over his Catholic father-in-law, King James II. **********In the last three years, the parade has provoked violence over the Protestants' demand that they be allowed to march past a short strip of Catholic homes on the Garvaghy Road, on the edge of Portadown. **********This year a British Government commission ruled that the Protestants may not march through the Catholic area, about one-quarter-mile long, but must detour around it. The decision last Monday pleased the Catholics. But the Orange Order has insisted that it will confront the security forces and try to march down the road anyway. **********This has angered many of the area's 6,000 Catholics, led by Brendan MacCionnaith, a former Irish Republican Army operative who served time in a British prison for taking part in the bombing of a Protestant meeting hall in 1981. Mr. MacCionnaith has proposed a compromise -- that if the Orangemen agree  voluntarily, without reference to the Government ban, not to march down the Garvaghy Road on Sunday, then the Catholics will allow them do so without hindrance next year. **********Because violence could spread,  threatening the new peace agreement, officials, both Catholic and Protestant, have tried to work out a compromise. Britain's Prime Minister, Tony Blair, spent Thursday in Belfast trying unsuccessfully to arrange one. **********But the Orangemen have rejected the Catholics' offer and insist they must march along the same route they have taken since 1807. **********For Protestants the march is a confirmation of their political and religious heritage. They don black suits, bowler hats and orange sashes, while their drums and fifes and bugles play military airs. **********Catholics say that the parades are triumphalist and that allowing the Orangemen to march through Catholic neighborhoods is comparable to allowing the Ku Klux Klan to march through Harlem. **********By this afternoon, no compromise was in sight, but officials continued to try. Mr. MacCionnaith, in an interview this morning, said the British Government had to ''make a stand'' to enforce the ban on the march through his area. He said he had made a ''very generous offer'' to the Orangemen. But the Orangemen, and many Protestant officials, refuse to talk to him because of his I.R.A. background. **********Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing, said in a speech on Friday, ''The Orange march on the Garvaghy Road is not about religious tolerance, but about intolerance. The standoff by the Garvaghy Road residents is not a threat to the Orange Order. If the Orange Order wishes to march along this route, it needs to talk directly to the coalition,'' that is, to Mr. MacCionnaith. **********David Trimble, the Protestant First Minister of the New Northern Ireland Assembly, said today that ''in this very dangerous time'' people should ''keep calm, keep the peace.'' **********At the parade three years ago, Mr. Trimble marched with the Orangemen and raised his arm in triumph, angering Catholics. The gesture helped win him the leadership of the Ulster Unionist Party. Now, as head of the new assembly, he is pledged to work with Catholics to enact the peace agreement approved on May 22 by voters here and in the Irish Republic. **********At a checkpoint along the Drumcree Road, by the Catholic enclave of Ballyoran Park, a man in a red car upbraided a policeman for barring his way. ''If this happens to you someday, you'll bloody know what it's like,'' he said. **********''Yes sir, thank you, sir,'' the policeman replied. **********A small boy fingered the muzzle of a policeman's rifle and looked through the ring-sight, then reached his finger toward the trigger. **********''Hands off!'' snapped the officer. **********''You can't talk to him like that,'' said a blond girl on a small bicycle who was pedaling closer and closer to the police armored Land Rover blocking the road. **********''He's my brother,'' she said. ''And I can ride in this road as long as I like.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/06/busin.main_headline: NO MORE JOB CUTS EXPECTED BY MOTOROLA CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; NO MORE JOB CUTS EXPECTED BY MOTOROLA CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/06/busin.body_text: **********The chief executive of Motorola Inc., Charles Galvin, said yesterday that the company did not expect, at this time, any additional job cuts beyond its announced plans to eliminate 15,000 positions in the next year. After the close of the stock market on Thursday, Motorola reported that it planned a major reorganization and series of job cuts. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/18/busin.snippet: Laura Pedersen-Pietersen column profiles Eagle Bay Hosta Gardens in Sheridan, NY, founded 17 years ago by Ransom Lydell; his success in raising and selling hybrid hostas described; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/18/busin.main_headline: In Lots Of Hostas, A Success
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/18/busin.print_headline: CALLINGS; In Lots Of Hostas, A Success
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/18/busin.body_text: **********RANSOM LYDELL guessed right 17 years ago when he thought there would be a booming market for the lilylike perennials called hostas. But spotting an opportunity is one thing and exploiting it is another, as millions of failed entrepreneurs have discovered. Today, Mr. Lydell, 59, runs one of the most successful hosta businesses in the country, mostly because he has figured out how to differentiate himself from his rivals in flower-selling. **********If you happened into the Corner Snack Bar here around noon on a recent weekday and witnessed him in his trademark pith helmet, digging into a plate of flapjacks and trading gossip with the other regulars, you would probably not have picked him out as a marketing genius. **********But appearances can be deceiving. When he had his brainstorm in 1981, Mr. Lydell knew a thing or two about flowers. As the owner of a small landscaping business, he understood that outdoor floral displays could work magic on consumers' wallets. And, as a graduate of the State Agricultural and Technical Institute at Alfred, he realized that hostas, unlike roses and other popular flowers, were nearly virgin territory for the creation of new varieties through hybridization. **********Today his Eagle Bay Hosta Gardens, a three-acre sanctuary of bridges, ponds, an arbor and a faded red barn, contain 800 hosta varieties and 15,000 plants. Outsiders can meander freely around it anytime they happen to be passing through this hamlet in the grape country of Chautauqua County, near Lake Erie. **********''It's incredibly important for people to see how the flowers they're buying will eventually look,'' he said.  On any day during the growing season, the enthusiasts wander in, video cameras in hand. Some are from Europe or Asia. **********In his research operation, Mr. Lydell has 1,000 hybrids ''under observation,'' monitoring them during six or seven years for flower color, form, height, uniqueness of the leaf pattern and resistance to slugs, a scourge of hostas. Once satisfied, he ships the hybrid off to the University of Minnesota, home of the worldwide hosta registry. If his variety is accepted, he can sell the first 100 plants, the flower world's equivalent of first-issue postage stamps, for a total of $1,500 to $10,000. His record sale for a single plant was $350. **********Currently, Mr. Lydell has registered 18 varieties. He calls his most recent creation Saybrook Surprise and his favorite, which resembles a yucca plant, Yucca Ducka Do. **********On the sales side, he is determined not to be outdone by the big mail-order flower merchants. He has his own Internet site (http://vinetime.com/eaglebaygardens/index.html) chock full of hosta news and, of course, order forms. But since gardeners can be technophobes, he continues to publish his color catalogue and accept orders by phone, fax and plain old snail mail. **********Sales have doubled every year in the last four years. Profits are up, too, enabling Mr. Lydell to buy his dream vacation home on Lake Erie not long ago. **********His second pith helmet is almost worn out, but Mr. Lydell has no plans to retire. ''You've got to be kidding me,'' he said. ''My youngest girl wants to go to medical school.'' He is expanding his flower park with picnic tables, public restrooms, a gazebo, a miniature tropical garden, an Alpine forest and a Japanese teahouse. **********TO be sure, the hosta business is not without its intrigue. ''There's a master plant thief who works out of New York City,'' Mr. Lydell whispered conspiratorially. ''He's stolen plants from the Emperor's gardens in Japan. It's like any other field where beautiful objects can sell for several thousand dollars. Serious collectors can get desperate.'' **********So far, Mr. Lydell's biggest problem with theft does not involve people. Last summer, some local deer became fond of feeding on one of his prized varieties. He tried everything to drive them off until he discovered that there was one thing they couldn't abide: country and western music on the radio. **********''The deer loved classical and soft rock,'' he said. ''It made them eat even faster. I finally found an upscale country station, which they absolutely hate. Now they have to go to the corner snack bar, just like the rest of us.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/09/world.snippet: While Syria is only Arab nation to flatly declare that new military attack against Iraq is unwarranted, no other Arab country, with exception of Kuwait has endorsed American threats of military force despite assurances by Sec of State Madeleine K ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/09/world.main_headline: Only One Arab Nation Endorses U.S. Threat of Attack on Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/09/world.print_headline: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: THE ARABS; Only One Arab Nation Endorses U.S. Threat of Attack on Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/09/world.body_text: **********Among the Persian Gulf war allies who fought to drive Iraqi troops out of Kuwait in 1991, only Syria among Arab nations has flatly declared that a new attack on Iraq now would be unwarranted.  But with the exception of Kuwait, no Arab nation has endorsed the American threats of military action, despite the assurances that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said she had received on her recent visit to the Middle East. **********And while Ms. Albright portrayed her trip as a success, the messages from top Arab officials have remained highly cautionary, heavy with suggestions that the renewed use of force against Iraq could set off more turmoil in a volatile region. **********After meeting today with King Hassan of Morocco, Egypt's Foreign Minister, Amr Moussa, said, ''As part of the ongoing consultations between Arab countries, Egypt and Morocco are against military strikes on Iraq.'' **********The resistance to the American strategy reflects the sentiments being voiced among many ordinary Arabs, and it could still complicate American decision-making about whether or how to carry out the threatened strikes. **********The message was expressed in less diplomatic language last week by the state-owned Egyptian newspaper Al Ahram. **********''The American position toward Iraq cannot be described as anything but coercive, aggressive, unwise and uncaring about the lives of Iraqis, who are unnecessarily subjected to sanctions and humiliation,'' the newspaper said in an editorial. **********Throughout the region, diplomats and other analysts say a new round of air strikes against Iraq could have a broadly negative political impact by reinforcing a view that the United States has little regard for Arab lives. **********Esmat Abdel-Maguid, Secretary General of the 21-member Arab League and leader of a delegation that returned from Baghdad over the weekend, warned here today that any resort to military force would be ''very detrimental to the situation in the world and the Middle East.'' **********A Cairo-based diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity echoed that view. **********''The clear view on the Arab street is that the United States is concerned only with promoting Israel's agenda,'' the diplomat said. ''And if the United States carries out its threats against Baghdad, it is going to have to face a new groundswell of anti-American sentiment.'' **********The editorial in Al Ahram called attention to what is widely called deliberate American blindness. **********''Current tensions in the region should be blamed on Israel, not Iraq,'' the newspaper said on Wednesday. ''Each time the United States toughens its line on Iraq and overlooks the nuclear, chemical and biological arsenal of Israel, which occupies Arab lands, it exposes its double standards. America will lose whatever remains of its credibility in the region if it launches aggression against Iraq.'' **********The Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, was clearly seeking to gain Arab support when his Government announced last week that it would free non-Iraqi Arabs from its prisons. **********Few Arabs regard Mr. Hussein with the esteem that many did before he invaded Kuwait in 1990. But many are prepared to see the Iraqi people, hit hard by United Nations sanctions, as victims, a sentiment that has permeated most Arab commentary on the current showdown. **********No Arab leader would be sorry if Mr. Hussein were ousted from power, and all have said Iraq must be given no choice but to heed the United Nations sanctions that require the weapons inspections. **********Some senior Arab officials -- particularly in the Persian Gulf region -- have even confided to diplomats and other visitors that their patience with Iraq has worn so thin that they agree that there may soon be no option but to subject Mr. Hussein to more punishment. **********But few if any Arab leaders are likely to express such sentiments in public, reflecting their apprehension that they could become targets of the kind of outrage likely to result if many Iraqi civilians fall victim to renewed American attacks. **********Such wariness made for a delicate backdrop as Defense Secretary William S. Cohen began his visit to the gulf tonight. Before he arrived, the Saudi Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, was quoted in the Saudi newspaper Arab News today as saying his country did not favor a military strike against Iraq. **********Only Kuwait has explicitly backed a possible American-led attack. It is permitting the United States and Britain to send warplanes to its bases to reinforce a contingent of F-117-A ''stealth'' fighters already there, and Kuwaiti officials have made clear that they would have no problem with these aircraft being used in combat. **********Similarly, Bahrain is allowing the United States to send a third B-1 bomber in addition to two already there, and the tiny island country, which serves as headquarters to the Navy's Fifth Fleet, has signaled a willingness to once again become a base for military operations. **********In public, however, Bahraini officials have remained guarded. The Foreign Minister, Sheik Mohammed Mubarak al-Khalifa, said in an interview last week that he would not address the subject of using force against Iraq until the United States and its allies had first sought to ''exhaust all diplomatic initiatives.'' **********Among other American allies, even President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt was saying early this month that a new attack would be ''inappropriate.'' Mr. Mubarak has softened such criticism since Ms. Albright's visit, and in the last week alone sent three separate messages to the Iraqi leader urging him to cooperate with United Nations inspectors. **********But even Mr. Mubarak, whose country played a leading role in the Persian Gulf war, went out of his way soon after Ms. Albright departed to announce that Egypt itself had no intention of joining in any renewed military action. And Syria, whose forces also joined prominently in the American-led gulf war coalition, has been so outspoken in its view that new attacks are unwarranted that Ms. Albright did not even stop in Damascus on her recent trip. **********Jordan, which backed Iraq during the gulf war, has switched sides since, even allowing American warplanes to use its territory as a base to enforce the ''no flight'' zone over southern Iraq. After meeting in London with Ms. Albright last weekend, King Hussein wrote a letter that he made public to prepare the country for the prospect that a new round of attacks may be ahead. **********But Jordan's Parliament replied with a statement that condemned ''any aggression against Iraq's territory and any harm that might come to the Iraqi people.'' **********Even in the gulf, within the tiny countries that Ms. Albright suggested should feel most threatened by Iraq, some commentators have tried to cast doubt on American claims of having won broad support for military action if diplomacy fails. **********''Albright's claims that she won significant Arab backing for the expected U.S. military operations against Iraq are most probably meant to embarrass the Arab sides and intimidate them to keep their mouths shut,'' Hafedh al-Sheik wrote last week in the Bahraini daily Akhbar al-Khalij.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/19/world.snippet: China puts Wang Dan, its most noted dissident, on airplane bound for US after releasing him for medical reasons; Wang, leader of Tiananmen Square democracy movement, was arrested in May 1995 and was serving 11-year prison sentence; he is expected ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/19/world.main_headline: LEADING DISSIDENT IS FREED BY BEIJING AND SENT TO U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/19/world.print_headline: LEADING DISSIDENT IS FREED BY BEIJING AND SENT TO U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/19/world.body_text: **********The Government of China today put Wang Dan, its most noted dissident, on an airplane bound for the United States after releasing him for medical reasons, according to the official Chinese news agency, Xinhua, in Beijing. **********Mr. Wang, 28, was a leader of the Tiananmen Square democracy movement, supressed by the Chinese military in 1989. He was accompanied on the flight to Detroit by an American diplomat, Mr. Wang's mother said. **********He was expected to be met by fellow dissidents in Detroit. **********His release was part of a negotiated arrangement reached last month between China and the Clinton Administration, in return for the United States' dropping its sponsorship of a resolution condemning China's human rights policies. **********A White House official reached early this morning said that the Administration was very pleased by the news, but that more would come from the President himself later today in Chile where he is attending a Western Hemisphere summit meeting. **********Mr. Wang served four years in prison for his role in the Tiananmen demonstrations. He was arrested again in May 1995 and was serving an 11-year sentence in a northeast China prison for ''subversion.'' **********American officials said that Mr. Wang had been moved to Beijing in the last few days, indicating that his release was likely. **********Mr. Wang's release paralleled that of another noted dissident, Wei Jingsheng, last Nov. 16. Mr. Wei was also released on medical grounds on condition that he, too, leave China and go into exile. **********Mr. Wei's release followed shortly after the summit meeting in Washington between President Clinton and Chinese President Jiang Zemin. Mr. Wang's release comes just before Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright visits China at the end of this month, preparing for Mr. Clinton's first trip to China as President in late June. **********The deal for Mr. Wang's release was first reported in The New York Times earlier this month. At the time, Chinese officials denied there was any deal with Washington, but said that releases of prisoners on medical grounds were a humanitarian practice, and that a final decision would be taken by the Chinese judiciary. **********But Mr. Wang's release, like Mr. Wei's, was a political decision by the highest levels of the Chinese Communist Party. **********On March 13 this year, the Clinton Adminsitration announced that it would not sponsor a resolution seeking to condemn China's human rights practices at the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva. Officials said China had met American requirements, including an agreement to sign the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and a willingness to release a number of prisoners. **********''Chinese judicial authorities recently allowed Wang Dan to be released on bail for medical treatment in accordance with law,'' Xinhua said. **********''In response to a question from a Xinhua correspondent, a spokesman of the Ministry of Justice said today that Wang Dan, who is ill, has already gone abroad for medical treatment,'' the Xinhua report said. **********Other prisoners who might be released include Gao Yu, a journalist arrested in 1993 just before she was to attend Columbia Journalism School in New York. **********She received a six-year sentence for divulging state secrets for an article she wrote in a Hong Kong newspaper about the Chinese budget. **********Another prisoner could also be Liu Nianchung, a labor activist serving three years in a prison camp and who is said to be in very bad health.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/23/busin.snippet: Group that oversees accounting procedures for American Institute of Certified Public Accountants approves changes that would force film studios to abandon some practices that have enabled them to inflate current profits; changes, if they pass othe...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/23/busin.main_headline: Movie studios may face more rigorous rules for how they keep their books.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/23/busin.print_headline: MEDIA: ENTERTAINMENT; Movie studios may face more rigorous rules for how they keep their books.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/23/busin.body_text: **********THE DAYS when film accounting was more creative than many film scripts may soon be coming to an end. **********For decades the movie studios have had great freedom in how they account for the revenues and expenses of motion pictures. The latitude in the accounting rules lets them write off advertising costs very gradually even when the bulk of the money is spent right as a film opens. **********In addition, revenues from sales of rerun rights to movies and television series can be recorded in full on the first day the products are available to run, even if a contract lasts three years or more. **********The result: A studio can make earnings look higher than they might really be by reducing near-term expenses and lifting sales. **********But last month, the group that oversees accounting procedures for the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants approved a set of changes in film accounting that would compel companies to write off marketing costs faster than many do now. **********The changes would also prohibit studios from recognizing certain kinds of revenues as quickly as they once did. And the new rules would prevent companies from taking an exaggeratedly long period to write off film production costs. **********The rules face a series of additional hurdles, and have yet to be approved by the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the private group that determines the nation's accounting rules. But if, as expected, some variation of the current proposals is ultimately approved, it will go into effect in the year 2000. **********In the long term, both investors and analysts are expected to benefit because reported earnings will more accurately reflect performance, said David Londoner, a media analyst at Schroder Inc. and a member of the group that drafted the changes. Equally important, he added, the rules would create accounting uniformity that would make comparisons of companies easier. **********Ted Howell, chief financial officer at Sony Pictures Entertainment, said: ''Analysts want a level playing field. They don't see any reason why film accounting should be different than consumer products or other businesses.'' **********The proposed changes would be tougher on some companies than on others. Mr. Londoner said that the companies most likely to be affected by the changes were 20th Century Fox, Columbia Pictures, Tri-Star Pictures and Paramount Pictures. These companies could face significant one-time write-downs if the new standards go into effect for accumulated advertising costs that are still carried in inventory. **********Mr. Londoner estimates that both Paramount, which is owned by Viacom, and Columbia Pictures and Tri-Star, which are owned by Sony, will have to take one-time $250 million write-offs. And 20th Century Fox, which is owned by the News Corporation, faces a $175 million write-down, he estimates. **********Simon Bax, chief financial officer at Fox Filmed Entertainment, said that the impact on that studio would depend on when the changes were adopted and how the films released in that period performed. Executives at Viacom and Sony declined to comment on Mr. Londoner's estimates. **********Two other studios, Time Warner's Warner Bros. and Seagram's Universal Pictures face relatively small write-downs, because they have used more conservative accounting methods, Mr. Londoner said. **********To be sure, because most studios are only parts of larger companies, any effect on the overall corporate bottom line would be muted. **********Studio executives have generally declined to comment publicly on the proposed rules. **********But privately, at least two have argued that it was unfair to force a speedier write-down of movie advertising costs. They said that even though advertising was concentrated during the time a film was in theaters, it was aimed at making a film more valuable later on, too, for release in other media. **********Though some of the major film studios have been aggressive in their accounting strategies, few have been as creative in this respect as a number of troubled smaller companies such as the now-defunct Carolco Pictures and Orion Pictures were in the 1980's when they sought to lift their earnings and keep investors happy. **********Facing a string of flops, they avoided the pain of losses by delaying write-offs for years. Among the tricks: they would forecast that a film that had bombed at the box office would make lots of money in television syndication or other media years after its release. **********Because movie companies have been able to write off expenses in proportion to projected revenues, when studios projected large future revenues they could stall writing off most of their current movie budgets for years. **********Ultimately, of course, many of those revenues never materialized, but companies still had heavy costs left on their books so they took huge one-time write-downs. ''People finally realized that the companies were not making money and had been borrowing against inflated inventories on their balance sheets,'' Mr. Londoner said. **********But even the more mainstream companies have used some techniques to maximize profits, strategies that likely will no longer be available. For example, studios have been able to write off advertising expenditures -- now $20 million a film, on average -- over more than 10 years in some cases. **********The new rules would require them to write off all marketing for the theatrical release of a movie in the initial three months. There would be equally strict parameters for when promotions for the home video and TV releases must be recorded. **********The new rules would also change the way studios could account for revenue from sales to television of the rights to movie or television series. Currently, when studios sell those rights, often for a multiyear period, they can reflect virtually all the revenues on the date the movie or series becomes available to television. The new rules would require that studios take in those revenues over the life of the contract. **********Currently, studios can take years to record production costs. That, too, will change. ''There will now be a cap of 10 years for the amount of time companies can project ultimate gross revenues,'' Dan Noll, technical manager for accounting at the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, said. ''That will force them to write off production costs over 10 years. The longer you can spread out the costs, the smaller the impact on the income statements.'' **********The origin of the accounting morass arises from changes in the movie business. ''The rules were written a long time ago and don't address how business is conducted today,'' Mr. Noll said. ''With home video, cable and television, the life of a film or series is far longer and it has left companies too much freedom to manage revenues and costs.'' **********Movie executives, Wall Street analysts and others will all have a chance to comment on the proposed rules. And though they may ultimately be altered, experts say there is a strong possibility that at least some tightening in film accounting policies is inevitable.
