https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/19/busin.body_text: **********Ciba Specialty Chemicals A.G., the Swiss company that is the world's second-biggest maker of specialty chemicals, said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,100 jobs and possibly sell one of its biggest units. Ciba's first-half operating profit rose 2.7 percent, to 490 million Swiss francs ($325.7 million) from 477 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. Analysts had expected an 11 percent increase. **********To improve earnings, Ciba plans to cut 5 percent of its work force, possibly sell its polymers unit and create a new colors division. The world's $100 billion specialty chemicals industry is consolidating. Earlier this year, Ciba bought Allied Colloids Group P.L.C., a maker of water-treatment chemicals, for 3.6 billion francs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/04/busin.snippet: Lobbying power of Big Oil in Washington assessed; two of biggest players in this monolithic and highly effective industry lobby are Exxon Corp and Mobil Corp; rich in cash, aggressive in style, with issues ranging from foreign policy to taxes and ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/04/busin.main_headline: Companies Used to Getting Their Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/04/busin.print_headline: Companies Used to Getting Their Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/04/busin.body_text: **********After tornadoes, El Nino rains and an ice storm swept across large swaths of the country, Congress enacted an emergency spending measure in May providing $2.6 billion in natural disaster relief. Deep inside that bill, though, in a last-minute addition, the oil industry won a big concession: relief of $66 million from the amount owed for extracting oil from Federal lands. **********Then in October, with Congress wrangling over a huge spending bill and eager to cut deals and leave town, the oil industry won again as the House leadership reaffirmed that relief. Indeed, in the end, Congress even sweetened the deal a bit, by extending the break a little longer. **********Such is the power of Big Oil in Washington, and two of the biggest players in this monolithic and highly effective industry lobby are the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation. Rich in cash, aggressive in style, with issues ranging from foreign policy to taxes and the environment, they have been effective in pushing their agenda through behind-the-scenes contacts at the highest level of Government and through arm-twisting in Congress. **********''Some companies have a narrow range of interests to lobby on,'' said Jennifer Shecter, a researcher at the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonprofit group that tracks Washington lobbying. ''But, by its very nature, oil is so pervasive and it is so affected by Government policy that they care about everything.'' **********With the oil and gas industry generally marching, and lobbying, in lockstep, it is often hard to separate Exxon and Mobil from their rivals. While somewhat different in their approaches, both companies are big supporters of the American Petroleum Institute, an industry trade association that spent $3.7 million on lobbying in 1997. They often join industry coalitions created to lobby about a specific topic -- the lifting of sanctions to oil-producing nations like Iraq, for example, or the ability of American oil companies to swap oil with Iran. **********By themselves, Exxon and Mobil have a combined total of 15 full-time lobbyists on their payrolls in Washington, and employ other Washington lawyers and lobbying firms as well. Last year, Mobil spent $5.3 million on Federal lobbying and Exxon spent $5.2 million, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. Combined, this would make them the fifth-largest entity in spending on lobbying the Federal Government. **********As multinational corporations with businesses in far-flung spots, Exxon and Mobil's interests in Washington touch on many trade and finance issues. The two companies have won favorable tax rulings before the Internal Revenue Service and the Treasury Department concerning the use of foreign tax credits to reduce their United States tax bill. **********They are sensitive to the State Department's Middle East and Asian policies, especially since oil is often found in pariah nations such as Libya, Myanmar and Iran. They are generally supportive of Arab nations. And new issues, like the proposed Caspian Sea pipeline route -- a region where Mobil has operations -- have engaged them. **********''They are probably most effective behind the scenes,'' said Martin Lobel, a Washington lawyer who represents consumer groups and small oil companies. ''They'll get their economists and lawyers to see the I.R.S. and the companies will stay relatively hidden. You've got maybe two Ph.D economists in the entire I.R.S. and Exxon can hire as many as they want. We were once in a big battle with Exxon on the issue of oil overcharges and there must have been 30 economists on the other side.'' **********Edward Rothschild, a senior associate with Podesta Associates, a Washington lobbying firm, said that the two companies' lobbying on complicated tax issues had paid off handsomely. **********''There's a lot of esoteric issues, especially in taxes, but which are worth hundreds of millions of dollars,'' he said. ''There were efforts by the Clinton Administration in the last two budget bills to reduce the value of the foreign tax credits. But Exxon and the industry descended and those provisions were quietly eliminated. I don't know who they talked to, but they got the job done.'' **********While Exxon and Mobil are usually allied on industry issues, each has a different operating style: Exxon is more aloof and somewhat diffident about how it is perceived; Mobil is quicker to defend its public image and more willing to enter the political fray. Exxon's brashness was evident when the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill, one of the worst environmental catastrophes in United States history, became a giant tax break, as the company wrote off all disaster-related expenses -- including legal bills and cleanup costs. **********Mobil makes few campaign contributions, while Exxon is a leading donor to the Republican Party and candidates. In the 1996 Presidential election cycle, Exxon contributed $593,928, donating 95 percent to Republicans; in the last Congressional races, Exxon gave $475,855, 84 percent to Republicans. **********This G.O.P. tilt could help the companies in the next Congress: the three new top House leaders are all Republicans from the Oil Patch: the House Speaker, Bob Livingston of Louisiana; the majority leader, Dick Armey of Texas, and J. C. Watts of Oklahoma, the party's new conference chairman. **********On Capitol Hill, Exxon and Mobil opposed the Clinton Adminstration's efforts to gain Senate approval of the Kyoto Protocol, an international treaty to curb global warming that had won support by other oil companies like Royal Dutch/Shell Group and British Petroleum. **********And, in the last Congress, they won significant victories to halt the Interior and Treasury Departments' efforts to get oil companies to pay more in royalties for oil and gas extracted from Federal lands and pay back some $345.5 million in past royalties that the Interior Department says is owed. **********The Justice Department has even filed suit to collect these royalties; last August, Mobil spent $56.5 million to settle these claims. Meanwhile, in Congress, Exxon leads an industry effort to pay royalties owed to the Government in oil rather than in cash -- a proposal the Government strongly opposes. **********''The oil companies lobby in a very coordinated way,'' said a staff member for a House energy-related committee, who spoke on the condition that neither he not his committee be identified. ''They rely heavily on the American Petroleum Institute, but they've also got their people. Exxon's lobbyist is very friendly and outgoing and the company is really involved in the royalty issue. On a technical point, Exxon's lobbyist will bring in 11 people to talk to you about it. They are incredibly influential.'' **********Lynn Russo, an Exxon spokeswoman, said it was too early to tell how the company's lobbying would be affected by the merger, a view shared by Donald Turk, a spokesman for Mobil. Mobil does plan to continue paying for op-ed newspaper ads and for the ''Masterpiece Theater'' television series through 1999, Mr. Turk said. **********If history is any guide, the companies' lobbying expenses will undoubtedly rise while the merger faces Federal scrutiny: The Bell Atlantic Corporation's lobbying costs shot up to $15.6 million at the time of its merger with Nynex, and the Boeing Company's costs rose to $10 million as it was acquiring McDonnell Douglas. **********Still, the specter of a combined Exxon-Mobil juggernaut on the Potomac scares some. ''They will be so huge and interested in an incredible number of issues,'' said Charles Lewis, executive director of the Center for Public Integrity, a Washington nonprofit group. ''They'll come up with new lobbying battlegrounds.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/04/world.main_headline: U.S. Pessimistic Before Middle East Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/04/world.print_headline: U.S. Pessimistic Before Middle East Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/04/world.body_text: **********If the meetings here on Monday between Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Israeli and Palestinian leaders go as badly as American officials seem to expect, President Clinton will face some hard choices that could bring him into more open confrontation with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel. **********After a week of Middle East shuttling by the special American envoy, Dennis B. Ross, and an extra, post-midnight session early today at the Tel Aviv airport between Vice President Al Gore and Mr. Netanyahu, American officials continue to say they have little expectation for a breakthrough here. **********They suggest that despite all the American massaging of Mr. Netanyahu lately, especially around the 50th anniversary of the founding of Israel, the Israeli leader is not prepared to accept the American proposals for a roughly 13 percent withdrawal from the West Bank and that he thinks he can withstand any political pressure that might result from public American disapproval. **********''Secretary Albright is entering this meeting without any advanced knowledge that the key gaps are about to be closed,'' her spokesman, James P. Rubin, said today. ''This is an extremely important meeting, and afterwards we'll decide what next steps to take.'' **********American officials deny that they would remove themselves from the search for peace. But if President Clinton approves, they could take steps to pressure Mr. Netanyahu or punish him, by publicly blaming him for the impasse or even suspending some American aid. **********While clearly intended to insulate Ms. Albright from accusations of failure after the talks Monday, Mr. Rubin's remarks also seemed to reflect genuine American pessimism and annoyance with the 14-month stalemate and the inability of Mr. Netanyahu to agree to American proposal, which Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, has accepted in principle. **********The American proposals are intended to complete interim Israeli withdrawals from the West Bank, as called for in the 1993 and 1995 Oslo accords, in stages, in return for Palestinian steps to counter terrorists. **********The proposals would commit both sides to begin accelerated talks on a final settlement between them, which under the Oslo agreements are to be completed by May 1999. **********Ms. Albright will meet separately here on Monday morning with Mr. Netanyahu at his hotel and later with Mr. Arafat at the American Embassy. Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and his Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, as hosts and representing the European Union, will meet both Middle East leaders first. **********The main gaps between the Americans and the Israelis, the officials say, are the size of the redeployment, the security arrangements for the Palestinians and the sequence for final status negotiations in combination with a third and final Israeli withdrawal, which Mr. Netanyahu says he wants to forgo. **********Today in Israel, Mr. Netanyahu's spokesman, David Bar-Ilan, said that ''it would be utterly impossible for Israel to adhere to a withdrawal of 13 percent,'' but that Israel was hoping for ''some incremental progress'' on such issues as a Palestinian airport and seaport in the Gaza Strip and an industrial park on the Israel-Gaza border. **********But Mr. Rubin said that the Americans ''are interested in the views of Mr. Netanyahu'' and that the focus of the London meeting is the American agenda, ''not the airport.'' **********Mr. Arafat, who met President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in Cairo today before coming to London tonight, said that success depended on Mr. Netanyahu and warned that ''we will not agree to a withdrawal of less than 13 percent'' and that ''the failure of the conference will lead to anarchy and violence.'' **********The Palestinians currently control about 27 percent of the West Bank, which was captured by Israel from Jordan in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. **********Mr. Netanyahu says publicly that he cannot, on security grounds, hand over more than another 9 percent before final status talks begin, but has privately told Mr. Clinton he might be able to yield 11 percent. **********But American officials do not think Mr. Arafat could politically accept much less than 13 percent, even though, under the 1997 Hebron accords, Washington recognized Israel's right to determine the size of its redeployments under Oslo. **********The American proposal, never publicly revealed but widely leaked, calls for a three-stage withdrawal in which 13 percent of the West Bank now under complete Israeli control would come under full or partial Palestinian control. **********In the first five weeks, Israel would hand over to the Palestinians 1.9 percent from Area C (West Bank land under complete Israeli control) to Area B (land under Palestinian political control but with security under Israeli control). Israel would also hand over 0.1 percent from Area C to Area A (land under complete Palestinian control). Israel would also hand over 7 percent from Area B to Area A. **********In return, Mr. Arafat would order a ban on all kinds of ''incitement'' to violence in areas controlled by the Palestinian Authority, and the Palestinian Executive Committee would reconfirm changes in the Palestinian Covenant by canceling all clauses calling for Israel's destruction. **********From the 6th to the 11th week, Israel would hand over another 5 percent from land under complete Israeli control to political, but not security, control by the Palestinians -- from Area C to Area B. Mr. Arafat would hand over a full list of Palestinian policemen, which currently exceed Oslo limits on their numbers. **********A security committee of both sides, with the Americans included, would discuss Israeli accusations of weapons smuggling to the Palestinians. A similar committee led by the Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat, and the Israeli Cabinet chief, Danny Naveh, and including the Americans would discuss mutual demands to extradite suspects in terrorist acts and how to approve the release from jail of Palestinian suspects. **********In the 12th week, presuming both sides meet their obligations, Israel would hand over another 5 percent of the West Bank from Area C (total Israeli control) to B (partial Palestinian control). It would hand over another 1 percent from Area C to A (total Palestinian control). It would also transfer another 5 percent from Area B to A. And both sides would begin accelerated negotiations on a final settlement between them, to be finished before next May. **********So in the end, 13 percent would be transferred from Area C, and Area B would remain, after shifts of land to A, at 23 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/27/techn.snippet: World Wide Web sites are devoted to all aspects of automotive experience; road rage has triggered number of sites set up to record license plates; one site, called How to Drive Like a Moron, sarcastically compiles every possible bad-driving habit ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/27/techn.main_headline: The Art of Driving Is All the Rage
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/27/techn.print_headline: The Art of Driving Is All the Rage
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/27/techn.body_text: **********ONCE you have come to terms with the number of computers inside your car, try looking at the number of cars on your computer -- Web sites devoted to just about all aspects of the automotive experience. And when it comes to popular driving topics on the Web, road rage is all the rage. **********Road rage, the phenomenon of agitated drivers' becoming aggressive, dangerous and potentially lethal to other drivers, has triggered a number of sites set up to record license plates and automotive offenders on the Web. Yahoo keeps a comprehensive index of recent news stories and Web pages about the topic (headlines.yahoo.com/ FullCoverage/US/RoadRage). **********Two rage pages in particular take vastly differing views on the subject. The Principles of Driving Psychology (www.aloha.net/ dyc/ch11.html) is a paper published on the Web by Dr. Leon James that explores attitudes and moral implications concerning transportation manners among individuals. A lengthy treatise on human behavior behind the wheel, the page also offers a test called What's Your Moral Driving IQ? (Sample yes-or-no question: ''When I encounter road-hugging pedestrians, I feel like pushing them out of my way.'') **********If you are in the mood for more rage than road, try the scathing site How to Drive Like a Moron (members.aol.com/doggiesnot). Decorated with illustrations and animations that bring to mind the look of Comedy Central's crudely animated ''South Park'' cartoon, the site sarcastically compiles just about every possible bad-driving habit as part of its instruction in the art of idiot behavior. In the Shopping Center Parking Lots area, for example, the site suggests: ''Always park on the lines, taking up as many spaces as possible. Diagonal parking is preferred.'' **********Because of its size and traffic congestion, the New York metropolitan area most likely has more than its share of angry drivers. For those wanting to know what they're getting into before leaving the office, there's the Metro Commute site, which will let you check a number of local regions for accident alerts, construction areas and traffic warnings and posts an illustrated map regularly (www.metrocommute.com). **********If you've finally made it home and find yourself locked in the Web's slow lane, you can even check out the Internet Traffic Report (www.internettrafficreport.com) to see how much congestion the Net is under. And remember, whether you're driving a Jeep Cherokee or a Dell Pentium, let's be careful out there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/busin.snippet: Atlantic Richfield Co will cut 900 jobs, or 4.5 percent of its work force, and reduce costs by $500 million (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/busin.main_headline: ARCO LAYING OFF 900 AND CUTTING COSTS BY $500 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; ARCO LAYING OFF 900 AND CUTTING COSTS BY $500 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/busin.body_text: **********The Atlantic Richfield Company, the seventh-largest oil company in the United States, said yesterday that it would cut 900 jobs, or 4.5 percent of its work force, and reduce costs by $500 million. Costs will be reduced over two years, with most of the savings, $350 million, expected in 1999, the Los Angeles-based company said. Facing the lowest oil prices in 12 years as well as slumping earnings, ARCO is seen by many analysts as a target for takeover by another oil company. ARCO's chief executive, Michael R. Bowlin, warned employees last month that spending would have to be reduced ''to insure that ARCO remains a strong and successful independent company.'' ARCO said the 900 layoffs would come mainly from technical and administrative positions at its Los Angeles headquarters and in Plano, Tex.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/03/techn.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********The article ''You Can Search, but Can You Hide?'' (Nov. 26) describes the search of a Florida woman who used the Internet to track down David Granger, her husband's old college buddy. **********The story ended happily. But in light of the many risks and perils of electronic people finders that the article describes, it's fortunate that her quest didn't put Mr. Granger in grave danger. **********DON HAUPTMAN **********New York, Nov. 26, 1998

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/24/busin.main_headline: MANAGERS OF INDIANA TRUCKING COMPANY TO LEAD BUYOUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; MANAGERS OF INDIANA TRUCKING COMPANY TO LEAD BUYOUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/24/busin.body_text: **********Celadon Group Inc., a trucking company that specializes in shipments between the United States, Canada and Mexico, agreed yesterday to a management-led buyout for cash, stock and assumed debt. Odyssey Investment Partners L.L.C., a new $680 million investment fund based in New York, will pay Celadon shareholders $20 a share in cash. It will join with Celadon managers in buying the trucking company, based in Indianapolis, and taking it private. Shares of Celadon rose $4.3125, to $18.9375, in Nasdaq trading. The cash portion of the transaction totals $154 million based on the company's 7.7 million outstanding shares. The remainder of the purchase price will include assumed debt and the retirement of outstanding stock options.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/01/busin.snippet: Demand remains strong for commercial guided expeditions to climb Mount Everest despite dozen deaths on Everest during 1996 climbing season; advice on choosing expedition; photos (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/01/busin.main_headline: The Steep Price Of Climbing To the Top Of the World
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/01/busin.print_headline: VICARIOUS CONSUMPTION; The Steep Price Of Climbing To the Top Of the World
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/01/busin.body_text: **********MAYBE it's because of his grandfather, a wild-animal collector still unaccounted for after a trip to British Guyana in the late 1930's. Or because of his father, who sailed in the merchant marine. Or his childhood in Puerto Rico spent yearning for snow. For whatever reason, Rick Werner really wants to climb Mount Everest. **********So despite his asthma and the fact that he hasn't hiked much higher than Mount Washington (elevation 6,288 feet) in New Hampshire, Mr. Werner, 31, will spend a month's vacation this year and whatever else it takes to prepare to climb the world's highest mountain in 2000. **********''It becomes sort of an obsession,'' said Mr. Werner, an Internet account manager for Bell Atlantic in Arlington, Va. ''You begin to feel the gravitational pull of this big rock.'' **********Join the crowd. Despite a dozen deaths on Everest in the 1996 climbing season, demand remains strong for commercial guided expeditions to the 29,028-foot peak. **********In light of a death rate of about one climber for every four who reach the top, some believe that only the most seasoned climbers should attempt the summit. But for those with the compulsion to stand on the roof of the world, access can be had, for a price. **********The leading expedition services now charge about $65,000 a client. And that does not include the air fare to Nepal or a climber's cold-weather gear. Also not included: a guarantee of success. **********The fee does include the necessary permits, food, Sherpas to carry gear and access to group gear like tents and cookstoves -- as well as the aid of guides to assist in an ascent. **********The very first step on the long walk is choosing a guide service. It helps to know what questions to ask. **********For a start, Todd Burleson, president and owner of Alpine Ascents International in Seattle, said to ask guides how many people they have taken to the summit -- his group has assisted 35 climbers who reached the top of Everest since 1990 -- as well as whether they have lost anyone. And ask to speak with 10 clients from previous Everest expeditions. ''If they can't do that, you begin to wonder who you're calling,'' he said. **********Gordon Janow, program director of Alpine Ascents, suggested that clients look deeper than the success ratio of summits to attempts. ''Are you turning people around in bad weather? Were your high-success days all in really good weather? What's your success rate in bad weather?'' **********Mr. Burleson said that the trend was toward private groups, in which a few climbers buy out an entire expedition; instead of taking eight clients, a guide service will take three or so, who pay from $150,000 to $200,000 each. Indeed, that's the only kind of expedition he will handle for now. **********Suz Kelly, a spokeswoman for Adventure Consultants Ltd. of New Zealand, said other factors to consider included the client-to-guide ratio and the overall group size. And climbers need to know what kind of base camp services are provided. She recommends asking if it has weather forecasting facilities, a doctor on the staff, and satellite communications for backup. **********Even after Rob Hall, Adventure Consultants' founder, died on the mountain in 1996, eight members of a group organized by the company reached the top last May. **********Dave McGovern, a guide with Mountain Madness, also of Seattle, said that beyond the particulars of an expedition's supplies and a company's track record, a prospective client should learn more about the guides than their climbing resumes. ''A lot of guides are 26 years old and have four 8,000-meter peaks under their belts,'' he said. ''Twenty-six is kind of young, so the bells start to go off.'' **********Look for compassion and sensitivity, Mr. McGovern said.'''Are they a parent, have they had any heartbreaks? Has the person dealt with issues of humanity, rather than just being a climbing jock? So many guides up there have had a lot of quick successes.'' **********Expedition companies are also demanding more of clients. Mountain Madness, which lost its founder, Scott Fischer, in the 1996 climb, now requires a client to participate in at least one of its other trips before going to Everest. In addition, it advises prospective Everest climbers to take its six-day high-altitude course on Mount Baker in Washington, then climb a volcano in Mexico or Ecuador or one of the shorter Himalayas. **********The company suggests, but does not require, that clients climb Denali in Alaska, or Aconcagua in Argentina -- the highest peaks, respectively, in North and South America -- as well as an 8,000-meter (26,246 feet) peak, before trying Everest. In the summer of 1999, a Mountain Madness group will take on such a peak, Gasherbrum 2, in Kashmir. **********An issue for both guides and clients is a willingness to bail out. That is crucial for clients who may have paid a year's salary and suffered through thin air, pounding headaches and grueling exercise only to be turned back within sight of the summit. **********Mr. Janow said: ''There's that really delicate balance of when to tell someone, 'This trip is over; you're not able to continue,' versus when to see if the client is just really tired and needs someone pushing them. It's sort of a thin line. You have to see if you can pinpoint those things when picking a guide.'' **********Mr. Werner has decided to choose Mountain Madness, in part, he said, because of the 1996 tragedy. **********''I have a good degree of confidence in this group, because they were touched by that and they have a good amount of people with alpine experience,'' he said. ''I think they take fewer chances, and would send you down the mountain if you were 10 feet away from the summit, if they had to.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/busin.snippet: Utilicorp United Inc will pay $206 million to increase its stake in Power New Zealand Ltd; Utilicorp will increase its ownership to 78.6 percent from 37.5 percent; will buy shares from Mercury Energy Ltd and WEL Energy Group Ltd (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/busin.main_headline: UTILICORP RAISES STAKE IN NEW ZEALAND POWER COMPANY
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; UTILICORP RAISES STAKE IN NEW ZEALAND POWER COMPANY
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/busin.body_text: **********Utilicorp United Inc., the sixth-largest electric utility in the United States, said yesterday that it would pay $206 million to increase its stake in Power New Zealand Ltd., ending a four-year battle for control of the New Zealand electric company. Utilicorp, based in Kansas City, Mo., said its Utilicorp N.Z. Inc. subsidiary would increase its ownership of Power New Zealand to 78.6 percent from 37.5 percent. Utilicorp will buy shares from Mercury Energy Ltd., New Zealand's largest electricity retailer, and WEL Energy Group Ltd. In 1997, Utilicorp and Mercury agreed to drop competing hostile bids for Power New Zealand and submit a joint offer. But the two companies were not able to come to terms on creating a joint venture.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/busin.snippet: DuPont Co will receive $7.5 billion as part of its plan for sale of stock in its Conoco Inc oil and gas subsidiary to the public; Conoco plans to raise at least $3.5 billion in initial public offering (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/busin.main_headline: DUPONT TO RECEIVE $7.5 BILLION FROM CONOCO OFFERING
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; DUPONT TO RECEIVE $7.5 BILLION FROM CONOCO OFFERING
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/busin.body_text: **********The DuPont Company will receive $7.5 billion as part of its plan for sale of stock in its Conoco Inc. oil and gas subsidiary to the public, a regulatory filing shows. Conoco, based in Houston, the nation's ninth-largest producer of oil, plans to raise at least $3.5 billion in the initial stock offering, the company said in a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Conoco will use the proceeds from the stock sale, along with cash on hand, to repay part of a $7.5 billion promissory note issued to DuPont on July 20, according to the S.E.C. filing. Analysts have estimated that the public offering could raise $3 billion to $5 billion through the sale of a 20 percent stake in Conoco.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/10/busin.snippet: Adweek is commemorating its 20th anniversary with record 232-page special issue; issue, which accompanies regular weekly issue sent to subscribers, is meant to look ahead more than back on advertising industry (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/10/busin.main_headline: Adweek magazine is commemorating its 20th anniversary with a record 232-page special issue.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/10/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Adweek magazine is commemorating its 20th anniversary with a record 232-page special issue.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/10/busin.body_text: **********HERE'S a question for Robert Stack and ''Unsolved Mysteries'': Why did so many advertising trade publications start in years ending in 8? **********Campaign in Britain marked its 30th anniversary in mid-September, followed by the 90th anniversary of Marketing Magazine in Canada. And this week in this country, Adweek is commemorating its 20th with a record 232-page special issue. **********The issue, which accompanies the regular weekly issue of Adweek sent to subscribers yesterday, is meant to look ahead more than back, assessing the effects of megatrends like consolidation of accounts, fragmentation of media, globalization of consumer products and integration of marketing services. **********''We wanted to give the reader something of value instead of something that was a shameless collection of dollars from the marketplace,'' said Mark A. Dacey, president of Adweek Magazines in New York. That company, part of the BPI Communications Inc. division of VNU N.V., publishes Adweek along with sibling trade titles that include Brandweek and Mediaweek. **********Among the features in the anniversary issue are an interview with the usually reclusive Mary Wells, co-founder of Wells Rich Greene; 28 pages of photographs reuniting leading agency figures from the last two decades (and yes, some refused to pose with their former partners), and a selection, sure to generate debate, of the 20 best campaigns of the last 20 years. **********Since it was founded in 1978, Adweek has dueled with its older, larger competitor, Advertising Age, in a rivalry that in Madison Avenue terms could be described as a puckish Pepsi-Cola against a stolid Coca-Cola or an upstart Newsweek against an established Time. In the 1980's, Adweek was castigated by top agency officers who complained that it lacked credibility and was fixated on gossip. That reputation is alluded to playfully in some advertisements in the issue. **********For instance, an ad bought by the J. Walter Thompson Company unit of WPP Group P.L.C. declares: ''Thanks, Adweek, for 20 years of stories about comings and goings, wins and losses, celebrations and scandals. And thanks for all the stories about other agencies too.'' **********And an ad from Seiter & Miller Advertising in New York says: ''For years, we've been trying to get a big splashy spread in Adweek. Now we know. Just pay for it.'' (Actually, the ad is a single page, not a spread.) **********''There are a couple of jabs,'' said Alison Fahey, editor of Adweek, ''but we felt it was only fair.'' **********As for Adweek's once-scarlet reputation, she added, laughing, ''We still print hot rumors, only now they're true.'' **********Adweek was created by three consumer magazine executives -- John C. Thomas Jr., Kenneth Fadner and W. Pendleton Tudor -- who bought and merged three regional trade publications known as ANNY, for Advertising News of New York; SAM, for Serving Advertising in the Midwest, and MAC on the West Coast, for Media Agencies Clients. Editions for New England, the South and the Southwest were added later. **********The executives' experience at magazines like Esquire, Life, New York and Time influenced the decision to have Adweek behave more like a consumer publication than a traditional trade paper. That was reinforced by a splashy design by Walter Berhard, who, Mr. Thomas recalled, suggested the name and produced the ''wonderful red'' cover logo in a type face, Ankzeiden Grotesque, that ''just jumps out at you.'' **********Ms. Fahey and Sid Holt, editor in chief of Adweek, demurred when asked to identify the industry leaders who would not pose for photographs with their former colleagues. **********The only ''group to say no,'' according to Ms. Fahey, was ''the brothers.'' That was of course a reference to Maurice and Charles Saatchi of Saatchi & Saatchi and M&C Saatchi, who ''just kind of said 'Happy anniversary' and very politely declined,'' she said. **********Adweek editors chose the 20 campaigns, Mr. Holt said, based on attributes like creativity, effectiveness and longevity. The best showing was made by the TBWA/Chiat/Day unit of the Omnicom Group and its predecessor agencies, which landed four campaigns on the list, for Absolut vodka, Apple Computer, Energizer batteries and the Nynex Yellow Pages. **********Tied in second place, with two campaigns apiece, were the Publicis & Hal Riney unit of Publicis S.A., for Bartles & Jaymes wine coolers and Saturn automobiles, and Wieden & Kennedy, for ESPN ''Sports Center'' and Nike Inc. **********Now that Adweek has celebrated its 20th anniversary, does Advertising Age intend to publish a 70th anniversary issue in 2000? **********''None planned,'' replied Scott Donaton, the New York-based editor of Advertising Age, owned by Crain Communications Inc. There are plans for two special issues next year, he added, one retrospective titled ''The Advertising Century'' and the other a forward-looking millennium issue. **********Perhaps that issue will assess whether the future will bring what the Wolf Group is predicting in an ad in the special Adweek. The ad presents the front cover of Adweek from Nov. 24, 2018, reporting Wolf winning accounts from General Motors, Microsoft and Pepsi-Cola, including brands like ''Pepsi Lite, Pepsi Phat, Pepsi Day and Pepsi Night.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/busin.snippet: Costco Companies agrees to buy three membership warehouse clubs from Shinsegae Department Store Co of South Korea for about $94 million, expanding discount retailer into that country (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/busin.body_text: **********The Costco Companies agreed today to buy three membership warehouse clubs from the Shinsegae Department Store Company of South Korea for about $94 million, expanding the discount retailer into that country. Two of the stores operate under the Price Club Korea name in Seoul and Taegu, with the third expected to open in Taejon this month. Costco said there were another nine to 10 markets where it would like to add stores. Shinsegae, Korea's oldest department store, will keep a 6 percent stake through a joint venture with Costco.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/09/busin.snippet: Susan Gianinno, who abruptly left J Walter Thompson Co unit of WPP Group on Oct 30, will join D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications, effective Jan 12, in new positions of executive vice president, global marketing director and chief brandin...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/09/busin.main_headline: A top woman executive who abruptly left Thompson re-emerges at D.M.B.& B.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/09/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; A top woman executive who abruptly left Thompson re-emerges at D.M.B.& B.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/09/busin.body_text: **********A TOP woman executive who recently left one big agency in a stormy exit has joined another, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications, as part of that agency's efforts to better interpret consumer behavior and thereby improve the marketing of brand-name products. **********The plans by D.M.B.& B., the flagship agency of the MacManus Group, include forming a unit, the Global Strategic Group, which will specialize in account planning, business development and brand-leadership research. Those efforts are emblematic of ambitious steps being taken by giant agencies to increase their value to clients and fend off attempts by strategic consulting companies -- and the clients themselves -- to perform functions that Madison Avenue has traditionally handled. **********Susan Gianinno, who abruptly left the J. Walter Thompson Company unit of WPP Group on Oct. 30, will join D.M.B.& B., effective Monday, in the new positions of executive vice president, global marketing director and chief branding officer. Ms. Gianinno, 48, had been chief executive of the flagship New York office of Thompson until she suddenly departed ''by mutual consent,'' as her exit was tersely described, after clashing with top management on operational, staffing and personality issues. **********The agency industry has been eagerly watching to see what would become of Ms. Gianinno, who has also held high-level posts at shops like the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group and Young & Rubicam Advertising. Ms. Gianinno, who will also serve on the board of D.M.B.& B., becomes the highest-ranking woman at that agency, which has billings of more than $7.5 billion from multinational clients like the Coca-Cola Company, the General Motors Corporation and the Procter & Gamble Company. **********''The fundamental thing we're all about is building brand leaders,'' Arthur Selkowitz, chairman and chief executive of D.M.B.& B., said in a telephone interview yesterday. ''The way to do that is to have a superior understanding of the consumer, which leads to better, fresher, more powerful creative work that ultimately builds brands.'' **********''Agencies, particularly during economic downturns, have cut back in the area of the strategic understanding of the consumer,'' he added, ''and risk abdicating that to clients and to consulting firms.'' **********Indeed, D.M.B.& B. in March wooed a top executive from one such firm, Booz-Allen & Hamilton, to serve as vice chairman and director for worldwide strategic planning and business development. That executive, Sam Hill, 44, who had been chief marketing officer at Booz-Allen, now takes the titles of vice chairman and chief strategic officer at D.M.B.& B., responsible for operations that include leadership strategy, which concentrates on how brands become leaders; consumer analyses, the strategic analysis of demographic groups and markets, and knowledge management, the realm of research and information services. **********Mr. Hill will continue to report to Mr. Selkowitz. Some of Mr. Hill's duties are being shifted to Ms. Gianinno, who will report to Mr. Selkowitz for parts of her job and to John Farrell, president at D.M.B.& B. North America, for others. **********''It has been a really interesting several weeks,'' said Ms. Gianinno, who joined Mr. Selkowitz for the interview, as she weighed opportunities with agencies, advertisers and the entertainment industry. **********''I have to say that I came away from that most excited about the potential that exists within agencies,'' she added, ''particularly this one, to apply consumer knowledge and insights to brand-building and the creative process.'' **********That reflects a refocusing of agencies' attentions from consumer attitudes to consumer behavior, which is examined with methods not unlike those used by detectives or anthropologists. For instance, account planners can videotape shoppers visiting a mall, explore teen-agers' closets to study apparel preferences or even ask consumers to create collages illustrating what a brand would look like if it were a person. **********''I've been fortunate to work on consumer insights from a number of different angles,'' said Ms. Gianinno, who is by training a behavioral psychologist, ''whether leading an agency, running worldwide accounts or branding and planning.'' **********''Clients are desperate for usable consumer knowledge,'' she added, ''and agencies are best equipped to make that happen.'' **********In another appointment involving the Strategic Consulting Group, Daniel Dahan, chief executive at D.M.B.& B. Advertising/France in Paris, will move to New York in the new position of executive vice president and director for leadership strategy. Mr. Dahan, 53, will head the leadership strategy group and report to Mr. Hill. **********And Tim Arnold, 51, who has been North American business development director, will assume additional responsibilities as worldwide business development coordinator. He will report to Ms. Gianinno.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/04/world.snippet: Many of 8,500 American soldiers in Bosnia have gone from dispassionate observers in confusing land to soldiers who feel their job is to help people they now know and like; map; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/04/world.main_headline: Unlikely Twist: G.I.'s Warm to Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/04/world.print_headline: Unlikely Twist: G.I.'s Warm to Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/04/world.body_text: **********Staff Sgt. Paul Correale noticed the elderly woman in black with the toddler when the two turned to watch his patrol from 50 feet or so away. The child waved a tiny, pink-mittened hand in greeting. **********The sergeant, 34, is a specialist in armed reconnaissance who describes what his training entailed this way: ''They tell us to go out and get information on the enemy so the main force can kill them.'' And that is what he is expected to do in Bosnia if the NATO-led peacekeeping mission deteriorates into combat. **********But, with that pink mitten waving back and forth, his patrol stopped while the sergeant, laughing, ran over to grasp the child's hand. **********''I'm doing what I'm doing for the kids here,'' he said afterward. ''I think the Bosnians are the hardest working, most decent people I've ever seen.'' **********The United States Army has worried about this sort of thing. Senior American officers in Bosnia spent much of the last two years telling their subordinates not to let soldiers get emotionally involved in what they were doing here. There was too high a risk that Western efforts would fail, the officers said, and if the soldiers cared too much about the country their morale might collapse along with the peace. **********But it seems too late for such concerns. To a considerable extent, American forces have gone from dispassionate observers in a confusing land to soldiers who feel their job is to help people they now know and like. **********Senior officers now say it may be better for the Army if the soldiers feel an emotional association with Bosnians. **********Soldiers get constant reinforcement from Bosnians who tell them it is good that the Americans are here.  Psychological screenings of soldiers leaving the danger, discomfort and loneliness of long tours in Bosnia find that the troops feel better about themselves and their jobs than the average American does, according to Army psychologists. **********An immediate benefit for the Army is that soldiers who have been assigned to Bosnia are more likely to re-enlist than others, officers say. This year the re-enlistment rates for some Army units in Europe, from which most the soldiers in Bosnia have come, are more than 50 percent higher than their goals, the Army says. **********In this town there was another statistic to note: The number of times per minute Bosnians smiled and greeted the American patrol. **********As they walked the frozen streets at the bottom of a cup-shaped valley where the mountains, the pine trees and the sky were uniformly white with snow and haze, most of the American soldiers spoke optimistically of their work. **********They did not dwell on the factories destroyed by shelling or the large number of refugees here who are barred from returning to their homes because the country remains splintered along ethnic lines. Instead, the men in this patrol noted the rebuilt homes and hospital. **********Their view of success comes in part from the limited view of their responsibilities expressed by the Army. Their orders do not include having them hunt down indicted war crimes suspects who still powerfully influence politics, although NATO troops are authorized to arrest suspects if security conditions allow.  Nor are they supposed to insure that the victims of so-called ethnic cleansing return to their homes. **********While a fractured Bosnia, brim-full with the unemployed, the homeless and the angry and governed by politicians who will not work together, may yet blow apart, the soldiers are told their work is going well. **********Many of the 8,500 Americans soldiers in Bosnia believe that since their deployment after the December 1995 Dayton accords, they have enforced a peace that is allowing civilian and international agencies to begin rebuilding a country many of them have come to like. **********Walking next to the rebuilt Olovo hospital, fresh plaster on the outside and warm clinics filled with children and their mothers inside, Capt. Dan McIntosh, who commands an armored cavalry company, said: ''Think of what that means to a community to lose its only hospital. And then, we help open it up. That is something. Our soldiers set the conditions for that.'' **********The executive officer of Captain McIntosh's company, First Lieut. Daniel Fickel, 25, of Miami, said his father tells him that what he is doing in Bosnia now is similar to what his father did earlier in the Peace Corps. **********''We're really helping people,'' Lieutenant Fickel said. ''You can't  send soldiers halfway around the world to save a country and then say don't get emotionally involved.'' **********Though the American Army policy has been to insist all three ethnic groups -- Serbs, Muslims and Croats -- be treated exactly the same, many soldiers feel that the Muslims, who have the highest number of displaced in Bosnia now, suffered the most during the 1992-95 war. Nearly everyone in Bosnia is relieved the fighting has stopped, but Muslims are convinced the West stopped a war of annihilation that was directed against them, and probably feel especially appreciative toward the peacekeepers. **********But with Western governments pressing Bosnian authorities to carry out terms of the peace agreement, there have been times when the NATO-led forces, including Americans, have met violence. **********The worst case for the Americans was in August, when troops tried to install a more cooperative police commander in Brcko in the Bosnian Serb-controlled area and mobs organized by local Serbian authorities blocked the attempt. Civilians attacked American soldiers with stones and gasoline bombs. **********Despite such incidents, relations between most Bosnians and American troops have been good. **********In Olovo, a town named for the lead mined here since Roman times and now inhabited mostly by Muslims, Sergeant Correale seems to have found a place he likes. **********Displaying considerable knowledge of medieval Bosnian history, Sergeant Correale, of Huber Heights, Ohio, pointed out a citadel-like building poking through the snow halfway up a mountain and explained that it was one of two centuries-old Roman Catholic monasteries in the area. He added that, based on his reading in the five months since he came here, he has come to doubt the theory that the recent fighting in Bosnia was an inevitable continuation of longstanding ethnic antagonisms. **********It is easier now for soldiers to study history and become acquainted with Bosnians than it was in January 1996, when the American troops fought rain, blizzards and a churning Sava River to enter this country. Then, everything was arduous, everywhere was dangerous and living conditions were terrible. **********But as political tensions have eased and the Army has become accustomed to working in Bosnia, the soldier's life here has improved. **********Even so, soldiers raised questions that senior officers say trouble them as well. **********''I think we are doing good, but it is taking a lot out of everyone,'' said Sgt. Sabrina Pinkard, a medical technician from Columbus, Ohio, who is based at Camp Gentry, a rather isolated base on the northern edge of the American sector. **********Referring to the Army's downsizing and the increase in overseas deployments in recent years, she said, ''If our unit keeps getting sent places, here or wherever, with no time to rest and catch up, we are going to wear out.'' **********''She's right,'' said Pvt. David Quinn, also with the Second Cavalry Regiment. Thinking about the stress on soldiers who are separated from their families, he said, ''We got our own trouble back home, too.'' **********Soldiers say what makes them think their mission is worthwhile is the balance between the personal burden and the task at hand. In Bosnia, they are getting extra pay and bonuses. Many feel that are sharpening their military skills. And life on their bases, though still difficult, has become less uncomfortable. **********At Camp Demi in north-central Bosnia, where the soldiers patrolling the town of Olovo are based, a dinner last week offered choices of 6 entrees including pretty tasty burritos, 6 vegetables, 12 kinds of salad and 8 desserts. **********Talk around the base was about how the Army has settled in in Bosnia. The mission has gone from short and arduous to something of indefinite length that has become part of the Army's life. **********Soldiers said they were not at all surprised by President Clinton's recent announcement that there is no longer a deadline to withdraw the troops from Bosnia. It seemed clear, many thought, that Bosnia was going to be an assignment to be rotated among combat units for some time. **********''I guess it's going to be somewhere between like what we did in Haiti and what we're doing in Korea,'' said Specialist Jason Suddeth, 21 from Galesburg, Ill.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/17/busin.body_text: **********Hoechst A.G., Europe's No. 4 chemical maker, and the United States buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company ended talks on Kohlberg Kravis's purchase of Hoechst's paint unit. The Frankfurt-based Hoechst said Kohlberg Kravis had reduced the price it was prepared to pay for the Herberts paint unit below what Hoechst would accept. In August, Kohlberg Kravis agreed in principle to pay 3 billion marks ($1.86 billion) for Herberts, Europe's leading coatings supplier. The news comes at the end of a week in which Hoechst warned that its 1998 earnings will fall from last year's level, as business in Asia, Latin America and Russia slumps. Hoechst said yesterday that it was in talks with other companies that have shown interest in buying Herberts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/26/world.snippet: United Nations war crimes tribunal is stepping up its investigations of war crimes in Serbian province of Kosovo; team of investigators, lawyers and military analysts has made its first fact-finding mission to area and is scheduled to go again soo...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/26/world.main_headline: U.N. War Crimes Tribunal Steps Up Its Inquiry Into Kosovo
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/26/world.print_headline: U.N. War Crimes Tribunal Steps Up Its Inquiry Into Kosovo
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/26/world.body_text: **********The United Nations war crimes tribunal is stepping up its investigations of war crimes in the Serbian province of Kosovo. **********The International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia has assembled a team of investigators, lawyers and military analysts to focus exclusively on Kosovo, tribunal officials said. Members of that team have made their first fact-finding mission to the area and are scheduled to go again soon. **********The investigators have instructions to identify the people responsible for the ongoing shelling and torching of civilian areas in Kosovo. And they are examining accounts that numerous civilians, most of them ethnic Albanians, have been kidnapped and killed in circumstances that cannot be defined as military combat. **********In recent weeks, thanks to additional United Nations funds earmarked for Kosovo, the tribunal has been able to hire about a dozen new experts. ''Kosovo is definitely one of our priorities,'' said Graham Blewitt, the tribunal's deputy prosecutor. ''We are doing all we can, collecting information, assembling cases and drawing up plans for indictments.'' **********Mr. Blewitt added that the tribunal was looking into war crimes by both parties in the conflict, a comment that seemed to address the frequent charges from Serbia that the tribunal was anti-Serb. **********''Our investigation involves not just Serbs but also the Kosovo Liberation Army,'' he said. ''There are allegations of war crimes on both sides.'' **********Since the conflict in Kosovo began early this year, the United Nations Security Council, which created the tribunal, has maintained that the court's jurisdiction includes Kosovo. The tribunal's chief prosecutor has repeated the point in the face of Serbian claims that events in the province of Kosovo are an internal affair. The tribunal was created in 1993 to prosecute war crimes in the territory of the former Yugoslavia since 1991. This jurisdiction is ongoing and has no expiration date. **********The dispute over war crimes, even as they are going on, once again raises the question of the purpose of the tribunal and whether it can fulfill its role to help heal war wounds and act as a deterrent. The six trials now going at The Hague involve war crimes from Bosnia and Croatia.  Seen from The Hague, where high-minded principles of international law are repeated in the quiet corridors and courtrooms, the events in Kosovo are remote. The horror of the refugees and of distant burning villages is hard to fathom. Human rights activists, aid workers and military observers report that 240,000 people, perhaps one-tenth of the population, have been left homeless by the Serbian drive to secure Kosovo from rebels who are fighting for independence. **********However remote the court may be from Kosovo, some tribunal officials believe it has made a difference. **********''We got more reports of atrocities, of summary executions, kidnappings and murders by the Serb police earlier this year,'' one senior official said. ''There's obviously still a lot of suffering and destruction. But we're not getting as much evidence of atrocities in the past few months since the prosecutor made it clear that the tribunal is involved.'' **********It would be hard to prove, he said, ''but it is possible that the prosecutor's several warnings have lessened the crimes.'' **********''It is also possible,'' he added, ''that the Serb military who got more involved from June onward had different instructions.'' **********Investigators are looking into war crimes such as mistreatment of civilians and prisoners of war along with arbitrary arrests, torture and killing, all of which are not related to direct military actions. **********''As bloody and messy and violent as war is, we need to establish there was criminal action,'' one official close to the investigation said. ''If the Serb army is trying to retake an area, the mere fact of shelling or bombing does not make the actions into war crimes.'' **********''But the wanton destruction of a village that is not a military target, where there are no military objectives or soldiers present, that is a war crime,'' he said. **********Drawing lessons from their slow progress in investigating war crimes in Bosnia and Croatia, prosecutors have changed strategy in their work on Kosovo. **********Mr. Blewitt, the deputy prosecutor, said that in Kosovo investigators would focus on people in positions of authority, ''the people who made things happen or who could prevent them from happening.''
