https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/18/busin.body_text: **********Christy & Viener, a Manhattan law firm of about 70 lawyers, is merging with Salans Hertzfeld & Heilbronn, a European law firm, in the first trans-Atlantic law firm merger. **********Partners of the firms said yesterday that the merger, creating a firm of nearly 300 lawyers, would help them serve global companies. **********''In times of uncertainty, clients seek out law firms with longstanding experience and expertise in different markets,'' said James S. Boynton, a partner at Christy & Viener. ''The merged firm is well positioned to meet this challenge.'' **********Lisa R. Smith at Hildabrandt Inc., a consulting firm in Somerset, N.J., said she expected more international law firm mergers. ''Firms that have been thinking about merging will now move more quickly,'' she said. ''They don't want to be left behind.'' **********When these law firms merge on Jan. 1, the firm will practice in New York as Salans Hertzfeld Heilbronn Christy & Viener and will be known elsewhere as Salans Hertzfeld & Heilbronn. **********Besides Manhattan, the law firm will have offices in London, Paris, Warsaw, Moscow and St. Petersburg as well as in Kiev, Ukraine, and Almaty, Kazakhstan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/04/world.snippet: Gerhard Schroder, who made his name in German politics in 1970's as leader of Social Democratic Party's radical, stridently anti-American, anti-nuclear youth group, has veered toward center over the years and now hopes to unseat Helmut Kohl in nat...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/04/world.main_headline: THE CHALLENGER: A special report.; A German Socialist Veers Toward the Center
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/04/world.print_headline: THE CHALLENGER: A special report.; A German Socialist Veers Toward the Center
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/04/world.body_text: **********Gerhard Schroder has changed with the times. **********He first made his name in German politics in the 1970's as leader of the Jusos, the radical, stridently anti-American, anti-nuclear youth group of the Social Democratic Party. In 1981, in his maiden speech in Parliament, he became the first man ever to speak there without wearing a necktie. Late one beer-fueled night, according to an often-told story, he stopped by to rattle the gates of the Chancellery, and to shout, ''I want in there!'' **********But the higher he rose and the older he got, the less rambunctious he became. He grew to admire the United States, he says. As premier of Germany's second largest and third most populous state for the last eight years, he as been the consummate pragmatist, cooperating with or disregarding the left-wing party hierarchy according to his purposes. He not only started wearing neckties, he took to smoking fine Havana cigars and sporting clothes designed by Armani. **********He got so chummy with business executives that trade unionists and other ideological stalwarts in his party started mocking him as ''der Genosse von Bossen'' -- the comrade of the bosses. **********Now the Social Democrats, who have failed three times to oust Chancellor Helmut Kohl, have turned to Gerhard Schroder to do the job in a national election on Sept. 27. Handsome, telegenic, a ferocious worker, Mr. Schroder, 54, is almost a generation younger than Mr. Kohl, who is 68. Not by accident, he is running a media-savvy campaign as ambiguous and devoid of specifics as those that brought Tony Blair and Bill Clinton to power in Britain and the United States. **********Mr. Schroder must grapple with the problem that has confronted left-wing politicians throughout Europe as well as the Democrats in the United States: big government has become too costly. **********Partly because of the huge expenditures in eastern Germany after reunification, partly because of the competition with countries that have learned to live with less, Germany can no longer afford the restrictive labor laws, ample pensions and generous health care system with which Mr. Schroder's party has been identified. ''There is no more West German island,'' said a Western diplomat here.  ''Germany has to live by the same rules as the rest of us, which means cutting back. That's the real dilemma for Schroder and his party.'' **********A victory would make Mr. Schroder one of Europe's most powerful men, standing at the helm of the continent's dominant economic and political power. It would also constitute an unprecedented accomplishment in modern German history; no sitting Chancellor has been defeated by a candidate of another party since the federal republic was established in 1949. **********The polls put him ahead, but only by a slender margin, with a sizable undecided vote. Germany is accustomed to a more carnivorous, less image-oriented politics, with plenty of ideological meat to chew on, and people are starting to grumble. **********''You can't quite get hold of him,'' said Josef Joffe, editorial page editor of the Suddeutsche Zeitung of Munich, one of the country's major newspapers. ''He was given the nod very grudgingly by the party bosses, who stand well to his left, because they were convinced he was the only one with a chance to win. So he tries to placate the left wing of his party and to win over the swing voters at the same time.'' **********''He obfuscates, prevaricates and says as little as possible.'' **********Michael Naumann, the German-born New York publisher whom Mr. Schroder has recruited as a potential culture minister, takes a different view. He sees Mr. Schroder as a man who has the capacity to answer a national craving, ''to fill this big psychological hole at the center of German life, the need to define what we live for in the midst of our amazing material well-being.'' **********Above all, he has a fresh face.  Mr. Kohl has been Chancellor for 16 years, as long as Franklin D. Roosevelt would have served as President had he not died in office. Mr. Schroder has apparently concluded that the electorate is tired of Mr. Kohl but resistant to a major deviation from his policies. So he talks, in pure Clintonese, of ''a New Middle.'' **********Recognizing Limits To Welfare State **********In mid-August, on the day before he announced his party's election program, Mr. Schroder sat down for an interview at the party's striking steel-and-glass headquarters, Willy Brandt Haus, in the heart of the new Berlin. **********''The welfare state has reached its limits,'' he said, sitting at a table covered with the detritus typical of campaigns everywhere -- half-eaten sandwiches and empty coffee cups. ''We won't be able to increase payments.'' **********You could almost hear the echo of Bill Clinton's voice proclaiming the era of big government over. **********But like generations of liberal politicians eager to sound a note of fiscal responsibility, Mr. Schroder insisted that by closing ''a labyrinth of tax loopholes,'' he could roll back the small welfare cuts made by Mr. Kohl and still cut income taxes. ''It's not that much of a riddle,'' he said. **********An engaging man with a large head, a boldly cut jaw and the beefy body of a former linebacker, Mr. Schroder spoke quietly but gestured vigorously with his squarish hands, waving a pair of half-moon spectacles as he talked.  His eyes are his most notable feature -- ice blue under fair, bushy brows and unwelcoming until he laughs, which he does often, in private as well as on the stump. **********''I've had to give up the old Hegelian idea that when theory and reality clash, reality is wrong,'' he said, apropos of his move to the middle. ''Reality is often right.'' **********Asked whether he feared that Mr. Kohl would try to discredit him by talking about the radicalism of his youth, Mr. Schroder responded, ''I don't think so. As you see, the revolution I planned didn't take place, so there's no point in bringing up what I said then.'' **********He added, in a paraphrase of what he said at Georgetown University earlier this year: ''Learning is the essence of politics. You should never trust politicians who think they have nothing left to learn any more.'' **********But Mr. Schroder predicted that his opponents might try to discredit him by talking about his private life, although Germans, he said, were less interested in scandal and gossip ''than you Americans or even the British.'' **********Mr. Schroder has been married four times. The first marriage lasted 3 years, the second 9 and the third 12, breaking up bitterly two years ago. When he eloped with Doris Kopf, a journalist from Bavaria, the spurned third wife, Hiltrud Hamel, called him ''a coward, an opportunist and an egotist.'' **********Although the Christian Democratic leaders have refrained so far from personal criticism, the party's youth group has produced a brochure that tackles the marriage issue. ''Schroder is a bad choice,'' it says. ''Three women couldn't be wrong.'' **********In another indirect assault, the owner of a big German car-rental company called Sixt is running a magazine advertisement that shows two pictures of Mr. Schroder, one looking left and the other looking right. ''Sixt,'' the caption declares, ''has cars for people who don't know where they want to go.'' **********One of the biggest questions about Mr. Schroder's destination is who would help him get there. It appears highly unlikely that the Social Democrats will gain a clear majority, even if they win, so he would need a coalition partner.  There are two possibilities -- an alliance with the Greens or teaming up with the Christian Democrats in the kind of grand coalition Germany had under Kurt Georg Kiesinger from 1966 to 1969. **********When his visitor suggested that a coalition with the often erratic Greens would make more sense in the party context, because they are more ideologically compatible, but a grand coalition would make more sense in a governmental context because of greater stability Mr. Schroder agreed. Then he added, with a malicious little grin:  ''There's an old saying in this country: If you want to be successful, think first of your country, then of your party.'' **********Whose old saying? he was asked. **********''Mine,'' he answered. **********But the decision will not be his alone. Parties matter more in German politics than in the United States, and Mr. Schroder does not yet control his party. Oskar Lafontaine, the party leader, is giving stout backing to Mr. Schroder for now, though he looked noticeably jumpy recently as Mr. Schroder announced the party program.  Many people wonder what he will do once the ballots have been counted, and the Christian Democrats are trying to play on that, suggesting that it would be the party bosses rather than Mr. Schroder who would call the ideological tune in choosing a partner and framing Government policy. **********Trying to Emulate Clinton and Blair **********Mr. Schroder tries to equate himself to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Blair. But the parallel is inexact.  Each of them took office having already won the main ideological arguments within his own party, and Mr. Schroder, if he wins, would become Chancellor with important questions still unresolved. **********For example, Mr. Lafontaine, a harsh critic of ''billionaire capitalists,'' wants to cut the top income tax rate from 53 percent to 49, while Mr. Schroder wants to bring it down to 45. Mr. Schroder sometimes emphasizes a ''modern'' Germany that shines in new technology, as when he named Jost Stillman, a businessman, as an economic adviser; other times he attacks the pension reform and labor flexibility that modernizers consider mandatory. **********Nor is it clear, despite tens of thousands of words and endless columns of analysis in the newspapers, exactly what Mr. Schroder would do to attack unemployment, one of Germany's most serious and intractable problems. **********The party platform says a Schroder Government would expect labor unions to permit ''the more flexible organization of work.'' Business, it continues, needs to invest more, innovate more and provide more apprenticeships. The Government itself, it says, needs to shrink the bureaucracy and increase public spending on research. **********It promises a ''crash program'' to fight joblessness among the young by bringing 100,000 unemployed young people into training programs. **********But the nuts and bolts of the program are still missing. Persuading labor and business to work together, devising practical programs and finding the money to pay for them would be the job of Walter Riester, the highly regarded 54-year-old deputy chairman of the powerful metalworkers' union, who has been designated as the labor-minister-to-be in a Schroder Government. **********One thing seems plain: with Mr. Schroder as Chancellor, Germany will remain a firm ally of the United States. Diplomats from both countries seem sure of this, as do officials Mr. Schroder met during his recent trip to Washington. **********Sometimes he stretches a point to dramatize his conversion from anti-American views. He tells people that ''my daughter was born in New York,'' when in fact she is his stepdaughter by his fourth marriage, and until 1997, he had not visited the United States in more than 15 years. **********But there is no doubt that Mr. Schroder admires Mr. Clinton's political style, especially his success in repositioning himself and his party. Mr. Schroder has embraced issues like crime that the Christian Democrats long dominated. He has even hired Hank Sheinkopf, a Clinton adviser in 1996, to help with instant rebuttal and research on the opposition. **********In the conversation at the party headquarters, Mr. Schroder said that despite an all-party agreement that Germany will not commit military forces abroad except on a United Nations mandate, he could not conceive of Germany holding back from intervening in the embattled Serbian province of Kosovo if the United Nations was silent and other European nations wanted to act. That would please the United States, which has long felt that the Europeans have been too slow to police their own turf. **********In a long career, Mr. Schroder, who is known as Gerd, has managed to find a way forward when others might well have felt stymied. **********He had no more promising a start in life than Bill Clinton. His father, a conscript, was killed during the retreat from Russia when Mr. Schroder was only three days old, and his mother raised him alone while working as a cleaning woman. He dropped out of school at 14, went to night school and ended up studying law at Gottingen University during the turbulence of 1968. **********These days, Mr. Schroder handles hecklers, commonplace in German politics, with great aplomb. Asked how he learned, he replied, ''By heckling.'' **********Climbing the Rungs Of the Political Ladder **********After a stint as an member of Parliament in Bonn, he won his party's nomination for premier in the state of Lower Saxony in 1984.  He lost that time, but won four years later. Last March, he gained a third term in a landslide, a victory that clinched his nomination for Chancellor. **********Except for the good suits and expensive cigars, Mr. Schroder lives unpretentiously in a smallish apartment in Hanover, the state capital. He has no vast entourage, disdaining all but the most basic security protection. **********Lower Saxony, covering most of the northwestern corner of the country, is perhaps best known outside Germany for the fact that Hanover's ruling family acceded to the British throne in the person of George I in 1714. The state includes Hamlen, where the Pied Piper played, and Wolfsburg, headquarters of Volkswagen. **********A seat on the Volkswagen board goes with the premier's job because the state government is the company's largest shareholder.  And that, by all accounts, has had a major impact on Mr. Schroder's life. In a number of ways, he modeled himself on the company's wily chairman, Ferdinand Piech. **********For centuries, Hanover has held annual trade fairs, and Mr. Schroder became a regular at them, courting businessmen, inviting them to dinner at a favorite Italian restaurant or to a game of tennis. **********But he always kept his fences mended with younger, more proletarian groups as well. Dr. Ludolf von Wertenberg, the head of the Federation of German Industries, who was a Christian Democratic member of Parliament when Mr. Schroder was in Bonn, recalled that Mr. Schroder always asked beforehand who would be in the audience when he was invited to make a speech. **********Keeping a Close Eye On the Audience **********''Students? He'd show up in a turtleneck,'' Dr. von Wertenberg said in an interview in his Cologne office. ''Entrepreneurs? The whitest shirt you ever saw. He's amazingly good on his feet, never uses texts or notes if he can avoid it, and if he sensed that what he was saying wasn't going over well, he'd change gears within seconds. Nice guy, provacateur, it didn't matter, as long as he wasn't ignored.'' **********He bulled his way to the nomination for Chancellor, taking his case over the heads of the party leaders to the rank-and-file. **********''Schroder's will for power is certainly impressive,'' the former party chairman, Hans-Jochen Vogel, wrote in his memoirs. ''But the question increasingly is, What does he want to do with that power?'' **********But the leaders gave him his shot at the Chancellorship anyway, and he opened his campaign two weeks ago with three rallies in a single day, in Berlin, Munich and Bonn. Relaxed, at times almost professorial in his interviews and news conferences, he let it rip on the stump. His voice hoarse from shouting, his face almost as red as his power necktie, Mr. Schroder greeted the crowds with both arms aloft in a V-for-Victory sign like Richard M. Nixon's. **********At Rheinaue Park in Bonn, along the riverfront, there were bratwurst stands and beer vendors, hot-air balloons and rock musicians. Some in the audience wore football jerseys marked ''Schroder 10'' -- a reference to the candidate's habit of giving people a flyer listing nine reasons to vote for the Social Democrats and telling them, ''The 10th is Helmut Kohl.'' **********There was also a lot of talk, from Mr. Schroder and other party figures about building an economy that was both humane and efficient, some complaints about the lot of the lowest-paid people in German society and the inevitable vague allusion to a new alliance linking labor, management and government. **********But there was not a single mention of socialism. **********Occasionally, Mr. Schroder got into some tried-and-true Social Democratic grooves, lambasting the Government, for example, for allowing disabled workers to collect only 80 per cent of their wages when sick. This, he said, ''is not social justice; they can't go to the store and pay 80 per cent of the price of a loaf of bread or get their landlord to give them a 20 percent discount.'' **********That went over well enough with the crowd of 8,000 to 10,000, although they had been soaked by rains. But what they had on their minds most of all, it seemed, was what Mr. Schroder is concentrating on: winning. **********Their loudest cheers came when he told them: ''We want to win -- we will win -- because we want to do -- we will do -- something for the German people.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/02/world.snippet: International market analysts say Venezuela's economy has been crippled by overvalued currency, government interference in monetary policy and irresponsible spending that relies too heavily on oil revenues; Col Hugo Chavez Frias, leading president...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/02/world.main_headline: Mistakes Hobble Venezuelan Economy, Experts Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/02/world.print_headline: WORLD ECONOMIES: IN LATIN AMERICA; Mistakes Hobble Venezuelan Economy, Experts Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/02/world.body_text: **********With investment holdings flying out of this country, international market analysts widely agree that Venezuela's economy has been crippled by an overvalued currency, government interference in monetary policy and irresponsible spending that relies too heavily on oil revenues. **********Many Venezuelans, however, beg to disagree. **********Their political mood seems to be swinging in precisely the opposite direction, with an overwhelming majority apparently convinced that the  oil wealth should guarantee decent salaries, government services, job protection and retirement benefits. Instead, with 80 percent of the population said to be living in poverty, the country faces broad suspicions of market changes, widely described here as ''capitalsmo salvaje,'' or ''savage capitalism.'' **********The leading candidate for the presidency by a wide margin is Hugo Chavez Frias, 44, a populist retired army colonel who led a coup attempt against President Carlos Andres Perez in 1992. Mr. Andres Perez was the architect of a short-lived stab at free-market changes in the early 1990's. **********Colonel Chavez is leading the polls with 46 percent, with his nearest rival, Henrique Salas Romer, trailing at 27 percent, according to a polling service, Datanalisis. **********Colonel Chavez, trading in his uniform and red beret for business suits as he campaigns, has raised the specter of protectionist barriers to foreign trade, hinted at the possibilities of a one- or two-year moratorium on debt payments and pledged to review concessions that the state has granted foreign oil companies. **********Those measures have been widely seen as hostile to foreign investors. **********Colonel Chavez's populist message, faulting government corruption for siphoning 15 percent of public revenues, resonates with Venezuelans who are hard pressed to reconcile the petroleum wealth with the fiscal difficulties. Colonel Chavez has called for a halt to privatization of state assets, at least, he says, until the country has some assurance that the revenues from the sales of assets are going to the national budget rather than the personal accounts of that corrupt officials have in Miami. **********''He's a nationalist,'' said Omar Lambaia, 53, a retired military photographer who drives a taxicab. Mr. Lambaia retired 11 years ago and collects a pension equal to the full salary of an officer on active duty, but he said the Government was shortchanging him. **********''Of course,'' Mr. Lambaia said, ''I'm democratic. But when you see that democracy is not doing anything for your country, that it's destroying the country, you become a nationalist.'' **********A survey by a poll analyst, Alfredo Keller, found that more than 85 percent of Venezuelans felt cheated out of the benefits of the oil wealth. **********''It's a mining-boom-town mentality that weakens the notion that one's well-being is tied to personal effort,'' said Robert Bottome, publisher of a newsletter, Veneconomy. **********Because of its failure to reduce the Civil Service system and revise its pension system, the Government has essentially used the revenues it gained during earlier years of high oil prices to pay the salaries of workers who are not really needed. More than 30 percent of the government budget goes to pay off debt, said Hugo Faria, a consultant at the Institute of Advanced Studies in Business. **********The price of oil, responsible for nearly half the country's revenues, has dropped a third in recent months, taking the bottom out of the economy. The stock market has dropped more than 70 percent this year. **********Analysts say the Venezuelan bolivar is overvalued by up to 40 percent. Although the Government has repeatedly denied plans to devalue the bolivar, expectations of a devaluation persist. That is forcing the Government to spend down international reserves to $13 billion to protect the bolivar and to pump up interest rates for short-term bonds to borrow additional money. **********At least $4.1 billion in short-term bond is due in coming months, further draining dollar reserves. **********''The market is jumping ahead so fast that nobody is willing to hold bolivars, because they don't know when the devaluation will come,'' said Mr. Bottome. **********Lending rates to consumers are hovering at 100 percent a year, and even at those rates the terms are punishing. Banks demand that company presidents put up their houses and cars as collateral for business loans. **********Yesterday, Standard & Poor revised its rating of Venezuela's financial prospects downward, to negative from stable. The service cited resistance from the presidency to the man in the street to ''essential market-oriented reforms needed to stabilize the economy.'' **********The agency said that fixed costs like debt service, Social Security and personnel took up 75 percent of Government spending and that the main source of government financing, oil revenues, was subject to shifts on the world market. The agency predicted that the Venezuelan budget deficit would reach 4 percent of the gross domestic product.

Safeguard, based in Wayne, Pa., is a computer-services and software company. Pac-West, based in Stockton, Calif., offers local phone service to customers in California. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/12/world.snippet: Moshood K O Abiola, Nigerian opposition leader, died of heart disease, according to American and other Western doctors who performed autopsy; their preliminary report would seem to rule out foul play; it confirms official account given by Nigerian...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/12/world.main_headline: Autopsy Says Heart Disease Killed Abiola
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/12/world.print_headline: Autopsy Says Heart Disease Killed Abiola
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/12/world.body_text: **********American and other Western doctors who completed an autopsy today on the body of Moshood K. O. Abiola, the Nigerian opposition leader who died in detention on Tuesday, said they had found no evidence of poisoning and concluded that his death was caused by heart disease. **********The preliminary report, anxiously awaited by an angry and disoriented nation, showed that ''there was severe longstanding disease of the heart of a type and severity that can cause unexpected death,'' said Dr. James G. Young, the Chief Coroner of the Province of Ontario. **********The results, confirming the official account of Mr. Abiola's death given by the Nigerian military Government, seemed unlikely to assuage Nigerians, who have reacted with fury to the death of the opposition leader on the eve of his promised release by the new military ruler, Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar. **********Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, has been ruled by military governments for all but 10 years of its 38 years of independence. Mr. Abiola, who appeared poised to win presidential elections in 1993 when the armed forces annulled the vote, incarnated the country's long-frustrated hopes for democracy. He was imprisoned by the military Government on charges of treason in 1994. **********Dr. Young, who headed a five-man team including two American doctors and an American technician, said that after a detailed examination of the body including the abdomen, chest and brain, and after conversations with witnesses present at the time of death, ''we believe that poisoning is extremely unlikely.'' **********But he added that for the sake of complete certainty, toxicological examinations of samples taken from the body would be performed at the Center of Forensic Science in Ontario. He said that tissue samples would also undergo microscopic examination in London and that a final report would be issued in three weeks. **********Family members and followers of Mr. Abiola have argued that he was poisoned, pointing to the cup of tea he drank with the United States Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, Thomas R. Pickering, and other American and Nigerian officials shortly before he was taken ill. **********But Dr. Young said nothing that happened on the day of Mr. Abiola's death, or that was in his body, ''lead us to believe that poisoning was a factor.'' He added, ''At this time, our preliminary opinion is that death was due to natural causes as a result of his longstanding heart disease.'' **********Mr. Abiola, 60, had never had a heart attack before. Dr. Young said his team had not been given any written medical reports compiled during the opposition leader's four years in detention, but had talked to Nigerian medical officials who said they had seen him in those years. **********''For me, it's irrelevant,'' Kola Abiola, the opposition leader's son, said of the autopsy. ''You don't have to poison a man, you don't have to spike his tea, to kill him. My father was locked up for four years without proper medical treatment, and that is what leads to death. We know who was responsible for locking him up.'' **********Kola Abiola today presided at the tumultuous burial of Mr. Abiola in the front yard of the large Abiola family compound in Lagos. Women sobbed and men wailed as the body, wrapped in white cloth as prescribed by Muslim custom, was laid to rest in the red earth, beneath a palm tree, just eight hours after the autopsy. **********For a national figure of such standing, the attendance was not huge, amounting to perhaps 500 people. Representatives of the Government were conspicuously absent. Although General Abubakar said this week that the death of Mr. Abiola represented ''one of the saddest moments of our life,'' he was a prominent member of the Government of Gen. Sani Abacha that jailed him. **********Given the impassioned mood of the mourners, any attempt by military figures to appear would almost certainly have led to bloodshed. **********The army and military police officers initially deployed about 50 yards from Mr. Abiola's house, but later fell back before protesters, taking up positions about 500 yards away from it. Although they blocked some people, they did not use their automatic rifles. Clearly, General Abubakar had called for restraint. **********Mr. Abiola, a man of the southwestern Yoruba tribe who had converted to Islam, the faith of the Hausa and closely related Fulani tribes of the north, tried to overcome the ethnic divisions of his country. **********His death, just as it seemed he would be freed, has left many Nigerians with a sense of deep frustration at a moment when General Abubakar is talking about the need to put the army back in the barracks and restore democracy. Sporadic rioting, in which as many as 50 people have died, has gripped the country since Tuesday, but Lagos was calm today. **********Dr. Young, who arrived here on Thursday, said the autopsy showed that Mr. Abiola had longstanding heart disease of two types, both of which could cause unexpected death. ''There was severe narrowing of the main coronary arteries by fatty plaques,'' he said. ''In addition there was very significant enlargement of the heart due to longstanding hypertension.'' **********The doctor declined to be drawn into discussing whether four years of imprisonment might have contributed to this hypertension by causing extreme stress. ''Is it desirable to have the best of diets and the most stress-free life?'' he said. ''Yes, of course it is.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/24/busin.snippet: Boeing Co stuns investors with news of steep drop in second-quarter earnings and even more unexpected warning that results for both this year and next will be about 40 percent below Wall Street estimates; earnings fell 46 percent, to $258 million ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY REPORTS; Boeing Earnings News Disappoints Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/24/busin.body_text: **********The Boeing Company stunned investors yesterday with news of a steep drop in second-quarter earnings and an even more unexpected warning that results for both this year and next will be about 40 percent below Wall Street estimates. **********The announcement from the world's largest aerospace company caused a 13 percent drop in Boeing's share price and was one of the catalysts for a nearly 200-point decline in the Dow Jones industrial average. Boeing shares, one of the Dow average's component stocks, had been rallying in recent weeks. **********''They know how to build bombs,'' said Howard Rubel, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, ''and they delivered one today.'' **********Boeing's results and the guidance it offered for next year helped convince investors that the company is not likely to cash in on the current boom in commercial aircraft sales because of its high costs and stiff price competition from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium that is Boeing's main rival. **********For the quarter that ended June 30, earnings fell 46 percent, to $258 million, or 26 cents a diluted share, compared with  $476 million, or 48 cents a diluted share, in the comparable period last year. The average forecast for the quarter by analysts was 33 cents a share, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks corporate earnings estimates. **********Boeing's revenue rose 9 percent, to $13.4 billion, from $12.3 billion in 1997. The company said it took a $78 million after-tax charge during the quarter to account for costs related to its previously announced decision to stop making the MD-11 jetliner and for penalties paid to airlines because of late deliveries of the new version of its single-aisle 737 jet. **********Investors reacted by dumping Boeing shares, which fell $6.5625, to $41.1875, in New York Stock Exchange trading on volume that exceeded 28 million shares. During the day the share price touched $40.0625, a 52-week low. **********Boeing has been struggling to right itself since last fall, when a surge in commercial airplane orders overwhelmed its assembly lines. The production difficulties have forced the company to take more than $3 billion in charges and delayed long-planned productivity improvements aimed at cutting costs. **********In addition, the costs of merging with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which it purchased for $16.3 billion last year, have proved to be more than expected and the economic crisis in Asia has dampened the demand for new airplanes from some of Boeing's best customers. **********As a result of these trials, Boeing's commercial airplane division, which represents about 60 percent of overall revenue, lost money in the first half of this year. The company predicted that the division's profit margins would be between zero and 1 percent this year, rising to between 2 and 4 percent in 1999 -- far lower than many analysts had expected. **********Philip M. Condit, chairman and chief executive of the Seattle-based company, acknowledged that the company's performance had been weak. But he said that he was determined to transform Boeing from a company that focuses primarily on the performance of its products to one that is ''financially driven.'' **********He outlined a series of ambitious goals, including raising Boeing's annual return on sales to 7 percent from its current level of 2 percent. The company also aims to save money by turning over its inventory four times a year rather than just two. **********Given Boeing's recent performance, even the company's short-term goals would appear beyond its grasp. Boeing plans to produce 620 planes next year, up from 546 in 1998. At the same time, it expects to reduce overall employment by the end of next year to between 210,000 and 220,000 from 238,000 today. **********Mr. Condit acknowledged that consistently earning a 7 percent return on sales would not be easy, though he said it could be achieved by 2000. ''This is clearly a difficult goal,'' he told analysts. ''This is not one we have reached before. We have only come close at the peak.'' **********Indeed, there are already warning signs that assurances from Mr. Condit earlier this month that Boeing's production difficulties were finally under control may have been premature. Yesterday Boeing said that expensive out-of-sequence work on its 747 production line had risen nearly 20 percent since July 1 and was above the company's plan. **********''It's worrying, but it is not disastrous,'' said Harry Stonecipher, Boeing's president. **********The situation in Asia also seems to be worsening. Boeing said it currently has 20 completed airplanes in storage waiting for final payment arrangements by Asian customers. Singapore Air said yesterday that it was deferring delivery of one 747, eight 777's and two Airbus A340's beyond 2000. Korean Air has also said that it will probably defer some 747's and 777's scheduled for delivery next year. **********Nevertheless, Mr. Condit said that after seeing its cash reserves drop to $3.5 billion this quarter from $5.1 billion at the end of 1997, Boeing expects to begin generating a lot of cash next year. **********Boyd Givan, the company's chief financial officer, said the money might be used for a share repurchase plan. Whether that will be enough to appease investors is unclear. **********''I don't think they are particularly proud of what they handed everybody today,'' Mr. Rubel said. ''At the same token, the hype is gone. The pieces on the board have moved back to Go. They now have to roll up their sleeves and work harder than they ever have before.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/24/techn.main_headline: Portable Music Player Uses No Tape or Disk -- Just RAM
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/24/techn.print_headline: NEWS WATCH; Portable Music Player Uses No Tape or Disk -- Just RAM
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/24/techn.body_text: **********A popular way to buy, trade and download music on the Internet may now become even more popular. The Rio PMP 300, created by Diamond Multimedia Systems of San Jose, Calif., is a portable music player that is about the size of a pager and does a lot more than beep. A departure from Walkman-like music players that use cassette tapes, compact disks or mini-disks, the Rio can store up to 60 minutes of digital-quality music directly into its 32 megabytes of memory. Because it can handle only music that is compressed in the MP3 format -- used to record and play music distributed on the Internet -- the Rio comes with software that also permits users to convert music on CD's into the MP3 format. **********A major feature of the Rio, which is expected to ship to retailers next month with a suggested price of $200, is that it cuts the tether that has previously tied MP3 music listeners to their computers. Other advantages: the tiny Rio can run for 12 hours on a single AA alkaline battery,  and during a recent demonstration it proved to be highly resistant to flutter and skip, something that just might cause the hearts of some mobile music lovers to skip a beat themselves.   MICHEL MARRIOTT

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/techn.print_headline: LIBRARY/PERSONAL-FINANCE SITES; Motley Fool Has Visitors Chiming In
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/techn.body_text: **********WWW.MOTLEYFOOL.COM **********AT the Motley Fool Web site, the fact that its contributing analysts might own stock in a given company is the entire point.  There are some 100 paid employees and 25 contributors to the site, based in Alexandria, Va. **********''We are one large foolish investing community,'' said Chris Hill, the site's media relations director, ''and we are all contributing.'' **********Corporate analysis on the site, which David and Tom Gardner began in 1994, is written by staff members, many of whom are former brokers. The Fool's School section provides the site's educational component, with all the information rendered in easy-to-understand, even jolly, language. **********But the Fool's flavor is largely provided by its 750,000 monthly visitors, who offer their opinions, experience and tips on the site's bulletin boards. Mr. Hill said the cooperative nature of the site, which eschews the idea of experts dispensing advice, ''gives us a leg up.'' The join-in atmosphere includes message boards that more experienced investors use to discuss their favorite stocks and on-line finance clubs that allow you to eavesdrop on their deliberations.  If you decide that an investor's analysis and commentary are particularly valuable or amusing, you can ask to read an archive of that person's  postings to the site. **********An example of just how investors without on-line access can fall behind wired investors: ''Gardners' Motley Fool Investment Guide'' (Simon & Schuster, 1997), written by the site's founders, extolled the virtues of Iomega, the Zip drive maker; in late July 1998, the Motley Fool Web site was decidedly bearish.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/29/busin.snippet: Profile of Sunbelt Communications Co owner and chairman James E Rogers, who recently made philanthropic history by doubling, to $100 million, earlier record pledge to University of Arizona's college of law in Tucson and promised $15 million matchi...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/29/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL BUSINESS; Determined To Share The Wealth
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/29/busin.body_text: **********THIS is a story about a very generous man named Jim Rogers. **********Not Jim Rogers the former hedge-fund manager, who wrote ''Investment Biker.'' We're talking about James Rogers -- but not the longtime General Electric executive who recently became an investment banker in New York. This is James E. Rogers -- but no, not the James E. Rogers who is chief executive of the Cinergy Corporation, the utility holding company in Cincinnati. **********Those sound-alikes may be pretty open-handed, but it is James E. Rogers of Las Vegas, Nev., who has just made philanthropic history. This Mr. Rogers, a lawyer by training, is the owner and chairman of the Sunbelt Communications Company, which owns KVBC, the NBC affiliate in Las Vegas, and eight other television stations in five Rocky Mountain states. **********Last week, Mr. Rogers doubled, to $100 million, an earlier record-breaking pledge to the University of Arizona's college of law in Tucson; promised $15 million more to match other donors' gifts to the school, and pledged $15 million to other programs at the university. Even at the initial $50 million, his gift was the largest ever made to an American law school, according to Joel Seligman, the dean of the school, which this month was named the James E. Rogers College of Law. **********Mr. Rogers has also made a $28.5 million pledge, announced on Nov. 4, to the new law school at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, and he has made numerous gifts to other colleges and schools in the towns where Sunbelt owns stations. **********What gives? **********''I think we should abandon the concept of 'giving,' '' said Mr. Rogers, a cherubic-looking man who wore jeans and a red tattersall shirt to a recent lunch at a modest bistro in Manhattan. That concept, he said, implies that one's success is one's own. **********In reality, he argued, ''your success is the convergence of a lot of lucky events -- you were born in America, with a good brain, with parents who taught you good values -- none of which you had any control over.'' **********In his view, if those lucky breaks helped you build a fortune, you should give most of it away. That's what he's planning to do. **********''I think you have a right to spend whatever you believe is necessary to maintain your chosen standard of living,'' Mr. Rogers said. Born into a middle-class family, he maintains a very pleasant standard of living himself -- with three homes, a horse-breeding ranch in Idaho and a collection of 85 vintage automobiles. **********But after you get all the toys, ''what you have left, you hold in trust for the public,'' he said quietly. ''I'm holding my money in trust for education.'' Then, he added with a grin, ''if you think of it that way, it makes it a lot easier to give it away.'' **********Mr. Rogers, who is 60, is worth somewhere around $500 million. And he has made it clear that he intends to give away about 75 percent of that money to promote education -- because ''it is part and parcel of who we are.'' **********Leaving the bulk of his fortune to his three successful adult children is out of the question. **********''Leaving children wealth is like leaving them a case of psychological cancer,'' Mr. Rogers said firmly, explaining that he believes a child can never gain a sense of his true worth under such circumstances. Beverly, his third wife, and his three children all support his plans, he said. **********Born in Louisville, Ky., Mr. Rogers moved with his family to Las Vegas in 1951. In 1960 he earned a bachelor's degree in accounting from the University of Arizona, and two years later he graduated from the law school there. He added a master's in law from the University of Southern California and almost finished a doctorate in law at the University of Illinois before opening his law practice in Las Vegas in 1964. **********In 1971, he and some business partners filed an application to take over an existing television license in Las Vegas. In late 1978, after years of litigation involving the former owner, the application was approved and Mr. Rogers, at 40, became a broadcasting executive -- just as his region's growth broke into a gallop. ''We caught lightning in a bottle,'' he said. **********HIS pledge to the Arizona law school -- half of which is to be paid over 20 years and the remainder upon his death -- will transform his alma mater, said Dean Seligman, whose current annual budget is just $7 million. Tuition increases, frequent in recent years, will be a thing of the past. More scholarship money will become available, and top faculty can be attracted. **********Yes, Mr. Rogers has heard most of the nasty lawyer jokes. ''Some of them are pretty funny,'' he said. But he still thinks the law is a noble calling. ''And I bet more lawyers would use their skills to help the downtrodden if they did not come out of law school $125,000 in debt,'' he added. **********Mr. Rogers denies any religious impulse in his giving, but John Sexton, the dean of the New York University Law School and an informal adviser to Mr. Rogers, said he thought ''a deep moral compulsion is at work -- and a belief in the impact the law can have on society.'' **********Mr. Rogers was clearly influenced by his friend and late business partner, Louis Wiener Jr., a legendary Las Vegas lawyer whose clients included most of the boom town's casino hotels and the gangster Bugsy  Siegel. **********Mr. Wiener, a tireless fund-raiser for charity, prodded friends to be more generous by asking those who had attended funerals ''whether they had seen a Brinks truck riding behind the hearse,'' said Mr. Rogers, who was his friend's executor. When Mr. Wiener died in February 1996, Mr. Rogers followed his wishes to the letter: Behind the hearse was a Wells Fargo armored truck -- all the Brinks trucks in town were busy -- bearing a sign that read, ''I've changed my mind; I'm taking it with me.'' **********Mr. Rogers got the hint: He is not taking it with him. ''I'd rather distribute my assets myself than have the Federal Government distribute them after I die,'' he said. ''I think I can do a better job. And I sure as hell can have a lot more fun.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/24/busin.snippet: Market Place column on outlook for Woolworth Corp focuses on future revenues from its Foot Locker division; graph (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/24/busin.main_headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Woolworth stock has been strong, but will Nike sales at the company's Foot Locker unit hurt?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/24/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Woolworth stock has been strong, but will Nike sales at the company's Foot Locker unit hurt?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/24/busin.body_text: **********DOTH the Woolworth Corporation protest a bit too much? **********The company, which closed the last of its namesake five-and-dime stores last summer, now gets most of its revenues from its Foot Locker division, and Nike, the leading maker of athletic shoes and clothing, accounts for a big portion of sales in those stores. Nike has reported several bad quarters and has dragged down much of the athletic market with it. **********Yet Woolworth's executives keep telling Wall Street they are undaunted and that the future looks bright. Investors are on board, having pushed up the stock 31 percent this year to close at $26.625, unchanged, yesterday. **********Still, Woolworth's sales fell 5.6 percent last year. Sales in its stores open at least one year, the best measure of a retailer's health, fell 4.3 percent -- 5.9 percent in the critical fourth quarter alone. Meanwhile, sales at Finish Line, Just For Feet and some other competitors rose. **********When it comes to investor relations, Woolworth scores points for damage control. Last week, when Nike announced that its fiscal third-quarter earnings fell 69 percent because of slumping sales at home and in Asia and that it would lay off 7  percent of its global work force, Woolworth put out its own cheery announcements: a licensing deal to make and sell shoes under the brand name Champion, owned by Sara Lee, and the sale of a handful of nurseries in the Silicon Valley. **********Woolworth no longer reports monthly same-store sales, but has managed to placate Wall Street stock analysts with news about how it plans to increase its square footage by 20 percent a year for the next few years and how it has budgeted $1 billion to remodel tired stores and open new, bigger ones. **********Further, it has been peddling a story to business reporters about its impending name change for several weeks, apparently in hopes of drawing attention away from the real question: just how much of Nike's pain will Woolworth share? **********Woolworth does not disclose what portion of its sales come from Nike merchandise, but analysts and money managers estimate that Woolworth controls about 16 percent of the United States athletic footwear market, and about 40 percent of the market for athletic shoes over $40 (i.e. Nike). **********The next biggest footwear merchant, J. C. Penney, claims just 6 percent of the athletic shoe market. Finish Line and Just For Feet each hold about 3 percent. **********At Foot Locker stores, footwear makes up roughly 75 percent of the merchandise, with Nike representing 30 to 50 percent of that category, investors estimate. This hardly represents immunity to Nike, which conceded last week that earnings would not improve until the 1999 fiscal year. Calls to the office of the chairman and chief executive, Roger N. Farah, were not returned. **********Changes are afoot, though, at Woolworth's athletic division, including Foot Locker, Lady Foot Locker, Kid's Foot Locker and Champs stores. In remodeled stores, Nike is not front and center, but other hot fashion brands like Vans and Timberland. Woolworth is also working to freshen its apparel merchandise, a weak portion of the athletic store business. **********Many athletic retailers have given lip service to better clothing. But Woolworth is one of the few run by a highly regarded merchant, Mr. Farah, formerly of R. H. Macy & Company and other stores. Investors say that remodeled stores are outperforming expectations. **********What is more, the company has done a good job with its balance sheet. When Mr. Farah took the helm in 1994, the company was teetering under a load of debt. It now has virtually none. Selling, general and administrative costs fell to 23.2 percent of sales last year from 24.4 percent of sales in 1996, even as the company expanded stores. **********Taking advantage of cash flow, Woolworth has made acquisitions to strengthen its lead. The company, which is expected to announce a new sporty name the first week of April, has acquired Eastbay Inc., an athletic goods catalogue business, and Athletic Fitters, a regional chain with stores in the West and Midwest. And the company's mall stores that do not sell athletic goods have been pared down to the best and brightest. **********What is more, investors give Mr. Farah and his company high marks for the plan to increase sales space by 20 percent a year for three years, arguing that even if same-store sales are flat, there will be revenue growth. **********''I think he has done a very good job with the company,'' said William Sams, a portfolio manager for First Pacific Advisors in Dallas. ''Before he got there, they were in real serious trouble with short-term debt, and when he got in there, it was worse than he thought. It didn't take him long to get the debt down.'' **********And on a positive note for all retailers, Nike has begun offering special deals and better allocations of once scarce merchandise. Woolworth should benefit the most, given its vast business in the past with the sneaker company. But if Woolworth's primary strategy is to fill its stores with brands like Vans and Timberland, those Nike deals may prove illusory. **********And while adding stores and brightening old ones are often easy ways to please Wall Street, Woolworth is hardly alone in its growth plans. Susan Silverstein, a retail analyst at Nations Bank Montgomery Securities, expects the top six athletic footwear retailers to increase their square footage by 20 percent in 1998, on top of a 21 percent increase last year. **********If investors believe in Mr. Farah, and those who remember his Federated days have good reason to, Woolworth's stock still looks cheap at about 14 times trailing earnings. **********But while America returns to shoes as diverse as Candies and Timberland in what have been traditionally considered athletic apparel stores, Woolworth will probably continue to smart from Nike's woes. **********''They are trying to diversify by adding private-label exclusives and other nontraditional athletic brands,'' Ms. Silverstein said. ''But nonetheless Nike is still half the athletic footwear business.'' And athletic footwear, no matter what the company's name, is what the market believes Woolworth is about.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/31/world.snippet: Saudi Arabia completes investigation into 1996 terrorist bombing of US military base in Dhahran, that left 19 airmen dead, but declines to immediately release results; announcement catches Clinton Administration by surprise and leads to new fears ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/31/world.main_headline: Saudis End Inquiry in Blast That Killed 19 U.S. Airmen
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/31/world.print_headline: Saudis End Inquiry in Blast That Killed 19 U.S. Airmen
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/31/world.body_text: **********The Saudi Arabian Government said today that it had completed its investigation into the June 1996 terrorist bombing there that left 19 American airmen dead but would not immediately release the results of the inquiry. The announcement caught the Clinton Administration by surprise and led to new fears that the culprits might never be brought to justice. **********Officials at the State Department and the Justice Department said the American investigation of the bombing of the Khobar Towers apartment complex in eastern Saudi Arabia was far from over and that the terrorists had not been identified with certainty. **********The American officials, who have long been critical of the Saudi Government for not cooperating in the investigation, said the Saudis had yet to share their detailed findings with the United States, although a Saudi official indicated the information would be made available. **********There was concern, officials said, that the Saudis did not conduct an adequate inquiry because it might produce evidence of a link between the bombers and Iran, embarrassing the Saudi Government. Relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran have warmed dramatically recently. **********''As far as we're concerned, the investigation is still wide open,'' said James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman. ''We do not believe it's over. We are continuing to pursue it and believe that at the end of the day, those responsible will need to pay a price.'' **********Mr. Rubin, who unlike other United States officials did not directly criticize the Saudis today, said he did not know ''what has or hasn't been shared between Saudi law enforcement investigators and American law enforcement investigators'' in recent days. But an American official with knowledge of the investigation, speaking on condition that he not be identified, said the Justice Department learned of the completion of the Saudi investigation through news agency reports today from Saudi Arabia. **********The relationship between the Justice Department, which is overseeing the investigation for the United States, and the Saudis remains ''chilly,'' the official noted. **********The 19 American airmen were killed on June 25, 1996, when terrorists drove a large truck filled with explosives to the perimeter of an apartment complex near Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, and fired a detonator. The blast left an 80-foot crater. **********Suspicion was widespread in Saudi Arabia and the United States that the bombing might have been directed by Iran, which has long protested the presence of American troops in Saudi Arabia and has been accused of involvement in other terrorist acts against the United States. **********The airmen had been deployed to Saudi Arabia to take part in American air patrols that have been conducted over southern Iraq since the 1991 Persian Gulf war. **********Iran has denied involvement in the Khobar Towers bombing and has recently moved to improve its relationship with the Saudis. American officials have said that the warming in Saudi-Iranian relations has complicated the investigation. **********The Saudi announcement today was made by the Interior Minister, Prince Nayef ibn Abdul Aziz, who said in a news conference in Mecca, the Saudi holy city, that ''all the facts concerning the crime are in our hands,'' and that Saudi investigators had ''exerted great efforts to learn all the facts and each detail about this incident.'' He said the findings ''will be released in due course.'' **********In the past the Saudis have confirmed that they had detained suspects in the case. But the number of suspects and their nationality have not been clear, and it was not certain today whether the suspects were still jailed and faced punishment. **********A spokesman for the Saudi Embassy in Washington said he could not comment on details of the investigation except to confirm the Interior Minister's comments. **********The United States announced last fall that it would drop criminal charges against a Saudi dissident who was once described as a central figure in the bombing and who is still in custody here, awaiting deportation hearings. **********The dissident, Hani Abdel Rahim al-Sayegh, who once lived in Iran, fled to Canada after the bombing and was arrested there. Saudi intelligence officials identified Mr. al-Sayegh as the driver of a car that signaled the driver of the explosives-laden truck to the site of the blast. **********Mr. al-Sayegh was deported to the United States from Canada as part of a plea agreement in which he initially agreed to provide the Justice Department with information about the bombing in exchange for a promise that he would not be returned to Saudi Arabia, where he almost certainly face execution by beheading. **********But on arrival in the United States, he reneged on the agreement with the Justice Department, claiming he was not involved in the bombing and had no information for American prosecutors. He has recently insisted that he was not in Saudi Arabia when the bombing occurred.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/20/busin.snippet: Continental Airlines reports record third-quarter earnings, excluding previously announced one-time charge, and acknowledges publicly for first time that Clinton Administration might file suit to block Northwest Airlines from buying controlling st...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/20/busin.main_headline: Continental Airlines Posts Record Net Before Charge
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/20/busin.print_headline: Continental Airlines Posts Record Net Before Charge
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/20/busin.body_text: **********Continental Airlines reported record third-quarter earnings yesterday, excluding a previously announced one-time charge, and acknowledged publicly for the first time that the Clinton Administration might file suit to block Northwest Airlines from buying a controlling stake in Continental. **********Continental said its net earnings declined 34 percent, to $73 million, because of a $77 million after-tax charge to retire older jets. Excluding the charge, however, the airline's profit soared more than 31 percent, to $150 million, or $1.94 a diluted share, from $114 million, or $1.48 a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. The average estimate of Wall Street analysts polled by the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings, was $1.93 a share. **********Revenue grew 12 percent in the quarter, to $2.11 billion, compared with $1.89 billion in 1997 as Continental, the nation's fifth-largest airline, continued to profit from a surge in air travel. On average, Continental's flights were a record 76 percent full over the summer, a level that only a few years ago seemed unattainable. **********In a teleconference with reporters yesterday, Continental executives were bullish about the future. Gregory D. Brenneman, the president and chief operating officer, said that bookings for the fourth quarter looked strong. **********Shares of Continental rose $2.125, to $41.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********As strong as passenger demand remains this year, however, airline stocks have declined sharply since the summer because investors are concerned about an economic slowdown in 1999 when the overall number of airplane seats is expected to grow. **********''They continue to outpace the industry in capacity growth,'' said Susan M. Donofrio, an airline industry analyst at BT Alex. Brown. ''Given the uncertainty over the economic outlook, it is definitely a concern for us.'' **********Continental, which prides itself on having the best labor relations in the industry, is also in the midst of contentious negotiations with its 1,200 commuter pilots. The Independent Association of Continental Pilots, which represents them as well as Continental's 5,000 main line pilots, has vowed to walk out if the airline does not improve its offer. **********''Gordon is drinking his own Kool-Aid if he thinks the pilot work force is squarely behind him,'' Bill Borrelli, the union's president, said in a recent interview, referring to Gordon M. Bethune, Continental's chief executive. **********Mr. Bethune said yesterday that he hoped that negotiations this week would result in an agreement with the pilots. **********He also said he expected negotiations with the Justice Department's antitrust division over Northwest's bid to buy a 51 percent stake in Continental from Air Partners, a Texas investment group, to be resolved ''shortly.'' **********As previously reported, the Government may file suit to block the Northwest investment and plans by the two carriers to enter into a strategic alliance. Although one deadline for the Government passed yesterday, the two sides have agreed to keep negotiating. **********''At this point, we can't predict whether the Justice Department's concerns will be addressed by agreement or by litigation,'' Jeffery A. Smisek, Continental's general counsel, said in a statement yesterday. **********If the Government does sue, Northwest and Continental are expected to challenge the Government in court because they think they have a strong case. **********Mr. Bethune said yesterday that Continental would probably remain profitable for the foreseeable future without the Northwest alliance but that its profits would be much greater if the deal went forward. **********''It is not necessary to us,'' he said, ''but it would be tremendously beneficial to us.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/24/busin.body_text: **********GITTLEMAN-Fannie C. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Isaac F. Gittleman, devoted mother of Maryann and Dr. Alvin Harris, and Ephros and Seymour Manello. Cherished grandmother of Patricia, Jonathan, Danielle, and Sarah. She was dignified, elegant, concerned, involved and will be greatly missed. Donations to the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, Inc., 138 So. Oxford St, Brooklyn, NY 11217 would be appreciated. Services Tuesday, 1 PM, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, Long Island. **********GITTLEMAN-Fannie. The Board of Directors and staff of the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn mourn the death of Fannie Gittleman. She served as a member of the Board of Directors for more than 25 years. Fannie will be missed by all who knew and loved her. She made a lasting contribution to the care of the homebound sick in Brooklyn with a graciousness that is part of her rich legacy to all of us. The Agency expresses condolences to her daughters Mary Ann Harris and Ethros Manello, their families and children. Fannie, we had too short a time with you.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/31/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Anti-Drug Group Selects Ogilvy
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/31/busin.body_text: **********The White House Office of National Drug Control Policy in Washington said yesterday that it had awarded Ogilvy & Mather New Yorkthe largest of three contracts for a big new anti-drug campaign aimed at young Americans, which is running as paid advertising rather than as public service announcements. **********The contract calls for Ogilvy New York to handle planning and buying for media including television, radio, print and the Internet. The contract runs for one year, with a budget of $129 million. There are four one-year renewal options; during those four years, plans call for annual budgets of $132.7 million, $136.6 million, $140.8 million and $145.1 million. Various agencies are donating their services in creating the ads for the campaign. **********The decision came after a long review that had been narrowed to Ogilvy New York, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of the WPP Group P.L.C., and two other finalists in New York. One was a partnership of the Bates USA unit of the Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C. and Zenith Media Worldwide, owned by Cordiant and Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. The other was a partnership of Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners, majority owned by the MDC Communications Corporation, and the Western International Media unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. **********A $9.4 million contract to handle most nonadvertising elements of the campaign was awarded this month to offices of Fleishman-Hillard Inc., a unit of the Omnicom Group.
