https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/busin.main_headline: BANK OF NEW YORK PLANS TO BUY 80% OF EVEREN CLEARING
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; BANK OF NEW YORK PLANS TO BUY 80% OF EVEREN CLEARING
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/busin.body_text: **********The Bank of New York Company agreed yesterday to acquire an 80 percent stake in the Everen Clearing Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Under the agreement, Everen Clearing will be merged into BNY Clearing Services, a newly formed entity. The seller, the Everen Capital Corporation, based in Chicago, will retain a 20 percent stake in BNY Clearing Services. Bank of New York said BNY Clearing Services would keep its headquarters in Milwaukee and added that no staff reductions were planned. Everen Clearing processes trades for Everen Capital's Everen Securities Inc., a brokerage firm.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/09/busin.body_text: **********Richard J. Meislin has been appointed editor in chief of The New York Times Electronic Media Company. The appointment, which takes effect today, was announced by Martin A. Nisenholtz, president of the media company. **********Mr. Meislin, 44, will oversee an editorial staff of 50 that produces The New York Times on the Web and on America Online, and is developing a locally oriented on-line service, New York Today, as well as other projects. **********For the last three years Mr. Meislin has served as The Times's senior editor for information and technology, directing such projects as the newsroom's conversion to electronic page layout and production and its development of new systems to handle color images in the daily newspaper. **********Mr. Meislin's successor in that role will be Terry Schwadron, formerly deputy managing editor of The Los Angeles Times. His appointment was announced by Joseph Lelyveld, executive editor of The New York Times. **********An early advocate of the use of the Internet for publishing and information gathering, Mr. Meislin was involved in much of the planning that led to The Times's presence on line. He was also responsible for projects that gave widespread Internet access to the news staff of The Times. **********An honors graduate of Harvard University, Mr. Meislin came to The Times as a copy boy in 1975. He worked as a reporter in New York City and Albany, correspondent in the Caribbean and Central America and bureau chief in Mexico City before becoming the newspaper's graphics editor in 1988. **********At The Los Angeles Times, Mr. Schwadron, 48, supervised newsroom technology, art, design, library research and photography. He was also editor of the paper's Web sites, of its remotely printed Washington edition and of Life & Style, a feature section. **********Earlier, Mr. Schwadron served in Los Angeles as assistant managing editor for graphics and technology, as executive news editor for the metropolitan staff, city editor and news editor. He has also been an editor and reporter for The Providence Journal-Bulletin and is a graduate of Brown University.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/08/busin.snippet: Faced with the ignominy of selling the nation's largest and oldest financial institution to the Dutch, the directors of Belgium's Generale de Banque SA decided after a reportedly bitter boardroom battle to become only half Dutch..The board of dire...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/08/busin.main_headline: ABN-AMRO Drops Out Over 'Poison Pill' : Generale de Banque Backs Bid by Fortis
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/08/busin.print_headline: ABN-AMRO Drops Out Over 'Poison Pill' : Generale de Banque Backs Bid by Fortis
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/08/busin.body_text: **********Faced with the ignominy of selling the nation's largest and oldest financial institution to the Dutch, the directors of Belgium's Generale de Banque SA decided after a reportedly bitter boardroom battle to become only half Dutch. **********The board of directors, in a marathon 15-hour meeting that ended Saturday, backed a buyout bid from the Belgian-Dutch insurance financial services group, Fortis, and proffered a "poison pill" to fend off a rival offer from ABN-AMRO Holding NV of the Netherlands. **********AMRO, which had sought the deal to create the European Union's largest bank, said later it was pulling out of the battle and would seek opportunities elsewhere in Europe. **********Ever since AMRO made its surprise challenge for Generale de Banque last month, the bidding war had been fraught with nationalistic overtones that contrasted with the creation of a European single market and currency. **********Generale de Banque, created eight years before the birth of Belgium, was a national totem that financed the country's industrial revolution and its colonial expansion. **********According to bank sources, members of Generale's management committee were in favor of the Dutch offer because it would have opened up a large continental market and created important economic synergies. AMRO contended that if Generale accepted the Fortis offer, it would be largely confined to a Belgian niche and left unprepared to deal with the restructuring and consolidation of the financial market caused by the adoption of the single currency in January. **********Fortis partisans, on the other hand, asserted that by accepting the AMRO bid, Generale would have become the subsidiary of a Dutch subsidiary of a Dutch holding company, and would have quickly lost its own identity. **********Explaining why its directors had sided with Fortis, Generale de Banque said AMRO would strive for "the dismemberment or sale to outsiders of various strategic activities." The Dutch group, it said, would have sold Generale's Dutch unit, absorbed its investment banking operations, centralized treasury operations in Amsterdam and taken direct control of units in Switzerland and Hong Kong. **********Fortis, on the other hand, would focus its banking business on Generale de Banque and "maintain its integrity and the consolidation in Belgium of an autonomous decision-making center," Generale de Banque said. **********AMRO denied that its bid had been hostile and said it had been the victim of special interests that were determined to keep Generale de Banque in Belgian hands. **********"In the context of business relations in Belgium, factors play a role that clearly prevent a free, economic choice for all shareholders in this case," it said. **********AMRO said it made no economic sense to try to match an improved offer by Fortis, after Generale de Banque directors approved their poison pill — a 10 percent increase in capital — to help Fortis win its bid. **********Fortis improved its offer Friday, raising it 16.2 percent higher than its original offer three weeks ago. The Fortis offer in stock, cash and guarantees was equivalent to 28,675 Belgian francs ($783.47) a share and valued Generale at $14.2 billion. **********AMRO had bid 27,095 francs a share, valuing the bank at $12.6 billion. It would have had to have outbid Fortis by 5 percent to conform with Belgian takeover laws, a goal that slipped out of its grasp when Generale increased its capital. **********Generale shares closed Friday at 28,675 francs, a 31 percent increase since Fortis made its first bid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/17/world.snippet: Holocaust Memorial Museum bars visit by Yasir Arafat, leader of Palestinian Liberation Organization, during his coming visit to Washington (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/17/world.main_headline: Holocaust Museum Rejects Visit by Arafat
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/17/world.print_headline: Holocaust Museum Rejects Visit by Arafat
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/17/world.body_text: **********Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestinian Liberation Organization, had intended to pay an official visit to the Holocaust Memorial Museum in the capital next week but was told by museum officials that he could not, a senior Administration official said tonight. **********The museum officials' rejection of an official visit emerged today as an awkward and embarrassing prelude to Mr. Arafat's visit to Washington next week to meet President Clinton, who will also meet Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. **********The Administration official confirmed that United States diplomats had suggested the idea of a groundbreaking official visit, accompanied by security measures and the ceremonial protocol afforded dignitaries, to Mr. Arafat, but he was rebuffed by museum officials. **********The Washington Post, which reported the episode in Saturday's editions, said the museum officials had been persuaded by some American Jews that the P.L.O. leader is ''Hitler incarnate'' and should not be allowed to make an official visit **********The Post said museum officials stressed that the museum is open to anyone, and that Mr. Arafat is welcome to drop by, but as no more than a common tourist. The prospect of the P.L.O. leader standing in line for a ticket was said to be an affront to his friends in the Arab world.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/20/busin.snippet: National Assn of Criminal Defense Lawyers will debate whether special code is needed for legal commentators on television; code would address issues like how closely a lawyer should follow trial in order to serve as commentator, whether criminal d...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/20/busin.main_headline: Guidelines For Lawyers In Court of TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/20/busin.print_headline: Guidelines For Lawyers In Court of TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/20/busin.body_text: **********Since her role as a television legal commentator on the Rodney King beating case in 1992, Laurie Levenson has kept a list of the most mindless questions put to her for analysis -- ranging from ''who's winning?'' to ''what are the jurors thinking?'' to ''why is that witness wearing chiffon?'' **********The list, she says, is symbolic of the poor quality of legal analysis in media trial coverage, particularly on television. Now Ms. Levenson, a law professor at Loyola Law School here, and Erwin Chemerinsky, another analyst and law professor at the University of Southern California, are calling for a special code of ethics to combat legal commentary they say fails to educate the public and brings disrepute to the bar. **********So the city that served as main stage for the sensational trials of the police officers who beat Mr. King, O. J. Simpson and the Menendez brothers -- and created a small industry for legal analysis in the process -- is now driving a fledgling debate over what standards those analysts should work by. Lawyers being lawyers, few concur on the answer. **********''I'm not so sure you could get everyone to agree on the same issues,'' said Roger Cossack, co-host of the CNN program ''Burden of Proof,'' ''so it may be an impossibility to get it done.'' **********The proposal by Ms. Levenson and Mr. Chemerinsky, framed as a voluntary measure to avoid any First Amendment problems, asks commentators to refrain from predicting the outcome of a trial or acting like a scorekeeper watching a sporting match. It also asks lawyers to state points of law and facts of a case accurately, avoid conflicts of interest like providing trial strategies to a lawyer involved in the case the commentator is following. It also asks lawyers -- believe it or not -- to closely follow a case in order to comment on it. **********The National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, the largest criminal defense lawyers organization in the country with 10,000 members, discussed adopting a code based on the professors' work during a meeting in New York in November, but the opposition was visceral and the group divided, and prospects for its ultimate approval are in question. The organization will consider a new proposal at a meeting this week in Santa Monica, Calif., this one a more basic version drafted by Barry Scheck, a frequent commentator who represented Mr. Simpson in his criminal trial. Mr. Scheck said he hoped the group would find this version more palatable. **********Some opponents say guidelines are unnecessary and toothless while others fear a violation of free speech. Some say it would be better to set guidelines for television interviewers who put silly questions to lawyers. **********''I suppose who you should really aim at are the networks who call in people to comment on the five o'clock news and six o'clock news and ask the questions they ask,'' Mr. Cossack said. **********Gerry Spence, a defense lawyer and frequent commentator, says he plans to skip the meeting altogether. **********''Codes of ethics don't make lawyers better,'' he said. ''A bad lawyer will find a way to break a code of ethics. I guess we need them for guidelines, but they don't help much.'' **********Proponents of the code are troubled by lawyers in criminal cases coming back as commentators in subsequent related civil cases, as occurred with several lawyers -- prosecution and defense -- in the Simpson case, although they do not seek to curtail such practices. **********They say that raises the danger that lawyers will accidentally let slip client confidences, or not provide frank and candid legal analysis for the public. They also say lawyers' failure to closely follow a case leads to outright mistakes on the air. Peter Arenella, a University of California at Los Angeles law professor and commentator for ABC during the Simpson criminal case, decries a widespread practice of legal commentators relying on media versions of courtroom events to then analyze the proceedings. **********Johnnie L. Cochran, a Simpson defender and now host of the Court TV show Cochran & Company, agrees an ethics code is needed but also says the onus should be on networks to hire experienced and informed trial lawyers. **********Mr. Scheck said: ''This draft is important because the duty of competence is what the nature of media constantly undermines. But people get seduced into going onto these shows and they don't know what they're talking about. As a general matter, it reduces the quality of what's out there.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/19/busin.snippet: Profile of Kerry K Killinger, chief executive of Washington Mutual Inc, whose $9.9 billion acquisition of H F Ahmanson & Co will create second-largest consumer bank on West Coast; Killinger, in his eight years at helm of Washington Mutual, negotia...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/19/busin.main_headline: Behind a Huge S.& L. Empire, a Low-Key Superstar
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/19/busin.print_headline: Behind a Huge S.& L. Empire, a Low-Key Superstar
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/19/busin.body_text: **********Kerry K. Killinger. **********It is not a name that has blazed its way across the top of the business pages in the way that Hugh McColl or Edward Crutchfield Jr. have as they built sleepy local institutions into super-regional financial powerhouses in a few short years. **********Yet, with the $9.9 billion agreement on Tuesday to buy H.F. Ahmanson & Company of Los Angeles by Washington Mutual Inc., the Seattle savings and loan company that he runs, Mr. Killinger has cemented his place alongside the entrepreneurial superstars that have transformed American banking. **********With his low-key personality and unpretentious life style, Mr. Killinger is unlikely to generate the same kind of headlines that his more flamboyant rivals do. Mr. McColl, whose no-holds-barred acquisition binges transformed a backwater North Carolina institution into what is now known as Nationsbank, the third-biggest bank in the country, is famous for keeping a hand grenade on his desk. And Mr. Crutchfield earned the nickname Fast Eddy for the speed with which he catapulted the First Union Corporation into the No. 6 spot. **********By contrast, the 48-year-old Mr. Killinger mows his own lawn (with a hand mower) and stays at Holiday Inns when he travels. Lean and boyish-looking in his wire-rimmed glasses, he relaxes by playing a round of golf or practicing his trumpet. **********His management style is equally unobtrusive, analysts say. ''He is very inclusive,'' said R. Jay Tejera, an analyst at Dain Rauscher in Minneapolis. ''McColl and Crutchfield have an 'it's my way or the highway' approach. Kerry is more of a motivator and delegator. He is the chief executive of this company, but essentially he has no day-to-day responsibilities.'' **********But what he lacks in flair, Mr. Killinger more than makes up for in drive and ambition. In his eight years at the helm, he negotiated a string of deals -- 22 in all -- that turned what had been a small Seattle-based savings and loan with $7.6 billion in assets in 1990 into the nation's largest savings and loan. **********During that same period, Washington Mutual's stock has turned in a quietly spectacular performance, posting an average compound annual return of 30.5 percent. **********With the planned acquisition of H. F. Ahmanson Inc., Mr. Killinger will create the second-largest consumer bank on the West Coast, trailing only BankAmerica. Needless to say, Mr. Killinger has lots of fans on Wall Street. **********''He is an indefatigible guy with enormous energy and optimism,'' Mr. Tejera of Dain Rauscher said. ''Since he took over in 1990, his stock is the best-performing issue among banks and major thrifts. He has made a lot of people wealthy.'' **********Jonathan E. Gray, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company who once referred to Mr. Killinger as the ''Alexander the Great of the thrift industry,'' said ''the highest rate of return for a bank or thrift is to acquire competitors in the same market.'' He added, ''That is a concept he understands well.'' **********A native of Des Moines and a graduate of the University of Iowa, where he earned B.A. and M.B.A. degrees in less than four years, Mr. Killinger displayed a penchant for doing deals before he ever got to Washington Mutual. **********After a brief stint as an investment analyst at the Bankers Life Insurance Company of Nebraska, Mr. Killinger took a position at Murphey Favre Inc., a Spokane-based brokerage firm. To augment his income in support of his young family, he began buying fixer-upper homes and restoring them on weekends. **********Mr. Killinger was no less entrepreneurial at Murphey Favre. A successful mutual fund manager, he acquired a large stake in the privately held firm by buying stock from retiring co-workers. In 1982, he helped to broker the sale of Murphey Favre to Washington Mutual. He was named president in 1988 and chief executive two years later. **********Through his big stock holdings in Washington Mutual, he has become an extremely wealthy man; analysts estimate he is worth $100 million or more. **********Analysts say it does not appear likely that he will sit on its laurels after the Ahmanson deal. **********Ahmanson operates some 40 branches in the Houston area, and Mr. Tejera from Dain Rauscher said he expected Washington Mutual to use that as a beachhead to acquire more properties in Texas. **********''With the Ahmanson deal they will be in a number of Western states, Florida and Texas,'' he said. ''But there is no doubt in my mind that Kerry Killinger has national aspirations.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/21/busin.snippet: IBM reports 10 percent increase in third-quarter earnings, but company's executives warn that global economic uncertainty could lead to short-term problems in months ahead; posts profit of $1.49 billion compared with $1.56 billion in year-earlier ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/21/busin.main_headline: I.B.M. Says Profit Rose 10% But Warns of Uncertainties
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY REPORTS; I.B.M. Says Profit Rose 10% But Warns of Uncertainties
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/21/busin.body_text: **********I.B.M. reported a 10 percent increase in third-quarter earnings yesterday because of stronger computer sales, but the company's executives warned that global economic uncertainty could lead to short-term problems in the months ahead. **********The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer company, posted a profit of $1.49 billion, or $1.56 a diluted share, compared with $1.36 billion, or $1.35 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue for the period increased 8 percent, to $20.1 billion. **********The results were slightly above analysts' expectations of $1.53 a share, and the anticipation of a strong quarter had pushed the company's stock up $10 over the last week, to a new 52-week intraday high of $142.4375 yesterday before retreating. The stock fell $1.50, to $137.875, before the third-quarter earnings were announced. **********Behind the numbers is a mixed business story. The company's sales of hardware, from its giant mainframes to personal computers, increased by 4.2 percent, to $8.7 billion. This is a turnaround from the first half of 1998, when a glut of personal computers and delays in mainframe purchases hurt sales. **********The company's information technology services segment, which provides software and computer equipment services to corporations, was also strong, with revenue rising by 22.6 percent, to $5.7 billion. (I.B.M. does not release earnings results for individual business segments.) The company attributed this rise to a desire by corporations to improve computer-related business efficiencies when faced with an economic downturn. **********On the negative side, however, was a decline in business in Asia and Latin America along with continued problems in the company's microelectronics business, which reflects severe price competition in the manufacture of computer memory chips. **********''While I.B.M. is entering the fourth quarter with some real momentum,'' said Louis V. Gerstner Jr.,  the company's chairman and chief executive, ''we are facing a number of significant short-term issues, including an uncertain global economic environment, ongoing weaknesses in some parts of Asia and Latin America and continued price pressures in semiconductors.'' **********With strong earnings against a backdrop of business uncertainty, I.B.M.'s chief financial officer, Douglas L. Maine, warned in a conference call with analysts against overly optimistic fourth-quarter earnings estimates. **********''While we are pleased with our strong third-quarter performance,'' he said, ''economic uncertainties should lead to a conclusion not to raise earnings estimates.'' **********David Takata, an analyst at Gruntal & Company, said: ''The good news is that I.B.M. wasn't hit as bad as what the worst fears might have indicated. I'm conservative, and I've expected the company to get hit with some economic fallout. But it just hasn't happened yet.'' **********Gary Helmig, an analyst at Soundview Technology Group, said, ''Loud and clear, we got a lot of good news.'' **********''They certainly had a strong revenue performance and they are well positioned in Europe and North America for a sustained performance,'' he added. ''Still, with currency risks and with the world economic scene, we'd all be better off to watch and see how it unfolds rather than taking the good news of the moment and increasing our expectations. That's the prudent approach.'' **********With a cost reduction program in place, most of the increase in revenue fell to the bottom line. Still, the company's gross profit margin of 37.2 percent in the 1998 third quarter fell slightly, compared with 38.2 percent in the quarter a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/15/busin.snippet: Financially troubled Reader's Digest Association, owner of exceptional art collection, will be selling estimated $100 million of Impressionist and 20th-century works by masters at public auction in November; while Sotheby's and Reader's Digest ref...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/15/busin.main_headline: Magazine Set To Auction Art Collection
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/15/busin.print_headline: Magazine Set To Auction Art Collection
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/15/busin.body_text: **********The financially troubled Reader's Digest Association, owner of an exceptional art collection, will be selling an estimated $100 million of Impressionist and 20th-century works by masters like Cezanne, Monet, Modigliani and Matisse at public auction in New York in November, several experts close to the negotiations said yesterday. **********While both Sotheby's and Reader's Digest refused to comment, art experts said that the York Avenue auction house had been chosen to sell the works in a special evening sale during the height of the fall art season. The auction is a big coup for Sotheby's, which competed fiercely for it against its archrival, Christie's. But the choice, experts said, was an obvious one, since Sotheby's has been working with Reader's Digest for years, doing its appraisals and last May selling two paintings -- a Monet and a van Gogh -- which totaled $6.2 million. Around the same time, Reader's Digest also sold a Braque still life privately. **********This fall, the best of Reader's Digest art holdings -- works carefully collected by the publisher's founders, Lila Acheson Wallace and her husband, DeWitt Wallace, since the 1940's -- will be up for sale. The highlights of the collection include two Modigliani portraits, a Matisse still life, a Cezanne landscape, two Monets -- a landscape the artist painted while he was at Vetheuil and one of the artist's famous waterlilies -- and a van Gogh, which the artist painted in Auvers-sur-Oise in 1890. **********The decision to sell this season is partly timed to take advantage of the strong prices realized at auctions of the last several years. The company is hardly the first corporation to sell its art at Sotheby's. In recent years, both I.B.M. and CBS, under financial pressure, sold parts of their collections. I.B.M.'s most valuable American paintings brought record prices when they were offered three years ago. CBS also made money selling about 100 works of contemporary art two years ago. **********But Reader's Digest is under enormous pressure to improve its performance because the company's results have been very disappointing over the last several years. **********Today, under its new chairman and chief executive, Thomas O. Ryder, its financial situation is somewhat better than several months ago, when it had a negative net worth. Not only has it sold some art, but it has also laid off some staff and closed some operations. Still, its $100 million in cash is a far cry from the flush days when the Reader's Digest balance sheet carried $700 million in cash. At its late 1992 high, the stock traded at $56.375 a share. It closed yesterday at $17.6875. **********''The company can meet its debt obligations, but they need capital to fund new ventures,'' said Mandana Hormozi, an analyst at Lazard Freres & Company. **********Ms. Hormozi and other analysts greeted the news of the pending sale of art as a positive for the company and noted that Mr. Ryder had said a sale was likely and that nothing was any longer sacred at the company. The previous chief executive, George V. Grune, had been reluctant to sell the collection. **********Though analysts are impressed with Mr. Ryder's no-nonsense approach -- not only has he already sold several pieces of art, he has also sold the corporate jet -- Reader's Digest's problems are deep. **********The books and home entertainment products are still not getting strong responses to mailings, Ms. Hormozi said. And the revenue for the magazine is down, in large part because of currency fluctuations. In addition, Reader's Digest failed to meet its rate base to advertisers of 15 million readers in 1998, delivering 14.7 million. Under these circumstances it is not unusual for publications to give advertisers free space to compensate for the readers they paid for but did not get. **********Ms. Hormozi said that she had scaled back her expectations for the 1999 fiscal year, which will end June 30, from strong growth to moderate growth. However she and other analysts said they were waiting to hear Mr. Ryder's extensive presentation to analysts scheduled for tomorrow. **********The company has a unique structure. About 71 percent of its voting stock is held by two charitable foundations established by the Wallaces. Underneath the big foundations are seven charitable funds, each of which supports a major cultural institution. The funds once owned a total of 42 percent of the nonvoting shares. However, Reader's Digest cut its dividend last year, and with the stock doing poorly, some funds lobbied for, and received, the right to sell some stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/15/busin.snippet: NBC reportedly agrees to pay Warner Brothers about $13 million an episode for television program ER over next three years for total of over $850 million, making series most expensive television show ever; deal reflects pressure on networks to reta...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/15/busin.main_headline: Outbid on Pro Football, NBC Retains 'E.R.' in Record Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/15/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Outbid on Pro Football, NBC Retains 'E.R.' in Record Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/15/busin.body_text: **********NBC agreed today to a deal to pay Warner Brothers, the studio that owns the drama ''E.R.,'' about $13 million an episode over the next three years for a total of more than $850 million, making the medical series the most expensive television show ever. **********The deal came a day after the National Football League concluded the richest television deal in history, a $17.6 billion deal with three networks, not including NBC. **********Taken together the deals showed how the television networks, weakened by losses of viewers to cable channels, feel compelled to pay once- unheard of prices to retain the few programs that generate consistently large audiences. The NBC agreement comes close to tripling what the network had agreed to pay earlier this year for what turned out to be the last season of its hit comedy series ''Seinfeld.'' **********Many network executives said in interviews here that the crushing programming costs were likely to lead networks to increase their efforts to own or control every program they put on the air. **********NBC announced it had concluded negotiations with Warner Brothers to hold onto television's most popular show without giving any financial details. But several executives on both sides of the negotiations said the price was $13 million an episode, a figure that exceeded even early predictions that it could go as high as $10 million. **********The show features an attractive cast of young doctors and nurses working in a Chicago hospital emergency room. It is the most valuable property in television for numerous reasons, beginning with its high ratings and the attractive makeup of its audience, which includes a high percentage of the adults between the ages of 18 and 49 that most advertisers seek to reach. **********The show has also proved to be television's best lead-in in decades to local news on affiliated stations, and it helped rebuild NBC's ''Tonight'' into television's dominant late-night franchise. **********Don Ohlmeyer, the president of NBC's West Coast entertainment division, said NBC had factored all those things into its bid to retain ''E.R.,'' although he added that NBC was confident ''we won't lose money'' on the deal, even without considering those ancillary benefits. **********Still, the per-episode price of $13 million towers over anything previously paid for the rights to broadcast a television series. **********Most series cost networks between $1 million and $1.5 million. ''E.R'' itself now costs about $2 million. This season NBC agreed to paid a then-record $5.5 million an episode for ''Seinfeld.'' **********But the star of that series, Jerry Seinfeld, announced last month that he was shutting down production on the comedy in May. That only increased the pressure on NBC to keep possession of its other ratings leader, ''E.R.'' **********Mr. Ohlmeyer acknowledged that the imminent loss of ''Seinfeld'' helped force more millions out of the NBC treasury. **********''Obviously the loss of 'Seinfeld' increased the importance of making sure we kept 'E.R.,' '' he said. **********Robert Daly, the chairman of Warner Brothers Inc., agreed that the timing of Mr. Seinfeld's decision ''certainly didn't hurt our negotiations.'' **********Indeed, NBC acted rather swiftly to lock up ''E.R.'' as its Thursday night anchor at 10 P.M., Eastern standard time, after it learned it would no longer have ''Seinfeld'' as its 9 P.M. centerpiece. Mr. Ohlmeyer said the ''E.R.'' deal was ''basically concluded'' even before NBC entered the final phases of its National Football League negotiations, during which it lost the rights to the American Football Conference games, which it had held for more than 30 years. **********NBC was long aware that its competitors had publicly stated their intention to bid for ''E.R.'' and Mr. Daly acknowledged that while Warner Brothers could not negotiate with any other party, ''Everybody talked to us.'' **********NBC's exclusive negotiation period was not set to begin until February, but Mr. Daly said he received a call from Mr. Ohlmeyer soon after the holidays seeking to initiate the ''E.R'' discussions. **********''The whole process only took four or five days,'' Mr. Daly said. ''NBC made a very fair offer that we felt reflected the show's market value.'' **********That market value is enormous. One senior executive from a competing network said NBC had made about $200 million a year in profit on the series. **********Mr. Daly noted that NBC had reaped these enormous profits during the first four years of ''E.R.'' when it held an exclusive contract for the show and did not have to increase the license fee it paid to Warner Brothers, which is a subsidiary of Time Warner Inc. **********''It was time for that to change,'' Mr. Daly said. **********Warner Brothers had actually made an effort to change the terms in the show's second year. Several current and former Warner Brothers executives said the studio had asked NBC, which is owned by General Electric, to increase the license fee to $4 million a year in exchange for a two-year extension on the initial four-year contract. When NBC declined, the executives said, Warner executives were upset and refused subsequent NBC efforts to extend the ''E.R'' deal before it reached the crisis point this year. **********Mr. Ohlmeyer noted that Warner Brothers had sought to open up the ''E.R'' deal at the same time it was looking for better terms for its comedy ''Friends.'' **********''We accepted the proposal on 'Friends' and not on 'E.R','' Mr. Ohlmeyer said. **********Mr. Daly said that Warner Brothers had preferred all along to keep the show at NBC, where it has thrived on Thursday night, and where Warner Brothers has placed several other shows including ''Friends'' and ''Veronica's Closet.'' **********''E.R.'' will remain on Thursday at 10 P.M. and will include all members of the current cast, at least for next season. After that, George Clooney is free to leave, but a Warner Brothers spokeswoman said the rest of the show's ensemble cast was under contract for two to four more years. **********With ''Seinfeld'' which is also under the Warner Brothers banner, the studio controls four of the five shows now on NBC's powerhouse Thursday night lineup. **********''We really have good relationships at NBC,'' Mr. Daly said. The studio already had commitments from NBC to put at least two other Warner Brothers shows on its schedule next fall. **********One prominent Hollywood business executive said the most likely impact of the deal was heightened pressure on the networks to own everything they put on the air. **********He added, ''I think you might hear NBC executives say: 'We had to pay for ''Frasier,'' for ''Seinfeld'' and we got it stuck to us by ''E.R.'' Never again.' '' **********One outcome may be much longer initial deals for series, the executive said, or perpetual options to insure that a series could not be offered to an outside network. **********Trying to put the scale of the ''E.R.'' deal and the N.F.L. deals in context, one senior network executive said, ''We're in a period of great desperation in television.'' **********But Mr. Ohlmeyer argued that the ''E.R'' deal, big as it was, was chiefly a reflection of how the television economy has traditionally worked, with a studio waiting for an initial four-year license period with a network to run out so that it can seek huge increases for renewals of hit shows. **********''If you look at the history of television,'' he said, ''When you have an enormous hit the network benefits for the first four years it's on the air. After that, the studio takes advantage. There's no real difference here.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/news/.main_headline: IMF and World Bank Wrestle With Panic and the Future : Shoring Up The World's Shaky Financial Pillars
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/news/.print_headline: IMF and World Bank Wrestle With Panic and the Future : Shoring Up The World's Shaky Financial Pillars
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/news/.body_text: **********WASHINGTON—                     It is very hard for policymakers to think clearly about the long term at a time of crisis, let alone to take on the monumental challenge of repairing and remaking two of the most important pillars of the global economy. **********Yet, this is precisely the dilemma facing top financial officials from the 175 members of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank system, along with their colleagues from the wealthy Group of Seven nations. **********The finance ministers participating in the annual World Bank/IMF meetings here, probably the most pivotal in the 53-year history of these institutions, are trying to plan for the future as turmoil and panic afflicts world stock markets, and as the global economy heads for either a dramatic slowdown or a recession. **********President Bill Clinton's call Friday for urgent steps at the G-7 and IMF level demonstrated the degree of concern about the escalating world financial crisis and the risk of recession. But even if the G-7 and IMF gatherings do produce a major initiative here, few financial experts expect a quick fix of the global financial architecture anytime soon. **********"Strengthening the banking and supervisory systems of many countries will take a long while," a senior American official said. "I don't see any way to avoid a multiyear workout, and it's going to be meaner, deeper and longer than anyone realizes." **********The obstacles to a quick fix are multiple: **********Japan in recent days has experienced the $16 billion bankruptcy of a leasing company, with fears that one or more sizable bank crashes could be just around the corner. Most economists agree that Japan will not be an engine of growth for Asia or the rest of the world until 2000. **********In the United States, Europe and Asia, meanwhile, controversy — and fear — continues to swirl around the $3.5 billion bailout of Long-Term Capital Management, the gigantic hedge fund, arranged at the behest of the Federal Reserve. LTCM leveraged itself with banks until its potential exposure reached a staggering level, estimated at more than $100 billion. The list of blue-chip banks with exposure to LTCM is spreading, as are write-offs at banks around the world. **********The destruction of wealth on Wall Street, not only for big-money interests, but also for the average investor, has been mirrored by market turmoil in Europe and Asia, and a quarter percentage point cut in interest rates by the Fed this week failed to stop the sell-off. The IMF and World Bank are urgently prescribing more interest rate cuts around the world to counter the economic slowdown, but even so a global credit crunch threatens to strangle both confidence and the real economy. **********Like a tidal wave whose course is unpredictable, the crisis that began 14 months ago in Southeast Asia — and contributed to the political and economic implosion of Russia in August — is now threatening Latin America, in particular Brazil, the continent's biggest economy. **********The human cost has been high, as millions of people have been thrown out of work in the hardest hit countries of Asia, where some economies have plunged into depression. The IMF estimated this week that the loss in terms of world output for 1998 would amount to $600 billion to $800 billion, equivalent to the loss of the entire economy of Canada for a year. **********It is against this backdrop that the World Bank and IMF are straining, and governments are scrambling, both to come up with a short-term economic fix and to set in motion a medium-term overhaul of the two institutions along with a new set of rules to reinforce the global financial system. **********The IMF is running low on funds and is facing, in the eyes of friends and critics alike, a serious threat to its credibility. The World Bank, in the view of its own president, is troubled by the creeping subversion of its role and risks having its mission as a project-oriented poverty fighter and adviser on financial reform being altered to that of another emergency financial fireman, or "junior IMF." Yet President Bill Clinton's initiative would further alter the World Bank's role in this direction. **********Perhaps the clearest message emerging from the meetings here is this: When the rhetoric about creating a new "financial architecture" for the 21st century is stripped away, the reality is that reform will come neither easily nor rapidly. **********A handful of finance ministers, central bankers and international officials interviewed for this article agreed that the process of reshaping the IMF and World Bank will take years not months, and will probably continue into the early years of the next century. These officials, speaking on condition they not be named, agreed that the challenge is enormous not merely because it is hard to effect change at a time of financial crisis, but also for these reasons: **********In a global economy where roughly $1 trillion in capital flows at the speed of electronic transfers each day, and where financial markets and investors often act with a herd instinct, effective regulation has become impossible for individual countries and a daunting challenge even if the world's major economies can agree on joining forces. **********Divergent and conflicting views of how to reshape the global financial system — between Europe and the United States, between Asia and the West, between emerging market economies and the established order, between bureaucrats and politicians — have restricted consensus on anything but the most basic policy concepts, such as the need for greater transparency, stronger oversight and supervision, and requiring business to accept greater responsibility. **********The leaders of the world's three most powerful economies — the United States, Japan and Germany — are to a certain degree handicapped by domestic concerns, be they a sexual scandal that is distracting the White House, a deflationary spiral and paralyzed political class in Japan or a generational and ideological shift that has swept in with elections in Germany, Europe's biggest economy. In addition, the Continent is distracted by preparations for its new single currency. **********Regulating a global financial system in which hedge funds can leverage themselves geometrically and with little supervision, and in which money flows are instantaneous and electronic is, as U.S. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin put it, "exceedingly complicated." **********Mr. Rubin has noted that "over the last 30 years, global capital flows have increased exponentially," and he underscored the market's "herd mentality" by saying that just as capital once flowed into emerging market economies without due regard for proper risk analysis, "it is now too often flowing out in a nondiscriminatory, overly negative reaction." **********As the G-7 and the so-called G-22, which includes 15 developing countries, try to come up with the recipe for strengthening the financial system, they must also try to find a way to attract capital back to emerging markets. **********"Not since the Lord parted the Red Sea has liquidity dried up so quickly in the developing nations," said Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. Mr. Hormats, like many financial officials, said it would be years before reform could be put in place, and he recalled that "in the United States it took us five years to deal with our savings and loan crisis." **********Even as reform is being discussed, the IMF is under fire for having misjudged the extent of the crisis, for having misunderstood the dangers in Russia, for having been too severe in its austerity programs and for having lacked an understanding of the political and social risks associated with its programs. **********"The IMF is guilty of hubris," said one of its sternest critics, a U.S. official who asked not to be identified. **********And an international financial official said: "We need a more participatory system, not a dirigiste system where the IMF comes in like an inspector-general and says, 'You have to balance your budget, get fiscal and monetary disciple and do it all by tomorrow.' The Fund is a sort of an elitist central banking unit, and what is emerging is that you can't do it all so quickly, you can't simply impose it." **********The IMF experience, this official said, has shown "that if you impose something on Indonesia, they take to the streets, and if you impose it on Russia, they toss the government out." **********Michel Camdessus, the Fund's managing director, is facing calls for more transparency from the G-7, and yet is denying that the IMF made any serious mistakes. The Clinton administration, which contains both boosters and detractors of the Fund, appears wedded to working through the IMF on a reshaping of the global financial system. **********Differences in outlook among the G-7 itself means that the annual meetings here may produce some quick confidence-building measures, but a more sweeping overhaul of the IMF and World Bank may have to take a back seat to calls for more transparency, more private sector burden-sharing and more rules to allow banking and financial supervisors to track capital flows.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/08/busin.snippet: Political power does wonders for self-esteem. Two years ago, Oskar Lafontaine came to Washington as an apparently fading star of Germany's opposition Social Democrats, his anxious body language radiating insecurity..Last week he was back exuding c...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/08/busin.body_text: **********Political power does wonders for self-esteem. Two years ago, Oskar Lafontaine came to Washington as an apparently fading star of Germany's opposition Social Democrats, his anxious body language radiating insecurity. **********Last week he was back exuding confidence as his country's new economic and financial supremo, arguably one of the most powerful men in Europe. His transformation, however, is not necessarily good news for everyone else. **********In his few weeks in office, he has alienated German business with ill-conceived plans to increase corporate tax burdens and raised questions over who really runs the country, he or the weak-looking Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder. **********By energetically pursuing old-fashioned socialist economic remedies, Mr. Lafontaine has undercut Mr. Schroeder's pre-election pledge to forge a pro-business "new center" in German politics, based loosely on the "New Labour" policies of the British prime minister, Tony Blair. **********As if to drive home the point, Mr. Lafontaine has upset Mr. Blair's government with calls for tax standardization throughout the European Union, to raise taxes in Britain and other countries closer to high German levels, and by challenging Britain's unquestioned right under EU procedures to veto his proposals. **********More generally, Mr. Lafontaine has aroused fears both in Europe and in the United States that the old unreconstructed European left is back in charge — aided and abetted, in Germany at least, by dangerously woolly-minded environmentalists. **********The question all this raises is whether Germany's European and American partners are right to be afraid — or will Mr. Lafontaine's bark turn out to be worse than his bite? **********Recently, Mr. Lafontaine has somewhat muffled his bark. He has complained, too often to be totally convincing, that his pronouncements have been twisted to exaggerate his more extreme views and eliminate the balancing elements. **********In Washington, he went out of his way to sound reasonable. He played down his proposal for target zones for international exchange rates, especially for the dollar and euro, and said he was not proposing much more than an extension of the kind of stabilization achieved between the Deutsche mark and dollar since the mid-1980s. **********He insisted that, appearances to the contrary, he supports the independence of the new European Central Bank, which will set interest rates in the 11 countries introducing the euro from Jan. 1. And he promised there was no risk that Germany would breach the European Union's stability pact by running a budget deficit higher than 3 percent of the nation's gross domestic product. **********Above all, he said that his proposals to bolster demand through monetary, wage and possibly fiscal measures were only part of a policy mix that would also include supply-side structural reforms, for example by improving Germany's social security system. **********It may be that Mr. Lafontaine is toning down his bark because he is discovering that his bite is not going to be as sharp as he thought — just as the French Socialists did after unexpectedly taking power last year. **********As Mark Howdle of Salomon Smith Barney in London pointed out, European developments over the past 20 years, including the EU single market, free capital flows, the stability pact and economic and monetary union, have progressively limited the scope for governments to adopt leftist policies. **********It seems, however, that Mr. Lafontaine's aim is to circumvent that hurdle by establishing his policies at a European level, now that 11 of the 15 EU governments are broadly of the center-left. **********The odds are he will fail. His policies will certainly not solve Germany's or Europe's unemployment problems. But Europe looked safer before Mr. Lafontaine recaptured his self-esteem. **********E-mail address: Thinkahead@washpost.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/01/busin.snippet: Article explains litigation participation certificates, which invest in major lawsuits and which are outgrowth of 1980's savings-and-loan crisis; graph (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/01/busin.main_headline: How to Win Big in Court And Never See a Lawyer
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/01/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; How to Win Big in Court And Never See a Lawyer
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/01/busin.body_text: **********EVER wish you could get a piece of a major lawsuit? You can, in the form of some wildly esoteric securities that track the outcome of three billion-dollar suits. **********Moreover, an award is expected next spring from the United States Court of Claims in Washington in one of the suits, which was filed against the Federal Government by the Golden State Bancorp, a savings and loan. So some analysts are rating the suit's related security -- generically known as a litigation participation certificate -- as a buy. **********Such certificates, listed by Nasdaq, grew from the savings-and-loan crisis of the 1980's, when the Federal Home Loan Bank Board was encouraging healthy savings and loans to buy ailing ones. The board created an accounting device that allowed the buyer to list the liabilities of the acquired institution as ''supervisory goodwill.'' This could be written off over 35 to 40 years, and during that time, the write-off would be accounted for as capital, against which loans could be made. **********In 1989, however, Congress dissolved the bank board and phased out the supervisory goodwill. The savings institutions contended that this move violated their agreements with the Government. **********More than 120 breach of contract suits have been filed against the Government by savings institutions seeking restitution and damages. The lawsuits could ultimately cost taxpayers $30 billion. **********Because pending suits were likely to complicate mergers in the rapidly consolidating savings-and-loan industry, three institutions -- Golden State, California Federal Bank and Coast Federal, created special securities to spin off the potential value of their suits to shareholders. **********Coast Federal has been acquired by Washington Mutual; California Federal is acquiring Golden State but is keeping the latter's name. The three institutions have all received summary judgments in their favor at trial court level. They are the only thrifts to have spun off such securities, which trade separately. **********Charlotte Chamberlain, an analyst at Jeffries & Company, said the Golden State certificates are the blue chips of the group because an award is so close, though the Government is likely to appeal any damages. **********Golden State, which calls its certificates litigation tracking warrants, is the only company that will pay off in stock, making the payout nontaxable until the shares are sold. The warrants closed at $4.875 on Friday. Ms. Chamberlain says they could pay off at $11 each if Golden State gets the full $1.9 billion it seeks. **********Coast Federal issued what it calls contingent payment rights, which pay off in cash. They closed on Friday at $9.50. The claims court, however, has urged Coast and the Government to reach a settlement. Barring that, hearings on damages are not likely to begin until 2000, diminishing the present value of the security, said David Dusenbury, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. Coast is seeking $1.1 billion. Mr. Dusenbury puts the pretax cash value at $24.40 a certificate if a full award were made today. **********California Federal's case has not advanced as far as the others. It has two certificate classes: contingent litigation recovery participation interests and secondary contingent litigation recovery participation interests, which will pay off differently depending on the amount of any award. They trade at $16.125 and $17.75, respectively, and Ms. Chamberlain said they could pay off at $48.60 and $70.89 if the institution gets the $1.64 billion it seeks. **********The wait has tired many investors, and the securities are trading well below their highs. Even so, a favorable award for Golden State is likely to run up the prices of all of them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/13/world.snippet: Excerpts from Sec Madeleine K Albright's speech to National Press Club (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/13/world.main_headline: In the Words of Albright: A Crisis of Partnership
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/13/world.print_headline: In the Words of Albright: A Crisis of Partnership
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/13/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's address today to the National Press Club, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House: **********The past year has been the most disappointing since the Oslo accords were signed in 1993. It was 16 months ago that active U.S. mediation helped to produce an agreement on Hebron. Since then, a crisis of confidence has arisen between Israelis and Palestinians that has stalled progress at the bargaining table and put at risk both historic accomplishments and future hopes. **********In only two years we have gone from a situation where Israel had some form of peace negotiation, relationship or promising contact with every Arab state except Iraq and Libya to a stalemate which has eroded regional cooperation on issues such as water, economic integration, the environment and refugees; stalled Arab-Israeli contacts,  and caused optimism to be replaced by a sense of fatalism and helplessness about the future. **********At the root of the stalemate is a crisis of partnership between Israelis and Palestinians wherein short-term tactical considerations have too often trumped broader understandings of common interest and cooperation. Indeed, we have gone from a situation where no problem was too big to solve to a situation where every issue is argued about. **********We have seen tragic incidents of terror, unilateral actions and provocative rhetoric undermine the historic accomplishments of the Israeli-Palestinian negotiations. **********For more than a year now the United States has been working hard to revive the missing spirit of partnership. We've been trying literally to restore the ability of the parties to talk constructively with each other, to overcome mistrust, to solve problems, to arrive at agreements and to implement obligations. **********Early last year we were approached by Prime Minister Netanyahu with an idea for reorienting the process. He argued that the confidence-building period provided for under the Oslo accords had begun instead to destroy confidence. And he was right. **********The Prime Minister argued that it therefore made sense to move directly into final status negotiations and to do so on an accelerated timetable. He asked President Clinton to help achieve this purpose. And as Israel's ally and friend, the President decided to try to do so. . . . **********During this period, there was some narrowing in the differences between the parties. But very substantial gaps remained. **********Despite our efforts we could not get the Israelis and Palestinians to agree to an accord. Both urged us nevertheless to persist and to help them find a way to bridge their differences. **********By early this year we had come to the conclusion that even if the parties could not be responsive to each other's ideas, they might respond to ours. Working closely and quietly with both sides, we began to share our views on how the parties might resolve their differences over the four-part agenda. **********In January here in Washington, President Clinton met with Prime Minister Netanyahu and Chairman Arafat, and I met with them when I traveled to the region in February and then again in Europe in March.  Ambassador Ross and Israeli and Palestinian negotiators have been in almost constant contact.  Throughout, we continued to urge the parties to sort out the issues directly with each. Unfortunately none of these discussions produced sufficient results. It was clear that tough decisions were required if Israelis and Palestinians were to reach an agreement that neither side was prepared to make. **********Having worked since January to share our thoughts informally with the parties at the highest level, it was logical that we should at some point share a more fully integrated set of ideas in an effort to facilitate decisions. We took this step not because we wanted to, but because there seemed no other way to break the dangerous logjam that had developed. **********Our ideas stem from intensive consultations with both sides and take into account both the obligations each side has accepted and the vital interests each must protect. **********They are balanced, flexible, practical and reasonable. They are based on the principle of reciprocity, another concept stressed by Prime Minister Netanyahu and embraced by us, because of our belief that parallel implementation of each side's obligation is the only way to restore the partnership between Israelis and Palestinians. **********In presenting our ideas, we made it clear that we were offering them as suggestions, not as an ultimatum or an effort to impose a settlement.  Both parties have their own decision-making processes and interests, which we respect. Our purpose was only in response to the parties' request to help them find the way forward. **********. . . **********We're not giving any ultimatums, and we're not threatening any country's security. We're not trying to make any party suffer at the expense of another. All we're trying to do is find the path to peace, as the parties have repeatedly urged us to do. **********And what we have especially been trying to do in the recent weeks is to issue a wakeup call. **********The leaders of the region have reached a crossroads. Act before it's too late. Decide before the peace process collapses, and understand that in a neighborhood as tough as the Middle East there is no security from hard choices and no lasting security without hard choices. **********The parties must understand, as well, that there is urgency to this task, for time is no longer an ally of this process. It has become an adversary. **********The historic accomplishments that flowed from the Oslo process represent a strategic opportunity for peace that is now being put at risk. . . . **********For the peoples of the region who have suffered too long the path out the wilderness is uphill, but clearly marked. **********The time has come now before the dusk obscures the guideposts to move up that road, and by so doing, to answer the too-long-denied prayers of the children, all the children of the Middle East. **********Thank you very much.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/10/techn.main_headline: Over the Hills and Into Valleys With Digital Television Signals
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/10/techn.print_headline: NEWS WATCH; Over the Hills and Into Valleys With Digital Television Signals
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/10/techn.body_text: **********A coalition of companies involved in the advancement of digital television is touting a new technological breakthrough in the industry. A group of engineers last week successfully tested technology that will allow them to more efficiently redirect digital television signals into hard-to-reach geographic areas, like valleys and areas behind ridges and mountains. **********The advance comes as the broadcast industry prepares to meet a Nov. 1 deadline to begin moving from broadcasting traditional analog signals to sending digital signals. Under the analog standard, when broadcasters wanted to reach more isolated areas, they would often have to transmit a signal to a more accessible destination, then rebroadcast it on another channel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/28/world.snippet: Interview with Sheik Ahmed Yassin, founder and spiritual leader of militant Hamas Islamic movement, who, day after controversial release from house arrest by Palestinian Authority has called for holy war against Israel; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/28/world.main_headline: Freed Palestinian Militant Leader Calls for Holy War Against Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/28/world.print_headline: Freed Palestinian Militant Leader Calls for Holy War Against Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/28/world.body_text: **********A day after the Palestinian Authority lifted Sheik Ahmed Yassin's house arrest, his Land Rover, a gift from the Saudis, plowed through the sand at a refugee camp here, headed for a sound stage decorated with murals celebrating armed struggle. **********Bodyguards hoisted Sheik Yassin's wheelchair up onto the stage, and the wraith-like Islamic cleric, swathed in flowing white, gazed out at the 10,000 people awaiting his first public words in two months. **********Against a backdrop of painted grenades, leaping flames and raised fists, Sheik Yassin, 63, the founder and spiritual leader of Hamas, delivered a fiery 15-minute speech. In his high-pitched, raspy voice, the words sounded as otherworldly as they were inflammatory. **********''We must continue on our path to holy war,'' he said, at this rally marking the 11th anniversary of the Hamas movement, which has waged a deadly war of terror against Israel. ''We celebrate today the uprising that confronted the Israeli occupation with stones, with Molotov cocktails and with guns, uniting our people, the sons of Palestine, the sons of Jerusalem, the sons of our homeland.'' **********After the American-brokered Wye River agreement between Israel and the Palestinians was signed in late October, Sheik Yassin was locked in his house by the Palestinian Authority. His telephone lines were cut and his daily parade of visitors was shut out. **********When the authority lifted his house arrest on Dec. 24, the Israeli Government was quick to condemn what officials described as a Palestinian retreat from the promise to crack down on terrorism. **********''Why do you want to interview me?'' Sheik Yassin asked in his distinctive voice, smiling as if at an inside joke. ''To show the world a first-class example of the famous revolving door?'' **********He may appear otherworldly, but he is as engaged as any Middle Eastern politician in the terms of debate. He was referring to the Israeli coinage for what they see as the circulation of terrorists through Palestinian jails. **********The Palestinians said they had released the sheik, a very popular figure in much of the Gaza Strip, as a gesture of good will at the start of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan. **********But Sheik Yassin agreed with the Israelis that the move had probably been made in direct response to an Israeli suspension of further withdrawals from the West Bank required by the Wye accord. **********''I am a card that they play,'' he said, referring to the Palestinian leadership. **********Seated in his brother's humble home in Gaza, Sheik Yassin, who is paralyzed, nearly blind and very hard of hearing, laughed with the relatives and acolytes who surrounded him -- and ribbed him -- during an interview. **********Several times he motioned with his head for the conversation to stop because airplanes overhead, audible to no one else, were interfering with reception on his hearing aid. **********''We could use you for radar,'' his brother joked, then grew serious. ''We do use you for radar, really.'' **********Fifteen months ago the Israelis released Sheik Yassin from their jails in exchange for the release from Jordanian prison of two agents of the Mossad, the Israeli intelligence agency, who had botched an attempt to assassinate a Hamas leader in Jordan. **********Since then, Sheik Yassin has proved a nettlesome presence to the Palestinians. That is partly because he preaches against the peace effort and assists, even if indirectly, in bringing terror attacks. But it is also because he holds as much sway over poor Palestinians in the Gaza Strip as Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestinian Authority -- if not more. **********Indeed, at the rally today, Mr. Yassin's words were received as if from an oracle by a worshipful crowd in the Shati camp -- a Hamas stronghold that Hillary Rodham Clinton visited 11 days earlier during President Clinton's ill-fated peacemaking mission. **********''He is a super-leader, larger than life,'' said Rawda Jamal, who held her swaddled baby up to see the frail cleric. ''It was a disaster that the Palestinian Authority put him under house arrest after all those years in Israeli prisons.'' **********During his house arrest, Sheik Yassin said, the satellite atop his modest home in the shabby Zeitun section of Gaza linked him to the world. He watched Mr. Clinton's visit to Gaza on television, he said, dismayed to see the American President presiding over a meeting of the Palestine National Council in which it revoked from its charter clauses calling for Israel's destruction. **********''It was a sad spectacle,'' Sheik Yassin said, ''to see my fellow Palestinians applauding and chanting while they were deleting part of our history and their charter. That's why our rallies took place in protest: because they were turning their back on our common purpose.'' **********Describing the two months of his house arrest, he again smiled his inward smile, while a son gently eased the sheik's swollen feet into fleece-lined boots. Because Sheik Yassin's physical therapists were not allowed to visit during that time, the son -- one of his 11 children -- trained at a local hospital to nurse his father and to exercise his lifeless limbs. **********''I was happy,'' Sheik Yassin said. ''It was excellent. I had time to worship, to read the Koran. I was able to finish reading three doctoral dissertations about the holy war. I had some time to see my wife and children. Reasonable people cannot look on ill fortune as ill fortune. I prefer to see the glass as half full.'' **********Still, he said of the detention: ''I was not happy that this order came from my brothers. If it had come from the Jews, it would have been natural.'' **********The house arrest followed a suicide bomb attack on a school bus filled with Jewish settlers' children in Gaza. The children escaped harm, but two Israeli soldiers, who drove their jeep between the bomber's car and the bus, were killed, along with the bomber. **********At the rally, one speaker thundered, ''Clinton is a Jew!'' Schoolchildren read poems extolling holy war. **********A group of young teen-age boys, who sounded like an Islamic Menudo, sang to the feedback of bad amplifiers. Iraqi flags were waved, but in deference to the conditions in their rally permit, no Israeli or American flags were burned and no weapons fired. **********In his speech, Sheik Yassin condemned the Palestinian Authority without naming it or Mr. Arafat. Directing his anger into the two orange microphones held in his face, he called it corrupt and spoke out against its attempt to stifle the Palestinian news media and what he called its concessions to the Israelis and the Americans. **********As he talked into a chill wind that swirled the sand, his bodyguard kept the sheik's white head covering from flapping forward and covering his face. **********Face to face, Sheik Yassin transmits an eerie kind of serenity, uttering harsh words as gently as if he were talking to a small child. The contrast between tone and substance can be chilling. **********''We extended our hand to the world to help us get back our land, and nobody cared,'' the sheik said. ''Don't you think it's reasonable, then, for us, to carry an ax on our shoulders and make demands?'' **********Asked if that meant that Hamas, which committed no attacks during the sheik's house arrest, would strike again soon, he answered indirectly and with one of the many metaphors he employs. ''As you have seen and will see, for every action there is a reaction,'' he said. ''Our Palestinian people are like gold. The more you pressure them, the more they shine.'' **********The men around him nodded, and some stomachs grumbled, as it was shortly before the day's fast for Ramadan was to be broken with a plate of dates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/13/world.snippet: Mexican Government and the opposition National Action Party (PAN) vote to reform a $61 billion bank bailout that has become an example of favoritism in high places toward the wealthy; PAN settles for language in the bill that puts some pressure on...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/13/world.main_headline: In Mexico, Rival Parties Pass Accord On Bank Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/13/world.print_headline: In Mexico, Rival Parties Pass Accord On Bank Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/13/world.body_text: **********After nine months of debate that strained Mexico's maturing democracy and threatened to destabilize the financial system, the Government and a major opposition party have reached full agreement on reorganizing a $61 billion bank bailout that had become an example of spectacular corruption favoring the wealthy. **********The bailout discussion utterly dominated Mexican politics this year, becoming the first opportunity for opposition parties voted into new positions of power in 1997 to question the Government's past economic performance, force it to admit errors and change its ways. **********The National Action Party, or PAN, a conservative opposition group, decided to accept an 11th-hour resolution with the Government to signal to Mexican bankers, debtors and international investors that the opposition will not push partisan politics at the expense of the nation's financial well-being. **********The opposition party reached the bailout deal late Friday with the Government's party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI. The proposal was immediately voted out of a congressional committee and is expected to be approved by the lower house of the Congress later today. Approval by the Senate is pro forma because the PRI holds a majority there. **********In the end, it was the delegates from the National Action Party who blinked in a standoff -- which had stalled the discussions for weeks -- over the resignation of Guillermo Ortiz as head of the central bank. The party's leaders were insisting that Mr. Ortiz leave because they argued that he had violated the Mexican Constitution when, as Finance Minister, he cobbled together the first bailout program in 1995. **********The National Action Party lawmakers settled for language in the bill that puts some pressure on Mr. Ortiz to resign in coming months but does not require him to do so right away. Mr. Ortiz is a close ally of President Ernesto Zedillo, and the Government staunchly refused to consider letting him go now. **********The complex legislation sets up a new agency that will absorb about $36 billion of the debts carried by the current bailout program, known as the Bank Fund for Savings Protection. Unlike the fund, the new agency will be able to issue fully guaranteed bonds for trading on international markets to raise capital. Banks will be required to pay higher quotas to the new agency to help with interest and administrative costs. **********The entire portfolio of the fund is being scrutinized by international auditors. Loans found to be fraudulent will be returned to the banks. **********The package also includes a program that will cost about $4 billion over five years of new assistance for mortgage holders and other debtors who were wiped out when interest rates soared over 100 percent during the 1995 economic meltdown. **********Although the Government blundered badly at the outset of the debate, it came out surprisingly well. **********Finance Minister Angel Gurria failed to anticipate the explosive issues behind the bailout and thought he would easily persuade Congress to transform the billions of liabilities on the bank fund's books into public debt. His proposal in March initiated the accusations by the opposition that the Government had used the banks and the bailout to shore up its corrupt cronies and finance the 1994 campaign of President Zedillo. **********But the Government stuck to technical arguments while the interest costs of the bailout continued to multiply. Meanwhile damaging rifts opened between the National Action Party and the other main opposition party, the Party of the Democratic Revolution, which accused the National Action Party of catering to the Government. The Party of the Democratic Revolution will vote against the bailout reform. **********The Party of the Democratic Revolution took out full-page ads in major Mexican newspapers in recent days denouncing the Government and the National Action Party as ''traitors'' to Mexican wage-earners. **********The formula that saved Mr. Ortiz has to do with the board of seven members that will govern the new agency, to be opened in March 1999. **********One seat will go to the head of the central bank, but the bill specifically bars Mr. Ortiz from occupying it because of his role in the original bailout. Another official, Eduardo Fernandez Garcia, the head of the National Banking Commission, is also barred. **********The agency can function with the two seats empty, but PAN deputies argued that the situation will grow increasingly uncomfortable for Mr. Ortiz and Mr. Fernandez and will eventually force them out. **********Several Government officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, agreed with that prognosis. They said that the bruising debate had done critical damage to Mr. Ortiz's political standing, although not to his reputation as a financial manager.

American International will be paid a $110 million fee for expenses incurred during the bidding process. Cendant will pay 673 pence a share, a 17 percent premium to NPC's closing price on Friday. The offer is backed by the NPC board, including its founders, Ronald Hobson and Sir Donald Gosling, who own 72.5 percent of the stock.
