https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/21/busin.snippet: Kobren Insight Group, investment management firm in Wellesley Hills, Mass, issues report predicting that 11 funds will soon be closed to new investors; list (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/21/busin.main_headline: Knowing When It's The Time To Close
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/21/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT; Knowing When It's The Time To Close
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/21/busin.body_text: **********FUNDS are closing at a record rate this year. But according to a new report issued by the Kobren Insight Group, a lot more of them ought to be slamming their doors. **********Kobren Insight, an investment management firm in Wellesley Hills, Mass., lists 11 funds that for various reasons it said should be closed to new investors. **********The reasons cited in the report run the gamut from over-diversification to an inability to maneuver quickly. What's surprising is the number of high-performance, high-profile funds that make the list, among them Janus, Vanguard Windsor II, Fidelity Equity-Income and Mutual Discovery. **********''Our research suggests that many funds have grown very large, and their size may begin to have an impact on their performance,'' said Edward R. Goldfarb, portfolio strategist for Kobren Insight. **********''None of these are panic sells, but shareholders would benefit from sponsors closing the fund and focusing on maximizing the return on existing assets,'' he said. **********Fund companies are often loath to close even those funds that have swollen asset bases because the fees they receive are figured as a percentage of assets under management. The larger the fund, the bigger the fund company's pay check. **********Indeed, not one fund company plans to close a fund named on Kobren Insight's list. And despite their size, some of these funds are still performing well. In fact, several are rated ''strong buys'' in Kobren Insight's investment newsletters, the firm's highest rating. **********One such fund is Fidelity Equity-Income. It held $24.8 billion in assets as of May 31, but its performance remains strong and Kobren Insight rates it a ''strong buy.'' **********But given a good alternative, Mr. Goldfarb said, Kobren Insight will always recommend a smaller fund over one of the behemoths. Mr. Goldfarb, for instance, favors Warburg Pincus Growth and Income for investors looking for a solid growth and income offering. **********Warburg Pincus holds less than $1 billion, which gives manager Brian S. Posner, who used to manage Fidelity Equity-Income II, opportunities that the Fidelity fund is just too large to grab, Mr. Goldfarb said. The strategies are similar, although the Warburg fund is slightly more value oriented than the Fidelity fund, he added. **********KOBREN INSIGHT rates these five funds as ''holds'', even though it said they would benefit from closing: Twentieth Century Ultra, Janus, Kaufmann Fund, PBHG Growth and Acorn. **********Mr. Goldfarb said investors should not scramble to buy shares if these funds announce they will close to new investors. He added that there's no point in dumping shares, either, if you hold them in a taxable account and have large unrealized gains. **********Twentieth Century Ultra uses an earnings momentum strategy that often requires the fund to trade quickly in response to earnings disappointments or rejiggered forecasts. At $26 billion, it may soon be too large to move nimbly, Mr. Goldfarb said. **********Gunnar Hughes, a spokesman for American Century, which runs Twentieth Century Ultra, said the fund has more good investment ideas now than the money to buy them, and has experienced no liquidity problems. **********The $22 billion Janus fund is not only a giant in its own right, it also owns many of the same stocks as other Janus funds. In the aggregate, then, Janus managers may have trouble moving large blocks of stock without affecting market prices, Mr. Goldfarb said. **********Moreover, the $14 billion Janus Worldwide is still accepting new investments, while Janus Overseas was closed at just $4.3 billion earlier this year. At the time, Helen Young Hayes, who runs both funds, said she was concerned that significant cash coming into the Overseas fund would make her job more difficult. Why not close the larger fund, too, Mr. Goldfarb asked. **********A Janus spokeswoman responded that Worldwide can own United States stocks as well as foreign stocks, and that makes it easier for Ms. Hayes to maneuver. **********It is especially important for small-cap stock funds to keep their asset bases small, according to Mr. Goldfarb. When these funds expand, they often tend to start buying mid-cap stocks. **********They also begin to move more sluggishly, handicapped by their larger size. Kaufmann is a clear example, said Mr. Goldfarb: its performance has suffered as assets rose to today's $6.4 billion. A fund official declined  to comment. **********The $4.1 billion Acorn fund also owns much larger stocks than it used to, although its manager, Ralph Wanger, blames that on the appreciation of the stock market, which he says has gotten ''stupidly overpriced.'' **********At the $5.3 billion PBHG Growth fund, liquidity is a concern, because the fund needs to be able to move quickly to execute a strategy driven by earnings momentum, Mr. Goldfarb said. Gary Pilgrim, the manager, said liquidity is less of a problem at lower-turnover funds like his. **********THE $4.3 billion Mutual Discovery fund has moved to mid-cap names in the United States, and its size will lessen its ability to buy the smaller European stocks that had bolstered its performance, Mr. Goldfarb says. **********Robert Friedman, a manager of the fund,  conceded that Discovery has moved into mid-cap stocks, but noted that these tend to be less volatile. He also said that managers have more clout with such companies, and so can pressure them into making shareholder-friendly moves. **********Finally, sheer size reduces a fund's ability to benefit shareholders by buying mid-cap and smaller-cap stocks, especially when funds balloon to $20 billion or more, Mr. Goldfarb said. **********Funds in this position include the $26.6 billion Vanguard Windsor II and Fidelity's $18.7 billion Equity-Income II fund, which Mr. Goldfarb nonetheless rates as buys because of their strong managers. But he advised investors to select smaller alternatives, if available. **********A Vanguard spokesman noted that Windsor II is run by four different managers who trade independently, adding flexibility that other large funds may lack. A Fidelity spokesman said the company would close its funds if it were in the best interest of shareholders. **********T. Rowe Price International Stock fund's $10.6 billion in assets have forced it to own a large number of stocks, and lose flexibility, according to Mr. Goldfarb. But Steve Norwitz, a Price spokesman, said size is not an issue because the fund owns large companies and is diversified internationally.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/22/busin.snippet: Brazilian stocks gyrate wildly in December, mostly downward, after soaring earlier on what analysts called excessive optimism about International Monetary Fund bailout; more irrational selling is expected as Congress balks at adopting austerity pr...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/22/busin.main_headline: Brazil Stocks Gyrate, Falling From Highs Inspired by I.M.F. Bailout
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/22/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Brazil Stocks Gyrate, Falling From Highs Inspired by I.M.F. Bailout
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/22/busin.body_text: **********Just a month ago, markets here were rallying as the International Monetary Fund moved toward announcing a $41 billion bailout for Brazil. **********In a spree of optimism over the I.M.F. backing that some analysts warned was wildly excessive, Brazilian stocks rose 91 percent in a nine-week period through Nov. 27, and 22.5 percent in November alone. **********There was no obvious cause for such enthusiasm, in either company performance or in the Government's progress toward fiscal discipline. **********This month stocks are bouncing wildly again, but mostly in the opposite direction. As of Friday, they had fallen 21.5 percent. **********Although the benchmark Brazilian stock index shot up 6.19 percent today, at least some of that buying was attributed to market gains elsewhere. The underlying sense in Brazil is that more irrational selling is in store. **********''I see it as unbridled pessimism, which has no foundation,'' said Rodrigo Fiaes, chief of equity research at Banco Icatu here. ''When the market was on the upswing, people were not discounting negatives. Now the market is only discounting the negatives, and not taking positive developments into account.'' **********Yet the urge to dump shares of Brazilian companies was not completely unwarranted, and some analysts considered it a correction of excessive confidence. Since the I.M.F. bailout was announced, there have been some signs that the Brazilian Congress may not be as quick, or as pliant, in accepting the economic belt-tightening proposals of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's administration as investors had hoped. **********Congress rejected a proposal to make retired civil servants pay into the pension system, and it went home for the holidays without approving the Government's revised 1999 budget, or extending and increasing a special financial-transactions tax that officials are counting on to meet revenue targets promised to the I.M.F. **********''It's a razor-edge situation,'' said Edmar Bacha, executive director of BBA Securities in New York. ''Because the price is not as low as indicating default, nor as high as indicating that Brazil is over the hump, there's a tremendous uncertainty right now as to which way Brazil is going to go. Is it Russia or Korea?'' **********In addition to the generally falling stock prices, trading volume has plunged, with daily trades toward the end of last week totaling $225 million in value -- one-third of what they were before the global financial crisis began. With such low liquidity, the stock exchange has become a kind of fun-house mirror, magnifying small movements of capital at price extremes. **********At the end of 1997, about 30 percent of the trading was done by foreigners. By now, most foreign investors have fled. **********''The market is leaving aside the fundamentals, and reacting strongly to any news related to Congress, or to the austerity package,'' said Roque Sut Ribeiro of the Marka Nikko Asset Fund here. **********Brazil's dollar reserves, now at $49 billion after it received a first installment of nearly $10 billion I.M.F. aid in recent days, are still in decline. As of the end of last week, $2.64 billion had flowed from foreign reserves. **********If trading takes place among a smaller number of investors these days, the number of companies they are trading is also minuscule, compared with those traded on stock exchanges in the United States. Brazil's main index, the Bovespa in Sao Paulo, is made up of a handful of blue-chip companies, including Telebras, Petrobras and Eletrobras. **********Investors will be watching for new appointments that President Cardoso is expected to make on Wednesday. He is expected to create some new jobs in his Cabinet, including a civilian Minister of Defense and, later, a Minister of Production who would wield considerable power. **********But the most important announcements for markets this week will involve appointments to head Petrobras; a savings institution, the Caixa Economica Federal, the Banco do Brasil and the National Bank for Development. **********One name that has been mentioned to head the development bank is Maria Silvia Marques, the chief executive of CSN, the national steel company. Her appointment would be taken as a sign by investors that privatization would continue to be a Government priority. **********''If Cardoso can get it right, in the sense of sending a positive signal to the market,'' Mr. Fiaes said, ''and if the market will be satisfied with the options, we'll see a general improvement in sentiment toward Brazil.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/world.snippet: Defense Department says Marine Corps jet that sliced through cables of Cavalese, Italy, ski lift, killing 20 people, apparently was flying far below minimum authorized altitude for training missions; does not dispute Prime Min Romano Prodi's view ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/world.main_headline: U.S. Doesn't Dispute Italians Over 'Recklessness' in Crash
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/world.print_headline: U.S. Doesn't Dispute Italians Over 'Recklessness' in Crash
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/05/world.body_text: **********The American military jet that sliced through the cables of a ski lift in Italy and killed 20 people appeared to have been flying far below the minimum authorized altitude for training missions, Defense Department officials said today. **********While they said it was too early to blame the Marine Corps pilot or the plane's navigational equipment, the officials said they ''cannot dispute'' the view of the Italian Prime Minister that ''tragic recklessness'' was responsible for the accident on a slope just south of Cavalese, an Alpine ski hamlet in northern Italy. **********Under Marine Corps rules, the jets, known as EA-6B Prowlers, are supposed to fly at least 1,000 feet above the ground on training missions. There have been conflicting reports from Italy on the altitude at which the jet hit the cables, but all have put the plane far closer to the ground than 1,000 feet. **********In Cavalese, residents said today that they had repeatedly complained to local and national government officials about low-flying planes, mostly Italian military aircraft, that use the craggy peaks surrounding the small resort towns as a training ground for low-level flying. But generally their complaints went unheeded. [Page A4.] **********The Italian news agency ANSA said the collision had occurred at about 450 feet above ground, while local officials near the crash site said it occurred as the plane unsuccessfully tried to fly beneath the cables at a height of about 210 feet. **********Prime Minister Romano Prodi, who visited the accident scene today with Defense Minister Beniamino Andreatta and Justice Minister Giovanni Maria Flick, said that ''tragic recklessness'' had resulted in ''a flight practically scraping the ground.'' **********Mr. Prodi told reporters that  President Clinton had assured him such an incident would never occur again. **********Mr. Andreatta demanded that the pilot be prosecuted. ''We are not asking for revenge, but that the law on criminal responsibility be applied to the commander of the airplane,'' ANSA quoted him as saying. **********The prosecutors office in Trento, the regional capital, said its investigators had questioned the pilot and  other crew members, but no charges were filed, the Associated Press reported. Other news services said the pilots declined to answer questions. **********Asked about the Italian accusations, Defense Department officials here said initially that it was too early to draw conclusions about the accident. Pressed for a response, a Pentagon official, speaking on condition that he not be identified, said, ''We cannot dispute that.'' **********Defense Department officials conceded that they were no position to argue with the Italian Government given the initial evidence at the scene of the crash. ''It's going to take several days to sort this out,'' the Pentagon official said. ''We've got conflicting reports on just about everything, from the altitude of the plane to what part of the plane actually struck the cable.'' **********The jet, which carried a pilot and three other crew members, returned safely to the NATO air base in Aviano, in northern Italy, despite damage to its tail and one wing. Italian television broadcast pictures of the plane that clearly indicated tail damage. **********The crew members have not been publicly identified by the Marine Corps, although they are known to be members of the Second Marine Aircraft Wing from Cherry Point, N.C.,  deployed to Italy to take part in NATO peacekeeping in Bosnia. **********Marine Corps officials in Washington disputed reports from Italian news organizations that local officials had complained repeatedly of low-flying American military aircraft, including instances in which jets tried to pass beneath cable lines on the way back to the Aviano base. **********The officials, who also spoke on condition that they not be identified,  said there had been only three official complaints last year against the American pilots based at Aviano, and that all of them involved excessive noise -- not dangerous flying --  in the immediate vicinity of the base. The accident on Tuesday took place about 90 miles from the base. **********The Marine Corps said Maj. Gen. Michael P. De Long, deputy commander of Marine Corps Forces in the Atlantic, had been sent from Norfolk, Va., to Italy to oversee the investigation of the accident. **********The main mission of the two-engine EA-6B jets is to identify the type and location of enemy radars and either to jam their signal or to attack them with high-speed anti-radiation missiles. Pilots do low-level training because in wartime they must sometimes fly as low as 100 feet to avoid detection by radar.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/01/busin.snippet: Profile of Colorforms Inc, small business struggling to survive in industry dominated by few large players; company, now owned by University Games, was innovator in marketing and advertising, seeing profit potential in licensing cartoon characters...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/01/busin.main_headline: A Family's Survival In a Toyland Jungle
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/01/busin.print_headline: EARNING IT; A Family's Survival In a Toyland Jungle
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/01/busin.body_text: **********HARRY KISLEVITZ never planned on being a toy maker. He and his wife, Patricia, were artists in postwar Manhattan, living in a railroad apartment on the Upper West Side, when they acquired a roll of vinyl sheeting. Noticing how the vinyl stuck to the apartment's semigloss walls, they put it, along with some scissors, in the bathroom. Friends would spend hours playing Matisse, cutting out designs and sticking them to walls. **********A game, and a family business, were born. In 1951, Mr. Kislevitz created Colorforms, nothing more than laminated paperboard and stick-on vinyl shapes. He ran the company out of the family's new home, in River Edge, N.J.; the factory where the pieces were cut and boxed was just a few miles away, in Ramsey. **********Colorforms became a staple of simple play. Even as the toy industry veered increasingly toward more complex and costly items, Colorforms held its own, its logo a distinctive and familiar presence in stores. **********But consolidation has turned the once-genial toy business into a much higher-stakes game dominated by Mattel and Hasbro, whose combined sales of $8 billion in 1997 represent more than one-third of the entire industry's. Similarly, among retailers, Toys ''R'' Us and Wal-Mart now account for more than one-third of all toy sales. **********Survival in such a marketplace has been tough for Geppettos like Colorforms Inc. In its struggle to recapture the success of its early years, Colorforms endured a rocky stretch in the last decade, which ultimately led to two new corporate parents in just the last year. **********With only a handful of sales representatives and a marketing budget that allowed little more than the occasional ''please touch'' display at a children's museum, Colorforms was not poised to compete. **********And in an era of videos, computer games and sophisticated toddlers, interest in the brand had long been in decline. The company will not divulge sales figures, but analysts estimate that Colorforms sales fell about 50 percent in the last decade; Gary M. Jacobson, an analyst at Jefferies & Company in New York, estimated that sales were about $7 million last year. **********''We suffered what most small companies suffer,'' said Joshua Kislevitz, who along with his brother David came in to run the business in 1988, when their father retired. ''We were underfinanced. At a certain point you realize you need to have certain resources to get to the next level.'' **********Still, with the kind of brand equity that others spend millions to attain, Colorforms had its suitors -- and accepted an offer last March for $4.2 million in cash plus other guarantees from Toy Biz, a New York maker of action figures and dolls. Joshua and David Kislevitz stayed on. **********But Toy Biz was preoccupied with its struggle with the financier Carl C. Icahn for control of the Marvel Entertainment Group. In late January, Toy Biz wound up selling Colorforms for $5.4 million to University Games, a privately held maker of board games in Burlingame, Calif. **********''What we see in Colorforms is the opportunity to create a preschool brand to compete head-on with Mattel's Fisher-Price and Hasbro's Playskool,'' said Robert Moog, chief executive of University Games. **********Mr. Moog, who hired Joshua, 40, and David, 41, to help manage the brand, wants to restore the luster Colorforms enjoyed in its early years. **********The company was an innovator in marketing and advertising, seeing the profit potential in licensing cartoon characters and producing versions of them in Colorforms. **********''Harry was aggressive with character licensing -- Popeye was his first license -- and he produced great, long commercials that feel today like mini TV shows,'' Joshua Kislevitz said. **********Licenses held by Colorforms today include Disney's Winnie-the-Pooh and Mattel's Barbie. The core line of about 70 varieties of stick-on sets sell for $4.99 to $9.99; depending on the complexity of the sets and factoring in licensing fees, they cost $1.50 to $6 to make. **********Toy Biz was lured by Colorforms' licensing business, and the Kislevitz family hoped its linkup with Toy Biz would provide advertising budgets and greater heft with retailers. **********But the time under Toy Biz was uncomfortable. Uncertain of their role, Joshua Kislevitz joked, he and David were ''vice presidents of nothing.'' Distribution faltered and the marketing push never materialized. Sales remained flat, and a sense of corporate drift was hard to shake. **********University Games was waiting on the sidelines. Mr. Moog had bid for Colorforms, losing out to Toy Biz. But that did not stop him from inquiring four months after the sale whether Colorforms was in play. **********Toy Biz would not discuss Colorforms beyond a statement released at the time of the sale. In it, Joseph Ahearn, the chief executive, said: ''Recent consolidation in the toy industry has resulted in fewer licensing opportunities for Colorforms products than we expected. The sale of this division would allow us to continue to focus on our core business and on our proposed acquisition of Marvel Entertainment Group.'' **********University Games plans to smooth Colorforms' distribution problems in the next 12 months -- an intention that is drawing praise from retailers. ''We had awful, awful distribution when they were by themselves,'' Alison Weinberger, the preschool activity buyer for Toys ''R'' Us, said. ''But University Games is a good vendor; we're very pleased about this.'' **********House-brand sets now constitute about 30 percent of the Colorforms line, while those featuring licensed characters make up the balance. Mr. Kislevitz and Mr. Moog would like to reverse that ratio; that way, the brand itself sells. **********And University Games is planning television commercials in 1999 and new products to extend the Colorforms brand to an array of educational toys and games. **********SO far, Colorforms has mostly sat out the digital revolution. In 1994, the Kislevitzes licensed the Gryphon Software Corporation to manufacture Colorforms computer graphics games. But Mr. Moog said that collaboration with Gryphon, now owned by the Cendant Corporation, had fizzled by the time he came on the scene. **********''There is a lot of interest, especially, in using the Colorforms brand in new media,'' Mr. Moog said, adding that he was still exploring high-technology options. **********Meanwhile, two new licenses this year -- for the Nickelodeon show ''Blue's Clues'' and a Dreamworks SKG children's film, ''Small Soldiers,'' which is scheduled for a summer release -- hold promise. **********Mr. Jacobson of Jefferies & Company said Colorforms had the potential to surpass $20 million in annual sales. ''First and foremost, Colorforms needs advertising support,'' he said. ''Another license like Barbie, which does really well for them, wouldn't hurt, and neither would some modernization.'' **********Ira Mayer, publisher of The Licensing Letter, a trade publication that tracks licensing deals, said Colorforms still owned a potent weapon -- ''the ability to appeal to multiple generations.'' **********He added: ''Licensing or no licensing, the play value is there. A toy like that will come back.'' **********Golden Oldies, Going Solo **********COLORFORMS is not the only classic in the toy universe that is feeling the tug of potential buyers. **********It is not even the only one that has been pursued by University Games, which has made a practice of rooting through the industry's dusty back shelves in search of possible acquisitions. A favorite on the company's wish list is Slinky, made by James Industries of Hollidaysburg, Pa. **********''I get a lot of calls from Bob Moog,'' said Betty James, the co-founder of the company, referring to University Games' chief executive. James Industries has held on -- and even enjoyed a surge in sales thanks to the Slinky Dog featured in ''Toy Story,'' Disney's hit children's movie. But Ms. James, 81, cannot imagine keeping the business much longer. **********Another classic going it alone is Etch A Sketch, made by the Ohio Art Company of Bryan, Ohio. The downside to owning a classic, said William C. Killgallon, 59, the second-generation chairman of the company, is that while everyone is familiar with the brand, everyone also thinks he knows what it should cost. **********Mr. Killgallon has had a hard time raising the price of the original Etch A Sketch, which for years has sold for about $10. He has brought new life to the product line and to the balance sheet through spinoffs like Zooper Sounds Etch A Sketch, which retails at twice the price. **********The voracious Mattel and Hasbro may be interested in the company, Mr. Killgallon said. **********''We're on their radar,'' he said. But he intends to keep Ohio Art independent, offsetting the ebb and flow of the toy business with revenues from a division that makes film canisters for Eastman Kodak and ashtrays for General Motors.   ELAINE UNDERWOOD

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.snippet: Edward Rothstein column examines manifesto drawn up by group of high-profile, young Internet advocates on how to view the Internet; manifesto calls for 'techno-realism,' favoring 'fertile middle ground between techno-utopianism and neo-Luddism'; n...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.main_headline: A rather benign declaration on the Internet is treated as a revolutionary manifesto.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.print_headline: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS; A rather benign declaration on the Internet is treated as a revolutionary manifesto.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.body_text: **********HOW neurotic is the Internet? **********Put aside for a moment its seeming hospitality for marginal characters, for hysterics and obsessives. After all, there are plenty of ordinary people plying their wares and interests there. What happens instead when the Internet thinks about itself and tries to imagine its place in the world? Can one trust the Internet's sense of proportion and purpose? Or, when it comes to the Internet, do its advocates and participants see anything clearly? **********The evidence has not been overly encouraging. And during the last two weeks, a group of high-profile, youngish Internet advocates began to say as much. The group decided that views of technology and the Internet had been skewed toward extremes. On the one hand, the Internet is treated as the electronic frontier, the hope of humankind, the harbinger of a coming utopia. **********On the other hand, this high-technology nexus has seemed to be a home for pornography and perversion populated by sexual predators, a fitting example of the evils and dangers of unfettered technology. **********In response to these views, the dissidents wrote a manifesto calling for ''techno-realism'' and calling themselves techno-realists. This manifesto -- instantly given its own World Wide Web site at www.technorealism.org -- rejects the ''louder voices at the extremes'' in favor of a more balanced consensus, a ''fertile middle ground between techno-utopianism and neo-Luddism.'' **********The eight principles of techno-realism generally seem as if they should be obvious to anyone. ''The Internet is revolutionary,'' the writers declare, ''but not utopian.'' It is, they say, a communications tool that will not bring paradise. ''The thrill of acquiring or distributing information quickly,'' they add, should not be confused with wisdom. Freedom is important, but some government intervention is necessary. Wiring schools to the Internet will not save the schools, but can augment education. **********This middle ground seems both commonsensical and very nearly trite. Who could object? And judging from the manifesto's signers, who has? Its supporters range from commentators like Steven Johnson, the editor of Feed (www.feedmag.com), to hip-hop Internet advocates like Douglas Rushkoff, a self-described youth-culture enthusiast who likes to ''poke holes in the system'' and has always seemed a bit of a techno-utopian himself. **********It is supported by David Shenk, the author of ''Data Smog'' and a techno-skeptic, as well as by Mark Stahlman, a founder of the New York New Media Association, who more than a year ago wrote an intriguing critical analysis of the utopian ideology of Wired magazine for the 'zine Rewired (www.rewired.com/96/Fall/ 1118.html). Even Kevin Kelly, one of the cyber-gurus behind Wired, has joined the ranks of supporters. **********But the triteness appears only when viewed through the scrim of real life. On the Internet, this mild-mannered declaration is being treated like a truly revolutionary document, with signatures still accumulating http://www.technorealism.org/list-html). **********Techno-realism has inspired flames and counterflames at forums run by Feed (http://www.feedmag.com/html/dialog/98.03dialog/intro.html) and even more hostile commentary on the Well. Sarcasm and insider allusions are the rule at another site that mocks the manifesto and its signers (www.technorealist.org): ''SEE The TECHNOREALISTS Go Against The Wired LIBERTARIANS'' as they ''FIGHT For The Digital FUTURE!'' **********The techno-realism ''movement,'' barely a week old, even inspired a conference at the Berkman Center for Internet and Society at the Harvard Law School on Thursday (http://cyber.harvard.edu/technorealism.html). At the conference, techno-realism was called ''a more nuanced and useful way to think'' about technology. **********But it is only in the slightly neurotic world of the Internet and its insider commentators that this kind of statement would cause this kind of controversy or inspire such hyperbolic advocacy. Outside the Internet, most of its points seem obvious or facile. In the Feed-sponsored dialogue on techno-realism, David Hudson, a founder of Rewired, points out that taking the techno-realist middle ground is a ''bit like establishing a political party for those who breathe air or put their pants on one leg at a time.'' **********There seems to be a fun-house quality to the fuss, as if the manifesto writers were pointing out that perhaps the emperor was not wearing pants at all, not realizing that neither were they. The statement is opposed to the distortions of the Internet's utopian thinkers, but its promotion and style can seem right at home. Wired magazine bears its utopian message with neon colors and high-concept color ads that seem custom designed for the Internet set; it gains stature with its links to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Media Lab through Nicholas Negroponte. **********Techno-realism preaches humility but has been just as earnestly promoted and pumped up, sprouting links on the Web and finding a Harvard connection in one of its creators, Andrew L. Shapiro, a fellow of the Berkman Center and a contributing editor at The Nation. In both cases, too little is carefully analyzed; too much depends on appearing to be progressive and ahead of the curve. **********But in a conversation, Mr. Shapiro noted out that the techno-realist statement was just a first step, one needed for attention. He argued that the kind of support now being given to techno-realism might be a sign that ''Internet thinking is coming of age.'' He suggested that the ''laissez-faire extremism'' of Internet utopianism might be coming to an end with a new kind of ''political maturity.'' **********In the meantime, the fact that techno-realism is being considered a revolutionary step is a sign of how undeveloped and off kilter most Internet thinking is.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/22/busin.snippet: Peter Passell Economic Scene column says price of salmon in market is lower because of successful efforts of lobbies for wholesale fish distributors and restaurants in America to beat back efforts by domestic salmon industry to use nation's trade ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/22/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Salmon eaters salute a victory against the protectionists.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/22/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Salmon eaters salute a victory against the protectionists.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/22/busin.body_text: **********THANKS to hard-charging Chilean exporters, fresh salmon -- in particular, the bone-free fillets ready for the broiler -- has become a major bargain. Check that: much of the thanks must go to lobbies for wholesale fish distributors and restaurants here in America. **********For at considerable cost they have beaten back efforts by the domestic salmon industry to use the nation's trade laws to bar the foreign competition. Indeed, optimists in the free-trade crowd see a glimmer of hope that consumers will more routinely benefit from organized resistance to laws designed for protectionists. ''We may be witnessing the emergence of an anti-anti-dumping coalition,'' suggested Greg Rushford, editor of The Rushford Report, a Washngton-based newsletter. **********With the world's supplies of ''free range'' salmon badly depleted by overfishing, large-scale commercial salmon farming in tidal pools has come of age. Salmon are raised in, among other places, Norway, Scotland and America. But Chile is the market leader owing to a combination of ideal water conditions, low-cost labor and entrepreneurs quick to incorporate both new technology and modern advertising. Chilean exports to the United States skyrocketed from nearly nothing in the late 1980's to 70 million pounds in 1996 -- almost half the market for farmed salmon. **********Not surprisingly, prices have fallen sharply, which accounts for the presence of salmon fillets in more supermarkets and on far more menus in midpriced restaurants. And while the domestic salmon industry, based in Maine and Washington, has remained profitable, it would be more profitable without all that low-cost Chilean fish flooding the market. So last year a coalition of eight American salmon farmers with a total of 440 employees hired Michael Coursey, the Washington-based lawyer who succeeded in knocking Norwegian salmon out of the market in 1990 by charging the Norwegians with selling below cost. **********In light of the dreary history of both subsidy and dumping -- or selling below cost -- cases over the last two decades, it seemed the Chileans and those who enjoy their fish didn't have a prayer. ''The trade laws are written to protect domestic producers,'' reminds Robert Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution. ''Consumers' interests don't figure in the equation.'' **********In fact, those $5.95-a-pound supermarket specials on salmon fillets are likely to be around a while longer. The subsidy charge has effectively been rejected and the preliminary anti-dumping duties assessed by the Commerce Department average just 5 percent -- a far cry from the 42 percent asked by the plaintiffs, and not nearly enough to send the Chileans packing. **********It's possible that the Commerce Department simply overcame its loathing for everything imported and judged the Chilean case on the merits. But if you believe that, you might want to invest in Princess Di commemorative ceramics before the factory runs out of clay. **********A more plausible explanation is that importers fought back with weapons that work. Atlas Air Inc., a cargo shipper that handles millions of pounds of Chilean salmon, hired Bob Dole's lobbying firm to make the case for importing tasty fish at reasonable prices. An alliance of importers in South Florida commissioned an economic consulting firm that came up with the preposterous (but eye-catching) estimate that 19,000 American jobs -- including 3,600 in Florida -- depended on easy Chilean access to the salmon market. And the National Restaurant Association weighed in with a shove at Congress and the Clinton Administration. **********In a better world, Mr. Litan argues, there would be virtually no laws specifically aimed at regulating imports. The consumer-oriented antitrust laws, which prohibit restraint of trade and outlaw sales below cost with the intent of bankrupting competitors, would apply to foreign companies the way they now apply to domestic ones. **********But foreigners don't vote in Congressional elections, and their efforts to buy favor with campaign contributions the way their American counterparts do is widely seen as a no-no. By the same token, large American exporters, who after World War II stood as a bulwark against protectionism, have lost their enthusiasm for open trade now that they have lost their commanding lead in technology. Many -- including Kodak and Boeing -- play both sides of the protectionist fence. And not surprisingly, ''the Commerce Department views corporations that compete with imports as its real constituency,'' argued Ronald Cass, dean of the Boston University School of Law. **********Hence from Mr. Cass's perspective, the best hope for consumers is a convergence of interest with businesses that depend on imports. To date, very few companies, with the notable exception of Caterpillar Industries, which lobbies hard for access to imported steel, have put in the political effort. But the success of the Salmon Trade Alliance (http://www.salmontrade.com) may just prove to be catching.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/06/busin.snippet: Bond prices surge for biggest one-day gain in more than year as investors worldwide seek relative safety of Treasury securities for fifth consecutive day; yields on Treasury's 30-year bond plummet to 4.72 percent, from 4.84 percent, lowest for lon...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/06/busin.main_headline: Bond Prices Surge as Investors Push Yields to 31-Year Low
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/06/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS: BONDS; Bond Prices Surge as Investors Push Yields to 31-Year Low
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/06/busin.body_text: **********Another big loss in stocks and fears of a further deterioration in nearly all types of financial assets drove investors worldwide into the relative safety of Treasury securities yesterday for the fifth consecutive day. Bond prices surged for the biggest one-day gain in more than a year, pushing yields to another in a series of 31-year lows. **********By the close of trading, yields on the Treasury's 30-year bond had plummeted to 4.72 percent, from 4.84 percent Friday, the lowest for long-term Government debt since April 1967. Prices rose 2 2/32  point, or more than $20 per $1,000 in face amount, the biggest gain since Sept. 16, 1997. **********''We are seeing a continued flight to quality,'' David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International, said. ''I don't know where the end of this process lies.'' **********Further deterioration in world stock markets yesterday only reinforced the demand for Treasury securities. Although the Dow Jones industrial average recovered from steep losses to end only 58.45 points lower, at 7,726.24, the Nasdaq stock market tumbled 78.29 points, or 4.85 percent, to 1,536.69. Most stock markets overseas also slumped. **********Analysts said there was disappointment that finance ministers and central bankers attending the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund had apparently failed to agree on a plan to shore up the faltering international economy. **********''Many went into the weekend thinking a credit package for Brazil would be in the works and announced just after the elections, which were held on Sunday,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president and chief money market economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter Inc. **********Mr. Sullivan said the recent steep slides in interest rates ''are divorced from underlying economic and credit market fundamentals'' in the United States. Instead, he said, ''they are based upon a whole different attribute: a heightened preference for quality, safety and liquidity.'' **********The severity of the challenge facing policy makers and market participants alike was underscored yesterday by William McDonough, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. **********Answering questions at a meeting of the Institute of International Bankers in Washington, Mr. McDonough said the current crisis was the most serious since World War II, adding that the declines in world markets and economies could ''get worse because there is a significant possibility of a credit crunch.'' **********''But the people in this room have the capacity to make sure this doesn't happen,'' Mr. McDonough said. ''It makes sense to control the risk aversion of 'let's batten down the hatches and protect our institution.' If every institution does that, I can assure you we will have a very large credit crunch.'' **********The collapse in the price of riskier fixed-income assets relative to Treasury securities claimed another victim yesterday, as Criimi Mae Inc., a real estate investment trust with a big portfolio of commercial mortgage securities, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection following big losses on its investments. **********''As all of these markets have blown up, the value of Criimi Mae's assets plummeted,'' said Jim Callahan, executive director of the Pentalpha Group, an investment advisory firm based in Greenwich, Conn. **********Still, Mr. Callahan said: ''a lot of people are breathing a sigh of relief at what Criimi has done. Filing for reorganization is a better outcome than a fire sale liquidation, like Long-Term Capital.'' **********Traders said Long-Term Capital Management, the formerly high-flying hedge fund that was salvaged from near-collapse late last month by a consortium of investment banking firms, was in the market yesterday selling mortgage-backed securities and older Treasury securities, and buying freshly issued Government notes and bonds. **********The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond was not the only maturity that registered big price gains yesterday. **********Near the close of trading in New York, the 4.5 percent two-year notes were quoted at a price of 100 29/32 , up one-quarter of a point, to yield 4.02 percent. The price of the 5.25 percent five-year notes rose by 17/32 , to 105 5/8, to yield 3.96 percent. And the 5 5/8 percent 10-year notes rose a full point in price, to 111 17/32 , to yield 4.16 percent. **********At one point during the day, yields on the Government's two-year, three-year and five-year notes were all trading below 4 percent, Mr. Sullivan from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********3-Mo. Bills   6-Mo. Bills       Average Price   98.950   97.884       Discounted Rate   4.15%   4.18%       Coupon Yield   4.25%   4.33%       High Price   98.954   97.892       Discounted Rate   4.14%   4.17%       Coupon Yield   4.24%   4.31%       Low Price   98.948   97.877       Discounted Rate   4.16%   4.20%       Coupon Yield   4.24%   4.35%       Accepted at low price   78%   20%       Total applied for   $31,556,861   $23,136,353       Accepted   $10,928,661   $11,647,353       Noncompetitive   $1,311,666   $1,165,228 **********Both issues are dated Oct. 8, 1998. The three-month bills mature on Jan. 7, 1999, and the six-month bills mature on April 8, 1999.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/31/busin.body_text: **********A unit of the privately owned French advertising company Decaux S.A. offered $:475 million ($799 million) in cash for More Group P.L.C., outbidding Clear Channel Communications Inc. of San Antonio. Decaux's 1,110-pence-a-share offer is 8 percent higher than Clear Channel's 1,030-pence-a-share offer. Decaux said on Friday that it was considering a rival bid to that of Clear Channel. Clear Channel responded with a statement that suggested it was considering another bid. Its shares fell $1, to $97.125. Clear Channel, which owns radio and television stations throughout the United States, made the offer as part of an effort to enter the international advertising market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/world.snippet: Russia's Railway Ministry refuses to move mail cars until Post Office makes good on some 210 million rubles in old bills; several airports hold up air mail over past-due debts; so much mail is backed up that post offices in Moscow and elsewhere si...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/world.main_headline: At Russian Post Office, Check Isn't in the Mail
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/world.print_headline: At Russian Post Office, Check Isn't in the Mail
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/world.body_text: **********In a season of crashing banks, plunging rubles,  bouncing paychecks, failing crops and rotating governments, maybe it is not the ultimate insult. But the nation that bore Tolstoy and Chekhov and still regards a well-written letter as a labor of love is buckling a little this week, because it can no longer wish good health to Baba Anya in Omsk. **********The Post Office is broke. **********In 60 of the country's 89 state-like regions, more than 1,000 mail cars have been sidetracked, many stuffed with up to 18 tons of letters, newspapers and parcels. The state Railway Ministry refuses to carry more mail until the Post Office makes good on some 210 million rubles in old bills -- about $13 million in today's dollars, or $35 million in dollars six weeks ago. **********Air mail, which amounts to one of every four or five letters, was also suspended at one of Moscow's major airports until this week, when the Post Office coughed up five million rubles for old bills. A second airport is still demanding three million rubles for past-due debts. **********So much mail is backed up that post offices in Moscow and elsewhere have simply stopped accepting out-of-town mail, except for areas that can be easily reached by truck. Delivery schedules have fallen weeks, and perhaps months, behind. **********''The situation is really extraordinary,'' said Vladimir V. Sherekhov, the deputy chief of mail service administration in the Government's Communications Committee. ''We've never had anything like this before.'' **********Maybe the Post Office has been lucky. Extraordinary is the rule elsewhere in Russia. **********Until today, the lower house of Parliament was preparing to sue the Government for failure to provide soap, heat, toilet paper and copy-machine paper in the legislature's monumental downtown offices. It turned out that politicians had exhausted their funds by cutting short their recess and returning to address the nation's economic crisis. **********Earlier in the week, officials said Russia's Arctic shipping routes may close next month because half the nation's icebreakers are in disrepair and there is no money to fix them.  The oldest of the ships is so ancient that its nickname is Granny. **********Such anecdotal evidence that Russia is losing its wheels, like one of its old, ill-maintained Volga sedans, is everywhere. But oddly, real signs of public distress are not all that common, perhaps because the system rarely seems to shed a part as big as a postal system. **********If America's Postal Service is increasingly a pipeline for sweepstakes notices and bills, the Russian Post Office still holds a special place in the national conversation. Russians still write letters to each other, frequently and fervently, and many in remote regions get their news through the mail. **********Millions use the mails to ship canned goods and other provisions to needy relatives and friends in faraway areas, an especially vital service in winter. And in the last few years, the Post Office has become a vehicle for a growing mail-order trade in books, clothes and other catalogue items not readily available outside big cities. **********Exactly why all this has rumbled to a halt is in some dispute. What is clear is that the Post Office and the Railway Ministry both suffer from what ails every Russian venture, private and public alike: nobody pays his bills. **********The state Railway Ministry complains that it is continually stiffed by customers who believe the railroads are honor-bound to carry freight whether they are paid or not. The Government has decreed nearly 40 categories of freight which the railroads must carry for next to nothing. **********Among the biggest deadbeats are the ''power ministries'' -- the military and interior departments -- which did not pay during Soviet times and feel little need to pay now. **********''It's a psychology formed during the socialist period,'' said Tatiana L. Pashkova, the deputy spokeswoman for the ministry, ''and the same situation exists with the Post Office. We've been in dispute for a very long time. Always we try to understand their differences. But we can't carry cargo for free.'' **********No kidding, says the Post Office: It, too, is owed 200 million rubles by Government agencies, and is barred from raising rates even though freight costs are outstripping revenues. Moreover, the Post Office is also required by the Government to carry some forms of mail, such as pension checks, at reduced rates. **********Officials at the state Communications Department say they also suspect an ulterior motive in the railroads' actions: a struggle to dominate the thriving mail-order business. **********''Here's competition between us and the railroads for the delivery of parcels, and I think decisions made by the railroads are mainly explained by this competition,'' Mr. Sherekhov said. ''They blame us for carrying some commercial cargoes instead of mail.'' **********The Railway Ministry's spokeswoman, Ms. Pashkova, said such ''commercial cargoes'' are indeed a problem, but only because the railroads know that the Post Office has already gotten cash to transport the packages. The railroads are still waiting for their share of that money, she said. **********In the meantime, the situation has come to a boil. In late September, the railroads cut mail service in and out of Moscow, effectively decapitating the postal system and forcing officials to draft a fleet of trucks to move letters in and out of the city. **********Hundreds of empty and full rail cars have clogged some local yards to the point where moving cars into position for unloading has become difficult. At last count, 39 loaded cars were awaiting service at one yard. And customers are getting angry. **********''We've gotten all kinds of complaints,'' said Viktor Salikov, a deputy in the Communications Department's mail shipping center. ''People are even coming to us, searching for mail that was sent weeks ago.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/10/world.snippet: In some of world's poorest nations, villagers who are themselves often illiterate yet who understand their children need education to succeed in life are beginning to make schooling a community effort and priority for spending what small amounts o...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/10/world.main_headline: Third World Fills a Void As Villagers Run Schools
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/10/world.print_headline: Third World Fills a Void As Villagers Run Schools
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/10/world.body_text: **********Yasmin Aidbar had never heard of charter schools. But as the only girl in her small village to get a secondary education, she seized an offer of free teacher training in return for a promise to come back home and open Bhumlairi's first school -- a project conceived and planned by parents, most of whom are poor farmers tired of waiting for a Government school. **********In neighboring Afghanistan, where the militantly Islamic Taliban Government has barred education to females, nearly a hundred girls flock every day to a mud-walled farmhouse compound in rural Laghman province. There, several women teachers have set up an alternative school with community help and money from a private Swedish aid group. **********In some of the world's poorest nations, villagers who are themselves often illiterate yet who understand that their children need an education to succeed in life are beginning to make schooling a community effort and a priority for spending what small amounts of money they are able to pool. **********Surprisingly, these efforts are not very popular with large organizations actively involved in third-world development. Carol Bellamy, executive director of Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, told disappointed mothers and teachers in Afghanistan who had been hoping for more help with their home schools that providing education was the responsibility of government. Her view is widely shared at the World Bank and in many government aid agencies. **********''The U.N. position is not that there is something inherently wrong with home schools,'' Ms. Bellamy said in Kabul. ''But if formal education is not supplied by government, a child's right to schooling is violated. Home schools are not a substitute for formal education.'' **********A mother in the Afghan city of Jalalabad, hearing this explanation again later, said, ''But isn't a home school better than nothing?'' **********Ravi Kanbur, a former World Bank official who is now a professor of development economics at Cornell University, said these positions reflect a wider debate now about the role of government in poor countries. **********''With the collapse of the state in many countries, particularly in Africa, local organizations have taken over local services,'' he said. ''The question is, 'Is this the right way to go or not?' There is a tension between two arguments. One is that the state has made such a mess of it in the past, with money going to universities and not the primary schools. The other side says: 'Aren't you emasculating the state to do some good? Shouldn't we be building up the capacity of the state to do the right things?' '' **********Mr. Kanbur says he falls somewhere in between, as do many other development experts. **********''I think we need some kind of structured set-up, where the overall framework and the regulatory framework is set out by the state, and within that, one has the options to explore,'' he said. **********One maverick development expert who comes down increasingly on the side of small self-help projects is Mahbub ul Haq, a former Finance Minister of Pakistan and United Nations official who quit to establish a development research organization  in Islamabad,the Pakistani capital. **********In April Mr. Haq, creator of the United Nations Human Development Report, introduced a comprehensive survey of education in South Asia that was sharply critical of the record of governments in his region -- in particular India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Nepal -- where populations have fallen behind sub-Saharan Africa in literacy rates and other measures of social development. **********Mr. Haq and his wife, Khadija Haq, a former adviser on education at Unicef and co-author of the report ''Human Development in South Asia 1998,'' conclude that in South Asia: ''Nonformal education is not the second-best option. Often it is the only option.'' **********In an interview in Islamabad, Mr. Haq said he found that in Pakistan, Government schools can cost 80 times as much to open as a simple village school, and three times as much to run. **********But most important, he said, is the way building community schools mobilizes villages, and often leads to other self-help projects. ''Successful programs meet the demands of the local community rather than the central planners,'' the Haqs wrote in their report. **********Mr. Haq said that in Bangladesh, local schools established by the Bangladesh Rural Advancement Committee, a nongovernmental organization, have raised attendance rates to more than 90 percent of primary-age children in many areas in recent decades -- at a cost of only $20 per child a year, compared with $51 in government schools.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/17/busin.snippet: Sunbeam Corp reports $587 million loss for first nine months of year; quarterly losses noted (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/17/busin.body_text: **********The bedeviled Sunbeam Corporation turned in yet another poor financial performance yesterday, reporting a $587 million loss for the first nine months of this year. **********While the company said the final quarter should show some improvement, it also indicated the hemorrhaging has not stopped. **********After restating its financial results in October to adjusted figures for six quarters through the first three months of this year, Sunbeam yesterday reported results for the second and third quarters, which reflected steep revenue drops and losses. **********The maker of Sunbeam and Oster brand blenders and toasters lost $344.1 million, or $3.41 a share, in the second quarter, including $213 million in primarily one-time charges. Revenue totaled $578.5 million, compared with $271.4 million in the prior year. But excluding revenue gains largely from three recently acquired companies, sales declined 23 percent, to $202.2 million. **********In the third quarter, it lost $188.9 million, or $1.88 a share, including $89 million in primarily one-time charges. That compared with earnings of $24.8 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue totaled $496 million, compared with $286.8 million a year earlier. But excluding revenue gains largely from the three acquired companies, sales declined 42 percent, to $162.6  million. **********The losses in those periods were far worse than the already negatively revised estimate of analysts polled by First Call. The company had been expected to lose 30 cents a share in the second quarter and 12 cents a share in the third quarter. **********Despite the performance, Sunbeam shares rose 25 cents, or 4.4 percent, yesterday to $5.9275. **********Investor reaction appeared to indicate confidence that the company's new management had adequately assessed its problems -- a retail pipeline jammed with too much product, confusion about the businesses' financial position and headline-grabbing management turmoil. **********Sunbeam has been in crisis since Albert J. Dunlap, its once-celebrated chief executive, delivered several quarters of unexpected earnings disappointments last year and was ousted in June. **********But even with the favorable market reaction, analysts expressed caution about the outlook. **********''They are by no means out of the woods yet,'' said William Steele, an analyst who follows Sunbeam for Buckingham Research Group. **********For the nine months ended Sept. 30, Sunbeam's lost $587.1 million, or $6.12 a share, compared with earnings of $28.8 million, or 33 cents a share, the previous year. The 1998 period includes $339 million in various charges related, in large part, to excess inventory, early debt payment and the issuance of warrants. **********''These losses provide a clear indication of the measures necessary to stabilize Sunbeam's businesses and get the company back on track,'' said Jerry W. Levin, president and chief executive. **********Even so, ''the losses are much larger than expected,'' said Nicholas Heymann, an analyst who follows the company for Prudential Securities. **********For the nine months, Sunbeam's revenue totaled $1.3 billion, compared with $810.7 million in the prior year. Excluding the revenue gains this year largely from the three companies Sunbeam acquired in the spring, revenue declined 24 percent,  to $594 million. **********''The good news is the company is beginning to manage cash flow and used substantially less than might be thought likely in the third quarter,'' Mr. Heymann said. **********The company also said it had worked down $80 million in excess inventory at the retail level and had begun to pare its own surplus of products, though management did not disclose the amount of unsold grills and electric blankets that were still in warehouses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/21/busin.main_headline: CENDANT TO SELL DIVISION TO FRENCH CONCERN
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; CENDANT TO SELL DIVISION TO FRENCH CONCERN
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/21/busin.body_text: **********The Cendant Corporation, the marketing and franchising company trying to recover from an accounting scandal, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its software business to the French utilities and communications company Vivendi S.A. for nearly $1 billion. Vivendi will give Cendant $800 million cash and make payments of up to $200 million through 1999. Cendant Software makes educational and entertainment software. It is expected to report sales of around $600 million this year. The software unit was part of CUC International Inc., which merged with HFS Inc. to form Cendant in December 1997. Cendant later learned that CUC had posted phony profit data. Cendant, based in Parsippany, N.J., said it would see a $450 million gain.
