https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; COKE EXPECTS 2D-QUARTER BEVERAGE SALES TO RISE 10%
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/26/busin.body_text: **********The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it expected sales of its beverages to rise as much as 10 percent in the second quarter. Coca-Cola, which is based in Atlanta, said second-quarter case volume, an important measure of the company's underlying growth, was expected to rise up to 8 percent in the United States, up to 11 percent in both Latin America and Europe, up to 17 percent in Africa and as much as 8 percent in the Middle and Far East. Coca-Cola, the world's largest beverage company, had 1997 revenue of $18.86 billion. Its stock rose 75 cents, to $84.875.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/21/busin.snippet: European's love of small cars has given rise to new type of vehicle, the micro-car; these cars have only one forward gear, seat two people but can cost as much as conventional cars--upwards of $9,000; so far few have been made, but they are starti...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/21/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Europe Takes To the Road In a Small Way; Despite Hefty Price Tags, Micro-Cars Gain a Toehold
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/21/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Europe Takes To the Road In a Small Way; Despite Hefty Price Tags, Micro-Cars Gain a Toehold
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/21/busin.body_text: **********Imagine a car 8 feet 2 inches long, with just two seats, whose diesel engine, purring like an outboard motor, propels it at a top speed of 27 miles an hour. Imagine a transmission so basic that it has only two settings, forward and reverse. **********Yes, there is such a car, and it is made in this town in western France. Amazingly, it sells for about 10 percent more than the smallest fully equipped models of Nissan, Ford or Fiat. **********What is the selling point? Simple. The car can be driven without a driver's license. Indeed, in several large European countries, like Italy and Spain, it can be driven by anyone 14 and older. For the half-dozen or so French and Italian companies that make the diminutive vehicles -- called voiturettes in France and quadricicli in Italy -- that has been enough to create a thriving market, particularly among the elderly and the very young. **********In fact, Europe's streets are so congested, and gasoline prices so high, that even licensed drivers are squeezing into these midget cars. The contrast with the United States, where drivers increasingly favor ever-bigger, ever-more-powerful vehicles, could not be more stark. Two of these tiny cars, parked end to end, could hide behind the Ford Motor Company's Expedition sport utility vehicle with room to spare. **********Voiturettes, which get about 68 miles a gallon, are probably the only automobiles, if they are in fact automobiles, with their roots in a legal loophole. French law exempts people who drive certain light vehicles from needing a license. The law was intended for motor scooters, but since it does not mention the number of wheels, enterprising French companies began building the bulbous four-wheeled runabouts two decades ago and found a ready customer base among people who for whatever reason lacked driver's licenses. **********But the manufacturers have expanded their market, two years ago banding together and lobbying successfully to have the cars legalized in much of the rest of Europe. In 1997, sales of the nine-member trade association totaled 16,000 voiturettes and are expected to rise this year to about 25,000. Top manufacturers like Microcar and Aixam, both of France, expect sales to double by 2000. **********More and more, these manufacturers are looking for buyers among professionals and homemakers who just want to get around the narrow lanes of villages from Tuscany to Touraine. **********European manufacturers of conventional small cars, like Renault in France, Volkswagen in Germany and Fiat in Italy, have poured billions of dollars into small-car development in recent years, paying little note to the voiturettes. But in October, fresh attention will focus on the market for two-seaters when Mercedes-Benz, a unit of Daimler-Benz of Germany, becomes the first large auto maker to enter the market with a fully equipped model called the Smart Car, which it developed with SMH, the Swiss conglomerate that makes Swatches. **********The makers of conventional cars say they are not fazed. ''Our products are significantly different,'' said Luc Bastard, a spokesman for the Association of European Automobile Manufacturers in Brussels. ''They are not really competing.'' **********Others are less sure. ''This is an interesting market,'' said Nigel Griffith, head of automotive research at DRI/McGraw Hill in London, ''because very few people know about it.'' **********Several changes combined to breathe fresh life into the voiturette industry, a Lilliputian copy of the mainstream automobile business. **********In the late 1970's, public transport in the French countryside declined as the state railway cut back underused routes, prompting several French companies to try their hand at building small cars for elderly people who were stranded in the country without a driver's license. French law specified that anyone 14 and older, license or no, could drive a motorized vehicle with an engine capacity of less than 50 cubic centimeters. (The age limit has since been lifted to 16.) **********In 1981, a pleasure-boat manufacturer named Jeanneau in this village about 50 miles from the Atlantic coast decided to adapt its skills with fiberglass paneling and motors to produce a four-wheeled vehicle that it dubbed the Microcar. ''The law didn't mention the number of wheels, or anything else,'' said Dominique Mathon, the Microcar division's managing director. Two years ago, after Jeanneau was acquired by the big French yacht builder Beneteau, best known in the United States for its sleek sailboats, it joined several other voiturette makers to lobby the European Union for laws that would make any voiturette model that was approved in one European country automatically marketable in all 14 other member states. **********''This town has 12,000 people, and there's one bus a day to Nantes,'' the next largest city, said Mr. Mathon, a former Volkswagen executive. ''So from a loophole we created a product, and from the product we created new legislation.'' **********Armed with the new law, Microcar last year enlisted Italjet S.p.A., an Italian motorcycle maker, to sell its cars in Italy and Spain. At the same time, Automobiles Ligier, another French manufacturer, signed a deal with Piaggio S.p.A., the Italian company that makes Vespa scooters, to market its Ambra brand of voiturette outside France. In 1997, the first full year of sales, Piaggio sold 2,200 Ambras in Italy alone, after selling 800 in the last two months of 1996, and this year it hopes to sell more than 3,000. ''The phenomenon is growing,'' said Simone Piattelli, a Piaggio spokesman. ''We're very satisfied.'' **********Touring Microcar's factory here is akin to going through a miniature version of an auto plant. The lightweight body is formed by gluing together nine sheets of reinforced polyester. Jean-Luc Martineau, Microcar's technical director, said that to keep costs down, Microcar cannibalized conventional vehicles. Thus, the headlights and taillights come from a General Motors subcompact, the Opel Corsa; the continuously variable transmission is supplied by Bombardier of Canada, which uses it in a snowmobile. ''The design is ours, and then we modify it to fit standard parts,'' Mr. Martineau said. **********Voiturettes, with their top speed of 27 miles an hour, are not permitted on highways, so for maximum efficiency they are equipped with one-  or two-cylinder diesel engines. By law, these mini-cars cannot weigh more than 770 pounds. The Microcar, like its French and Italian competitors, is almost four feet shorter than Ford's smallest model, the Ka, which weighs about 1,900 pounds and is made and sold in Europe and South America. **********But Ford, which sold 202,000 Kas in Europe last year, its first full year of sales, says it does not fear the voiturettes. Don Hume, a spokesman for Ford Europe in Britain, when asked if he thought of them as competition, replied, ''In all honesty, no.'' Their engines are small, he said, and their use limited to city driving. And in some large countries, like Britain, they are prohibited. ''If you look at the customer profile, they're quite different,'' he said. **********Market analysts say the voiturette's real problem is price. Microcar models, for instance, sell for up to 78,000 French francs, about $13,000, more than you can pay for subcompacts like the Ka, the Renault Twingo or Fiat Cinquecento. Yet those cars, built for up to five passengers, feature five-speed transmissions and are equipped for highway driving. Many models come with air-conditioning, air bags and other safety features lacking in voiturettes. **********The cars are so costly, said Didier Joos, an analyst at DRI/McGraw Hill in London who recently studied the voiturette market, because of their reliance on expensive standard parts and small production runs. Last year, the biggest manufacturer, Aixam, turned out only about 5,800 cars. ''With this volume it is difficult to produce cheaply,'' he said. **********Moreover, he said, future legislative changes, such as requiring a driver's license, could turn the boom into a fluke. The industry estimates that about half of all voiturette owners are older than 65. **********No one expects prices to come down significantly. Mr. Mathon says the components and materials needed to keep the size and weight within the law are simply too expensive. But prices are expected to come down a bit, and there have even been hints of a price war in France recently. **********If a market for two-seaters arises in Europe, experts like Mr. Joos say, it will more likely be driven by cars like Mercedes-Benz's new Smart Car. ''One is a real car trying to be a forward-looking approach to urban mobility,'' Mr. Joos said, referring to the Smart Car. ''The other is something very much related to legislation and the social fact that some people have no access to mobility.'' **********Still, some motorists with driver's licenses are willing to pay a premium for the voiturette's minuscule size and extreme mobility in congested cities. **********''This car helps me to schedule one or two more appointments a day than my colleagues,'' said Dominique Fessart, a 50-year-old property manager in Paris who paid about $9,600 for his white Microcar Lyra. ''I can practically park wherever I want.'' **********But ''I know what a real car is,'' he added. He has a BMW for the highway. **********The safety issue has not come up much, though in some countries, like Italy, there is talk of requiring youngsters 14 and over to take driver education in school. And some manufacturers, like Microcar, offer buyers several hours of free driving lessons. (Others just hand you a booklet that says, in effect, Here's how to drive your voiturette.) **********But the voiturette makers are prepared if a discussion does arise. They argue that elderly people, their main customers, who statistically are most prone to accidents, are actually safer in a tiny car, since it is easier to drive, cannot go nearly as fast and is not allowed on highways. **********Asked whether he thought a market for voiturettes existed outside Europe, Microcar's Mr. Mathon replied that it might ''in any country where you don't need a license.'' **********Mr. Mathon said he even sold one, outfitted with an electric motor, to a buyer from the United States who had seen one in Paris and said he wanted it for use on his own property. **********Yet experts said they doubted the car's diminutive size and questionable safety would qualify it for American roads. **********''Can you believe a crash between a Dodge Ram and a voiturette?'' asked Mr. Joos of DRI.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/22/busin.snippet: Peoplesoft Inc's shares plunge 23 percent after maker of business management software warns that its sales growth will plummet by half because of stronger competition (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/22/busin.main_headline: PEOPLESOFT SHARES PLUNGE ON GROWTH WARNING
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/22/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; PEOPLESOFT SHARES PLUNGE ON GROWTH WARNING
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/22/busin.body_text: **********Peoplesoft Inc.'s shares plunged 23 percent yesterday after the No. 2 maker of business management software warned that its sales growth would plummet by half because of stronger competition. The shares fell $6, to $19.75, in trading of 37.7 million shares. The company, based in Pleasanton, Calif., posted earnings Monday in line with expectations. Peoplesoft has lost nearly $9 billion in market value, a drop of nearly 70 percent, in the last six months on concerns about slowing demand in the $14.4 billion market for business software. It expects 1999 revenue to rise 25 percent to 35 percent, compared with the 60 percent gain expected this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/15/busin.snippet: Hilton Hotels Corp says third-quarter earnings will fall short of analysts' expectations and figures a year earlier (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/15/busin.main_headline: Hilton Says Its Earnings Will Fall Short
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/15/busin.print_headline: Hilton Says Its Earnings Will Fall Short
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/15/busin.body_text: **********The Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that its third-quarter earnings would fall short of analysts' expectations and figures a year earlier, in part because the Asian financial crisis had kept overseas travelers from its hotels in Hawaii and California. **********Hilton said earnings for the quarter ending Sept. 30 would be in the low 30-cents-a-share range. A First Call Corporation survey of 14 analysts had predicted earnings of 38 cents a share for the quarter. Hilton earned $94 million, or 35 cents a diluted share, in the period a year earlier.. **********Hilton attributed the lower-than-expected earnings to softness at its Honolulu and San Francisco hotels because of the continuing Asian crisis. It also cited lower management fee income from international properties, particularly the Conrad International Hong Kong. **********The hotel and gaming company, based in Beverly Hills, said it had also won less than usual at gambling tables at Bally's Park Place in Atlantic City, and that a sluggish Las Vegas, Nev., market, had also hurt earnings **********Hilton expects fourth-quarter operating results to be in line with company and Wall Street expectations of 31 cents a share. **********Today, shares of Hilton Hotels fell 62.5 cents, to $18.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/12/techn.snippet: Robert Hercz brief assessments of some World Wide Web sites on wine (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/12/techn.body_text: **********THE World Wide Web site of the Wine Spectator (www.winespectator.com) is an impressive starting point for on-line wine resources. The magazine's text is only one issue behind the newsstand, and there is a free searchable database of 15,000 reviews, with tasting notes and ratings, covering the previous two years. There is a Wine Basics section with essays on tasting and varietals, country-by-country descriptions of wines and more. **********Folksy and friendly, Robin Garr's Wine Lovers' Page (www.wine-lovers-page.com) includes a huge volume of resources, highlighted by Mr. Garr's ''Quick Wine-Tasting Course,'' a collection of articles he wrote for The Louisville (Ky.) Courier-Journal. There are also tasting forms, a glossary, vintage charts and bulletin boards for discussions. **********Other magazines worth visiting on the Web include Smart Wine Online (smartwine.com) and Wine Enthusiast (www.winemag.com). All sites, of course, have links to other sites, increasing the chances of finding pleasant surprises like Corkscrew.Com (www.corkscrew.com), devoted to a San Francisco Bay Area couple's 20-year passion for collecting corkscrews.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/27/busin.snippet: Wall Street's ability to be taken in by outsized success and trappings of genius is made manifest in the faltering of Long-Term Capital Management LP, hedge fund operated by John W Meriwether with some of the brightest securities traders, includin...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/27/busin.main_headline: BILLIONS UPON BILLIONS: A special report.; Fault Lines of Risk Appear As Market Hero Stumbles
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/27/busin.print_headline: BILLIONS UPON BILLIONS: A special report.; Fault Lines of Risk Appear As Market Hero Stumbles
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/27/busin.body_text: **********Wall Street, often hard-nosed and cynical, was utterly dazzled by John W. Meriwether. He was viewed as a bond trader with a Midas touch, a mathematician of genius who found gold nuggets in markets where others saw only sand. **********In the giddy 1980's, he presided over a team of bond traders who generated immense profits for Salomon Brothers with arcane strategies that were dubbed ''rocket science.'' But in a world of sharp tongues and sharper elbows, Mr. Meriwether was softly self-possessed, inspiring confidence among equals and hero-worship among underlings. A brush with scandal, as the supervisor of a trader caught manipulating bids on Treasury securities in 1991, did little to tarnish his gleaming reputation. When he left the firm in February 1994, some of his best traders and two Nobel-laureate economists followed him into a celebrated exile in Greenwich, Conn. **********There, with fishing breaks when the bluefish were running, Mr. Meriwether and his partners operated Long-Term Capital Management L.P., a largely unregulated investment pool for the wealthy known as a hedge fund. By early 1998, Mr. Meriwether's team had invested $90 billion, most of it borrowed from Wall Street bankers so confident of Mr. Meriwether's skills that a few had even sunk some of their personal wealth into his new fund. **********And it was there, last week, that the glittering Meriwether image toppled from its Wall Street pedestal and shattered. A hastily assembled consortium of international banks and brokerage houses took possession of the faltering firm and pumped in $3.65 billion to prevent a disorderly collapse that could have panicked the credit markets and sent shock waves from small-town real estate offices to the halls of Government in Brazil. If the fund had been forced to liquidate its entire portfolio, its sales could have undermined the value of financial contracts worth as much as $1.25 trillion. **********How one man, utterly unknown beyond his rarefied world, became such a potent source of instability in one of the deepest, richest markets in the world reveals how Wall Street can be seduced by outsized success and the trappings of genius. And while the last-minute rescue grew out of an emergency warning system  that provides some comfort to the nation's financial markets, the march to the precipice reveals how little regulators, investors and even traders themselves understand the fault lines of risk buried in today's global financial landscape. **********''It is too early to give the definitive answer to what the lessons are, but clearly firms have got to look at their exposure and leverage, and at what margins of safety they have in these transactions,'' said Peter Bakstansky, senior vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which provided the framework for the rescue. ''And they must have a better sense of the risk analysis being done by their borrowers.'' **********A top Wall Street executive briefed on the negotiations last week said he was clear about the lesson for his own firm: ''We will never let our exposure to one counterparty get to these levels again -- never. He had gotten too big for the market. Everybody gave him too much money.'' **********In a world where the concept of too much money is met with blank stares, John Meriwether was able to borrow heavily from more than a dozen financial institutions, each of which was largely unaware of how much he had borrowed from the others. Hedge funds are private partnerships that are not required to disclose their trading strategies, and that can take money only from institutions and wealthy individuals, on the theory that these sophisticated investors understand the above-average risks involved. **********Mr. Meriwether's hedge fund was even more secretive than most, to prevent rivals from copying its strategy or from anticipating its next move. In essence, the fund placed bets that tiny deviations in the traditional relationships between the prices of various securities would eventually return to normal. **********For example, the interest rate on corporate bonds is usually about one percentage point higher than on comparable Treasury bonds, reflecting the greater risk of lending to companies. If the gap, called the spread, widened to more than one percentage point, the Meriwether team  could bet with confidence that the relationship would ultimately revert to normal. Myron S. Scholes and Robert C. Merton, who shared a Nobel prize in economics, helped program powerful computers to recognize countless similar profit opportunities. **********The profit on each of these trades was so small that the Meriwether fund had to make its money on volume. As one Solomon Brothers veteran described it, the fund was like a roulette player betting on red and doubling up its bets each time the wheel stopped on black. ''A gambler with $1,000 will probably lose,'' he said. ''A gambler with $1 billion will wind up owning the casino, because it is a mathematical certainty that red will come up eventually -- but you have to have enough chips to stay at the table until that happens.'' **********Last week's rescue, in effect, keeps Long-Term Capital at the table, buying time in which its massive gamble might yet pay off. **********One way the fund accumulated its chips was by borrowing at least $20 for each $1 in capital. **********At the end of 1997, Mr. Meriwether had so many chips that he was giving some back. Investors who had joined the fund after February 1994 were handed $2.82 for every $1 they had invested, and were told very politely to go away. Original investors from outside the firm -- who considered themselves the lucky ones -- took out their profits but kept their original stakes in the fund. After all, the fund had posted profits of 43 percent in 1995 and 41 percent in 1996. **********As a result, the fund, whose capital base started at $1.2 billion, including $100 million in general partners' money, was reduced to about $4.7 billion at the beginning of this year, from roughly $7 billion at its peak. **********Storm Warning **********An Eastern Wind Rakes Greenwich **********The first gust of the approaching storm came in June. The fund was down 10 percent, its worst monthly loss ever. Early August was even worse. As the Russian financial markets and other emerging markets grew increasingly treacherous, investors sought the safety of Treasury securities, pushing up Treasury prices while most other bond prices fell. Unfortunately, this pattern was the opposite of the Meriwether team's bets, and its paper losses grew. **********Around Aug. 15, Mr. Meriwether warned his investors and trading partners about the grim results. But with roughly $3.7 billion left in capital, the partners were still confident they could weather the storm, and many left on vacation. **********Then came Friday, Aug. 21 -- a terrible day for the bond market as skittish buyers, dumping corporate bonds to buy Treasury bonds, sent Treasury rates to a 20-year low.  Long-Term Capital's general partners rushed back to their Greenwich offices, working through the weekend and the following week to review their positions, which had dropped 40 percent that month. **********They approached new investors. But when the stock market plummeted on Aug. 31, any hope for new money evaporated. **********On Sept. 2, Mr. Meriwether invited existing investors to put in more money to help the fund stay the course. Again, there were some talks, but no cash. **********Around this time, one key element of the Wall Street warning system was activated: Mr. Meriwether's clearing broker, the Bear Stearns Companies, intensified its scrutiny of the fund's trading activities. **********Clearing brokers execute the trades of their client firms, and if one of those firms cannot deliver the cash or securities required to satisfy its obligations, the clearing broker must settle the trade with the opposite party. To reduce their own risk, such brokers require their clearing clients to keep funds on deposit as collateral, and they can limit trading. Bear Stearns did, and Long-Term Capital complied, people who were briefed on their relationship said. **********Another part of the Wall Street warning system was tripped, too. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which monitors the key commercial banks that serve the Wall Street community, was questioning how much Mr. Meriwether owed to institutions under its supervision. **********Distress Call **********A Legendary Trader Reaches Out **********On Friday, Sept. 18, what had been a deeply worrisome problem became a full-blown crisis. The triggering event is still shrouded in official silence, but several people with sideline seats say that Mr. Meriwether, the celebrated bond trader, was blindsided by an unraveling stock investment. As the prices of Ciena and Tellabs shares fell following the collapse of their merger, Long-Term Capital had to provide additional collateral to brokers who had lent it money to buy those shares. Federal regulations on such transactions leave no room to wiggle. **********In any case, the $3.7 billion in capital that Long-Term Capital had in mid-August had dwindled by more than two-thirds. It had become clear to several top Wall Street executives that Mr. Meriwether needed fresh money or his firm would fail. **********''And if this firm had to liquidate in distress, the ramifications for the global marketplace would be very negative,'' one senior Wall Street executive said. How negative? ''No one felt they could even quantify it.  That's one of the things that made it so scary.'' **********No one knew exactly the magnitude of the fund's liabilities, not even Bear Stearns, in part because the fund used complex financial contracts, known as derivatives, whose value was difficult to assess. But the yawning fear was that the nascent recovery in the market for bonds -- from mortgage-backed securities that help underwrite home purchases to the sovereign debt of Brazil -- would be ''stopped in its tracks and turn the other way'' if Long-Term Capital failed. **********Though early reports have credited the Fed with pulling together -- some say forcing -- the bailout, it seems to have begun on Sunday afternoon, when Jon S. Corzine, a senior partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company, talked with Peter R. Fisher, an executive vice president of the New York Fed who was monitoring the crisis in Greenwich, and with top executives at Merrill Lynch, UBS of Switzerland and J. P. Morgan. Some of the firms had lent money to the fund, while others were trading partners or investors. **********Those calls helped knit together a group to solve the crisis: Mr. Corzine; David H. Komansky, chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company, and Herbert M. Allison Jr., Merrill's president; David Solo from UBS A.G. and Douglas A. Warner 3d, chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company. **********At 7:30 on Tuesday morning, the core group decided to gather on neutral ground in a private dining room that Mr. Fisher made available at the New York Fed's headquarters a few blocks from Wall Street. At the same times, teams from the investment banks were dispatched to Greenwich ''to look at the situation,'' one top-level Wall Street executive said. **********That examination made it clear that the fund would not be able to cover its obligations if it were forced to hurriedly liquidate its positions. **********At 7 p.m., sleek black limousines again converged on the Fed's headquarters. This time, the core group had invited six other banks and brokerage houses, including Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and the Travelers Group. **********While the Fed officials encouraged the group to come together, how pivotal a role the Fed played in the rescue effort is the subject of considerable disagreement among the participants in the drama. **********''The Fed just provided the forum,'' one senior Wall Street executive said. Some of the bankers, however, have complained privately that regulators were in fact pressuring them to rescue the fund. **********The negotiations were difficult, but the executives finally agreed they had no alternative but to give Mr. Meriwether more money. **********Help Arrives **********Buying Time, But at a Price **********At 10 A.M. Wednesday, senior officers of 16 banks and brokerage firms  assembled in a Fed conference room. They waited for more than a half-hour for William J. McDonough, the president of the New York Fed, who had just returned from London. At 10:40, he came in to explain that Mr. Corzine of Goldman, Sachs might have found a buyer to come to Long-Term Capital's rescue. **********''Everyone in the room knew'' that the potential buyer was the celebrated investor Warren E. Buffett, said one senior executive who was briefed on the meeting. Mr. Buffett had stepped in to rescue Salomon Brothers in 1991, after the bond trading scandal that prompted Mr. Meriwether's departure, and his involvement would have injected instant confidence into the marketplace. When Mr. McDonough suggested a recess until 1 P.M., the executives left the Fed, no doubt with their fingers crossed. **********When they returned, however, the Fed president announced that the potential buyer had balked. Mr. Komansky of Merrill Lynch then challenged the group: How much additional money would each firm contribute to keep the fund alive and forestall the crisis of confidence that its collapse could produce? **********There were angry arguments and resentful speeches, reflecting the tensions the men faced. Each executive knew that if his firm seized its collateral from Long-Term Capital and fled, only a few of them would reach the exit before the roof fell in. Nevertheless, collective action was difficult for such natural competitors, even with the Fed's brooding oversight. **********Bear Stearns insisted, successfully, that its risks as the fund's clearing broker should exempt it from further contributions. Executives from three foreign banks initially balked at contributing anything, provoking a lecture from a senior Wall Street executive. The trio huddled privately, and announced they would participate after all. **********In the end, 14 firms committed $100 million to $350 million each. That they could do so on such short notice is one happy result of the long, fat years in the capital markets that preceded these last anxious months. That the rescue effort was organized so smoothly suggests, too, that a strong habit of informal cooperation and close consultation has been forged in past crises. **********At most, the deal bought the fund  some breathing room in which their bets may, just possibly, ripen into the extraordinary profits that tempted them into this risky territory in the first place. But the cost was high. The rescue was essentially an informal, high-speed bankruptcy reorganization that turned Long-Term Capital's creditors into its new owners, who will oversee every aspect of the restructured firm's existence. **********When the rescue package was reported to Mr. Meriwether in Greenwich at around 7 p.m. on Wednesday, he gathered his exhausted partners in his office and explained the deal, as he understood it. The partners in the room, and those listening by telephone in Tokyo and London, were calm as their future took an unexpected and personally painful twist. **********Honeymoons would be canceled, weddings postponed. Homes under construction might never be finished, and once-glittering reputations might be lost forever. **********At the end of the week, Mr. Meriwether and his partners retained a sliver of equity in the firm that they built on genius and panache. Their 180 employees -- most of whom had invested each year's bonuses in the fund -- were left with little more than uncertain jobs. **********But regulators and others are left pondering how a small band of traders could threaten the confidence that knits together the world's financial markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/world.snippet: US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright will spend extra day in London for further talks with Israeli and Palestinian leaders to restore momentum to peace talks; has been unable to win agreement from Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu to American p...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/world.main_headline: Albright Says She Will Add Day to Talks On Mideast
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/world.print_headline: Albright Says She Will Add Day to Talks On Mideast
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright decided tonight to remain here an additional day to extend what she hopes will be decisive talks with Israeli and Palestinian leaders that restore momentum to the search for peace. **********Ms. Albright, in a long negotiating day, was unable to win agreement from the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to American proposals for an Israeli withdrawal from 13 percent of the West Bank over 12 weeks, parallel with specific Palestinian moves to counter terrorism. **********Ms. Albright had a second meeting, of an hour, with Mr. Netanyahu, after five hours with him earlier, but had little to say in public. **********She is to meet Mr. Netanyahu for breakfast on Tuesday morning before seeing Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. She spent 90 minutes with Mr. Arafat today. **********Mr. Arafat has accepted the American ideas in principle, and a senior Palestinian negotiator, Nabil Shaath, said, ''Ms. Albright did not propose to us any significant alteration.'' **********Senior American officials confirmed tonight that the main stumbling block was Mr. Netanyahu and his insistence that he could not withdraw, for security reasons, from the 13 percent of the West Bank the Americans think is the minimum that Mr. Arafat can accept. **********Mr. Netanyahu has publicly said he can yield 9 percent before final status talks begin, but has privately told Mr. Clinton that he might be able to give up 11 percent. **********Mr. Netanyahu also wants firmer assurances on security from the Palestinians, and the two sides disagree about the scope and timing of a later Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank, due by the end of August. **********Ms. Albright's spokesman, James P. Rubin, was carefully downbeat, saying this evening, after the early sessions, ''At this point we do not have compelling evidence that the meetings will yield a breakthrough.'' **********Although ''the situation is relatively unchanged,'' Mr. Rubin said, Ms. Albright ''is determined to keep at it in the course of the night, because she wants to do all she can to make the meetings in London decisive.'' **********Mr. Rubin declined to assign blame, but said: ''A failure to put the process back on track will carry with it grave risks of disillusionment and violence in the Middle East, and that is why Secretary Albright is working so hard.'' **********If the meetings fail, he said, the Americans would decide ''what next steps to take.'' Those steps could include efforts to increase pressure on Mr. Netanyahu, including a public discussion of the American proposals and a clear statement of who disagreed with them. **********Mr. Netanyahu, with the support of 81 of the 100 Senators in Washington, has urged President Clinton not to go public with proposals that they contend an elected Israeli Prime Minister cannot accept. The Americans deny that they want a confrontation  and say their proposals are intended just ''to get both parties to 'yes,' ''  one official said. **********An important part of the proposals, if accepted, would commit both Israel and the Palestinians to accelerated negotiations, which Mr. Netanyahu favors, on a final settlement. Under the 1993 and 1995 Oslo Accords, which mandated the interim withdrawals, talks on a final settlement are supposed to continue in parallel and conclude a year from today, in May 1999. **********''Time is running out to complete the sequence laid out in Oslo,'' Mr. Rubin said. ''In the absence of that, there is a grave danger that the vacuum in the peace process will cause violence.'' **********Mr. Arafat has said he will unilaterally declare a Palestinian state in May 1999 if there is no agreement. **********Mr. Rubin warned today that given ''the extreme complexity and sensitivity of the issues involved,'' including final borders, control of water sources and a resolution of the status of Jerusalem, ''a year is not a long time to complete that process.'' **********Mr. Arafat was largely noncommittal today, saying only that little progress had been made. Mr. Netanyahu, by contrast, was typically expansive, saying he was here to try to achieve a breakthrough and urging compromise on both sides. **********''It is time to move the process forward,'' he said after meeting Ms. Albright this afternoon. **********''There is an equal willingness to move forward on the other side,'' Mr. Netanyahu said of Mr. Arafat. ''Both of us have suffered from wars and terrorism. **********''I think the Americans understand our position better. There are certain decisions which I can only take in Israel,'' with the Cabinet. **********But American officials, even privately, were pessimistic that Mr. Netanyahu would settle on a figure that Mr. Arafat could accept. Mr. Netanyahu insists that Israel maintains the right to decide how much territory to hand back. **********Mr. Rubin was circumspect. ''We're working assiduously and we're trying to be as creative as we can to bridge the gaps,'' he said. ''But our optimism is not high, given what we've seen so far.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/15/busin.snippet: Terence Smith to join PBS to head special unit that will examine performance of news media; will report on press-related issues regularly for News Hour With Jim Lehrer; Pew Charitable Trusts funds effort (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/15/busin.main_headline: Media Talk; A PBS Look at Press Behavior
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/15/busin.print_headline: Media Talk; A PBS Look at Press Behavior
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/15/busin.body_text: **********In an unusual agreement between a charitable trust and a news program, ''The News Hour With Jim Lehrer'' on PBS has added Terence Smith, the longtime CBS correspondent, to its staff to head a special unit devoted to examining the performance of the news media. The work will be financed by a two-year, $3 million grant from the Pew Charitable Trusts, an organization based in Philadelphia devoted to supporting activities in culture, public education and public policy. **********Mr. Smith, who worked as a correspondent and editor for The New York Times for 20 years before joining CBS in 1985, will leave his CBS post and report on press-related issues regularly for ''The News Hour,'' the weeknight news and analysis program. His work is scheduled to begin appearing in the fall. **********In a statement, Rebecca W. Rimel, the president of the Pew Charitable Trusts, said: ''What is needed is a reasoned but impassioned examination of press behavior on a regular basis. The 'News Hour' will provide that much-needed forum.'' **********Mr. Smith said he expected to examine such subjects as the content of the news, its packaging, issues of taste, the effect of money on the news media, the trend toward tabloid treatment of the news, consolidation in the industry and the debate over free broadcast time for political candidates.   BILL CARTER

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/04/world.main_headline: KEY SENATE PANEL PASSES RESOLUTION TO EXPAND NATO
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/04/world.print_headline: KEY SENATE PANEL PASSES RESOLUTION TO EXPAND NATO
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/04/world.body_text: **********The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted overwhelmingly today to reshape the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, founded in 1949 to stop the spread of Communism in Europe, by adding three former foes, Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. **********The committee's 16 to 2 vote, reflecting only modest misgivings on the right and the left, sent a resolution to approve NATO expansion to the full Senate, which is expected to pass it later this month by the necessary two-thirds majority. **********The committee chairman, Senator  Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican, said it appeared that the NATO resolution would pass the full Senate ''on a substantial positive vote.'' He called the vote today ''an obvious vote of confidence in the democracies of Eastern Europe.'' **********Senator Joseph R. Biden of Delaware, the senior Democrat, said that ''NATO enlargement is an historic opportunity for the United States, and voting to enlarge NATO now sets a positive course, expanding the zone of stability eastward.'' He called the measure ''truly a bipartisan document, and one that will serve the interests of our country well.'' **********Senator Richard Lugar, Republican of Indiana, said that ''NATO expansion will set the foundation for decades of European peace and prosperity.'' And he warned, ''If we fail, historians may look back at the early post-cold-war period as a tragic loss of opportunities.'' **********The opponents to the measure represented the ideological poles on the commmittee. On the right, Senator John Ashcroft of Missouri voted no because he was worried about what NATO's role might become. On the left, Senator Paul D. Wellstone of Minnesota argued that expansion to include former Soviet-bloc countries would dim the prospects for Russian democracy, economic reform and commitment to arms control. **********And Senator Robert C. Smith, a New Hampshire Republican, began to circulate a letter, signed this evening by about a dozen Senators, his staff members said, that asks the Senate leadership to postpone the vote by the full Senate until after June 1. **********The letter asks for the delay to allow for clarification on the questions raised about expansion, including its cost and whether or not new NATO members should first be admitted to the European Union. **********While the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said he was not inclined to postpone the vote more than a week or two, senior Administration officials were more cautious. ''We think we will win this vote, but this adds a little last-minute, last-ditch drama,'' one official said. ''When the Senate votes is up to the Senate.'' **********Senator Wellstone, a Democrat, said that he had agonized over voting no, that the Czech President, Vaclav Havel, ''is a hero to me,'' and that ''of all the decisions I've made as a Senator, this is the most difficult one.'' **********But he added: ''I'm very worried -- I've got a prickling in my finger tips -- about a redivision of Europe.'' Such an event, he said, would cause ''a poisoning of relations with Russia and ultranationalists coming into power.'' **********Senator Wellstone said that his father was born in pre-Soviet Ukraine and had fled before the 1917 revolution, and that his father's family was believed to have been murdered in the Stalin-era purges. **********''He was the wisest man I've ever known,'' the Senator said, ''but I think he'd be in agreement with George Kennan,'' the American diplomat and historian who said a year ago that ''expanding NATO would be the most fateful error of American policy in the entire post-cold-war era.'' **********Senator Ashcroft, a Republican who is considering a Presidential race, questioned in today's hearing ''what the role of NATO is'' now that the collapse of the Soviet Union has removed any threat to the alliance. **********He said he worried that NATO was moving ''from a defense of territory to a defense of the interests of member countries'' anywhere in the world. ''I have real reservations about what the role of NATO is, and should it be expanded not just to include new countries but redesigned as an instrument of international policy around the world.'' **********''We need limits and safeguards,'' Mr. Ashcroft added. ''Maybe we need a new organization, like a United Nations, with a standing army.'' **********Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, said she had begun nearly a year's worth of hearings on NATO expansion ''with an anti-NATO bent, and I've changed my mind.'' Citing the benefits of NATO forces in Bosnia, she said that a larger NATO would improve ''a solidification of the European community'' and a closer binding of the United States to Europe. **********Her theme -- that this first round of expansion is fine, but let's be careful about a second round -- was echoed by other liberal and centrist Senators today. Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, said he would vote for this first round but added, ''I share a lot of the concerns expressed about NATO.'' **********Senator Kerry also expressed skepticism about the stated costs of NATO expansion, saying, ''I've been very suspicious of cost analyses that keep getting reduced as the vote approaches.'' **********Senator John Warner, Republican of Virginia, has introduced an amendment to delay any second round of NATO expansion for three years after the current round is approved. The Clinton Administration has sharply opposed any binding time delay. **********His co-sponsor is Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who today introduced his own amendment, co-sponsored by Senator Warner, that would bar Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic from joining NATO until they are first admitted to the European Union. **********In an interview today, Senator Moynihan cited the words of Mr. Kennan and said he was most concerned about the impact of expansion on Russia. ''It's time to say, 'Hey, let's talk this one out, my heavens,' '' the Senator said. **********Administration officials said they took the worries over expansion seriously, but noted that the number of Senators expressing the most concern had been hovering at 20 or so since the summer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/26/techn.snippet: Archeologists are turning to Internet to announce their finds and findings, with many of their postings geared more toward generalist than specialist; journal articles follow later for colleagues and historical record; array of archeological Web s...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/26/techn.main_headline: Show Me the Mummy! Internet Offers a Home to Archeology
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/26/techn.print_headline: Show Me the Mummy! Internet Offers a Home to Archeology
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/26/techn.body_text: **********THE archeologist Heinrich Schliemann used Homer as his guide when he excavated Troy, and he published his findings in books. When Howard Carter unearthed the tomb of Tutankhamen in 1922, the world learned of his discovery through a spectacular scoop by The Times of London in a dispatch sent ''by runner from the Valley of the Kings.'' The paleontologist Richard E. Leakey drew widespread attention to humankind's African origins with a series of popular television documentaries. **********Runners are no longer needed to carry the latest news from the Valley of the Kings. Archeologists are turning to the Internet to announce their finds and findings, with many of their postings geared more toward the generalist than the specialist. Journal articles follow later for colleagues and the historical record. So with only a modicum of digging, the armchair archeologist can uncover a wealth of archeological sites. Web sites, that is. **********A few clicks of the mouse will transport a Web surfer to the Valley of the Kings, the great necropolis on the west bank of the Nile where archeologists are busy excavating one of the largest tombs ever found in Egypt. They are combing through what they call Tomb Five, believed to be the tomb of the many sons of Ramses II, who dominated the known world in the 13th century B.C. and, in his spare time, fathered more than a hundred children. **********Visitors to the Theban Mapping Project's Web site (www.kv5.com) can, with the aid of a plug-in or two, watch that excavation through a montage of color photographs. One by one the layers are peeled away on screen: first, discolored reddish dirt, which suggests the presence of mummified tissue to the practiced eye; 20 centimeters lower, the mummified thigh bone of a calf, which was once a prized food offering; below that,  three skulls, some with vertebrae still attached, and beneath them, a fully articulated skeleton lying amid bits of wrapping and burned fragments of wood. **********Thanks to the nature of interactive sites, the Web surfer can watch these skeletons unearthed in slow motion or at double speed or, should the desire strike, go backward to bury the bones all over again. **********Archeological Web sites are proliferating and come from all corners of the world. You can visit a dig of Mayan ruins in Belize (alishaw.sscf.ucsb.edu/ford), check out the excavation of a Maltese tomb from 2500 B.C. and see computer renderings of what it  might have looked like (www.bris.ac.uk/ Depts/Archaeology/html/research/ comvis/insite.htm) and (www.apva.org) learn about the excavation of Jamestown, Va. **********Field workers no longer have to wait as their manuscripts languish on the shelves of understaffed, underfinanced university presses. They can go on line almost instantly. Scholarly publishing and peer review can come later. More immediately, the Web connects archeologists to their far-flung colleagues (for consultation, or information on where to buy a centimeter scale or a good hieroglyphic pattern for needlework). But many sites are aimed at the general public, for education and entertainment and sometimes a little fund-raising. **********Many find the medium uniquely suited to the message. ''One of the wonderful things about the electronic media is the pace at which you can continue to change and update things,'' said Angela M. H. Schuster, an associate editor at Archaeology, the publication of the Archaeological Institute of America. ''One fragment or one glyph can suddenly readjust your entire understanding of a site. The Web allows you to revise very quickly.'' **********Archaeology magazine now has its own Web site (www.he.net/archaeol), and its editors have compiled a useful directory of favorite sites (www.he.net/archaeol/ wwwarky/wwwarky.html). Its parent organization, the Archaeological Institute of America, put its own directory of favorite sites on the Web this month, graded by appropriate audience (csaws.brynmawr.  edu:443/web2/AIAWebSites.html). **********Nigel Strudwick, an Egyptologist at the University of Cambridge, set up Egyptology Resources (www.newton.cam.ac.uk/egypt), one of the first such Web pages, in 1994. ''I was thinking of, to use a posh English term, the educated lay public,'' Dr. Strudwick said. ''Egyptologists are very bad about publicizing their work, and it is difficult to interest the media except in the most spectacular finds. Books are expensive -- 120 pounds sterling for a two-volume set with a lot of black-and-white photos and a few color plates -- and reach a small audience.'' **********Dr. Strudwick's site takes an in-depth look at his excavation of the tomb of Senneferi in Luxor. There are Quick Time Virtual Reality panoramas that place visitors in the shrine of the tomb, enabling them to examine the hieroglyphics and paintings on the walls (''My apologies for the various items of expedition equipment visible in the photographs''), a Coffins page and some very detailed explanations of how excavations are done, from digging techniques to staffing rotations to the forms that must be filled out for each artifact recovered. **********BACK in Thebes, the mapping project maintains a mixture of useful and enjoyable information on its site: timelines of 3,500 years of Egyptian dynasties, 365-degree color panoramas taken from various spots in the Valley of the Kings, the names and hieroglyphics of the known sons of Ramses II, blueprint-like plans of the tombs and pictures and biographies of the major players on the dig. **********The director of the mapping project and dig, Kent R. Weeks of the American University in Cairo, keeps Web visitors apprised of the latest developments through occasional progress reports. His letter of March 15 tells of sailing the Nile from Aswan to Abu Simbel to photograph scenes of Ramses II and his sons on the walls of temples, of the engineering problems involved in shoring up the walls of the ancient tomb to guard against collapse and, most important, the news that he and his colleagues have identified 108 chambers and corridors in the tomb so far and expect to find a total of 150. **********At its best, the sites give visitors an Indiana Jones, you-are-there sense. **********''On some walls, traces of finely carved raised relief scenes can still be seen,'' Dr. Weeks wrote. ''In many chambers, pieces of carved limestone or painted plaster lie on the floor where they fell after floodborne debris knocked them from the walls.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.snippet: Serge Schmemann analysis contends that scandal that broke in Washington in midst of Pres Clinton's separate meetings with Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat was boon for Netanyahu and setback for Arafat; says ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.body_text: **********Neither Benjamin Netanyahu nor Yasir Arafat would admit it, but the scandal that broke in Washington last week in the midst of their separate meetings with President Clinton was a boon for the Israeli Prime Minister and a setback for the Palestinian leader. **********On the record, both declared that Mr. Clinton's problems were not a factor in American efforts to revive the foundering Oslo accords, and both declared their meetings useful. But their respective reactions left no doubt that anything that served to deflect the White House from the Arab-Israeli front brought benefit to Mr. Netanyahu and dismay to Mr. Arafat. **********If the leaders concealed their sentiments behind diplomatic words,  some hard-liners made no secret of theirs. Focusing on the fact that the woman in the latest scandal, Monica S. Lewinsky, is Jewish, Muslim fundamentalists like Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the spiritual leader of Hamas, painted her as an agent of ''world Zionism,'' while some nationalist rabbis were said to have depicted her as a biblical Esther, who garnered favor with the ruler to save her people. **********Both Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat are to meet with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who intends to stop over this weekend, evidently to demonstrate that the United States intends to persevere in its mediation effort. Ms. Albright is to make the stop en route to Saudi Arabia and other countries to discuss the crisis with Iraq. **********Mr. Netanyahu had gone to Washington braced to resist pressures by Mr. Clinton to make significant withdrawals in the West Bank. The President and Ms. Albright made no secret of their frustration with Mr. Netanyahu, denying him a lunch or a joint news conference at the White House. Mr. Netanyahu responded by scheduling meetings with fundamentalist Christians and Republican leaders hostile to Mr. Clinton. **********But the idea that Mr. Clinton reportedly broached at the meetings, linking the three required Israeli withdrawals from the West Bank to a concrete list of Palestinian obligations, in effect supported Mr. Netanyahu's central insistence that any revival of the Oslo process be contingent on Palestinian fulfillment of specific conditions, ranging from adoption of a new charter to steps to combat militant organizations. **********After Mr. Netanyahu concluded his meeting and before Mr. Arafat began his, the scandal broke. Even if Mr. Clinton was not totally distracted while meeting Mr. Arafat, the Palestinian leader was denied the chance he had eagerly awaited to make his case public. **********On his return, Mr. Netanyahu was greeted by his right-wing coalition as a conquering hero. Even Zeev Begin, a Likud hard-liner who has been one of Mr. Netanyahu's fiercest critics, enthusiastically approved the Prime Minister's performance. ''Standing firm is the right line to take, and it will have its rewards,'' he said. **********As if to demonstrate that he had not retreated an inch, Mr. Netanyahu indirectly rejected a central Palestinian demand, that Israel cease building new settlements in the West Bank. ''The Oslo accords do not negate our rights to construct new settlements or to continue to build in the city of Jerusalem,'' he said. **********At the same time, Mr. Netanyahu denied accusations that his real goal was to kill the Oslo accords and to put the blame on the Palestinians. **********''I am not looking for Palestinian opposition in order to undermine the peace process,'' he said. ''I want a Palestinian commitment to continue with the process. We are ready, willing and able to advance, provided the Palestinians agree to hold up their end of the agreement.'' **********Mr. Arafat, by contrast, left Washington in a sour mood. ''What he is offering is peanuts,'' he said of Mr. Netanyahu. ''It cannot be accepted.'' **********Convinced that Mr. Netanyahu had no intention of continuing with the Oslo process, and lacking any real leverage, Mr. Arafat had placed high hopes on Mr. Clinton to compel Israel to return to the land-for-peace formula that both sides accepted in 1993. **********Saeb Erekat, a senior negotiator who accompanied Mr. Arafat, said the Palestinian leader had warned the President that if the stalemate continued, he would step down. **********''He said that if Mr. Netanyahu continues with noncompliance, with all the security plans and settlements, I will tell my people that we failed, and resign,'' Mr. Erekat said. **********Mr. Erekat denied that Mr. Arafat's resignation threat was a response to American proposals. But Palestinian officials said it was clear that he intended to warn Mr. Clinton that unless the Americans changed Israel's stance, they would bear responsibility for any ensuing chaos. **********Many Israelis, Americans and Palestinians believe that Mr. Arafat's death or resignation could plunge the Palestinians into a bitter power struggle, with unpredictable consequences for the peace effort. **********From Washington, Mr. Arafat embarked on a tour of North Africa and Europe to try to drum up Arab and European support. But Arabic newspapers reported that he was unlikely to get more than a brief and limited summit meeting of Arab leaders. And in London, Prime Minister Tony Blair, the current chairman of the European Union, made clear that he would follow the American lead on the Arab-Israeli front. **********On his return to Gaza on Wednesday, Mr. Arafat vented his frustration when he was asked if he agreed to the proposed linked withdrawals. ''Definitely not,'' he snapped. His aides said he meant Mr. Netanyahu's proposals, not Mr. Clinton's.

The properties comprise seven office properties and seven research and development holdings. The portfolio is 95 percent leased, and more than 50 percent of the leases will come up for renewal within three years, giving the company a chance to raise rents, it said.
