https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/27/busin.snippet: Japanese call their government's repeated efforts to get the economy moving "strip-tease policy," according to Philippa Malmgren of Bankers Trust Co. in London — but no one on foreign-exchange markets seems to be getting excited by it..
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/27/busin.main_headline: Tokyo's Stimulus Plan Doesn't Excite Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/27/busin.print_headline: Tokyo's Stimulus Plan Doesn't Excite Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/27/busin.body_text: **********Japanese call their government's repeated efforts to get the economy moving "strip-tease policy," according to Philippa Malmgren of Bankers Trust Co. in London — but no one on foreign-exchange markets seems to be getting excited by it. **********Japan's cabinet approved its largest economic-stimulus package so far Friday, a combination including tax cuts and public-works spending with a total value put at 16.6 trillion yen ($128 billion). **********But only the possibility of yet another package, or the fear of another bruising round of official intervention to keep asset prices where Tokyo wants them, inhibits investors from acting out their disapproval by dumping yen wholesale. **********The dollar finished last week at 131.25 yen, down 0.4 percent from the previous week. **********Nevertheless, Ms. Malmgren said, a further depreciation of the yen is inevitable. **********In her view, the 7.7 trillion yen in spending on public works in the latest **********package is an impressively large figure, but only because it is not included in the calculation of the government's deficit under the Fiscal Consolidation Act. **********That law, which requires a deficit no larger than 3 percent by 2003, keeps Tokyo from spending its way to an economic recovery. Although the government agreed Friday to delay that deadline until 2005, Ms. Malmgren said the underlying question about its true intention remained unanswered: Is its main aim to control the deficit or to fix the economy? **********Robert Feldman at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Tokyo said the stimulus plan "at best stops the deflationary spiral and offers protection against the worst of the downside." But, he said, "This is not the stuff on which a long-term upgrade of the Japanese economy is made." He said the dollar was headed to 140 yen. **********Even Brendan Brown, a London-based analyst at Tokyo-Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. who warns against underestimating how much such a large spending package could spur a recovery, sees the yen weakening. **********"The exchange rate is no longer the issue," he said. "So long as Japan is doing what the international community has asked it to do, and so long as the exchange rate is not manipulated, the dollar can climb to 140 yen and it would be no big deal." Yen weakness will be driven by huge capital outflows from Japan in search of higher yields in U.S. and European markets, he said. **********But Jim O'Neill of Goldman, Sachs & Co. in London cautioned against assuming a sharp sell-off of the yen. Although questioning whether the package can trigger a self-sustaining recovery, he asked why the Bank of Japan needed a record $200 billion in reserves. **********"They could be halved and Japan would still have the largest ratio of reserves to imports of any other G-7 country," he said, referring to the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations. **********By running down the reserves, he said, Japan could affect the foreign exchange market, hold the dollar within a range of 127 yen to 133 yen and "buy time for a new package of more convincing measures" after elections in July for the upper house of the Diet, Japan's Parliament.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/05/busin.snippet: Alan Meier, scientist at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, estimates that American consumers spend $3.5 billion a year powering electronic devices and household appliances that they think are off, when actually appliances are in suspended sta...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/05/busin.main_headline: Compressed Data; Scientist Sees a Power Drain In Switched-Off Appliances
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/05/busin.print_headline: Compressed Data; Scientist Sees a Power Drain In Switched-Off Appliances
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/05/busin.body_text: **********Alan Meier would like people to mean ''off'' when they say ''off.'' **********Mr. Meier, a scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in California, estimates that American consumers spend $3.5 billion a year powering electronic devices and household appliances that they think are turned off, when actually those appliances are in a suspended state called stand-by mode. **********TV's and VCR's are among the biggest culprits, as are high-end PC's chock-full of power-sucking chips and gadgetry. While a TV, for example, might use 50 watts of power when it is on, it may still use as much as 10 watts when it is off. This stand-by feature makes possible the much-revered remote control, among other things. **********Battery chargers, like those used for cellular phones, continue to use energy even when there is no phone plugged in. Even microwaves consume energy when they are not in use, mostly to power the electronic keypad. And Intel's Pentium chip, the brains inside most PC's sold today, is a huge stand-by energy hog, Mr. Meier says. **********Though the wasted electricity amounts to only a few cents per appliance, the total being wasted is enormous: equivalent to the amount produced by eight power plants. That comes to about $50 a household a year, Mr. Meier says. **********The solution? Mr. Meier says it is unreasonable to expect consumers to unplug, particularly when they have come to appreciate the conveniences made possible by stand-by mode, as in remote-control garage door openers. Rather, the responsibility lies with manufacturers, who are simply not paying much attention to energy use. Using an energy-saving power supply adds nothing to the cost of producing a device, according to the makers of energy-efficient power technology, like Power Integrations of Sunnyvale, Calif. **********Mr. Meier says he and his colleagues hope to avoid promoting government regulation to deal with this problem by getting manufacturers to agree voluntarily to build products that use only 1 watt in stand-by mode. **********The other side of the problem, he says, comes from misuse of the word ''off,'' which in electronics has come to mean neither off nor on. Someday, if Mr. Meier's efforts pay off, pressing the ''off'' button will, once again, actually mean ''off.''   LAURIE J. FLYNN

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/busin.snippet: The clearest signals of a political shift under Germany's new leftist government flash most freely from the talkative man who is front-runner to become finance minister..After 16 years of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right free-marketeers — pa
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/busin.main_headline: Probable Choice for Finance Minister Makes Central Bankers Uneasy : A Strong German Voice for Change
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/busin.print_headline: Probable Choice for Finance Minister Makes Central Bankers Uneasy : A Strong German Voice for Change
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/busin.body_text: **********The clearest signals of a political shift under Germany's new leftist government flash most freely from the talkative man who is front-runner to become finance minister. **********After 16 years of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right free-marketeers — particularly the outgoing finance minister, Theo Waigel — Oskar Lafontaine sounds jarringly unorthodox by comparison. **********Taken at his word, Mr. Lafontaine's comments since the elections Sunday raise the prospect of seismic changes in the way Germany will play its heavyweight role at international gatherings meant to manage the new European currency, say economists like Adolf Rosenstock at Nomura International in Frankfurt. **********At a sensitive time for interest rate decisions, Mr. Lafontaine has set the stage for an early clash with the autonomy of the newly minted European Central Bank in numerous policy pronouncements since the triumph by the Social Democratic Party. **********By calling for German interest rate cuts, he breached a sacrosanct national convention against injecting politics into central banking, observers said, creating an uneasy precedent as the European Central Bank prepares for the January changeover to the single currency. **********That rapidly has spawned worries that Mr. Lafontaine could join the Socialist government of France in creating a "political counterweight" to the European Central Bank, something the bank vows to resist, some economists and Bonn political strategists said. **********"Red lights are flashing at the ECB," Mr. Rosenstock said. **********The Bundesbank has turned a deaf ear to Mr. Lafontaine. At a meeting of its governors Thursday, it left German lending rates unchanged, unwilling to follow the government-elect's unsolicited advice or the easing Tuesday by the U.S. Federal Reserve Board. **********In another lurch away from Mr. Kohl's free-market policies, Mr. Lafontaine announced last week an initiative to help tame the world's unruly currency markets, which have strewn their economic wreckage this year from Brazil to Russia. **********He wants to impose trading parameters on the dollar and other currencies, creating in effect a new international financial architecture. It would be similar to the 1941 Bretton Woods agreement, which pegged the world's currencies to the dollar, with the difference that the euro would be a second anchor. **********But the same central bankers who would have to operate such a rigid system dismiss the idea as unrealistic. Echoing views heard in national central banks, the European bank president, Wim Duisenberg, this month said such currency controls were years away at best. **********"It is not at all on the agenda for the moment," he said, "and I do not expect it to come on the agenda very soon." **********The prospective new finance minister is raising expectations that he probably cannot fulfill, not least because the United States will never agree to a trading grid for the dollar, said Joachim Fels of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. **********"He will not get very far," Mr. Fels said. **********Whether or not he gets the job of finance minister, Mr. Lafontaine already has imprinted his economic ideas on the new government. Chancellor-designate Gerhard Schroeder this week endorsed Mr. Lafontaine's ideas about currency controls, for instance. **********For now, Mr. Lafontaine has the right of first refusal on the finance portfolio, although a decision may take days or weeks. That will depend upon the progress of negotiations toward a coalition government between Mr. Schroeder's Social Democrats and the Greens party. **********As chairman of the Social Democrats, Mr. Lafontaine can choose his own job, party insiders say. Mr. Lafontaine could opt for the role of parliamentary faction leader. **********Although Mr. Schroeder won the election, many see Mr. Lafontaine as a sort of co-chancellor because of his uncontested control over the party, which Mr. Schroeder must consult for any big decisions. **********The traditionally left-leaning views of Mr. Lafontaine clash particularly strongly with those of the outgoing Mr. Wagiel. The latter endlessly lectured his counterparts from Washington to Paris about his creed of fiscal rectitude, austerity and free-floating currencies. **********Mr. Waigel, who watched speculators blow apart the best-laid exchange rate plans of Europe's leaders in 1992 and 1993, would never have proposed a showdown with the markets by foisting a trading grid on the dollar. Quite the contrary, Mr. Waigel spent much of his time preaching a hands-off approach to dollar markets, arguing that the only way to keep speculators at bay is to run a tight and credible budget at home. **********Critics of fixed dollar rates call them a throwback to the 1970s, noting that Bretton Woods collapsed in 1971. **********"All experience has shown that fixed exchange rates are the start of politicized rates," said Hans-Olaf Henkel, president of the German Industry Federation. "Wanted or not, it leads to a wave of worldwide protectionism." **********The proposal "shows naiveté" and "pure nostalgia," he said. **********"Stable exchange rates cannot be ordained and cannot be politically arranged," said Hans Tietmeyer, the president of the Bundesbank, in reaction to Mr. Lafontaine's proposal. "They must be earned."

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/22/busin.snippet: Question-and-answer article with Anthony M Gallea, senior portfolio manager at Smith Barney office in Rochester, NY, where he oversees $600 million in client assets; Gallea is a contrarian who studies psycholgy of possible investment; describers h...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/22/busin.main_headline: The Art of Swimming Against the Tide
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/22/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT/MUTUAL FUNDS; The Art of Swimming Against the Tide
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/22/busin.body_text: **********''BUY when blood is in the streets.'' No one takes that  investing adage more to heart than a contrarian like Anthony M. Gallea. **********Mr. Gallea, 48, is a senior portfolio manager at the Smith Barney office in Rochester, where he oversees $600 million in client assets. He is also the co-author, with William Patalon 3d, a business reporter for The Baltimore Sun, of ''Contrarian Investing'' (Prentice Hall/New York Institute of Finance, $25). **********Here, Mr. Gallea discusses the central premise of contrarianism --  that when everyone holds a stock or sector or country in low esteem, it may be precisely the time to invest. He also explains how to pick winners,  how to limit risk in this chancy field and which investment areas he is keeping a contrarian eye on: Japan, the metals market and energy stocks, among others. **********Q. What is the contrarian philosophy? **********A. It attempts to ascertain an extreme or consensus opinion and then see if there is an argument for investing in the other direction. It's the theory that if everybody believes something and has acted on it, then the money available to push that investment in the same direction is diminished. **********Q. What's the difference between contrarian and value investing? **********A. I think that a contrarian starts with the sentiment or the psychology of the situation and then proceeds to the financials, and a value investor starts and ends with the financials.  Both try to buy assets at a discount, but I think all investors try to do that, even growth investors. **********Q. You have said that contrarians have nerves of steel. What other personality traits do they have? **********A. I'm not so sure it's nerves of steel.  It's more a willingness to think independently. For most people, it's not easy to invest in a way that is in disagreement with their friends, their seeing and reading and so on. **********Q. Can you give an example of the  extreme opinions contrarians seek? **********A. The crash in '87 is one example. The consensus opinion was that the market was in deep trouble. That turned out not to be the case. **********But right now the U.S. market isn't  saying a thing to me as a contrarian. I don't think there's extreme bullish or bearish sentiment; opinion seems equally divided. People feel that I'm bearish, as a contrarian, because there's a lot of bullishness around. But I don't sense any extreme. **********I sense more of an extreme in the Far East, in the metals market and  in Japan. Those markets may be saying something to contrarians. **********One sector that is worth watching is energy. People are becoming more bearish about energy and there's more in the papers about it that reminds me of what I used to see in the 70's. It's not there yet, but if you got some additional drop in energy prices, energy stocks would become a lot cheaper and then a contrarian might see it as a time to buy. **********Q. How do you know if there is extreme opinion against a stock? **********A. One difficulty we've had as contrarians is to quantify extreme opinion. Then we ran across a study by John Howe of the University of Kansas about stocks that are down 50 percent or more. He did an exhaustive study -- thousands of stocks over many years -- and found that stocks that had dropped 50 percent or more from their 52-week highs tended to outperform the market and those that were up 50 percent or more tended to underperform. **********That led us to the work of other academics and market people saying that this works. So, we don't consider a stock unless it's dropped at least 50 percent from its 52-week high. That's our proxy for contrarian sentiment. **********Q. Are you looking at any particular stocks right now? What about Nike? **********A. There is no stock I'm looking to buy this morning. As for Nike, I've been following it. It doesn't meet the first criterion of down 50 percent, so I wouldn't buy it. But the world is awash in sneakers. People are generally not pleased with that whole sector. They think that sneaker prices are too high. If I could buy Nike 50 percent below its highs, then, sure. **********Q. Because you still think that it's a good company. **********A. Any time you can buy a big-name blue chip or a franchise stock at 50 percent off, the odds are well in your favor. These companies have lots of resources, lots of money, lots of people. They can work out problems that small, one-product companies can't. If you look back, all of these big, big companies that have gotten into trouble -- Citicorp, I.B.M. -- make it out, by and large. **********Yet, people tend to take a piece of news, extrapolate a new worry from it, treat that as fact and extrapolate yet another worry. We take events and psychologically push them forever into the future in a straight line. We underestimate the muddle factor: that we all tend to muddle through problems eventually. **********You have a parallel situation in Japan today. You have widespread difficulties in financial companies that are well publicized. The Government seems to be ''pushing on a string'' -- do you remember that phrase from many years ago, when the Fed was dropping interest rates but couldn't get the economy moving? The market there is down more than half from its highs of several years ago. Yet it's a great industrial power; it's not going to slide into the ocean and disappear. We have $10 million invested there now. **********Q. Your secondary criterion is buying by insiders or savvy outsiders. **********A. We found a study showing that a net increase in such buying tends to forecast a higher price. So we set inside buying as additional confirmation because once you've got a stock down 50 percent, that doesn't mean it's going to go anywhere. **********Q. Can you give me some examples of insider buying? **********A. Here's one: Sunglass Hut. I should note that we do make a market in Sunglass Hut and we have a speculative rating on the stock. **********At any rate, you see them in all the malls. The stock declined from $20 to the $6-to-$7 range between July 1996 and July 1997. So it met the first screen: down at least 50 percent. **********Then we picked up in the S.E.C. filings that Sunglass Hut insiders  had bought about 100,000 shares in several transactions last summer. **********The story was pretty simple: there hadn't been any new lines of fashion sunglasses in the prior year and  there was a bit of overexpansion. But those are the kind of things you work out of. Anybody who's ever been in retail knows that you get overinventoried at times. **********So we bought the stock at $6.75 last summer and it is now at $10.50. So it hasn't had a big move yet. But that is the kind of stock that we look for. **********Q. How can you predict whether an ailing company will recover? **********A. After you find a stock trading at a 50 percent discount to its 52-week high, you do the fundamental analysis by reading an analyst's report, whatever. Then we pick four of the  fundamental ratios a value investor might look at. If we get a stock down 50 percent or more and then two of these four line up, you don't have to have insider buying. **********Of course, in looking at these four ratios, everything is not necessarily going to be pretty because a stock doesn't drop 50 percent and look beautiful. What you want to get is a sense of whether the company has got time to work it out. **********We start with a price-to-earnings ratio of less than 12. That means earnings are not highly priced. Next we look for a healthy price-to-free cash flow -- less than 10. Free cash flow is the money that's left over, after paying for basic expenses and enlarging the existing business, for creating new products, buying complementary businesses and the like. **********Then comes the price-to-sales ratio. If it is less than 1, each share is backed by a good amount of sales --  say, the share is $7 and sales per share are $10. So you've got some good numbers coming in the top line, although whether they get to the bottom or not you don't know. And then if the book value is less than 1, that tells you there are good underlying  assets: bricks, mortar and the like. **********Q. How long does it typically take for a contrarian portfolio to generate satisfactory returns? **********A. Ben Graham, the father of value investing, believed that it took approximately two years for a company to work out its problems. But in some cases, a stock just seems to go right out of the chute. **********Q. How do you limit risk? **********A. We put no more than 3 to 5 percent of a portfolio in any single stock because these companies are in some trouble. And we have a 25 percent stop-loss order -- an order to sell if the stock falls below a certain price -- because you can be wrong and there are times just to get out. **********If you find a stock with a big price decline you often are led to other stocks in the industry. So we limit ourselves to 15 percent, 20 percent, in  any industry, so we don't substitute industry risk for a stock's risk. **********As for selling, Ben Graham believed that a 50 percent profit was a good target. That dovetails with John Howe's work, that a stock up 50 percent tends to underperform. **********If you believe a sale after a 50 percent profit is premature, you can stay in and set a stop-loss order at a 30 percent profit. So if the stock goes  from 10 to 15 you're going to set a stop at 13. **********Another risk rule we have is that after three years if you don't have a 50 percent profit, you just leave. **********Those are the basic risk rules. You try to set some discipline for yourself because we're all weak. We go to cocktail parties and tell our friends about a stock we bought. Then the stock starts to drop and you find yourself defending it and then your ego is at stake. We need something to save us from ourselves. **********Q. How can average investors get into the contrarian game? **********A. If somebody has a 401(k), for instance, he may say, ''Of all my funds, what hasn't done well?'' If the Far East hasn't done well, he might say, ''Maybe I should put 5 or 10 percent of my 401(k) there.'' **********That is, just begin to take a more skeptical view and get some side investments that are going in a different direction. I'm not comfortable having all my assets moving in the same direction all the time. Maybe this is doing well for me this year, this isn't doing well for me. But next year maybe they'll flip-flop. **********Q. Why do people overreact to news and create the kind of extreme opinion that you look for? **********A. I think that's the real story about contrarian investing. People constantly look outside themselves for the answer, in the market. What is required is more introspection. I don't mean this to sound like crystals and Sigmund Freud, but we don't spend enough time analyzing ourselves. We are the filter through which all this information flows.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/world.snippet: Investigators are trying to get lone survivor of mass shooting in Kosovo out of Serbia to testify about killings at war crimes tribunal; Western diplomats say unidentified witness was among 14 ethnic Albanians who were systematically shot by Serbs...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/world.main_headline: War Crimes Panel Seeks a Way For Massacre Survivor to Testify
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/world.print_headline: War Crimes Panel Seeks a Way For Massacre Survivor to Testify
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/world.body_text: **********Investigators were trying today to get the lone survivor of a mass shooting in Kosovo out of Serbia to testify about the killings at a war crimes tribunal. **********The witness, about 35 years old, was among 14 ethnic Albanian men who were ordered to lie face down against a fence and were systematically shot by one or more Serbs, said Western diplomats who interviewed the man on Tuesday. His identity was kept secret. **********The witness was shot in his left arm and leg and badly wounded, but managed to survive by pretending to be dead, diplomats said the man told them. **********Two investigators from the International War Crimes Tribunal, based in The Hague, were in Kosovo today to look into the matter, one of two executions of ethnic Albanians that witnesses said Serbian forces carried out in central Kosovo on Saturday. The 13 men were killed in the village of Golubovac, while 18 members of an extended family were killed about four miles away near Gornji Obrinje. **********The Serbian authorities today denied that their forces were involved in the killing of the 18 women, children and elderly people of the Deliaj clan near Gornji Obrinje. But the Serbian authorities did not address the question of culpability for the 13 deaths in Golubovac that the survivor said he had witnessed. **********The killings took place in an area where Serbian forces had been shelling and burning villages in a campaign of intimidation against ethnic Albanian civilians. Kosovo, once an autonomous province, is fighting for independence from Serbia. **********Col. Bozidar Filic, the Serbian police spokesman in Pristina, the capital of Kosovo, said today that it was not possible that Serbian police had shot the civilians in Gornji Obrinje. The Police units involved in ''breaking up terrorist bands'' in the area were under the direct command of their superior officers who submitted regular reports about their activities, he said. The officers, he said, did not report any incidents involving the killing of women, children or the elderly. **********The Yugoslav Army did not issue any statements today, although witnesses implicated them in the deaths of the Deliaj family. **********In Belgrade, the official Yugoslav news agency, Tanjug, which usually reflects the position of the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, said the reports of the killings of the Deliaj clan were made by ''foreign media'' anxious to advance the calls for NATO intervention in the conflict between the Serbs and the ethnic Albanians who make up 90 percent of Kosovo's population. **********NATO officials have called on Mr. Milosevic in the last week to end his tank and artillery operations against the separatist guerrillas and attacks on ethnic Albanian civilians and their property or face possible military action. **********In an apparent move to comply with the NATO demands, the Serbian Government said on Monday that the offensive had ended and all was quiet in Kosovo. **********Two long convoys of Serbian police and Yugoslav troops were seen by Western diplomatic monitors on the roads today, indicating the offensive might be over. One was heading north to Pristina, the other was heading out of Pristina farther north. **********But Western diplomats and monitors remained unconvinced. It was ''too early to say'' whether the convoys on the move were merely intended to make it ''look as though the troops were going back to barracks,'' one diplomat said. **********The survivor told diplomats that 14 men between the ages of 18 and 35 from different villages in the area had been selected for a firing line from a larger group of men. They were told to lie face down on the ground against the fence of a house, the survivor said. After shots were fired by what the survivor described as at least one Serbian policeman but possibly more, one of the Albanian men cried out that he was still alive. The man was immediately shot dead, the survivor recounted. **********The bodies were said to have been returned to their villages and buried before diplomats arrived. **********Because of the survivor, Western officials here said that the killing of the 13 Albanians provided the best case for prosecution at the war crimes tribunal, which has established jurisdiction over the Kosovo conflict. Another witness, Adem Hoxhaj, said he saw the shooting from nearby. **********By comparison, the most vivid description so far of the shooting of the Deliaj clan came from a member of the family who said he saw Serbian forces approach but did not see the actual slaughter. **********One of the diplomats said the survivor was ''an important witness'' and ''we are very concerned about getting him to The Hague. **********The issue of how to get the survivor to The Hague is developing into a test case of how the tribunal can exercise jurisdiction in Serbia, which is now the dominant part of Yugoslavia. **********Mr. Milosevic's Government has refused to recognize the authority of the tribunal and granted visas for only two investigators from The Hague. One of the investigators was scheduled to talk to the survivor today, a Western official said. **********The investigators, who are police detectives on loan to the tribunal, have no power of extradition or mandate to decide how to get the survivor who remains seriously wounded and needs medical treatment, to The Hague. The investigators were discussing with the Red Cross and Western diplomats how to proceed, the official said. **********Tanjug, the Yugoslav news agency, lashed out at the foreign press today for some reports of the civilian killings that mentioned the possibility that they had been committed as a reprisal for the reported deaths of Serbian police officers killed recently when their vehicle hit a land mine in the same area. **********''The policemen are mentioned now, but only in the context of speculation that Albanian civilians were killed in retaliation,'' Tanjug said. The news agency said seven police officers were killed in the incident while other reports said five died. Mines in that area, a former stronghold of the Kosovo Liberation Army, are believed to have been planted by the separatist fighters. **********Western monitors assessing the military situation in Kosovo said there was significantly less shelling today. But shells were fired at four villages east of Suva Reka this morning, an area that had been sealed by the Serbs until today, monitors said. Columns of smoke from burning buildings were easy to see a few miles away today, and people who had fled their homes said there were Serbian policemen around their village. **********In nearby Vranici, men and women were returning to their homes after an ordeal with the Serbs. **********On Sunday morning, they heard warning shots that an attack on the village was under way, so they fled up the mountain in a caravan of vehicles. On Monday morning, the Serbian police invited them to come back, saying they would be safe. **********But when they agreed to return, the villagers said, the police took about 250 men, loaded them onto buses and took them away. The women were bused away separately, they said. Many of the women were returned to the village on Monday and others today. Late this afternoon many of the men were returned as well. They said about 50 of their number were still in Serbian custody. **********On their return this afternoon, the villagers found the bodies of two ethnic Albanian men on the ground at the mosque of Vranici. One of them, Hafir Elshani, had been shot in the chest and his nose had been cut off. The other man, Milam Bugari, had been shot at close range behind the ear. **********The villagers found that many of the vehicles in the convoy of 250 or so cars and tractors they had abandoned on Sunday had been set on fire or vandalized and their belongings had been strewn on the ground. **********Because Mr. Milosevic has been criticized by the West for allowing about 50,000 Albanian refugees to live outdoors, the operation by the Serbian police in Vranici seemed designed to create chaos and fear but also to insure that those forced to flee their homes would not end up in the forest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/05/busin.snippet: Article on rising value of mutual funds that invest in corporate bonds (Money & Business Part 2: Mutual Funds Report) (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/05/busin.main_headline: As Stocks Teeter, a Safe Harbor May Be Found in Corporate Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/05/busin.print_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; As Stocks Teeter, a Safe Harbor May Be Found in Corporate Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/05/busin.body_text: **********LIKE sailors flocking to safe ports, mutual fund investors have long turned to bonds whenever stocks appear dangerously close to imploding. **********But what are the nervous to do when the safest bonds around -- benchmark Treasuries -- have soared in price? **********Concerns about Asia's fractured economic machine have caused investors -- especially those overseas -- to pull money out of certain stock and bond markets and pour it into United States Treasury bonds. So prices have risen and yields -- which move in the opposite direction of prices -- have sunk to 30-year lows. As of June 30, the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond was just 5.62 percent, compared with 6.78 percent one year ago. **********The safety-conscious as well as the yield-hungry investor cannot help but wonder if it's time to forage elsewhere. And if so, where? **********Funds that invest in corporate bonds, it turns out, may carry the most value now. These bonds pay a higher yield than Treasury securities because the risk of corporate default, of course, is greater than that of a default by the United States Government. The yield spread between corporate and Treasury bonds is the widest it has been in five years and, given the economy's strength,  the risk of default seems limited for investment-grade bonds. With inflation low, the yields look quite nice. **********What's more, companies have issued a mountain of new debt, taking advantage of low rates to finance  capital improvements and to refinance older debt. That has left the market flooded and helped keep prices down -- a situation that, in correcting itself over time, is likely to benefit bond investors. **********The big risk is the economy. Potential buyers have been worried that corporate earnings are on the verge of a long snooze. If earnings decline, the prices of corporate bonds will fall, too, leading to lower total returns, even if dividends stay steady. **********Oversupply is also a problem in the municipal bond market, which has been second after Treasuries in investor safety. To be sure, after an uninspiring first four months of the year, munis rallied in May, as stocks stumbled and as investors snapped up the first half of the largest muni bond sale ever -- $7 billion in Long Island Power Authority bonds. Demand for these bonds, and their unusually rich yields, effectively drained money from other munis. **********The glut remains a problem, with more issues on the way. **********Still, for high-income investors looking for the best returns after taxes, municipal bonds may be the way to go. There has been a solid improvement in credit quality: Half as many issues were downgraded in 1997 as in 1996. The good news can be attributed to the booming economy and a surge in local tax revenues. **********Also, in the last year, yields on municipal bonds, relative to taxable bonds, have narrowed significantly. According to Richard J. Moynihan, head of tax-exempt fixed-income investing at the Dreyfus Corporation, the typical insured 20-year muni gives investors 91 percent of the yield of a 30-year Treasury bond, up from about 81 percent a year ago. **********For people in a 31 percent income tax bracket, ''that's roughly equal to the 7.50 percent yield they might get with a taxable security,'' he said.  ''And there aren't too many triple A-rated securities on the taxable side that return 7.50 percent.'' **********The downside, however, is that munis are less likely to appreciate, so their total return may be weak. **********FOR investors in munis, he recommends longer-term issues. ''When it comes to short-term munis -- say five-year issues -- the market is fully priced relative to Treasuries,'' he said. ''Beyond that -- going out 10 years or more -- then these bonds continue to be very  cheap relative to Treasuries.'' **********Investors who bought the longest-term issues were rewarded last quarter. The best-performing bond funds had long maturities, including the American Century-Benham Target Maturity funds, several Vanguard long-term funds and T. Rowe Price U.S. Treasury Long-Term. **********What about investors who are looking for even better values than corporate and muni issues, as well as potentially higher yields? Les Nanberg, the chief fixed-income officer at Massachusetts Financial Services, says the best opportunities are in high-yield junk bonds and emerging-market bonds, not surprisingly the riskiest areas of the bond world. **********He says yields on junk bonds are now 3.5 percentage points more than Treasuries, on average, while emerging-market bonds average about 6.5 percentage points more. **********After registering nifty price gains for months, junk bonds are now trading at two-year lows. Funds that invest in junk bonds posted a slight loss on average in the last quarter. **********But the news was worse for most emerging-market bond funds. On average, they lost more than 8 percent in the latest quarter, according to Morningstar. Among the bottom performers were Phoenix B Emerging Markets Bond and Merrill Lynch American Income. ''If investors can live with the volatility of these bonds, they'll be rewarded,'' Mr. Nanberg said, ''although they're clearly not for everyone.'' Anticipating more volatility, he is shying away from most of Asia but spots value in Poland, Bulgaria, and other Eastern European countries, as well as Mexico. **********What about junk bonds? Again, Mr. Nanberg is treading carefully, focusing on companies that meet at least one of three criteria: they are leaders in their industries, are benefiting from a strong economy or are benefiting from recent acquisitions. One company that he expects to benefit from the strong economy is BE Aerospace, which makes replacement parts for aircraft. **********Roger E. King, a senior portfolio manager for high-yield securities at Dreyfus, says the news on the high-yield front isn't all bad. **********''Right now, there are no panic sellers,'' Mr. King said, ''so we're in a kind of controlled downturn.'' **********That said, Mr. King advises investors to choose issues with very short maturities, to guard against changes in interest rates and the junk market's current volatility. **********Indeed, the greatest risk in bonds today may be credit risk, said John F. Poole, the head of fixed-income group at Mellon Private Asset Management. ''We don't think the economy is about to collapse,'' he added, ''but we think that individual companies may be at risk.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/08/busin.body_text: **********Marketing Chief of G.M. Gives Gloomy Assessment **********The strike this summer at two General Motors parts factories will continue to hurt the auto maker's sales until October, and some customers have been permanently lost, G.M.'s top marketing executive said. **********In a gloomy assessment of the strike's damage, Ronald L. Zarrella, the group vice president for North American sales, service and marketing, said dealerships would not be restocked until mid-September. The rollout of some 1999 models will also be delayed because G.M. has so many parts left over for 1998 models that it is cheaper to keep building them instead of discarding parts. [Page D2.] **********Ex-E.D.S. Chief to Get $38.6 Million **********Electronic Data Systems in Plano, Tex., said that the retirement of Lester M. Alberthal Jr. as chairman and chief executive would cost the company $38.6 million in benefits. Shares of E.D.S. rose 14 percent. Mr. Alberthal announced his retirement after the stock market closed on Thursday under pressure from board members and shareholders dismayed by the company's loss of its former leadership in computer services. [D3.] **********Award vs. Lockheed Suppliers **********A Los Angeles jury awarded 28 former Lockheed Martin workers $760 million in punitive damages from five companies that supplied toxic chemicals used in making Lockheed's Stealth jet fighter plane. [D14.] **********Worldcom Expects MCI Charges **********Worldcom expects to take charges of $6 billion to $7 billion in connection with its $37 billion purchase of MCI Communications, and other big one-time costs could follow as the company contemplates a reorganization. [D3.] **********Drug Wholesalers End Deals **********The nation's four biggest drug wholesalers abandoned plans to merge into two companies. The collapse of the deals -- Cardinal Health's $2.8 billion acquisition of Bergen Brunswig and McKesson's $2.3 billion purchase of Amerisource Health -- had been expected since regulators opposed the mergers, saying that they would hurt competition. [D3.] **********Hotel-Casino Deal Called Off **********Crescent Real Estate Equities, the real estate investment trust controlled by Richard Rainwater, has canceled a planned $1.7 billion acquisition of Station Casinos. [D3.] **********Vietnam Devalues Its Currency **********Vietnam, as expected, devalued its currency, the third such move since the Asian financial crisis took hold more than a year ago. The Government has been under pressure to open its markets and to devalue the currency, the dong, to bolster export-dependent industries, especially after nine months of bad weather hit crops especially hard. [D2.] **********Phone Workers Stage Brief Strike **********Thousands of unionized telephone workers shut down directory assistance in New York as they staged a two-and-a-half-hour wildcat walkout aimed at pressuring Bell Atlantic to help avoid a strike at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow, when their contract expires. [B1.] **********Earnings Flat for Unilever **********Unilever, the British-Dutch household products conglomerate that makes Lipton tea, Q-Tips and Wisk laundry detergent, said that its second-quarter profit was little changed from a year earlier as the Asia crisis continued to weigh on its business. [D2.] **********Lewinsky Good for Cable Business **********For 24-hour cable news channels like MSNBC, CNBC, Fox News and CNN, the Monica S. Lewinsky story is big business, meaning more revenue and higher ratings to shows that mostly struggle at the margins, looking for -- at best -- the mysterious murder of a beauty queen. [A10.]

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/28/busin.body_text: **********Hoechst A.G., Germany's largest maker of chemicals and pharmaceutical products, said yesterday that it swung to a fourth-quarter profit as it spent less money on revamping measures like plant shutdowns and job cuts. Hoechst said fourth-quarter profit was 154 million marks ($85 million), in contrast to a loss of 336 million marks a year earlier. Full-year net income fell 36 percent, to 1.343 billion marks ($741 million) from 2.114 billion marks. **********Hoechst plans to sell its chemical units by 2000 to focus on pharmaceuticals and farm products. Hoechst's American depository receipts rose $1.5625 yesterday, to $38.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/techn.snippet: Michel Marriott reviews Prima's Official Strategy Guide: Unreal, by Joe Grant Bell; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/techn.main_headline: Fight, Survive And Conquer: The Shortcuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/techn.print_headline: LIBRARY/COMPUTER BOOKS; Fight, Survive And Conquer: The Shortcuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/techn.body_text: **********PRIMA'S OFFICIAL STRATEGY GUIDE: UNREAL **********By Joe Grant Bell (Prima Publishing, $19.99). **********ANYONE who has ever played even a mildly engaging computer game, especially multimedia, 3-D challenges like Quake 2, Mech Warrior 2 and Warcraft II, knows that it takes only a few minutes to learn how to play but dozens of hours to learn to play well. Who has the time? It didn't take hard-core game players long to realize that they could considerably shorten their learning curves by trading tips and secrets about popular computer games. **********It also didn't take the publishing world long to realize that there was a growing need among the millions of computer game players for well-written, easy-to-follow help in navigating the spooky digital domains of, say, Myst, or the temples of Tomb Robber II. **********Prima Publishing, among others, took up the challenge, and the result is a long line of official as well as unauthorized guides to computer games. Joe Grant Bell's guide to Unreal, an intense, fight-your-way-through-a-hostile-alien-world game, is one of the latest. **********Like all the Prima guides, the book has numerous but rudimentary illustrations in black and white. But what makes the books such hot sellers (Prima's ''Myst: The Official Strategy Guide'' sold more than a million copies) is the apparent depth of knowledge they impart about the games. **********''Unreal'' is broadly organized into four sections: first, the many weapons and devices, like flak canons and antitoxin suits, and the myriad capabilities a player must know about them. Next there is a detailed discussion, bordering on the anthropological, about various enemies a player  is likely to encounter. What constitutes the bulk of this 193-page guide is a step-by-step tutorial in how to survive and win in the game's creepy labyrinths of terror and sudden game-ending mayhem. That includes a section on advanced combat techniques like circular strafing, which is the constant circling of a target while firing, inflicting maximum damage while making it difficult to get hit by enemy fire. The last section is for players who wish to enter the game's multiplayer matches on the Internet. **********Throughout the guide, Mr. Bell effectively maintains an air of authenticity about the elements of the Unreal environment. Whole passages never hint that all the firepower specs and tactics concern a world that is only a game, a game that exists only on the shiny surface of a CD-ROM. **********For example, Mr. Bell writes about the flak cannon that it ''fires high-velocity metal shards that rip a hole in your enemy in seconds flat. It isn't the prettiest weapon, but it makes up for its lack of beauty with raw power.'' Or consider his advice about fighting on the go: ''Never stop. Even the weakest alien in the galaxy is capable of hitting you if you stand still.'' **********Good thing the aliens can't read Prima's guides.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/22/busin.body_text: **********Japan's Prime Minister Cites Others' Costly Errors **********Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan, blamed his predecessor, the nation's powerful Finance Ministry and the heads of the country's huge financial institutions for wasting years before the country began to deal with its crippling banking crisis and a deep recession that is worsening the world's economic turmoil. **********Mr. Obuchi's comments, in an interview as he prepared to address the United Nations, was the first acknowledgment by a Japanese leader that his country's leadership, both in government and in the private sector, had made huge errors that have now ricocheted around the world. [Page A13.] **********Financial Promises in Russia **********Russia's leaders offered assurances that the country's fiscal crisis could be tamed without provoking high inflation or social unrest. But few people seemed convinced. Neither President Boris N. Yeltsin nor his new Prime Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, has settled on a choice for Finance Minister. [A3.] **********NASA wants to spend up to $660 million over five years to bail out its Russian partner in building a planned space station. [A1.] **********A New Airline-Marketing Link **********British Airways and American Airlines announced a new marketing link called oneworld with Canadian Airlines, Qantas Airways and Cathay Pacific. It is intended to compete with the Star Alliance headed by Lufthansa and United Airlines. [C2.] **********Lockheed Martin Stock Falls 5% **********Shares of Lockheed Martin fell 4.9 percent amid concern that the world's largest military company is putting earnings at risk with its $2.7 billion bid for Comsat. Created by the Government, Comsat is the United States gateway to Intelsat, among the world's largest providers of commercial satellite services. [C6.] **********A Rift at Nationsbanc Montgomery **********Thomas Weisel resigned as chairman and chief executive of Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities L.L.C. after months of bitter quarreling with his new bosses in Charlotte, N.C. Nationsbank bought Montgomery Securities of San Francisco, which Mr. Weisel founded, for $1.2 billion in October. [C4.] **********Philips Electronics Shares Off 17% **********Royal Philips Electronics shares fell 17 percent, to the equivalent of $43, in Amsterdam after the company warned of a signifcant decline in profits. [C2.] **********Concession Offered on Merger **********American Home Products and Monsanto offered to scale down their proposed $37.8 billion merger to overcome European Union antitrust hurdles. [C2.] **********Blair Calls for New Procedures **********Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain called for modernizing the way of dealing with global economic turmoil. The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, which were created 54 years ago, ''were constructed for a world of fixed exchange rates and capital controls, when capital flows were much smaller,'' he said. [A13.] **********Rule Eased on Cash Reports **********The Treasury Department said it was trimming its requirements for reporting large cash transactions to ease the paperwork load on banks. Bankers will still be responsible for reporting any sign of criminal activity. [C6.] **********New Pressures on Labor Market **********The tight labor market -- unemployment nationwide is just 4.5 percent -- has put new pressures on many economic hot spots like Florida and California. BellSouth Telecommunications of Miami, for example, says it took more than six months to fill 500 newly created jobs. [C4.] **********Treasury Bond Yields Decline **********Treasury bond yields declined for the fourth consecutive session, with no significant economic reports to move the market. [C10.]

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/02/busin.body_text: **********Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin pointedly asked a group of South Korea's wealthiest tycoons on Wednesday if they were considering a "big deal" for getting rid of money-losing divisions and companies. **********He received, according to one account of the meeting, an ambivalent reply from Kim Woo Choong, chairman of the Daewoo group, Korea's third-largest chaebol or conglomerate. **********"It will take a long time," replied Mr. Kim, who is the acting chairman of the Federation of Korean Industries, made up of chaebol chairmen, as quoted by a federation aide. "We have many other technical problems to discuss in detail." **********The interchange underlined the reluctance of the chaebol to go along with efforts by the government to convince them to merge some of their biggest companies, in fields ranging from motor vehicles to petrochemicals to electronics, in order to cut mounting losses. **********Mr. Rubin refused to comment on his meeting with the chaebol leaders but said earlier that he discussed the role of the chaebol throughout a one-day visit that began with a breakfast in which American businessmen discussed the frustrations of doing business here. **********Mr. Rubin said he had come away from a meeting with President Kim Dae Jung, who has pressured the chaebol to speed up reform efforts, "with a sense of deep commitment to reform" under terms of the package of nearly $60 billion worked out by the International Monetary Fund. **********With foreign reserves in South Korea now up to about $39 billion from $4 billion in the darkest hours of the crisis in December, Mr. Rubin said the United States did not need to help directly, but he added that "we are available for advice and counseling." **********The Treasury secretary's session with chaebol leaders, after he had offered his optimistic view of Korea's reform program, marked a low point in an otherwise upbeat day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/26/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is preparing to open a round of shuttle diplomacy on American soil, traveling between Washington and the United Nations in New York in the hope of securing progress in talks between Israel and the Palestinians, Administration officials said today. **********The goal, the officials said, is for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, to hammer out at least some of the final details of an agreement before they meet separately with President Clinton next week. **********''One can break off parts of this and try to get agreement on it,'' said James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman. ''The question is whether the political will is there to make the hard decisions.'' **********American officials said there was little hope of an overall settlement next week, especially because Prime Minister Netanyahu must be back in Israel before Tuesday evening for the start of the Yom Kippur holy day. He is to meet President Clinton in the White House on Monday morning and then leave immediately for Israel. **********Still, Administration officials said the White House hopes for some concrete agreements next week, if only to prove that the President remains actively involved in foreign policy and has not been distracted by the political turmoil resulting from his sexual misadventures. **********After nearly two years with little visible progress in peace talks, Israel and the Palestinians are reported to be near a agreement under which Israel would cede another 13 percent of the West Bank to the Palestinians. About a quarter of the newly ceded area would be designated as nature reserves to prevent Palestinian settlements. **********The Israeli Army radio quoted Prime Minister Netanyahu as officially confirming that Israel was ready to withdraw from another 13 percent of the West Bank. The report also quoted a senior Israeli official as saying an agreement with the Palestinians could be signed within two weeks. **********But American officials say there are various issues to be resolved, including Israel's demand for concrete guarantees from the Palestinians that they will not allow their territory to be used as a haven for terrorists. **********Ms. Albright, who met with Mr. Netanyahu earlier this week when both were in New York for the opening of the United Nations General Assembly, is expected to return to New York on Saturday for late-night meetings with both the Israeli leader and Mr. Arafat. **********Mr. Rubin said she was expected to remain in New York on Sunday ''in order to continue to work on this effort in advance of meetings the President will hold.'' State Department officials did not rule out the possibility that she might try to arrange a joint meeting this weekend with Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat. **********She is scheduled to be back in Washington on Monday for the White House meeting with Mr. Netanyahu, and then to return to the United Nations, possibly to talk to Mr. Arafat again in preparation for his White House meeting with the President later in the week. **********Mr. Arafat is to address the General Assembly on Monday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/14/world.snippet: Mexican authorities say they are holding two Americans, Hugo Ambriz Duarte and his brother Rene, for questioning in Mexico City in connection with transfer of over 1,000 automatic rifles and other firearms to drug dealers (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/14/world.main_headline: Mexico Holds 2 U.S. Brothers in Gunrunning Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/14/world.print_headline: Mexico Holds 2 U.S. Brothers in Gunrunning Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/14/world.body_text: **********The Mexican authorities said today that  they were holding two American  brothers for questioning in connection with the transfer of more than 1,000 automatic rifles and other firearms to drug traffickers. **********The two, Hugo Ambriz Duarte, 26, a student of international trade at El Paso Community College through early 1997, and his brother Rene, 24, a business administration student at the University of Texas at El Paso,  were detained by an elite federal police unit on Saturday in Ciudad Juarez, which forms a single metropolitan area with El Paso. They were then flown to Mexico City. **********Officials said the apparent involvement of the Americans in gunrunning appeared to exemplify the increasing tendency of Mexican traffickers to recruit collaborators among youths living north of the border. In another case, a San Diego man recruited as a teen-ager by Mexican traffickers was killed in Tijuana as he tried to assassinate a newspaper publisher in November. **********Under police questioning, the brothers acknowledged having sold arms to the Juarez drug cartel, according to a statement issued today by the Federal Attorney General's office. Relatives of the brothers who spoke to reporters in El Paso, however, said the two were innocent. **********The statement said the men were detained after a complaint presented by the American authorities, who  asserted that the ''the Ambriz Duarte brothers introduced into Mexico more than 1,000 firearms, including hundreds of AK-47 rifles.'' The statement said some of the weapons were later confiscated from members of the cartel. **********Why the American authorities would turn over information to Mexico, rather than make an arrest themselves, was not immediately clear. **********The detention of the brothers initially caused a furor in Juarez because they were reported kidnapped. A senior Mexican official, however, said the detention was carried out in a strictly legal fashion. **********The brothers were seized by eight federal agents traveling in two unmarked vehicles, who blocked their Dodge Ram Charger on a Juarez street, dragged the two out and drove them away, along with their Dodge, which was later found abandoned. **********The brothers were among nine people detained by armed men in several incidents in Juarez on Saturday. Four businessmen who were seized have reappeared, saying they  were robbed by the men who detained them. Three men are still missing, although the police are trying to determine whether a body found on Sunday, bound and bearing signs of torture, is that of one of them. **********Nearly 100 people have disappeared in Juarez in recent years, most of them after having been detained by state or federal agents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/21/busin.snippet: French Government will reduce its stake in France Telecom to 62.5 percent from 75 percent in sale of shares worth as much as $9 billion; Government will sell 5 to 6 percent of existing shares, while France Telecom will sell new shares equivalent t...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/21/busin.main_headline: France to Sell Another Piece Of State Telephone Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/21/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; France to Sell Another Piece Of State Telephone Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/21/busin.body_text: **********The French Government said today that it would reduce its stake in France Telecom to 62.5 percent from 75 percent in a sale of shares worth as much as $9 billion. **********The Government will sell 5 to 6 percent of the existing shares, while France Telecom, Europe's second-largest phone company, will sell new shares equivalent to 5 percent of the company. The action is expected to occur in September or October. **********As France announced the sale, the Government and Germany also scaled back plans to swap up to 8 percent in their formerly state-owned phone companies -- reducing the stakes to a symbolic 2 percent meant to cement France Telecom's partnership with Deutsche Telekom. The sales will give the two Governments cash to help cut their budget deficits, as required for participation in the European single currency starting in January. **********''This is the perfect time to sell with the way the shares have risen,'' said Jean-Michel Maingain, who manages $6.4 billion at CDC Gestion in Paris. **********While France Telecom's stock price fell 6 percent today, to a one-month low of 391 francs, or $65.44, it is still more than double the 182 franc price last October, when the Government sold a quarter of the company. **********France Telecom said that the stakes the two companies were buying in each other had been reduced to avoid tying up too much capital. The cross-holding was a key argument used by France's Socialist Cabinet to defend its sale of shares in the phone company last year, after promising during its election campaign to slow state asset sales. Officials said the company had to be able to swap shares with partners, especially Deutsche Telekom. **********Still, the plan had been widely questioned as equity stakes lost their allure as a way to cement alliances. British Telecommunications P.L.C.'s venture with MCI Communications, in which it owns 20 percent, fell apart last year when it lost a battle for the company to Worldcom. Last month, an accord for Italy to sell 1.2 percent of Telecom Italia to Unisource, an AT&T grouping, and the dominant phone companies in the Netherlands, Sweden and Switzerland, expired without a final agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/19/world.snippet: Turks who believe that military has become too deeply involved in politics hope that emergence of new military commander in August will have profound effect on national life; five-year term of Turkey's chief of staff, Gen Ismail Hakki Karadayi, wh...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/19/world.main_headline: Turks Hope General Will Lead Army Pullout From Politics
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/19/world.print_headline: Turks Hope General Will Lead Army Pullout From Politics
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/19/world.body_text: **********Turks who believe that the military has become too deeply involved in politics here are hoping that the emergence of a new military commander in August will have a profound effect on national life. **********The five-year term of Turkey's Chief of Staff, Gen. Ismail Hakki Karadayi, who has led the military deeply into politics in an effort to stem what he says is the rise of religious fundamentalism, expires on Aug. 30. His successor is likely to be an officer who believes that the military should stay closer to its barracks and further away from politics. **********Turkey has had weak and fragmented Governments for the last five years. This week the latest in the line of embattled Prime Ministers, Mesut Yilmaz, announced that he would resign at the end of this year and that new national elections would be held in April. **********As civilian leaders have proved unable to overcome personal and political rivalries, the role of the military has increased considerably. It is now the country's most potent political force, as it showed last year by forcing the resignation of Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan, whom officers accused of supporting fundamentalism. **********The military has also taken over principal responsibility for Turkey's relations with Greece and other nearby countries, as well as for policy toward Cyprus and toward this country's Kurdish minority. It encourages prosecutors to pursue cases against writers, journalists and politicians who express heretical  views on these or other matters. **********Military commanders have compiled a list of businesses that Government agencies should boycott because they have been deemed favorable to political Islam. They are pressing Parliament to pass a series of anti-fundamentalist laws, including curbs on Islamic foundations and new restrictions on the construction of mosques. **********With the military now so involved in civilian policy, and with political parties so weak and fragmented, a change in the top military command might have a far more profound effect on Turkish life than an election. **********The Turkish military command operates under strictly observed rules and traditions. They dictate that General Karadayi will step down in August and that he will be replaced by the army commander, Gen. Huseyin Kivrikoglu. Although General Kivrikoglu has kept a low public profile and declines requests for interviews, officers who know him and commentators who monitor the army believe that he will seek to curb the military's political role.  Some speculate that he will transfer senior officers who have directed the anti-fundamentalist campaign and will abolish the West Working Group, a military intelligence unit that closely monitors Islamic trends in society. **********''If Kivrikoglu gets the job, and I think he will, the army will begin pulling back from politics,'' said a veteran newspaper and television commentator who asked not to be identified. ''He is a secularist and against Islamic politics, like all top military people. But he's not an activist. He takes a more limited view of what role the military should play in Turkish politics and society.'' **********The final decision about changes in the military command will be made at the end of August by the Supreme Military Council, a panel composed of top military and civilian leaders and headed by Prime Minister Yilmaz. Military commanders have become impatient with Mr. Yilmaz for his failure to press harder against fundamentalism.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/02/busin.main_headline: Sprint in Plan To Enter Local Phone Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/02/busin.print_headline: Sprint in Plan To Enter Local Phone Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/02/busin.body_text: **********The Sprint Corporation, the No. 3 long-distance telephone carrier, plans to announce today its long-awaited strategy for competing in local communications markets, executives close to the company said yesterday. **********The strategy is based on an ambitious plan to deliver high-speed access to cyberspace, the executives said. **********Today's announcement comes after Sprint has spent the last two years essentially sitting on the sidelines in terms of competing in new local telephone markets. The company seems to have spent that time devising some new tactics for use in the continuing battle between long-distance and local phone companies. **********A person close to Sprint said the company was hoping to cooperate with the five Bell local telephone companies rather than attack them head-on. That cooperation could take the form of Sprint's agreeing to buy capacity on advanced local data networks that many of the Bells are planning to build. **********The Bell Atlantic Corporation, which offers phone service for much of the area from Virginia to Maine, and SBC Communications Inc. appear to be the Bells that are negotiating most seriously with Sprint, a person close to Sprint said. **********As they await permission from regulators to sell long-distance service within their traditional local telephone regions, Bell Atlantic and SBC each have already signed contracts with Sprint to buy wholesale capacity on Sprint's national fiber optic network. **********Bell Atlantic, Sprint and SBC, which includes Southwestern Bell and Pacific Bell and which has agreed to acquire the Ameritech Corporation, declined to comment yesterday. **********In its announcement today, code-named Operation Fast Break, Sprint intends to unveil what it calls an ''integrated on-demand network.''  Sprint plans to say that consumers can use a single connection to the new network for multiple phone lines, access to the Internet and other advanced data services and video conferencing. **********The company plans to begin offering the new service to large business customers later this year and make it generally available to business clients around the middle of next year. Sprint plans to begin offering the service to residential consumers in late 1999. **********Sprint plans to offer the service both in areas where the company already offers local phone service as well as in new regions. **********People close to Sprint said the company had spent about $2 billion the last five years developing the new network. Among the companies that have tried the new system is Hallmark Cards Inc., the greeting card giant based in Kansas City, Mo.  Sprint is based in Westwood, Kan., a suburb of Kansas City. **********Sprint plans to announce that it has formed three strategic alliances in connection with the new system. Cisco Systems Inc., the maker of data networking equipment, will provide high-speed communications equipment that uses an advanced sort of technology known as asynchronous transfer mode. **********Bellcore, the former research venture of the regional Bell companies, will provide the main software for the venture. Bellcore is now a unit of the Science Applications International Corporation, a private company based in San Diego that is best known for its work in computer security. **********Sprint's main partner in retail distribution will be the Tandy Corporation's chain of Radio Shack electronics stores. Sprint already uses Radio Shack to help promote Sprint's wireless telephone service. **********The Telecommunications Act of 1996 was meant to unleash broad competitive forces in local and long-distance communications markets. But while consumers can choose from among hundreds of long-distance carriers, most Americans only have one choice of local phone company: the same provider they had before 1996. **********Many telecommunications experts expected the three largest long-distance companies -- the AT&T Corporation, the MCI Communications Corporation and Sprint -- to invade local phone markets quickly. But that has not happened. **********MCI had an aggressive plan to build local networks and compete against the Bells, but after losses began to mount last year MCI pulled back. In fact, unexpectedly large losses in its local operation led to perhaps the most traumatic event in MCI's corporate history: its grudging renegotiation of its deal to be acquired by British Telecommunications P.L.C. last year and an unsolicited $37 billion takeover offer from Worldcom Inc., which was accepted and which is awaiting approval from regulators. **********Sprint is expected to say today that it has already spent most of the money required to build the new network. That could lead to tough questions about how many residential consumers the company really wants to serve.
