https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/27/world.snippet: Nigeria's northern Muslim elite stages show of force with book party in city of Kano celebrating publication of biography of Gen Hassan U Katsina, former military governor of northern region, as well as its hold on power for past two decades; maps...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/27/world.main_headline: A Book Party Promotes Nigerian Elite's Hold on Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/27/world.print_headline: A Book Party Promotes Nigerian Elite's Hold on Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/27/world.body_text: **********As book publication parties go, it was a singular occasion -- held in a soccer stadium, attended by several former heads of state, backed by the army's top brass, and amounting to perhaps the first act in the looming battle for political control of Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation. **********''The Nigerian Army has contributed one million naira!'' a guest speaker from the northern city of Kano boomed. He did not specify how many copies of the book the army would receive for this sum of about $125,000, but pressed on to announce payments from the inspector-general of police, and from the air force, the military governor of the northern Kaduna state and, not least, the Kaduna Polo Club. **********''As for the head of state,'' the speaker said, referring to Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar, Nigeria's recently installed military ruler, ''we will not, out of respect, announce the size of his contribution.'' In all, more than $1 million was raised. **********The book, published by a Kaduna company, is a biography of Gen. Hassan U. Katsina, a former military governor of the northern region of Nigeria. But that was scarcely the point. For this was clearly a show of force by the northern Muslim elite of military officers, traditional rulers or emirs, and businessmen whose coalition has retained control of Nigeria for two decades. **********''General Abubakar has said the military Government will no longer fund political parties, but he said nothing about funding a book,'' a Western diplomat in the stadium said. ''What you have here is a political project built around a book.'' **********The precise form of that project is as yet unclear, but it seems certain to involve the formation of a northern, conservative political party, close to the armed forces. The man described as the ''chief launcher'' of the book was Aminu Dantata, the director of a powerful northern group of companies, and the ''chief sponsor'' was the former military ruler, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida. **********Among the others present were other former northern military rulers, including Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari -- who seized power in 1983 and was deposed by General Babangida in a coup in 1985, and Gen. Yakubu Gowon, who seized power in 1966 and ceded it in a coup in 1975. **********It is from this coalition, often referred to as ''the Kaduna mafia,'' that southern Nigerians are determined to wrest power in presidential elections now set for next year. **********They thought they had done so in the 1993 presidential election, with the apparent victory of the late Moshood K. O. Abiola, a man of the Yoruba people of the south. But General Babangida annulled the vote, sharpening the north-south divide that has plagued Nigeria since independence in 1960. Mr. Abiola died in detention this month. **********The area known as northern Nigeria, but embracing much of the center of the country, is ethnically mixed. But it has been largely united by its Hausa language, its overwhelmingly Muslim character, and its fear of ceding political control to the mainly Christian south. It is in the south that economic and commercial power -- essentially the country's oil -- are concentrated. **********Since taking office last month, after the unexpected death of Gen. Sani Abacha, General Abubakar has been at pains not to fan these divisions. He has appointed Yoruba officers to the key military posts, and he has promised to hand power to a civilian on May 29 next year. **********Although he was billed as the star speaker in the stadium, General Abubakar did not attend, apparently out of concern that he might polarize the country further by identifying too closely with the northern military elite from which he has emerged. But his financial contribution made his sympathies clear enough. **********''What you have here is a group of conservative people who regard power as their heritage,'' said Bashir Ikara, a Kaduna-based political scientist. ''But the fact is that ordinary northerners have nothing to show for this long domination and are simply clamoring, like the rest of the country, for honest government.'' **********In many ways, the domination by a northern elite of military men and the emirs appears to have perpetuated elements of the old colonial system. Kaduna, home to Nigeria's military academy, was founded by Frederick Lugard, the British governor general who created Nigeria in 1914 and who favored the north because it was less unruly and more conservative than the south. **********''The bastions of northern society joined forces with the British to plunder our resources,'' Mr. Ikara said. ''Then the Nigerian armed forces replaced British soldiers. But elements of the system -- and the plundering -- have continued.'' **********Lord Lugard once described the people of the southern city of Lagos as ''the most seditious and disloyal, the most purely prompted by self-seeking money motives of any people I have met.'' In Kaduna, the regional assembly meets in a building still known as ''Lugard House,'' and the Polo Club, Nigeria's best, and the Rugby Club are situated on Waff Road -- named after Britain's former West African Frontier Force. **********Many Yoruba seem determined to overcome this legacy, referring in Lagos newspapers to the ''internal colonialism'' to which they see themselves subjugated. But, as the turnout at the meeting in Kaduna showed, the battle to shift Nigeria's political gravity promises to be a bitter one.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/10/techn.snippet: Newest version of 3Com's popular Palm Pilot has been criticized for offering only limited Web access; 3Com's Joe Sipher says company concluded it would be too costly and unwieldy to offer full Web access on its personal digital assistant (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/10/techn.main_headline: Perhaps We Should Be Amazed That It Can Surf the Web at All
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/10/techn.print_headline: NEWS WATCH; Perhaps We Should Be Amazed That It Can Surf the Web at All
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/10/techn.body_text: **********Since 3Com announced its newest version of the popular Palm Pilot, the Palm VII, it has been criticized by some users for offering only limited Web access. That access, called Web Clippings, allows Palm users to see updated, albeit abridged, information from 22 corporate Web sites through a wireless connection. **********Joe Sipher, director of wireless products for 3Com, of Santa Clara, Calif., said the company had concluded that it would be too costly and unwieldy to offer full Web access on its personal digital assistant. ''Try hooking into the Web on a Windows CE device,'' he said. ''It's a terrible, terrible experience.'' **********The information available through Web Clippings is restricted to that which is well suited for the Palm's small screen and very slow access speed of 8 kilobits per second. For instance, Etrade will allow access to stock quotes, but not trades; the Yahoo function will allow telephone and address searches, and USA Today Online will provide a digest of news and sports. The service is not designed to offer general Web access, nor is it cheap. The wireless access will cost $9.99 a month for about 6 transactions a day, or $24.99 for up to 18 a day, Mr. Sipher said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.snippet: Joint investigation by New York Times and CBS News finds that significant portion of American-made weapons, military jets and parts that Iran buys illicitly move through Canada, taking advantage of regulatory loopholes and Canadian Govt's decision...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.main_headline: Sneaking U.S. Jets to Iran: The Canadian Route
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.print_headline: Sneaking U.S. Jets to Iran: The Canadian Route
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.body_text: **********Several times over the past few years, Reza Akrami, an Iranian, left his home in the Vancouver area and flew to San Francisco to see a mysterious man who spoke in Persian and called himself Dr. Afshar. **********They met at a swank hotel or an expensive restaurant. A few times they lunched on a private yacht docked in the bay. There were thick steaks and fine wines. **********Eventually, a shadowy deal was put on the table. Dr. Afshar would arrange delivery of American-made jets and military parts, including electronics to guide antiaircraft missiles. The destination for the parts was Iran, and the suggested payment was a large shipment of heroin, according to a fax sent from Iran to Mr. Akrami that outlined the arrangement. **********The deal never came off. ''Dr. Afshar'' was an undercover agent for the United States Government posing as an arms dealer bent on evading the American embargo against Iran. **********Mr. Akrami and an associate were arrested in Vancouver this week and are being held pending extradition to the United States. They face charges of conspiring to smuggle sophisticated military parts to Iran in violation of the United States embargo. **********A joint investigation by The New York Times and CBS News has found that this is not an isolated case. A significant portion of the American-made weapons and parts that Iran buys illicitly move through Canada, taking advantage of regulatory loopholes and the Canadian Government's decision not to support the American embargo. **********The result, say American officials and the Iranians involved, is a steady flow of American-made military parts across the border into Canada and on to Iran. ''Sanctions against Iran make no sense because they get everything they want through other countries,'' Mr. Akrami said in an interview here before his arrest. **********According to an indictment returned this week by a grand jury in San Francisco, Mr. Akrami, 60, told undercover agents the Iranian Government wanted to buy as many klystron tubes -- the heart of missile guidance systems -- as he could find. **********''There is a significant amount of circumvention of our sanctions through Canada,'' said Raymond W. Kelly, an Under Secretary of the Treasury, who is awaiting confirmation as the new head of the Customs Service. ''Because of the relaxed border situation that we have with Canada, the potential for abuse there is greater than perhaps with other allies.'' **********Among the Iranian arms deals involving Canada are these: ***********A Long Island man was arrested in February by United States Customs agents as he tried to deliver engines and parts for F-14 Tomcat fighters to Iran; some of the items were to be routed through Canada. He is awaiting trial. ***********A Canadian businessman was indicted in Washington, D.C., last year on 27 counts of shipping embargoed aviation parts to Iran by way of Canada and then Germany. He is currently a fugitive. ***********In Miami in 1994, an Irish businessman pleaded guilty to charges of attempting to send military night-vision goggles to Iran by way of Canada. **********And Iran is not the only destination for embargoed American military equipment from Canada. **********Several Americans and Canadians were arrested last August and charged with attempting to sell to Iraq 35 American-made military helicopters that Canada had declared surplus. The buyers had asked that some helicopters be outfitted with chemical-spraying equipment. Two Canadians have already pleaded guilty; the other defendants are awaiting trial. **********Last fall a Toronto businessman pleaded guilty to selling $6 million worth of jet parts to Libya, including some that could have military uses. **********''I'll be honest with you: Canada does not pretend that it is enforcing a U.S. embargo,'' said Lynda E. Watson, director of the export controls division in the Canadian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Trade. While Canada tries to make sure it is not used as a decoy to get around American export restrictions, she explained, its efforts are limited. **********''It's not our embargo,'' she said, ''and it's not our job to enforce a U.S. embargo.'' **********The Middleman **********From Army Doctor To Refugee **********There are many unanswered questions about Mr. Akrami: Precisely on whose behalf was he shopping for parts? What did the Iranian Government knew about his activities? **********And while American agents were luring him into their sting, Canadian intelligence agents were using him as their informant. **********Mr. Akrami said in an interview before his arrest that he was merely a purchasing agent for Iran. ''I cannot stop them to fax me what they want,'' he said, ''but it doesn't mean I can do something or I want to do something.'' **********Mr. Akrami's lawyer, Irvine E. Epstein, said his client had exaggerated the importance of his contacts in Iran and expected Dr. Afshar to arrange the necessary export permits if the deals went through. **********''He's absolutely adamant that he has not committed any crimes in Canada or the United States,'' Mr. Epstein said of his client. ''If anything, what we have is perhaps some overzealous undercover agents trying to make something out of nothing.'' **********Before coming to Canada, Mr. Akrami said, he was a colonel in the Iranian Army and a cardiac surgeon in contact with many of Iran's most powerful people. He boasted to friends that he had once treated the Ayatollah Khomeini. **********Mr. Akrami said he had received his medical degrees in Germany and returned to Iran just a year before the 1979 revolution. His foreign training made him suspect in the turmoil of fundamentalist, post-revolution Iran. He was imprisoned but was allowed to see patients, he said. **********Soon after being freed from prison, Mr. Akrami married an Iranian woman with family in Vancouver. In 1991 he emigrated to Canada, where he quickly fit into Vancouver's substantial Iranian refugee community. **********''I'm connected to everybody,'' he said during the interview at his office. **********He does not practice medicine in Canada but gained notoriety when his mother-in-law won a divorce settlement that was the equivalent of $12 million, one of the largest in Canadian history. He helped her invest the money in various ventures, and made no secret of his intention to do business with Iran. **********In the interviews, he said he helped arrange for the delivery of two shiploads of American chemicals to Iran about four years ago, which he believed did not violate terms of the embargo. He also said he regularly received faxed messages from Iran requesting help in purchasing everything from Braille typewriters and spare parts for jumbo jets to a fleet of used civilian aircraft. **********People close to the investigation said he once told undercover agents, ''Canada is Iran's free-trade zone.'' **********The United States first imposed economic sanctions on Iran after the hostage crisis in 1979. In 1995, after Iran was linked to terrorist attacks, a total ban was imposed on all American trade with the country. Before then, certain items, including some chemicals, could be exported from the United States. **********The Introductions **********Linking Heroin To Fighter Jets **********Mr. Akrami might not have come to the attention of American authorities if not for another Iranian immigrant to Canada who was arrested by drug agents in San Francisco in 1994 and charged with a conspiracy to distribute large amounts of heroin. **********Prosecutors in San Francisco had substantial evidence against the man, Abrahim Hamidi. But after he developed medical problems, they let him return to his home in Langley, a Vancouver suburb where he lived in a modest house and grew Iranian sour plums in the backyard. **********Shortly after his return to Canada, Mr. Hamidi held a dinner at his home and invited a young Iranian friend, Mohsen Lessan, and Mr. Akrami, who said he was looking for new business opportunities. **********But this was apparently more than a social engagement. According to officials familiar with the investigation, Mr. Hamidi was cooperating with American agents who wanted to broaden their investigation into the Iranian heroin connection. The charges against Mr. Hamidi in California were dismissed in April 1996, but within a few days he was arrested on a similar drug charge in Canada. In an unusual move, the records in that case were sealed, and it is not possible to learn its outcome. **********Mr. Lessan, now a 30-year-old real estate salesman in Vancouver, said in an interview that he and Mr. Akrami had flown to San Francisco and met the man they knew as Dr. Afshar. They lunched in grand style on a yacht they believed was his. They discussed the purchase of up to 30 used jets for Iran, as well as parts and other items. **********Mr. Lessan said he felt he was in over his head. While Mr. Akrami returned to San Francisco at least twice, Mr. Lessan never again met Dr. Afshar. He was arrested this week along with Mr. Akrami and is being held pending extradition to San Francisco, where a United States Attorney, Michael J. Yamaguchi, plans to prosecute him and Mr. Akrami on the smuggling conspiracy charges. **********Mr. Lessan's lawyer, Jamie Paez, has refused to comment. **********The End of the Deal **********A Disputed Fax, An Angry Ex-Wife **********In his first interview with The New York Times and CBS, Mr. Akrami denied knowing Mr. Hamidi. But at a subsequent talk in his high-rise apartment, he admitted that he had gone to Mr. Hamidi's house, but only because his wife liked the sour plums that Mr. Hamidi grew. **********Mr. Hamidi did not respond to several phone calls or visits to his home. **********Mr. Akrami eventually admitted he had discussed several deals with ''Dr. Afshar,'' adding, ''Ninety-nine percent of the discussion was about planes.'' **********But he said one fax he received from his contact in Iran -- a man known as Sultanipour whom American officials have linked to the Iranian Government -- requested sophisticated military parts, including the American-made klystron tubes used in missile guidance systems. **********At the meetings in San Francisco, which were monitored by United States agents, Mr. Akrami openly discussed military parts and displayed a detailed knowledge of how they worked. Once, he even commented that the suitcase-sized klystron tube the agents had brought was a slightly different color than those he had seen before. **********During this period, officials said, Mr. Akrami also met regularly with the Canadian Security Intelligence Service, Canada's spy agency, which sometimes uses recent immigrants to gather information. He insists he never told them about the San Francisco meetings. **********Mr. Akrami acknowledged there were other faxes as well, including one that mentioned paying for the parts with a ''shipload of heroin.'' But he insisted that although he presented the faxed letter to Dr. Afshar, he never had any intention of actually going through with the deal. **********''This was nonsense,'' said Mr. Akrami. ''How can I have drugs to offer to someone for something like that?'' **********After repeated contact and telephone conversations with the undercover agents, Mr. Akrami abruptly backed away from the deal last summer. He said things had changed because of the tightened American embargo and because of the more moderate Government that had come to power in Iran's elections. But there appeared to be another reason: his recently divorced wife, who had some of the faxes from Iran, was threatening to expose him. **********He said his former wife had shown the faxes to authorities in an attempt to discredit him. People close to the investigation confirmed that the Canadian Security Intelligence Service, a local prosecutor and a member of Parliament had talked to the woman. **********The Loophole **********An 'Exception' For a Neighbor **********Although Mr. Akrami is not charged with actually shipping any embargoed parts to Iran, recent incidents indicate that plenty of American military goods leave Canada's shores, largely because of ''the Canada exemption.'' **********For decades it has been policy of both Canada and the United States that Canada would purchase major arms systems from the United States instead of developing its own military industry. For this reason, such goods being shipped to Canada are exempt from the licensing requirements that apply to every other country. **********''Since we don't issue a license here, there's no trail to follow,'' said John Hensley, the former head of enforcement for the United States Customs Service. ''Therefore we can't tell how much is leaving Canada en route to other countries.'' **********Canada does $1 billion a year in legitimate trade with Iran. While Canada has regulations to keep Canada from being used to hide shipments to Iran, officials here make it clear that the embargo is America's fight, not Canada's. **********''We feel that we are taking very responsible and strong steps to deal with this,'' said Ms. Watson, the Canadian customs official, ''but we're not 100 percent effective.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/17/world.snippet: Massimo D'Alema, former Communist and leader of largest leftist party in Italy, is selected to try to form a new Govt; D'Alema, is chosen after Acting Prime Min Romano Prodi, who resigned after losing confidence vote last week, failed to gather en...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/17/world.main_headline: Leftist Leader to Try to Assemble a New Government in Italy
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/17/world.print_headline: Leftist Leader to Try to Assemble a New Government in Italy
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/17/world.body_text: **********Massimo D'Alema, a former Communist and leader of the largest leftist party in Italy, was selected today to try to form a new government. **********Mr. D'Alema, 49, was chosen after Acting Prime Minister Romano Prodi, who resigned after losing a confidence vote last week, failed to gather enough support in Parliament to form a new government. **********If Mr. D'Alema succeeds in cobbling together a majority among Italy's many splintered political factions, Italy will fit even more closely with the European wave of social democratic governments or at least some of them. **********Mr. Prodi, a pragmatic economist with centrist views, was closer in outlook to Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain. In background and political approach, Mr. D'Alema resembles the Socialist Prime Minister of France, Lionel Jospin, and Gerhard Schroder, the German Chancellor-elect. Like them, he will face the challenge of marrying social democratic aspirations with the austerity measures already written into a unified European economic system. **********''I feel the weight of conflicts and expectations,'' Mr. D'Alema said after accepting the mandate. ''And I will try to do what I can do to lessen the conflicts and to not betray the expectations.'' **********Mr. D'Alema was also referring to the narrow political shoals he has been maneuvering in his search for a majority. The leader of Democrats of the Left, a party he helped form out of the embers of the Italian Communist party after the fall of the Soviet Union, said he thought he could count on the support of some Communists and also on a small center-right party led by Francesco Cossiga. **********If Mr. D'Alema and Mr. Cossiga reach agreement, it would put Mr. D'Alema in the position of leading a center-left coalition with more centrist votes in it than his more moderate predecessor. Mr. D'Alema explained his entente cordiale with Mr. Cossiga, a former Christian Democrat and President of Italy, this way: ''President Cossiga is telling our country that the cold war is over and that the men and ideas that openly fought for many years can also collaborate.'' **********Opposition leaders, including Silvio Berlusconi, the media tycoon and former conservative Prime Minister, were outraged by Mr. Cossiga's defection, calling it a fraud. **********Mr. D'Alema is counting on another fallout from the end of the cold war: the split among the Communists that occurred after hard-liners withdrew their support from Mr. Prodi. **********Mr. Prodi's coalition relied on Communist Refounding, the party that remained after leaders like Mr. D'Alema became ex-Communists and formed new, non-Marxist factions. The general secretary of Communist Refounding, Fausto Bertinotti, refused to accept the 1999 budget. That drove Armando Cossutta, president of Communist Refounding, to quit and form his own party, unwilling to be associated with the Communists who caused the leftist Government to collapse. Mr. D'Alema made it clear he was not planning to horse-trade to win Mr. Bertinotti back into the fold. **********''I turn to him and say that his request that we redraft the budget is mistaken. It is a good budget. And if his 'no' does not change, it means the government will have to be formed from the political parties that accept the budget.'' **********Italy badly needs to pass a budget that cuts $9 billion from the deficit to meet the requirements to enter the single European monetary unit, the euro, on Jan. 1, 1999.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/world.snippet: Mongolians see political motives in stabbing murder of Sanjaasuren Zorig, man known as father of their democracy; Zorig, who served as Minister of Infrastructure, was due to be nominated for Prime Minister by his party; Zorig was one of 13 men who...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/world.main_headline: A Gentle Hero Dies, and Mongolia's Innocence, Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/world.print_headline: A Gentle Hero Dies, and Mongolia's Innocence, Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/world.body_text: **********Who killed Zorig? **********From the apartment blocks, offices and countless bars of this capital city to the nomadic tents across the endless countryside, Mongolians have been obsessed with the question in the three weeks since the man known as the father of their democracy was stabbed to death by masked attackers. **********Still unsolved, the killing of the 36-year-old Sanjaasuren Zorig occurred in circumstances that strongly suggest a political or financial motive: on the day of his death, party leaders had agreed to nominate him for Prime Minister, promising to end a three-month standoff that has paralyzed the Government. **********And the speculation about why he was killed reveals the lost innocence of a country that only in 1990 -- thanks in part to Mr. Zorig's leadership -- began a peaceful and exuberant transition to free-market democracy after 70 years of Communism. **********''This is the end of the romantic phase of Mongolian democracy,'' said Hashbat Hulan, 37, a member of Parliament. As in many countries of Eastern Europe and Central Asia that shook off the Soviet empire, euphoria has given way to bitter truths and not a little disillusionment. **********It is telling that the first thing everyone says about Mr. Zorig is that he was honest. Equally telling, as a sign of the blend of sparse fact and plentiful fiction that characterizes many post-Communist societies, the fantastic theories being bruited about are seen as entirely plausible. **********In recent months Mr. Zorig served as Minister of Infrastructure, overseeing multimillion-dollar construction contracts. In a painful interview on Thursday his widow, Bulgan, who was tied up in the bathroom of their home as her husband was stabbed to death, said he had told her of being offered bribes -- of $5,000 and $50,000, among others. **********''Of course he refused,'' said Ms. Bulgan, bursting into tears. ''If he had taken these bribes, perhaps he would be alive today.'' **********Others wonder whether he was killed because, if he had become Prime Minister, he might have uncovered cronyism in the country's sell-off of state industries, or exposed misuse of foreign aid. Or was it the Russian mafia -- a favorite suspect for evils here -- fearing that he would interfere with lucrative business interests? **********Of course it might have been a simple robbery gone bad, and the timing a bizarre coincidence. But nobody in this country of 2.4 million people seems to believe that. **********Politicians were clearly shaken. **********''Why did this happen now, just as we were beginning to unify our coalition?'' asked Delgermaa, a 39-year-old former law professor who is a member of Parliament. ''This was not a coincidence,'' she said. Like many Mongolians, Ms. Delgermaa uses one name. **********One of the country's richest capitalists, Jargalsaikhan, spoke out about Mr. Zorig's killing this week. ''He was an honest, principled and educated person,'' he told a local newspaper. ''These qualities of his were not liked by some people.'' **********''Lately there are a lot of disputes about how to divide the pie, different cases involving money and financial deceit,'' added Mr. Jargalsaikhan, director of the giant Buyan Company, which trades in cashmere. **********For the last three months the Government has been hobbled by an impasse between the Democratic Coalition and the President. The coalition controls Parliament, and the President is from the opposition Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, the former Communists, who now call themselves social democrats. **********Coalition members had helped vote down two of their own Prime Ministers, in the most recent case largely because of an abortive effort to merge a large state bank with a private one. The merger, accomplished and then reversed, has been denounced as poorly conceived -- and, the opposition asserts, pursued in an illegal and corrupt manner. **********Under the Constitution, the President must be consulted before Parliament votes on a new prime minister. The President, Natsagiyn Bagabandi, has repeatedly turned down candidates, calling them unqualified. Finally, on Oct. 2, the coalition factions found common ground, agreeing to nominate Mr. Zorig. The President said he had been ready to approve the nomination. **********That night, a masked man and woman entered the couple's modest apartment in one of the monotonous blocks in central Ulaan Baatar, tied up Ms. Bulgan and ambushed Mr. Zorig at the door, stabbing him 16 times. Ms. Bulgan said her husband had not indicated any suspicions of danger. **********In a land where wrestling is the national sport and Genghis Khan the revered ancestor, Mr. Zorig was a gentle hero. Although his grandfather had been killed decades earlier by Stalin's henchmen, in the 1980's Mr. Zorig, like many Mongolian intellectuals, attended a university in Moscow, studying Marxist-Leninist philosophy. He returned to teach Marxism at a university in Ulaan Baatar, but his thoughts had turned to Western ideals. **********At the end of 1989, as democratic movements coursed through the Soviet empire, Mr. Zorig was one of 13 men who began agitating for Mongolia's freedom. In early 1990, as demonstrations blossomed in Ulaan Baatar's giant central square, he emerged as the most articulate and respected leader. **********He was not so much an eloquent orator, friends say, as a man of wise counsel and a quietly powerful voice of conciliation. **********On one tense day in April 1990, tens of thousands of demonstrators were pressing toward soldiers in front of the Government House. When Mr. Zorig climbed onto friends' shoulders and appealed for calm, witnesses recall, the entire crowd sat down to show their support for peaceful talks. The Communists agreed to write a new, democratic constitution. **********In the country's first real elections, in 1992, the former Communists won handily. But the task of beginning to build a market economy took a toll, with homeless children taking up residence in Ulaan Baatar's sewers, rampant inflation and a growing disparity in incomes. In 1996, to its own astonishment, the coalition of new democratic parties found itself voted into office. **********With the support of an array of international aid agencies and nongovernmental organizations, the youthful leaders vowed to speed up privatization. They also found themselves haggling over Cabinet posts and the management of complex financial transactions. **********While the corruption here does not appear to have reached the rapacious heights of Russia and some other places, it has stirred resentment in a nation with a strong egalitarian tradition. **********''This is a very small country,'' said Ms. Hulan, the legislator. ''People have eyes and ears, they can see how much their leaders are spending, and how much they earn in their public jobs.'' **********She added, ''We entertained naive thoughts that Mongolia could escape the pitfalls of all the other post-Communist countries that are now submerged in corruption and racketeering.'' **********A small group including Ms. Huran has proposed new laws to require that legislators disclose their total earnings and campaign donations, and that records of Government financial transactions be made public. **********This year, just as Mongolia seemed to be turning the corner economically, the country was battered by plummeting global prices of copper and cashmere, its main sources of revenue and foreign exchange. **********Between the economic woes and public impatience with the Government's performance, most politicians here predict that the former Communists will regain power in the next general election, in 2000. **********In the meantime, Mongolians -- an exceptionally literate and well-informed people -- are dismayed by the stalemate. In the warmth of his traditional tent-like dwelling, known as a ger, Demberelmolom expressed his exasperation by reciting a Mongolian saying: ''If the people up high can't stand on their feet, the people down below can't find a seat.'' **********Mr. Demberelmolom and his wife tend monastery ruins in a mountain valley south of Ulaan Baatar. Their theory about Mr. Zorig's murder?  ''Maybe they were having trouble dividing up their pie.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/17/busin.snippet: Unisys Corp says net income more than doubled in second quarter; net income rose to $90.1 million from $41.9 million a year earlier; sales rose 9 percent, to $1.73 billion from $1.59 billion (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/17/busin.main_headline: Unisys Reports Big Rise in Net Income
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/17/busin.print_headline: Unisys Reports Big Rise in Net Income
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/17/busin.body_text: **********The Unisys Corporation said today that net income more than doubled in the second quarter, aided by cost cuts and strong sales by its information-services business. **********Net income rose to $90.1 million, or 24 cents a diluted share, from $41.9 million, or 8 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts had expected earnings of 21 cents a share, and Unisys rose 87.5 cents, to $29.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The company's chairman and chief executive, Lawrence Weinbach, who took the helm in September, continues to cut costs and pay down debt. He is working to turn Unisys into a computer networking and services company after years of losses in its traditional mainframe business. Unisys got out of the personal computer business in the first quarter. **********Sales rose 9 percent, to $1.73 billion from $1.59 billion, paced by a 29 percent jump at the information services business, which helps integrate computer systems and handles outsourcing for corporate customers. Unisys said orders in that business increased at a double-digit rate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/15/busin.snippet: Lee Apparel Co unit of VF Corp names ad agency Fallon McElligott to handle advertising for Lee jeans in Europe; account, with billings estimated at $20 million, had been handled by London offices of Grey Advertising (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/15/busin.main_headline: Fallon McElligott Gets Lee for Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/15/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Fallon McElligott Gets Lee for Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/15/busin.body_text: **********The Lee Apparel Company unit of the VF Corporation in Merriam, Kan., said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis by naming that agency to handle advertising for Lee jeans in Europe. That account, with billings estimated at $20 million, had been handled by the London office of Grey Advertising. **********The decision, which was expected, came after a review that included Fallon McElligott, which handles advertising for Lee in the United States; Grey, and two agencies in London: Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, part of Omnicom Group, and Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters. Executives at Fallon McElligott said last month that they would open a London office in the summer regardless whether the agency was awarded the European Lee account.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/28/busin.snippet: Advertising column on decision by Frito-Lay and its parent, Pepsico Inc, to consolidate global accounts at BBDO Worldwide; says this follows trend among large marketers to consolidate (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/28/busin.main_headline: Consolidations by Frito-Lay and Pepsico move a host of choice assignments to BBDO Worldwide.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/28/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Consolidations by Frito-Lay and Pepsico move a host of choice assignments to BBDO Worldwide.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/28/busin.body_text: **********THE snack giant Frito-Lay is joining the ranks of large marketers that are consolidating global accounts by unexpectedly moving virtually all its creative advertising assignments to BBDO Worldwide. **********At the same time, BBDO was awarded a second tasty consolidation treat by Pepsico Inc., the parent  of the Frito-Lay Company and the Pepsi-Cola Company. Pepsico is uniting the United States media services duties for both those divisions at BBDO. **********The twin consolidations, announced yesterday, are the most recent in a lengthy skein that includes similar steps by the Compaq Computer Corporation, Citicorp, Club Mediterranee S. A., the Colgate-Palmolive Company and I.B.M. Multinational marketers are combining accounts at single agencies for such reasons as fostering consistency in sales pitches across borders and seeking more influence in negotiating rates for commercial time and advertising space. **********The Frito-Lay consolidation comes as the company is intensifying efforts to widen its lead in snack sales in markets like the United States as well as fend off feisty competitors like the Procter & Gamble Company. **********''The aim of our partnership,'' said Allen Rosenshine, chairman and chief executive of BBDO, a unit of Omnicom Group in New York, ''will be to leverage Frito-Lay's global scale and communicate consistent worldwide brand messages that connect with consumers everywhere.'' **********Though Frito-Lay had divided its creative assignments among many agencies around the world, three were considered to be its principal global roster shops. **********One was BBDO, which has created campaigns for brands like Baked Lay's snack chips; Doritos tortilla chips; Ruffles potato chips; Tostitos tortilla chips, salsa and dips, and the new Wow! line of snacks made with the fake fat Olestra. The BBDO New York office has taken the lead on the agency's Frito-Lay assignments and will continue to do so under the consolidation. **********The second was DDB Needham Worldwide, another Omnicom unit based in New York, which has created campaigns for brands like Cheetos cheese-flavored puffs, Fritos corn chips, Lay's potato chips and Rold Gold pretzels. The Rold Gold campaign, featuring the ''Seinfeld'' star Jason Alexander, has been one of the most successful recent efforts to increase sales of a snack brand. **********BMP DDB in London, which is the DDB Needham British agency, has handled creative work for the Walkers line of snacks owned by Frito-Lay in Britain. **********The third was the Young & Rubicam Advertising unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York, handling creative assignments for snack brands like Cheetos in Asian-Pacific and Latin American markets. **********Though Frito-Lay, based in Plano, Tex., did not break out the billings that are being shifted as a result of the consolidation, BBDO already handles brands that account for about half the company's estimated annual advertising spending of $125 million. DDB Needham is relinquishing brands that spend an estimated $45 million to $50 million, while Y.& R. Advertising is giving up brands that spend an estimated $15 million to $20 million. **********Frito-Lay spends an additional sum estimated at $75 million annually on other marketing communications programs. TL Partnership in Dallas, owned by Omnicom, handles sales promotions, and Landor Associates in San Francisco and New York, a unit of Y.& R. Inc., handles brand identity and package design assignments. **********Among the other agencies that have handled creative duties for Frito-Lay, one will not be affected by the consolidation: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, a unit of Omnicom in San Franciso, which will continue to work on the Cracker Jack brand. **********''Because it's a new brand for Frito-Lay,'' said Lynn Markley, a spokeswoman for Frito-Lay, referring to the company's recent acquisition of Cracker Jack from Borden Inc., ''we decided to stay with that agency.'' **********The trade publication Advertising Age reported last month that Frito-Lay was considering unspecified realignments in its worldwide agency roster. But the consolidation yesterday -- which followed a review among BBDO, DDB Needham and Y.& R. Advertising -- extended well beyond that. **********''This consolidation represents one of the largest account wins in our history,'' Mr. Rosenshine said. **********As for the United States media services consolidation by Pepsico, BBDO was selected after a review that included several undisclosed agencies; Advertising Age and Adweek reported that the decision had been narrowed to BBDO and Grey Advertising in New York. **********The media duties for Frito-Lay, with billings estimated at $100 million, had been divided between TN Media, a unit of True North Communications in New York, for media buying, and Team Frito-Lay, a unit of DDB Needham in Dallas, for media planning. **********BBDO had already been the media services agency in the United States for Pepsi-Cola beverages, with spending last year in measured media, according to Advertising Age, of $179 million. **********Though Y.& R. Advertising lost its Frito-Lay creative assignments, a sibling, the Media Edge in New York, was awarded a consolidation consolation prize. **********Dr Pepper/Seven Up Inc., a unit of Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., consolidated media planning and buying for its national account, with billings estimated at more than $125 million, at the Media Edge, the Y.& R. Inc. media services agency. **********The Dr Pepper/Seven Up assignment had been divided between the Media Edge, which handled media services for accounts with billings estimated at more than $100 million, and TN Media, which handled domestic media planning and buying for soft-drinks brands like A&W, Canada Dry, Schweppes and Sunkist.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/25/your-.body_text: **********IF SOMEONE TOLD you the local swimming pool was favored by sharks, you probably would not go there. If someone told you a stock exchange was a notorious site for ambushes on foreign investors, you likely would put your money elsewhere. **********That is how investors have been treating the Czech market for the past year, but analysts say now could be a good time to cautiously dip a toe in. **********According to Albert Oesterreicher of the Prague brokerage Oesterreicher & Co., elections on June 19 and 20 "will not bring any surprises, even if the Social Democrats get into power." **********"It's more than clear they won't take any major steps back from the transformation process," he added. "There's now a stable currency, a stable political scene and no really major economic problems, and the market is heavily undervalued." **********Cynics might argue with the political analysis, but a consensus is emerging that rich opportunities exist with stocks judged to be at bargainprices. **********While noting the market has an atrocious reputation, Stephen Pettyfer, Czech analyst at Merrill Lynch & Co. in London, said: "There are certainly some interesting valuations, especially among the banks. The question really is whether it's better to wait until closer to the election." **********Choosing winners among the major players is tough going. The Czechs boast some of the biggest companies in Central Europe, and many seem cheap at current prices. But analysts such as Mr. Pettyfer said local giants such as the heavy manufacturer Skoda Plzen a.s. and the indebted chemicals company Chemapol Group a.s. have not done nearly enough restructuring. **********"A lack of restructuring means a lack of earnings growth," Mr. Pettyfer said. "The question is whether these companies have an interest in pleasing minority shareholders. The answer is that they don't." **********That leaves stock pickers searching for value among a handful of professionally managed, Czech-owned companies and among businesses with majority foreign ownership. Favorites include the monopoly phone provider SPT Telecom a.s; the Philip Morris Cos. Czech operation Tabak a.s.; Cokoladovny a.s., the candy company controlled by Nestle SA and Danone SA, and the brewer Prazske Pivovary a.s. **********Czech picks include the mobile-phone provider Ceske Radiokomunikace as, the equipment-maker CKD Praha Holding a.s., the coal-tar processor Deza Valasske Mezirici a.s. and the builder Inzenyrske & Prumyslove Stavby a.s. **********For those with nerves of steel, there are opportunities in the fund sector, especially over the next six to 12 months. Ondrej Datka, an analyst at the Czech investment bank Patria, said legislation likely to be passed by Parliament in coming weeks would substantially narrow the discount between funds' asset values and their stock prices. **********Analysts stress the fund sector is a dangerous place for novices. But Mr. Datka said the big banks' funds were reasonably safe. He cited the SPIF Ceske fund, owned by the national savings bank Ceska Sporitelna. **********For those who find the Czech market forbidding , there are also a number of Czech country funds and emerging-market funds with Czech exposure. **********Caution is called for here, too. The Czech funds recently have produced some dismal returns. Funds that lose money l included Regent Kingpin Czech Value Fund, Fleming Czech & Slovak Investment Corp.and MC Bohemia Investment Co. **********For investors seeking exposure to Czech blue chips in the belief that they are undervalued, Bohmeia Investment and the more widely based Templeton Central & East European Investment Co. have substantial exposure. **********Some general emerging-market funds with an element of Czech exposure have done better than the country funds. The $300 million Central European Growth Fund managed by Credit Suisse fell by 10 percent over the past 12 months, but has notched up a 66 percent rise over three years. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/20/busin.body_text: **********Cablevision Official Offers To Buy a Stake in Yankees **********George Steinbrenner, the controlling owner of the New York Yankees, acknowledged talking with Charles Dolan, the chairman of Cablevision Systems, about Mr. Dolan's buying a piece of the club. **********Even so, a member of the Steinbrenner family and baseball officials warn that any thought of a sale of part of the Yankees is extremely premature. They also point out that offers to acquire a portion of the club are quite common.   [Page A1.] **********Cablevision would love to add the Yankees to its media empire. The company owns a portion of Madison Square Garden, the Knicks, the Rangers and six regional sports cable services, and already shows Yankee games on them.   [C8.] **********Fidelity Is Closing Three Funds **********Fidelity Investments plans to close three of its stellar performers, its Growth and Income, Contrafund and Low-Priced Stock funds, to new investors after April 3.   [D6.] **********Sunbeam Stock Falls on Estimates **********An announcement by Sunbeam that it might not meet sales estimates for the first quarter because of a decline in orders from retailers sent shares of the stock plummeting 9.4 percent. Analysts had not expected that news from the consumer appliance maker, which recently said it would buy Coleman outdoor equipment, Mr. Coffee machines and First Alert smoke alarms.   [D4.] **********Indonesia and I.M.F. Meeting **********Indonesian and International Monetary Fund officials are meeting to resolve a deadlock that has caused a halt in disbursements of international aid.   [A8.] **********Consumer Prices Increase Slightly **********Consumer prices rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in February, keeping inflation subdued. Though the Labor Department said the number of new jobless claims rose by 9,000 last week, that level still suggests that job creation remains strong.   [D5.] **********Coke Marketing Guru Departs **********Sergio Zyman, a hard-charging and innovative marketing executive who rejuvenated Coca-Cola's advertising over the last four and a half years with a zestful multibillion-dollar campaign, will resign May 1 to spend more time with his family and write a textbook on marketing. ''Life After Sergio'' could mean a more local orientation by Coke in its soft-drink marketing. Advertising.   [D4.] **********Internet Tax Deal Reached **********An agreement was reached by state, city and county government leaders on a bill to mediate the thorny issue of taxing Internet services and commerce. It is expected to be voted on by the House of Representatives in the next few weeks, but it differs significantly from a Senate version.   [A21.] **********BBC and Discovery Form Alliance **********The BBC and Discovery Communications signed a deal to form a $565 million alliance to create new programs and new cable channels around the world.   [D2.] **********Dow Records, Day 4 **********Major stock market indexes rose to records again despite new warnings from several companies about earnings weakness. The Dow industrials surpassed 8,800 for the first time, up 27.65 points, to 8,803.05, the fourth consecutive day that the blue-chip index has closed at a record. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also rose to its fourth consecutive all-time high. The Nasdaq and Russell 2000 indexes increased to records for a second consecutive day.   [D6.] **********Treasuries Little Changed **********Treasuries ended little changed. The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond fell to 5.89 percent from 5.90 percent.   [D6.] **********$6.15 Minimum Wage Proposed **********The Democrats formally introduced a plan to raise the minimum wage by 20 percent, to $6.15 an hour. Unions praised the plan but even some supporters expressed concern that the higher level could cost jobs.   [A14.]

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/26/world.snippet: Nearly one month after BMW AG reached agreement to buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars from Vickers PLC, Volkswagen AG is expected to ignite new bidding war by offering more money and lavish promises to invest billions of dollars in future expansion (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/26/world.main_headline: Volkswagen Expected to Set Off a Bidding War for Rolls-Royce
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/26/world.print_headline: Volkswagen Expected to Set Off a Bidding War for Rolls-Royce
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/26/world.body_text: **********Nearly one month after the German car manufacturer BMW A.G. reached an agreement to buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars, the board of Volkswagen A.G. met today and is expected to ignite a new bidding war by offering more money and lavish promises to invest billions of dollars in future expansion. **********Volkswagen's move threatened to unravel what had seemed to be a done deal between BMW and Vickers P.L.C., the parent of Rolls-Royce, and set the stage for what could be an expensive and complicated battle between two companies that covet a position in the rarefied market for superluxury automobiles. **********The Volkswagen supervisory board held a special meeting this afternoon at company headquarters, and, according to German press reports, approved a broad new offer. **********The company would offer about $700 million for Rolls-Royce and another $300 million for a separate engine company owned by Vickers, the reports said. The offer also includes a promise to invest about $2.2 billion in Rolls-Royce factories and to quintuple its capacity to 10,000 cars a year from 2,000. **********Four weeks ago, after an auction in which BMW and Volkswagen offered rival bids to the manufacturer of Silver Shadows and Bentleys, Vickers announced that BMW had won with an offer of nearly $600 million for Rolls-Royce alone. BMW said it would triple capacity to 6,000 cars a year over the next several years. **********Under that agreement, Vickers pledged to negotiate exclusively with BMW over the next 30 days to reach a binding contract. That 30-day period ends next Thursday, and Volkswagen has let it be known for weeks that it was ready to fire back with a better offer. **********The intensity of the competition has astonished many experts. While the Rolls-Royce name has unparalleled allure as a synonym for luxury worthy of kings and rock stars, it remains a tiny company in the automobile industry and nearly went bankrupt more than a decade ago. **********But European car manufacturers are now in a fierce rivalry to expand into the market of super-luxury cars, automobiles with price tags of $200,000 or more. **********Mercedes-Benz is expected to launch production of a new sedan known as the Maybach, which is intended to compete with Rolls-Royce. BMW, which produces cars that sell for $50,000 and up, wants to move into the highest realm of the market and to expand it. BMW has said it would introduce two new lines of Rolls-Royce, which are expected to fall somewhere between top-of-the-line BMW's and Rolls-Royce's current line of cars. **********Volkswagen, though it originally became famous for economy cars like the Beetle, owns Audi and has steadily pushed into the ranks of more expensive and potentially more profitable cars. It recently unveiled a prototype for a high-performance sports car that would compete with the likes of Ferrari and Porsche. **********It remains unclear whether a more generous offer from Volkswagen can derail the agreement with BMW. Although BMW is not believed to have increased its original offer, despite clear signs that Volkswagen would make another offer, BMW has other advantages. **********The most important is that BMW already supplies engines to Rolls-Royce, which uses them in its newly introduced Silver Seraph. When Volkswagen hinted last month that it would sweeten its offer after the auction had closed, BMW executives warned that they would stop supplying engines if their deal fell through.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/04/busin.snippet: South Korean Government announces sweeping plan to privatize wide range of industries, including giant Pohang Iron and Steel Corp (known as Posco), world's second-largest steel producer,in hope of earning as much as $8 billion by year 2000; plan c...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/04/busin.main_headline: South Korea Announces Plans For Privatizing Its Industries
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/04/busin.print_headline: South Korea Announces Plans For Privatizing Its Industries
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/04/busin.body_text: **********The South Korean Government announced a sweeping program today for privatizing a wide range of industries, including the giant Pohang Iron and Steel Corporation. **********The Planning and Budget Commission said the Government's shares in Posco, as the steelmaker is known, and four other state-controlled companies and their subsidiaries would go on sale immediately. Another six companies would be privatized over a four-year period, with the Government hoping to earn as much as $8 billion by the year 2000. **********The announcement set off a wave of speculation about how the Government would carry out the program -- and who would be the most interested buyers. Offering no specifics, the commission chairman, Jin Nyun, said the Government would sell ''stocks and assets or issue of exchangeable bonds and depository receipts.'' The timing, he said, would be decided later ''to maximize the value of the privatized corporations.'' **********The news that the Government would sell its 26.7 percent stake in Posco, the world's second-largest steel producer after the Nippon Steel Corporation, shocked workers at the company's headquarters here. ''It's a small revolution,'' said Lee Jong Sung, an assistant manager. ''We hardly expected that.'' **********The plan calls for the Government to withdraw restrictions on individual as well as overall foreign ownership of Posco by the year 2001. The first stage of the plan calls for raising the limit on individual ownership of Posco shares from 1 percent to 3 percent while foreign ownership is held to 30 percent. **********Analysts said Posco -- founded 30 years ago as the country's single most prestigious industrial project at the height of the rule of President Park Chung Hee -- could fall under foreign control. Even now, said Hwang Ki Doo, steel industry analyst at W. I. Carr Securities, foreign investors ''could form a consortium and completely take over the company'' as soon as the stocks go on sale. Shares of Posco jumped 3.55 percent today as word spread of the impending announcement. Advisers to President Kim Dae Jung have been urging him over the last year to sell the Government's stake in Posco and other state-controlled companies. **********''It's kind of an inevitable decision,'' said Song Byung Jun, a director at the Korea Institute for Industrial Economics and Trade. ''We can make money very quickly this way.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/27/busin.snippet: Dalgety PLC says it agreed to sell its Spillers food ingredient business in two separate deals to Kerry Group PLC and E I du Pont de Nemours & Co for total of 359 million pounds ($600 million) (S)

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/27/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; British Food Company Sells Unit to 2 Buyers
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/27/busin.body_text: **********The British food company Dalgety P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Spillers food ingredients business in two separate deals to Kerry Group P.L.C. of Ireland and E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company for a total of $:359 million, or $600 million. Dalgety will sell the flour milling and food coatings operations to Kerry for $:335 million ($560 million) and the division's intellectual property rights and research to DuPont  for $:24.5 million ($41 million). **********Dalgety, whose other interests include pet foods and agricultural supplies, put the food ingredients division up for sale in September. The sale price was about $:60 million above the market's expectations, analysts said. The division has been under pressure as the global industry consolidates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/25/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Hitachi to Take $905 Million Loss for the Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/25/busin.body_text: **********Hitachi Ltd., Japan's largest maker of electronics, said today that it would take a loss of 117.5 billion yen ($905 million) for the year that ended on March 31 to write off losses incurred in restructuring its chip business and building up its pension fund. **********The Tokyo-based company expects a gain of 117.6 billion yen from sales of securities in its portfolio for the period, so the extraordinary write-off will probably have ''little effect'' on pretax profit, Hitachi said in a statement. **********About 70.5 billion yen of Hitachi's loss for the period results from the cost of restructuring its chip business, the company said. **********Hitachi will write off 34.2 billion yen to liquidate Twinstar Semiconductor Inc., an unprofitable United States affiliate that made computer memory chips. The company will book a further 23.1 billion yen charge to write down the value of equipment used to make chips, it said. **********Hitachi is also allocating 43.8 billion yen to cover unfunded pension liabilities. **********A further 3.2 billion yen is being written off from investments in subsidiaries facing difficult business conditions, Hitachi said. **********Hitachi said in February that a combination of weak domestic demand for its consumer and heavy electronics and tumbling computer memory chip prices forced it to lower its earnings forecast. **********Hitachi, founded in 1920, makes products ranging from thermal power plants and industrial robots to washing machines and air-conditioners.
