https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/03/busin.body_text: **********Now this is networking. **********The on-line bookseller Amazon.com has enrolled the 100,000th Web site for the Amazon.com Associates Program, a so-called affiliate network that pays a commission of up to 15 percent for each sale referred from a site. Members simply recommend titles at their sites and establish links that enable direct purchases from Amazon.com. **********''It expands our presence to the far corners of the Web,'' said Shawn Haynes, who runs the program for Amazon.com. The 100,000th site, signed on Thursday, was the Miami-based Careernet.com, a nationwide recruitment and job-posting service that will recommend career-guidance books to visitors. Other recently enrolled, high-profile associates include Intuit's Quicken.com, Compaq Computer, and ABCnews.com. **********Amazon.com's affiliate network is up sharply from 30,000 just last February, with much of the growth driven by the company's expansion into music CD sales. That move has attracted die-hard fans of every conceivable musical artist, affiliates who feed traffic to Amazon.com from on-line shrines to Frank Sinatra or Barenaked Ladies or David Cassidy or just about anyone else who has ever put lips to microphone. **********Mr. Haynes said the two-year-old Associates Program generated a significant minority of Amazon.com's total revenue, which topped $100 million in the second quarter. **********One of Amazon.com's closest competitors in the on-line music business, N2K Inc.'s Music Boulevard site, has renamed its 7,000-member Remote Access Music program, now simply calling it the Affiliate Program. It, too, pays other Web sites commissions of up to 15 percent for referred sales.   EVAN I. SCHWARTZ

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/05/busin.main_headline: DESPITE AN EASING OF RULES, MILLIONS EVADE 'NANNY TAX'
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/05/busin.print_headline: DESPITE AN EASING OF RULES, MILLIONS EVADE 'NANNY TAX'
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/05/busin.body_text: **********Four years ago, after President Clinton withdrew Zoe Baird's nomination to become Attorney General because she had not paid taxes on her children's nanny, Congress simplified the requirements for reporting wages paid to nannies, maids and other servants and for paying the employer's share of Social Security, Medicare and Federal unemployment taxes. **********The new law also added a line to the 1040 individual income-tax form -- line 52 -- asking for the amount of Social Security and Medicare taxes owed on wages paid to household help. Because the form is signed under penalty of perjury, people who employ household help must choose between declaring the taxes due and lying to the Government. **********The response was immediate, if not exactly what Congress had in mind: The number of people paying the tax on household help fell 40 percent, from nearly 500,000 in 1994 to just below 300,000 in 1995, the year the new law took effect, and 314,000 in 1996, and the Internal Revenue Service expects little change for 1997. **********Based on I.R.S. estimates that as many as four million people owe nanny taxes each year, that means that fewer than 1 in 13 are obeying the law, compared with 1 in 8 under the old, more cumbersome reporting system. And some people have even figured out how to combine a legal tax break for child care with tax evasion, in essence double-dipping the system. **********Of course, the main reason for the cheating is probably that it is so easy to get away with: Of the millions who have flouted the new law, only two have been charged with wrongdoing. **********''My accountant told me I have to stop this and issue paycheck stubs and report what I pay to the I.R.S.,'' said Elaine, a divorced 42-year-old mother of two who covers Hollywood for a magazine and asked that her last name not be used. ''But since no President is ever going to nominate me for the Cabinet, what do I care about paying this stupid nanny tax? And if I get caught, I'll just pay the fine and go on doing what I am doing.'' **********The spread of noncompliance among such people raises troubling questions for some about whether the foundation of the tax-collection system in the United States -- the assumption of honesty by filers -- is crumbling. **********''A culture is being created that this is fair game to do,'' said Jay A. Soled, a Rutgers University tax expert who has studied tax cheating by people who consider themselves honest. Political attacks on the current tax system as unfair only encourage people to cheat on the ground that ''this is our way of evening the playing field,'' he said, adding, ''This is a dangerous game.'' **********Dangerous or not, Elaine is probably right not to fear the wrath of the tax collector. There is no national nanny-tax enforcement effort because of a lack of staff, said Tom Burger, the I.R.S. official in charge of employment taxes. Indeed, the service has never pressed a civil case in court and has filed criminal charges only twice, both times as part of a more serious criminal prosecution. **********The law requires anyone who pays a nanny or other servant more than $1,100 this year to report those wages to the I.R.S. Assuming that only one in 13 is doing so -- and that the tax evaders spend as much on household help as the upright citizens do -- the Federal Government is losing $1.2 billion a year in Social Security and Medicare taxes. **********To be sure, some people question whether the problem is as serious as the I.R.S. contends. Michael Graetz, a Yale Law School professor and former Bush Administration tax official, said he thought the agency's estimate was inflated. And he says fewer people may be reporting because their accountants advised them that they were exempt from nanny taxes because their maid or gardener was arguably an independent contractor, not an employee. **********For those who know they are cheating, the motive is often not only to save money but also to avoid paperwork and the inevitable exasperation that comes with dealing with the tax bureaucracy. **********''The truth is that Government has not made it easier to comply,'' said Roger L. Conner, executive director of the American Alliance for Rights and Responsibilities, a Washington nonprofit group that urges people to become more involved in their local communities. ''Congress made it easier on the Federal level, but you also have to pay state taxes and pay state unemployment taxes, and if you live in one state and your nanny in another, then you are forced to master the arcana of Social Security and Federal unemployment taxes plus two state unemployment and tax systems.'' **********James Neff, a journalism professor at Ohio State University who writes books on crime, said he discovered how frustrating complying with state requirements could be after he used three nannies last summer. Together they made slightly more than $1,500, the threshold for paying quarterly state unemployment taxes, and Mr. Neff discovered that he had to cope with complex state tax forms designed for corporations, not individuals. **********Worse, even though Mr. Neff only used nannies in the summer, the state required him to file every quarter and report zero as the amount due for the other three seasons. **********In interviews, parents in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, California, Virginia and the District of Columbia reported similar difficulties dealing with state tax forms designed for corporations rather than individuals. One of their greatest frustrations was navigating through bureaucracies that they said were unresponsive or, worse, behaved as if their efforts to comply were a nuisance. **********Mr. Neff and others who pay the taxes say they do so not only out of moral duty but also because they or their spouses hold jobs that require scrupulous compliance with all laws. Mr. Neff's wife is a Federal prosecutor; Mr. Conner's organization preaches self-reliance and individual responsibility for the welfare of communities. **********Many Americans legally avoid the nanny tax by sending children to day-care centers or by hiring maid services or lawn-care companies rather than paying individuals directly. Also, maids who bring their own tools and cleaning solutions are arguably independent contractors, not employees, and thus might be exempt from the nanny tax. **********Even if an employer wants to go by the book, household servants -- many of whom are immigrants or welfare recipients, or juggling more than one job -- often accept money only under the table. **********In Central Park in New York, a nanny who was taking her charge to a playground and who identified herself only as Elena said her weekly pay included a $100 check and $260 in cash. The check allows her employers to take advantage of a tax break known as a flexible spending account in which $5,000 is deducted from their paychecks and then reimbursed when they produce canceled checks and a Social Security number for their nanny. The I.R.S. does not routinely match these payments with tax returns, however. **********Thus, they benefit twice, saving as much as $1,980 through a legal deduction and almost $1,400 more by evading their share of the nanny's Social Security and Medicare taxes. **********Michael Josephson, founder of Character Counts in Marina del Rey, Calif., which promotes ethical behavior by youngsters, said he did not even know the nanny tax existed until the Zoe Baird hearings. He said he then felt compelled to pay five years of back nanny taxes, penalties and interest. **********Mr. Josephson said he thought the Government should either enforce the nanny tax or repeal it. ''Congress needs to be thinking about this law that makes honest people feel like fools,'' he said. **********There is no move in Congress to overhaul the system at the moment, and tax specialists say they see no easy solution. But, they say, some of the more promising ideas being kicked around include making all household servants independent contractors, responsible for their own taxes; raising the threshold to $5,000 or higher from $1,100, then making a greater effort at enforcement and imposing a surtax somewhere else, perhaps a fraction of a penny on each gallon of gasoline, to cover the lost Social Security and Medicare taxes. **********Failure to pay the nanny tax can boomerang in the long run, for both parties involved. Social Security benefits are now based solely on reported wages, so household servants who never report their income can face poverty in old age unless they plan to return to countries where their needs will be met in other ways. **********They might also make life difficult for their former employers by reporting the income years later in an effort to get more Social Security money. **********Mr. Josephson recommended making nanny-tax compliance an issue in audits of all higher-income people because ''almost everyone over a certain income, especially when both of the couple work, has a maid, a nanny or both.'' **********Turning a blind eye to the problem, he added, is the worst possible way to deal with it. ''When the Government encourages systematic lying, it undermines the whole notion of voluntary compliance'' on which the tax system rests, he said. ''It has an incredibly corrosive effect on people voluntarily complying with all tax laws.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/31/busin.main_headline: Labor Costs Rose Slightly In the Spring
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/31/busin.print_headline: Labor Costs Rose Slightly In the Spring
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/31/busin.body_text: **********Despite signs that economic growth is slowing sharply, wages and benefits are climbing a bit faster than a year ago. **********The Labor Department's employment cost index -- a broad gauge of compensation trends closely watched by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and other policy makers -- rose nine-tenths of 1 percent this spring, slightly more than the seven-tenths of 1 percent increase in the winter. For the 12 months ended in June, pay for all civilian workers, including government workers, rose 3.5 percent, up from 2.8 percent in the previous year. **********The pickup in labor costs reflects one of the tightest peacetime labor markets in memory. Even as the Asian crisis, the recently settled General Motors strike and a lull in inventory additions have combined to drag down growth in recent months, unemployment is well below 5 percent, as it has been for a year, hiring plans have remained robust, and thousands of jobs in industries from high technology to hotels have gone begging. **********The acceleration in wage inflation is of the creeping, not galloping, variety: pay and benefits are rising just one percentage point faster than at the low-point for such cost increases nearly three years ago. **********As such, the latest reading is not likely to provoke Mr. Greenspan, who only a week ago reiterated how closely he watches the index, to raise interest rates. **********''We haven't moved into new territory,'' said Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist at the Fleet Financial Group in Boston. ''This report reduces the odds that the Fed will tighten.'' **********Ever since unemployment first slipped below the level that most economists regard as consistent with steady inflation, the Federal Reserve has been on the lookout for any hint that wage pressures are getting out of hand. But now that the economy seems to be slowing on its own, the modest pickup in pay may well show up in slimmer profit margins rather than in higher prices for consumers. Investors, in any case, seemed to take that view. Bond prices rose after the report's release, and the stock market closed higher ahead of today's much anticipated report on economic growth for the second quarter. **********Workers are getting a better deal than the raw numbers imply. Thanks to a minuscule 1.6 percent rise in the cost of living over the last year, relatively restrained nominal pay increases are being translated into relatively robust real gains. Real pay is up nearly 2 percent from a year ago. **********If anything, the employment cost index, though widely regarded as the broadest and most reliable gauge of employers' labor costs, may understate just how well workers are doing. It does not include one-time payments like signing bonuses and bounties, which businesses are increasingly relying on to fill vacancies without raising their entire pay structure. It also does not take account of another widespread phenomenon: promotions that are given purely to raise a worker's pay or promotions that workers give themselves by switching to better-paying jobs. One sign that these factors may add up is that another Department of Labor measure, compensation per hour, has risen about a percentage point more in the last year than the employment cost index. ''We're seeing some dramatic wage inflation'' in some job categories, says Maury Hanigan, a human resources consultant in New York. **********Wages and salaries grew nine-tenths of 1 percent, not much more than the eight-tenths of 1 percent growth in the winter. But benefit costs jumped sharply to eight-tenths of 1 percent, twice as fast as they had risen in the previous quarter. Part of the pickup in benefit costs is probably temporary; it reflects commissions and bonuses being paid on Wall Street and elsewhere in the financial industry, where compensation has risen by 7 percent from a year ago. But at least half of the benefits, including Social Security payments and vacation pay, are tied directly to wages. And one-fifth consist of health benefits, which are once again marching higher. ''Health insurance costs are picking up for the first time in three and a half years,'' said Wayne M. Shelly, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which issued the report. **********Wage pressures may not fade. Some of the forces holding down living costs are clearly temporary. As Asia struggles back, oil prices are apt to firm. And the strong dollar, which has made many imports a bargain, could weaken. **********More important, even if the economy settles down to a growth rate of 2 percent or 2.5 percent over the next year or so -- as Mr. Greenspan and other forecasters expect -- it will not be slow enough to loosen up the labor market much. ''The unemployment rate stays exactly where it is,'' Mr. Perna predicted. ''The overall degree of tightness stays exactly where it is.'' **********Two other reports made public yesterday suggest that this is the case right now. The Conference Board reported that its help-wanted advertising index rose to 91 in June  from 90 in May and 88 a year ago. And new claims for unemployment insurance dropped to 304,000 last week from 317,000 the week before, the Labor Department said. That's the lowest level since early April.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/09/world.snippet: Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin remains holed with advisers at residence outside Moscow, pondering next move after Communist-led Parliament rejected for second time Viktor S Chernomyrdin, his choice for Prime Minister; Yeltsin's silence underscores his...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/09/world.main_headline: Yeltsin's Silence Fuels Talk Of New Choices for Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/09/world.print_headline: Yeltsin's Silence Fuels Talk Of New Choices for Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/09/world.body_text: **********The big news in Russia today was what did not happen. **********After the Communist-led Parliament, in a stormy debate on Monday, again rejected Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, President Boris N. Yeltsin's  choice for Prime Minister, the President did not rush to renominate him. **********Instead, Mr. Yeltsin was holed up with his advisers at his residence just outside Moscow, pondering his hand. The silence out of Mr. Yeltsin's headquarters underscored his dilemma and nourished speculation that he was considering other candidates. **********''It is now the President's turn to have his say,'' said Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist leader. **********None of Mr. Yeltsin's choices are good. Mr. Yeltsin could press ahead with Mr. Chernomyrdin's nomination and dare the Communist-led Parliament to vote down his choice for a third time, a move that would force the dissolution of the legislature. **********That would enable Mr. Yeltsin to stand firm against the Communists, but it would turn the political battles over the last two weeks into an all-out war. The Communists warned the President today against disbanding the Parliament and trying to rule by decree, invoking the specter of huge social unrest. **********Mr. Yeltsin could settle on a compromise candidate. That would spare the nation a prolonged political squabble as the Russian economy is reeling. But that could also mean ceding influence and prestige to the Communists and perhaps backing away from market reforms. **********As the President weighed his options, the potential replacements for Mr. Chernomyrdin were piously hiding their ambition under a cloak of their humility and statesmanship. **********Yegor Stroyev, the 61-year-old leader of the upper house of the legislature, has often been mentioned as a compromise choice. A Yeltsin ally, he also serves as the head of the administration in Oryol, an agricultural area south of Moscow that tends to be pro-Communist and was the birthplace of Mr. Zyuganov. **********Today Mr. Stroyev urged Mr. Yeltsin to think long and hard before re-entering the political fray, but insisted that he had no interest in being  Prime Minister. He endorsed Yevgeny M. Primakov, the hard-line Foreign Minister whose candidacy has also been promoted by Grigory Yavlinsky, the leader of the liberal Yabloko Party. **********Mr. Primakov was not to be outdone in disclaiming any interest in higher office. This afternoon he issued a statement emphasizing how happy he was in his current job and asserting that he had not encouraged Mr. Yavlinsky to propose him as Prime Minister. **********''I cannot consent to this,'' he said. **********But the canny Foreign Minister seemed to leave the door open a crack. ''It is my consistent belief,'' he said, ''that a way must be found out of the current political crisis within the shortest possible time by means of consensus.'' **********That left the Mayor of Moscow, Yuri Luzhkov, who has been waging an entirely unsubtle campaign to position himself as a likely successor to  Mr. Yeltsin. **********Mr. Luzhkov raised eyebrows the other day by criticizing Mr. Chernomyrdin. But today he insisted that he had not talked to Mr. Yeltsin about taking Mr. Chernomyrdin's place. **********''I am already head of the Moscow government,'' he said. ''Isn't that enough?'' **********As Moscow speculated about just who might be nominated, Mr. Chernomyrdin sought to demonstrate that it was too soon to write his political obituary. **********His aides today issued a blizzard of decrees and statements intended to show that their man was on the job and in control of the situation. **********Mr. Chernomyrdin, they announced, had signed decrees on customs duties, bank policy and personnel. All told, Mr. Chernomyrdin has signed 67 resolutions and 58 directives since he was appointed Acting Prime Minister last month, his spokesman said. **********As Russia's leaders jockeyed for power, the economic collapse continued. The exchange rate slipped to 23 rubles to the dollar, a far cry from the rate of 6.2 rubles in mid-August. There was talk of postponing the last major privatization of a state oil company for lack of buyers. **********The enclave of Kaliningrad declared a state of emergency. Workers struck in the closed nuclear cities of Chelyabinsk and Arzamus over wage arrears and even picketed in front of the Atomic Energy Ministry building in Moscow. **********As the politicians caught their breath before another round of wrangling and intrigue, even they agreed that Russia would pay a heavy price for allowing the political circus to go on for too much longer. **********''It is impossible to calculate the budget in these conditions,'' said Aleksandr Zhukov, chairman of the Parliament's budget committee. ''If in the next three to four days the situation with the Prime Minister is not resolved, the economic conditions will deteriorate and it will be very difficult to get out of the economic whirlpool.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/busin.body_text: **********Usinor S.A. of France, Europe's fourth-largest steel company, said yesterday that it planned to buy private investors' shares in the Belgian steel company Cockerill Sambre S.A. on top of the majority stake in Cockerill that it agreed to buy on Wednesday from the government of Wallonia, a region of Belgium. **********Over all, Usinor is offering 37.5 billion Belgian francs ($1.1 billion) to acquire 75 percent of Cockerill. That includes a 53.77 percent stake from Wallonia for 26 billion francs ($770 million), or 152 a share, and an offer yesterday of 164 francs a share for the 21.23 percent of Cockerill shares that are publicly traded. The extra 12 francs a share is in compensation for a dividend payment the private shareholders would receive next year. Usinor also said it would have the option, in seven years, to buy Wallonia's remaining 25 percent stake.

Meriwether in 1993 that nearly collapsed last month, has laid off 33 people, or about 18 percent of its 178 employees. [C5.] **********Judge Permits a Recording Device **********A Federal judge has refused the recording industry's request to halt production of a device that can record and play back digital music found, often illegally, on the Internet. [C9.] **********Losses at 2 Japanese Concerns **********Toshiba and Hitachi reported losses for the six months ended Sept. 30, illustrating how even Japan's vaunted high-technology companies are vulnerable to its economic malaise. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/08/world.snippet: IMF economic austerity plan being imposed on Indonesia is pushing up prices and feeding rumors; villagers across vast nation warn that if prices keep rising they will protest in streets; in dozen towns over last two weeks in eastern Java, small ri...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/08/world.main_headline: Price Rises Exact a High Cost in Java
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/08/world.print_headline: Price Rises Exact a High Cost in Java
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/08/world.body_text: **********When hundreds of rough-looking men burst through the alleyways of the nearby town of Kraton two days ago, throwing stones and waving sharpened sickles, most of them came from here in Semari, a placid village of farmers and fishermen. **********''Rising prices! Rising prices!'' they shouted as they smashed a couple of windows and tried unsuccessfully to set a barrel of kerosene on fire, angered by reports that a Kraton merchant had raised prices. **********The police quickly choked off the riot, though shopkeepers had pulled down their metal shutters and retreated into back rooms. The green and blue shutters of most shops remained closed today, and the town was still tense. **********Half a mile away, Semari seemed as calm as ever. White cows grazed in its bright green pasture and sunshine sparkled from its flooded rice fields. Men smoked quietly on cool porches. Small children, seeing a foreign visitor, called out the only words of English they knew: ''One, two, three, four!'' **********Here on the far eastern tip of Indonesia's main island of Java, the political debate of the capital city of Jakarta seemed worlds away. Currency devaluations, collapsing banks and frightened stock markets are unknown concepts in Semari. No one here has heard of the International Monetary Fund, which has imposed an economic austerity program as part of a $40 billion rescue package. **********But Semari and villages like it around this vast nation of 200 million are at the heart of the crisis that threatens Indonesia's stability. And the people here know exactly why that is. **********''Let me tell you something: the problem is the price hikes,'' said Muhammad Jamil, a 37-year-old farmer. ''Our income stays the same, but prices keep going up. If the prices come down, the problems will be solved. That's the solution. Just bring down the prices.'' **********On the other hand, he said, ''If the prices keep going up, we'll protest in the streets.'' **********It is already happening up and down the coast of eastern Java, as well as in several other places. In a dozen towns over the last two weeks, small riots have broken out as the prices of rice, cooking oil, kerosene, flour and other staples have begun to rise. **********Most analysts say this is just the beginning. Government price supports are only now starting to be removed from staple items as part of the I.M.F. plan. Gasoline prices are scheduled to rise in two months. Bigger, broader and more damaging riots are feared as inflation intensifies and prices rise further. **********Indonesia is already a restive nation, held together by force for the last 32 years under President Suharto. A pervasive government apparatus offers little outlet for grievances over corruption, abusive officials, unresponsive courts, disparities in wealth and wrenching cultural changes as cities grow and new factory towns devour fertile farmland. **********''There is no rule of law,'' said Saukat Mifta, a 48-year-old businessman who lives in Kraton. ''There is no way for people to channel their frustrations. The common people feel they are ignored by the law. The Government does not respond to their complaints. So if there's a problem, they quickly become angry and they turn to violence. They don't try to understand. They just react.'' **********And so, as life becomes harsher for the farmers and fishermen here, even unfounded rumors of price rises have been enough to spark riots in places like Kraton. **********As they gathered around a visitor to shout their complaints today, the villagers of Semari were a fount of exaggerated reports of rising rices. **********''Kerosene is 1,000 rupiah a liter, can you believe it?'' they said. ''Rice is up to 2,000. Cooking oil is 6,000. Everything is up! Some say sugar is 6,000 a kilo.'' **********A woman whispered, ''Coconuts cost 200 each.'' **********These are impossible prices, said a farmer named Abdul Mukti. ''Can you imagine, just 2,000 rupiah for working all day in the fields, and then prices like that? What if you have three kids to feed?'' **********Before the Indonesian currency, the rupiah, began its steep fall last summer, 2,000 rupiah was worth about 80 cents. Today its value is closer to 20 cents. **********So on Monday morning, when word spread that a prominent Kraton trader named Nuning had raised the price of a liter of kerosene to 1,000 rupiah from 350, the people of Semari were already seething. Kerosene is a key commodity, used by many Indonesians to fuel kitchen stoves. **********''We headed into town,'' said Mr. Jamil, the farmer. **********''Raising our knives!'' shouted a young man. **********''No, no, no,'' the older men hushed him, glancing at their visitor. ''No knives. No knives.'' **********Men from another village brought two small potash bombs that are used illegally by fishermen to stun fish. One was a dud, the villagers said, but one exploded in front of the iron shutters of Mrs. Nuning's shop. (Like many Indonesians, she uses only one name.) **********''The interesting thing is that Nu ning hadn't raised her prices,'' said Mr. Saukat, whose mother-in-law owns a restaurant across the street from Mrs. Nuning's shop. ''She wasn't even open that day. She hadn't been open for five days.'' Many Indonesian shops had not yet reopened following the Muslim holiday last week that ended the holy month of Ramadan. **********But like so many of the conflicts that have produced Indonesia's crisis -- from small-town riots to questions of governmental mismanagement -- events here were driven as much by personal frictions and rivalries as by deep-rooted issues. **********''She's known as a rude person,'' Mr. Saukat said, voicing what seemed a common opinion in the nearby marketplace, where people described Mrs. Nuning as ''hardheaded'' and ''troublesome.'' Mrs. Nuning was not available to defend her reputation; she was under military guard in a local hotel. **********One local version of the Kraton riot is that a rival kerosene merchant had spread the rumor that Mrs. Nu ning had raised her prices. On a broader stage, a prominent official in eastern Java has suggested that a rival politician is fomenting riots to discredit him. **********Along with deepening poverty and spreading unemployment, the economic crisis has heightened frictions between political and economic rivals, between employers and their workers, between shopkeepers and their customers and between ethnic and religious groups. **********However the crisis plays out, everyone here seems to agree, Indonesia has become a more dangerous place. **********As in many a town in many a country, the last word today came in the Kraton market's barbershop, a tiny whitewashed room decorated with demure pinups of women wearing Muslim head scarves. **********''These price increases are incredible, incredible,'' said Dahlan, 65, a retired furniture finisher who spends his days relaxing on a small bench here. ''It's not a game anymore.'' **********His friend Suwandi, a retired military officer, agreed. ''The common people are shaken,'' he said. ''They're confused. It's going to be noisy here. People will shout. You know how young men love to shout.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/08/busin.snippet: Magazine Teen People is scheduled to hit newsstands on Jan 9, and it is something of significant departure for its publisher, Time Inc; given Time Inc's reputation as male-dominated company that has spoken mostly to adult male readers, Teen People...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/08/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Time Inc.'s Take on Teen-Agers; Yes, From the House That Luce Built, a Girls' Magazine
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/08/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Time Inc.'s Take on Teen-Agers; Yes, From the House That Luce Built, a Girls' Magazine
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/08/busin.body_text: **********Tips on the latest ''zit zapper,'' hair spray and eye shadow. His and her horoscopes. Articles such as ''Can You Really Tell If Someone's a Virgin?'' and ''Six Star Couples' Secrets for Everlasting Love.'' **********Can this magazine possibly be coming from Henry R. Luce's venerable, button-down Time Inc.? That male bastion of testosterone titles like Time, Sports Illustrated, Money and Fortune? Yes, indeed. Tomorrow, Teen People is scheduled to hit the newsstands, and it is something of a significant departure for its publisher, Time Inc. **********The monthly magazine, aimed at teen-age girls, combines the standard teen-age fare of beauty, fashion and boys with the People magazine formula that has proved so successful: articles about celebrities and entertainment, leavened with a dose of real-life issues. **********But it goes beyond the People approach into a type of service journalism that has stealthily been infiltrating the Time Inc. stable to the point that it now includes everything from In Style's celebrity living rooms to Cooking Light's high-calcium goat cheese quesadillas. **********Given Time Inc.'s reputation as a male-dominated company that has spoken mostly to adult male readers, Teen People also exemplifies the latest and perhaps most extreme example of how the company is aggressively extending its reach to new audiences: women, children, teen-agers and minorities. **********''I've always felt that women and children are underserved,'' said Ann S. Moore, the president of People, In Style, Teen People and People en Espanol. ''Marketing to women, writing to women is not something we traditionally did at Time. We had a lot of men's books, a lot of news magazines, but we didn't have a division that understood women. I think we have that expertise now.'' **********On Monday, Time Inc. will also switch People en Espanol to monthly publication (it started as a quarterly in October 1996). That magazine, aimed at a growing Hispanic market, was the fourth -- and Teen People is the fifth -- new title to grow out of People. The first was Entertainment Weekly, in 1990. That was followed by Who, an Australian version of People that started in 1992, and In Style, in 1994. **********''We approached all the projects in this division looking at them from the point of view of what readers we were missing,'' Ms. Moore said. ''We've targeted women, teens and Hispanics, and the bonus has been that we have extended the franchise into new ad categories because we've brought in new readers to the company.'' **********These spinoffs -- known as brand extensions in the marketing world -- are part of a larger strategy that has been gradually taking shape at Time Inc., a division of Time Warner and one of the nation's most prominent magazine publishers. In essence, Time Inc. hopes to trade on the strength of its established titles without diluting the core publications. ''It's been an evolution,'' said Don Logan, the chairman and chief executive of the company. ''I can assure you,'' he added, ''Time Inc. will continue to publish new titles.'' **********People, which is read mostly by women, was the first to rock the Time Inc. boat when it was introduced in 1974, prompting some to proclaim the death of the company. Richard B. Stolley, the first managing editor of People and now the senior editorial adviser of Time Inc., recalled: ''To some of the purists inside the building it seemed frivolous and a stain on the escutcheon of Time Inc. We took a fair amount of hits early on, but we survived.'' **********If Time Inc. was unfamiliar with the world of women's magazines -- an age-old formula that includes fashion, beauty, fitness, food and sex -- it has educated itself over the years through a series of start-ups and acquisitions. In 1985, the company bought Southern Progress, the Alabama company that publishes the monthlies Southern Living and Cooking Light and that recently acquired Weight Watchers and started Coastal Living, both of which are published about every other month. **********Time Inc. went on to add the monthlies Parenting, Sports Illustrated for Kids, Sunset, Baby Talk and Martha Stewart Living, which the company sold last year, although it still retains a minority interest. **********This diversification has accelerated under Mr. Logan, who came to Time Inc. as president and chief operating officer in 1992 from Southern Progress and was appointed chief executive in 1994. Under him, Time Inc. has added the weekly Time for Kids as well as This Old House and the shelter magazine Wallpaper, both of which will be published eight times this year, and the monthlies In Style, People en Espanol and, now, Teen People. **********In addition, five years ago, Time Inc. began managing American Express's titles, including the monthlies Food and Wine and Travel and Leisure, and Departures, a magazine for platinum-card holders that is published every other month. **********Teen People ''makes Time Inc. a different-looking company than has been the popular perception,'' said Norman Pearlstine, the editor in chief of Time Inc. ''But it is not as much a duck out of water as you might otherwise think.'' **********Still, some women's titles have proved easier than others. The company has yet to give the green light to Sports Illustrated Women/Sport, which had two test issues last year. Mr. Logan said: ''We're not in any big hurry to bring that magazine to market. It's a little more complicated than some of our people thought.'' **********While Teen People's photo spreads featuring platform sneakers and advertisements for plastic tampons may be new to the company, the magazine In Style paved the way for hard-core fashion and beauty coverage. ''I hired the first-ever beauty editor at Time Inc.,'' said Martha Nelson, the managing editor. ''When we launched the magazine, we used to say that Henry Luce would be spinning in his grave because we published a horoscope.'' **********As a result, though Teen People might have once been an intolerable shock to the Time Inc. system, these days even the company's old-timers see it as business as usual. **********''There is real logic in applying the People concept to a magazine aimed at that audience,'' said Henry Muller, the editorial director at Time Inc., who has been at the company since 1970. ''Time Inc., in many people's minds, still conveys an image that is a quarter of a century out of date.'' **********For one thing, the demographics argue strongly for an entry into the teen-age market. The nation's teen-age population is projected to grow to 34 million from 29 million by 2010 and now accounts for about $122 billion in consumer spending. **********More simply, Time Inc.'s brand-extension strategy is paying off. Mr. Logan estimated 1997 earnings in the range of $600 million on revenue of $4.4 billion to $4.5 billion, up from $530 million in 1996 on revenue of $4.1 billion. Even Time Warner's stock price is finally looking up, having reached a 52-week high of $62 at the end of last year -- up from a low of $36.375 in January 1997. Yesterday it closed at $61.9375, up $1.625. **********Nevertheless, Teen People still sticks out a bit in the Time Inc. culture. The magazine's executives say their fashion closet -- where clothes are stored for coming photo assignments -- has become something of a curiosity at the company. **********''The management team knows nothing about fashion,'' said Nora McAniff, the publisher of Teen People and People. ''If Mel Gibson walked in the room, I don't think Don Logan would know who he was. Now we're talking to him about Puff Daddy,'' the rap star. **********Moreover, this venture is perhaps a riskier one because Teen People is entering a crowded, intensely competitive market and because Time Inc. has gone down this road before. In 1994, it unsuccessfully tested the teen-age magazine Mouth 2 Mouth, a venture that joined a graveyard already crowded with the failed teen-age titles Tell, which was published by Hachette Filipacchi and NBC, and Quake, a venture of Welsh Publishing Group and Cowles Magazines. **********More recently, the teen magazine Sassy closed and was merged into Teen by Petersen Publishing, which owned both. **********Nevertheless, the teen-age market has grown increasingly strong, and Teen People will jockey for newsstand attention with such heavyweights as Primedia's Seventeen (circulation 2.5 million), Gruner & Jahr's YM (2.1 million) and Petersen's Teen (1.7 million). **********Two new publications entered the field last year: Jump, published by Weider Publications, and Twist, published by the German company Bauer Publishing. A teen-age title called Glossy, which will appear every other month, is due to start this month, an outgrowth of the teen-age Webzine glossy.com., owned by Attitude Network Ltd. **********Publishers of established teen-age titles say they welcome new competition and do not view the new Time Inc. entry as a threat. ''It's narrower than our magazine,'' said John Heins, president and chief executive of YM's publisher. ''The People name does not mean beauty; the People name does not mean fashion.'' **********Indeed, because Time Inc. is new to the traditional teen-age categories, some magazine experts wonder whether it will be able to compete with the big guns. ''Time is going to have a lot of problems doing the kind of synergistic editorial that fashion and beauty advertisers want,'' said Martin Walker, a New York magazine consultant. ''In most teen magazines, the editorial is really about your advertisers' products. That's not what Time Inc. does; they do news magazines, and the advertisers come in to reach the audience.'' **********But Teen People -- which is guaranteeing advertisers a circulation of 500,000 -- maintains that there is a place in the market for something new. ''We will leave the boy-crazy niche to the ones who are already filling it very nicely,'' Ms. Moore said. '' We only win if we can deliver something different.'' **********Christina Ferrari, Teen People's managing editor, said the magazine would not use professional models and would feature teen-agers in a range of shapes, sizes and races. ''We decided we're going to go all the way,'' said Ms. Ferrari, who spent two years as executive editor at YM and one year as editor in chief. ''Teen-agers need images that reflect who they really are and what they really look like.'' **********While most teen-age magazines focus on fashion and beauty, Teen People will devote a third of its editorial space to celebrities and another third to articles about ''real'' issues, such as eating disorders and college drinking. And though Teen People -- which calls itself the first magazine to start simultaneously on the World Wide Web -- expects to be read mostly by young women, it also hopes young men will make up about 15 percent of the audience. **********Perhaps the most distinguishing feature about the new magazine is that it has behind it People (which folks at Time Inc. have now taken to calling Big People). **********By Time Inc.'s figures, five million teen-agers already read People. With a circulation of 3.5 million and ad pages that have steadily increased, People has become Time Inc.'s showpiece, leading the Cappell Circulation Report's 1997 list of most impressive performers. **********People spinoffs have exceeded Time Inc.'s financial expectations -- In Style became profitable last year, about three years in advance of initial projections, and Entertainment Weekly achieved profitability in 1996, a year ahead of schedule. Mr. Logan said he expected Teen People to turn a profit in three to four years. **********That is why the editors finally decided it would be foolish not to make the People connection loud and clear, even though Time Inc. considered other names for the magazine such as The Mix and 411. (Petersen Publishing is suing Time Inc. for using the word Teen.) **********It is also why Teen People will look and sound a lot like People, including teen-age versions of popular People columns such as Star Tracks (celebrity photos) and Style Watch (celebrity fashion). **********''They've locked on the strength of the People franchise,'' said Roberta Garfinkle, the director of print media at the McCann-Erickson ad agency. ''There are enough similarities so that you know you're reading People and enough differences so you're not confused.'' **********Nevertheless, a teen-age girl trolling for lip gloss advice will not be disappointed. The magazine devotes the final third of its editorial space to clothes, makeup and hair. **********''There is a balance between service and journalism and education and so forth, and it seems to me the balance is right,'' said Mr. Pearlstine, Time Inc.'s editor in chief. ''The idea of doing a magazine for teens that denies the importance of appearance doesn't make a lot of sense to me. If you want to do Ms. magazine for teens, be my guest.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/18/busin.body_text: **********3 Ex-Archer Executives Convicted of Fixing Prices **********Three former executives of Archer Daniels Midland -- including the son of its powerful chairman, Dwayne Andreas -- were found guilty of engaging in an international conspiracy to fix the prices of a widely used additive for animal feed. **********The verdict by a Federal jury in Chicago marked an important victory for prosecutors and capped a six-year effort by the Government to crack an illegal cartel and to bring participants in the conspiracy to trial. The investigation and trial have been declared hallmarks by the Government, which said it upended a conspiracy that controlled the prices of $1 billion in commerce. [Page A1.] **********$3.4 Billion Approved for I.M.F. **********The House approved only $3.4 billion of the $18 billion that President Clinton is seeking for the International Monetary Fund. The action left the agency in limbo as its reserves dwindle and economic crises mount around the world. The Senate has approved the full amount, and there is still a chance that when both houses meet over the next few weeks to iron out their differences they will agree to provide the full request. [C2.] **********Bond Yields Continue Their Slide **********Treasury bond prices rallied as investors sold stocks and sought the safety of Government securities. The yield on the 30-year bond dropped to 5.18 percent, from 5.22 percent on Wednesday, its lowest level in 30 years. In the last three months the 30-year bond's yield has fallen more than half a percentage point. [C5.] **********Bayer to Acquire Unit of Chiron **********Bayer, the German drug and chemical giant, will buy the American diagnostics business of Chiron for $1.1 billion and 50 percent of the farm seed subsidiary of Crompton & Knowles. Bayer also said it would raise money for reorganization by selling to the public up to 75 percent of its Agfa-Gevaert unit. [C16.] **********Amendment Slows Spending Bill **********A proposal to make it easier for farmers to hire foreigners, most from Mexico, at harvest time is clouding prospects for Congressional approval of a spending bill for the Commerce, Justice and State Departments. [A20.] **********House Panel Passes Tax Cut Bill **********The House Ways and Means Committee passed an $80 billion Republican tax cut, setting up a confrontation with President Clinton. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/04/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; Prices Close on Downside, With Dow Retreating 87.44
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Resilient concerns about weakness in the technology sector pushed stocks lower yesterday, with the Nasdaq composite index falling more than 1 percent. **********The drops in technology shares contributed to a late-day selling spree that spread across the market. It was worsened by a wave of computer-generated sell programs, which erased a small gain in the Dow Jones industrial average and left it with a loss of more than 87 points. **********The Intel Corporation, the bellwether semiconductor issue, led the declines among technology issues. It fell 3 5/16, to 65 15/16, its lowest level since April 1997. **********The stock came under pressure after a research analyst, Robert Chaplinsky of the Hambrecht & Quist Group, lowered his second-quarter earnings estimate due to expectations of slowing sales abroad. **********A rumor that Intel would warn that April-June earnings could disappoint -- coming in at 65 cents a share compared with the 70 cents widely forecast -- contributed to the decline. **********Intel's problems illustrated investors' persistent concerns about the technology sector. Worries about the impact of Asia's financial crisis on earnings as well as dampening domestic consumer demand have pressured chip makers, computer companies such as Dell Computer and software companies such as Hewlett-Packard. **********Investors are worried that disappointing earnings from technology shares, which have been among the leaders of the current rally, could signal similar declines in other sectors, said Anthony Conroy, a managing director for Bankers Trust Global Investment Management in New York. Such concerns have heightened investors' unwillingness to buy stocks, continuing a recent trend in which early market gains evaporate into declines by the day's end. **********''It's still a kind of skittish market and there's no real trend,'' said Charles W. Washington, head equity trader for Blaylock & Partners in Baltimore. **********''The market is not capitalizing on the good news,'' said William E. Barker Jr., chief investment strategist at Dain Rauscher. He noted that recent planned merger deals such as Tellabs purchase of Ciena and American Home Products' joining with Monsanto had failed to excite investors and cause strong gains in those stocks. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which traded higher briefly during the day, closed down 87.44 points. One sell program during the last 40 minutes of trading took 80 points off the blue-chip index, according to to Birinyi Associates, a Greenwich, Conn., research firm. **********The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 10.49 points and the Nasdaq plunged 19.48 points, to 1,742.31, a 1.11 percent decline. **********However, the long-term sentiment remains bullish with analysts like Goldman, Sachs's Abby Joseph Cohen forecasting that earnings growth will resume later in the year and propel stock prices higher. **********Stocks are currently priced at fair value, Mrs. Cohen said in a recent market comment. The current climate of low interest rates and attractive fundamentals, such as the Federal budget surplus, well-managed corporations and solid financial institutions will be the catalysts to push prices higher, she said. **********And investors like Mr. Barker and Alan Bond, chief investment officer at Bond Procope Capital Management, said they were ready to pick up stocks like Intel if their prices continued to fall. **********''Intel looks pretty cheap here,'' said Mr. Bond, who recently sold some shares of the stock at a price above $80 a share. **********''I would be a buyer on weakness, but I would make darn sure the company has visible earnings growth and a reasonable valuation,'' Mr. Barker said.                     -------------------- **********Treasury Prices Gain **********By Bloomberg News **********Treasury prices rose yesterday in slow trading as investors were reluctant to buy before tomorrow's report on May employment, which is expected to show the economy is strong. **********The price of the 30-year bond rose 6/32, to 104 29/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.78 percent, from 5.79 percent on Tuesday. **********''We're in a wait-and-see mode,'' said David Johnson, who helps manage about $30 billion in bonds at Van Kampen Capital Management in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill. Concern ''that we may be running out of workers,'' may make the Federal Reserve more likely to increase interest rates, he said. **********The report will probably show the jobless rate stayed near a 28-year low in May, economists said. **********Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the labor market was ''remarkably resilient'' at a private meeting yesterday with central bank chiefs from Germany, France, Britain and Austria, according to a banker who heard his remarks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/05/busin.snippet: Allied Signal, maker of aerospace automotive products, says it is starting $9.8 billion unsolicited offer for AMP Inc, a 55 percent premium over closing price on Aug 3 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/05/busin.main_headline: Allied Signal In $9.8 Billion Hostile Bid In Electronics
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/05/busin.print_headline: Allied Signal In $9.8 Billion Hostile Bid In Electronics
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/05/busin.body_text: **********Allied Signal, a maker of aerospace and automotive products, announced yesterday that it was starting a $9.8 billion unsolicited offer for AMP Inc., a 55 percent premium over Monday's closing price. **********The offer, $44.50 a share in cash, will begin in five days if management of AMP, a maker of electronics connectors, does not agree to sit down and discuss a deal on friendly terms, said Allied's chairman and chief executive, Larry Bossidy. **********Mr. Bossidy said he had made several attempts in the last week to discuss a deal with AMP management, including two phone calls and a letter. The move has been approved by Allied Signal's board. **********Shares in AMP rose $13.9375 after the 3:30 P.M. announcement to close at $42.5625. Shares of Allied closed down $3.5625, to $40. **********AMP said that it was referring the offer to its board, but that it was urging shareholders not to take any action until the board reviewed its offer. **********AMP, based in Harrisburg, Pa., has been struggling lately, making it an attractive target for Allied Signal, which is based in Morris Township, N.J. **********In July, AMP said it was closing a Pennsylvania plant and would cut 3,000 jobs in the next two years, a result of the weak economy in Asia. That region accounted for 20 percent of AMP 1997 sales. The company has 48,300 workers in 53 companies, another attractive element for Allied. **********For the most part, Wall Street analysts said a deal made sense, assuming that Mr. Bossidy and his team from Allied Signal could change the way AMP operates. **********''From what we are beginning to learn about AMP, it is a nice, undermanaged company,'' said Phua K. Young, an analyst with Lehman Brothers. ''With a strong management team, a combination with Allied Signal could lead to some nice synergies.'' **********Allied Signal's offer, if accepted, would dilute Allied earnings by 27 cents a share, said Mr. Bossidy. It would be financed by the sale of $2 billion worth of Allied assets -- some analysts suggested in the automotive business -- as well as a $1.5 billion equity offering. That would offset the dilution, he said, and 1999 earnings of the combined companies would rise 13 to 17 percent. He added that the combination would generate cash flow of $200 million in 1999, $300 million in 2000 and an additional $100 million in 2001. **********Analysts attending a meeting with Allied executives were skeptical of Mr. Bossidy's projections, particularly because his team had not inspected AMP's books. **********''This strikes me as a kind of 'trust me in 2000 and 2001,' '' one analyst said. ''What is your competence on these numbers?'' Mr. Bossidy replied, ''I don't think we have any rose-colored glasses.'' He later added, ''It will be difficult.'' **********Allied may also face difficulties with its hostile offer because Pennsylvania has some of the toughest anti-takeover laws in the country. **********As a defensive measure, Allied filed a suit in a Federal District Court in Pennsylvania in an attempt to insure that investors would not be denied the opportunity to consider the offer. **********Still, analysts agreed that the rich offer would put pressure on AMP's management to consider the bid carefully. **********''Part of the reason the premium is as big as it is is to get AMP shareholders in line,'' Mr. Young, the Lehman Brothers analyst said. ''If AMP management can't do as much as Allied Signal to get the stock price up, they run the risk of getting sued,'' by shareholders. **********Eli Lustgarten, an analyst with Schroder & Company, said that Allied was seeking out AMP as an addition to what he said was a growing stable of high-growth and high-margin businesses. ''AMP is a dominant company in a niche that has seen its market position and profitability eroded fairly considerably,'' he said. ''But with a little bit of management smarts you can hopefully reinvigorate the company.'' **********Mr. Lustgarten said that by going after AMP, Mr. Bossidy was seeking to reinvigorate the company's growth early in the next century. ''With aerospace likely to slow, you can begin to raise questions about where they would turn for faster growth,'' he said. ''This is pretty well thought out.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/03/busin.snippet: Bell Atlantic Corp, which agreed to new contract with its unionized workers only weeks ago, extends voluntary buyout offer to some of its management employees; Bell Atlantic executive says involuntary layoffs might be necessary if voluntary progra...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/03/busin.main_headline: Voluntary Buyout Offer Extended by Bell Atlantic
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/03/busin.print_headline: Voluntary Buyout Offer Extended by Bell Atlantic
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/03/busin.body_text: **********Only weeks after agreeing to a new contract with its unionized workers, the Bell Atlantic Corporation has extended a voluntary buyout offer to some of its management employees. **********In an internal message dated Tuesday, one senior Bell Atlantic executive said that involuntary layoffs might become necessary later this year if the voluntary program did  not attract enough employees. **********A spokeswoman for Bell Atlantic, the nation's largest local telephone company, said there was no plan to cut jobs across the company. Instead, she said, some departments were offering the buyouts to cut their work force in an effort to meet existing financial targets. **********''This is not a massive effort to lay off 20,000 people,'' said Susan Kraus, the spokeswoman. ''There was a top-down effort to get everyone to meet their budget targets. **********''This is all within the normal course of business. We continually look at ways to streamline and adjust our force.'' **********About 47,000 of Bell Atlantic's 142,000 employees are not unionized. It was unclear yesterday how many of those management employees would be eligible for buyout programs and how many jobs the company planned to cut. Last night, Ms. Kraus said it was unclear how many of the company's departments had recently started buyout programs. **********But in a printed message dated Tuesday to ''all management employees'' in the finance group for the unit that runs the company's communications network and the unit that sells communications services, Doreen A. Toben, the units' chief financial officer, said the buyout applied to ''all director level and below management employees in my organization with limited exceptions.'' **********''No cap will be placed on the number of employees who will be allowed to accept the offer,'' her memo said, adding that the buyout plan was necessary to help her department meet a goal of reducing costs by 10 percent. **********Referring to the voluntary buyout plan, called the ''force management program,'' the message said, ''If a sufficient number of employees do not take advantage of the F.M.P. offer, an involuntary reduction in force (R.I.F.) may be required later in the year.'' **********According to the memo, employees will have until Oct. 14 to accept the offer, and those who join the program will be released from the company's payroll as of Oct. 16. **********In a voice-mail message early this week to ''all business marketing personnel,'' Ron Rothenbach, a vice president for marketing to business customers, suggested that major parts of Bell Atlantic might feel pressure to cut jobs. **********Referring to his boss, Bruce Gordon, the group president for retail marketing, Mr. Rothenbach said, ''I do have additional head-count challenges, challenges that have been leveled against the entire Gordon organization, and therefore, of course, mine.'' **********''We've grown from 1.5 percent to 3 percent in revenues,'' Mr. Rothenbach said, referring to his department's annual growth targets. ''We're still not making the revenue targets of 4.4 percent and as a result need to downsize so that the corporation can stay financially viable and be able to compete in the marketplace.'' **********Ms. Kraus said that Mr. Rothenbach was speaking for himself and not for the corporation as a whole. **********''One of the major benefits contemplated in the merger of Bell Atlantic and Nynex was the ability to eliminate certain duplication in employees, and some force reduction is not therefore a surprise,'' said Eric Strumingher, a telecommunications analyst at Paine Webber. ''However, if it is true that revenue targets are coming below expectations this would by definition not have been anticipated and potentially suggests some other issues at work, potentially the effects of competition.'' **********Ms. Kraus did not estimate the size of Mr. Rothenbach's department. She said that Ms. Toben's finance organization had between 500 and 600 management employees. **********In his message, Mr. Rothenbach said he planned to come up with a more detailed buyout plan for his department by the end of the month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/02/busin.snippet: Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan, parrying rare wave of criticism, defends central bank's role in averting collapse of Long-Term Capital Management LP, saying it acted out of concern for stability of financial markets rather than a desire to as...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/02/busin.main_headline: FED CHIEF DEFENDS U.S. ROLE IN SAVING GIANT HEDGE FUND
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/02/busin.print_headline: FALLEN STAR: THE REGULATORS; FED CHIEF DEFENDS U.S. ROLE IN SAVING GIANT HEDGE FUND
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/02/busin.body_text: **********Parrying a rare wave of criticism, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, defended the central bank's role in averting the collapse of Long-Term Capital Management L.P. today, saying that it had acted out of concern for the stability of the financial markets rather than a desire to assist the investment firm's wealthy owners. **********Appearing before the House Banking Committee with William J. McDonough, the president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, Mr. Greenspan built a case that it was the central bank's responsibility to play a role in addressing a crisis whose effects could extend far beyond the fate of Long-Term Capital's owners, investors and lenders. **********''Financial market participants were already unsettled by recent global events,'' Mr. Greenspan said, referring to the spread into Russia and Latin America of the financial crisis that began last year in Asia. **********''Had the failure of L.T.C.M. triggered the seizing up of markets, substantial damage could have been inflicted on many market participants, including some not directly involved in the firm, and could have potentially impaired the economies of many nations, including our own,'' he said. [Excerpts, page C3.] **********Mr. Greenspan is usually heaped with praise for his stewardship of the economy when he appears before Congress, and the world has increasingly looked to him for leadership in containing the spreading financial crisis. But today, two days after the Fed cut interest rates in an effort to insulate the United States from that turmoil, Mr. Greenspan offered no words to reassure the markets, which fell sharply in another bout of selling. [Page C1.] **********Instead, Mr. Greenspan sat through a four-and-a-half-hour hearing in which he heard respectful but nonetheless pointed questions and doubts from members of both parties about the Federal Reserve's involvement in saving a risky investment fund that catered to the wealthy. **********Lawmakers expressed considerable reservations about the Federal Reserve's decision to use its influence to buy some time for Long-Term Capital last week by helping to arrange a $3.6 billion rescue package from a group of big banks and investment houses. **********They also asked whether the Federal Reserve and other regulators should do more to regulate hedge funds, which often make high-risk bets on the direction of stocks, bonds and exotic securities. They are structured in ways that enable them to largely avoid disclosure requirements that apply to brokerage firms, banks and other financial businesses. **********Representative Spencer T. Bachus 3d, Republican of Alabama, said the message from Washington to welfare mothers and small businesses had been ''that it's not the job of the Federal Government to rescue you.'' **********The same message, he said, ''ought to also apply to rich Greenwich, Conn., investors who are multimillionaires, that we ought to use the same standards that we've used on the welfare mothers on these large hedge funds.'' **********Representative Bruce F. Vento, Democrat of Minnesota, said there seemed to be a gap between free-market theory and policy makers' decisions. **********''We hear a lot of speeches about free enterprise and the marketplace, but a lot of folks don't like to practice it,'' he said. ''The problem we have as representing our constituencies is that there seem to be two rules, a double standard: one for Main Street and another one for Wall Street.'' **********Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who is the committee's chairman, said the structure of the rescue engineered by the Federal Reserve raised antitrust concerns. He also questioned whether it had undermined a separate offer from a group including Warren E. Buffett, the multibillionaire investor, and Goldman, Sachs & Company. The terms of that offer were reportedly less attractive to Long-Term Capital's owners, including its founder, John W. Meriwether, than the deal later struck by the group assembled by the Fed. **********''Perhaps the only smart deal of the month that Long-Term Capital did was they played the Fed off against another party,'' Mr. Leach said. **********Other members seemed to be searching in frustration for ways to contain the risks posed by a small number of investment firms operating outside the regulatory system. **********''I hope that we are going to be comforted that the regulators do now, in fact, have plans in place that would help avert such unfortunate circumstances in our future,'' said Representative Richard H. Baker, Republican of Louisiana. **********Mr. Greenspan, however, stuck to his position that it would be difficult or even counterproductive to impose more direct regulation on hedge funds. Regulating the funds, Mr. Greenspan said, would drive them to operate from other nations with looser regulations, undermining the ability of the United States to monitor them even indirectly through their lenders and investors. **********The best way to rein in gambling by those firms, Mr. Greenspan said, is to encourage their lenders to assess rigorously the risks they are taking and deny credit to those whose bets become unwise. In that way, he said, banking supervisors and other regulators can act as a second line of defense by pushing lenders to make sure their risk assessments are adequate. **********Under questioning from members of the panel, Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that same approach had failed in the case of Long-Term Capital Management. **********But he said that such failures were inevitable in markets, that he had been surprised at how few had occurred in the last five years and that he expected more of them in the future. Moreover, he said, if the financial system is unwilling to assume risks, the economy's ability to grow will be impaired. **********''Let's not presume that the ideal outcome is more regulation,'' Mr. Greenspan said. **********Under pressure from members of the committee to explain why Long-Term Capital's troubles justified help from the Fed in arranging a rescue plan, Mr. Greenspan and Mr. McDonough said no taxpayer money was used and that the case should not be seen as a precedent for future intervention by the Fed in the marketplace. **********Indeed, they said, although the Fed brought all the players together, the deal that emerged stripped Long-Term Capital's owners of all but 10 percent of their stakes. **********In the long run, Mr. Greenspan said, the plan ''may well work to reduce the ultimate losses to the original owners of L.T.C.M., but that was a byproduct, perhaps unfortunate, of the process.'' **********He acknowledged, however, that the case raised questions about what economists call moral hazard -- the idea that rescuing investors from a bet gone bad encourages further overly risky bets. **********But wiping out investors through a forced liquidation of the sort that Long-Term Capital faced would have made investors perhaps too frightened to take risks, Mr. Greenspan said, hurting the economy's ability to grow. As a result, he suggested, it is appropriate to intervene in the markets to stem potential panic. **********''Risk-taking is a necessary condition for wealth creation,'' he said. ''The optimum degree of risk aversion should be governed by rational judgments about the marketplace, not the fear flowing from fire sales.'' **********Representative Maurice Hinchey, Democrat of New York, pressed Mr. Greenspan on his opposition to further regulation of exotic securities called derivatives, which are essentially bets on the direction of stocks, bonds, currencies and interest rates. **********Mr. Greenspan replied that the ''degree of supervision and regulation of the over-the-counter derivatives market is quite adequate to maintain a degree of stability in the system.'' He supported language in a spending bill now before Congress that would postpone efforts by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to develop tighter regulations on derivatives. **********But Brooksley Born, the chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, later told the committee that not requiring more disclosure from banks and investment firms of their derivatives positions could imperil market stability.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/world.snippet: Prime Min Romano Prodi's center-left government loses confidence vote, 313-312, suggesting return to chronic political instability in Italy; Prodi resigns but will remain in charge as caretaker until new government is formed; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/world.main_headline: Italy's Center-Left Government Is Toppled by One Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/world.print_headline: Italy's Center-Left Government Is Toppled by One Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/world.body_text: **********By only one vote, the center-left Prime Minister of Italy, Romano Prodi, lost a confidence vote in Parliament today and was toppled from power. **********The collapse of his Government after two and a half years, the second-longest tenure since World War II, suggested that the chronic political instability that marked Italy for decades had sprung back to life. **********Though obliged to tender his resignation, Mr. Prodi will remain in charge as a caretaker Prime Minister until a new government is formed. He may get a second chance to form a new majority, but even if he does, negotiations to that end could take days and even weeks, clouding decisions on such urgent issues as the crisis in Kosovo. **********NATO military planners preparing for possible air strikes against Yugoslavia had expected to use key air bases in Italy. In his weakened position, Mr. Prodi will have difficulty persuading Parliament to approve NATO strikes. He will have similar problems passing the 1999 budget, which is necessary before Italy can cut its lending rates, a requirement for joining the single European monetary unit, the euro, on Jan. 1. **********Immediately after today's vote of 313 to 312, in a tense and at times raucous session, Mr. Prodi met with President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro to submit his resignation and discuss his options. In the coming days Mr. Scalfaro will consult with dozens of other leaders to ascertain whether Mr. Prodi has enough lingering support to try to form a new government. If not, the President is expected to turn to another political leader. **********If no compromise is found, Italy could be plunged into early elections. But parties of all political stripes may be reluctant to push things that far, for opinion polls suggest that voters are no more enamored of the center-right opposition parties than they are of the governing majority. **********Mr. Prodi, an economist, is admired by his Western allies as a down-to-earth leader who vowed to tame Italy's bloated economy and reckless government borrowing and actually lived up to his pledge. By raising taxes, lowering interest rates and reducing the deficit, Italy met the requirements for membership in the euro last spring, a feat that only a year before was considered impossible by German and French economists. **********Mr. Prodi was helped by a healthy global economy and a rare consensus among industrialists, labor unions and taxpayers, who feared that exclusion from the euro would condemn Italy to third-world status. **********But his fiscal discipline was not followed by reform of a political system that is inherently fragile. There are more than 40 parties in Italy, and the Government's efforts to amend the Constitution to introduce a two-party system failed. **********''Unless the Italian political system changes, Italy is condemned to political instability,'' said Sergio Romano, a former diplomat and political science professor. ''The country needs stability and credibility, and that will never happen as long as the government is hanging from a thread.'' **********In 1996 Mr. Prodi won with a patchwork quilt of center-left factions mostly made up of Catholic moderates and leftists. He relied on a fringe Marxist group, the Communist Refounding Party, for a majority in the lower house. And that alliance, fragile from the beginning, finally frayed to the breaking point this week. The hard-line leader of Communist Refounding, Fausto Bertinotti, said his party would vote against the 1999 budget and would also end its 28-month-old pact with the center-left coalition. **********That position drove the moderate wing of Communist Refounding, worried that a vote against Mr. Prodi would open the doors to a center-right government, to split away. But the 20-odd deputies who defied Mr. Bertinotti were not enough to squeeze Mr. Prodi through. **********''I am not bitter,'' Mr. Prodi said moments after his defeat. ''Even today I received a lot of support.'' **********In the end the coup de grace was delivered by one of his own, a member of the coalition. ''They have won by the treachery of one single person,'' Sergio Mattarella, a deputy in Mr. Prodi's coalition, angrily told reporters, referring to Silvio Liotta, a member of the Italian Renewal Party. Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini, who heads that party, said Mr. Liotta would be expelled. **********Mr. Prodi has often said he would not govern with any other majority than the center-left one that elected him in 1996. But throughout his tenure, he was forced to seek temporary alliances to push through major policy decisions. **********He struggled to the last to try to keep his original majority intact. On Thursday, in an effort to woo more moderate Communists to his side, the Prime Minister, a staunch ally of the United States, warned that he would oppose a NATO strike aimed at stopping Serbian violence in Kosovo unless the United Nations Security Council approved the attack. Washington maintains that NATO does not need a new United Nations resolution to order a strike.
