https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/15/world.snippet: Human Rights Watch/Americas catalogues five-day seige of Mapiripan, Colombia, by right-wing paramilitary troops in July 1997 and dozens of other abuses; says Mapiripan operation, which involved connivance of army officers, was singular in its size...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/15/world.main_headline: Rights Report Blames Paramilitary Forces in Colombia Violence
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/15/world.print_headline: Rights Report Blames Paramilitary Forces in Colombia Violence
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/15/world.body_text: **********Gruesome and dependent on the connivance of army officers as it was, the ravaging of the town of Mapiripan was singular just in the size of the operation and the logistics involved, a report by a human rights group says. **********Right-wing paramilitary troops arrived on a charter flight at San Jose del Guaviare airport, which shares an airstrip with an American-financed anti-narcotics base. **********Colombian soldiers usually record the arrivals. But that day they waved the visitors through, the report, by Human Rights Watch/Americas, says. **********The study catalogues the massacre at Mapiripan, in July 1997, and dozens of other incidents. After having passed several checkpoints unimpeded, the paramilitary forces reached Mapiripan, torturing and killing at least 14 peasants accused of organizing protests against the aerial spraying of drug crops, witnesses told Government investigators. **********Two men were decapitated, their heads kicked like soccer balls down the street, the report says. The body of another was hanged and quartered. A local judge who called the military base and police station at San Jose eight times for help during the five-day siege was ignored. **********Soon after the action residents fled, joining 1.2 million refugees from the longest-running guerrilla war in Latin America. The wide-ranging report issued here says the violence once largely committed by the military has been taken over by right-wing paramilitary forces. But the ties between the two are so close that they may as well be one, the report says. **********''Although the Government and Colombia's military leaders deny that they promote or even tolerate paramilitaries, abundant evidence is consistent and terrifying,'' said the 222-page report, which was issued here a few days ago. **********Two civilians and two army officers have been arrested for the massacre, though witnesses said 200 people carried out the attack. **********The report also details torture, murder and mutilation by the three leftist rebel groups that are fighting. Like the military and the paramilitary forces, the rebels unilaterally designate civilians as ''military objectives,'' the report said, and commit most kidnappings. Last year the conflict killed 2,183 people, including rebels, soldiers and civilians. **********The report was issued as the United States kick-starts military aid,  which it cut severely in 1994 over human rights concerns, and as a new President, Andres Pastrana, prepares for talks with the rebels. **********The chief of military forces, Gen. Fernando Tapias, said that the military had no policy of violating human rights and that it was committed to prosecuting cases of collusion with paramilitary forces. **********The human rights report details many examples of army connivance with paramilitary death squads and of top army commanders, including Gen. Manuel Jose Bonett, former chief of the combined armed forces, thwarting investigations. **********--------------------        Legislators Invite Rebels to Speak **********RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 14 -- Colombia's Senate voted unanimously today to invite chiefs of two rebel groups to address legislators. **********Colombia's new President, Andres Pastrana, has vowed to begin talks next month with the main rebel faction that has been fighting the Government for three decades. **********Acceptance of the invitation, at least by rebel chiefs who are still at large, appeared unlikely.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/06/busin.snippet: Forbes is running what it intends as humorous new ad campaign; but some editors and writers at magazine are not laughing; campaign, designed by Merkley Newman Harty, features tag line 'Fearless writers. Tireless editors. Business reporting as toug...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/06/busin.main_headline: A campaign for Forbes raises some internal hackles.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/06/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; A campaign for Forbes raises some internal hackles.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/06/busin.body_text: **********FORBES is running what it intends as a humorous new ad campaign. But some editors and writers at the magazine aren't laughing. **********Designed by Merkley Newman Harty in New York, part of Omnicom Group, the campaign features the tag line ''Fearless writers. Tireless editors. Business reporting as tough as business itself.'' **********The campaign is meant to point up the notorious comments often scribbled in the margins of Forbes's articles in progress, some of the most scathing of which have been known to come from James W. Michaels, the magazine's top editor. **********Each ad cites an article on which the comment presumably appeared. For example, one ad reads, in part: **********''congratulations!this is a masterful job of interviewing an interesting and colorful man and getting precisely one quote. CALL HIM AGAIN!!!!!! -- Editor's comment on draft #1, 'World-class Sprint-er,' 2/23/98'' **********The problem, some editors say, is that the comment was not made on that piece, nor did any of the other comments featured in the advertisements actually appear on the articles indicated -- they appeared on other pieces, some of which were several years old. **********''As an editor, I have never written a comment like that to anybody, and I never got that comment on any story,'' said Subrata N. Chakravarty, an assistant managing editor, who has worked at Forbes on and off since 1972 and who wrote the article on Sprint. ''It makes me look like an amateur, and I'm not.'' **********In a statement relayed from Forbes Inc. through Elizabeth Ames, a spokeswoman, Forbes said: ''When the ads were shown to the staff, they were greeted with applause and good humor. We are sorry that some see it differently. But edgy humor has been part of Forbes ads forever.'' **********The statement did not address whether the editorial comments had appeared on the articles cited. **********Mr. Michaels, along with several other top staff members at Forbes, was out of the country at a meeting of the magazine's bureau chiefs in London and could not be reached for comment. Officials at Merkley Newman Harty did not return telephone calls seeking comment. **********The tension over the ads comes at a time when morale has suffered as several Forbes staff members have left for other publications. **********The ad campaign was presented to members of the staff at a lunch meeting last Thursday by Bruce H. Rogers, the magazine's vice president for marketing communications. Mr. Rogers was traveling and unavailable for comment. **********The presentation took a little while to sink in. **********''The ad agency apparently felt it was necessary that the comment be identified by a story because it would not be believed if it weren't,'' Mr. Chakravarty said. ''They didn't think to ask whether it was reasonable to put it on a story that had nothing to do with the comment and what that might do to the reputation of the writer. Initially we thought it was funny. It was only when we thought about it that we realized, hey, wait a minute. **********Indeed, some members of the staff said that although they understood their colleagues' concerns, they found the ads funny. ''I still kind of think it's amusing,'' said one who refused to be identified, ''because I'm one of those people who have saved these comments for the last 15 years.'' **********A couple of staff members, however, have asked Mr. Rogers to discontinue the ads. **********In a Forbes interoffice memo dated April 23, Mr. Rogers alerted the staff to the coming ads. ''The ads are real, raw, humorous, self-deprecating and uniquely Forbes,'' he wrote. ''Contrast that to the slick artifice of the Fortune campaign, which features models and a contrived 'yuppie' environment. You could easily substitute Money, Worth, Smart Money, Vanity Fair or any number of magazines for Fortune and the ads would still work.'' **********According to the memo, the Forbes ads were scheduled to run in Advertising Age, Mediaweek, The New York Observer and Content magazine, Steven Brill's coming publication about the media, ''as well as select outdoor locations.'' **********The other comments featured in the campaign -- complete with mistakes -- are: **********''forget what anal7sts or experts or industrywatchers think.WHAT DO YOU THINK AND WHY????? pls.fix or dump. -- Editor's comment on draft #2 'LBO Madness!' 3/9/98.'' **********And: ''this story is intrinsically weak.nothing new.no analysis. just facts aboutthe airline idustry juxtaposed with quotes. THIS ISN''T REPORTING. THIS IS TYPING! !!! -- Editor's comment on draft #2 'Lofty Alliances.' 1/12/98.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/25/busin.snippet: France's Finance Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn says Government has lowered its 1999 growth forecast to 2.4 percent from original 2.7 percent (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/25/busin.main_headline: France Now Predicts A Less Bubbly 1999
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/25/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; France Now Predicts A Less Bubbly 1999
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/25/busin.body_text: **********France lowered its 1999 growth forecast yesterday to 2.4 percent from an original 2.7 percent in what Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the Finance Minister, called a prudent step as exports fall and production slows. **********In a three-year budget draft, the Finance Ministry said France's gross domestic product would rise only 2.4 percent. Slowing growth in France, which together with Germany makes up 55 percent of the 11-nation European single currency region's economy, could raise pressure on the French Government to trim spending next year to keep its deficit within the 3 percent limit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/20/busin.main_headline: ADAPTEC SAYS IT WILL BUY A HYUNDAI SUBSIDIARY
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; ADAPTEC SAYS IT WILL BUY A HYUNDAI SUBSIDIARY
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/20/busin.body_text: **********Adaptec Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Symbios Inc., a subsidiary of Hyundai Electronics America, for $775 million in cash as it seeks to diversify its business and reverse a recent slowdown in sales growth. Adaptec, which makes computer adapter cards that connect PC's to printers, storage drives and other accessories, will take a charge to buy Symbios, which makes external storage devices for Sun Microsystems and Hewlett-Packard. Last month, Adaptec, based in Milpitas, Calif., said its third-quarter profit fell 11 percent, to $37 million, because of weak sales in North America. Symbios, based in Fort Collins, Colo., had 1997 sales of $620 million. Adaptec rose 93.75 cents yesterday, to $25.625, before the deal was announced.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/25/world.snippet: Article on ethnic violence in Rwanda notes that Pres Clinton is expected to say that world should have responded sooner to head off killings (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/25/world.main_headline: Why Washington and the World Largely Failed to Act to Head Off the Blood Bath
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/25/world.print_headline: CLINTON IN AFRICA: THE RWANDANS; Why Washington and the World Largely Failed to Act to Head Off the Blood Bath
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/25/world.body_text: **********Nearly four years ago, Rwanda and its neighbors dissolved into genocidal violence, and today President Clinton is expected to say the world should have responded sooner to head off the killings. **********Hundreds of thousands of Rwandans and others perished in the ethnic conflict. It is still not over. **********Tragically for the people of Rwanda, both Hutu and Tutsi, their moment of greatest peril occurred too close to the United States debacle in  Somalia, in which 18 American soldiers died, setting off a political storm in Washington. **********At the time, the Clinton Administration was concerned that there was no clear strategy, viable goal or exit plan for a military mission in Rwanda. It was also divided over how to respond to fast-moving events, with Madeleine K. Albright, then the American representative at the United Nations, arguing for some kind of international response, and the Pentagon and White House opposing any United Nations peacekeeping force. **********Ms. Albright ultimately prevailed, but the force created was a very small one of only 270 troops. She has since said repeatedly -- most recently in December on a visit to Africa as Secretary of State -- that the United States and other Western nations did too little too late in Rwanda. **********A senior United Nations official said this week that Washington had been ''absolutely paralyzed by Somalia.'' Other nations, already mired in Bosnia, were also reluctant to intervene in the small Central African country. **********''The Security Council was traumatized by what had happened,'' a European diplomat recalled, ''but Washington was more traumatized than the others.'' **********Mr. Clinton is not expected to name any country today for a failure to act, but diplomats involved in the United Nations debate in 1994 say they now doubt, despite all the praise and promises of economic assistance for Africa now, that Washington would join or support a peacekeeping operation if a similar crisis arose. **********Rwanda descended into genocide in 1994 after years of ethnic tensions. A guerrilla army, the Rwandese Patriotic Front, had been attacking from Uganda. In August 1993, an agreement between the country's minority Tutsi, represented by the front, and the Hutu majority promised to end the ethnic war and introduce a power-sharing system. **********By the fall of that year, the Rwanda agreement was already in danger, and the United Nations sent a peacekeeping mission to the country. But early in 1994, the United Nations commander in Kigali warned that Hutu militias were plotting to kill large numbers of Tutsi. **********The Security Council, with the United States as its most powerful member, did not act. On April 6 and in the weeks that followed, those Hutu plans were put into horrific effect. The trigger was a plane crash, which many believe to have been an act of sabotage, that killed Rwanda's Hutu President, Juvenal Habyarimana, along with the President of Burundi, Cyprien Ntaryamira. **********Among those who died in the rampage that followed were 10 Belgian peacekeepers guarding the Prime Minister, Agathe Uwilingiyimana. The peacekeepers had laid down their arms only to be butchered, as she was. Belgium decided to withdraw all its troops. On April 21, the Security Council dramatically cut the peacekeeping force to a bare 270 soldiers. Meanwhile, tens of thousands of Tutsi were trying to flee the country to Tanzania as their communities -- and those of Hutu opposed to the massacres -- were decimated. **********Kenneth Roth, executive director of Human Rights Watch, called the Security Council action at the time ''a thin veil over another massacre.'' **********Late in April and into May, as the toll of massacred Tutsi mounted into the hundreds of thousands, Bourtos Boutros-Ghali, the Secretary General of the United Nations, went repeatedly to the Security Council to ask for a credible force for Rwanda. **********When the Council finally agreed to a force of 5,500, the United States and other Western nations balked, and Washington forced the United Nations to delay sending any soldiers until there were moves toward an end to the violence. **********Mr. Boutros-Ghali, trying vainly to recruit Africans or anyone else for a force, called the situation ''a scandal.'' Eventually, Ghana, Ethiopia and Senegal volunteered. **********Events then moved beyond the Security Council. As the Tutsi-led guerrillas of the Rwandese Patriotic Front began a march of conquest across Rwanda, France decided to field a force, which established sanctuaries in southwestern Rwanda, largely for Hutu fleeing the R.P.F. **********Many more Hutu chose flight. By mid-July 1.5 million refugees had entered what was then Zaire, which is now Congo. **********Again the United Nations asked the Security Council for help. Although Washington was prepared to provide some relief aid, the Administration turned a deaf ear to pleas from Sadako Ogata, High Commissioner for Refugees, for a force in the camps to separate out Hutu leaders who had committed acts of genocide and who would no doubt rearm for a return to Rwanda. **********''We asked for help in getting those people out of the camps,'' Mrs. Ogata told an audience at the Holocaust Museum in Washington last year. ''No country offered to get help. My staff had to continue feeding criminals as the price for feeding hundreds of thousands of innocent women and children.'' **********The rearming took place as predicted. By late 1996, when the pro-Tutsi forces of Laurent Kabila, now Congo's President, were emptying the camps of Hutu and forcing them back into Rwanda, a Canadian-led  mission to provide security for the displaced was only reluctantly supported and then in effect undermined by the United States. **********Tens of thousands of Rwandans are still missing, Mrs. Ogata said recently. She believes that they perished in the absence of a protection force. Mr. Kabila's Government, now being wooed by the United States, is blocking investigations into reports of massacres by victorious Tutsis or their supporters among his troops. **********To bring the story full circle, Hutu gangs are now killing Tutsi again in remote areas of Rwanda, and Hutu in turn are being attacked by Rwandan Government troops.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/world.snippet: Pres Clinton urges Israeli and Palestinian leaders to break logjam in peace talks and take risks required to bring new hope to their peoples; promises his own intense involvement as Prime Min Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat go to Wye Conference Center ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/world.main_headline: Clinton Urges Netanyahu And Arafat to Take Risks
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/world.print_headline: Clinton Urges Netanyahu And Arafat to Take Risks
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/world.body_text: **********President Clinton, promising his own intense involvement to secure agreement, today urged the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to ''break the logjam'' and take the risks required to provide new hope to their peoples. **********Opening a four-day summit meeting between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, Mr. Clinton warned that ''too much time has already been lost'' in the search for an interim accord that will provide the Palestinians an additional 13 percent of the West Bank in return for Palestinian steps to fight terrorism. **********''Concessions that seem hard now will seem far less important in the light of an accord that moves Israelis and Palestinians closer to lasting peace,'' Mr. Clinton said in the White House Rose Garden, flanked by the two Middle East leaders. **********This afternoon Mr. Clinton traveled to the Wye Conference Center near Queenstown, Md., on the eastern shore of the Chesapeake Bay, where Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat have agreed to be isolated in comfort, with their aides and American officials, in the hopes of finishing the interim deal, now long overdue. **********Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright will continually be at the center. Mr. Clinton said he would go there as needed. **********Although American and Israeli officials said much hard work remained, failure on a long-delayed interim accord would be embarrassing to President Clinton just before the Nov. 3 elections. More importantly it would leave the peace effort on the verge of collapse seven months before May 4, when the Israelis and Palestinians are supposed to have completed their final agreement. **********Mr. Arafat has threatened to declare Palestinian statehood unilaterally if May 4 passes without a final settlement. **********Mr. Netanyahu and Israel's opposition Labor Party have warned him against such a step. **********But senior American officials acknowledged that Mr. Arafat had to have ''something concrete'' to point to by then, with talks on a final settlement proceeding well. **********A main task at the talks in Maryland, the American officials said, in addition to finishing the interim agreement for the 13 percent Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank in return for specific Palestinian antiterrorism steps, is to find a way to avoid a more fundamental crisis in seven months. **********If the interim deal can be achieved here, after more than 19 months of stalemate, talks on a permanent settlement will immediately restart. **********Natan Sharansky, one of Mr. Netanyahu's closest advisers in the Cabinet, said in an interview today that ''no date is sacred'' and that it could take two years for a final settlement to be negotiated. **********The chief Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat, called that unacceptable. Mr. Sharansky tried to play down the stakes for the meeting here, saying Israel could not accept any agreement just to have one. **********''We are coming to a summit where expectations are so high,'' he said. ''Yet the most outstanding issues are not resolved. While what we in Israel have to give is clear, what we are to get is not.'' **********The main issues for the Israelis are Palestinian steps to improve security, fight the radical Islamic Hamas movement and stop public and private ''incitement'' of violence against the Israelis. **********An important part of the private violence issue, Mr. Sharansky said, is requiring a public change in the Palestinian charter to remove clauses calling for the destruction of Israel. **********''I want it to be hard for Arafat,'' Mr. Sharansky said. ''I want him to have to argue for such a change. To me the heart of the question is not the percentage of land we give, but to change the charter.'' **********Mr. Netanyahu was cautious, saying, ''We come with the best intentions and we hope that there will be an accord.'' **********Mr. Arafat was optimistic. But he again mourned Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's assassination by an Israeli extremist. He reminded Mr. Netanyahu, in a reiteration of their long argument about whether peace flows from security or vice-versa, that ''peace is the most important platform for security, and he has to remember this and not to forget that some of his extremist gangsters have killed my partner Rabin.'' **********The old arguments are a prime reason why American officials want to isolate the leaders from outsiders, in particular from the press, and force them to concentrate in secrecy on the hard bargaining needed for a deal. The Wye Center, set amid dense woods along the unspoiled Wye River some 70 miles from Washington, was the next best choice, and a far more elegant one, after the Israelis rejected the Presidential retreat at Camp David in the Maryland hills. Israeli officials did not want the comparison to the 1978 marathon sessions there that led to a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt. **********This afternoon at the Wye Center, Mr. Clinton said that the Americans were ''ready to do whatever we can.'' He urged all sides to focus on the talks only. **********''Therefore we have agreed to confine our dealings with the media to periodic briefings to be conducted by spokespersons,'' he said. **********But the spokesmen like James P. Rubin of the State Department have pledged to say as little as possible. **********Mr. Sharansky joked that he was hesitating to enter the conference Center ''because I'm afraid they won't let me out again.'' **********But his presence, combined with the arrival on Friday of the new Foreign Minister, Ariel Sharon, and Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai, is a sign of Mr. Netanyahu's seriousness. The three figures make up the ''kitchen cabinet'' and must themselves agree if Mr. Netanyahu has any chance of getting a deal through his Cabinet. **********Mr. Sharon and Mr. Mordechai remained in Israel an additional day for a commemoration of a famous tank battle in the 1973 war. Mr. Sharon will fly directly to Rochester, Minn., where King Hussein of Jordan is undergoing cancer treatment at the Mayo Clinic, for a visit before joining Mr. Netanyahu at the Wye Center. **********But with the Israeli delegation unable to work after sundown on Friday because of the Sabbath, American officials acknowledge that the time is short for the breakthrough that Mr. Clinton and Ms. Albright want so badly. **********Among the issues to be settled include a third shift of Israeli troops due under previous accords, a move quite likely to be settled by a panel on borders at the final-status talks after they have begun. **********There are also arguments about how Palestinians will travel unhindered between the West Bank and Gaza, with the Israelis suggesting buses and even trains. The Palestinians insist on being able to travel in individual cars. An airport and an industrial park in Gaza are essentially settled, but security questions remain on a planned seaport. **********The real danger of the summit meeting, said Stephen Cohen, vice chairman of the Center for Middle East Peace and Economic Cooperation, is that ''everyone will settle for a very little thing that they call an agreement and that resolves nothing in the region.'' He urged Mr. Clinton ''to aim high,'' saying, ''A fairy-tale agreement about too little will not solve the problems.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/03/busin.snippet: George Lucas's movie company, Lucasfilm Ltd, announces that next three films in 'Star Wars' series, one of most powerful franchises ever produced, will be distributed by 20th Century Fox, film division of News Corp; first new 'Star Wars' film, whi...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/03/busin.main_headline: Fox Gets Deal To Distribute 'Star Wars'
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/03/busin.print_headline: Fox Gets Deal To Distribute 'Star Wars'
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/03/busin.body_text: **********George Lucas's movie company announced today that the next three films in its ''Star Wars'' series, one of the most powerful movie franchises ever produced, would be distributed by 20th Century Fox, the film division of the News Corporation. **********The announcement was no surprise, since the first three ''Star Wars'' movies were distributed by Fox, but it was good news for the studio, currently basking in the success of ''Titanic,'' which it helped finance and distribute. **********Fox will earn less on these films than it would ordinarily make because Mr. Lucas's company, Lucasfilm Ltd., will retain ownership, and because Lucasfilm will also retain the rights to license and sell merchandise, an enormously profitable business. Still, Peter Chernin, chairman of the Fox group of companies, called the announcement ''a banner day for the company'' because of a number of ancillary benefits. **********For one, he said, it means that in the competition among the studios to line up major event movies every summer, Fox can be assured it will have three powerful contenders. In addition, Fox secured rights to show the first of the new movies on its Fox Broadcasting network after its theater release. Mr. Chernin also said the films would add to Fox's international distribution power and thus would help attract other film makers eager to take advantage of it. **********The first new ''Star Wars'' film, which is currently untitled, is scheduled to be released in May 1999, with the others coming at intervals of perhaps two or three years afterward, said Gordon Radley, the president of Lucasfilm. Mr. Lucas wrote and directed the movie, the first time he has done so in years. **********Neither company would disclose the terms of the deal, but executives at other studios said Fox had probably agreed to significantly lower distribution fees than it received on most films, and was probably making large up-front payments.

Life Financial, based in Riverside, Calif., purchases and originates nonconventional mortgage loans through its Life Bank unit. The company said on Monday that its directors had decided the agreement was not in the best interest of shareholders because of recent developments concerning Firstplus.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/26/world.snippet: Swiss Government report about wartime dealings in Nazi gold concludes that Swiss National Bank officials knew that some of gold sent to Switzerland had been looted from occupied areas during World War II; confirms allegations that gold included so...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/26/world.main_headline: Report Says Swiss Knew Some Nazi Gold Was Stolen
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/26/world.print_headline: Report Says Swiss Knew Some Nazi Gold Was Stolen
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/26/world.body_text: **********A long-awaited report about wartime dealings in Nazi gold concludes that Swiss National Bank officials knew that some gold sent to Switzerland had been looted from occupied areas, and confirms allegations that the gold included some stolen from Holocaust victims. **********The report, commissioned by the Swiss Government and issued today by an international panel of historians, says that Swiss bank officials turned a blind eye toward the origins of much of the gold, which included wedding bands and other jewelry and coins taken from Jews sent to death and concentration camps. **********The head of the panel, Jean-Francois Bergier, criticized wartime officials of the Swiss National Bank for following an ''ethic of the least effort'' to trace the sources of the gold, even though starting in 1941 they ''became increasingly aware that Jews and other persecuted groups were being robbed.'' **********''And in 1943, at the latest, the S.N.B. had knowledge of the systematic extermination of victims of the Nazi regime,'' the report said. It said officials nonetheless ''neglected taking measures to distinguish looted gold from other gold holdings of the Reichsbank.'' **********Over all, the report estimated that Switzerland's central bank had bought gold worth $280 million in wartime dollars from the Nazis, or more than $2.5 billion at today's prices. While not providing a full estimate of so-called victim gold -- that taken from those sent to death and concentration camps -- the report said gold worth about $134,000 in wartime dollars, more than $1.2 million today, was sent to Swiss banks. **********Although the report held no surprises, it immediately fueled further rancor between Swiss officials and American Jewish groups that have been pressing Switzerland to pay into a global settlement to atone for the wartime trade and to compensate Holocaust survivors and the heirs of Holocaust victims. **********The Swiss National Bank has so far refused to join the country's commercial banks in negotiating a settlement with Jewish groups. A senior Government official, Thomas Borer, who heads the Swiss Government task force on the issue, said today that the Government ''won't take part in any settlement that involves taxpayers' money.'' **********''The report says clearly the Swiss government and the Swiss National Bank did not know that it was victims' gold,'' Mr. Borer said in an interview today. ''No one could know because the gold was melted into normal ingots.'' **********Elan Steinberg, executive director of the World Jewish Congress, the leading voice for global reparations, said by telephone: ''They know now.  It's a moral stain on Switzerland if they create a commission and don't act on its conclusions.'' **********Mr. Borer maintained that there was nothing in the report that warranted reopening of the 1946 Washington agreement under which Switzerland turned over some gold obtained during the war. The Federal Council, Switzerland's governing body, issued a statement today ruling out revisiting the 1946 accord on grounds that ''the Allies were informed extensively from the very beginning'' on the gold transactions. **********Urging the Swiss to make restitution for victims' gold, Mr. Steinberg said, ''Switzerland shouldn't act dishonorably just because the Allies did 50 years ago.'' **********The report said that Swiss National Bank officials were so uneasy about the prospect of wartime trafficking in looted gold that they considered melting it down to disguise its origin. That idea was later abandoned as ''impractical.'' **********The report also provided details of exactly where some of the victims' gold came from. An SS captain, Bruno Melmer, had responsibility for collecting gold from some concentration and death camp victims, including those at Auschwitz and Birkenau. **********The Melmer gold sent to Switzerland was a portion of all victim gold. **********The panel criticized Switzerland's past justifications for those wartime gold purchases, particularly that the country had to accept Nazi gold to stave off an occupation by Hitler's forces. This reasoning was advanced late in the war, in 1943, the report said, showing that ''it was an argument cobbled together to justify the previous gold policy.'' **********The Swiss National Bank, in a statement today, said it ''regrets most profoundly that in accepting gold deliveries from the Reichsbank it may unwittingly also have acquired gold deriving from victims of concentration camps.'' **********The report, more than a year in the making, will be made available at bookstores and on the Internet shortly, the panel said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/05/busin.snippet: For music lovers in, say, London or Paris, it is often easier and cheaper to order compact disks via the Internet from the United States, and to have them delivered by express mail, than to buy them in a local store..Soon customers will be able to...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/05/busin.body_text: **********For music lovers in, say, London or Paris, it is often easier and cheaper to order compact disks via the Internet from the United States, and to have them delivered by express mail, than to buy them in a local store. **********Soon customers will be able to cut out the mailman as well as the store by creating disks on their own computers with music downloaded from the Internet. **********The first kind of transaction, in which a package actually moves from one country to another, should, at least in theory, be subject to import duties. But what about the second? **********Is the creation of a compact disk from the Internet in the privacy of one's home equivalent to trading in goods or is it more like a service, such as a trans-Atlantic telephone call, which has always been duty-free? **********That is the kind of thorny issue that governments are just starting to tackle as what is known as "electronic commerce" begins to take off. **********Most estimates suggest that business conducted over the Internet around the world will run to several hundred billion dollars a year by early next century. **********According to one estimate, 1 billion people, or nearly 20 percent of the world population, will have access to the Internet in less than 15 years. But private individuals buying compact disks and airline tickets will account for only a small fraction of total electronic commerce. **********The vast bulk of transactions will be between businesses doing such things as placing orders from suppliers or transferring financial and legal information to clients or subsidiaries. Airbus Industrie is already designing the parts of its airliners on-line in four different European countries. **********It is the United States, as the world leader in information technology and in many of the items likely to be traded on the Internet, that stands to benefit the most. **********So it is perhaps not surprising that Washington is leading a campaign to make all Internet transactions duty-free, at least when products and services are delivered electronically. The European Union, the other giant of the world trading system, agrees. **********But most developing countries are suspicious of the U.S. plan and unsure how they might benefit from it. **********That is the main reason why the World Trade Organization in Geneva last month agreed to do no more than adopt a temporary moratorium on new Internet duties until the issue is reviewed again next year. **********Another big problem is that the EU and the United States fundamentally disagree over how far the Internet should be subjected to international regulation, with the EU calling for WTO rules to be updated and clarified to apply to electronic commerce and Washington insisting that Internet users should regulate themselves. **********Both make good points. The EU argues that electronic commerce will not fully flourish unless there are commonly agreed rules in such areas as data protection, privacy, the validity of electronic signatures on contracts and competition questions such as price fixing and restrictive business practices. **********The United States is terrified that excessive regulation — indeed virtually any regulation — will hamstring the Internet and stifle the creativity and imagination that have been the main sources of its success so far. **********It is clear, however, that the United States will not single-handedly be able to dictate the way the Internet is run. **********In one way or another, electronic commerce will have to be brought under the rules of the trading system. **********The hope must be that the regulatory touch remains as light as possible and that governments do not encumber this dynamic new activity with the kind of damaging obstructions they have spent so many years trying to remove from the rest of world trade. **********- **********E-mail address: **********thinkahead@washpost.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/08/busin.snippet: Japan's Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, in his first major policy speech since taking over as Prime Minister a week ago, proposes cuts in individual and corporate taxes and additional spending for public works while making less-concrete promises to d...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/08/busin.main_headline: Tokyo Leader Calls for Cuts In Tax Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/08/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Tokyo Leader Calls for Cuts In Tax Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/08/busin.body_text: **********In his first major policy speech since taking over as Prime Minister a week ago, Keizo Obuchi today proposed cuts in individual and corporate taxes and additional spending for public works while making less-concrete promises to deregulate the economy and trim the Government budget. **********While Mr. Obuchi spoke forcefully, he proposed primarily to speed up changes his politically less powerful predecessor had pursued for some time; he offered little in the way of shock therapy for Japan's ailing economy. **********He plans to serve up a quick cocktail of tax cuts and public spending aimed at spurring the economy over the next year or two. For the long term, his menu is a far less detailed list of promises to deregulate, push administrative change, privatize the public sector and overhaul the tax system -- in short, the program the man he succeeded, Ryutaro Hashimoto, pushed for. **********''I am determined to make my utmost effort, at the risk of the Cabinet's life, to bring the Japanese economy to a recovery path within a year or two,'' he told Parliament, alluding to newspaper reports that have described his Cabinet as standing on the edge of a cliff. **********Mr. Obuchi may not have much time.  ''It seems he wants to engineer a soft landing of the Japanese economy,'' said Heizo Takenaka, a professor at Keio University, ''and the basic question is, Is that possible? I personally feel that some kind of shock therapy is necessary.'' **********In Washington, the Clinton Administration continued to walk a line between hope that Japan would move quickly to enact the changes necessary to shore up its economy and skepticism that decisive action was forthcoming. **********''The early restoration of growth in the Japanese economy is critical not only for Japan but for Asia, other emerging markets and the world economy as a whole,'' said a senior official at the United States Treasury Department, speaking on the condition of anonymity. **********''Japan also needs to move aggressively to use public money along with actions to strengthen and restructure banks, to dispose of the burden of bad assets and to improve bank supervision and disclosure,'' the official said. **********The pace of deterioration in the Japanese economy has gained momentum of late. In the week since Mr. Obuchi took office, the unemployment rate hit yet another high, domestic auto sales were down for the 16th straight month and the yen sank against the dollar. Manufacturers are cutting production, and even in the midst of sweltering heat, air-conditioner sales are off. **********''The problems are so serious right now that the best we can hope for even in a year's time is that he can stabilize the situation,'' said Jeffrey D. Young, chief economist at Salomon Smith Barney in Tokyo. And, indeed, Mr. Obuchi's immediate plans are to do just that. He promised 6 trillion yen, or roughly $41 billion, in overall tax cuts next year, effectively making permanent the 4 trillion yen in temporary cuts for individuals that Mr. Hashimoto extended this year. **********He pledged to lower the maximum combined local and national income tax rate to 50 percent from 65 percent, the first step toward what he hopes will be a comprehensive reworking of the tax system. **********And borrowing another page from Mr. Hashimoto's book, he said he would lower the corporate tax rate to 40 percent from 46.3 percent starting in April, bringing it roughly in line with Western levels. **********Economists and business leaders have long criticized Japan's high taxes for inhibiting entrepreneurs and forcing dynamic individuals to move to other countries. ''I paid 200 million yen in taxes last year,'' Takuya Okada, chairman and chief executive of Jusco Ltd., one of Japan's largest retailers, fumed recently. **********The temporary tax cut he got this spring returned just 18,000 yen to him, which ''did not really inspire me to spend,'' he said. ''Now, if they cut my income tax to 50 percent, then I might think about spending,'' he added. Few economists, though, say a tax cut will put the economy on a path to lasting recovery. **********''Tax cuts are necessary because bankruptcies are increasing and unemployment is spiraling up,'' said Andrew Shipley, an economist at Schroders in Tokyo. ''But it's not going to start a consumer-led recovery.'' **********Neither will corporate tax cuts necessarily stimulate capital investment. Only 35 to 40 percent of Japanese corporations pay taxes, and the low cost of capital -- companies can borrow at around 1 percent -- offsets the tax burden for those companies doing well enough to have to pay taxes. **********While economists welcome a corporate cut, many say the tax structure itself is in need of a fix. ''Companies now get tax breaks for certain types of investment that made sense a long time ago, but, given changes in technology and the economy, now make no sense,'' Mr. Young said. **********Voters, however, are demanding something that makes sense. Mr. Obuchi's ruling Liberal Democratic Party lost control of the Upper House of Parliament when voters turned out in unexpected droves on June 12 to vent their anger. Popularity ratings for Mr. Obuchi and his Cabinet are so low that commentators see a bright side: they probably cannot get any worse. **********The loss of the Upper House threatens to stall the passage of legislation to revamp the debt-ridden banking system, and foreign investors will continue to punish the stock market and the yen until they see evidence that change is for real. **********Mr. Obuchi is well aware of that, and he was at his most eloquent when speaking about the financial sector. ''The flow of funds is like the blood of society, and the financial institutions that are responsible for its circulation assume the role of the heart,'' he said. ''A partial failure of the financial sector, therefore, might lead to a systemic crisis.'' **********Nonetheless, he left lingering doubts about the Government's ability to swallow the strong medicine of failed banks and falling asset prices that would accompany a banking system overhaul. At a news conference after the speech, Akitaka Saiki, Mr. Obuchi's deputy press secretary, was pressed about whether the Prime Minister would allow insolvent banks to fail. Foreign investors are all but baying for a bank failure as a sign that the Government is serious about cleaning up the system. **********''We don't intend to save bad banks,'' Mr. Saiki said. ''They need to take responsibility for their actions.'' **********The only specific long-term goal Mr. Obuchi proposed was to push through measures that would cut the Government payroll by 20 percent over the next decade and cut Government costs by 30 percent, both ideas that have been floated for years. **********Mr. Obuchi plans to pay for tax cuts by issuing deficit bonds, a financing technique all but prohibited by last year's Fiscal Structural Reform Act. That law severely limited Mr. Hashimoto's ability to maneuver when the economy started sliding toward recession late last fall, and the Prime Minister said today that he would submit legislation in the fall to suspend that law. **********He also proposed a supplemental spending budget of 10 trillion yen, or about $69 billion. That will come on top of 16 trillion yen put together in the spring by Mr. Hashimoto, meaning that Japan will spend more than 4 percent of its gross domestic product this year trying to get its economy going again with public works projects. ''This is an amazingly big set of packages by any standards,'' Professor Takenaka said. **********Mr. Saiki, the Prime Minister's spokesman, said Mr. Obuchi intended to spend this money somewhat differently from the way such budgets have been spent in the past, when they largely went to building bridges, transportation facilities and roadways that kept the politically loyal and labor-intensive construction industry afloat when the bubble economy started losing air. **********Mr. Obuchi, he added, wants a bigger portion of the new supplemental budget spent on ''industries of the future,'' like medicine and technology. **********Those industries are considered the best hope for putting a plug in rising unemployment, which is a source of continuing discomfort for politicians, who consider it a ticking time bomb that could blast them out of office. **********But economists see higher unemployment as painful but necessary, for it means companies are trying to increase productivity and profitability, which makes them more competitive globally. **********And even Mr. Saiki said that if deregulation proceeded, Japan may face more unemployment in the short term. ''The structure of the economy has to be changed,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/busin.print_headline: Money Isn't Everything, Especially in Retirement
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Re ''When Enough Really Is Enough'' (Seniority, Oct. 4), in which Fred Brock discussed how retirees don't need huge nest eggs -- the kind recommended by many mutual fund companies -- in order to lead happy, fulfilling lives: **********After reading so many articles, with substantive charts and graphs, in yours and other publications as to why one needs so many big bucks tucked away for retirement, it was gratifying to see your column  -- especially its description of Elton Pasea,  who lives quite nicely on $1,200 a month in a small town in Texas. **********I have always assumed that there are more Elton Paseas in this world than people  with seven-figure nest eggs who still worry about running out of money before death. **********JAMES H. CHAPMAN **********Greensburg, Pa., Oct. 7

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/19/busin.snippet: From the Desk Of commentary by Hedrick Smith on growing feeling that middle class is not sharing fully in America's prosperity, and suggestions of various experts on what should be done to correct situation; drawing (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/19/busin.main_headline: FROM THE DESK OF; How the Middle Class Can Share in the Wealth
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/19/busin.print_headline: FROM THE DESK OF; How the Middle Class Can Share in the Wealth
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/19/busin.body_text: **********AS Wall Street celebrates three years of spectacular gains, seven years of economic growth and the creation of millions of new jobs in the 1990's, it is fashionable to observe the financial clouds cast by Asia's turmoil. **********But thoughtful voices warn that the real peril to American prosperity lies not overseas but at home, in the way we have run our own economy in these boom times. And these voices contend that we can manage our economic destiny differently -- and for the better -- for the middle class. **********No less a corporate leader than Henry B. Schacht, chairman of Lucent Technologies, asserts simply that the cost-cutting, bottom-line fever that has powered Wall Street and corporate America in the 1990's cannot last. ''This is going to blow up in our faces,'' warns Mr. Schacht, who earned more than $1.5 million last year and holds over $34 million worth of uncashed Lucent stock options. ''There is no way a society can have this much of its accumulated wealth distributed to these few people.'' **********To those who say the middle class shares fully in America's prosperity, Stephen Roach, chief economist of Morgan Stanley, replies: ''I am hard-pressed to believe that this is a period when we've got a rising tide that has lifted all boats. There are millions of workers who have never seen the harbor let alone even know what a boat looks like.'' **********John H. Dasburg, chief executive of Northwest Airlines, adds: ''Democracy didn't work without certain rights being guaranteed, what we call a Bill of Rights. And in my view there is somewhat a bill of rights to capitalism. You just simply must take into consideration all of the various interests in society in the enterprise. And if you fail to do that, capitalism will fail.'' **********These are minority viewpoints for now. But there is no denying that Mssrs. Schacht, Roach and Dasburg are charter members of the free-market club, and from that vantage point, these leading business spokesmen warn that the economic payoff in the 1990's has been so skewed to the upper brackets that our prosperity is in danger. **********In the era of the so-called people's market, Federal Reserve statistics show that 60 percent of Americans own no stock at all -- no 401(k) plan, no mutual funds, no pension stock, nothing. Analysis by economists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Dartmouth College tell us that the wealthiest 1 percent of Americans own nearly 50 percent of all stock; the bottom 80 percent own only 3 percent. While most Americans are better off today than in the recession of 1990-91, average household income in real terms is still not up to the 1989 level. **********The warning from Mr. Roach, among others, is that unless American capitalism does a better job of sharing the wealth, a political backlash is coming from the so-called middle middle of America. **********MR. SCHACHT'S ideas for reducing income inequality and for tempering the wild scramble for short-term payoffs on Wall Street include letting the traders trade but denying them the voting rights of ownership for two years. He would also raise the progressive income tax rates and lower capital gains taxes on a sliding scale to zero, based on the investment's duration. **********''You cannot have the very few of us making these enormous amounts of money and a large number of folks feeling that the system of which they are the majority is treating them less fairly than they feel is equitable,'' Mr. Schacht argues. **********Mr. Dasburg's answer has been to include Northwest's employees as genuine partners in the enterprise, pursue labor-management cooperation and share decision making as well as more of the profits. When Northwest verged on bankruptcy in 1993, he says, it was the giveback of $900 million in wages and work-rule concessions by pilots, machinists, flight attendants and ground personnel that saved it. In return, employees got 30 percent ownership and three seats on the board. **********Other power-sharing arrangements have enabled Northwest to keep more than $100 million of work in-house rather than outsourcing it. **********Such examples are still unusual but hardly unique. United Airlines, Allied Signal and U.S. Sugar have bet on employee ownership and power-sharing. In more than 1,000 American corporations, employees hold more than 20 percent ownership and have both profit-sharing and some decision-making power. **********Sitting far away in Manhattan, the corporate ownership of the Hathaway Shirt Company of Waterville, Me., decided two years ago that the business could not compete with third-world imports even after relentless cost-cutting. But people in Maine saw Hathaway as too valuable to the regional economy to be buried for the sake of the short-term bottom line. An investor group rallied to buy the plant, struck a deal with the union, received government bridge financing and hired an experienced chief executive to restore Hathaway's historic quality standards and  to sell the improved shirts to upscale stores. Today, Hathaway thrives. **********In Virginia, the end of the cold war meant the loss of huge Navy contracts and thousands of jobs at the Newport News shipyard. But as the shipbuilding company struggled to find commercial contracts to replace lost Government business, six labor unions banded together to invest millions of dollars of workers' pension money to clinch a huge deal to build oil tankers. That revived the shipyard and 2,000 jobs. **********Such examples reach beyond the bottom line and illustrate the advantages of sharing the gains. They show that we can do much better for the middle class. In the new economy, the prime issue for most Americans is not how many jobs there are, but what kind of jobs, what kinds of lives they let people enjoy and what kind of future is ahead for their children. The test is not survival of the fittest but the fitness of society to provide a greater share of the gains to a larger majority.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/01/world.snippet: Defense Min Yitzhak Mordechai of Israel attends cornerstone-laying ceremony for new extension of Jewish settlement at Beit El on West Bank; United States has repeatedly called for 'timeout' on settlement building to smooth path for upcoming talks ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/01/world.main_headline: Hopes for Peace Talks Dim As Israel Extends Settlement
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/01/world.print_headline: Hopes for Peace Talks Dim As Israel Extends Settlement
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/01/world.body_text: **********Despite American calls for a ''timeout'' in settlement building, Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai of Israel shoveled cement into a hole today for a new extension of this Jewish settlement in the hills north of the Palestinian-ruled town of Ramallah. **********The cornerstone-laying ceremony, a year after a Beit El woman and her son were killed by Palestinian gunmen, signaled the Government's determination to go on expanding settlements despite the American demands. **********Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, are expected to travel to Washington in late January for separate meetings with President Clinton to discuss a further Israeli troop withdrawal in the West Bank and talks on a final peace settlement. **********Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has repeatedly called for a ''timeout'' in Israeli settlement activity to smooth the path to negotiations. **********Still, more than 4,700 housing units are under construction in 61 of the 140 settlements in the West Bank, according to figures compiled by Peace Now, a left-wing Israeli group that closely monitors settlement activity. **********In fierce bargaining this week over passage of a new state budget, Mr. Netanyahu's right-wing coalition partners have wrung promises of tens of millions more dollars for settlements and for construction of new bypass roads linking them. **********Work on the new neighborhood of Beit El is expected to start in 10 months, and in the first phase of construction 40 apartments are to be built out of a planned total of 130. The housing will be in an area that is now part of an Israeli Army base next to the settlement. **********Mr. Mordechai said that the new construction was necessary to accommodate the natural growth of Beit El, a community of 4,000, and was not meant as a political signal to the United States or the Palestinians. **********''Everyone has to understand clearly that this quarter is necessary for the people of Beit El,'' Mr. Mordechai told reporters. ''The people of Beit El have to build their houses here like the people of New York, Paris or Tel Aviv have to build apartments.'' **********''It is agreed with all the elements, including with our American friends, that settlements will be expanded near their fences, contiguously,'' Mr. Mordechai said, referring to the perimeter of the settlements. ''There is no departure here from the accepted principles. This neighborhood is adjacent to the fence, to meet the needs of the settlement.'' **********American officials, however, have made clear in recent months that they consider any settlement activity an obstacle to the peace effort. **********For the hundreds of Beit El residents who danced and sang to celebrate the new project, the expansion of their community was laden with political meaning. **********''This ceremony is a declaration to everyone that the entire Land of Israel is the land of our forefathers, the land of God, and we are permanently here in Beit El and in all parts of the Land of Israel,'' said Zalman Melamed, the rabbi of the settlement. He warned the Government against giving up ''a single inch of the Land of Israel.'' **********The planned neighborhood, called Maoz Tzur, is named after Ita Tzur and her 12-year-old son Efraim, who were killed when Palestinian gunmen attacked their family's car on a road near Beit El in December 1996. **********After the shooting, settlers from Beit El parked trailers on a hill overlooking the settlement in an attempt to force the Government to expand their community. They left after Mr. Mordechai promised to consider their demands. **********Yoel Tzur, whose wife and son were killed in the shooting, was the driving force behind the moves to expand the settlement, and he wept during the ceremony today. ''I think this is a very appropriate response to the murder that was committed,'' Mr. Tzur said. ''The murderers and those who sent them should know: You murder people, we will build. We won't be defeated.'' **********But Hanan Ashrawi, a minister in the Palestinian cabinet, called the  Israeli settlement expansion a death-knell for peace efforts. **********''They are not just laying a cornerstone, these are the gravestones of any kind of peace,'' she said. ''On the ground they are burying it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/25/world.snippet: Kazimierz Dziewanowski, Ambassador of Poland to United States from 1990 to 1993, dies; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/25/world.body_text: **********Kazimierz Dziewanowski, the first Ambassador of what he proudly called the ''new, democratic and free Poland'' to the United States from 1990 to 1993, died on Wednesday in a hospital at Pisz, Poland. He was in his late 60's and lived in Warsaw. **********His death came from a sudden illness, The Associated Press reported from Warsaw, citing news reports. It said his family had not disclosed the exact cause. **********Mr. Dziewanowski, a tall, courteous writer, was active in the dissident Solidarity movement before the longtime Communist rule in Poland ended when free elections in 1989 gave Solidarity a majority in both houses of the parliament. Then a coalition Government led by Solidarity took power. **********Earlier, he was deputy chief editor of the weekly Solidarity newspaper Tygodnik Solidarnosc at its founding in 1981. In 1989 the weekly's chief editor, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, became Poland's first Prime Minister after Communism. He asked Mr. Dziewanowski to accept the ambassadorship. **********As Ambassador, he strived to build support for Poland's admission to NATO. After Mr. Dziewanowski died, Lech Walesa, the former Solidarity leader and former President of Poland, said: ''He opened the doors to NATO for us. It is a pity he did not live to the moment they are wide open.'' Poland is to join NATO in April. **********Recalling his Washington years in a 1997 interview, Mr. Dziewanowski was frank about the appeal of the United States to young Poles. ''I was once approached by the Polish community in America to meet with some young Poles living in the region of Washington, Baltimore and Philadelphia.'' he said. ''So I invited them, and we had a great gathering at our embassy, until I realized that at least half of the audience was illegally in the country. So I had to make it short.'' **********In recent years his writings about United States and international affairs in the Polish daily Rzeczpospolita were widely quoted. **********A native of Warsaw, he studied law at Warsaw University and became a journalist and author. In 1981, when the Government imposed martial law, he was dismissed from his job at an intellectual weekly, Literatura. **********His survivors include his wife, Malgorzata, and a daughter, Krystyna..

No further information was disclosed. McLeod Russel agreed in August to acquire Trion for $7.27 a share. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/14/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; Dow Off 63 Points as Eastman Kodak Revenue Declines
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/14/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices fell as the flow of third-quarter corporate earnings reports began to intensify. **********Many companies have prepared investors with pre-announcements about a slide in profits, but investors showed yesterday that they are looking at more than just the bottom line. **********Shares of Eastman Kodak were pounded after the company reported a 10 percent drop in revenues, largely as a result of a decline in sales to consumers in emerging markets like Russia and China. Even though revenues sagged, Kodak's net income figures beat analysts' expectations, in part because of cost reductions. **********That sort of report might have cheered Wall Street at other times, but these are not other times. **********''People are suspicious when companies can't pull out top-line growth,'' said Henry Herrmann, the chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed, a mutual fund company in Overland Park, Kan., with $26 billion in assets under management. **********Kodak's stock fell by 11 3/16, or 13 percent, to 72 3/8. That result was responsible for 73 percent, or 46.1 points, of a 63.33-point decline in the Dow Jones industrial average, which closed at 7,938.14. It also contributed to a much smaller 2.91-point fall in the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which closed at 994.80. **********''Two or three years ago, if a company showed improving earnings growth through lower costs, the market rejoiced,'' said A. Marshall Acuff, an equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. ''Now the market senses that the world economy is slowing down, and is focused on growth in the top line, as well as on profits. Kodak gave the market a kind of smack in the face.'' **********Sagging computer share prices dragged down the Nasdaq composite index, which fell 36.63 points, or 2.37 percent, to 1,509.45. **********Monsanto was another big contributor to the decline in the Standard & Poor's 500 index. Shares of Monsanto fell 13 3/8, or 26.55 percent, to 37, after it said its proposed $35 billion merger with American Home Products  had been canceled. American Home Products fell 5, to 45. **********Nasdaq stocks were dragged down by computer companies like Dell Computer, which lost 3 1/16, to 53. **********Not every company that reported earnings yesterday saw its stock price head lower. **********Johnson & Johnson rose 1 5/16, to 77 3/4, after a solid earnings report. And Merrill Lynch, which has been clobbered in recent weeks, rose 1 1/16, to 44 15/16, after it reported a net loss of $164 million and said it would lay off 3,400 employees. **********''It is hard to imagine things getting a lot worse in the financial sector,'' Bob Gasser, head of block trading at J. P. Morgan & Company, said. **********Some market analysts, a group that includes Mr. Acuff at Salomon Smith Barney, said conditions have improved over the last week or so, and that the Dow was not likely to successfully test its Aug. 31 low. **********But Mr. Herrmann said he could be happier. ''We have been doing some buying, especially in small- capitalization stocks, but nothing wholesale,'' he said. **********To feel better, Mr. Herrman said he would like to see long-term bond yields rise above short-term interest rates. **********''That would allow the banking sector to reliquify itself by extending credit rather than just holding bonds,'' he said. ''I would also like to get a sense that the hedge fund world, which includes big money- center banks, has finished unwinding its money-losing trades.'' **********But even those accomplishments would not do much to help corporate earnings. **********''No matter what we do there is going to be material pressure'' on earnings, he said. ''There is such an incredible excess of supply that companies don't have any pricing power. It will take us a while to work through that.'' **********--------------------        Treasuries Close Higher **********By Bloomberg News **********Bond prices rose for the first time in five days yesterday as investors bought Treasuries after last week's plunge in prices drove long-term yields to a two-week high. **********The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 19/32, to 106 10/32. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/01/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; Olivetti's Profit Ends String of Annual Losses
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/01/busin.body_text: **********Olivetti S.p.A., the Italian telecommunications and office equipment company, said yesterday that it posted its first annual profit in seven years as it sold off telephone assets to its new partner, Mannesmann A.G. Olivetti earned 16 billion lire, or $9 million, last year after losing 4.77 trillion lire, or $2.7 billion, over the six previous years, including a 1996 loss of 915 billion lire, or $515 million. Olivetti posted a gain of 972 billion lire from selling Mannesmann 25 percent of its telephone businesses. **********The return to profit is the latest sign of Olivetti's turnaround since Roberto Colaninno took over as chief executive in 1996 and sold off money-losing units to focus on telecommunications.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/world.snippet: Indonesia students resume demonstrations in Jakarta, gathering in holiday mood outside Parliament to reject new Government timetable for elections next year; demands for immediate voting are repeated by Muslim leader Amien Rais; student movement i...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/world.main_headline: Indonesian Students Resume Demonstrations in Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/world.print_headline: Indonesian Students Resume Demonstrations in Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/world.body_text: **********Students resumed their demonstrations in the capital today, gathering in a holiday mood outside the gates of the Parliament building to reject a new Government timetable for elections next year. **********Once again setting a public agenda, as they have for the last two months, they held up a black banner demanding ''Immediate Elections.'' **********Their demand was repeated by the Muslim leader Amien Rais, who used the student demonstrations in recent weeks as a platform to consolidate his position as the country's most influential opposition figure. **********The timetable was announced today by House Speaker Harmoko after a meeting with President B. J. Habibie at which he said they agreed that an electoral assembly would be convened late this year or early next year, followed by an election some time in 1999. **********That 1,000-member assembly is dominated by backers of former President Suharto, who was forced to resign last Thursday after a weeklong occupation of the Parliament building by thousands of students. Opponents fear that the procedures and timetable set forth today will allow Mr. Habibie to consolidate his position, along with the rest of the power structure that was left in place by Mr. Suharto. **********The students were not permitted to enter the grounds of Parliament today. But some 400 demonstrators from 40 universities gathered outside its gates, climbing onto the roofs of buses and waving the red-and-white Indonesian flag. **********''Hang, hang Habibie! Hang Habibie next to Suharto!'' they chanted, to the beat of drums, as some 200 soldiers looked on. **********It was the first demonstration by students in the capital since they were peacefully removed from Parliament a day after Mr. Suharto's resignation. Elsewhere around the country, students have moved to a new stage of action, sitting in at regional parliament offices and city halls to demand local reforms. **********Other students have formed committees to spread their message of democratic reforms among villagers and poor urban residents. **********But as the momentum builds here for political change, with new political parties and labor unions forming and with public figures like Mr. Rais jockeying for position, the students have found themselves groping for a new political role. **********''When Suharto stepped down, many students were confused,'' said Rainer, 21, a student of political science who like many Indonesians uses only one name. ''We have no program for our next step. We have never done this before.'' **********But they have not faded from view. For two months after the ritual reannointing of former President Suharto in mid-March, it was the students who refused to accept his continued manipulation of the country as its economy crashed and its people seethed with discontent. **********Many Indonesians still look to them for moral leadership, and they are a force the Government must now take into account as it addresses questions of democracy, free speech and human rights. **********''I admire the students because they are very courageous and, God willing, they always lead the way for the people,'' said Nemin Pustanil Arfin, a minibus driver. ''They are the ones who had the guts to topple Suharto and the faith to fight for the truth.'' **********As for the future, he said, ''I'm going to wait to see what the students do.'' **********The student movement is a curious political force, headless and leaderless, without a central organizing force. During the occupation of Parliament, representatives of more than 40 universities met separately, with little coordination. **********In the Parliament's courtyard, students from the various universities sat in separate groups, sometimes competing to compose naughty chants about Mr. Suharto. Now they are meeting on campuses across the country to discuss whether to support the new President, whether to call for a new election or a special session of the electoral assembly, whether to support individual leaders or broad principles. **********''You cannot call this a movement,'' said Muridan S. Widjojo, an anthropologist who is studying the student protests. ''It is impossible to say the students are unified. The do not have an organization or a structure or an ideology. Some try to embrace the opposition. Some still try to maintain themselves as independent groups. Some are ready to make coalitions with some prominent figures.'' **********As fellow students in jeans and shoulder-length hair lounged on the Salemba campus of the University of Indonesia, strumming guitars and talking politics, Roysepta Abimnanyu, 21, said they hoped to lead a transformation of Indonesia. **********''We don't want this to be just a teen-age movement,'' he said. ''We want this to be a people's movement for better conditions.'' **********This is an extraordinary moment in Indonesia, when all rules seem to have been cast aside. The strongman who held the country in his grip is gone, to be replaced by a President few people fear or expect to remain in office long. **********Political prisoners are being freed and are holding news conferences. The formerly timid press is suddenly one of the freest in Asia. No one can foresee the future course of the nation and many are relying on university students to set the agenda. **********''The most important thing is that the republic of fear has fallen,'' Mr. Widjojo said. ''The fear Suharto created over 32 years is gone. People are free to think what they want and say what they want.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/04/techn.body_text: **********WANT to prove to your wisecracking, history-challenged progeny that ''Roll Over Beethoven'' -- and not old Ludwig himself -- was all the rage when you were born? **********For an instant dose of personal nostalgia, just beam your Web browser to the dMarie Time Capsule (dmarie.com/asp/history.asp). Once there, type in a birthday or other significant date. The Time Capsule will reward you with a quick recap of the top headlines for the three months surrounding that date and the sports achievements and most popular songs from the year. You can find out other ephemera from that period, including average income, the prices of a stamp and a gallon of milk, and Academy Award winners. The site offers specific data for the years 1900 to 1997, although some facts from 1995 to 1997 are not available yet. **********The Time Capsule comes courtesy of dMarie.com, a do-it-yourself site that lets its users compile and lay out their own virtual scrapbooks and also features chat rooms, discussion boards and a poetry database. ''The information here is to serve as a fun, reminiscent stroll through past days,'' reads a disclaimer on the Time Capsule page. ''Use it to put together a heritage page for your scrapbook -- NOT for your school history report!'' **********While the Capsule provides a soft-focus-lens look at a certain time, surfing scholars looking for events occurring on a particular day may need to dig a little deeper. The History Channel's Web site has an on-line version of its popular ''This Day in History'' television spot (historychannel.com/thisday). After selecting a date, users are treated to a page of historical and pop-culture events that took place on that day. For instance, on this day in 1939, the first grocery-store shopping cart was introduced in Oklahoma City. June 4 is also the birthday of England's King George III (in 1738), and ''Love Me Do'' by his future countrymen the Beatles was topping the American pop charts on this date in 1964. **********Yahoo also boasts an extensive list of time-specific tidbits on its Today in History page. It includes a link to the Library of Congress's Today in History site, illustrated with items from the library's collection. More focused efforts, like the Literary Calender, Mathematicians Throughout the Year and Today in Movies, also round out Yahoo's collection (www.yahoo.com/Arts/Humanities/ History/TodayinHistory). **********The brief synopses these history pages offer -- particularly if you search, say, on your high-school graduation date -- are enough to transport you, emotionally at least, back in time. And if you can't remember all the words to what were your favorite songs, you might find them at the Lyrics Library Homepage (web2.kw.igs.net/wgarvin/ lyrics.html). You can find all the words to ''American Pie'' there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/01/busin.body_text: **********Vickers P.L.C., Britain's fourth-largest military company, agreed yesterday to buy most of Ulstein Holding A.S. of Norway for $:304 million ($502 million) in cash in a move that will extend its position as the world's biggest maker of propulsion equipment for ships. In addition, Vickers will assume $:42.5 million of Ulstein debt. The offer of 175 kroner a share for Ulstein is more than twice the closing share price on Nov. 23, after which the stock was suspended. **********Shares in Vickers, a British maker of tanks, marine propellers and turbines, fell 4 pence, to 179.5 pence ($2.96). Ulstein shares almost doubled, to 164 kroner ($21.73) from 86 kroner. The purchase fits with the Vickers strategy of expanding its business beyond armaments, an industry that is shrinking as governments cut spending.
