https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/16/busin.main_headline: Officials Aim to Prevent Short-Term Debt From Causing Another Crisis : Getting Banks to Lend More Carefully
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/16/busin.print_headline: Officials Aim to Prevent Short-Term Debt From Causing Another Crisis : Getting Banks to Lend More Carefully
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/16/busin.body_text: **********Why do banks overlend? Why are there no whistle-blowers calling for a lending halt? **********What kind of rules can be adopted that encourage the desirable free flow of long-term investment funds across borders but screen out the often destabilizing flights of short-term capital? **********These questions are at the top of the international agenda as officials sort through the Asian crisis to find a way to end the frequency of such international upsets. **********Answers are being sought by expert committees within the Group of Seven, which really consists of eight leading industrial countries: Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Russia and the United States. **********Likewise, at the Bank for International Settlements — home to the world's leading central bankers — the Eurocurrency Standing Committee, made up of the Group of Ten which is really 11 nations, is also looking for solutions. The G-10 does not include Russia, but it encompasses the rest of the G-7 plus Belgium, the Netherlands, Sweden and Switzerland. **********Now, still another forum looking into the issues of crisis prevention and management will emerge this week — the Group of 22. This group includes the eight countries from the Group of Seven plus Australia, Brazil, China, Hong Kong, India, South Korea, Mexico, Poland, Singapore and South Africa. Also on the list are four countries — Argentina, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand — who, unlike the others, are not members of the BIS. **********Like the G-7 committees, the new group will have not only central bankers but also politicians — Treasury and Finance Ministry officials who control the public purse. The deputies of these officials will hold their first meeting in Washington on Tuesday. **********The task of these officials will be to lay the groundwork for a ministerial meeting. The desire to hold such a meeting was spelled out by President Bill Clinton in November at the meeting of Asian-Pacific leaders in Vancouver, a U.S. Treasury representative said in Washington. She added that the president had said the meeting of ministers "from key countries" would explore "the implications of the current financial situation in Asia and the ways to deal with these challenges." **********As in the postmortems of earlier crises, there will be a call for better information — more timely, more reliable data on international lending and borrowing. **********But, although more complete information is always desirable, "it's unrealistic to hope that is a solution; it will not solve everything," warned Alexandre Lamfalussy, former head of the Bank for International Settlements. He noted that data published by the BIS had fully signaled the worrisome size of the pile of short-term debt that built up in East Asia and said published warnings from the BIS had been ignored. **********For Mr. Lamfalussy, the key question is "how to liberalize fully the flow of long-term capital, which is very desirable, without fully liberalizing short-term flows." **********Charles Wyplosz at the Graduate Institute of International Studies in Geneva, another proponent of restraining short-term capital flows, said that the inevitable calls for more data, more reporting and more disclosure were "politically cheap" solutions that amount to "a bureaucratic papering over" of the fundamental issue. **********He argued that apart from Thailand, which had serious financial problems, a crisis that need not have happened engulfed the rest of East Asia and was magnified once the International Monetary Fund became involved. **********"My main criticism of the IMF strategy," he said, is that it is "based on the crucial point that it does not want to recommend a moratorium" on debt repayments. "Either because it sees itself as an official agency that shouldn't support a strategy that goes against the law," Mr. Wyplosz said, "or because it fears it would be exposed to suit from creditors, the IMF always insists that every debt be repaid." In Mr. Wyplosz's view, this requirement not only worsened the Asian crisis but also contributes to the reasons that banks overlend. **********Although banks, he said, charge a premium to lend to risky debtors, this premium is not enough either to cover the real risk of default or to dissuade the debtor from borrowing. Instead, he said, the premium simply increases the attraction of lending to risky clients. **********"As a result," one international official said, "we get banks doing excessively risky business." **********"The sooner we get banks to accurately charge for the risk," he said, "and the sooner governments get out of the business of implicitly or explicitly guaranteeing the banks, the better off we will all be." He added that this inevitably would involve a redesigning of the unofficial safety net that currently prevents large internationally active banks from ever failing. **********He summed up by asking, "If you do something silly, do you have to pay for it? If you have a system that says 'no,' people will do a lot of things that are silly."

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/21/busin.snippet: Stock market stages comeback, with Dow Jones average closing at 8,413.94, up 33.36 points; graph (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/21/busin.main_headline: Markets Rally After Trading Lower for Most of the Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/21/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; Markets Rally After Trading Lower for Most of the Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/21/busin.body_text: **********The stock market staged a comeback yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average returning to positive territory after a decline Thursday snapped a six-day streak of consecutive records. **********Although it was lower throughout most of the day, the blue-chip average rallied, closing at 8,413.94, up 38.36 points, with companies like Merck, American Express and McDonald's among the leading gainers. **********Because of the expiration of stock options and futures, known as ''double witching,'' traders and analysts had anticipated a volatile session. **********While the Dow did rebound from early losses, which pushed it down as much as 57 points, the average failed to beat the high of 8,451.06 reached Wednesday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, however, did reach a new record, closing at 1,034.21, up 5.93 points. **********''People knew that they wanted to buy,'' said Alan Bond, chief investment officer at Bond Procope Capital Management in New York. ''It was just a question of how long they wanted to wait. They really want to own them,'' he said of investors' stance toward stocks. **********After strong gains among technology shares helped to push the Nasdaq composite index closer to its October 1997 record high of 1,745.85 on Thursday, the technology-laden index rose just 1.12 points yesterday, to 1,728.13. **********The modest gain, however, belied the strength of one of the Nasdaq's newest members, Doubleclick Inc. **********After trading as high as 31 3/4, Doubleclick closed at 26 3/4, up 9 3/4, or 57 percent, on its first day of trading. **********The New York-based company, which provides Internet advertising, sold 3.5 million shares at 17 in an initial public offering on Thursday. The size of the offering and original price range were increased based on expected strong demand. **********The success of the deal illustrated the keen interest of investors in Internet-related companies, said Mark Basham, a research analyst at Standard & Poor's. **********In an offering in late January, another Internet-related initial offering, Verisign Inc., a data security company, rose 11 1/4 from its 14 offering price during its first day of trading. **********Those stocks also benefited from the record highs logged by broader market indexes, which have made some investors less nervous about investing in riskier smaller-company shares, analysts said. **********Doubleclick also illustrates a pickup in the pace of initial public offerings, which got off to a slow start in January, said Linda Killian, a research analyst with the Renaissance Capital Corporation, a firm that specializes in such deals and is based in Greenwich, Conn. **********So far this year, 53 offerings, each exceeding $5 million, have raised about $2.7 billion, according to the Securities Data Company, a research firm in Newark. Over all the offerings have gained about 10.2 percent. That rise eclipses the 10.05 percent gain of the Nasdaq, and far outdistances the Dow's 6.4 percent rise this year and the S.& P.'s 6.6 percent increase. **********Although some analysts do not expect initial public offerings this year to exceed last year's issuance of about $43 billion, a continued increase in the number of such offerings could signal trouble for the market, said Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker. **********If the continued strong demand for equities causes the pace of initial public offerings and secondary stock offerings to outstrip demand, the stock market could falter, Mr. Cripps warned investors in a recent research report.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/02/techn.body_text: **********Yet another reason to stay indoors: Symbol Technologies has introduced the Infopen, a ball-point pen that is also a portable bar-code scanner. ''Whenever you notice that something is running short, you just scan the bar code of the product,'' said Michel Jacobeus, vice president for scanner marketing. ''Whether it be in the kitchen, in the bathroom, wherever -- you cannot drag a PC around with you.'' The user can upload the bar-code data through the included Infopen docking station into a PC and place an on-line order. The Infopen is $195. **********Home shopping is not the only application for the ball-point. Visitors to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Media Laboratory use the Infopen to scan one another's bar-code badges, which contain personal information and photographs.   SHOSHANA BERGER

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/21/busin.print_headline: GM Hopes to Recharge Adam Opel
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/21/busin.body_text: **********Gary Cowger is about to receive an all-expenses-paid immersion course in the German language, courtesy of General Motors Corp. **********He'll need it. **********GM announced Wednesday that it had chosen Mr. Cowger to lead its main European operations as chairman of Adam Opel AG, assigning to the relatively unknown executive the task of cutting jobs and costs, restoring competitiveness and helping spearhead GM's ambitious global expansion. **********Mr. Cowger, 51, will succeed David Herman, 52, who has headed German-based Opel since 1992. GM hopes that Mr. Herman's departure will bring to an end an embarrassing public feud in the top echelon of GM's international managers. **********After six years in the hot seat, sparring with other GM officials over Opel's role in GM's ambitious global expansion, Mr. Herman has asked to be moved to Moscow, GM says. There he will manage the company's comparatively tiny but growing operations in the former Soviet Union. **********By jumping to the head of Opel, Mr. Cowger will instantly assume one of the leading roles in European industry. **********Mr. Cowger will arrive as Opel's chairman at a pivotal time for Europe's third-largest carmaker. He will preside over Opel's plants in Germany, Poland, Hungary and the Netherlands and must complete a trenchant restructuring when Opel has struggled with stagnant profits and quality problems. In January, Mr. Herman struck a five-year job-cutting agreement with Opel's unions to reduce 4,000 jobs in its four German auto works, eliminating nearly 10 percent of the staff. **********The new assignment at Opel's headquarters in Ruesselsheim, just outside Frankfurt, amounts to Mr. Cowger's most high-profile position after 33 years with GM. From 1994 to the end of 1997, Mr. Cowger was president of GM's Mexican operations, helping make GM the leader in the Mexican market. At the start of 1998, he moved to Zurich to oversee production at GM's European plants. **********When other German carmakers have been posting record profits and sales, Opel has been backsliding. Because of the one-time charges to cover severance payments in Germany, Opel expects a 1997 loss of between 150 million and 250 million Deutsche marks ($84 million to $140 million). **********Without the charge, Opel's earnings would be stagnant at around the 314 million DM level reached in 1996, company executives said. **********Opel's unions, meanwhile, issued a statement saying they would withhold support for Mr. Cowger until GM's international strategy had been clarified. **********GM stands to gain handsomely with the appointment of Mr. Herman in Moscow. Mr. Herman's family is of Belarussian descent, and he speaks Russian. He also studied the Soviet economic system at Harvard University and gained a reputation as an East-West trade expert, making him an asset as GM negotiates two new joint-venture assembly operations in Ukraine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/25/busin.snippet: America Online's acquisition of Netscape Communications Corp marks company's entry into entirely new market, in which it will work behind-the-scenes to help corporations open and operate online stores; has already created software that made it pla...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/25/busin.main_headline: Building A Business Behind The Screen; America Online's E-Commerce Goals
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/25/busin.print_headline: Building A Business Behind The Screen; America Online's E-Commerce Goals
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/25/busin.body_text: **********America Online built itself into the most potent force in cyberspace largely by appealing to families with chatty teen-agers who want to flirt on line and adults looking for an easy way to send electronic mail while checking the weather and sports scores. **********Now, the company has to get serious if it is to win the hearts and minds of corporate executives in pin-stripe suits. **********Nearly lost in the complexity of America Online's deal to buy the Netscape Communications Corporation is America Online's announcement that it will enter an entirely new market: working behind the computer screen to help companies open and operate on-line stores. **********Netscape has already created software that made it a player in providing support for what is already known as electronic commerce. But America Online now says it has ambitions to offer a much wider array of software, consulting and services for on-line merchants. **********''Most companies that sell to consumers realize that they need to get into the E-commerce space,'' Robert Pittman, America Online's president, said in a news conference yesterday. ''We see a major business in offering them an end-to-end solution.'' **********The market is big and growing bigger by the day. Forrester Research estimates that $325 million will be spent this year on electronic commerce software and another $5.3 billion on services that range from graphic design to the turnkey operation of entire on-line stores. By 2002, Forrester estimates, the combined market for electronic commerce services and software should top $35 billion. **********''E-commerce services are the silver bullet that will enable companies to be able to take advantage of the true business opportunities on the Web,'' said Traci Gere, an analyst at the International Data Corporation. ''The market is growing very rapidly, but it is very fragmented.'' **********Analysts say the leader today in E-commerce services is I.B.M., which has a full line of offerings from sophisticated software products to hand-holding consulting. **********Other competitors include well-known information technology consulting companies like Andersen Consulting, the spinoff from the Arthur Andersen accounting firm; Electronic Data Systems, which runs computer systems for big companies, and PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offers accounting and consulting separately but under one umbrella. Software companies like Microsoft and Netscape sell packaged programs, typically with little or no consulting to help customers use them. **********There are also plenty of new companies that have sprouted up to provide electronic commerce services. Some, like Agency.com and Organic Online, started basically as advertising and design firms. Others, including U S Web and Viant, have emphasized programming and consulting. In fact, those two strains are blurring together, as exemplified by U S Web's pending merger with CKS Group. **********America Online argues that its advantage in this increasingly crowded bazaar is its ability to combine a broad subscriber base of about 15 million customers with Netscape software, plus hardware from Sun Microsystems, which has joined in America Online's venture into electronic commerce engineering. **********''This is the first time anyone has put a true end-to-end solution that starts with the silicon and ends with the audience,'' said Barry Schuler, America Online's president for interactive services. ''We start with Sun's line of servers, then the commerce tools to build a store, the support services to process orders and then a deal for on-line real estate that can drive the traffic.'' **********Despite the advantages Netscape and Sun bring, analysts say that America Online faces a variety of problems in its new quest. **********Chief among them is whether it can appear to have the consistency, focus and follow-through that corporate customers demand. **********''AOL is not the first company that comes to my mind when it comes to business-quality software,'' said Robert Chatham, a senior analyst with Forrester Research. **********Its decision to keep Netscape as a separate unit and offer electronic commerce services in partnership with Sun will not enhance its credibility, Mr. Chatham said. ''America Online doesn't look like a homogenous vendor,'' he added. ''It looks like customers will have to tangle with a menage a trois of AOL, Netscape and Sun.'' **********Nor have Internet service providers and other telecommunications-oriented companies shown much evidence, Ms. Gere of International Data said, that they are capable of offering the highly specific customized services that big corporate clients demand. **********''Telecommunications companies that try to do things efficiently for a large number of customers have not been able to offer customized one-to-one relationships,'' she said. **********Mr. Pittman said that America Online had been driven to the E-commerce business because companies that approached it wanting to sell their goods needed more help than simply advertising on line. **********''We are finding people who are expert in running bricks-and-mortar stores are limited by their infrastructure,'' he said. ''They have an on-line store, but their square footage is too small.'' **********Even before the Netscape deal, America Online was moving to provide some electronic commerce software and services. It has been rewriting the software that lets companies open on-line stores to be based on universally accepted Internet standards rather than the specific computer language used only on America Online. This new software, which now will be combined with Netscape's on-line store services, will be available for companies to use both on America Online and on the Internet. **********Similarly, it has developed a service that lets users create a file with their credit card numbers and shipping address so they can make on-line purchases without retyping all that information each time. American Online is working to offer it -- for a fee -- to stores on the broader Internet. **********There is a wide range of services that are incorporated in electronic commerce. These include high-end strategy consulting to help companies decide whether and how to sell on line without hurting their traditional sale in stores. There are all sorts of computer systems to be developed, ranging from the on-line stores themselves to connecting those sites to a company's existing inventory and accounting systems. **********There are creative services that include graphic design, media buying, customer list analysis and other marketing and promotional efforts. And there are operational services that involve actually maintaining the big servers that users connect to when they use the on-line stores that display catalogues, take orders and process payments. **********America Online, Mr. Schuler said, will emphasize services that relate to marketing rather than back-office functions. ''We will consult on how to merchandize and sell on line,'' he said. ''We understand the consumer piece of the puzzle.'' **********Some competitors worry that America Online's electronic commerce services may simply be a device to sell its software and hardware. ''The challenge is to prove that clients are getting the best possible solution for their business,'' said Robert Gett, the chief executive of Viant. ''If they offer AOL and Netscape and Sun, their answer is a bit tainted.'' **********Netscape does have an expanding force of about 700 people who provide consulting and custom programming. But they have been most competitive, Mr. Gett said, in competing for nuts-and-bolts projects rather than the more lucrative assignments to develop and carry out a full-fledged strategy on the Web. **********''They say, 'Who knows our software better than Netscape?' '' Mr. Gett said. ''We help customers decide which platform is best for them.'' **********But America Online argues that the combined might of it, Netscape and Sun is just what the business needs. ''We always believed that commerce, that is buying goods and services, is the huge revenue stream of the future,'' Mr. Schuler said. ''We have only seen the tiniest tip of the iceberg.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/05/world.snippet: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu has begun intense campaign, deploying Israeli officials and lobbyists, to prevent Clinton Administration from announcing specific proposal for reviving peace talks with Palestinians (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/05/world.main_headline: Israel Urges U.S. to Keep Peace Plan Quiet, but It's Already Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/05/world.print_headline: Israel Urges U.S. to Keep Peace Plan Quiet, but It's Already Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/05/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has begun an intense campaign, deploying Israeli officials and lobbyists to prevent the Clinton Administration from announcing a specific proposal for reviving peace talks with the Palestinians. **********The Americans, in negotiations with both sides, have been refining their proposal for an Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank in parallel with Palestinian moves against terrorism. But the Israelis are unhappy with the size of the withdrawal suggested and with the reluctance of the Palestinians to move against radical groups. **********The Israelis especially do not want the Americans to disclose their proposal before a compromise can be reached, saying public diplomacy will put unfair pressure on Mr. Netanyahu to accede on security issues. **********Israeli officials, including the Government's spokesman, David Bar-Ilan, are running around Washington seeing reporters, columnists and legislators like the Republican Senators Sam Brownback of Kansas and Jesse Helms of North Carolina. And Mr. Netanyahu is enlisting American Jewish leaders to help stave off a plan that senior American officials swear is neither imminent nor inevitable. This morning White House officials told Uzi Arad, Mr. Netanyahu's national security adviser, that there would be ''no surprises'' in the peace talks. **********A senior Administration official said later, ''Public mediation usually fails.'' But he said that if the stagnation continues, there is a ''logical progression'' that would involve ''getting them to accept our reasonable proposals.'' **********That is best accomplished with private diplomacy, the official said, although the idea of a speech by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright or by President Clinton laying out the proposal has been discussed. **********Israeli officials said they are concerned that the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, is trying to block progress in order to push the Americans to intervene more forcefully. **********Since Mr. Netanyahu knows Washington has made no decision to announce its proposal, some American officials say he is trying to limit the size of the American role itself by focusing his big guns now on a minor issue: a public announcement. **********But those guns are blazing, and the White House has heard them. **********On Monday night, at a dinner in Israel for the Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations, Mr. Netanyahu attacked the idea of American pressure on Israel. ''Only the people of Israel can determine what their security needs are,'' he said, ''and no third parties can impose what it should have as its security needs.'' **********Howard Kohr, executive director of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, said: ''We believe that a strategy of pressure will be counterproductive for the peace process, leading the Palestinians to look to the United States rather than Israel as their negotiating partner.'' **********Not everyone agrees. Jonathan Jacoby, executive director of Israel Policy Forum, said: ''This fear is unjustified. The Administration is proposing, not imposing.'' **********The outlines of the American proposal, which have in fact been leaked to the news media, include an Israeli withdrawal from 13.1 percent of the West Bank areas that it controls, in return for parallel Palestinian acts to fight terrorism. At the end of the withdrawal, which would be in third stages over three months, both parties would begin talks on a permanent peace agreement, and Israel would agree to halt expansion of Jewish settlements.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/06/world.snippet: Coverage of slow progress of Pres Clinton's penitence over his relationship with Monica S Lewinsky overshadows his trip to Russia, Ireland and Northern Ireland; Clinton remains popular overseas, but foreign leaders are aware that even without scan...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/06/world.main_headline: Clinton Trip Fails to Silence Doubt on His Domestic Clout
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/06/world.print_headline: Clinton Trip Fails to Silence Doubt on His Domestic Clout
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/06/world.body_text: **********It has been a question from the start of President Clinton's five-day trip to Russia, Ireland and Northern Ireland this week: will his domestic troubles affect his ability to function abroad as the nation's leader? **********The answer, from the President's aides, has been a resounding and unanimous no. **********But others are not so certain, and a strong piece of evidence came from Moscow on Friday, when Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the Acting Prime Minister, announced measures to try to pull Russia out of its economic tailspin. **********Less than a day after Mr. Clinton left Moscow, where he delivered a series of stern lectures on fiscal and monetary responsibility, Mr. Chernomyrdin proposed an ''economic dictatorship'' that would include a huge  infusion of new rubles to prop up failing banks, almost certainly a prescription for a burst of inflation and a step that Mr. Clinton specifically warned against. **********To be sure, Mr. Chernomyrdin is in a tough battle for confirmation and Russia's internal politics are little influenced by outside forces. But it was clear that Russia's leaders either were not listening to Mr. Clinton's lectures or they did not fear the effects of defying him. **********Other evidence came on the front pages of American newspapers all week, which were dominated by stories not of Mr. Clinton's diplomacy but of the slow progress of his penitence over his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky. **********Mr. Clinton took questions twice from reporters, during a news conference on Wednesday with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and a Friday meeting with Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland. **********Both appearances were overshadowed by questions about Ms. Lewinsky, and the coverage in the United States focused almost exclusively on the President's calibrated regrets over the affair. **********Scholars say it is impossible to separate a President's domestic fortunes from his prestige abroad. Although Mr. Clinton remains popular overseas -- particularly in Ireland, where he is given credit for supporting efforts that led to the Northern Ireland peace accord this year --  leaders recognize that even without the Lewinsky scandal, Mr. Clinton is a lame duck with a little more than two years remaining in his term, if he completes it. **********''It is difficult to be damaged goods at home and to be effective abroad,'' said Dmitri K. Simes, director of the Nixon Center research organization in Washington and a longtime foreign policy aide to Richard M. Nixon during his Presidency. **********Mr. Simes said that many Russians have written Mr. Clinton off, not only because he is crippled by domestic difficulties but also because Russians perceive him as being too close to Mr. Yeltsin, who is widely reviled by his countrymen. **********Mr. Clinton today lacks the moral authority to be ''a lasting partner for the Russians, particularly during the post-Yeltsin era,'' Mr. Simes said. **********Mr. Clinton's aides insisted that the President was not hampered in his ability to do his job by the low cloud of scandal hanging over him. **********Michael D. McCurry, the President's press secretary, said on Friday that Mr. Clinton operated in ''parallel universes'' -- battling scandal at home while conducting high policy abroad -- and declared that the two did not intersect. **********Asked whether Mr. Clinton's authority had been diminished by the Lewinsky matter, Mr. McCurry replied: ''It clearly has not been, and I think the President takes some satisfaction in that. He dealt with world leaders on this trip and is confident that he continues to do good work in the interest of the American people as he fulfills his constitutional responsibilities.'' **********In a less guarded moment, Mr. McCurry conceded that the Lewinsky matter had ''detracted'' from the main missions of the trip -- encouraging Russian leaders to stick to the course of economic reform and urging Catholics and Protestants in Northern Ireland to press ahead on the road to reconciliation. **********But Mr. McCurry and other aides blamed the press for an unhealthy obsession with the Lewinsky matter and for drowning out the President's message. ''It's all so circular,'' said one of Mr. Clinton's top foreign policy aides, his voice tinged with bitterness. ''You ask the questions and then you write that Clinton was forced once again to deal with Lewinsky. It hasn't come up in one meeting that we've had on this trip.'' **********But if the Lewinsky matter did not arise in meetings, neither did foreign leaders rally to the President's defense, at least not in public. Mr. McCurry assured reporters that Mr. Clinton had received many messages of encouragement from leaders around the world, but declined to identify any of them. **********Neither Mr. Yeltsin nor Mr. Ahern spoke on the President's behalf as he took questions about the scandal. Nor did Tony Blair, the British Prime Minister, with whom Mr. Clinton spent the day in Northern Ireland on Thursday. Mr. Blair offered Mr. Clinton private solace and public support during a visit to Washington last January, shortly after the President's relationship with Ms. Lewinsky was first disclosed. **********The trip has taken Mr. Clinton from meetings in a Moscow gripped by political and economic crisis to a meeting with families of the victims of the car bomb in Omagh, Northern Ireland, to a festive rally in the streets of Limerick this morning. Mr. Clinton's mood has shifted as dramatically as the settings: somber in Moscow, mournful in Omagh, upbeat in Limerick. **********Mr. Clinton was hailed as a peacemaker in his appearances in Northern Ireland and Ireland the last three days, and he clearly reveled in the warmth of his reception here. **********Everywhere his message to the Irish was the same: though terror will surely return, the will to peace will overcome those who seek to destroy it. **********Looking out over a sea of waving American and Irish flags among the crowd packed into downtown Limerick this morning, Mr. Clinton said, ''As we mourn the losses in Omagh and the three little boys who were killed and taken from their parents' arms, remember there will still be efforts by the enemies of peace to break your will, to get you to turn back, to get you to lose faith.'' **********''Don't do it,'' the President implored the enthusiastic throng of thousands. ''Don't do it. This is you at your best. Do not let them break your will.'' **********Mr. Clinton spent the afternoon pursuing the real reason he came to southwest Ireland today, playing golf at the historic course at Ballybunion. **********-------------------- **********Clinton Back in Washington **********WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The President and his wife, Hillary, returned to Washington late tonight, landing aboard Air Force One at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., at 11:10 P.M. after a flight from Shannon, Ireland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/12/busin.snippet: John C Malone, chairman of Tele-Communications Inc, has decided to use Sun Microsystems Inc's Java programming language rather than let Microsoft provide all the software for his interactive cable network; Malone seeks to create model that puts va...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/12/busin.main_headline: TCI Seeks Variety in Software And Suppliers for TV Boxes
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/12/busin.print_headline: TCI Seeks Variety in Software And Suppliers for TV Boxes
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/12/busin.body_text: **********John C. Malone, the chairman of Tele-Communications Inc., believes he can succeed where his predecessors have failed. **********With two deals announced at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Nev., this weekend, Mr. Malone has disclosed a plan that is intended to rein in the Microsoft Corporation's power and simultaneously fuel the dynamic economic growth that the cable television industry has been seeking so eagerly. **********By using Sun Microsystems Inc.'s Java programming language as a counterweight to a consumer version of Microsoft's Windows operating system, Mr. Malone is trying to relegate Microsoft to the same status as his other vendors. **********Rather than letting Microsoft provide all of the software for his interactive cable network, Mr. Malone is trying to create a model that puts the various components of the set-top box in the hands of numerous different vendors, much as if the box were a faucet and he were parceling out to different vendors the handle, washer, filter and pipes that affect the flow of the water. **********In this case, the water -- or programming -- is supposed to flow both ways, and needs a variety of software and hardware to do so. So Mr. Malone has created a ''layer cake'' business model in which each vendor provides only one piece of an integrated system that includes set-top box hardware, operating system software, the Java programming environment, software applications and a head-end server for distributing video and other digital content. **********But it is a risky gamble. **********Industry executives in Las Vegas this weekend said the cable industry infighting reminded them of the early days of the personal computer industry, where in 1981, I.B.M. initially offered PC buyers three competing operating systems: Microsoft's MS-DOS, the Digital Research Corporation's CP/M and UCSD Pascal. **********In the PC industry, however, consumers quickly settled on the low-cost alternative. Because Microsoft's operating system was the least expensive option, it became a standard, attracting the widest selection of software applications. **********Indeed, despite his efforts to create a more competitive marketplace, Mr. Malone may have repeated over the weekend the blunder made years ago by the International Business Machines Corporation. **********''Think of this as a poker table where most of the chips say Windows and William Gates is now holding them,'' said Richard Doherty, president of Envisioneering Inc., an industry consulting firm in Seaford, N.Y. In Mr. Malone's vision of the future interactive cable industry, the line between traditional television channels and personal computer software applications will rapidly be blurred. **********For example, while watching the History Channel, a television viewer  will eventually be able to use a handheld clicker to select a character on the screen and call up a box with additional information via the Internet. **********Because the new set-top boxes will actually be powerful computers, today's one-way channels will be complemented by the equivalent of personal computer programs that have been converted for the television screen, programs for bill paying, electronic mail or games. **********Mr. Malone sees this as nirvana for the ambitious cable television industry, which has consistently promised new services, like home banking, that it has proven unable to deliver. He wants his company to collect a portion of each electronic transaction made over the new interactive set-top boxes that Tele-Communications will begin offering to consumers in 1999. **********Tele-Communications is the nation's largest cable operator, with its boxes in 12 million of the nation's 65 million cable-equipped homes. The biggest, Time Warner Inc., is still in negotiations with a variety of potential suppliers for both software and hardware. **********Microsoft last year invested $1 billion in another cable company, the Comcast Corporation. Brian L. Roberts, the president of Comcast, said over the weekend, ''The industry has been searching for a new revenue stream for a number of years, and the prospect of this convergence is very promising.'' **********Mr. Malone, who is eager to avoid total dependence on Microsoft, is using Sun's Java as an additional layer of software to offer more choices to software developers and an alternative to Microsoft. **********The advantage of Java is that it permits software developers to write programs that can be run on many different types of computer hardware. That could be important if different and competing types of hardware are used in the set-top boxes distributed by the cable companies. **********A second advantage of Java is its security design, which is better than most personal computer environments today. The language was created by Sun engineers specifically to thwart rogue programs like computer viruses and worms, which threaten computer networks. **********Security is an important consideration if cable companies expect to gain the confidence of consumers they hope will do their banking, pay bills and shop via their television screens. **********But the more software applications are running, the more memory the set-top box will need, and more memory costs more money. **********On Saturday, Mr. Malone acknowledged that in order to run the Java alternative, it would be necessary to add memory chips to the set-top boxes. That, industry executives said, could end up consigning Sun to the same role as the losing personal computer operating systems in the early days of PC's. **********People familiar with the cable agreement signed by Sun and Tele-Communications on Friday said that in order to avoid that Sun's chairman, Scott G. McNealy, had agreed to pay Tele-Communications the additional costs to insure that there is room for the Java standards. **********Several company insiders said the payments could amount to as much as $10 to $12 a machine. Sun officials would not comment. **********At the same time, Mr. Malone also said Saturday that Tele-Communications was continuing discussions with Microsoft on a possible $1 billion investment to help build an interactive television network more quickly. **********One cable industry chief executive, who spoke on the condition that he remain anonymous, said the industry badly needs new sources of revenue and that at a practical level, it might be worth ceding domination to Microsoft if that would help add new revenue sources. ''Cable has not had a big new product in years,'' he said. ''We need the catalyst of Silicon Valley to move ahead.'' **********At the same time, although the battle has now been joined, it is clearly not over. In addition to Microsoft and Sun, Oracle, Intel, I.B.M. and AT&T are all still jostling for a place at the table -- or inside the new digital set-top box. **********Moreover, while Mr. Gates proposed a new computer-oriented digital television standard called HD0 in his speech at the Consumer Electronics Show on Saturday, the nation's television broadcasters have yet to settle on a standard. **********And then of course there is the largest unanswered question: Do television viewers care about any of this? **********The computer industry is betting heavily that consumers will be willing to open their wallets for these new services. However, with many American homes already paying $25 or more a month for cable, there is little evidence yet that they will be willing to foot the bill for the much-hyped interactive television of the future.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/busin.snippet: Brazil sells control of most of its telephone system for about $19 billion; auction of 12 pieces of Telecomunicacoes Brasileiras SA, known as Telebras, is dominated by Telefonica of Spain, Portugal Telecom and MCI Communications Corp--partners in ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/busin.main_headline: Brazil Sells Most of State Phone Utility
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Brazil Sells Most of State Phone Utility
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/30/busin.body_text: **********In the one of the largest privatization transactions ever, Brazil sold control of most of its telephone system yesterday for about $19 billion. **********The auction of the 12 pieces of Telecomunicacoes Brasileiras S.A., known as Telebras, was dominated by Telefonica of Spain, Portugal Telecom and the MCI Communications Corporation -- partners in a loose global alliance that spent a total of $11.6 billion. **********The sale was a success for the Brazilian Government, which raised 64 percent more than the minimum bids it advertised for the 12 companies of the broken-up Telebras. **********Coming amid the Asian economic and financial turbulence, when investors have been wary of emerging markets and economies like Brazil's, the auction's strong demand signaled confidence in the Brazilian economy, Government officials and Wall Street analysts said yesterday. **********For the big European and North American telecommunications companies that had winning bids, Brazil is a market with enormous growth potential. The world's fifth-largest nation, with 162 million people, Brazil has two-year waiting lists for telephones in some fast-growing areas. **********To be sure, multinational business customers are the most profitable segment of the telecommunications industry, and Brazil's prospects there are not as strong as those of some more advanced industrial and commercial nations. Indeed, companies like AT&T, which on Sunday announced a joint venture with British Telecommunications to serve multinational business customers, did not make bids. **********But the Brazilian market's sheer size and untapped profit opportunities were too potentially lucrative for companies like MCI, Portugal Telecom and Telefonica to ignore. **********Telefonica, which by dint of equity-stake purchases was already the largest phone provider for Latin America, bought the single richest license, spending $5 billion for control of the phone company that serves the Sao Paulo region. It also spent $1.2 billion for the wireless carrier that serves the regions of Rio de Janeiro and Espirito Santo. **********The success of Telefonica in yesterday's auction only serves to strengthen its alliance with MCI, which is to square off against the AT&T-British Telecom venture and the Global One consortium, which includes Sprint, Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom. **********For the auction, Telebras was split into three local phone companies, one long-distance carrier and eight wireless providers. While the Brazilian Government owned only about 20 percent of Telebras, it controlled 51 percent of the voting rights. **********The total sale was about 13 percent larger than the privatization of British Telecom for about $16.8 billion in the early 1990's, according to Securities Data of Newark. **********The auction of Telebras took about four hours on the trading floor of the Rio de Janeiro stock exchange. Near the exchange, police officers used tear gas, water cannon and batons against thousands of angry demonstrators, the Reuters news service reported. **********Opponents of the Brazilian Government contend that the privatization plan was a plot to deliver one of the nation's most valuable corporate assets into the hands of foreigners on the cheap. **********Brazil, which had been relatively slow in joining the global wave of privatization and deregulation, has now sold one of its last remaining state assets. The Government had already sold its stakes in Embraer, an aircraft manufacturer, and in steel, petrochemicals, railroads and much of the electricity industry. **********Among the large buyers yesterday were Telecom Italia S.p.A., which spent about $3 billion, and a Brazilian partnership of Andrade Gutierrez, a construction company, and Inepar, a communications and electric power equipment concern, which spent $2.9 billion. **********The Gutierrez-Inapar consortium spent $2.9 billion for control of the local phone company serving the Brazilian northeast, now the country's fastest-growing region. **********Telecom Italia spent $1.8 billion for the local phone company that serves the southern and central areas of Brazil, about $600 for the wireless company that serves the southern region and $570 million for the wireless company in the northeast. **********Telesystem of Canada spent about $650 million for the wireless company than serves the Minas Gerais region and $160 million for the wireless carrier for northern states. **********Portugal Telecom acquired the wireless company for the Sao Paulo region for $3.1 billion. Iberdrola, a Spanish electric power company, acquired the wireless carrier for the Bahia and Sergipe regions for $370 million. The wireless company for the central and southwestern parts of the country was acquired by Splice, a Brazilian high-technology concern, for $380 million. **********While yesterday's bidders could be concealing the identity of United States partners, MCI appeared to be the only such company to win licenses. It spent $2.3 billion for control of Embratel, Brazil's long-distance and international carrier. **********To acquire Embratel, MCI had to beat out Sprint, the No. 3 United States long-distance company. The two companies' initial, sealed bids were within 5 percent of each other, prompting an open auction process, which MCI won. **********Stock prices in Brazil surged yesterday after the Telebras auction. The main index of the Sao Paulo stock exchange rose 223.93 points, or 2.2 percent, to close at 10,542.41. In New York, American depository receipts of Telebras rose $4.9375, or 4.4 percent, to $118, after only two hours of trading. Also on the New York Stock Exchange, a basket security representing shares in the 12 spun-off companies of Telebras rose $5.6875, or 5 percent, to $119. **********The Brazilian Government was advised on the sale by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and by Salomon Smith Barney.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/02/world.snippet: United Nations special investigator Abdelfattah Amor rejects charges by Scientology movement that German Government is using Nazi tactics of persecution and ill treatment against it (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/02/world.main_headline: U.N. Derides Scientologists' Charges About German 'Persecution'
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/02/world.print_headline: U.N. Derides Scientologists' Charges About German 'Persecution'
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/02/world.body_text: **********A United Nations special investigator today rejected charges by the Scientology movement that the German Government is using Nazi tactics of persecution and ill treatment against it. **********''This comparison between modern Germany and Nazi Germany is so shocking as to be meaningless and puerile,'' the investigator, Abdelfattah Amor, said in issuing his report. The report counters criticisms made by Scientologists, and by the United States State Department in its annual human rights report. **********Mr. Amor, a law professor at Tunis University, compiled his report on religious intolerance and discrimination in Germany, looking not only at Scientology but at other religions, too, including Islam. He was appointed by the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, which is holding its annual meeting here. **********Emphasizing that he had spoken with Government officials and with Scientology officials, Mr. Amor said that the German debate over religious beliefs and freedom was overly emotional. ''There has been too much passion and exaggeration by all sides,'' he said. **********German officials have characterized Scientology as a commercial enterprise or a ''psycho group'' that manages people's lives, instead of a religion. This has denied Scientologists the legal and tax advantages enjoyed by established religions. **********In June 1997, German officials placed Scientologists under national surveillance for a year. Scientologists protested that such a step was unjustified without evidence linking their movement to criminal activity. **********The group maintains that the German Government has encouraged the blacklisting and boycotting of its members by requiring individuals to disavow any connection with Scientology or its teachings. **********Since November 1996, candidates for civil posts in the Bavarian government must state on a questionnaire any connection or belief in Scientology, but are not automatically banned from such jobs. Similar disavowals are required in Bavaria to join a political party, trade union, or any social, professional or sports club, as well as to sign a commercial or service contract or to open a bank account or obtain a bank loan. **********In his report, Mr. Amor said that German officials has maintained that the key question is not whether Scientology is a religion, but whether it respects the law. Government measures, he said, are ''simply designed to protect citizens and the liberal democratic order,'' by assuring the Scientologists do not, among other actions, use ''immoral and illegal techniques of psychological manipulation and repression.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/27/busin.body_text: **********A former Securities and Exchange Commission lawyer was sentenced last week to 18 months in jail for taking part in a stock-fraud scheme he himself had investigated for the Government. **********James W. Nearen, a former lawyer in the S.E.C.'s Denver office, will also be on probation for three years as part of the sentence imposed in Federal court in Brooklyn. District Judge I. Leo Glasser did not impose any fine or restitution. **********''I don't think you will ever know how sorry I am and how sad I am because I let this court down,'' said Mr. Nearen, who also lost his law license. **********Mr. Nearen pleaded guilty last year to securities fraud, money laundering and conflict of interest for taking part in a fraud scheme involving Comprehensive Environmental Systems Inc. and the Alter Sales Company. Prosecutors said he investigated the scheme, which involved fraudulent stock issuance and stock manipulation, as an S.E.C. lawyer, and then took part in it when he joined Comprehensive after leaving the S.E.C. **********Six other people have pleaded guilty in connection with the charges, which reports have said are related to a Federal investigation of the financial journalist Dan Dorfman over Mr. Dorfman's ties to a stock promoter who purportedly earned fees for introducing corporate clients to him. The promoter, Donald Kessler, is one of the six who have pleaded guilty.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/world.snippet: Egypt celebrates 25th anniversary of October 1973 war against Israel, starting festivities with mass wedding of 250 couples in shadow of Great Pyramids; both Egypt and Israel claim victory in the war, which was a turning point in Arab-Israel relat...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/world.main_headline: Cairo Journal; Praising Love and War, Beneath the Pyramids
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/world.print_headline: Cairo Journal; Praising Love and War, Beneath the Pyramids
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/03/world.body_text: **********In a nation whose modern history has provided little cause for celebration, there is always October. **********It was in October 1973 that the Egyptians and their fellow Arabs, so roundly defeated in every previous war with Israel, gained what they insist was a victory. And as the 25th anniversary approaches, it is clearly a memory that Egypt does not want a new generation to forget. **********A four-day ''silver jubilee'' that began today will feature a military parade, the first in 17 years. On Oct. 6, the anniversary of the day the war began, radio stations are to rebroadcast Communique No. 1, announcing that Egyptian troops had stormed across the Suez Canal. **********And to kick off the festivities, the Government staged a mass wedding  of 250 couples tonight in the shadow of the Great Pyramids, and broadcast it on television, in the clear determination that October might be remembered for years to come. **********The blend of war and romance has made for a passionate mix. **********''I am very proud that the happiest day of my life, which is my wedding, is the same day of the Israeli defeat, shame and sadness,'' said Iglal Adley, a 22-year-old law school graduate who was one of the brides taking part in the pageant. **********Less than a month ago Egypt allowed another anniversary to pass without notice, choosing not to commemorate the date 20 years ago when its acceptance of the Camp David accords made it the first in the Arab world to make peace with Israel. The slight was noticed in Israel, which has long bridled at the coldness of the peace. But in Egypt, the Camp David accords still evoke mixed feelings at best, and with little else in the recent past to cheer about, particularly on the Arab-Israeli front, the Government is trying to stir renewed pride on what is being remembered as a ''war for peace.'' **********''History is the memory of the nation,'' the Government newspaper Al Akhbar wrote in an editorial the other day, ''and the youth who did not live in the time of this great victory should know how Egypt defeated a foe that claimed it was unbeatable.'' **********In fact, the outcome was equivocal enough that Israel also calls it a victory, after it rebounded from the initial Arab attack, which came as Israel marked Yom Kippur. But no one disputes that the war was a turning point in the Arab-Israeli conflict. **********After the humiliations of 1948, 1956 and 1967, Egypt and its allies managed, for a short time, to regain the upper hand with a sudden thrust across the Suez that military historians have described as a masterpiece of planning and strategic surprise. **********In the first days of battle, Egypt on the south and Syria on the north advanced into Sinai and the Golan Heights, the territory that Israel had captured from them six years before. And while Israel regained control of those territories by the time of cease-fire, the war did prompt the first real consideration of the concept of land for peace. **********It was not until after Camp David that Egypt officially regained Sinai, but Egyptians have long been taught that it was what happened in October 1973 that restored the country's ''glory and self-confidence.'' **********In Egypt's recent history, only the 1952 revolt that toppled the monarchy and the 1956 nationalization of the Suez Canal are remembered with nearly as much zeal. **********A satellite city outside Cairo and a bridge that spans the Nile both bear the name 6 October, while in the capital itself, the first three days of battle (but, conveniently, not the ones that followed) are re-enacted in miniature at the October panorama. **********But some of the glow has faded with time. It was at a parade in honor of the anniversary in 1981 that Islamic militants assassinated President Anwar el-Sadat, and in the years since, the country's main preoccupation has been with internal problems. **********And so officials planning the 25th-anniversary celebration said they wanted to reach out to those too young to remember the war itself. **********Along with the tradition of an annual parade, they seized on a wedding at the Pyramids, designed to include in particular those born in 1973 -- in order, as Hosni Ghazi, deputy director of the Youth Authority put it, ''to remind the young generation of their glorious past.'' **********Dazzled by their free wedding dresses, flowers and the lavish entertainment -- all laid on by the Youth Authority and business sponsors -- many couples said that without this help that might not otherwise have been able to marry. **********In rural villages, mass weddings have long been embraced, and the Government has seemed to encourage the idea, even staging a 1992 wedding of 200 couples at Cairo Stadium, until tonight the largest that anyone could remember. **********But the fervor tonight often seemed less personal than political. **********Oula Mahmoud Sultan, 25, the bride who cut the cake, pronounced herself proud to be having ''such a big wedding at a time when all of Egypt is celebrating such a big victory.'' Because her father was killed in the war, she and her new husband, Ahmed Abdel Mohsen, 28, were granted a one-month honeymoon in Germany, a particular luxury, they said, because they still cannot afford an apartment of their own. **********''I do not want Egypt to ever fight again,'' Ms. Sultan said before the ceremony. ''But if it happens, I would be the first to fight.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/busin.snippet: Federal Communications Commission intends to propose rules that may accelerate deployment of high-speed cyberspace links to homes across the nation; commission will propose that nation's big local telephone companies be allowed to avoid reselling ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/busin.main_headline: F.C.C. Easing Rules to Build Data Systems
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/busin.print_headline: F.C.C. Easing Rules to Build Data Systems
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Communications Commission intends to propose rules tomorrow that may accelerate the deployment of high-speed cyberspace links to homes across the nation, officials said yesterday. **********As expected, the commission will propose that the nation's big local telephone companies be allowed to avoid reselling the use of their advanced data systems if they establish separate data subsidiaries, the officials said. **********If the proposal survives the lobbying that it will surely elicit, it will give the local Bell phone companies one of their biggest regulatory victories since passage of the Telecommunications Act of 1996. **********Currently, local phone companies must resell the use of their systems to new competitors. The incumbents have said the resale rules discourage them from investing to upgrade their lines to carry high-speed data because the resale obligation could prevent them from recouping costs. **********By giving the local phone giants, including the five remaining Baby Bells and GTE, a way around the resale rules, the commission is trying to encourage them to speed the introduction of high-speed on-ramps to the Internet. **********While broadband access to the Internet is becoming more common, it is still not nearly as available to everyday consumers as lawmakers anticipated when they passed the telecommunications act two years ago. That situation has created intense pressure from Capitol Hill for the F.C.C. to come up with results. **********''The major impediment that the Internet faces in becoming more useful to the American consumer is bandwidth capacity,'' said William E. Kennard, the commission's chairman, who supports the plan. The outline of the plan became clear a few weeks ago as the commission's staff issued the first draft of the proposal. Since then, F.C.C. officials have been hammering out details.  The proposal will provoke a high-stakes lobbying battle. The long-distance industry and new local carriers are expected to say that allowing the Baby Bells to avoid reselling their data systems will harm competition. The Bells are expected to say they should not have to create new subsidiaries to avoid resale rules.

Under the agreement, Primus will exchange stock valued at $10 for each of Trescom's 12.5 million shares outstanding. The deal is conditioned on Primus's shares maintaining a price of $15.89 or more. If Primus's stock is lower, the value of the deal will be adjusted downward. Shares of Trescom, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $9, on the Nasdaq stock market, where Primus, of McLean, Va., gained 75 cents a share, to $20.75, a new 52-week high. Warburg Pincus Investors L.P., which owns about 52 percent of Trescom's stock, agreed to support the acquisition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/15/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; Profit Woes Cause Broad Stock Losses
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Stocks fell again yesterday, pulled down by a host of year-end concerns that are not likely to be resolved for weeks, if not longer. **********Topping the list, according to analysts and traders, were worries about fourth-quarter earnings. Moreover, few expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates again anytime soon. And problems in important international markets like Japan and Brazil are continuing, and developments over the weekend in Washington did little to clarify how -- or when -- President Clinton's political future would be determined. **********''There are a confluence of negatives,'' said Michael Molnar, a managing director in retail sales and trading at Salomon Smith Barney. ''There is no doubt people are questioning earnings growth at a time when the market is not cheap.'' **********Unlike Friday, when the market turned in a mixed performance, every main market gauge was solidly negative yesterday. **********The Dow Jones industrial average fell for the fifth straight session, dropping 126.16 points, or 1.4 percent, to 8,695.60, its lowest level in six weeks. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 25.26, or 2.2 percent, to 1,141.20. The Nasdaq composite index had its worst performance since Nov. 30, falling 62.39, or 3.1 percent, to 1,966.92. And the Russell 2000 index of small stocks fell 7.43, or 1.9 percent, to 387.94. Nearly three stocks fell in price for every one that rose on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Mattel, the world's biggest toy maker, became the latest company to tell Wall Street that fourth-quarter earnings would not come close to expectations because of cutbacks in purchases by retailers. Mattel joined a growing list of companies, including Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble, that are facing difficult business conditions. **********''The earnings concerns are real,'' said Bill Allyn, head of listed trading at Jefferies & Company. ''Coke and Procter are companies that routinely hit their numbers. When these big, blue-chip, mother's milk companies surprise the Street, there is some concern.'' **********Mattel was the most active stock and the biggest loser in the S.& P. 500, falling 8 1/8, to 22. It was the stock's biggest decline in 16 years. **********Worries about weakness in foreign markets and economies also helped to drag down stocks. **********Stock prices in Japan fell more than 2 percent on Monday after the release of a survey of manufacturers showed that Japanese executives are the most pessimistic they have been in more than four years. And rumors that a capital-gains tax may be imposed on both foreign and domestic investors in Brazil prompted an 8.5 percent decline in Brazilian stocks. **********Worries about continued problems in these important countries translated into weakness in the stocks of companies that do a lot of business with them. **********I.B.M. fell 5 1/8, to 162 7/8. Another Dow component, J. P. Morgan, dropped 3 7/16, to 97 1/16. And General Electric lost 2 1/4, to 86 13/16. **********Technology stocks, which were extremely strong last week, pulled back sharply yesterday on profit taking and concern about the global economy. **********Microsoft dropped 6 1/16, to 127 15/16. Intel fell 4 7/8, to 111 9/16. Dell Computer slid 2 7/16, to 64 3/4. And Cisco Systems lost 3 1/8, to 80 3/8. **********Even with the sharp decline in technology stocks yesterday, the Nasdaq is still up more than 25 percent for the year. **********Elsewhere, stocks of some local telephone companies fell as the Federal Communications Commission considered whether to block Bell Atlantic's acquisition of GTE and SBC Communications' purchase of Ameritech. **********At hearings yesterday, the F.C.C. heard testimony from advocates for consumer and some competitors urging the commission to block the deals. The mergers are being scrutinized closely because if consummated, the new companies would control two-thirds of the local phone lines in the country. **********Bell Atlantic fell 1 3/16, to 53 1/2. GTE lost 1 3/16, to 63 3/16. SBC fell 1 11/16, to 48 1/8. And Ameritech dropped 1 5/8, to 56 5/8. **********Thomas Galvin, chief investment strategist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said he expected the market to resume its upward path. But he acknowledged that concerns about earnings would remain a factor for some time. **********''At the end of every quarter for about the last 10 quarters, the earnings sinners have spoiled the punch for everyone else,'' he said. **********''Until we get better information from companies that will have good earnings results, which won't happen until the second week in January, people will remain impatient. And, if you overlay that uncertainty with the political situation in Washington, it forces them to the sidelines.'' **********-------------------- **********Treasury Prices Rise **********By Bloomberg News **********Bonds rose for the fifth time in six days, bolstered by declines in stocks and by economic reports pointing to slower worldwide growth. **********''There are more worries about equities,'' and that's helping bonds, said John Burgess, who oversees about $90 billion at the Bankers Trust Company. Investors sought the safety of bonds as dim prospects for a recovery in Japan and concern about impeachment proceedings against President Clinton hurt stocks, he said. **********The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 18/32, to 104 3/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 4.99 percent from 5.02 percent. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction for three-  and six-month bills: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********3-Mo.
