https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.snippet: Netcheck Commerce Bureau is attempt at self-regulation of electronic commerce; agency, which has 700 corporate members in 80 countries, maintains list of companies involved in electronic commerce; visitors to Netcheck's site can register consumer ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.main_headline: Taking In the Sites; Finding Business Ethics on and About the Internet
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.print_headline: Taking In the Sites; Finding Business Ethics on and About the Internet
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.body_text: **********The World Wide Web is not exactly a haven for good business ethics. It can be a lawless place filled with unscrupulous operators pushing get-rich-quick schemes and other scams. **********Naturally, those who study business ethics worry about the Web. ''Every possible abuse of integrity and decency takes place on the Web,'' said Laura Pincus Hartman, director of the Institute for Business and Professional Ethics at DePaul University in Chicago. **********Randy Pennington, an ethics consultant based in Dallas, said there was ''a sense that moral and ethical values are not important'' on the Web. But that does not surprise him. ''There is no standardization in technology on the Web, so why do we expect standardization in behavior?'' he said. **********Mr. Pennington said that to avoid an attempt at ''regulation of ethical behavior in the future, the on-line community must regulate itself.'' **********''This country has a history of regulating those industries that do not control themselves,'' he added. Despite the global nature of the Web, he sees the possibility of Government intervention. **********The Netcheck Commerce Bureau is one attempt at self-regulation. The agency, which has 700 corporate members in about 80 countries, maintains a list of companies involved in electronic commerce. Visitors to Netcheck's site can register consumer complaints about anything from unsolicited E-mail to copyright disputes. There is even a place to compliment a company. The site's philosophy is that ''public pressure is the only real deterrent in this new frontier.'' **********The Web is also a great place to learn about and research the issues of business ethics, both within the Internet and beyond. An excellent starting place is the site of the institute at DePaul that Ms. Hartman heads. The site provides an introduction to business ethics but goes well beyond that. It is home to the Online Journal of Ethics and has comprehensive links to other sites that deal with the topic. **********The business of domain names and how they are registered involves some of the worst breaches of ethics on the Internet. Corporations and nonprofit groups are being forced to spend a lot of time, money and energy to fight piracy of high-profile .com and .org addresses. Even in the world of business ethics, names can be less than clear. For example, Business-ethics.org is the home of the International Business Ethics Institute, and Businessethics.org belongs to the Council for Ethics in Economics. The institute, which has a truly global background, has a site that contains a sparse brochure. The council -- which is trying to ''strengthen the ethical fabric of business and economic life'' -- has a more substantial site with articles from the quarterly publication Ethics in Economics, and texts of speeches on ethics organized by the institute, based in Columbus, Ohio. **********The Ethics Resource Center is a leading nonprofit ethics consultancy. The site offers information about the  center's work with large corporations in developing ethics programs. **********The Center for Business Ethics, at Bentley College in Waltham, Mass., is home to the Ethics Officer Association. This group represents the executives that help police many of the nation's large corporations. **********Few industries have been mired in as many questions about ethics, both real and perceived, as the military industry. One attempt to address its problems is the Defense Industry Initiative on Business Ethics and Conduct, a group of large military contractors, which has an in-depth site about the organization and aspects of Government contracting. Much of the information is applicable to other industries. **********Unlike many other sites, the Better Business Bureau site, which is run by the Council of Better Business Bureaus, is aimed at consumers in addition to the corporate world. It provides tips on various consumer frauds. It also has a guide to ''establishing an ethical business'' and a detailed code of advertising that explains common abuses and misleading claims. **********Establishing an ethics code is an important step for any company or industry, and a growing number of sites carry such codes. The DePaul site has compiled a list of direct links to a variety of codes, including Johnson & Johnson, Northern Telecom and the National Association of the Remodeling Industry. Also included is the code of ethics of the International Ethical Business Registry, a Canadian organization that promotes ethics codes. Among the aims of the registry: donating at least 10 percent of its gross income ''toward the betterment of mankind.'' Its site has pointers about setting up a first-time code and answers a common question: ''Is a code of ethics like a mission statement?'' **********(Answer: ''No. A mission statement states what you do. A code of ethics states how you do it.'') **********At first glance, a site that promises ''business ethics from an Islamic perspective,'' as the Islamic Training Foundation does, seems to be far removed from most of what is available on the Web. But in a closer look at some of the material, readers learn that Allah describes successful people as those who are ''inviting to all that is good, enjoining what is right and forbidding what is wrong.'' What non-Islamic business ethicist would not endorse such a view?

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/06/busin.snippet: Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers reaches tentative contract agreement with Screen Actors Guild and American Federation of Radio and Television Artists, but situation remains delicate and volatile; agreement, which is subject to ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/06/busin.main_headline: The threat of a strike by actors remains despite a tentative labor agreement.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/06/busin.print_headline: MEDIA: ENTERTAINMENT; The threat of a strike by actors remains despite a tentative labor agreement.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/06/busin.body_text: **********SHERRY LANSING, chairwoman of the Paramount Motion Pictures Group, said simply, ''You have to prepare for the worst, but hope for the best.'' Across town, Bill Mechanic, chairman of Fox Filmed Entertainment, said: ''You do what you can. You plan for contingencies.'' **********The two executives are hardly talking about a new deal with James Cameron -- the studios financed ''Titanic'' -- or a blockbuster gone awry. What's on the minds of Ms. Lansing and Mr. Mechanic is the possibility of a strike by actors that would not only damage the entertainment industry but also Southern California's economy. About 262,000 people work in the television and movie business in the Los Angeles area. **********Although the three-year contract between the producers and actors -- represented by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Radio and Television Artists -- does not expire until June 30, negotiations grew intense last week. Both sides bargained all weekend and reached a tentative agreement early yesterday morning. **********But the situation remains delicate and volatile. The agreement is subject to approval by a board representing both groups. And then the joint membership of 130,000 must vote on it, too. So must members of the management side, the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers. **********Richard Masur, head of the Screen Actors' Guild, said yesterday that he expected the membership to vote on the proposal in the next few weeks. ''I feel very secure that when we have a chance to present what's in the package that there won't be any disappointments,'' he said. **********The last actors' strike came in July 1980, stirring turmoil mostly with that year's fall television schedule until the actors returned to work three months later. But the most serious Hollywood strike in recent years took place in 1988, when the Writers Guild of America went on strike for 22 weeks. The walkout cost the industry and writers an estimated $500 million. (The writers, whose East and West Coast branches have engaged in a high-profile squabble in recent months, are now in negotiations on a new contract with producers and the networks. The deadline is  May 2, but, for the moment, studios seem to think that an actors' strike may be a more immediate threat than a writers' walkout.) **********At issue in the talks between the actors and management is the subject of foreign and cable television ''residuals'' -- the share of revenues that actors earn when their films are shown abroad or on cable. The unions insist that it is time for studios and companies to share the wealth they are reaping from such sales. They argue that the residual formulas -- set up in the 1980's, when the lucrative foreign marketplace was less developed and cable channels less numerous -- are outdated. **********Producers, on the other hand, insist that expenses have exploded: the average cost of making and marketing a movie has reached $75.6 million. Producers say that keeping costs down, and companies profitable, can create more jobs for actors. **********Under the tentative contract, both sides agreed to undertake a joint study to define the structure for a deal on the residual issues. The study is expected to be completed in two years. **********A strike would hardly affect the fortunes of Leonardo DiCaprio or Jerry Seinfeld. But 8 of 10 members of the Screen Actors Guild earn less than $10,000 a year from acting, and most hold down other part-time jobs to pay the rent. **********Mr. Masur of the Screen Actors Guild has said that a strike is just about the last thing his members want but that the union will call one if the members see no progress in their key demands. **********Film studios are reacting nervously to the threat of a strike. What especially concerns studios is the possibility of a strike in the midst of making a film. **********''We're taking precautions,'' Ms. Lansing said. ''We are not shooting any pictures that don't finish before a strike.'' Ms. Lansing said that she was hopeful, in fact, that films currently in production would be completed three weeks before the June 30 deadline. ''We want to have a three-week cushion,'' she said. **********Like many other studios, Fox is to start filming several new projects in July -- not May or June. So if a strike takes place, the studios would simply delay new productions. **********Mr. Mechanic, the Fox executive, said, ''Everything should either be wrapped or ready to start. We won't get caught in the middle.'' **********Mr. Mechanic said that the last thing the movie business needed was a strike. ''A strike is obviously bad -- and the only positive that could come out of it will be to perhaps slow down production,'' he said. ''Maybe all the studios will decide that less may be better and that the costs of movies are out of control. Maybe we'll get sane at the same time.'' **********Not every studio is alarmed about a potential strike. Dreamworks, for example, is moving ahead with film production that could be interrupted by a strike. And producers said that if a top star became available, other studios would take the risk, too. ''Believe me, if Tom Cruise said he wanted to start a movie before that deadline date, they'd start it,'' said Scott Rudin, one of Hollywood's most prolific producers. Mr. Rudin has three new movies about to start production -- a remake of ''Shaft,'' the adaptation of the book ''Angela's Ashes,'' and the film version of the television show ''South Park.'' None of them are starting before June 30.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/31/world.snippet: Herero tribe in what is now central Namibia is seeking apology from German Government for massacre of many tribe members by German soldier from 1904 to 1907; Germany seems to be wavering on edge of apologizing and even paying reparations, but poli...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/31/world.main_headline: Its Past on Its Sleeve, Tribe Seeks Bonn's Apology
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/31/world.print_headline: Its Past on Its Sleeve, Tribe Seeks Bonn's Apology
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/31/world.body_text: **********Asked where he got his traditional Herero dress hat, Alexander Tjikuzo, 63, answered, ''My grandfather left it to me.'' **********What is unusual about the old khaki hat with the round gold badge is that it is an imitation of those worn by the German soldiers who from 1904 to 1907 nearly wiped out the Herero tribe, which dominated what is now central Namibia. Locally, Mr. Tjikuzo is said to have one of the snappiest German uniforms that the Hereros wear on Red Flag Day and Heroes Day, when they visit the graves of their chiefs here. **********It was in this sleepy farm town in 1904 that the Herero finally exploded. For 20 years, German settlers moving inland had been stealing land and cattle, raping women, lynching men with impunity and calling them ''baboons'' to their faces. When the Herero attacked, they killed all the men, but on the orders of their leader, Samuel Maherero, spared women, children, missionaries and the few English and Afrikaner farmers. **********When word reached Kaiser Wilhelm II in Berlin, the counterattack was brutal and quickly expanded into slaughter, which some later saw as an ominous portent of the Holocaust. In a bizarre twist, many racist theories adopted by Hitler were being formed at roughly the same time here by a visiting geneticist. **********In this age in which national apologies are demanded, in which President Clinton expressed regret for slavery on a trip to Africa and German leaders have gone down on their knees to Jews and Poles for World War II, the Herero are asking for their turn. Germany seems to be wavering on the edge of apologizing and even paying reparations, but the politics of modern Namibia -- the former German colony of South-West Africa -- complicate matters. **********The historical facts are not disputed. Lieut. Gen. Lothar von Trotha, notorious for his butchery in German East Africa, was dispatched with 10,000 volunteers and a battle plan. **********Von Trotha pushed the Herero guerrillas and their families north to Waterberg and then attacked from three sides, leaving one exit: the Omaheke Desert. When the Herero fled into it, he poisoned the water holes, erected guard posts along a 150-mile line and bayoneted everyone who crawled out. **********He then issued the Vernichtungsbefehl, or extermination order:  ''Within the German borders, every Herero, whether armed or unarmed, with or without cattle, will be shot. I shall not accept any more women or children. I shall drive them back to their people -- otherwise I shall order shots to be fired at them.'' **********The remaining Herero were rounded up and sent to labor camps, where they starved or died of overwork, typhus and smallpox. **********By 1907 the order had been denounced and von Trotha had been recalled -- but the rebellion had been crushed. Before the war there were 80,000 Herero. In the 1911 census, 15,000 were found. **********Few people outside southern Africa or Germany have heard of the tribe unless they have read Thomas Pynchon's novel ''Gravity's Rainbow'' or seen travel books depicting their unusual clothes. **********In Mr. Pynchon's 1973 novel, a psychedelic take on World War II during the rain of German rockets on London, a fictional Herero battalion called the Schwarzkommando runs rocket batteries in the occupied Netherlands. Historians say they are a figment of Mr. Pynchon's imagination. The tiny numbers of black Germans, descendants of French African soldiers occupying the Rhineland after World War I, were sterilized by the Third Reich, not drafted. **********The unusual clothes are another issue. Alone in Africa, Herero women habitually wear hoop skirts. They adapted their high-waisted dresses and hats that jut out like cattle horns from the wives of Victorian-era missionaries. On holidays they wear versions of the dress in red and black, the colors of Herero nationalism -- and of the 19th-century German Empire. Their men wear the German volunteers' uniform. **********German diplomats are always invited to Herero celebrations. ''We are treated like V.I.P.'s and often asked to give the keynote speech,'' said one diplomat, who confessed that he is baffled by the practice. **********The peculiar attraction between the Herero and Germans here resembles the one in the Natal region of South Africa between the Zulus and British, two other peoples who fought a brutal colonial war. **********''It's the respect of a soldier for a soldier,'' explained Kuaima Riruako, paramount chief of the Herero. ''We never gave up our army, even during the German period.'' The chief is a leader in the quest for reparations. **********But the links are much closer. Because many Herero women were forced into sexual slavery to survive after the rebellion, many Herero today have German ancestors, and German is widely spoken here. **********Those relationships later helped underwrite Nazi pseudoscience used to justify the Holocaust. Eugen Fischer, a University of Freiburg geneticist, studied mixed-race children in the colony and concluded that each was physically and mentally inferior to his or her German parent. Hitler read his book, ''The Principles of Human Heredity and Race Hygiene,'' while in prison in 1923 and used its notions of subhuman races in ''Mein Kampf.'' Under Hitler, Fischer was named rector of the University of Berlin and in 1934 taught the first course for SS doctors. **********''This was the peak of scientific racism,'' said Frank Chalk, co-director of the Montreal Institute for Genocide and Human Rights Studies **********Now the Herero are a minor tribe, greatly outnumbered by the northern Ovambo people, who were beyond German reach in colonial days but led the fight against white South African rule, which ended victoriously in 1990. The governing party, the South-West Africa People's Organization, is dominated by Ovambo and many Herero belong to the opposition, so the Government does not back their quest. Per capita, Namibia gets more German aid than any other country -- $350 million since 1990 -- but almost every pfennig is spent in Ovambo areas. **********Another Herero leader, Mburumba Kerina, says his people do not want cash but ''a mini-Marshall Plan'' to get businesses started, and scholarships to German universities. **********''Helmut Kohl came here in 1995,'' Mr. Kerina said, ''but he refused to see us.'' Mr. Kerina led protests. **********In March, President Roman Herzog of Germany visited and the issue was raised anew, with different results. Calling the massacre ''a dark chapter in our bilateral relations,'' Mr. Herzog declined to apologize, but came close in saying that the colonial authorities had ''acted incorrectly'' and that the killings were ''a burden on the conscience of every German.'' **********He said international laws requiring reparations were not in place in 1907, but he promised to take the Herero petition to Bonn. **********One diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he would not be surprised if some aid were forthcoming, although it would never formally be called ''reparations'' and paying one tribe might offend others. The Nama, for example, rebelled after the Herero did and lost 50 percent of their population. But they never faced a written extermination order. **********A further complication is the nervousness of the country's small but economically powerful white German-speaking population. **********''It wasn't our generation that did it,'' said Eberhard Hofmann, editor of Allgemeine Zeitung, a local paper. ''It's like the biblical quote -- the sins of the fathers being paid for by the children. If you asked all the Germans in Namibia today, I'd say the majority would not want reparations.'' **********Since any apology and money would come from modern Germany itself, the issue would seem to make no difference to Mr. Hofmann's subscribers. But their real fear is land rights. Half of Namibia's 1.7 million people are impoverished and living in crowded tribal areas, while German-speaking ranchers own millions of acres seized 90 years ago. **********''We want reparations to buy land and give it to people who need it,'' said Chief Riruako. ''We don't want to seize it the way they're doing in Zimbabwe. I don't want to destroy.'' **********Efforts to win apologies gain strength when abuses on one side of the world are mirrored on another. Mr. Kerina, who like many Herero has a German grandparent, is delighted that Japan apologized for having kept Korean women as army sex slaves during World War II. **********''I thought, hey, that's my grandmother -- a comfort woman,'' he said. ''And I thought, if the Japanese could pay for that, the Germans could.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.snippet: Trial of former French Vichy official Maurice Papon for complicity in German war crimes during occupation in World War II is mired in controversy about whether presiding judge, Jean-Lois Castagnede, should step down after unexpected assertion that...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.main_headline: French Judge in War Crimes Case Said to Be Related to a Victim
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.print_headline: French Judge in War Crimes Case Said to Be Related to a Victim
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.body_text: **********The trial of a former French functionary for complicity in German war crimes during the occupation in World War II ended its 58th session early today, mired in controversy about whether the presiding judge should step down after an unexpected assertion that he was distantly related to one of the surviving victims. **********The judge, Jean-Louis Castagnede, who has conducted the trial of the former Vichy official, Maurice Papon, since it opened in Bordeaux on Oct. 8, gave no indication today that he would recuse himself, but suspended the trial until Monday without explanation. **********Marc Robert, a prosecutor in the case, said the judge had no idea that any relative of his had been a victim of the wartime roundups, arrests and deportation of Jews to Nazi death camps that Mr. Papon is accused of ordering when he was deputy head of the French civil administration in occupied southwest France. The judge, he said, had only the vaguest childhood recollection of the relative in question. **********Late Wednesday, the Nazi-hunter Serge Klarsfeld and his son, Arno Klarsfeld, representing several families that became civil parties in the trial to bolster the case against Mr. Papon, said they had discovered that an uncle of the judge named Jean-Pierre Castagnede had married Esterina Benaim, a Jew who had managed to escape deportation from Bordeaux with her family in 1943. Her parents and two sisters died in Auschwitz. **********''To our knowledge, Presiding Judge Jean-Louis Castagnede has avoided mentioning this relationship,'' Arno Klarsfeld said on Wednesday, and his father said today that the judge should disqualify himself. **********''He can't stay on as presiding judge,'' Serge Klarsfeld told Le Monde. ''There would be doubts about the verdict, so it's up to him to draw the consequences.'' **********Other lawyers for the civil parties, and prosecutors, expressed consternation today and puzzled over the Klarsfelds' motives. The Klarsfelds had pressed Judge Castagnede to keep Mr. Papon in custody during the trial, as is usual in such criminal cases, but the judge ordered the 87-year-old defendant released on his own recognizance because of frail health shortly after the trial began. **********''I'd rather disrupt the trial now than have it be disrupted in a few months, right before the verdict,'' Arno Klarsfeld said. Speaking of Mr. Papon's lawyer, Jean-Marc Varaut, Mr. Klarsfeld added, ''I don't want to let Mr. Varaut make the announcement on the eve of the verdict, which could taint it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/22/busin.snippet: Despite acknowledgment by Betty Sinnock, who brought together 16 women and founded Beardstown Business and Professional Women's Investment Club, that accounting error meant club earned only 9.1 percent from its stock investments, not 23.4 percent ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/22/busin.main_headline: Do Grannies Know Best, Despite a Fiscal Slip-Up?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/22/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT/MUTUAL FUNDS; Do Grannies Know Best, Despite a Fiscal Slip-Up?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/22/busin.body_text: **********BETTY SINNOCK brought together the 16 women who founded the Beardstown Business and Professional Women's Investment Club in 1983. It turns out, though, that Mrs. Sinnock may have made her greatest contribution to the Beardstown Ladies, as the famous stock-picking group became known, with an embarrassing accounting error more than a decade later. **********Remember that 23.4 percent annual return the ladies thought they had received on their investments from 1984 to 1993? It was heralded as trouncing the Wall Street pros in the club's 1995 best seller, ''The Beardstown Ladies' Common-Sense Investment Guide,'' and in four subsequent financial advice books. Well, the return would actually have been a modest 9.1 percent but for Mrs. Sinnock's mistaken data entries. The grandmothers from the rural Illinois town of 6,200 whom publicists called among ''the great investment minds of our generation'' would have been just another investment club falling unimpressively short of the 14.9 percent annual return for the Standard & Poor's 500 for that decade. **********The ladies might then have missed out on book royalties, exciting travel, television appearances, the thrill of turning their obscure hometown into a tourist stop -- and the fringe benefit of amusing marriage proposals. (Maxine Thomas, 77 years old, has 37 so far.) **********True, the club had achieved some prominence before Mrs. Sinnock's slip-up; it was spotlighted on ''CBS This Morning'' in 1991, for example. But the ladies became national celebrities with the ''Common-Sense Guide.'' The book, which spent nearly three months on The New York Times best-seller list, was subtitled, ''How We Beat the Stock Market -- And How You Can Too.'' **********Others would also have missed out if the group had not become so famous. The long bull market is the biggest factor in the growth of investment clubs, to more than 34,000 today from fewer than 13,000 in 1994, but the Beardstown Ladies are undoubtedly second, said Robert O'Hara, vice president of development for the National Association of Investors Corporation. Based in Madison Heights, Mich., the N.A.I.C., a clearinghouse for investment clubs, has long used the ladies as a stellar example of a club. **********Indeed, people love the ladies, who now number 14 and average more than 70 years of age, for their folksy manner and their message that average people can make money by researching stocks and investing steadily, and learn about the world and enjoy their friends at the same time. **********''A lot of our investors are saying that how well the ladies did is not the point,'' Mr. O'Hara said. ''The point is that the ladies invested all those years and have done well for themselves, as have those who followed their example.'' **********Moreover, thanks to improving performance since 1993, the annual return for the club's 14 full years has climbed to 15.3 percent, according to a Price Waterhouse audit. That compares with 17.2 percent for the S.& P. 500 in that period. **********Still, Hyperion, the publishing arm of the Walt Disney Company that has sold one million Beardstown books and just shipped 133,000 copies of the latest, ''The Beardstown Ladies' Pocketbook Guide to Picking Stocks,'' must be holding its breath. **********The trouble started last month when a Chicago magazine article delved into a disclaimer on the copyright page of a 1996 reprinting of the ''Common-Sense Guide.'' **********The disclaimer suggested that the ladies' track record might have been inflated by an incredible bookkeeping tactic: the dues put into buying stocks -- $25 from each member each month -- were not being subtracted in calculating the club's returns. The disclaimer had been inserted by Seth Godin Productions, a Irvington, N.Y., company that had assembled the books from interviews, its own research and papers from the ladies. **********Things got muddier when Mrs. Sinnock, 66, told The Wall Street Journal, also last month, that she did not think dues had been mixed with returns but was not sure. That is when Price Waterhouse was brought in to provide an independent audit of the club. **********That review led to the announcement last week that the disclaimer was mistaken. The returns were indeed inflated, the Beardstown Ladies acknowledged, but only because Mrs. Sinnock got befuddled by the N.A.I.C. computer program. Apparently,  none of the outsiders involved in assembling the materials for the books ''authored'' for the ladies by Seth Godin Productions had questioned the figures. **********''We are terribly sorry for the error,'' Mrs. Sinnock said. ''The ladies were very concerned that the public would think we had purposely misrepresented the results in any of our books.'' **********There seems little chance of that. Although some investment advisers say the Beardstown legend has contributed to dangerous overconfidence in the long-soaring stock market, it is hard to find investors who say  unkind words about the ladies. **********''I think they just made an honest mistake,'' said Frances Coe, vice president of Women Investing Now, a club in suburban Chicago. ''I really don't think they were doing it to sell books or anything like that.'' **********Nevertheless, the ladies may face exile to the heap of the ho-hum. ''You'd suspect sales won't be as strong going forward,'' said Marshall Loeb, the author of several financial advice books. **********Hyperion is expressing vague corporate confidence that demand will remain strong, promising to send out correction slips for books already out and to include correct data in ''all future printings.'' **********Seth Godin, president of the company that assembled the books, added that the Beardstown message is not about beating index funds but about coming out ahead of doing nothing at all. The ladies' next book, he said, will be a guide to estate planning. **********Judging from the warm reception for the four ladies who were featured speakers on March 14 at a fund-raiser in Oak Park, Ill., the Beardstown members will be out of the spotlight only if they leave on their own. **********The audience loved the cheerful shtick that accompanies their anyone-can-do-it message. ''From birth to 18, you need good parents,'' Mrs. Thomas advised. ''From 18 to 30, you need good looks and from 30 to 50 a good personality. But after 50, you'd better have some good investments.'' **********Elsie Scheer, one of three members in their 80's, told listeners she was ''looking after the hereafter'' -- as in ''I go upstairs, I go downstairs, I go to the basement and I ask, 'What am I here after?' '' **********And it is hard to go too wrong with the investing tactics they described here. ''We look at Value Line and we want to see 5 to 10 years of growth,'' said Carol McCombs, who is Mrs. Scheer's daughter. The ladies -- who have a $350,000 portfolio, far larger than the N.A.I.C. average of $90,000 -- also spread their risks among different sectors. **********No one at the fund-raiser asked about the inflated claims, although some conceded privately that they were curious. When asked what she would have said if the subject had come up, Mrs. McCombs answered: ''We're not worried about the numbers. We are just interested in getting people to save and invest.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/06/busin.snippet: Cyberspace Research Associates Inc, computer consultant, was reportedly monitored downloading hundreds of screens of proprietary Bloomberg LP data during one-day periods; Government is investigating whether Cyberspace Research was commissioned to ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/06/busin.main_headline: Reuters Consultant Seen Taking Large Amounts of Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/06/busin.print_headline: Reuters Consultant Seen Taking Large Amounts of Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/06/busin.body_text: **********A Manhattan computer consultant linked to a suspected scheme with a subsidiary of Reuters Holdings P.L.C. to steal information from Bloomberg L.P. was monitored downloading hundreds of screens of proprietary Bloomberg data during one-day periods, people briefed on the case said yesterday. **********The amount of information said to have been obtained from the Bloomberg terminal used by the consultant, Cyberspace Research Associates Inc., was so large that it significantly exceeded the amount downloaded by other Bloomberg customers. Indeed, at one point Bloomberg executives were said to have debated shutting down the consultant's terminal, but were persuaded to keep it active by law enforcement officials in order to allow the investigation to continue. **********The Government is investigating whether the subsidiary, Reuters Analytics, commissioned Cyberspace Research to steal the information from Bloomberg. The investigation, which has been under way for about a year, is examining whether the data were incorporated into products of Reuters, and whether officials used it to reconstruct analysis programs used by Bloomberg through a process known as ''reverse engineering,'' Reuters said in a statement this week. **********Michael Bloomberg, the chairman and chief executive of the company, did not return a telephone call seeking comment. Robert Crooke, a Reuters spokesman, also declined comment. Telephone calls to Cyberspace Research have gone unanswered for several days, and the line was disconnected yesterday. A telephone number for David Schwartz, the president of Cyberspace Research, could not be obtained. **********The investigation, which is being handled by prosecutors in the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, is said to be examining a number of possible charges, including violation of the Economic Espionage Act of 1996, which made theft of trade secrets a Federal crime. **********People who have been briefed on the case said prosecutors believe that Cyberspace Research obtained thousands of screens of Bloomberg data, the fundamental product of the computer system. Prosecutors believe that the information was then turned over to Reuters executives, these people said. The inquiry is examining whether that information was used in Reuters products. **********Cyberspace Research, a customer of Bloomberg, obtained the data directly from its authorized terminal. But, if it did so in order to turn the information over to Reuters, those acts would violate its agreement with Bloomberg and could well constitute a criminal fraud, lawyers said. Reuters was not a customer of Bloomberg, and indeed, companies in this industry do not allow competitors to have access to their computer systems. **********The most valuable data to obtain from a Bloomberg system, industry experts said, involve historical information about an investment, as well as related facts, such as payment dates for bonds. Bloomberg established a lead in such data early on, although Reuters maintained its strength in pricing data fed from exchanges and information known as ''contributed data,'' which is provided by financial institutions reporting in such areas as foreign exchange. **********In the week since Reuters first disclosed the grand jury investigation, Cyberspace Research has rapidly emerged as the linchpin of the inquiry. Federal prosecutors were said to have obtained more than 100 written communications between Reuters Analytics, which is based in Stamford, Conn., and Cyberspace Research. Moreover, law enforcement officials were said to have confronted an executive with the consulting company months before Reuters was told of the inquiry -- a sign that the consulting company may have been cooperating with the investigation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/14/world.snippet: Some United Nations officials are unhappy about Sec Gen Kofi Annan's celebrity, but his aides say they have no apologies to make about using Annan and his personal image to enhance standing of UN (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/14/world.main_headline: Annan's Stratospheric Profile Gives U.N. a New Cause Celebre
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/14/world.print_headline: Annan's Stratospheric Profile Gives U.N. a New Cause Celebre
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/14/world.body_text: **********For the first time in its half-century of life, the United Nations seems to be basking in the glow of a celebrity Secretary General. **********Kofi Annan, his aides say, is the man all New York wants at dinner parties. In this season of graduation speeches, photographers have zoomed in on him. He is held up as a fashion example, and this month George magazine named him one of the 20 most fascinating men in politics. **********The United Nations family is not totally united in happiness about this. When bulletin boards around headquarters became almost exclusively devoted to photographs of his every meeting and trip -- Kofi conquers Baghdad, Kofi goes Hollywood -- the grumbles started. Some officials called the addition of a pictorial Annan display outside the cafeteria a shrine. **********Camera teams began to accompany the Secretary General and his wife, Nane, just about everywhere. Then came a little booklet of speech extracts titled ''The Quotable Kofi Annan,'' published by the organization's Department of Public Information. Was someone, people asked, at work creating a cult of personality here? And if so, who? **********''I would not accept the term 'personality cult' because that's not the way the U.N. functions,'' said Shashi Tharoor, a close aide to Mr. Annan, as he acknowledged a role in these recent developments. ''Nothing could be more foreign to a man of Kofi Annan's extremely well-known modesty and humility as a human being.'' **********''But'' Mr. Tharoor added, ''we have no apologies to make about using Kofi Annan and his personal image to enhance the standing of the United Nations.'' **********A well-known writer on Indian politics and novelist, Mr. Tharoor has years of experience in the United Nations. He is about to become the Secretary General's communications director, a new slot in the system. **********''To put a warm and human face on the U.N. is almost basic public relations -- and Kofi Annan is that face,'' said Mr. Tharoor, who worked with Mr. Annan in peacekeeping and moved with him to the Secretary General's office last year. ''In his first year and a half in office, he has become increasingly identified to television viewers around the world, and indeed to headline writers.'' **********Gone, Mr. Tharoor said, are the days when New York magazine could joke, ''If you thought Kofi Annan was a decaffeinated brew . . . '' **********The Clinton Administration forced out Mr. Annan's predecessor, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, to get a leader it considered more attractive to Congress. But it has seen many hopes dispelled by Republican leaders' refusal to pay the organization a debt of over $1 billion. **********Still, Mr. Tharoor is optimistic, and banking on Mr. Annan's appeal. Critics may describe the United Nations as a glass box full of faceless bureaucrats, but Mr. Annan is a major exception. **********''Here we have someone who is neither anonymous nor faceless and comes across not as a bureaucrat but as a regular human being who thinks, who is reflective, is witty and cares,'' Mr. Tharoor said. **********''Given the difficulties in our relationship,'' he said, ''given the financial sword of Damocles over our heads, it would be crazy not to use the Secretary General's ability to reach out to Americans.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/28/world.snippet: Newly released Swiss court papers show that within weeks after police investigators found more than $130 million that Raul Salinas de Gortari, elder brother of former Mexican Pres Carlos Salinas, had secreted away in Swiss banks, Raul Salinas's wi...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/28/world.main_headline: Ruling Says Salinas Sister-in-Law Told of Bribes
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/28/world.print_headline: Ruling Says Salinas Sister-in-Law Told of Bribes
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/28/world.body_text: **********Within weeks after Swiss police investigators found more than $130 million that Raul Salinas de Gortari, the elder brother of former Mexican President Carlos Salinas, had secreted away in Swiss banks, Raul Salinas's wife admitted to the authorities that the money had come from bribes, newly released court papers show. **********In a procedural ruling issued late last week, Switzerland's highest court, the Federal Tribunal, indicates that United States prosecutors suspected almost from the start of their investigation that Raul Salinas had raised the money by protecting major drug traffickers. **********The Justice Department confirmed nearly two years ago that it had opened a criminal investigation into suspicious transfers by Mr. Salinas of more than $80 million through the New York headquarters of Citibank. But it had never publicly stated its suspicion that at least some of the Swiss money came from the drug trade. **********The Swiss court papers, issued in Lausanne, also establish for the first time that the money found in bank accounts of Raul Salinas in November 1995 totaled $132 million. **********Swiss officials have said they are ending their investigation into the origin of Mr. Salinas's frozen wealth.  They said they expected to confiscate the funds as drug money, but have not disclosed any evidence. **********United States officials have focused on Mr. Salinas in two investigations, but they, too, have not brought formal charges against him. **********In a telephone interview this evening, Mr. Salinas's wife, Paulina Castanon, said she had never intended to say that her husband had received bribes. She said a misunderstanding had arisen when she had been questioned in French by the Swiss authorities in late 1995 over her assertion that some of Mr. Salinas's money might have come from commissions he received on business deals. **********The 12-page Swiss ruling does not quote American officials directly, does not refer to Mr. Salinas and his wife by name, and its Swiss German wording is at times oblique. It suggests that Ms. Castanon, who was detained briefly in Switzerland, had made her statements to American investigators, but it does not state that directly. Nor does it specify whether the bribes that she acknowledged, according to the court papers, were kickbacks from companies that had business with the Mexican Government or payments by drug traffickers. **********Mr. Salinas has repeatedly denied having done anything illegal. He said last year that he had cashed in on ''huge opportunities'' that came his way as the President's brother. But in paraphrasing a United States request for Swiss legal assistance on Feb. 14, 1996, the Swiss document says the American prosecutors had argued that ''very important drug dealers'' had given Mr. Salinas part of his fortune ''to secure the undisturbed passage of drugs through Mexico to the U.S.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/01/busin.snippet: Article on rally in Japanese bank stocks in wake of scandals and closures in the industry; says rally in stocks can be linked to promise by Japan's banks to come clean on bad loans by adopting international disclosure standards; holds since Jan 12...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/01/busin.main_headline: Japanese Bank Rally Is Just Beginning
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/01/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH; Japanese Bank Rally Is Just Beginning
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/01/busin.body_text: **********The most important scandal these days might not be the scandal you've been reading about. It might instead be the one that is engulfing Japan's Finance Ministry. **********Two ministry officials were arrested last week on charges of taking payoffs -- mostly in the form of expensive meals -- and then doing favors for the banks that had fed them. A little titillation was supplied by the allegation that one of the bureaucrats had been entertained at a restaurant known for its scantily clad waitresses. The Minister of Finance and his top bureaucrat promptly resigned. Another bureaucrat killed himself, perhaps because of the investigation. **********As corruption goes, taking a free meal doesn't rank very high. But it looks as though those out to get the ministry have just started. By the end of the week, a Japanese newspaper was claiming that the ministry had suggested the scheme by which the now-bankrupt Yamaichi Securities had covered up huge trading losses. **********Viewed from across the sea, it appears that somebody in Japan's establishment has figured out that things must change economically, and so has decided to defang the Finance Ministry, hitherto the roadblock to reform. If that impression is correct, Japan may finally be ready to do what has long been needed -- stimulate its economy with a loose fiscal policy and use a lot of public money to clean up the sick banking system. **********If so, the last thing you want to own is stock in a Japanese bank that is about to be closed down. But what you should most want to own are shares in Japanese banks that are destined to survive. ''It is Citicorp at $10,'' says Robert Barbera, the chief economist at Hoenig & Company. **********Early in this decade, the American banking system looked as though it was going broke, and Citicorp shares fell to the single digits. Now they sell for well over $100. **********For years, Japan was in denial about its banks' problems. The Government's policy was to push interest rates down to almost zero and hope banks would use the cheap money to make enough profits to offset the bad loans whose existence was officially denied by both banks and ministers. The strategy did not work, as was clear even before bad loans to other Asian countries began mounting. **********On Jan. 12, the Topix index of 100 Japanese bank stocks was 73 percent below its level at the end of 1989 and 41 percent below where it was at the end of 1996. If it went much lower, that would imply the death of the financial system of the world's No. 2 economy. **********The next day, Japan's banks promised to come clean on bad loans by adopting international disclosure standards. That was one sign that the Japanese establishment realized action was needed. This week's scandal is another. **********Previously, there were false indications that Japan was going to act. But now the stakes are higher. With the rest of Asia in so much trouble, the need for action in Tokyo is clear. Without it, the implications for Japan, the rest of Asia and the world economy are bad, and there will be few good investments available anywhere. But if action is forthcoming, Japanese bank shares will soar, as American ones did after 1990. **********Japanese bank shares already have started to move. Since Jan. 12, the bank index is up 23 percent, much better than the overall Japanese market.  Among the better banks, Tokyo-Mitsubishi is up 10 percent; Sumitomo has gained 23 percent. **********If reform is coming, and the power of the Finance Ministry is really being broken, those moves are just the beginning.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/30/world.snippet: National debate is under way in Irish Republic over provision of new Northern Ireland peace agreement that would grant early release to Irish Republican Army prisoners convicted of terrorist acts, possibly including murder; agreement will be put t...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/30/world.main_headline: Debate in Ireland Centers on Provision to Free I.R.A. Prisoners
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/30/world.print_headline: Debate in Ireland Centers on Provision to Free I.R.A. Prisoners
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/30/world.body_text: **********A national debate is under way in the Irish Republic over a provision of the new Northern Ireland peace agreement that would grant early release to Irish Republican Army prisoners convicted of terrorist acts, possibly including murder. **********The peace agreement, which was approved on April 10 by political leaders of the Protestant majority and the Roman Catholic minority in the British province of Northern Ireland, provides that, after a review, paramilitary organization prisoners may be released within two years. The agreement will be put to separate referendums here and in Northern Ireland on May 22. **********The debate began five days after the agreement was reached, when nine I.R.A. prisoners serving terms for terrorist offenses were released early by the Irish Government. The act was widely seen as a concession to Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., both of which consider prisoners a major issue. **********There was an immediate outcry from politicians and the public that the agreement made it possible that murderers of Irish policemen would be released before serving mandatory 40-year terms. There are still about 40 I.R.A. prisoners, including several convicted murderers of policemen, in prison in Ireland. **********The focus of public anger, expressed by members of Parliament and in hundreds of calls to radio programs, is the case of Detective Sgt. Gerry McCabe. While escorting a cash deposit in an unmarked car, he was shot to death with a machine gun in June 1996 in the village of Adare, in western Ireland, by men later officially identified as I.R.A. guerrillas. They were arrested on murder charges in Limerick. No trial date has been set. **********On Monday the dead officer's brother-in-law, Pat Kearney, a member of the Limerick Chamber of Commerce, said in an interview on national radio that ''they should not be released for at least 40 years,'' adding, ''If I was in charge, I would favor execution.'' **********Mr. Kearney, a former policeman, said: ''The policemen put their life on the line to protect society. Society should protect the policemen. People tell me I am articulating what people are thinking, that the murder of Gerry McCabe had nothing to do with the political life of this country.'' **********Michael Kirby, the vice president of the Garda Representative Association, the police union, said the I.R.A. had murdered 13 Irish policemen since 1969, when the sectarian violence in the North began to grow. **********''We see these acts as criminal acts which could not be described as political,'' he said on Monday. **********The protest puts the Government of Prime Minister Bertie Ahern in a difficult position. Dublin wants to support all aspects of the new agreement, and does not want to antagonize Sinn Fein, hoping it will tell its supporters to vote for the new pact. Among other things, the agreement will give the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republic more influence in the affairs of the mostly Protestant British province. **********Mr. Ahern's Justice Minister, John O'Donoghue, said the men accused of killing the detective would not be released if they were convicted of murder. But many people, aware of the major concessions made to Sinn Fein to win its approval of the new agreement, fear that the Government may find a loophole for early release if the accused I.R.A. men are found guilty of murder. **********They point to the position of Sinn Fein, which has remained adamant that all I.R.A. prisoners, including those convicted of murder, be freed early under the agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/24/techn.snippet: Alice Keim reviews Bailey's Book House computer reading program for toddlers; photo (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/24/techn.print_headline: LIBRARY/READING TUTORS; Modest Approach for Toddlers
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/24/techn.body_text: **********BAILEY'S BOOK HOUSE **********AGES 2-5 **********(Edmark; $19.95; Windows 3.1, 95 and 98, and Mac 7.0.1 and later.) **********THIS is an example of interactiv ity that fails to interact. The Bailey's Book House program is popular but doesn't accomplish anything that could not be better accomplished away from the screen. **********Bailey is a cat who hangs out in his play book house. Different areas of his house lead to different learning activities. The Three-Letter Carnival section, for example, has two different areas of activity. The first area shows a lawn with different characters and objects scattered around. Click on any object and the word for it is written out and sounded out slowly. Reading with your child can accomplish this goal better. **********The second level is better. The child must fill each car of a roller coaster with rhyming words. If the first car has a bug in it, the user could click on pictures of a rug, a jug and a mug to complete the train. Every word is spoken out loud when the child picks it. **********If the user clicks on the typewriter in Bailey's house, the Letter Machine pops up. If your child likes to use the computer, this is an effective tool for teaching the alphabet and letter sounds. Clicking on any letter brings up that letter and a phrase using it. The sound quality of the program is excellent, and it is easy to hear the emphasis on the letter sounds. But, again, the same goal could be accomplished with a good alphabet book. **********The Read-a-Rhyme section is a wonderful area for parents to work with their children. The screen shows a phrase with a missing last word. In the corner are four pictures of words that would complete the sentence with a rhyming sound. The phrase ''Rub-a-dub-dub, three kids in a . . .'' could end with tub, sub, shrub or club, depending on the user's choice, and the completed sentence is then read aloud and the sentence is shown as an animated picture. Children find this hilarious. **********The My Friend activity is something like a digital Mr. Potato Head.  This area should help cement the words for body parts, like eyes and nose, but the presentation is too confusing. On the screen are an animated creature and three columns, two with descriptive words and one listing body parts. Click on a word to change the character's appearance. **********I watched some kindergartners play with this program and they clicked furiously, paying no attention to the actual words. Some of the level's elements are effective for teaching the children to identify body parts but not for recognizing actual written vocabulary. **********The program is designed for 2- to 5-year-old children and consequently does not require any reading skills. That is important, as many programs that cater to this age group fail to recognize that even the simple words ''click the mouse'' on the screen mean nothing to a child who cannot read. **********Children may learn some basic vocabulary from Bailey's Book House, but the program is too simple. Children will probably outgrow it quickly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/04/busin.snippet: A prolonged period of regional peace, combined with the collapse of the Soviet Union, has brought sharp shifts of trade patterns along the borders of China..Relaxed restrictions have paved the way for Chinese traders to sell a flood of cheap goods...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/04/busin.main_headline: Chinese Look to Their Neighbors for New Opportunities to Trade
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/04/busin.print_headline: Chinese Look to Their Neighbors for New Opportunities to Trade
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/04/busin.body_text: **********A prolonged period of regional peace, combined with the collapse of the Soviet Union, has brought sharp shifts of trade patterns along the borders of China. **********Relaxed restrictions have paved the way for Chinese traders to sell a flood of cheap goods to such poor and formerly isolated neighbors as Burma, Laos, Mongolia and Vietnam. **********Consumers snap up inexpensive Chinese-made building materials and plastic shoes, but many living along the edge of the world's most populous nation remain wary of ulterior motives. **********"Why do the Chinese come here?" asked R. Munkbat, a trader running a small shop in the Mongolian capital that sells soap, soft drinks and other household goods, including some from China. "China is so big that I am sure they want to try to take over Mongolia again." **********To China's south, recent treaties with Burma have ended years of bloody fighting and resulted in thriving trade and casino businesses along the border. But a distaste for the new trade is emphasized by merchants who complain about an onslaught of low-priced, inferior-quality goods and an often-repeated story that Burma's dogs and cats were being exported to China for food. **********In Vietnam, a traditional enemy of China, Hanoi has frequently griped that China is undermining the country's economy with an invasion of cheap exports. **********In Mongolia's case, suspicion of China is deep and historic. The 19th century domination by Beijing that ended with the integration of Nei Monggol, or Inner Mongolia, into China remains a more bitter memory than the recently ended 70 years of Soviet-backed dictatorship. **********Wary of Mongolian sensibilities, Chinese business executives tend to keep a low profile, but Beijing has been actively courting the government. Since 1991, China's president, prime minister, speaker of Parliament, foreign minister and the son of the late leader Deng Xiaoping have all visited Mongolia. **********The concrete result of this increased interaction is a treaty that completely opens the border between China and Mongolia for at least 30 days a year. **********Beijing's friendship offensive comes as cash-strapped Moscow is unable to keep up a Soviet-era level of influence in Ulaan Baatar. Diplomats describe the shift of influence in Mongolia from Moscow to Beijing as the eastern fringe of the modern struggle for power in Central Asia. **********A decade ago, almost no trade and investment came to Mongolia from China. Since opening up in 1991, Mongolia's trade with China has grown to $250 million in 1997. Mongolia's exports to China rose 24 percent in the first three months of this year compared with the same period last year. **********By some estimates, China now buys nearly half of everything Mongolia exports, including copper sent for accounting reasons through Switzerland. **********As foreign investors, the Chinese, with 260 joint ventures in production of clothes and milk and in the construction industry, now outnumber all other nationalities. **********The strongest effect of Chinese businesses is being felt in the cashmere and textiles industries. Mongolian cashmere factory owners complain that the more pro-active Chinese traders buy up the raw goats fur and refine it in China at lower cost. **********"I just cannot compete with them on their tight margins," a cashmere processor said at a recent investors conference in Ulaan Baatar. **********Government officials also allege that Chinese traders are taking advantage of low tariffs accorded Mongolia through its membership in the World Trade Organization. Although no new factories have been built in Mongolia, the country's textile exports more than doubled in the first quarter of this year to 10 billion tugricks ($12.2 million) from 4.8 billion tugriks for the same period last year. **********"Trade can be good, but we must be careful with China and be certain that rules are established," an adviser to Mongolia's prime minister said. **********Along the Chinese border in Burma's Shan State, local merchants and former rulers of the northern states also fear the consequences of open trade with their gigantic neighbor. **********"We're the next Tibet," a prominent hereditary ruler of Shan province told a visitor, describing the flood of traders and lengthy convoys of Chinese trucks carrying away Burma's tropical forest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/28/busin.snippet: Increasing number of banks, brokerage firms, money managers and mutual fund companies are wooing high-paid professional athletes; athletes and advisers face challenge of planning for lifetime of assets after brief playing period; photos (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/28/busin.main_headline: A Bigger League Is Playing to the Players
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/28/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT; A Bigger League Is Playing to the Players
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/28/busin.body_text: **********WALL STREET'S competitive culture has always been populated by more than a few sports fans. But now the institutions themselves -- banks, brokerage firms, money managers and mutual fund companies -- are developing a love of the game. Or, more exactly, a love of the players and their substantial paychecks. **********In a period when skyrocketing salaries and signing bonuses, multiyear contracts and lucrative endorsements can push annual incomes well into the millions, professional athletes as a group have become highly desirable and actively courted clients. **********A few institutions have gone as far as setting up separate departments just to serve athletes. For example, the Star Banc Corporation in Cincinnati opened such a division three years ago and put two former college football players and current vice presidents, Jonathan Hayes and Earl Layne, in charge of managing money for some 80 professional athletes. State Street Research and Management, the country's second-oldest mutual fund manager, which has guarded the fortunes of generations of patrician Bostonians, inaugurated its Athletes fund last autumn and hired a retired Bruins hockey star, Derek Sanderson, as resident rainmaker. Others, like Merrill Lynch & Company, have tried to make their sales forces more athlete-savvy. **********These companies are charging onto a field once used only by a handful of boutique money managers, like CSI Management in San Francisco or Investment Advisors International in Cleveland. (I.A.I. is a division of the International Management Group, which got its start representing golfers and tennis players in the 1960's.) **********''We are seeing a lot more competition, especially from traditional Wall Street houses and even Big Six accounting firms,'' said Leland H. Faust, president of CSI. **********Until recently, most professional athletes were considered anything but the carriage trade. Just ask John Havlicek, the legendary Boston Celtic and 13-time National Basketball Association all-star. Mr. Havlicek earned only $15,000 as a rookie in 1962, equivalent to about $80,500 today, and even worked in the off-season as a representative for a hardware and home-appliance company. He and a couple of other Celtics tried to pool their money and buy a few hundred dollars' worth of stock, but had trouble finding a broker who would take them on as clients, Mr. Havlicek recalled. **********According to Mr. Faust, ''When the top salary in major league baseball was $700,000, it wasn't chump change, but there were still a lot of higher-paid people around.'' Now, when the median salary in major-league baseball is $1.3 million, he said, ''you have a bigger market.'' **********Athletes now ''qualify as bona fide clients,'' Mr. Faust added. **********As a rule, however, athletes are very different from other clients in their income bracket, like corporate executives, doctors or lawyers. They are typically much younger and suddenly wealthy -- often signing fat bonus contracts in their teens -- and have spent their lives learning to excel in their sport, not in finance. Many are from small-town or working-class backgrounds, and few have had much exposure to money management. They have too often been prey to dubious advice from flamboyant agents or hangers-on. **********As a result, institutional money management for professional athletes has become a specialty that combines private banking and trust-department functions with the roles of coach, psychologist and even guardian. **********Advisers find themselves steering clients clear of risky ventures like nightclubs and restaurants, car-wash franchises and oil-and-gas partnerships that are often pitched to athletes and other celebrities. ''Every day I see guys lose money on bad investments,'' said Victor Green, a defensive back for the New York Jets who recently signed a three-year contract for a total of $3 million and keeps his money with Star Bank, a unit of Star Banc. **********ATHLETES and their advisers also face the challenge of planning for a lifetime around a peak earnings period that can be agonizingly brief. **********John L. Macklin, president of I.A.I., which has $1 billion in assets under management and counts Mr. Havlicek and the retired tennis champion Martina Navratilova among the firm's clients, says he invests an athlete's money as if it were the portfolio of a 58-year-old executive just a few years shy of retirement. **********Such an outlook calls for a fairly conservative strategy. Star Bank's portfolio managers typically suggest a mixture of about 60 percent large-cap equities, 30 percent bonds and the remainder in money market funds. Specific stocks that Star Bank recommends to athletes include Walt Disney; Sofamor Danek, a medical-supply company, and Clear Channel Communications, which operates a large chain of radio stations. **********At State Street Research, F. Gardner Jackson Jr., a portfolio manager, says the firm's new Athletes fund, which requires a minimum initial investment of $500,000, is mainly invested in large-cap growth stocks, and performs like a State Street institutional mutual fund that had a 47.4 percent total return for the 12 months ended April 30, a bit better than the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index during the period. The fund holds stakes in 55 companies including General Electric, DuPont and two hot drug companies, Warner-Lambert and Pfizer. **********Advisers often find themselves helping their athlete clients with day-to-day money matters. Surrounded by temptations to spend heavily on luxury clothes and cars, multiple homes and late nights on the town, professional athletes sometimes need reminding that succumbing would mean robbing their own future, the advisers say. **********Kenneth W. Ready of the Denver office of Prudential Securities, who has about 50 football players as clients, said one player called him from Las Vegas to ask for more money after he had lost $4,000 gambling. ''I told him no,'' Mr. Ready said, ''and he got mad. But when he got back to Denver, he gave me a big hug.'' **********At Star Bank, Mr. Layne, who played football at Liberty University while earning a degree in finance, has attracted many players as clients with similarly personalized service. He and Mr. Hayes, who founded the bank's pro sports division, routinely take care of extracurricular tasks like seeing that clients' bills are paid and that their insurance policies are renewed on time. **********Not all clients, of course, need or want such help. And advisers say it is often hard to persuade naturally aggressive athletes to play it safe with their money. ''I tell the guys that they are already on third base and don't need to hit a home run,'' Mr. Layne said. ''All they need to do is hit singles and doubles, and that will get them home.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/05/busin.snippet: Congress is moving toward most sweeping overhaul of nation's patents law in 45 years, but it is unclear whether legislation will receive final approval this year (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/05/busin.main_headline: Patents; An overhaul of the rules is possible, but opposition to the plan remains fierce.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/05/busin.print_headline: Patents; An overhaul of the rules is possible, but opposition to the plan remains fierce.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/05/busin.body_text: **********CONGRESS is once again moving toward the most sweeping overhaul of the nation's patents law in 45 years, but it is unclear whether the legislation will receive final approval this year. **********The patents bill has been held up for several years, in part because of heavy opposition from some inventors. Last year it was passed by the House and approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee. The bill would make four key changes: ***********It would broaden the rights of third parties to initiate a full-fledged re-examination by the Patent and Trademark Office of patents that have already issued. ''Currently, in most circumstances you have to go to court,'' said Jay R. Thomas, an associate professor of law at George Washington University. ''This would turn Patent Office officials into judges and is similar to what other countries do. The question is, can the U.S. Patent Office handle this responsibility?'' ***********It would require the publication of patent applications after 18 months; now they are kept secret until the patent is issued. ''The idea is that you enrich the bank of technology information, no matter what the fate of an individual patent,'' Professor Thomas said. An amendment tacked on in the House would exempt independent inventors and universities from this provision, thereby creating ''a lot of loopholes,'' he said. ***********It would give greater rights to those who, instead of seeking a patent, protect their technology as a trade secret. Under current law, those who keep their ideas trade secrets are considered infringers once a patent on similar technology is issued to someone else; the infringer must either stop using it or pay royalties to the patent holder. ''Right now, winner takes all,'' Professor Thomas said. ''This would spread the wealth by allowing trade-secret users to keep using the technology without penalty.'' ***********It would recast the Patent Office as a semiprivate corporation much like the United States Postal Service, on the theory that it would be run more efficiently. **********The legislation has faced spirited opposition from many independent inventors, whose symbolic leader was Jerome Lemelson, an inventor who had been granted about 500 patents and successfully challenged several companies with infringement suits. Mr. Lemelson died last fall, but inventor groups say that his absence will not diminish the opposition to the patent bill. **********Alexander Fraser, president of the Inventors Network of the Capital Area, said the most troublesome aspect of the legislation was the part that would make the office a semi-private corporation, with a board of directors from the private sector. **********Mr. Fraser posed this hypothetical situation: ''Imagine that you are a patent examiner and I come along with my new transistor that will cut Sony's profits by 50 percent. Sony has a member on the board controlling the corporation. Is the examiner going to give me my patent?'' **********Bruce A. Lehman, the Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, who initiated much of the patent legislation, called such fears ''absolutely ridiculous.'' **********''In fact it's quite the opposite,'' he said. ''Politics would be taken out of the Patent Office, to the extent that it is here.'' **********Important Rulings Awaited on Appeals **********Two important decisions are expected this year from the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, the highest patent court in the nation: ***********In re Zurko. This case turns on a narrow technical issue that has much broader implications about how much deference should be made to previous Patent Office rulings when the appeals court decides to hear a case. ***********State Street Bank and Trust Company v. Signature Financial Group regarding a patent for a financial management technique. This long-awaited ruling should help establish what types of business practices can be patented. ''A lot of patents are issuing that people are starting to get embarrassed about,'' said Professor Thomas, who cited as examples a recent patent covering a way to swing a golf club and another that covers a method of remodeling a home. ''Unfortunately,'' he said, ''the delay in the ruling doesn't bode well'' for a decisive opinion. **********Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/31/busin.body_text: **********Three marketers have announced their choices of agencies to handle their accounts. **********The Motley Fool in Alexandria, Va., a personal finance and investment site on the Internet, selected the Martin Agency in Richmond, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were not disclosed. The decision came after a review in which the other participants were not identified. **********The Miller Brewing Company in Milwaukee, part of the Philip Morris Companies, named UNO Comunicaciones in Dallas, a unit of Square One, to handle advertising aimed at Spanish consumers for the Miller Lite beer brand. Billings were not disclosed. **********The account had been handled for a year by Lucero/Bentz in Dallas, a joint venture of Square One and Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis; the venture was dissolved in April. UNO, which was selected without a review, will work with Fallon McElligott, which continues as the Miller Lite agency of record. **********And Advance America in Spartanburg, S.C., named BBDO South in Atlanta, part of Omnicom Group, to handle its account, which had been handled by Bazil-Victory in Greenville, S.C. Billings were estimated at $12 million. The decision came without a formal review. Advance America offers cash advances to cover unexpected expenses in exchange for a personal check that is held until the next payday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/busin.main_headline: Auto Dealers Settle Charges of Boycott
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/busin.print_headline: Auto Dealers Settle Charges of Boycott
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/06/busin.body_text: **********A group of 25 auto dealers in the Northwest agreed today to settle Federal charges it illegally threatened to boycott the Chrysler Corporation in an effort to thwart competition from low-priced Internet dealers. **********In an agreement with the Federal Trade Commission, the car dealers, members of the Fair Allocation System Inc., agreed not to participate or threaten a boycott of any automobile manufacturer. The Montana-based group includes a substantial number of Chrysler dealerships in eastern Washington, Idaho and western Montana, the F.T.C. said. **********The F.T.C. said the group planned to boycott the nation's third-largest car maker unless it restricted distribution to rival dealers that market on the Internet. Group members threatened to refuse to sell certain Chrysler vehicles and limit warranty service, the F.T.C. said. **********The group primarily picked as a target Dave Smith Motors of Kellogg, Idaho, a Chrysler dealer that had been attracting customers by offering low, pre-determined prices via the Internet, the Federal agency said. **********Chrysler allocates vehicles based on a dealer's total sales. Fair Allocation System members wanted the company to distribute based on expected number of sales in a dealer's local area. That would have substantially cut the number of cars to Dave Smith Motors, whose customers hail from a wider geographic region, the F.T.C.'s complaint contended.
