https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/05/your-.print_headline: VII- Weir Group:Unfairly Priced : Near the Bottom, Looking Up:Stocks That May Deserve a Break
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/05/your-.body_text: **********Adverse industrial sentiment has played havoc with the valuations of British manufacturing companies. Weir Group Ltd., a Scottish engineering company that produces valves and pumps for export, has had almost 37 percent wiped off its share price since February. The shares closed Friday at £1.985 ($3.30), despite what some describe as positive fundamentals. **********"While most British engineering companies with a strong export bias have been hit by the crisis in Asia and currency problems at home, some companies have proved to be more resilient than others," said Judith Mackenzie, a broker with Glasgow-based brokerage firm Bell Lawrie, White & Co. "But, it would appear that this resilience is not always reflected in the company valuation." **********"Given the Weir Group's full order books and strong earnings potential, the share price should be up at around £3.00," she said. "Weir Group supplies components for basic infrastructure projects, such as sewage systems. These projects are less likely than, say, more sophisticated and costly projects to be put on hold during times of economic uncertainty. Weir Group is still getting orders from its main export markets in Asia and Eastern Europe, despite extensive economic problems in these regions." **********If valuations do not pick up soon, Ms. Mackenzie said companies like Weir could become the targets of predatory U.S. conglomerates. She added: "Managers of some British engineering companies are getting increasingly frustrated by what many in the industry see as unjustifiably low valuations. It is possible that some of the companies effected will be bought out by management."

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/14/world.snippet: Blood feuds, which follow precepts laid down in medieval canon, is again part of Albanian society in which it lay superficially submerged during 50 years of Communist rule; since early 1990's revenge killings have spread among clans in village of ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/14/world.main_headline: Feuds Rack Albania, Loosed From Communism
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/14/world.print_headline: Feuds Rack Albania, Loosed From Communism
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/14/world.body_text: **********Beneath the snow-splashed escarpments that protect northern Albania from the outside world and have left life much as it was centuries ago, the Sylaj family have been cooped up on their homestead for months, too afraid to move. **********A blood feud, following precepts laid down in a medieval canon, hangs over the men of the household, including the patriarch, Shaban Sylaj, 99, who welcomes visitors with a two-tooth grin, wisps of ash-colored hair poking out from under his skullcap. **********Mr. Sylaj's son, Chel, 38, shot and killed another Albanian man in January, and now the dead man's family have the right, under the still-flourishing code, to take revenge. Their target is one of the Sylaj men. **********The threat is real. Since the early 1990's, revenge killings have spread among the clans here, where the precepts of Lek Dukagjin, a 15th-century chieftain, prize honor and freedom above honesty, and where vengeance is the ruling passion. **********Weapons -- pistols in the old days, automatic assault rifles now -- are valued as much as human life: a man who kills another man and takes his weapon too can be avenged with the taking of two lives. **********''Who knows how many people have been killed through revenge?''  said Man Mulosmani, 64, a clan leader who is preaching reconciliation rather than retribution. ''Countless, countless. People don't want to report killings to the police because then the accused would be protected by the state in prison instead of being available to kill.'' **********This closed corner of Europe was described by British spies who trekked here on mule and foot during World War II as the wildest physical -- and psychological -- terrain on the continent. It is still reached by a precipitous dirt road hacked out of the mountains and a jade-tinted lake that swerves through vertical limestone cliffs and stony land. **********For nearly 50 years, the world's most isolated Communist system superficially submerged the customs that decree an eye for an eye and keep women in the lowliest position. But as Enver Hoxha's Communism evaporated at the beginning of this decade, so did the temporary covering it provided for ingrained ways of living. **********When the Albanian police force and army disintegrated during civil strife last year and the arms depots stashed with assault rifles and mortars sprang open, revenge killings skyrocketed. With households heavily armed and escaped prisoners in possession of armories of weapons, the Tropoje region became off-limits for outsiders, even for Government officials from the capital, Tirana. The fact that the sparsely settled area is the stronghold of the former President, Sali Berisha, adds to the inability of the new Socialist Government to impose order. **********In some places, like the village of Dragobi, the instability of the past and the present are easy to see. The Ismaeli family's house, for example, has narrow slits in the limestone walls. They are ideal for aiming a gun at the outside world while providing protection against anyone who might want to attack, family members explained. In their living room, a hole in the wall covered by a sliding door once served as a hiding place for their grandfather's pistol. Now this is where the women keep their embroidery. Instead of a pistol, the family now keep assault rifles. **********As hard as Mr. Mulosmani, a retired agronomist with a shock of white hair, tries to mediate between feuding families, it is a difficult task. He spent a session cross-legged on the Sylajs' living room floor -- a manner borrowed from the Turks who dominated Albania until 1912 -- discussing ways to avert more bloodshed. He came away with no resolution. **********Intended to regulate medieval life, the Canon of Lek, as it is known, has been perverted by people to suit their own needs, Mr. Mulosmani said. Now, the lawless society floats between the ages-old customs and a state unable to adapt to modernity in the wake of Communism. **********For example, Fatmir Haklaj, 27, recently resigned as police chief of Tropojo to avenge a family murder and is reported by his former colleagues to have killed, or ordered the killing, of eight men so far for the murder of his brother. His brother was sprayed with nine bullets in January. **********The leader of one of the most powerful clans, Mr. Haklaj vowed that he would kill one man for every bullet pumped into his brother's body, his colleagues said. According to Mr. Haklaj's arithmetic, he has one killing to go. **********Last week the opposing Hoxe clan, which is accused of killing Mr. Haklaj's brother, were in mourning after burying a relative who they believe was the latest victim of Mr. Haklaj's revenge. The police have stood by, pleading powerlessness. **********The unchecked violence in the Tropoje district is combined with extreme poverty. **********The Communist-era hospital has been looted so often that robberies have subsided because there is nothing left to steal. International aid agencies are too frightened to come to help. **********Many families make do with one chicken a week made into broth and served with a plank of hard cornbread. There is no industry and only families who have men abroad -- often as illegal immigrants in Greece or Italy -- can make ends meet. Those families sometimes flaunt their flimsy foreign contact with pictures of Western starlets pinned to their walls. **********Such families usually spend the first remittances from abroad on a television set. But those wealthier families remain self-sufficient, living off the land, even down to the limestone rocks that are fashioned into bricks in outdoor kilns. **********The Ismaelis in Dragobi are one such family. Another is the family of Hatixhe Selimi, 42, a teacher in Valbone, a tiny settlement near the border with Kosovo. **********By necessity, Mrs. Selimi is a prudent homemaker. For her 12-year-old daughter, Aurela, and her 7-year-old niece, Viola, she uses milk from her cow, makes feta-style cheese and bakes bread from water and corn in a wood-burning oven. For guests, she serves potatoes and cabbage from her garden. She and her daughter dress in Western castoffs sold at outdoor markets and keep warm in socks hand-knitted from the wool of their sheep. **********When Lek conceived his canon in the mid-15th century, women were held in such low esteem that they were exempt from most feuds and were regarded as chattel to do a man's bidding. Today, women still back out of a door so as not to show disrespect to the men in the room. **********Under the Communists, Mrs. Selimi was allowed to choose her own husband. But such freedom was unusual even then and is getting rarer now. The old rules of arranged marriages are back in vogue, she said. **********Asked how the Canon of Lek affected women now, Mrs. Selimi rolled her eyes, held her breath and looked around her living room, where several male visitors were gathered. **********''Well, I suppose I'll tell you,'' she replied tentatively. **********Last year, she recounted, there was a marriage ceremony in Valbone. As usual, the wedding feast was strung out over several days. Suddenly the festivities stopped. **********The groom had discovered that his bride was not a virgin. He dispatched her back to her parents. **********Later, unable to bear the shame -- the worst kind of affliction in these stubborn highlands -- the young woman slipped away down the mountains to the anonymity of the lowlands.

TrizecHahn agreed to sell the 20 malls in April to Westfield America Inc. of Los Angeles and to the Rouse Company of Columbia, Md. Among of the office properties it bought are 12 buildings from the Equitable Life Assurance Society for $561 million. It also bought Laing Properties Inc., a unit of the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company of Britain, which owns nine office and warehouse properties, for $300 million, and the Silver Spring Metro Plaza in Silver Spring, Md., for $91 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/08/busin.snippet: Dilemma of workers who are laid off and then asked to sign waiver releasing company from legal claims discussed; photo of Paul C Bevan, former Honeywell marketing director who refused to sign and later won age-discrimination lawsuit, and $900,000 ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/08/busin.main_headline: Laid Off? Dismissed? To Sue or Not to Sue
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/08/busin.print_headline: EARNING IT; Laid Off? Dismissed? To Sue or Not to Sue
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/08/busin.body_text: **********AS if getting laid off wasn't bad enough, a growing number of workers have an extra-tough decision to make on their way out the door: whether to forever give up their right to sue the boss. Those who do can walk away with a sweet deal. Those who don't gamble that they'll be better off in the long run. **********Consider the case of Paul C. Bevan, a former marketing director for Honeywell Inc. in Minneapolis, who was replaced by a younger man and  laid off in 1992. At the time, Honeywell offered Mr. Bevan $273,000 if he would release the company from any legal claims. Mr. Bevan, who was 52 and had been with the company for 24 years, refused to sign the release. Honeywell then reduced the severance package to about $60,000, he said. **********Soon after the layoff, Mr. Bevan sued Honeywell, contending age discrimination. His five-year battle ended last summer when the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit upheld a jury verdict in his favor. The award, including interest and legal fees, was more than $900,000, he said. Honeywell declined to comment beyond a statement saying it had a ''corporate-wide policy'' against discrimination. **********In asking for a release, or waiver, companies want to rule out trouble down the line -- discrimination cases based on race, sex or age. A waiver is ''almost standard operating procedure whenever severance is given out,'' said Janice Goodman, an employment lawyer in Manhattan. **********Courts have said these waivers are legal as long as they are given voluntarily for ''adequate'' consideration. That usually means anything more than an employee would otherwise be entitled to, Ms. Goodman said. If the company does not normally give severance pay, which is not required by law, a worker may need to sign the release to get anything at all. **********In deciding whether a waiver is valid, the issue is not how much the company will pay but ''the circumstances under which the waiver was obtained,'' Ms. Goodman said. Economic coercion -- withholding severance unless the waiver is signed -- is not illegal, she said, though how far a company can go has yet to be tested. **********The key Federal law on waivers is the 1990 Older Workers Benefit Protection Act, which covers people older than 40. It says companies must give workers at least 21 days to decide whether to sign waivers and 45 days if a group of people is being terminated at one time. The waiver must let workers know that they are giving up the right to sue for age discrimination and must say that they have at least seven days after signing to change their minds. **********When a release is part of a voluntary buyout or a program offered to a group of employees, the company must give more information, including selection criteria for the program and the ''class, unit, or group of individuals covered''; the job titles and ages of the people selected, and the ages of people ''in the same job classification or organizational unit'' who are not eligible. **********Until recently, it was not clear whether workers who sign invalid waivers must return the severance money if they sue. Last month, the Supreme Court said they did not. **********That case involved Dolores Oubre, a former scheduler at a nuclear power plant in Killona, La., run by a unit of the Entergy Corporation. After she received a poor performance review, Entergy offered her a choice in early 1995 of trying to improve or resigning and receiving $6,258 in severance pay. Entergy gave her 14 days to make the decision -- a week less than the law requires. Ms. Oubre, then 41, signed the waiver. **********When she sued later, contending age discrimination, the company tried to get the case thrown out. Even if the waiver was invalid, it argued, the contract was binding because Ms. Oubre kept the money. **********Two lower courts ruled in Entergy's favor, but the Supreme Court reversed the decision on Jan. 26. Ms. Oubre must still prove that she was dismissed because of her age. **********While employment lawyers hailed the case as a victory for workers, they called the circumstances unusual. ''Don't sign a release with the idea that you're going to be able to disavow it later,'' advised Wayne N. Outten, a New York lawyer who has helped negotiate thousands of severance agreements. A better course, he said, is to ask for as much time as you need to decide and to talk to a lawyer before giving up any rights. **********Before pursuing legal action, of course, a key question is whether you have a good case. No matter how badly employees feel they have been treated, they do not have a claim unless it fits into some legal framework like discrimination, wrongful termination or violation of a law protecting whistle-blowers, said Gary Laturno, a San Diego employment lawyer. Even then, they should not count on hitting the jackpot. **********Typically, workers just get back pay -- the salary and benefits they would have earned from the time of dismissal until a court decides the case. If an employee finds another job while pursuing the case, the award is cut by whatever the person has earned at the new job. **********HARDER to predict is the effect on an employee's psyche, finances and career should the worker turn down the waiver and proceed with a lawsuit. **********Six years after he was dismissed, Mr. Bevan is negotiating an agreement to license his own invention -- a device to create an undulating practice-putting surface for golfers. But he had a tough time finding new employment while his case against Honeywell was pending. **********Ultimately, a former colleague helped him land a position in Boston as a branch manager for a company that makes fire alarm and building security systems. He resigned in January to spend more time marketing his invention. **********Mr. Bevan said he did not regret suing, but ''there's no calculation you could run that would show the return on investment was worthwhile.'' **********Lawyers typically advise clients to try negotiating a better severance package before contemplating legal action. Those with the most bargaining power are high-level, long-term employees with a good case, said Nancy Erika Smith, an employment lawyer in West Orange, N.J. Often the company is willing to improve on its initial offer, she said. **********One former vice president at a Midwestern advertising agency negotiated six months' salary and health benefits, instead of the three months of pay that was first offered. Other items that can ease a transition cost a company little, such as outplacement help, favorable references and the right to keep the company car or personal computer or to buy them for a nominal sum. **********A lawyer need not handle the negotiations. One marketing executive laid off from a large consumer products company never let on that she had a lawyer coaching her behind the scenes. As the lawyer counseled, she met with a personnel representative, rather than accepting a telephone brush-off. Though she had been with the company less than a year, she persuaded it to pay three-and-a-half months' severance -- a month more than the company had offered. **********Even after paying the lawyer, she figured she was $4,000 ahead. And, she said, she learned an important lesson. ''Always attempt to negotiate before you accept the first thing they hand you,'' she said. ''You have nothing to lose.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/09/world.snippet: Senior American and NATO officials say that NATO effort to persuade Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic to back down is following a clear track; say it is designed to ratchet up political and military pressure, while providing him with various opport...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/09/world.main_headline: NATO Plans to Intensify Its Pressure on Milosevic in Stages
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/09/world.print_headline: NATO Plans to Intensify Its Pressure on Milosevic in Stages
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/09/world.body_text: **********The NATO effort to persuade the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, to back down is following a clear track, senior American and NATO officials said today. It is designed to ratchet up the political and military pressure, while providing him various opportunities to change his mind. **********First, the American envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, will try to win Mr. Milosevic's compliance during a last-ditch mission to Belgrade beginning on Friday. **********If Mr. Holbrooke fails or if his mission is protracted, NATO countries will vote within days to increase his leverage by giving the last required permission to the NATO Supreme Commander, the Gen. Wesley K. Clark, to begin air strikes against Serb positions and troops. **********That go-ahead -- known as an activation order -- requires the unanimous vote of all 16 NATO members. Afterwards, General Clark could proceed on his own timetable. But first NATO intends to make a significant display of its preparations -- the forward deployment of attack aircraft, for instance. **********The military plan has already been agreed upon: a series of phased attacks, intensifying at each step, with pauses built in to allow Mr. Milosevic and his military commanders to back down. **********The last phase -- an intensive attack on military installations anywhere in Serbia -- may require another NATO political vote first, the officials say. The same pattern held true when NATO bombed Mr. Milosevic to the bargaining table in 1995, over Bosnia, and NATO never did have to go to the final stage of its attack. **********If Mr. Milosevic ''simply intends to defy'' the international community, NATO's goal will be ''to destroy his capacity to inflict violent repression on the Kosovars,'' Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said. **********Mr. Milosevic's main backing is in the security forces and special police, not in the regular Yugoslav military, which is not likely to want to have its expensive air-control and command systems blasted by NATO. **********NATO aims not to destroy Mr. Milosevic but to persuade him to comply. The point, a senior NATO official said, is to negotiate and to get aid to refugees. ''NATO has no intention of going to war against Serbia or on behalf of an independent Kosovo,'' the official said. **********Mr. Milosevic, the Administration official said, has pulled out of Kosovo only about 60 percent of the troops and special police that NATO is insisting leave. Mr. Milosevic must withdraw the forces sent into Kosovo since February and keep in barracks the forces normally stationed in Kosovo, the officials said. **********Before February, there were 12,500 troops in Kosovo and about 6,500 special police, American officials said. There are now about 18,000 troops and 11,000 special police, the officials said, and while some of the troops are in barracks, none of the special police are. **********If Mr. Milosevic complies, NATO wants clear procedures to monitor his continued compliance, so that his troops do not pour back in to Kosovo. To do that, the West will need more than the 50 or so diplomatic observers currently in Kosovo. **********Some NATO countries feel strongly that a number of NATO ground troops must be used, in addition to troops from other organizations, for adequate monitoring. American officials, reluctant to put American ground troops into Kosovo, oppose the use of NATO troops, though the use of NATO aircraft and intelligence-gathering is foreseen. **********It is only in the last few days that Mr. Milosevic has begun to take seriously NATO's threat to use force, the Administration official said. **********The NATO official was blunter: ''Milosevic doesn't doubt NATO's capacity to carry out these attacks, but he does doubt our will. We have to convince him. The question becomes whether you just have to shout more loudly, or actually hit him before he gets the point.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.snippet: Prime Min Tony Blair announces that he is opening new judicial inquiry into killings of 14 unarmed civil rights marchers by British soldiers in Northern Ireland on Jan 30, 1972: Blair's action amounts to reopening of widely disparaged investigatio...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.main_headline: BRITAIN TO REOPEN ITS INQUIRY OF '72 IN ULSTER KILLINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.print_headline: BRITAIN TO REOPEN ITS INQUIRY OF '72 IN ULSTER KILLINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/30/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Tony Blair announced today that he was opening a new judicial inquiry into the killings of 14 unarmed civil rights marchers by British soldiers in Northern Ireland on ''Bloody Sunday,'' Jan. 30, 1972. **********The event became a focus of Roman Catholic rage in the troubled province, where 3,235 have died in sectarian violence since 1969. **********The killings, in Londonderry, convulsed Northern Ireland, fueling hatred of the British Government and its Protestant supporters and provoking thousands of young men to join the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republican Army. All the victims were Catholics. **********Today's action amounted to a reopening of a speedy and widely disparaged investigation in 1972 that exonerated the heavily armed paratroopers and faulted the civilian protesters. **********It concluded there was a ''strong suspicion'' the marchers were carrying bombs and weapons, even though none were ever found, or even seen in the many photographs of the episode. **********Mr. Blair's announcement came after considerable pressure to review the investigation from the Irish Government, which said it had presented London with a ''compelling'' case for a review. **********In a report issued today, Dublin said the original investigation had ignored ballistic and medical evidence, and more than 500 accounts by witness that conflicted with testimony by soldiers. **********Today, with family members of the victims gathered in the gallery of the Commons, Mr. Blair told a hushed House: ''Bloody Sunday was a tragic day for all concerned. We must all wish it had never happened. Our concern now is simply to establish the truth and close this painful chapter once and for all.'' **********He said he was setting up a three-judge international panel led by a Briton, Lord Saville of Newdigate, who will pick two others from Commonwealth countries. **********The panel will have the power to summon witnesses, decide on granting immunity and produce a report that will be made public. **********While Mr. Blair expressed regret for the events of that day, he avoided any official apology, saying that kind of response would await the outcome of the new investigation. He also paid tribute to the ''dignity'' of the victims' families, who have been waging a vigorous campaign with leaders of the Catholic community for a new inquiry and who, he said, wanted ''not to accuse individuals or institutions or invite fresh recriminations, but to establish the truth.'' **********Mr. Blair's decision represented another of the ''confidence-building moves'' his Government has been adopting to accompany political progress in five-month-old peace talks that are aimed at settling the conflict by May. **********These steps have included the early release of prisoners, the transfer of inmates from jails in England to jails in Ireland and the granting of holiday leaves to imprisoned guerrillas. **********Producing a credible account of what happened on Bloody Sunday was, he said, ''a way forward to the necessary reconciliation which will be such an important part of building a secure future for the people of Northern Ireland.'' **********The families' goal has been to clear the names of the victims, and they gained the active support of the Irish Government, which seven months ago sent Mr. Blair a dossier of new evidence. Bertie Ahern, the Irish Prime Minister, sought to force Mr. Blair's hand by saying he would publish the new information before Friday's anniversary. **********The 178-page document was issued in Dublin shortly after Mr. Blair made his announcement. It accused Lord Widgery, the Lord Chief Justice of England, who conducted the 1972 inquiry, of ''tainting the victims with responsibility for their own deaths'' in order to clear the conduct of the elite paratroopers. **********The closest a British Government has ever come to a review was a letter in 1992 from Prime Minister John Major to John Hume, the head of the Social Democratic and Labor Party, which runs the government in Londonderry. **********Mr. Major wrote, ''Those who were killed should be regarded as innocent of any allegation they were shot whilst handling firearms or explosives.'' **********The expression was considered evasive by many Catholics because it left unchallenged the ''strong suspicion'' put forth in the Widgery report that the marchers might have been handling weapons or bombs earlier. **********The Widgery report, which was issued less than three months after the killings, cited the ''strong suspicion'' that the marchers were armed, accepted soldiers' claims of having been under attack, and argued that ''there is no reason to suppose that the soldiers would have opened fire if they had not been fired upon.'' **********Among the items of evidence cited by campaigners for a new inquiry were minutes of a Downing Street meeting the day after the shootings between Prime Minister Edward Heath and Lord Widgery, where Mr. Heath reminded the Justice that ''we were in Northern Ireland fighting not only a military war but a propaganda war.'' **********Mr. Heath, a wintry figure in the Commons these days, rose today from the front-row bench he customarily occupies to defend his decision to produce a quick report at the time. ''The general feeling was that the matter should be dealt with speedily,'' he said. **********The dead were among thousands of marchers who took to the main street of the Catholic working-class Bogside neighborhood on Jan. 30, 1972, to protest the British policy of internment without trial. They were met by British paratroopers newly arrived in the city and better versed in combat than crowd control. **********The gunfire sent the protesters scurrying in panic into stairwells and through alleys of the grey stone housing projects. A monument with the names of the victims and a whitewashed wall with the words ''You Are Entering Free Derry'' now mark the spot in the still dreary neighborhood where the dead fell. **********New ballistic and forensic evidence suggests that at least three victims were not killed by the advancing paratroopers, but were picked off as they tried to flee by military snipers above on the massive 17th-century walls that ring Londonderry. **********Paddy Ashdown, head of the Liberal Democratic Party and a Royal Marine Commander in Ulster in the immediate aftermath of the killings, said today, ''There is a general view at the time that there was a failure of professionalism on the night of Bloody Sunday, and I think there was a general view afterwards that the Widgery inquiry didn't get to the bottom of this.'' He said he thought the proposed new examination was ''wise, right and proper.'' **********The Conservative Party leader, William Hague, said he was glad Mr. Blair had called for an inquiry rather than offering an apology, as others had counseled him to do. **********''It would have been bizarre for you to make an apology in advance of any inquiry,'' he said. ''When it comes to discussing apologies, it would be both right and helpful to our hopes for peace to have an apology or see some sign of contrition from terrorist murders on both sides of the sectarian divide.'' **********Mr. Blair said he deplored all the killings in Northern Ireland, but argued that Bloody Sunday presented his Government with a special responsibility because the state was directly involved in the shooting and in the investigation. **********The only disapproving voice in the Commons was that of David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, the largest Protestant party in Northern Ireland. To cries of ''Shame! Shame!'' from other members, he accused Mr. Blair of using ''namby-pamby'' language and said, ''Opening old wounds like this is likely to do more harm than good.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/30/techn.print_headline: Toast Robot Keeps Orders On Light Side
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/30/techn.body_text: **********AT first glance, it seemed like the perfect marriage of marmalade and microchips. The Electronic Toast-Butler -- as advertised in a catalogue from the Edge Company (www.edgeco.com) in Vermont -- offers to ''pluck the toast, manipulate the knife, spy the dish and put your favorite spreadable on for you'' via skinny robotic arms protruding from the sides of a sturdy-looking appliance. **********Sound too good to be true? It is. **********Offering a prize of $15,000 in sterling silver bullion, the company challenges its shoppers to find five imaginary products lurking among the genuine items (mainly sleek electronic gadgets and samurai swords) offered for sale in its Spring 1998 catalogue. But if you just flip open the catalogue, missing the contest information on the cover and an inside page, you might get confused when you place that telephone order. **********''It's very funny -- I've taken a couple of the calls myself,'' said the Edge Company's president, Patrick Gaffney. He said he thought that perhaps 20 or 30 unsuspecting souls had called to order one of the decoys. **********Mr. Gaffney said he was not surprised that the company had not had more inquiries about the artificial items. ''What happens is that they get all excited about it until they show somebody else who says, 'Well, if you look on the cover. . . .' '' **********But if the Toast-Butler is not to be, can somebody there invent some other toast-meets-technology items -- say, a vacuum knife that will keep toast crumbs out of the butter and the peanut butter out of the jelly?

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/19/world.snippet: Jacques Medecin, Mayor of Nice, France, from 1966 until 1990, when he fled to Uruguay to avoid prosecution on corruption charges that later landed him in jail for nearly two years, dies at age 70; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/19/world.body_text: **********Jacques Medecin, Mayor of Nice from 1966 until 1990, when he fled to Uruguay to avoid prosecution on corruption charges that later landed him in jail for nearly two years, died in Uruguay on Tuesday after several heart attacks, his family said. He was 70. **********Nice, where Mr. Medecin made casinos, business leaders and the tourist industry rich but left municipal coffers nearly empty, loved him like a godfather and prepared to lay him out in state in the City Hall. The city plans to pay for funeral ceremonies, Mr. Medecin's successor, Jacques Peyrat, announced, and even Mr. Medecin's left-wing critics did not object. **********''One day in 1938, I decided I would be the Mayor of Nice, like my father,'' Mr. Medecin once wrote. ''I was 10 years old.'' Between him and his father, Jean, the Medecins ruled for 62 years. **********Jacquou, as people of Nice called him, never got the law degree he studied for, but soaked politics at home and as a journalist for Paris-Presse and the local daily, Nice-Matin, before picking up the reins after his father died in December 1965. For most of the next 15 years, there seemed little he could do wrong. **********The Medecin method, as it was called, was to spread public money around, lavishly -- for a convention hall here, for a water-purification plant there, for an arts pavilion, not forgetting the casinos. **********His support for Valery Giscard d'Estaing for the presidency in 1974 was briefly rewarded two years later when he was named a junior Government minister for tourism, until Prime Minister Raymond Barre ejected him from the post in 1978. **********Still at the height of his power in Nice, he was divorced from his first wife, Claude, who had been a model for the Jacques Fath fashion house, and in 1979 married an American 21 years his junior, Ilene Graham, a 31-year-old Southern Californian. **********In 1981 Mr. Medecin's nemesis, the Socialist Party, came to power. Soon tax inspectors and magistrates began looking into the Mayor's methods, and he began to take long trips to Miami and Los Angeles. **********The prosecutors found that a traffic-signal company had paid many of his campaign expenses. They discovered that Nice-Opera had also sent money to his private accounts in Panama. And they found that municipal contractors had been taking paid advertisements in his newspaper. Investigation followed investigation. **********''In the Nice-Opera affair, I am guilty of carelessness,'' he later told the newspaper Le Figaro. ''I paid certain expenses incurred for the city of Nice or for promoting it, without proper documentation. But I would like to repeat: the amounts drawn never exceeded $24,000.'' **********From the president of the traffic signal company, he admitted, he had received $800,000 over four years. But that was before campaign financing laws made such payments illegal, he protested. Prosecutors paid no attention. **********On Sept. 15, 1990, Mr. Medecin cracked under the pressure while on a city-paid promotional trip to Japan and fled to Uruguay. ''Never will I accept being photographed with my wrists in handcuffs on the courthouse stairs,'' he declared. **********His second marriage had fallen apart, and in Uruguay, where he hoped to be safe from extradition, he settled in Punta del Este and married Berta Bittar, his third wife. She survives him, as do three daughters from his earlier marriages. **********In France in 1992, a court convicted him of malfeasance, and prosecutors obtained a court order for his arrest in Uruguay. A year later, he was flown to France to face further trials. **********Released on appeal in September 1995 after being convicted of embezzlement and fraud and sentenced to three and a half years in prison, Mr. Medecin never went back to jail again. In January 1996 an appeals court upheld the convictions but sentenced him to time served, and Mr. Medecin went back to Uruguay. **********With about $800,000 -- from the sale of family property, he insisted -- he invested in real estate and lived living happily until Sunday, when he was felled by heart attacks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/09/busin.snippet: Pennzoil Co says it will take $115.6 million of charges for debt refinancing, foreign projects, low oil and gas prices and weather problems, giving it a loss for third quarter (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/09/busin.main_headline: PENNZOIL TO TAKE $115.6 MILLION CHARGE IN THIRD QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/09/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; PENNZOIL TO TAKE $115.6 MILLION CHARGE IN THIRD QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/09/busin.body_text: **********The Pennzoil Company said yesterday that it would take $115.6 million of charges for debt refinancing, foreign projects, low oil and natural-gas prices and weather problems in the Gulf of Mexico, giving it a loss for the third quarter. The charges will total $2.43 a share. Pennzoil, whose motor oil is the top-selling brand, warned that results before the charges would also be hurt by the low oil and gas prices and severe gulf weather. The company had been expected to earn 30 cents a share, the average estimate of eight analysts polled by the First Call Corporation. A year earlier, Pennzoil, based in Houston, had net income of $35.2 million, or 75 cents a share, after taking a $2.9 million charge. Pennzoil shares fell $3.625, to $28.5625.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/22/busin.snippet: Pfizer Inc says it is warning paramedics and emergency room physicians not to administer nitroglycerin to patients taking Pfizer's impotence drug Viagra; Viagra label already has warning that it should not be used by those taking organic nitrates ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/22/busin.body_text: **********Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that it was warning paramedics and emergency room physicians not to administer nitroglycerin to patients taking Pfizer's impotence pill Viagra. **********The Viagra label already has a warning that it should not be used by those taking organic nitrates like nitroglycerin, which is primarily used to treat angina -- chest pain caused by clogged arteries. In a statement yesterday, the drug maker cautioned against inappropriate use. **********Viagra, which is easier to use than other impotence remedies on the market, became one of the best-selling United States drugs after its introduction last month. **********Using Viagra and nitrates together can lead to large and sudden drops in blood pressure, Pfizer said. **********Pfizer's stock fell $3.6875, to $109.125, yesterday as more than 6.1 million shares were traded. **********A spokeswoman for the United States Food and Drug Administration said she had not heard of any incidents involving Viagra. **********The great demand for the product is reflected in an apparent price war involving two of the biggest United States discount chains. According to The Associated Press, the Kmart Corporation is advertising a five-tablet prescription for $39.99, while Wal-Mart Stores Inc. says it is offering five pills for $38.98. Viagra generally has been retailed at $10 a pill.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/31/busin.snippet: CBS is betting heavily on football to restore it to profitability, having agreed to pay $500 million a year for eight years for package of American Football Conference games; football broadcasts come at critical time for CBS and its president, Mel...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/31/busin.main_headline: Can Football Revive CBS?; Network Places A $4 Billion Bet That Its Deal With the N.F.L. Will Bring Back Days of Glory
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/31/busin.print_headline: Can Football Revive CBS?; Network Places A $4 Billion Bet That Its Deal With the N.F.L. Will Bring Back Days of Glory
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/31/busin.body_text: **********Forget all those quarterbacks surrounded by 300-pound charging linemen: When the National Football League season starts this Sunday, the real pressure will be on the executives who call the plays at CBS. And they don't get to wear helmets. **********The contract that CBS signed in January to bring the N.F.L. back after a four-year absence from the network is surely the most scrutinized deal in recent television history: an eight-year, $4 billion commitment for a package of American Football Conference games. At $500 million a year, the deal is more than a 100 percent increase over the $217 million a year that NBC had been paying for the same package. **********CBS executives have characterized the deal as a strategic coup that they hope will be the linchpin to a resurgence in profits for television's once-dominant network, which has recently posted annual losses of $50 million to $100 million. **********At the same time, critics of CBS -- mainly executives at NBC, now out of  N.F.L. television -- call the deal financially irresponsible and predict CBS will begin losing $100 million to $150 million a year on football alone. **********The football broadcasts come at a critical time for the network and for Mel Karmazin, the president who owns 1.1 percent of CBS's stock and who was the driving force behind the deal. Only last Thursday, CBS announced a reorganization that included cost-cutting measures calculated to save $180 million. Among the moves announced were layoffs of 200 to 300 employees. **********Cost-cutting measures have been announced at both NBC and ABC this summer; but given the questions surrounding the size of the football deal, the moves at CBS were seen in some quarters as preparations for Hurricane Pigskin. **********CBS executives forcefully denied the cost-cutting was related to the football deal, just as they have forcefully asserted, in the face of contentions that they overpaid for N.F.L. games out of desperation, that their contract is sound and that the deal will, in the words of Mr. Karmazin, ''make a dollar'' for CBS. **********One week before the first slate of Sunday afternoon games, Sean McManus, the president of CBS Sports, is not backing away from that rosy analysis of the deal. ''We're right on target,'' he said. **********The numbers that give him confidence, Mr. McManus said, come from increased advertising sales at both the network and CBS-owned stations, revenue generated from an exchange of commercial time with CBS affiliates, reduced costs for advertising in other media to promote CBS shows and anticipated benefits to CBS's prime-time lineup. **********The latter was among the biggest reasons CBS thought it had to reacquire the N.F.L. Without it, the network had almost no programming that attracted young male viewers. ''Over the last few years, young men had really left us,'' said Leslie Moonves, the president of CBS Television. ''At the least, football will get some of that blood flowing.'' **********Among those still skeptical about CBS's positive numbers is Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports, who said, ''CBS is practicing a form of mathematics with which none of my professors was familiar -- because they didn't have enough beads in their abacus.'' **********NBC is the network most familiar with CBS's football package because it owned it for 33 years. That relationship ended in January when NBC declined to match CBS's bid. Mr. Ebersol said NBC did not think the package could be worth more than $300 million a year. **********Tom Wolzien, a neutral observer as a media analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein, pointed out that NBC had a special incentive for disparaging the CBS deal: ''NBC said no way would they spend that much, so they're trying to prove the rightness of their vision. Still this is a tough go for CBS. I'm projecting they'll lose $50 million on football this year.'' **********That would be significant because CBS's payments to the N.F.L. will rise over the length of the contract. The network is actually paying the least amount this season, an estimated $350 million. The later payments will be especially huge, but CBS is counting on advertising revenue to increase over time. **********Mr. McManus said, ''The true value to CBS is not going to be felt for four or five years.'' **********Nevertheless, he said, there is reason to be optimistic about this season. CBS is getting better prices for commercial time during the A.F.C. games than NBC did, he said. Advertising industry publications have estimated that CBS is getting about a 10 percent increase, a figure NBC questions. Mr. McManus declined to comment on the figure, but CBS's private estimates are that it will do even better than that, an executive close to CBS said. **********One reason CBS may be doing better with ad sales, Mr. McManus said, is that the A.F.C. teams are finally perceived to be fully competitive with those in the N.F.C., whose games are broadcast by Fox. **********CBS estimated that NBC sold ads in its package for about 15 percent less than Fox did, a disparity that CBS regarded as unfair. But Mr. Ebersol pointed out that advertisers prefer to be in games that reach the country's 10 biggest cities. The N.F.C. has eight teams in those cities; the A.F.C. has three. **********What might help CBS in selling the games is simply that they are new to it. When NBC pried the National Basketball Association games away from CBS starting in 1990 for $600 million, the bid was labeled dangerously high. But NBC, which extended the deal in 1993 for $750 million and again last year for $1.75 billion through 2002, found aggressive new ways to sell the games and made a huge profit. CBS says it is doing the same thing with football this year. **********Mr. McManus pointed to $45 million in new business that CBS has attracted from Nasdaq, Southwest Airlines and other companies. But Mr. Ebersol said that $25 million to $30 million in new business was typical every year. **********Mr. McManus said he was also counting on about $40 million in a deal the network made with affiliates to exchange commercial time in other parts of the CBS schedule. Then there is about $25 million that CBS is counting on saving from money it has been spending in other media to promote its programs, which it now thinks it can do during games. **********Some competing network executives question whether CBS can really count on the $40 million in cash from its complicated deal with its affiliates. And the questions about CBS come from more quarters than just NBC. ABC and Fox were no more happy that CBS started off the N.F.L. negotiations with its pre-emptive bid for the A.F.C. In effect, the N.F.L. used CBS's urgency to set the price for every package. **********One senior executive from a competing N.F.L. network said CBS's approach was amateurish. ''They didn't have to go in that high,'' the executive said. **********But CBS was fighting for nothing less than survival, at least in terms of perception. ''The perception when CBS lost football was that it was a second-class network,'' Mr. Moonves said. **********Always encumbered by being the network with the oldest audience -- in a business where advertisers pay premiums to reach younger adults -- CBS has been disastrously deficient in reaching younger men. Just adding the young men from NBC's A.F.C. audience last year would improve CBS's reach among men by 60 percent to 90 percent, CBS says its research estimates. **********Mr. McManus said CBS carefully calculated the value of the N.F.L. before it made its huge bid. Crucial was the benefit to the stations CBS owns, seven of which are in cities with A.F.C. teams. Those stations are adding many tie-in programs to the football games -- coaches' shows for example. If the stations gain in local market share, that will help justify the price, Mr. McManus said. **********Similarly, if CBS gains younger male viewers for its prime-time shows, the football deal will help pay for itself. David F. Poltrack, the executive vice president of CBS Research said, ''As little as a 10 percent increase in male viewers, spread around prime time, could generate a substantial profit increase.'' **********If that success came because CBS had a breakout hit show, the increase in advertising revenue could make up a large bit of the football price all by itself, though CBS has not had a hit with young male viewers in years. CBS is hoping that by promoting its shows during the football games, viewers will at least start to sample CBS shows. **********But the promotional value of sports has always been one of television's biggest imponderables. CBS had the Winter Olympics last year, yet no show the network promoted during that event developed into a hit. And Sunday football presents some special problems for CBS's program promotions. **********First, there are questions about the duration of any promotion's effect. Can one really be used to promote, say, CBS's new martial arts show, ''Martial Law,'' on Saturday nights, six days after the last tackle is made on Sunday? **********Promotions during Sunday football are most effective for shows on Sunday nights. CBS already has its best night on Sunday. Its top show, ''60 Minutes,'' is almost certain to be helped by direct lead-ins from football. But how many football fans can be delivered to ''Touched By an Angel'' and CBS's Sunday movie, which mainly appeal to women? **********CBS does have some Monday shows with male stars, including ''Cosby,'' ''Everybody Loves Raymond'' and the new ''Benben'' show. But all those shows will run against ''Monday Night Football'' on ABC, which presumably would be a stronger draw to fans who watch football on Sunday. **********Mr. Poltrack questioned that, citing statistics that showed that only 30 percent of the younger men watching the A.F.C. on Sunday tuned in to ''Monday Night Football.'' **********He also noted that while promotional effect diminishes as days pass, viewers could be at least made aware of shows. Thus, if a younger man sees a promotion for ''Martial Law'' on Sunday and happens to be scanning channels the next Saturday, he might find the show and remember he had seen the commercial for it. **********Whatever happens in terms of the profit and loss this season, CBS executives say they think they did the right thing to get back into business with the N.F.L. because network television is becoming more and more dependent on one-of-a-kind event programming. They pointed to the deal Fox signed with the N.F.L. four years ago, which was then ridiculed as recklessly overpriced at $395 million a year. But, even though Fox eventually took a $350 million write-off on losses related to football, the N.F.L. deal by every other assessment was a huge success, helping to put Fox on the map as a network. **********Chase Carey, the chairman of Fox Television, said in a speech in June that NBC's decision to pass on the N.F.L. deal ''will go down as one of the defining moments of recent network history,'' one, he said, that NBC is likely to regret. **********With the N.B.A., the Olympics and other sports events still in their grip, NBC executives are convinced their network can survive easily without football. The question, as Mr. Ebersol and other NBC executives see it, is whether CBS can survive with it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/12/busin.snippet: Jerusalem-based Teva Pharmaceutical Industries is in talks to acquire unidentified European pharmaceutical company with annual sales of $100 million (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/12/busin.main_headline: Israeli Drug Company Pursues European Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/12/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; Israeli Drug Company Pursues European Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/12/busin.body_text: **********Teva Pharmaceutical Industries said yesterday that it was in talks to acquire an unidentified European pharmaceutical company with annual sales of $100 million. Teva, based in Jerusalem, makes drugs, medical supplies and veterinary products. The company, which had net income of $25.1 million on revenue of $269 million for the quarter that ended March 31, said the acquisition would add to its earnings after one year, but did not elaborate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/27/busin.main_headline: Neckties at Work: Untangling the Knot
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/27/busin.print_headline: Neckties at Work: Untangling the Knot
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/27/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Re ''Foulard and Rep, Rest in Peace? Not So Fast!'' (The Culture of Money, Dec. 6): **********In discussing the declining use of neckties in America, and the backlash against the trend, the column stated that ''there is no substitute'' for a necktie in a man's wardrobe. ''Without neckties to channel decorative instincts,'' it said, ''men are left to flounder uncertainly in a sea of corduroys, khakis and 'dressy casuals.' '' **********For years, I and other men have found that the use of bola ties can channel decorative instincts without projecting an image of formality. (A bola tie, of course, is a string tie held in place by an ornament that is called a bola; the ends of the string are tipped in silver or other material.) **********Bolas encourage a feeling of informality. They can be worn with the top of the shirt buttoned or unbuttoned and can be loosely or tightly fitted. **********Unfortunately, bolas are not common outside the Southwest and West. Perhaps their greater use across the country would solve wardrobe problems for both men and women. I have worn them on business trips to Baltimore -- and have received compliments. **********TERRY TORZALA **********Tucson, Ariz., Dec. 6 **********The writer is a regulatory-affairs consultant for the medical equipment industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/28/news/.main_headline: Challenge for Jewish President/ Weighty Matters of Conscience : A Swiss 'Facilitator' Searches for the Middle
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/28/news/.print_headline: Challenge for Jewish President/ Weighty Matters of Conscience : A Swiss 'Facilitator' Searches for the Middle
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/28/news/.body_text: **********BERN—                     Ruth Dreifuss says it almost before her visitors are settled into their chairs: She will not be an alibi, a public relations prop depicting Switzerland as reconciled with its past, or a marker to paint its history with the harsh, dark lines of caricature. **********But being Switzerland's first woman and first Jewish president may come with difficulty. **********Her success, as she suggests, would mean helping find a new context, a still uncertain middle space, where Switzerland could begin to come to terms with its old self-vision of virtue, and its new and unwelcome persona of World War II accomplice and profiteur. **********A reservoir of anger and grief that has not yet found resolution accompanies the post she takes over for a year on Jan 1. **********How does she do the job right, getting all the nuances, choosing the references between bucolic picture postcard and self-flagellation, that both confront and try to explain an aching reality? How does Ruth Dreifuss serve as the emblematic representative of a country that for years tried, in effect, not to know how much it was a conscious onlooker to the Holocaust or even more, its shameful beneficiary? **********Her job is largely ceremonial, a mission she defines as more one of a "facilitator" than an uncontested leader at the head of the Federal Council, or Swiss government. Her election as president, she stresses, came not as part of a vast Swiss image-retouch, but because it was simply her turn, as the council member responsible for health and social affairs since 1993, to take over the country's rotating presidency. Even so, being President Dreifuss is not less delicate; getting to the consensual middle on the issue of Switzerland's conscience cannot be comfortable for her. **********When she talks to visitors in an office of careful unpretentiousness, her sentences almost always seem to come in pairs. It is as if her articulation of her dilemma, expressing the many contradictory levels of her vision of Switzerland, had a double track, a constant negative plus positive link, an on-the-one-hand layer of resolve and directness, and an on-the-other-hand layer of modifiers and clauses. **********So, when Miss Dreifuss points to how Switzerland started to resolve the issue of money owed Holocaust survivors by Swiss banks, she quickly adds, "This was an initiative, I recognize, that was born only under outside pressure." **********The pattern is strong. On-the-one-hand: "I don't want that my presidency gives anybody the feeling that Switzerland no longer has to be concerned with its past" or the elements of anti-Semitism in it. Then, on-the-other, about anti-Semitism: "I deny that it's any greater here than elsewhere. Don't have me saying that. But that's enough. Even if it's like it is elsewhere, that's enough." **********Yes, she says, there are now "certain marks on Switzerland's reputation," but no, "I don't think you can talk about damage" to Swiss effectiveness economically or on the international level. **********- **********THE PATTERN seems almost instinctive, and curiously it reflects the way Miss Dreifuss sees Switzerland dealing with its fears about its past: "There have always been two movements. We try to find out a bit more, and then we close up the cellar so as not to see what's in there. I think we're going much further now." **********Possibly the most intense period of Miss Dreifuss's presidency will come in the spring when a government-appointed panel of international historians will issue a report on Swiss policy during the war. She has said she expects to launch a national debate, and — the hunt for the middle comes in here — to explain to Jewish organizations where their demands are justified and where, as she signaled in advance, they are less so. **********Miss Dreifuss, who is 58 and not married, was born to Swiss-Jewish parents in St. Gallen and moved during the war to Geneva, across the lake from Nazi-occupied France, or as she puts it, "a few kilometers from a death sentence." She recalls her father as a Swiss patriot, experiencing "a moment of joy" when he put on a Swiss military uniform for the first time. **********There was no massive, popular Swiss anti-Semitism during the war, Miss Dreifuss believes, but real anti-Semitism nonetheless in the country's asylum policy. "The worst was the indifference, and pushed to the extreme, considering Nazism normal and that it didn't concern us." **********Her own career developed through the Socialist Party and feminist activities as she worked in the trade union movement. A reputation of calm, fairness, and competence allowed her to leap local politics, bringing her directly into the government five years ago. **********- **********MISS DREIFUSS talks sparingly of her own personal history, but she says her family "lived in fear" during the war. There has been no change in the volume of her mail since the Parliament approved her selection as president in early December, although some letters were "more vehement, more stupid." As for anti-Semitism in Switzerland, "I've encountered it, you could say. It happens. I've never suffered from it as an obstacle." **********In a country in which women received the right to vote in all its cantons only in 1990, Miss Dreifuss sees herself as a new face. "I represent another Switzerland. More urban. More egalitarian. More tolerant." **********She is an advocate of Swiss membership in the United Nations and the European Union. Neither will happen on her watch, but should be taking place, she believes, during the next five years. **********If she insists she is unwilling to serve as anyone's lever or alibi, Miss Dreifuss says she will pay special attention to the needs of women's and human rights groups. Then she adds her modulating clause. They must not be demagogic. **********At her most bold, Miss Dreifuss, says, "I'm happy to be able to say that Switzerland is moving and that I'm part of what's moving." **********This, of course, had its own careful preface: "I don't want the Swiss to think that equality is achieved because I'm president of this country." **********"There's a long way to go," she says.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/18/busin.body_text: **********The Hot Wheels line of miniature vehicles, best known for souped-up sports cars, is adding something different to its lineup: a dairy delivery truck named for the popular ''Got milk?'' campaign by the Goodby, Silverstein & Partners unit of Omnicom Group in San Francisco. **********The toy marks the second collaboration between the California Milk Processor Advisory Board, which sponsors the campaign and also licenses it nationally, and Mattel Inc. In May 1996, they teamed up to introduce a Barbie doll with a ''Got milk?'' theme. The dairy truck will be available in the spring at all major toy retail outlets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/11/busin.print_headline: W. H. Conzen, 84; Led Expansion of Schering
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/11/busin.body_text: **********W. H. Conzen, the former chairman and chief executive of the Schering-Plough Corporation, died on Dec. 21 at his home in Lynchburg, Va. He was 84. **********The cause of death was a stroke, said his daughter, Elizabeth Conzen Zellner. **********One of corporate America's most successful leaders, Mr. Conzen became chief executive of the Schering Corporation in 1966 and almost immediately led the company into one of its most prosperous periods. Determined to expand Schering's global presence, Mr. Conzen merged the company with Plough Inc. in 1971 and bought Scholl Inc., the foot-care company, in 1979. **********The moves turned Schering-Plough into one of Wall Street's greatest darlings of the day, with a growing array of prescription drugs and health care brands that ranged from Coppertone sun lotion to St. Joseph's aspirin for children. **********Schering-Plough's earnings rose 30 percent to 35 percent each year in the early 1970's. The gains were enough to increase the company's stock price from $46 a share in 1970 to $87.675 one year later. **********Born Willibalb Hermann Conzen in Dortmund, Germany, in 1913, he started his career with Schering A.G. of Berlin in 1931. He was transferred to Scherag Ltd., the company's subsidiary in Johannesburg, in 1938 and was named general manager in 1941. **********During World War II, the United States subsidiary of Schering A.G. was seized by the Federal Government and became the Schering Corporation U.S.A. In 1947, the Schering Corporation bought a majority interest in Scherag. **********In 1952, Mr. Conzen was appointed manager of Schering's International division, a stint that led to a corporate vice presidency seven years later. After serving as the general manager of the company's laboratory division, he became a senior vice president in 1965. **********Mr. Conzen became chief executive in 1966 after Schering's chairman, Francis C. Brown, was killed in an automobile accident. **********He served as chief executive for 12 years, stepping down in August 1978. Mr. Conzen remained chairman of the board until 1980 and a director until 1987. **********Mr. Conzen's first marriage, to Salome Bruwer, ended in divorce in 1982. He is survived by his daughters from the marriage, Ms. Zellner and Dr. Suzanne D. Conzen of Chicago. Mr. Conzen's son, Vincent, died of a brain hemorrhage four years ago. **********Mr. Conzen later married Shirley O'Neill, a partner in the law firm of Riker, Danzig, Scherer, Hyland & Perretti of Morristown, N.J. She died of lung cancer in July. **********Along with Ms. Zellner and Dr. Conzen, Mr. Conzen is survived by a sister, Elisabeth Conzen of Koblenz, Germany; two brothers, H. W. Conzen of Saulgau, Germany, and Johannes Conzen of Hohenschaftlarn, Germany, and four grandchildren.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/busin.body_text: **********The Bates North America unit of Bates Worldwide in New York, part of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C., is promoting several top executives as part of a restructuring. **********The changes involve the combining of services such as direct marketing, sales promotion and interactive advertising into a unit called 141 Integrated Communications. John Marchese, 46, executive vice president and director for marketing and development at Bates USA, was named to the additional new post of overseeing 141 as president for integrated communications at Bates North America. **********Gary Steele, 47, was named to the additional new post of managing director at another new unit, Bates Retail, which will oversee work for accounts like CVS and Wendy's International; he continues as executive vice president for account management at Bates USA and head of the Wendy's account. Dany Khosrovani, the executive vice president at Bates USA who heads the T. Rowe Price account, was named to the additional new post of chief executive at a new unit that will focus on marketing to older consumers. **********And Mark Morris, 56, managing director at Bates USA and worldwide client director on the Warner Lambert Company account, was named to the additional new position of chairman of Bates North America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/13/busin.main_headline: Cathay Pacific Shares Plunge on Forecasts
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/13/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; Cathay Pacific Shares Plunge on Forecasts
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/13/busin.body_text: **********The stock of Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. plunged yesterday as analysts slashed their 1998 profit forecasts because last year's earnings fell 55.5 percent. An analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, Wendy Wong, slashed this year's forecast by 82 percent, to 300 million Hong Kong dollars, after Cathay said on Wednesday that it earned 1.69 billion Hong Kong dollars last year and added that business could get worse. **********''Things are looking very bad,'' Ms. Wong said. Cathay's stock fell 2.3 percent, to 6.35 Hong Kong dollars. The stock is down 60 percent since June -- traffic has fallen every month since then.   (Bloomberg News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/24/world.snippet: Recent discovery in Switzerland of at least four bank accounts registered to former members of Argentine military provides prosecutors, human rights advocates and politicians with new ammunition in battle to punish those responsible for crimes dur...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/24/world.main_headline: Argentines Press Ex-Soldiers on Swiss Cash
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/24/world.print_headline: Argentines Press Ex-Soldiers on Swiss Cash
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/24/world.body_text: **********The recent discovery in Switzerland of at least four bank accounts registered to former members of the Argentine military has provided prosecutors, human rights advocates and politicians with new ammunition in the battle to punish those responsible for crimes during the country's last dictatorship. **********Prosecutors said last week that they had learned the identities of four former military men who are listed as holders of Swiss bank accounts that human rights groups say contain millions of dollars pillaged from political prisoners during the junta's campaign against leftists from 1976 to 1983. **********Although Argentine amnesty laws protect former members of the military from prosecution for abuses during the dictatorship. the prosecutors said they were trying to determine if those who hold Swiss accounts can be charged with tax evasion, illicit enrichment or other financial misconduct. **********One of the four men, Antonio Bussi, is a former general who is now  Governor of the northern province of Tucuman. He is facing impeachment proceedings by the provincial legislature, brought after he admitted under pressure last week that he had failed to declare the Swiss account on his tax returns. **********Ricardo Quintela, a Congressman from the governing Peronist Party, said that the ''time is right to jail officers who have escaped responsibility for their crimes.'' He called for Argentine prosecutors to model their cases after the United States Government's successful prosecution of the organized crime boss Al Capone for income-tax evasion. **********''Though the mere fact of holding an account in Switzerland does not  constitute a crime, it's clear that it raises suspicions that call for an  investigation into the possible criminal origins of the funds,'' said Emilio  Martinez Garbino, also a Peronist Congressman. **********Based on the testimony of survivors and relatives of victims, human rights groups estimate that the armed forces stole $70 million in assets -- including cash, cars, real estate and jewelry -- from those detained. At least 9,000 people were killed or disappeared, and tens of thousands more were tortured, a Government inquiry concluded. Human rights groups put the death toll at 30,000. **********It was common practice during the dictatorship for the military to loot the homes of people detained on suspicion of subversion, confiscate their autos and real estate and then resell them, and to extort money from businessmen and from family members of those detained. **********The Swiss accounts were discovered by a Swiss State Prosecutor, Carla del Ponte, who is assisting a Spanish court investigation into the disappearance of 600 Spaniards in Argentina during the dictatorship. **********Argentine prosecutors said the Spanish court had revealed the identities of Mr. Bussi and the three other men. One, former Sgt. Carlos Vega, worked at a torture camp in Cordoba province where 3,000 detainees disappeared, Government documents  show. Another, former Lieut. Alfredo Astiz, was recently forced out of the military because of his actions during the dictatorship and is wanted in France for the killing of two French nuns in Argentina during the dictatorship. The third, Col. Roberto Roualdes, who died in 1995, had been  a leading figure in a military strike against leftists in Cordoba. **********The Argentine prosecutors said the Swiss had not revealed exactly how much money the four bank accounts contain, but the Argentine prosecutors said they believed that the total was at least $3 million. The prosecutors said they expected more information to emerge about other accounts belonging to members of the Argentine military. **********Legal experts said they believed that prosecutors could build a strong case against the three surviving men if it can be proved that they failed to  declare the bank accounts as personal assets or failed to pay taxes on the interest. Moreover, they could also be prosecuted for illicit enrichment. **********Until now, the Argentine Government has refused to cooperate with the Spanish inquiry, contending that Spain has no jurisdiction and that the amnesty laws prevent the Government from taking the men to court. By releasing the names of the holders of the Swiss accounts to Argentine prosecutors, Spanish investigators have taken the case directly to the Argentine public. **********The effort by some prosecutors and politicians in Argentina to use the Swiss bank accounts to prosecute the men is part of a crusade under way in several Latin countries to find  ways to punish the military for past crimes despite amnesty laws. **********Mr. Bussi, the provincial Governor who is facing impeachment, declared his innocence last week and said the money in the Swiss account -- $100,000, according to local newspapers -- had not come from plundering political prisoners. **********Mr. Bussi, who was implicated in many political crimes, including participation in illegal firing squads, said his failure to declare the account on his taxes was an ''error of omission,'' and he apologized. **********But human rights defenders said they believed that money came from the former military Government's widespread theft from thousands of people who died or disappeared during the anti-leftist crackdown.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/04/busin.body_text: **********With subtle shifts of tone and emphasis, the British Government is signaling new warmth toward the soon-to-be introduced European single currency, promising to divulge a ''national change-over plan'' for the euro earlier than many people had previously thought. **********British pundits detected the shift from ministerial statements on Monday, replacing the word ''if'' with a more decisive ''when'' in references to the conditions for euro membership by Britain -- by far the biggest economic and political heavyweight of the four European Union nations outside the current euro club of 11 nations that will participate in using the new currency on Jan 1. **********Economists and political analysts said the shift could mark the beginnings of a campaign to prepare Britain's deeply divided public for a less contentious approach to the new currency. In recent years, the British economy has outpaced those of Continental Europe, provoking the argument among critics of monetary union that Britain has more to lose than gain from joining in the euro. **********But ''with the economic outlook worsening for cyclical reasons, this splendid isolation is no longer looking so splendid,'' said Holger Schmieding, senior economist with Merrill Lynch, and adding, ''That should mean that British public opinion should become a bit more euro-friendly.'' **********Indeed, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, reduced the Government's forecast today for 1999 growth to a range of 1 percent to 1.5 percent from about 2.5 percent. **********At issue is what Mr. Brown on Monday called a ''national change-over plan'' to be published in January setting out the practical steps for Britain to join the euro at a later date. Previously, the Government had insisted that no decision be made before a referendum after the next national election, which will most likely be in mid-2002. **********While Mr. Brown did not modify that timetable, he said the Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair wanted to prepare for joining in euro participation before the proposed referendum. **********''This Government has decisively and unambiguously put this country on a new road of constructive engagement with Europe,'' he told British business leaders at a meeting in Birmingham. ''We will set out the stage-by-stage procedures that will need to be followed. We will spell out the practical implications of changing to the euro, and we will give new advice to companies on the way to take forward their preparations.'' **********Peter Mandelson, the Trade and Industry Secretary, said: ''It would be economic lunacy for the sake of Euro-skeptic ideology to marginalize Britain on the sidelines of what should be its own market. We have made clear that we will join the single currency when it is in Britain's economic interests to do so.'' **********The remarks had little effect on the market, with the pound already well down from highs earlier this year against the German mark, the key European currency. The pound was quoted today at 2.75 marks, compared with 3.10 marks at its strongest level several months ago. Part of the pound's strength was ascribed by dealers to its role as a potential hedge against the euro. **********But the issue remains deeply divisive, with the opposition Conservatives demanding a much longer delay before a referendum, while the bulk of British business is in favor of joining in the new currency. Even on the current schedule, Britain will be outside the euro zone not only in January, when it goes into use in electronic business -- including huge euro-denominated stock, bond and derivatives markets -- but also when euro notes and coins enter circulation in January 2002. **********And some economists expressed puzzlement today at reports that Mr. Brown was considering a 40-month gap between announcing a referendum and introducing euro notes and coins -- a schedule that could delay full British membership until 2005, later than many financial institutions here had expected. **********''I think the way we look at it is that the Government has decided that it's the right thing to do and it's just a question of time after a referendum,'' said David Mackie, an economist at J. P. Morgan & Company. ''But I'm a bit puzzled. The Government gives the impression that it's a done deal, but they also give the impression that a pretty long timetable is needed.'' **********The issue has touched off heated debate. For instance, The Sun tabloid, a staunch and powerful opponent of the euro, characterized Mr. Brown and Mr. Mandelson as ''euro fanatics'' in an article today -- echoing assertions by Tories that the Labor Government was seeking to stampede Britons into supporting the single currency without proper debate. **********By contrast, many business leaders at the Birmingham meeting urged the Government to go further and set a date for joining, complaining that official vagueness made it hard to plan for the euro's introduction. **********''We believe our members very much support joining the single currency, but we are concerned that there is not enough leadership given by the Government in terms of preparation by business for the euro,'' said Sir Clive Thompson, president of the Confederation of British Industry, the influential employers' group. **********--------------------        Interest Rates Lowered **********(By The Associated Press) -- The central banks in Spain, Portugal and Sweden cut key lending rates yesterday in an effort to maintain economic growth. **********The cuts could put added pressure on Germany, France and other European nations to trim their rates. **********The Bank of Spain lowered its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 3.50 percent. Hours later, the central bank in Portugal trimmed a quarter-point from its benchmark lending rate, to 3.75 percent. **********Earlier, Sweden's central bank cut its one-week fixed securities-repurchase rate, a key indicator of lending trends there, to 3.85 percent from 4.10 percent. **********Many European central banks are facing the need to lower key interest rates before the European single currency is introduced next year.
