https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/11/your-.main_headline: The New Rules For Trading in Asia's Gloom : The Risks and Rewards of the Emerging-Markets Currency Game
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/11/your-.print_headline: The New Rules For Trading in Asia's Gloom : The Risks and Rewards of the Emerging-Markets Currency Game
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/11/your-.body_text: **********IN THE SPACE of a year, Asia's currencies have gone from being among the most boring to some of the most volatile investments on Earth. For years, most currencies in the region were in some way pegged to the U.S. dollar. Now, with the Hong Kong dollar the only fixed, tradeable Asian currency left, the rest often bounce around by huge margins in the space of a day. **********With many down 40 percent or more from this time a year ago, Asian currencies are not for the faint-hearted. The Thai baht's 100-day volatility against the dollar is 30.6 percent, the Philippine peso's is 20 percent and that of the South Korean won is 28 percent. These are two to four times the volatilities of the major European currencies measured against the dollar. **********Nor are Asian currencies for the traditional value-investor who is used to buying low-priced stocks or stodgy government bonds. For anyone trying to gauge longer-term currency values in Asia, the task is almost hopeless. **********"Timing is important," said Steven Chang, managing director of foreign exchange at State Street Bank in Hong Kong. "It's not just buy-and-hold. You have to be smart." **********These days, Asia's currencies move according to the latest readings not of the dollar, as in the past, but according to news emanating from Japan. **********"The yen dominates all other factors," said Frank Gong, senior economist, foreign exchange, at Bank of America in Hong Kong. **********If the yen seems set to rebound, currencies strengthen, but there are plenty of doomsayers who see the dollar rising above 200 yen, from the current 141, by the end of this year. **********Is Japan's bridge-bank solution announced on July 2 the sum total of its promised "total plan" to fix its sick banking system? Given that the yen has weakened since the announcement, investors who have bought Asian currencies should hope not. **********"It's as much a bridge for a plan as it is a bridge for a bank," said Pelham Smithers, strategist at ING Barings in Tokyo . "To say it's got holes in it misses the point. There are about two slats in place out of two million." **********Santander Investment's strategist, Christopher Wood, called the plan "another warehousing solution," and criticized the idea that bad banks would stay in business for years to come. **********"Do not be surprised if many of the companies enjoying continued funding are politically influential construction companies," he warned. **********ING's reading for the yen in the coming months is that it will bounce within a wide range. The dollar could get as high as 160 yen after central bank intervention, or as low as 120 as hedge funds continue to be tempted by borrowing yen at interest rates five percentage points below what they earn by converting the money into dollars and buying U.S. Treasury paper. **********Others are even gloomier, from the point of view of anyone hoping for a stable, or stronger, yen. Martin Armstrong of Princeton Economics said the dollar would rise to 200 yen by year's end, because deregulation of Japan's financial sector will free $9 trillion, or 40 percent of the world's savings, to go abroad. Not only might the yen fall as a result, but so could Japanese government bonds, the high-price paper responsible for some of the lowest interest rates anywhere, ever. **********"If the yen continues to be weak, there's little room for the ringgit or baht to recover," Mr. Gong said. If the yen stays weak, in his view the most vulnerable currency is the Singapore dollar, which he thinks is overvalued against other Southeast Asian currencies. **********The major risk for Asian currencies, other than a weakening yen, is that countries in the region will decide that lower interest rates and the risk of accelerating inflation are preferable to the high rates that have choked off investment. The move to print money may inflate away a lot of domestic debt, but in the meantime currencies would surely weaken. **********The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that almost all of Asia's currencies will be weaker against the dollar next year than they are now. So how to profit if things seem gloomy in the shorter term? **********As volatile as the markets now are, in many cases they are far less liquid, as imports plunge, trade financing evaporates and foreign investors flee to the safety of other stock markets. One of the most liquid is the Australian dollar, which moves along with feelings about the yen and is easy to sell short. Lower growth in Japan means lower commodity prices, and commodities are what drive Australia's economy. Australia's largest single market is Japan, most of Australia's big customers are in Asia, and commodities consitute nine of its top 10 exports. **********At about 61 U.S. cents, the Australian dollar is stronger now than when it bottomed earlier this year at 58 cents and it also has plenty of upside for those optimists who think Asia has seen the worst of its troubles. **********Jardine Fleming, Fidelity, Rothschild Asset Management and Lloyds International all offer Australia dollar money-market funds in Hong Kong. Australian dollar futures trade on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which on its Web site explains how derivatives work and walks users through a simulated futures trade. . **********One cautionary note: Do not believe analysts who say a currency is strong because it is not fully tradeable. In May, Taiwan banned some trading in nondeliverable forward contracts (an agreement to buy and sell dollars at a prearranged price and date that is settled in local currency), but the Taiwan dollar has weakened anyway. The trade restrictions were blamed for sharp falls in the stock market as risk-averse foreign investors bailed out. **********For further information: **********CHICAGO MERCANTILE EXCHANGE Web site: www.cme.com **********JARDINE FLEMING. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/16/busin.main_headline: FRONTIER SAYS IT WILL BUY GLOBALCENTER FOR $190 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; FRONTIER SAYS IT WILL BUY GLOBALCENTER FOR $190 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/16/busin.body_text: **********The Frontier Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Globalcenter Inc., an Internet service provider, for stock valued at $190.3 million based on Wednesday's closing price. It will also assume $11.5 million of Globalcenter's debt. Frontier, based in Rochester, plans to combine its fiber optic network and 1,000-employee sales force with Globalcenter's commercial Internet-service business. Globalcenter, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., had revenue of about $24 million last year. Globalcenter specializes in setting up multiple computer sites to cut response time when consumers seek information from World Wide Web sites operated by Yahoo, USA Today and others.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/world.main_headline: Malaysia's Chief Suggests Jailed Deputy Caused His Own Bruises
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/world.print_headline: Malaysia's Chief Suggests Jailed Deputy Caused His Own Bruises
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/01/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad suggested today that his jailed former deputy, Anwar Ibrahim, might have punched himself in the eye in order to accuse the police of beating him. **********''According to some quarters, this is not something that is impossible as he will gain much mileage if it can be shown that he is being tortured by police,'' Dr. Mahathir said at a news conference. **********He added that Mr. Anwar's statement in court on Tuesday that he had been beaten by his jailers would be investigated, but he sounded skeptical. **********''Why? Why was he assaulted, if at all he was beaten?'' Dr. Mahathir said. ''This is to his advantage as it is now seen that he has already experienced what he had forecast at the very outset. His prediction was, if arrested he'll be tortured.'' **********The dismissal and subsequent arrest of Mr. Anwar, 51, who had been the Deputy Prime Minister and designated successor of Dr. Mahathir, 72, has stirred unexpectedly widespread anger in what had been seen as one of Southeast Asia's most politically stable nations. **********The Prime Minister's remarks today appeared to inflame the growing condemnation here and abroad of the treatment of Mr. Anwar, who appeared in court for a second day today with bruises on his left eye, his neck and his arms. **********The Bar Council of Malaysia together with several opposition politicians spoke out today to condemn what they said was the beating of Mr. Anwar. **********A local human rights group called Suaram said the Prime Minister's remarks went ''against every basic principle of sanity and logic.'' **********The Prime Minister's statement was met with puzzlement by some people here, who are already confused and distressed by this sudden Government turmoil. Some, obedient by habit, nodded their heads and murmured that the man they call ''Dr. M'' might well be right. **********Others seemed outraged. ''He thinks the people are stupid, accusing Anwar of this and that,'' said a restaurant worker. ''Our people are not stupid, I can tell you that.'' **********In the courtroom today, Mr. Anwar wiped his eye with a handkerchief and pinched his waistband to signal that he had lost weight since he was arrested 10 days ago. **********He pleaded not guilty to a fifth and final charge of performing illegal sex acts. On Tuesday he pleaded not guilty to four charges of sodomy and five charges of corruption -- all but one of which also related to the sodomy charges. **********After much talk about sedition and the leaking of secret documents, as well as of capers with prostitutes and transvestites, all but one of the 10 charges against Mr. Anwar boil down to allegations of four instances of homosexual acts, which are illegal here. **********The one exception is a charge that Mr. Anwar tried to use his influence to deflect corruption charges against an aide. **********The allegations of homosexual acts were weakened Tuesday when two men with whom Mr. Anwar was accused of having sex appealed their convictions. **********Mr. Anwar's contention that he had been beaten received support today after an independent doctor was allowed to examine him. ''In my expert opinion, Anwar Ibrahim was assaulted over the left forehead and neck and received blunt trauma that resulted in residual bruises over the left upper and lower eyelids,'' the doctor, Ahmad Shukri Mohamed, said in a written report after examining him on Tuesday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/18/busin.main_headline: Sky-High Bond Yields Tempt the Brave
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/18/busin.print_headline: Sky-High Bond Yields Tempt the Brave
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/18/busin.body_text: **********Worries about a deepening crisis in Asia are again upsetting the financial markets, driving risk premiums on all emerging-market securities sharply higher. **********But this time, in contrast to previous episodes when such fears temporarily shut down the market for high-yield debt, rising yields have become too irresistible an attraction to disregard. **********The first bout of turbulence in Asia, which started last summer and ran into midwinter, provoked such a outflow of capital that bond markets in perceived havens such as the United States and Europe rallied explosively. This time, however, with that "hot money" already gone, the markets barely shrugged, and investors who thrive on extraordinary income generated by volatile prices saw no choice but to look for bargains in the high-yield market. **********The example most often cited by traders was the South Korean government's 10-year debt. Issued in April, the first international securities ever sold in the government's own name were priced to yield 355 basis points — 3.55 percentage points — more than comparable U.S. government debt. The spread subsequently fell to 320 basis points as confidence in the region and in the country recovered. But last week, falling prices drove the spread out to 430 basis points before it recovered somewhat by week's end to 410 basis points. **********Even Latin American debt was affected, although to a much smaller degree. The spread on Argentina's 30-year bonds rose to 450 basis points, up 50. **********Russia's debt was also caught in the downdraft, and its central bank raised interest rates Friday by as much as 10 percentage points, the first change since March, as slumping bond and equity prices threatened the ruble. **********Despite these unsettled conditions, Slovakia — rated two notches below the lowest investment grade — marketed its multiple offering in yen, Deutsche marks and dollars. Managers said the amount of the mark portion sold had been increased to 600 million DM ($337.4 million) from the initially intended 500 million DM, paying investors 350 basis points over German government paper. **********The dollar portion, the toughest sale, was priced at a spread of 370 basis points. As a measure of just how difficult the environment was, the yield was 70 basis points higher than on comparably dated Argentine paper, which is rated one notch riskier than Slovakia. **********Slovenia, rated single-A, sold 500 million European Currency Units ($552.5 million) of seven-year notes paying 57 basis points over the benchmark level. The Ecu, soon to be the euro, is seen as an appreciating currency, while Slovenia is considered an eventual candidate for a rating upgrade. **********The triple-A rated Asian Development Bank was also caught in the draught, selling $2 billion of five-year notes. A much larger issue had been rumored.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/20/world.snippet: Iran trumpets Clinton Administration decision to waive sanctions against three European companies that trade with it as moral victory for European Union and one that should signal an end to American attempts to deter similar investments (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/20/world.main_headline: Iran Smiles After U.S. Waives Sanctions Against 3 Companies
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/20/world.print_headline: Iran Smiles After U.S. Waives Sanctions Against 3 Companies
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/20/world.body_text: **********Iran today trumpeted a Clinton Administration decision to waive sanctions against three foreign companies that are doing business here as a moral victory for the European Union and  one that should signal an end to American attempts to deter similar investments. **********''The United States finally bowed down to pressure from the European Union,'' the official Iranian news agency declared in a statement that was reflected across the front pages of Iranian newspapers. **********A Government communique called on the United States to repeal altogether the legislation that requires sanctions on companies that deal with Iran. The Administration waived that requirement in the case of French, Russian and Malaysian companies involved in a $2 billion energy deal. **********Iranian officials otherwise withheld formal comment about the decision. But in private conversations, economists and executives have expressed hope that it might signal the abandonment of American attempts to enlist allies in the economic isolation of the Teheran Government. **********Iran, and its energy sector in particular, have made clear their hunger for an influx of foreign investment. But for two years most European and other foreign companies have moved gingerly in negotiations with Iran, as they have watched to see how vigorously the United States would enforce legislation adopted by the Republican-led Congress. The laws require the President to penalize companies that invest more than $20 million a year in the oil and gas  operations of Iran or Libya. The United States has singled out those  countries, accusing them of a role in sponsoring terrorism and in opposing the Middle East peace effort. **********In justifying the shift, American officials said they hoped to win greater cooperation from Europe and Russia in preventing Iran from sponsoring terrorism and acquiring weapons of mass destruction. **********The waiver was granted to Total of France, Gazprom of Russia and Petronas of Malaysia, which joined last year in signing a $2 billion deal to develop the enormous South Pars gas field in the Persian Gulf. **********Iranian officials have suggested that a more immediate result could be a flood of further investments from European companies that had been waiting to measure the United States reaction to the deal. **********In Iran the decision could further boost the standing of President Mohammed Khatami, who, since winning election a year ago, has sought repeatedly to emphasize the importance of opening Iran to greater foreign investment. Mr. Khatami, a relative moderate, has been criticized by his conservative opponents for remarks perceived as too gentle toward the West, including the United States. **********But Mr. Khatami may now be able to portray the removal of the barrier to the big energy investment as the first significant fruit of his policies of increased openness.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.snippet: Sen Jesse Helms, chairman of Senate Foreign Relations Committee, proposes $100 million aid package for Cuba that he contends will improve lives of Cubans while weakening hold of Fidel Castro; proposal, which is endorsed by more than 20 others Sena...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.main_headline: Helms Plans $100 Million Aid Package for Cuba
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.print_headline: Helms Plans $100 Million Aid Package for Cuba
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.body_text: **********Senator Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, proposed a $100 million aid package for Cuba today that he said would improve the lives of Cubans while weakening the hold of Fidel Castro. **********The proposal announced by the North Carolina Republican, which was endorsed by more than 20 other Senators from both parties, would channel food and medical assistance to the Cuban people through the Roman Catholic Church and politically independent relief organizations. **********As envisioned by Mr. Helms, the package would weaken one of the last avowedly Marxist dictators in the world no matter what Mr. Castro did. If Mr. Castro allows the aid to come into his country, ''it will remove his ability to use deprivation as a tool of oppression,'' Mr. Helms said. And if Mr. Castro shuns the help, ''then 11 million Cubans will know exactly who is responsible for their daily suffering.'' **********The announcement by Mr. Helms was no surprise. He has been talking for several months about relief aid for the Cubans. Proposals with similar intent have also been talked about in the House of Representatives. **********Mr. Helms's announcement brought a cautious response from the White House. Eric Rubin, a spokesman for the National Security Council, called the Senator's ideas ''good starting points'' but said the Administration was not endorsing any specific Cuba-aid program at this point. **********''We want to work with the sponsors of these initiatives toward the values we share -- getting food and other humanitarian assistance to the people of Cuba,'' Mr. Rubin said. He said President Clinton had already asked Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright to work with Congressional leaders on the issue. **********Given the complexity and sensitivity of issues about Cuba, Mr. Rubin said, it is not clear when an aid bill will reach Mr. Clinton. But the bipartisan support of Mr. Helms's proposals made some Congressional action seem all but inevitable. **********Mr. Helms's backers included the Republican Senators Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader; Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York and Orrin G. Hatch of Utah. They also included the Democratic Senators Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut and Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey. Mr. Torricelli said the Helms bill ''recognizes the need for humanitarian assistance for the Cubans because of Castro's oppressive policies, and it puts the Castro regime on record as violators of the basic tenets of human rights.'' **********Mr. Clinton announced in March an easing of some American curbs on aid to Cuba. He said he would allow Cuban-Americans in the United States to send money directly to relatives in Cuba through licensed agencies, and that certain charitable organizations would be allowed to conduct direct charter flights from the United States to Cuba, carrying goods for relief purposes or passengers for emergencies like funerals. **********The President's lifting of those curbs was largely a reversal of measures he imposed in August 1994, when in response to an organized exodus of Cuban boat people he barred Cuban-Americans from sending money to relatives on the island.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/30/world.snippet: Boris Berezovsky, Russian tycoon whom Pres Boris N Yeltsin dismissed from his position on Russia's security council six months ago, is appointed chief executive of Commonwealth of Independent States, with Yeltsin's support (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/30/world.main_headline: Yeltsin Appoints Tycoon, a Foe, to Run Commonwealth of States
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/30/world.print_headline: Yeltsin Appoints Tycoon, a Foe, to Run Commonwealth of States
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/30/world.body_text: **********Boris Berezovsky, the tycoon who last week was sidelined in the battle over President Boris N. Yeltsin's nominee for Prime Minister, was given a new job today as chief executive of the Commonwealth of Independent States. **********At a summit meeting today of the loose alliance of former Soviet states, Mr. Yeltsin backed Mr. Berezovsky's nomination, despite objections from some of his fellow heads of state. The Russian President, who six months ago dismissed Mr. Berezovsky from his position on Russia's security council, praised him today as a man of action who will be charged with injecting new life into the floundering Commonwealth. **********Afterward, Mr. Yeltsin was almost gloating over his latest surprise move, relishing the political storm it was bound to raise among Mr. Berezovsky's many enemies. ''For many, it is unexpected, and I think many will explode tomorrow, particularly you,'' he told reporters. ''But swallow it, because it is done for the sake of getting on with business.'' **********The appointment, coming on the heels of Mr. Berezovsky's failed campaign to prevent Sergei V. Kiriyenko from becoming Prime Minister, could be seen as a move to both console Mr. Berezovsky and to keep him away from coming battles over privatization of Russia's rich energy business. Today Deputy Prime Minister Boris Nemtsov -- a Berezovsky foe -- staked a firm claim on that territory in the new Government. **********Mr. Berezovsky's appointment also put a skilled businessman with political ambitions inside an organization that, for the last few years, has been struggling to define itself and its geopolitical role. ''The time has come for decisive steps to build a real Commonwealth,'' Mr. Berezovsky, 52, was quoted as saying. ''Time will show what form it takes.'' **********The Commonwealth meeting, delayed earlier this year because of Mr. Yeltsin's health, was due once again to tackle its identity crisis, as well as a restructuring of its bureaucracy, which is based in the Belarussian capital of Minsk. **********But a disheartened President Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan said he did not expect to see much progress. ''The Commonwealth presidents do not seem to be ready for C.I.S. restructuring,'' he said. **********Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Nazarbayev had also been expected to sign a new pact on dividing the Caspian Sea bed, an issue that is closely watched by oil and gas interests here and in the West. Final agreement has been postponed till July, when Mr. Yeltsin is scheduled to visit to Kazakhstan. **********The Belarussian President, Aleksandr Lukashenko, said the nomination of Mr. Berezovsky, apparently put forward by his old ally, Ivan Rybkin, who is now in charge of Russia's relations with the ex-Soviet states, had generated ''lots of disputes.'' He said it would be ''absurd'' to expect the Russian tycoon to solve the Commonwealth's problems, the blame for which should rest ''with the presidents, because we have too-different approaches to key problems and a very different vision of future development of the C.I.S.'' **********Russia's leftist politicians, who share the deep distrust of Mr. Berezovsky held by the Government's pro-market proponents, pounced on the appointment as another example of what they said was Mr. Yeltsin's high-handed style. Gennadi Zyuganov, head of the Russian Communist Party, said the appointment only ''shows that the Russian President totally neglects public opinion.'' **********But a leader of the Our Home Is Russia faction, Aleksandr Shokhin, said Mr. Yeltsin was using Mr. Berezovsky's business talents to enliven the Commonwealth's economic links.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/14/busin.main_headline: True North Opposed Publicis Unit Merger
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/14/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; True North Opposed Publicis Unit Merger
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/14/busin.body_text: **********Shareholders of Publicis S. A. in Paris have approved the merger of a subsidiary, Publicis Communication, into Publicis despite opposition from a large shareholder, True North Communications in Chicago. **********The approval came at a special meeting on Friday at which True North voted its shares against the transaction. ''I can only regret the confused behavior and contradictory statements by True North,'' Maurice Levy, the president and chief executive at Publicis, said in a statement. **********Publicis has now exchanged True North's 26.3 percent stake in Publicis Communication, which was not publicly traded, for an 8.3 percent stake in Publicis, which is. **********''While we like the liquidity that the merger provides us,'' said Susan Geanuleas, a spokeswoman for True North, ''we're more than a little negative on the value received.'' True North has asked the London Court of International Arbitration to rule whether it was entitled to monetary damages because of a difference between the book value of the True North investment in Publicis and the value of the Publicis shares.

Salmans, a spokesman for Quick & Reilly, who confirmed the deal. **********Mr. Salmans said that the acquisition would make JJC Specialist the second-largest specialist firm after Labranche & Company. **********Specialists are responsible for maintaining orderly markets for exchange-listed stocks, matching buyers and sellers. **********Merrill Lynch, which posted a $164 million in the third quarter, said last month that it would cut 3,400 jobs or about 5 percent of its work force because of global economic turmoil. But a person close to Merrill said that the sale of the specialist firm was not related to that reduction. **********Instead, the person said, Merrill Lynch executives had been considering selling the specialist unit for months because it was not considered to be one of the company's core businesses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/27/busin.snippet: Newly announced alliance between Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines may be harbinger of new wave of domestic joint ventures in airline industry; analysts say US Airways is next on the block, but Delta Air Lines is unlikely suitor because ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/27/busin.main_headline: Merger? What Merger? Call It a Joint Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/27/busin.print_headline: Merger? What Merger? Call It a Joint Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/27/busin.body_text: **********It's been more than a decade since the airline industry saw its last major merger. And if the alliance between Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines is any indication, it might be a while before the streak is broken. **********Instead of traditional mergers, investors may be in for a new wave of domestic joint ventures. ''This is an experiment, a unique arrangement,'' said a person close to the talks. ''The question is, 'Does this deal constitute enough destabilization to have a ripple effect?' I think every company is saying right now, 'I should run the numbers and see.' '' **********Analysts say US Airways is next on the block, a prediction Wall Street traded on all day. Shares peaked at $62.375 before closing at $60, up $3 for the day. Volume was twice its average. **********Jeffrey Long, an airline analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities, said Delta Air Lines was an unlikely suitor for US Airways because there was too much overlap in their service areas. US Airways has routes along much of the East Coast, while Delta has a hub in Atlanta and a large presence in Boston and New York. **********But there are plenty of other partners. Mr. Long said American Airlines, a unit of AMR, and United Airlines, a unit of UAL, were the two most logical candidates to battle for US Airways. Both are weak in the routes that US Airways serves, he said. But neither wants to be forced into it. **********''Both are fearful of each other,'' said the person close to the talks who asked not to be named. ''United is controlled by the unions and there is nothing in it for the unions to merge. From American's viewpoint, unless they are afraid of losing US Air to the competition, why should they aggravate their labor force?'' **********After US Airways, the next logical round of candidates are small regional airlines, like Alaska Airlines, a unit of Alaska Air Group, and America West Airlines, according to Kevin C. Murphy, an airline analyst at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company. **********By his reckoning, the airline industry has little room for new growth, and buying a small regional airline is a way for a large company to gain market share in a region it does not have a presence in. ''If you want to get the West Coast, you buy Alaska Airlines,'' he said. **********But yesterday investors were less optimistic about these stocks than they were about US Airways. Alaska traded down 6.25 cents, closing at $44.50. America West was up 31.25 cents, closing at $21. **********Mr. Long of J. P. Morgan said the Northwest and Continental alliance structure could avert one of the biggest impediments to a merger: labor unrest. Traditionally, he said, ''Outright mergers don't work well because you have a unionized work force,'' and too many people stand to lose jobs. ''They live and die by seniority lists,'' he added. **********For instance, two years ago United wanted to acquire US Airways, then USAir, but the matter was dropped because it posed too much labor risk for United. **********That said, a Northwest-Continental alliance could provide an alternative model for companies to gain efficiencies while preserving many jobs. ''Merging the different unions would be a nightmare,'' Mr. Murphy said. ''That is why you aren't going to see a lot of other mergers.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/21/world.snippet: Ethiopia and Eritrea appear to be on verge of war over 250 square miles of disputed land known as Yigra triangle; both sides, formerly staunch allies, have massed troops in area and accused other of invading zone; crisis has worsened despite effor...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/21/world.main_headline: Ethiopia and Eritrea Seem Ready to Do Battle
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/21/world.print_headline: Ethiopia and Eritrea Seem Ready to Do Battle
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/21/world.body_text: **********Eight years after they jointly won a civil war against a Communist dictator, the leaders of Ethiopia and Eritrea seem to be on the verge of attacking each other over a triangle of rocky land along their shared border. **********Over the weekend each Government massed thousands of troops on each side the disputed territory. In the last week officials from the two countries have attacked each other in increasingly harsh rhetoric, each accusing the other of invading a 250-square-mile zone around Badame known as the Yigra triangle. **********The crisis has worsened despite the efforts of a United States Assistant Secretary of State, Susan E. Rice, who has been shuttling between the two capitals for three days trying to avert a blood bath, Washington officials said. **********''Both of these countries are close friends of the United States,'' a spokesman for the State Department, James P. Rubin, said on Tuesday in Washington. ''We have urged both Governments to practice restraint.'' **********But in a statement issued today, the Ethiopian Foreign Minister, Seyoum Mesfin, said his country was running out of patience and would take ''necessary measures'' unless Eritrea immediately withdrew its troops. Eritrea denies that its forces are even on Ethiopian soil. **********''In case we go into full-scale conflict due to Eritrea's failure to heed Ethiopia's call for unconditional withdrawal of its troops,'' Mr. Seyoum said, ''Ethiopia would like the international community to appreciate how we handled the conflict imposed on us.'' **********Mr. Seyoum delivered his hard-line message a day after the pro-Government newspaper in the Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa, Abiyowawi Democracy, accused Eritrea of having deployed 20,000 troops along the frontier, digging trenches and building defenses around Badame and a second town, Sheraro. **********The report could not be confirmed, although journalists who visited the region on Sunday said that thousands of Eritrean troops had taken up defensive positions. **********The crisis erupted last week, when Ethiopia accused Eritrea of invading its territory. The countries have disagreed about their border since Eritrea gained independence from Ethiopia in 1993, but remained staunch allies, anyway. **********One reason is historical. Eritrean rebels played a pivotal role in the alliance of Ethiopian rebel groups that ousted the Marxist dictator of Ethiopia, Mengistu Haile Mariam, in May 1991 and set up the current Government. But the amicable dispute between old comrades-in-arms over which colonial-era map should be used to draw a modern border took a nasty turn on May 6, when forces from both sides clashed inside the disputed zone. **********Details of what occurred are sketchy. Ethiopia says Eritrean troops crossed into its territory, ransacked health centers and schools and kidnapped civil servants. Ethiopian officials maintain that the troops are still inside their territory.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/28/techn.snippet: German magazine Stern plans to carry translation of on-line magazine Nerve, which bills itself as 'literate smut,' in its on-line version; Nerve editor-in-chief Rufus Griscom says magazine pursues other foreign deals and possible print version in ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/28/techn.main_headline: Zine of 'Literate Smut' Finds a Significant Other
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/28/techn.print_headline: NEWS WATCH; Zine of 'Literate Smut' Finds a Significant Other
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/28/techn.body_text: **********Nerve, the on-line magazine that bills itself as ''literate smut,'' has found a mainstream partner, a magazine that is more used to covering celebrities and news than publishing long personal essays about sexuality and artful nude photographs. **********But not in America. In the middle of June, Stern magazine, Germany's popular newsweekly, will begin carrying a translation of Nerve, complete with photographs, in its on-line version. **********Since it began last year, Nerve has attracted attention for its impressive roster of writers. It reprinted a long out-of-print interview with Norman Mailer in which the author discussed at length his own sexuality, and former Surgeon General Joycelyn Elders wrote about masturbation. Other contributors include Sally Tisdale, Nancy Friday and Christopher Durang. **********Rufus Griscom, Nerve's editor-in-chief, said the magazine was pursuing similar deals in Japan, France and Sweden, and was talking to a handful of publishing companies in the United States about the possibility of a print version of Nerve. But he said American mainstream magazines were squeamish about Nerve's content. **********Fortunately, said Genevieve Field, Nerve's executive editor, ''our content isn't limited by geography or time.'' She added, ''These are universal human experiences our writers are writing about. It translates very well.'' Some 27 percent of the site's traffic comes from outside the United States, she said. **********England, on the other hand, has not been quite as receptive, Ms. Field said. ''Even though there's more sex in the media there, with more nudity in advertising and brashness in comedy, they are largely a society of manners,'' she said. ''And the kind of brutally honest writing Nerve prides itself on does not keep a polite distance on the subject.'' **********Nerve is one of very few American Web-based magazines to be translated into a foreign language. Sonicnet, a Web zine for alternative music, has Japanese and Swiss (German) versions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/06/world.main_headline: Former Korean Dissident Returns to Land of Exile as Head of State
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/06/world.print_headline: Former Korean Dissident Returns to Land of Exile as Head of State
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/06/world.body_text: **********Fourteen years ago, Kim Dae Jung was a pro-democracy activist living in exile in Washington, struggling with his English and with American officials who saw him as a pest. **********''I was an irritant that the State Department and the President wanted to do without,'' Mr. Kim wrote about the Reagan Administration in his unpublished autobiography. ''The White House consistently rebuffed my direct approaches and my request for a meeting with the President.'' **********When President Kim of South Korea returns to the United States for a nine-day state visit beginning on Saturday, he will get better treatment. This time he is to stay in Washington at Blair House, the American Government's official guest residence, and address a joint session of Congress. **********Mr. Kim, the onetime dissident who became South Korea's President in February, will also get a state dinner at the White House, receive a human rights award and pick up an honorary degree at Georgetown University. **********Yet, asked if he was tempted to pick up the telephone at Blair House and place an ''I told you so'' call to some of the former gate-keepers who used to fend him off, Mr. Kim paused only a moment to savor the idea. He grinned and demurred, but he said he did draw some lessons from his reversal of fortune. **********''You have to live long,'' he said with a sparkle in his eye. **********Mr. Kim has indeed lived long -- he is 74 -- and he credits his survival in part to American intervention when Korean dictators planned to kill him. That makes his state visit an especially poignant moment, diplomats and Korean officials say. **********Moreover, Mr. Kim in some ways trumpets what are often called American values even more than Americans do. **********''The fact that the United States so frequently speaks out on human rights issues in other countries, sometimes to the disadvantage of its own national interests, that is what makes the United States great, that is what makes it earn respect from around the world,'' Mr. Kim said in an hourlong interview this week in Blue House, the presidential mansion in Seoul. **********Still, Mr. Kim acknowledged that in some respects he is now in the position of the officials who fended him off when he was a dissident. Asked if he sometimes faces a choice between his moral principles and the dictates of statecraft, when he ponders whether to speak out on issues  like human rights in China, Mr. Kim nodded. **********''I am faced with that dilemma,'' he said. ''And certainly I cannot say at this point whether I will or will not make a public statement about that. But I do have a great deal of personal interest in what happens in China and Myanmar, especially Myanmar,'' he added, referring to the country formerly known as Burma. **********These days, Mr. Kim has emerged to some extent as a spokesman for the region and not just his country. The state visit to America will add to his stature and to this regional leadership role, a role that he seems to relish. **********''As painful as the current situation is, we wish to use it as much as we can to push through economic reforms, to make our democracy stronger, so that we will be a model for the Asian region, a model that says that you have to promote democracy and the free market in parallel, and that the future of Asia lies in this model,'' Mr. Kim said. **********Yet for Mr. Kim to sustain his role as a model for the region, he will first have to overcome South Korea's economic crisis. And that too is a reason for the state visit: Mr. Kim will begin his visit in the financial capital of New York, not the political capital of Washington, and he will emphasize South Korea's efforts to restructure its economy and woo investors. **********''It is of utmost importance that we win foreign investment,'' Mr. Kim said. ''With the capital that comes in with foreign investment, we can pay back our debts. With the foreign capital will come new ways of management, making our management more rational and breathing new life into our economy.'' **********After arriving in New York on Saturday and helping open the Korea Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and speaking to several organizations, Mr. Kim is to go to Washington on Monday for a meeting with President Clinton and his speech to Congress. On Thursday, he will travel to California and deliver a speech at Stanford University and visit Silicon Valley. On June 12 he will go on to Los Angeles, a center for Korean-Americans, and will leave for home the next day. **********Mr. Kim was hailed at home as virtually a savior when he took office, even as he lectured his nation on the need to accept the pain of layoffs and restructuring. But in recent weeks, some business analysts have said the steam has gone out of his initiatives. **********Mr. Kim disagrees. He said he is concerned about rising unemployment but still confident that South Korea is on the right track to recreate itself as a more open and market-oriented economy. **********''What gives me hope is that we are probably over the worst phase of the foreign currency crunch,'' he said, adding that foreign exchange reserves have risen from $3.8 billion last December to $34 billion today. Interest rates have dropped and a trade deficit has turned into a substantial surplus, he noted. **********One concern for foreign investors has been the militancy of South Korean unions, which have been hostile to layoffs and have turned to strikes and sometimes violence to resist restructuring. The unions have agreed to postpone strikes until Mr. Kim's return from the United States, however, and Mr. Kim argues that the worst is over for the labor unrest. He also promises to crack down on unions that break the law.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/19/busin.body_text: **********Barnes & Noble Inc. is expecting sales at its Internet book-selling site to reach $8 million in the current quarter, helped by the holidays. **********The company also said sales in the fiscal year that begins this month are expected to exceed $100 million. **********The sales forecasts come as Barnes & Noble moves to expand its Barnesandnoble.com site, which offers books for as much as 40 percent off the list price. **********Since the site was introduced in May, sales have doubled in each of its three quarters of operation, as the number of customers using the service rose to more than 250,000, the company said. **********Barnes & Noble said sales during the holiday season ended Jan. 3 were $5.6 million. During the site's first quarter of operation, sales were $2.1 million and in its second quarter, they were $4 million, the company said. **********Barnes & Noble also said it would increase advertising and marketing efforts during the next year to encourage more sales. **********Barnes & Noble, based in New York, is the largest United States bookseller, with 484 superstores and 555 stores in malls. **********Its mall stores include the B. Dalton Bookseller, Doubleday Book Shops and Scribner's Bookstores chains.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/10/busin.body_text: **********The French companies Aerospatiale, Thomson-CSF, Lagardere and Alcatel agreed not to compete with each other for missile contracts, ending a dispute that had threatened to derail France's plans to reshape its military industry. The pact also reverses an earlier accord that would have kept Aerospatiale out of the satellite business after it gave its satellite unit to Thomson-CSF, the four companies said. **********France's reorganized military companies, led by Aerospatiale and Thomson-CSF, are under pressure to forge partnerships with European rivals before potential partners look to the United States for alliances. Behind the accord is the French Government's insistence that it play a leading role in a single European aerospace and military company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/17/techn.snippet: Newest feature on Internet is personalization, tailor-made collection of information that user gets regularly; without 'personalized page,' user must resort to laboriously searching Internet, plowing through more than 650,000 sites on Web alone; I...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/17/techn.main_headline: Happy Birthday, Your Team Won, Your Stock Crashed
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/17/techn.print_headline: Happy Birthday, Your Team Won, Your Stock Crashed
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/17/techn.body_text: **********WEEKDAY mornings for Jessica Nierenberg, a 23-year-old research manager at a market research company in San Francisco, usually begin with a dash to her neighborhood bus stop for a 30-minute ride to her office in the city's financial district downtown. By 8:30 she is at her desk, pouring herself a bowl of breakfast cereal and firing up her computer for a glimpse at what the planet has wrought while she slept. **********What greets her on her computer's screen is selected and displayed by My Yahoo, a free service by Yahoo, the giant Internet information company based in Santa Clara, Calif. My Yahoo shows Ms. Nierenberg how many E-mail messages she has waiting to be read and a sampling of news headlines -- she can decide to call up any of the articles on domestic, political and international news for a more detailed look. Weather forecasts for her area and for Boston, her hometown, are parked in a corner of the screen. **********That wake-up dose of Internet offerings is, more or less, created specifically for Ms. Nierenberg, who, while computer savvy, doesn't consider herself a computer nerd (she does not have a computer at home, for instance). What she gets is a tailor-made collection of information that she has informed Yahoo she wants to get regularly. ''It definitely saves me time,'' said Ms. Nierenberg, whose work requires her to be on a computer for at least eight hours a day. ''It's nice to be able to push one button whenever I log on and to get all of this.'' **********The process that delivers all of that daily digital data to her and millions more is called personalization, the newest wave washing over the ever-changing shores of the Internet. After years of shaky starts, personalization promises to re-emphasize the personal in personal computing. **********Without a ''personalized page,'' as she likes to call it, Ms. Nierenberg would have to resort to laboriously searching the Internet herself, plowing through more than 650,000 sites on the Web alone. One of the chief ideas driving personalization, many Internet experts say, is that the Internet, a victim of its own success, has become too voluminous for most people to handle comfortably and efficiently. If you're not using personalization, said Joe Kraus, senior vice president and co-founder of Excite, ''you are not taking advantage of the medium.'' **********The thinking behind personalization goes something like this: What if your computer ''knew'' you, had a reasonable sense of your on-line interests and preferences and could respond to them? Forcing the computer to conform to your information needs rather than forcing you to conform to the computer's requirements is a step, many agree, toward realizing the vision that Nicholas P. Negroponte, director of the Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, calls ''the daily me.'' **********Services like My Yahoo, My Excite and even the set-top Web cruiser My Web TV (like other personalized features offered by America Online and the Microsoft Network, it is part of a service that requires a monthly fee) are increasingly fetching the kinds of content that their users say they want: specific types of news, weather forecasts, sports scores and schedules, stock quotations, horoscopes, television schedules, movie show times and state lottery results, for example. Many of these services also feature lists of users' favorite Web sites, chat rooms and message boards, along with daily health tips, travel alerts and on-line reminders of occasions like anniversaries and birthdays of relatives and friends. **********''It is empowering,'' said Steve Boxer, a  computer consultant who owns Pachyderm Consulting in Brooklyn, speaking of his experience with personalization. ''It really molds your computer to your interests.'' **********The first personalization service from a major on-line company was the Microsoft Network, or MSN. When it began in the fall of 1995, it offered users a relatively primitive capacity to customize the kinds of information they received. In January the following year, Excite created My Excite, which was followed that summer by My Yahoo. In July, Netscape, the leading Internet browser company, started offering My Netscape. While America Online offers its members very limited personalization with My AOL, a company spokesman said AOL will begin a much more fully featured service called My News in the next few weeks.. **********Competition among the companies offering personalization is intense, resembling at times the browser wars between Netscape and Microsoft. Refinements by one are often followed quickly by similar refinements by the others. **********Representatives of the personalization services refused to disclose just how many dollars each company has poured into creating and continually tweaking its service. But Mr. Kraus did say that his company, Excite, had spent a ''significant investment in terms of manpower, money, hardware and engineering time'' in creating its version of personalization, called My Excite. **********Nor will the companies reveal the number of subscribers for each service. ''It has exceeded some expectations,'' said Henry Sohn, a senior producer for personalization for Yahoo. ''Part of that is due to the overall growth in the Internet with each quarter. But it is clear that personalization services are really popular.'' **********THE promise of personalization had been on the lips of computer visionaries for years, even while the Internet struggled to find its identity. In the mid-1990's, software makers began selling off-the-shelf products like Pointcast Network that automatically log on to the Net, download categories of information broadly defined by users and then log off. These products, known as ''push'' technologies, began falling out of favor because they tended to be resource hogs and to deposit overwhelming amounts of information on computer hard drives. **********As many began to complain that push information was not selective enough, some users started looking for something that could pull from the Internet more specific information that matched their interests. **********''Back then, people didn't know what they wanted, so they wanted things pushed at them,'' said Rob Bernstein, a senior editor at Yahoo Internet Life, a monthly magazine about Net use. ''The Net pretty much rejected that idea. Pull it down. That is the idea of personalization.'' **********But the idea of personalization, some experts acknowledged, has been difficult to sell. Part of the problem, said David Sze, vice president for network programming and content at Excite, is that personalization is hard to describe. The concept, he noted, tends to ''come off very soft, vague.'' **********Using personalization is hardly automatic. First, you must register for it. (Many of the companies offering personalization, including Excite, Yahoo and MSN, have been trying to entice potential users by including very visible links from their popular home pages to their personalization pages.) Registration also means filling out an on-line questionnaire that can take anywhere from a few minutes to a half-hour to complete. (My Excite goes another step, giving brief descriptions of why it requests certain information. It says, for example, ''Your birth date is used to provide your horoscope.'') Designers of personalization services noted that the more information users provided about themselves, the more personalized the service would be. **********The My Yahoo form is much more tedious when it asks users to choose the information they want and how it is to be displayed. Each user enters preferences for a front page and pages for subjects like health, entertainment, business, chat and message boards. Each subject page has a dozen slots, and each slot holds a pull-down menu offering 36 choices of content, like sports scoreboards, information about vitamins and herbs, and news headlines. **********A user may choose one menu item for each slot. Each selection leads to that categories of information being displayed and updated whenever the personalized pages are viewed. My Yahoo goes even further, pressing for even more detail about a user's ''specific interests.'' The categories there, like news, life styles, music and shopping, are more finely tuned. The answers may very well determine whether the Epicurious Web site for fine cooking appears on your finished page rather than Gamespot, which is popular among computer twitch gamers. **********''It helps us in a number of ways to offer a service that users find more relevant,'' Mr. Sohn at Yahoo said of the questionnaire. **********Once the services have an idea of what users want, they extract the information from various sources. To do that, they use relationships with news operations and other partners as well as their own powerful search engines. In most cases, as with My Yahoo, My Excite and My Netscape, the information is stored in central databases. **********When someone goes on line and types in a user name and a password, a cookie -- an identifying tag stored on the user's computer -- tells the personalization service who is requesting information. Based on what is in the cookie (for My Netscape it is a 16-digit number) the information is unlocked from the database and sent in a fraction of a second to the user. Most of the services regularly update their information and use both machines and people to match the right streams of information with the right users, personalization managers say. **********Just how these services actually work depends on closely held proprietary technologies, but many personalization operators agree that the services have been made possible by advances in database hardware and software in the last several years, by high-speed user-indentification systems and by the capacity to generate pages on the fly over the Internet. **********''Making it easy for people is our overarching design point,'' said Eckart Walther, product manager for My Netscape. ''It makes information come to you rather than you going to the information.'' **********Nathan Beckord, a 26-year-old research associate for an investment bank in San Francisco, uses My Yahoo to check his stock portfolio and to glance at news about his investments. **********''For each portfolio, I have it customized to display what I want, quote the volume, and below that it shows the news,'' he said. Mr. Beckord also has the service set up as his default page, so it is the first thing he sees when he goes on line at work or at home. **********Users like Mr. Beckord are very useful to Internet companies, which is why the companies invested in personalization. The detailed information users give them about exactly what they want to see on line serves as a kind of survey. The information helps personalization managers decide what kinds of content to add, maintain or remove from their offerings. More important, many of the same managers said, the information makes it possible to match the advertising to users' interests and needs. **********Much as sporting goods manufacturers know that they have a better chance of reaching their market by advertising on ESPN, the national cable sports network, rather than with general-interest programs, advertisers are looking for much of the same result by having their advertisements sent over the Internet to people whose declared interests identify them as likely customers, explained Mr. Sze, of Excite. **********Mr. Sohn, of Yahoo, offered an example. ''If we know someone is not interested in travel,'' he said, ''then we are not likely to display an ad from an airline or travel agency.'' And the better his company is able to aim advertising, he added, the more it can charge for that advertising. **********But Mr. Sze said the use of personalization as an effective advertising tool had just begun. ''The true value of this is not being realized the way it is going to be,'' said Mr. Sze, adding that on a scale of 1 to 10, personalization's use of advertising was in the 3-to-5 range. But, he said, Excite is preparing to step up its use of targeted advertising on the Internet. **********Mr. Walther also noted that personalization made good business sense because it was a way to capture more users, people who are approaching the Internet differently from their early-adopter predecessors. **********''We are seeing a lot more practical use of the Web,'' he said. ''A lot of people don't go on the Web to just have fun.'' He said people tended to care more about how much time they were on the Internet and how much they accomplished. Personalization, he said, especially speaks to such users. **********And, added Mr. Boxer, the New York computer consultant, many new Internet users start with personalization services and keep returning to those companies. ''Everyone has to start someplace,'' he said, ''and the people who control the starting place hold some very valuable real estate.'' **********Because personalization requires the user to give a series of very specific preferences, there are growing concerns about what companies will do with all this new information. Mr. Sohn and other personalization service operators said the industry followed  strict guidelines to protect users' privacy. Many of the companies' policies regarding privacy are clearly stated on line and linked to the questionnaires. **********''We care very deeply about privacy,'' Mr. Sohn said. ''We go overboard to make users aware that we don't sell usage information to anyone.'' **********Another objection to the current personalization services is that they simply do not go far enough. Walter Bender, associate director of the M.I.T. Media Lab, said he would like to see additional levels of integration between, for example, on-line information and personal on-line calendars. The result, he said, would be more sophisticated services that would not only deliver tailored content but would also match that information with what a user was actually doing. You're taking a business trip to the Caribbean? Your computer would start delivering news, weather and travel information about the Caribbean as your departure date approached. **********Nonetheless, many Internet experts say, personalization is expected to be the buzz on the Internet for years to come, as it is tweaked and refined along the way. ''It's not going to go away,'' Mr. Sze predicted. **********It is simply a matter of Internet destiny, others say. **********''This is the only medium,'' Mr. Kraus said, ''that is inherently personalizable.''

F&M, based in Frederick, Md., which has total assets of about $1.07 billion, is buying Monocacy, parent of Taneytown Bank and Trust, to move into a contiguous region of Maryland, the bank said. F&M agreed to pay 2.22 million shares to purchase Monocacy, based in Taneytown, Md., and which has assets of $294 million.
