https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/16/news/.main_headline: Amid Uncertainty, Policymakers Talk Up Currency : Trans-Atlantic Cheer for Euro
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/16/news/.print_headline: Amid Uncertainty, Policymakers Talk Up Currency : Trans-Atlantic Cheer for Euro
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/16/news/.body_text: **********WASHINGTON—                     The European commissioner overseeing the historic shift to a single currency brought a message of reassurance here Wednesday, saying that while the advent of the euro will represent "an unprecedented challenge," the transition from 11 currencies to one should bolster the global economy without unduly roiling foreign exchange markets. **********The comments by Yves-Thibault de Silguy, the European commissioner for economic and financial affairs, followed meetings here with Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and the deputy Treasury secretary, Lawrence Summers. **********His remarks came against a backdrop of uncertainty about what the euro, which is to go into use Jan. 1, will mean to the dollar and other major currencies, whether it will lead to short-term volatility in foreign-exchange markets, and whether, in the longer term, it will come to rival the dollar as a global reserve currency, which could push U.S. interest rates higher. **********To those who cite such reasons in saying the euro could become a source of confrontation between Europe and the United States, Mr. de Silguy was blunt: "I do not agree." The euro, he said, would create an opportunity for a more balanced international monetary system. Mr. de Silguy told a group of bankers, business leaders and economists that the "euro is not a leap in the dark" but is built on "rock-solid political commitment." **********To give grounding to his enthusiasm, he noted that long-term interest rates in Europe — determined by the markets and not by politicians — have converged to record low levels in the 11 European countries set to form the euro zone. **********While he did not venture to estimate to what extent the euro would supplant the dollar as a reserve currency held by central banks, he did predict that the switch would begin immediately. **********As the euro accounts for a greater share of reserves, he said, the result would be a more balanced monetary system, as well as new trade and investment opportunities that would "create additional incentives for policymakers on both sides of the Atlantic to look outwards." Trans-Atlantic cooperation will be necessary, he said, "to avoid protracted currency misalignments which could provoke protectionist reactions." **********The use of the euro in commercial transactions, he added, would spread quickly from euro-zone countries to nations on their borders, and then quickly around the Mediterranean. He said it would make strong inroads on the dollar, which is now used for 50 percent of global commercial transactions and 80 percent of financial deals. **********The volume of new government debt issued in euro will "be equal at least to that issued by the U.S. Treasury," he said, without stipulating a time period. "I do not expect brutal change overnight, but progressively." **********His comments came after a week in which foreign exchange markets took center stage in the Japanese economic drama, a fresh sign of the power of currency values in determining a nation's fiscal well-being. Japanese authorities intervened to prop up the yen against the dollar amid fears that a weak yen could further destabilize Asia and swell the U.S. trade deficit. **********The American position on the euro was voiced on Tuesday by Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin, who said: "It has been our view — the view of the United States government — for a long time that anything that benefits Europe economically is good for the United States." **********"I don't think it's going to adversely affect the position of the dollar," Mr. Rubin said, "either as a reserve currency or with respect to the use of the dollar in international finance." **********The euro, following a road map to be confirmed at a special EU meeting in Brussels starting May 1, will be used in financial exchanges in the 11 euro zone countries starting Jan. 1; it will circulate in note and coin form three years later. **********Most European traders, economists and officials have expressed confidence that the euro will be a sound and stable currency. Exchange rates among the countries of the euro zone — Austria, Belgium, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain — have been stable, and interest rates have been converging. **********Most economists stress the gradualism of the process. **********"I don't see Japan or anyone else flocking to the euro on Day 1," Greg Berger, a Treasury official in the U.S. mission to the European Union said recently in Brussels, "particularly selling dollars to buy euros. And at the end of it all, if the Euro begins to put pressure on the dollar, the net effect is to put pressure on the United States to pursue sound economic policies." **********But some analysts have raised concerns about short-term ups and downs. **********"The dollar-euro rate can go anywhere," said Daniel Gros, deputy director of the Center for European Policy Studies in Brussels. "It can be volatile. But in the short run, I don't think a lot will happen." He said he expected the world's central banks eventually to split their dollar and euro holdings evenly. **********Francois Charriere, managing partner of Andersen Consulting in Paris, said: "In the short term, we may have very high volatility between the dollar and the euro, given the vast amounts of dollars to move. But then it'll stabilize." **********But Alan Watson, chairman of Burson-Marsteller Europe, predicted a more rapid rise for the euro. **********"I have no doubt the euro will become a trading and reserve currency quite quickly," accounting for as much as 40 percent of global reserves "in the next few years," he said recently in London. "That's a situation the U.S. has not faced in the postwar period. That's going to have an impact on the dollar, on the American deficit."

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/15/busin.snippet: John Wong has patented for TAL Apparel Ltd process to perfect wash-and-wear cotton shirt by embedding adhesive material into seams to prevent threads from shrinking or puckering; shirts with company's maintenance-free seams are already on market; ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/15/busin.main_headline: Patents; Laundries, beware! Here comes a prototype improved wash-and-wear cotton shirt.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/15/busin.print_headline: Patents; Laundries, beware! Here comes a prototype improved wash-and-wear cotton shirt.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/15/busin.body_text: **********COTTON shirt is soft, comfortable and, very often, wrinkled -- especially right after it is pulled out of the dryer. The sleeves and panels come out faintly lined, like a dry riverbed, but it is the cuffs, collar and pockets that take -- and show -- the real beating. A bit of time and effort with an iron and spray starch can restore a smooth sheen, but nothing looks as neatly tailored as a cotton shirt fresh from the dry cleaner. **********It costs more, too. Permanent- press polyester and then wrinkle-free cottons were hailed as eliminating the need for ironing or dry cleaning. But even when the best of those materials went into a shirt, the seams would pucker. That is because thread used to sew the shirt together shrinks at a rate different from the fabric. So, fresh from the dryer, even wrinkle-free fabrics looked rumpled around the edges. **********This makes a prototype shirt sewn with a patented seam technology all the more remarkable. Half the shirt is made of ordinary fabric and thread, the other half from wrinkle-free cotton and treated seams. After washing in warm water and ordinary detergent, the shirt comes out of a hot tumble-dry cycle looking as if the right side had just been removed from the store packaging. The collar and cuff are flat and flawless. There is a temptation to throw it back in the wash just to make sure it's not an optical illusion. **********The patented technology belongs to TAL Apparel Ltd., a Hong-Kong based clothing maker that produces 30 million shirts a year for companies like Calvin Klein, Eddie Bauer, the Gap, Banana Republic and Burberry's. The inventor is the company's textile scientist, John Wong. **********Mr. Wong perfected the wash-and-wear cotton shirt by embedding an adhesive material into the seams to prevent threads from shrinking or puckering. TAL's Washington patent lawyer, Bradford E. Kile, said the adhesive was applied via a fusible tape about an inch wide. He explained that the tape was laid between adjoining pieces of fabric, and  ''the thread is sewn through the outermost layer and the fusible bonding strip and the layer beneath it.'' **********''After the stitch is made, the seam is placed under heat and pressure, and the seam is fused together,'' he added. **********Mr. Kile said the adhesive tape adds only pennies to a shirt's cost. **********''I have all my shirts laundered, and it costs a dollar a shirt,'' Mr. Kile said. ''The starch tends to shrink the collar, and that can be harsh and irritate the neck. The added cost to manufacturing is saved after the first time you take the shirt to the laundry.'' **********The seam technology is designed to last for the life of the shirt, Mr. Kile said, adding that TAL is ''using the technology themselves and including it in all the seams that their clients want.'' TAL makes shirts in Hong Kong, Thailand and Malaysia. It has also licensed its patents to competitors like Phillips-Van Heusen. Shoppers can already buy shirts with maintenance-free seams, if they know what to look for. **********''This just came out at the end of 1997, and it's going to have a negative impact on the laundry industry, but I guess they'll survive,'' Mr. Kile said. ''Brooks Brothers makes it in pink, blue, yellow and white. But you have to ask for it, and they'll send it to you in the mail.'' **********Mr. Wong received patents 5,713,292; 5,590,615 and 5,568,779. **********New Way to Replace Elevator Doors **********The Americans with Disabilities Act stipulates that elevator doors must open and close automatically. But many elevators in older apartment buildings have swinging or telescoping doors or gates that must be operated by hand. In New York City, high-rise public housing buildings from the 1940's and 1950's still feature their original swinging elevator doors. Past solutions for replacing them included taking space from inside the elevator car, or tearing out walls in the hallway to accommodate new equipment. Making elevator cars smaller is inconvenient for all users, not only the disabled, and removing walls during construction is dangerous **********Harold Friedman says he has a better solution. Mr. Friedman owns the National Elevator Cab and Door Company in New York City and has patented a sliding elevator door assembly and installation process that uses the space occupied by swinging door mechanisms. He came up with the solution after ripping open a wall to replace a swing door the traditional way. **********''I had an image of our company and my picture on the 10 o'clock news because somebody fell down an elevator shaft,'' Mr. Friedman explained. With his system, the old door assembly is replaced with a frame for a sliding door. The frame is attached adjacent to the car door, and a track and hanger system is added to the transom area above the door. **********''The door then slides into the frame like a pocket door,'' Mr. Friedman explained. The side and transom frames are covered with the stationary panels. ''We can do it in one day.'' **********The patented system has already been installed in older buildings in New York City. Mr. Friedman received patent 5,673,770. **********Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/04/news/.main_headline: They Soften Schroeder's Position : Social Democrats Talk Up the Euro
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/04/news/.print_headline: They Soften Schroeder's Position : Social Democrats Talk Up the Euro
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/04/news/.body_text: **********FRANKFURT—                     - A day after Germany's Social Democrats nominated a candidate for chancellor who once recommended that Europe consider a delay of its planned single currency, the party took pains Tuesday to portray itself as a supporter of the euro. **********In a reassurance to Bonn's European partners, the Social Democratic Party's parliamentary leader, Rudolf Scharping, issued a response to the appeal Monday by its candidate, Gerhard Schroeder, for a fresh debate on the risks of currency union. **********Immediately after his nomination, Mr. Schroeder promised to convene a "roundtable of the best brains in the land to analyze the risks of the euro in an impartial manner." To lead the panel, Mr. Schroeder said he would recruit Karl Otto Poehl, a former president of the German central bank and a Social Democrat. **********In an interview on German radio, Mr. Scharping touted his party's pro-European credentials. "The goal of our party is to protect the consumers and ensure the stability of the currency," he said. "This has nothing to do with Euro-skepticism." **********Known more for his pragmatism and populism than for his convictions, Mr. Schroeder recognizes that monetary union has gained too much momentum to be delayed without unleashing chaos in Europe's economic and political affairs, political observers said. **********"He will not do anything to undermine the position of his party, it is not worth it," said Dieter Roth, senior researcher at the Forschungs Gruppe Wahlen, an independent political research firm. "The whole discussion will be over in May and the election is not until September," said Mr. Roth, referring to the selection of the euro's launching nations by European Union leaders in early May. **********Although Mr. Schroeder spent much of last year honing an image as a Euro-skeptic, he has distanced himself since then from Germany's hard-line opponents of the single currency. He kept the issue on the back burner during the campaign before his re-election Sunday as state premier of Lower Saxony, where his emphasis on Germany's record unemployment and his strident attacks on Chancellor Helmut Kohl won him a strong majority. **********Attempts by the Social Democrats to exploit voter fears over the loss of the trusted Deutsche mark failed to win votes in several state elections in the last two years, most recently in Hamburg last September — a misstep that Mr. Schroeder was careful not to repeat in his state. **********Despite his latest calls for a review of any risks, Bonn's European partners probably have little to worry about if the chancellorship switches hands in the Sept. 27 election, said Holger Schmieding, senior economist at Merrill Lynch in Frankfurt. **********"The issue might have had some value before the Hamburg election in attracting right-wing votes, but it will not be interesting after May," Mr. Roth said. **********Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats have accused Mr. Schroeder of populism over his calls for a delay in the inauguration of the euro in January if the EU fails to apply the euro's budget deficit benchmarks strictly. But adopting an anti-euro stance has become more difficult in Germany since all 11 candidate nations announced last week that they had succeeded in meeting the deficit benchmarks, Mr. Schmieding said. **********"In any event, the political decision on the euro was made long ago," Mr. Scharping told German radio.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/14/techn.snippet: Joseph Siano, editor at The Times who covered auto racing for the paper from 1989 to 1997, evaluates CD-ROM game Cart Precision Racing, from Microsoft; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/14/techn.main_headline: Road Races Are a Challenge But Graphics Don't Keep Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/14/techn.print_headline: LIBRARY/AUTO RACING SIMULATIONS; Road Races Are a Challenge But Graphics Don't Keep Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/14/techn.body_text: **********CART PRECISION RACING **********(Microsoft; $54.95; Windows 95 and NT.) **********IF a steady diet of left turns isn't for you, this simulator provides a mix of high-speed ovals and twisty road-racing courses, negotiated in a much faster and more technologically exotic form of racer: the Indy car. Like Nascar Racing 2, however, CART Precision Racing does not contain the most famous racetrack of all, the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Thanks to the real-world politics of motor sports, that race is part of the rival Indy Racing League series (which licenses its own simulation game through ABC Sports). **********The CART game (the name refers to the Championship Auto Racing Teams series) is also missing the driver with the most famous last name in the sport: Michael Andretti, whose family licenses its name to another game maker. But you can still drive Mr. Andretti's car, or that of any other driver in the 1997 CART season. The tutorials here -- narrated on the disk by Bobby Rahal, the 1986 Indy 500 winner -- are very good, explaining the proper techniques for various types of turns as well as how to brake and steer. The accompanying manual contains maps of each of the 17 courses on the disk, with pointers on which gear the car should be in at each turn. Patrick Carpentier, last season's rookie of the year, used this simulator to familiarize himself with the real racetracks. **********Once on the track, you can have the proper path through each turn (or the ''line,'' as racers call it) illustrated by a red stripe, as well as by ghost highway cones. Nigel Bennett, a noted Indy-car designer, provides voice-over tips for the dozens of mechanical adjustments players can make. As with all these games, a set of default settings is automatically used unless a player chooses otherwise. **********This game has the weakest graphics of the games reviewed here; the graphics are fluttery and a touch jerky, although with minimum pixelation. The trackside scenery just barely outran the car -- the highway ramps over the downtown Vancouver circuit would grow before your eyes -- although the background scenery, like the Gateway Arch and the rest of the St. Louis skyline at one track, was good. The flutter can be eliminated with simpler graphics settings, but these produce very pixelated and jerky images. **********To run the game, Microsoft recommends a 166-megahertz chip, 32 megabytes of RAM, 100 free megabytes on the hard drive, a 6X CD-ROM and a super VGA graphics card. **********The first thing you will probably want to do with CART Precision Racing is mute the annoying music that plays whenever you are on the track. Otherwise, the sound quality is good. **********Tip: During a race, make sure you don't accidentally steer into the pit lane; if you do, the game automatically assumes that you want to make a pit stop, a time-consuming process you cannot override.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/17/techn.snippet: Article appraises America Online's new 4.0 version of its software; drawing (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/17/techn.main_headline: A Second Look at AOL, the Refurbished Ellis Island of the Net
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/17/techn.print_headline: USER'S GUIDE; A Second Look at AOL, the Refurbished Ellis Island of the Net
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/17/techn.body_text: **********EVERY society has its own class system, and so it is with the Internet. So, of course, the people who were first on line -- the early settlers who can reminisce about the good old days of the Arpanet -- get the most points for snob appeal. They are the on-line equivalent of those who claim that their ancestors were on the Mayflower. **********It is this class system that explains the simmering resentment among early adopters toward America Online. That on-line service has long been a kind of wired Ellis Island, a gateway through which the great unwashed arrive on the Internet shore. I felt no gratitude to America Online for easing my own on-line arrival a few years ago because I, too, wanted desperately to be mistaken for the kind of blueblood who had been on line since the early days, a charter member of the Daughters of the Internet Revolution. It never occurred to me to applaud the service for creating a painless gateway with its easy installation and setup process and its See-Dick-Run interface. **********As soon as I could, I traded in my place on AOL's crowded network (where I might as well have been michele43333759329602349-579873493@aol.com) for an E-mail address with more cachet. Around the end of 1995, I abandoned AOL altogether, complaining about the clunky nature of the service's proprietary browser, the paucity of sophisticated E-mail features and the relentless stream of advertisements that greet the masses upon logging on. **********Only in recent weeks, as America Online began with great fanfare to roll out the new 4.0 version of its software, have I looked inside my soul and wondered, Was I too quick to judge? After all, the service has  attracted more than 13 million customers, a number that keeps growing. The only fair thing to do would be to test the 4.0 version -- as objectively as possible, given my social-climbing tendencies -- to see if the AOL software could meet my needs. **********Truthfully, I did not think I would be interested in many of the new features that AOL was most proud of, like the new design that mimics a browser or even a channel guide that makes it easier to navigate through such topics as Sports, News or Lifestyles. Even the new feature that enables users to change screen names without logging off held no appeal for me: I don't use aliases, nor do I allow my daughters to use my account. **********The only on-line activities I engage in regularly are E-mail and Web browsing. No gaudy welcome screen greets me when my modem connects. Instead, I rely on a tiny, tasteful icon depicting two linked computers. Could AOL do better than my current minimalist setup? **********First, I had to download AOL 4.0 from www.aol.com. Although the final version for Windows was released at the end of July, production is still under way on the CD-ROM's. AOL expects to start mailing millions and millions of the disks within the next month, however, just in time for my cranky friend Ron Reason to continue his annual Halloween tradition of handing them out to unsuspecting trick-or-treaters in his South Florida neighborhood. (The Macintosh version will lag by a few weeks, an AOL spokeswoman said.) **********In the meantime, I was surprised that downloading the 4.0 version -- which warned that it might need as much as 17.5 megabytes on my hard drive -- seemed to take forever. Assuming that the process would end quickly, I sat at my desk, waiting. I flipped through the entire autumn Pottery Barn catalog. I phoned the toll-free number to get some information about velvet drapes. Still downloading. Called back to order the drapes. Still downloading. Worried drapes would be wrong color. Phoned to request complete set of drapery fabric swatches (free). Rebuffed in attempts to get Pottery Barn saleswoman to confirm whether this year's ''plum'' differs from last year's ''plum -- 1198134.'' Still downloading. Composed frosty letter in my mind to Pottery Barn. **********Luckily for the people at Pottery Barn's customer service department, the download was completed before I wrote the letter. I phoned Jeanie Ryan, a spokeswoman for America Online, to accuse her of forcing me to purchase unnecessary window treatments. **********''One hour? That's not bad -- you're on the good end,'' Ms. Ryan said. She explained that Microsoft's Internet Explorer was integrated with the new AOL software so users who have not already installed the browser could wait for up to three hours for the packgage to download. ''We thought people would run away screaming,'' Ms. Ryan confided. (Or at least just wait to go trick-or-treating!) ''Yet millions of people have sat through it, and we're like, oh my gosh.'' The good news was that installation and setup took me just three minutes more. **********Although determined to ignore the bright colors of the welcome screen, I had to admit that AOL 4.0's newly designed toolbar across the top of the screen was very helpful. Click on any of the three buttons on the left to use E-mail. Click on My AOL, then Preferences, then Marketing to speedily cancel all those ''valuable product and service offers'' that AOL and its partners serve up via E-mail, phone solicitation, the Postal Service and pop-up on-screen windows. And AOL 4.0 eliminates many of the tedious delays found in earlier versions. To start surfing the Net instantly, type a Web address in the space right under the icons. If you prefer another browser, it is easy to minimize the AOL window and open Netscape Navigator in its place. **********But the main thing that bothers me about AOL was that the E-mail features are still not robust enough. Unlike my Eudora E-mail program, AOL has no function that allows me to sort messages by date, sender, status, priority, label, size -- or even by various shades of plum. **********Nor does it allow me to attach a preconfigured signature file -- you know, the kind that gives my name, phone number and a quote from Descartes. ''We're working on that,'' Ms. Ryan said. **********I won't trade in my current setup for AOL yet. But, amazingly, I did manage to snag the simple and understated slatalla@aol.com as my new E-mail address. I'll be proud to give it out, even to my snootiest Internet friends.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/28/busin.snippet: More Americans over last three decades, despite proposal to push back Social Security retirement age, are taking early retirement; early retirees comment; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/28/busin.main_headline: When to Retire? Planners and Workers Are on Opposite Paths
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/28/busin.print_headline: When to Retire? Planners and Workers Are on Opposite Paths
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/28/busin.body_text: **********THEY are the boys of endless summers, measuring lives in golf putts and long winter vacations in Florida and saying daily prayers of gratitude that they had the wisdom, foresight and luck to take early retirement. **********And they are not reluctant to add a note of thanks to Social Security for helping to make it all possible. **********For those who scoff at early retirement as a fast track to redundancy, who say that life without work well into one's 60's is, well, pointless, the men in the clubhouse at Woodlake County Club here in the piney woods of the Jersey Shore patiently acknowledge that added years of leisure may not be for everyone. But they can't hide their delight at having left the rat race before they were too old to realize their dreams. **********Virtually every plan to put Social Security back on a sound financial footing calls for pushing back the retirement age from 65 and trimming the benefits of early retirees. But that proposition flies in the face of Americans' conduct over the last three decades. The percentage of those choosing to retire before they are eligible for full Social Security benefits has more than doubled, to 71.1 percent of those receiving benefits in 1996, from 31.7 percent in 1965. **********The Woodlake golfers represent the trend. So do many people interviewed recently in other towns in Ocean and Monmouth counties, which have some of the highest concentrations of retirees outside Florida and Arizona. **********To this sampling of people who have retired early -- or are about to do so -- the idea of of giving up the daily grind has enormous appeal. **********''I marvel at people driven by the need to make money and have few other interests in life,'' reflected Joe Albowicz, 59, a former mortgage banker who essentially retired four years ago when his company was acquired by another and he was let go. **********''Being without a job and an office gave me a chance to ask myself, 'Where am I going? How much money is enough?' '' he said after completing a round of golf with friends. **********Mr. Albowicz, who has no pension, said he had accumulated enough money to live the next quarter-century in comfort just by drawing on the principal, without benefit of interest or dividends. Though without a pressing need to draw an early Social Security retirement benefit at age 62, he nonetheless said he was entitled to it, a sentiment echoed by others who, for the most part, are more dependent on the added income. **********Job dissatisfaction or burnout was often cited as the motivation to leave work early for those who could afford to do so. For many, fattened retirement programs, bolstered by zooming individual stock investments, helped move up the target date for retirement. No doubt that explained why the television set in the clubhouse bar was tuned to CNBC, the financial news network, with stock prices streaming across the bottom of the screen. **********''We may be the last generation able to enjoy this quality of life in our early 60's,'' said Marty Stern, 63, a retired manufacturer's representative. ''If in the future you can't retire until you are in your 70's, you are going to be a lot older and a lot less active. Who wants to sit at a desk all your working life and then sit around when you retire?'' **********''If you're still alive and breathing at that age,'' said another golfer, Ralph Arbia, half-jokingly. At age 59, Mr. Arbia has the sturdy build of a much younger man. **********Death, particularly early death, was a specter haunting some men who opted for early retirement. ''My father was 62 when he retired, and he dropped dead a while later,'' explained Joe Mento, who played a round of golf with some friends earlier this month to celebrate his 63d birthday, days after returning from a gambling vacation in Las Vegas, Nev. ''Let's face it: Men die early, so why hang around in a job if you can afford to have some fun before you check out?'' **********Mr. Mento sold his Brooklyn company, which rebuilt auto air-conditioners, and moved to the Jersey Shore to be near his grandchildren. **********''I wanted out; it was just a way of making money, and I hated it,'' he said with emphasis. **********For Luis Alvarez, 56, a construction worker on a road project in Monmouth County, the issue is enduring the rigors of outdoor work until he turns 62 and can collect early Social Security benefits. He said painful arthritis in his hands nearly cripples him on cold winter days, and speculated that those who wanted to push back the Social Security retirement age never carried a lunch pail to a job site on a raw day in January. **********As gingerly as Washington deals with Social Security, it seems more loath to address the spiraling costs of Medicare. And for many older workers, medical benefits are as much an issue in retirement planning as is a pension. **********Margaret Lewis, 57, of Manalapan, N.J., is a supervisor in the state employment services office in Freehold, and plans to retire at the end of this year, citing job burnout. Her husband, Michael, 58, is a self-employed paperhanger with no pension or medical benefits of his own. But Ms. Lewis has 34 consecutive years of service with the state and can claim a $30,000 annual pension with full medical coverage for both her and her husband. **********When she turns 62, she expects to start receiving $980 a month in Social Security payments, which she says gleefully ''will be like winning the lottery.'' **********Her words resonate with Bob Matthews, 64, who retired eight years ago from teaching at a middle school in East Orange. ''I was burned out dealing with all the problems of an inner-city school, trying to figure out a way to retire at age 55 and keep myself going on a pension until I was eligible for reduced Social Security benefits when I turned 62,'' said Mr. Matthews, of Toms River. ''Then I hit the state lottery jackpot of $1.5 million, which gave me a nice annuity for 20 years,'' he beamed. **********The grin fading, he said that for future generations, hitting the lottery may be among the few ways of achieving the dream of early retirement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/busin.snippet: Germans are expected to mourn 50th anniversary of German mark on June 20, 1948 in light of Europe's decision to go with single currency, the euro, on Jan 1, 1999; anyone seeking to understand why Germans will mourn need look only at tumultuous day...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/busin.main_headline: Germans to Mourn Mark, The Symbol of Revival
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Germans to Mourn Mark, The Symbol of Revival
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/05/busin.body_text: **********Half a century ago, from the ration lines and ruins of defeated Germany, a new German mark was born. Like many a child of postwar occupation, the mother was German, the father a foreigner. The date was June 20, 1948. **********But with the coming of a European single currency, its details agreed to at a heads of government meeting in Brussels this weekend, that 50th anniversary is likely to be much more of a wake. Among the 11 European nations ceding fiscal sovereignty as they shed marks, francs and pesetas for the euro, Germans will mourn the most. **********Anyone seeking to understand why need look only at the tumultuous days when the mark was born -- not simply the new coinage of a fallen realm, but the infant emblem of Germany's regeneration as postwar Europe's economic colossus. **********As the Brussels meeting got under way, the latest opinion survey here said 56 percent of Germans remained opposed to the new currency because its introduction, quite simply, meant the end of the mark that many people still associated with that first Volkswagen Beetle and that first postwar vacation in the sun -- the budding fruits of Germany's economic miracle. **********''The Deutsche mark is the incarnation of 40 or 50 years of prosperity,'' said Prof. Klaus von Beyme, a political scientist at Heidelberg University. And as they contemplate a future without it, many Germans are reminded of a past in which inflation wiped out savings and left their parents and grandparents bereft. ''Every monetary reform has been associated with a loss of money,'' Professor von Beyme said. ''And people are afraid.'' **********As of Jan. 1, 1999, the euro will be used in some electronic trading. By 2002, euro notes and coins will have banished not just the mark, but francs and many other currencies, in the one of the boldest financial adventures undertaken by a group of disparate lands. **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl came under fire over the weekend for making a last-minute political deal with France to introduce the euro. Under the arrangement, Wim Duisenberg, a Dutchman favored by Germany, will step down voluntarily as head of the forthcoming European central bank after only four years on the job, to be replaced by a Frenchman. **********Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party lambasted Mr. Kohl's maneuvering to placate France, asserting that the Chancellor had ''lost trust over his foreign policy.'' Even allies of Mr. Kohl, including the Bavarian state premier, Edmund Stoiber, said the compromise had ''thrown shadows over the start of the currency union.'' **********The prickliness of Germans was perhaps not surprising, because in this country, the loss of the mark carries a lot more emotional freight than Europeans normally associate with pocketbook issues. Currencies, of course, are national totems -- just as the dollar is part of being American or the pound sterling, part of being British. **********But the mark was always more than that -- an emblem of a new respectability after the horrors of Nazism, of success and prosperity and, above all, of stability. **********As a measure of its meaning, consider, for instance, that the postwar mark -- the Deutsche mark in West Germany as distinct from the reichsmark of the Weimar and Nazi eras -- was born 11 months before the Bonn Government was created. It entered history on the front line of the cold war, at a time when many Germans were beginning to sense that postwar deprivation was coming to an end. **********''After the war, there was nothing to eat, nothing to wear,'' said Erika Ritter, now a pensioner, who was 18 when the new money was introduced. ''Everything was rationed and families would send their children into the food lines in relays, the queues were so long. We were given the new money with our ration cards, and the shops suddenly filled up with glasses, food, everything.'' **********Indeed, a commentator, Michael Schmidt-Klingenberg, writing in the news magazine Der Spiegel, said, ''The founding myth of the new state was not the Constitution, but the miracle of the store windows.'' **********From its birth, with Americans and the other Western Allies as midwives, the mark molded postwar Germany as a land whose fortunes were intertwined with those of the West and of capitalism. **********For 49 days from April 1948 onward, sequestered in an attic conference room near Kassel in central Germany, in a villa encircled by American barbed wire, a group of German financial experts, nudged forward by the Occupation powers -- the United States, Britain and France -- met quietly. As they met, rumors swirled about of an impending currency reform in a land that had no real currency. **********And when on June 20, 1948, Germans in the west were permitted to exchange 40 old, virtually worthless reichsmarks for 40 of the crisp new notes (printed in Philadelphia), the Soviet occupiers of eastern Germany followed suit, issuing their own Ostmarks. **********The dispute over which currency would be used in divided Berlin led to the Soviet blockade of the city, and to the beginning of the Berlin airlift. If ever there was an emblem of Germany's division, and a defining symbol for the split-up of Europe for decades to come, this was it. **********Compared with some other European currencies, the mark has kept its strength: These days, one mark has 27 percent of the buying power it had in 1948. By contrast, the Italian lira has 4 percent of its 1948 value. **********The fear of losing all that, perhaps, is why Chancellor Kohl has had some difficulty in persuading his compatriots that, as he frequently insists, the euro will be ''as stable as the mark.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/24/busin.snippet: Autobytel.com Inc, which operates popular on-line car-buying service, will announce hiring of Grey Advertising as it ad agency; Autobytel.com will increase total spending next year from $20 million that was budgeted for 1998 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/24/busin.main_headline: From the department of old dogs and new, on-line tricks that need the old dogs' expertise.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/24/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; From the department of old dogs and new, on-line tricks that need the old dogs' expertise.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/24/busin.body_text: **********IN another demonstration of the blurring of the lines between on-line and off-line advertising and media realms, a leading Internet marketer is naming the world's ninth-largest agency to handle duties ranging from global brand-building to creating campaigns for television, magazines and newspapers. **********Autobytel.com Inc., which operates a popular on-line car-buying service, will announce today the hiring of Grey Advertising in New York as its agency for those traditional tasks, which will supplement the marketing efforts the company makes in cyberspace through the Grey interactive division. Autobytel.com, which is based in Irvine, Calif., plans to increase total spending considerably next year from the $20 million that was budgeted for 1998. **********Grey, with billings of more than $7.6 billion, works for such giant blue-chip marketers as Conagra Inc., the Procter & Gamble Company and SmithKline Beecham. The decision by Autobytel.com to join their ranks is indicative of the growing presence of Internet advertisers in conventional media as they seek to appeal to cyberspace newbies -- or even to those consumers who think ''on line'' refers to a telephone call or a fish. **********''The large traditional marketers built their brands with large traditional agencies,'' said Anne Benvenuto, senior vice president for marketing at Autobytel.com. ''To help us become a household name like P.& G., we wanted an agency known for building brands globally with expertise beyond the Internet.'' **********''We knew it was time to build more of an emotional bond with consumers,'' she added, ''and you do that through traditional media.'' **********Ms. Benvenuto discussed the decision to hire Grey in an interview yesterday in midtown Manhattan. She was joined by executives of Grey and RBI Communications Inc., an advertising and public relations agency in Hollywood that created Autobytel.com spots for the 1997 and 1998 Super Bowls. RBI will continue handling corporate communications for Autobytel.com. **********The increased attention and business generated by those Super Bowl spots underscored for Autobytel.com ''the power of traditional media like television,'' Ms. Benvenuto said, and ''the need to take the traditional side more seriously.'' **********''A balance between driving the sale and driving the brand is what we're looking for,'' she added. **********Among the interactive marketers that have also recently hired traditional agencies to produce advertising off line are Snap, a search engine controlled by the NBC unit of the General Electric Company, which selected the San Francisco office of Saatchi & Saatchi, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., and ZDTV, a cable network operated by the Ziff-Davis unit of the Softbank Corporation, which chose the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding, owned by True North Communications. **********As cybermarketers look beyond agencies specializing in on-line advertising, mainstream shops are beefing up their interactive abilities. **********Wickersham Hunt Schwantner in Boston, for instance, which is owned by Snyder Communications, has agreed to acquire Berenson Isham & Partners, a Boston agency with billings estimated at $40 million that manages interactive assignments for such advertisers as Club Med, The Financial Times and Fidelity Investments. That deal was for cash and stock valued at $3 million. **********The hiring of Grey Advertising by Autobytel.com comes seven months after the company named the agency's on-line unit, Grey Interactive, to handle a variety of marketing communications assignments that included brand advertising and campaigns to run in traditional media. **********But ''we needed to take things to the next level,'' Ms. Benvenuto said, ''because I don't think you can build a brand with the Internet alone.'' **********''If we want to seed the likely prospects who will be on line next year, we have to start developing preferences for our brand off line,'' she said. **********Michael Rasmussen, the vice president at Grey Advertising who is group management supervisor on the Autobytel.com account, said the agency would ''operate as an integrated resource with all our disciplines working together,'' particularly as Autobytel.com expands internationally. Web sites are in the works for the first quarter of 1999 for Britain and the Nordic countries, to join the site operating for the United States and Canada (www.autobytel.com). **********The media services for the creative work produced by Grey Advertising and Grey Interactive, Mr. Rasmussen said, will be handled by Grey's Mediacom Worldwide (off line) and Media.com (on line). A mainstream campaign from Grey Advertising is due early next year. **********If executives at Autobytel.com are, as Ms. Benvenuto put it, ''maverick marketers,'' the choice of Grey Advertising is at odds with the old perceptions that the agency's creative output was as colorless as its name. **********''Creative is very important,'' Ms. Benvenuto said, ''and Grey has strong creative. But there's also a lot to be said for strategy and strong account management.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/22/busin.snippet: Xerox executive Barry Rand, who has announced his resignation, says he plans to vacation with family and is unsure whether his being black will hinder or help his search for new job (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/22/busin.main_headline: Off the Slopes of Xerox, And Seeking New Mountains
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/22/busin.print_headline: PRIVATE SECTOR; Off the Slopes of Xerox, And Seeking New Mountains
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/22/busin.body_text: **********For someone facing the great unknown, A. Barry Rand sounds awfully upbeat. He and Donna, his wife of eight years, have rarely taken vacations, almost never with their two children, and he intends to rectify that. ''We'll go golfing, we'll go skiing, we'll travel to new places,'' he said. Mr. Rand, 54, announced this month that he was leaving the Xerox Corporation, where he was a front-runner to succeed Paul A. Allaire as chief executive until the company hired G. Richard Thoman from I.B.M. last year and made him the heir apparent. So Mr. Rand, Xerox's highest-ranking black executive, quit to look for a job as chief at another Fortune 500 company. He has no idea whether his race will help or hinder his search. ''It's like an election,'' he said. ''Until the votes are in, you don't know whether your traits are perceived as advantages or disadvantages.'' **********No one's knocked down his door yet. Gerard R. Roche, chairman of Heidrick & Struggles, an executive search firm, said Mr. Rand had the right stuff but ''the question is what's available.'' Mr. Rand says he has no hard feelings and even plans to ski with Mr. Allaire in Aspen this winter. **********CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/03/world.snippet: French train conductors have been on strike since Nov 26, disrupting long-distance rail service in many regions; journalists have gone on strike against Government plan to do away with special tax deduction of up to 50,000 francs, or $8,850, that ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/03/world.main_headline: Unions Turn Chilly, Too, By Striking In France
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/03/world.print_headline: Unions Turn Chilly, Too, By Striking In France
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/03/world.body_text: **********French train conductors say they're lonely and overworked, so they have been on strike since last Thursday, disrupting long-distance rail service in many regions. **********French journalists say their paychecks don't buy as much as they used to, so they went on strike this week, too -- not against their newspapers and television and radio stations, but against a Government plan to do away with a special tax deduction of up to 50,000 francs, or $8,850, that they have enjoyed since 1934. **********The long-term unemployed, who closed state job offices last Christmas and demanded higher benefits, occupied an unemployment office on Monday in Marseilles, where the movement began, demanding a Christmas bonus of 3000 francs, or $530, like the one they received last year. **********The French have been taking to the streets since the Revolution, usually to demand something from the state. Not surprisingly, because Government spending amounts to 56 percent of the gross domestic product, compared with 41 percent in the United States. **********The end of the year, when the days become short, cold and gray, usually brings a spate of labor disputes and visions of paralyzing national shutdowns like the three-week transportation strike in 1995 that sealed the fate of a conservative Government that had tried to reduce pension benefits. **********The latest strike on the state railroad is not anywhere near that big. But its 11,000 conductors have kept up steady pressure to try to force the network to hire additional conductors. A union conductor in Bordeaux, Sauveur Ventura, told Agence France-Presse on Monday that it was sometimes a lonely job with many responsibilities but nobody to talk to except passengers. ''We're also attacked by customers who complain about fares' being raised,'' Mr. Ventura said. **********Then Agence France-Presse shut down for most of Tuesday because of the journalists' strike. **********The 182,000 railway workers run some of the fastest, cleanest and sleekest trains in the world. These days they work, indirectly, for a Communist, Transport Minister Jean-Claude Gayssot, under a Socialist Government that promises to reduce the workweek for all of them to 35 hours starting next year, as some have had for years. But the conductors are also striking to make sure the workweek reductions are negotiated seriously. **********The former aerospace executive in charge of the railroad, Louis Gallois, said last week that railroad employees accounted for 20 to 30 percent of all workdays lost to strikes in France. **********''It's the way the enterprise resolves its internal conflicts,'' Mr. Gallois said. ''Everybody lives off strikes: the hierarchy, the administration, the staff and the labor unions.'' **********Even though fewer than 10 percent of workers in France belong to unions, polls show that the public generally sympathizes with them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/busin.snippet: Steven Brill, founder of new media watchdog magazine called Brill's Content (formerly Content), says proposal to co-produce segments on errant journalism with Dateline NBC has been killed after several staff members questioned how magazine could r...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/busin.main_headline: Founder of Media Watchdog Magazine Kills NBC Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Founder of Media Watchdog Magazine Kills NBC Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/busin.body_text: **********A proposal by a media watchdog magazine to co-produce segments on errant journalism with ''Dateline NBC'' is dead, the founder of the new magazine said yesterday. **********Steven Brill, the founder of Brill's Content, a monthly that will make its debut in June, said he killed the arrangement after he read articles yesterday that raised the issue of a potential conflict of interest. **********''The reporters asking the questions were really right and I was wrong,'' said Mr. Brill, who started Court TV and The American Lawyer. ''This is one of these instances where perception is as important as the reality.'' **********With the magazine -- originally named Content but changed this week after a legal challenge by a California magazine of the same name -- Mr. Brill has promised a hard-hitting product that will expose the shortcomings of the news media. He also wants to reach at least a half million people, which would go well beyond the audience of a journalism review. The deal with the prime-time news magazine offered the opportunity for valuable exposure. **********Mr. Brill said that some of his staff members questioned how the magazine could remain impartial if it was co-producing episodes with a news show that was a potential subject of its criticism. A staff member at ''Dateline NBC'' who spoke on condition of anonymity said some employees of the news program were surprised that Mr. Brill would be interested in such a venture. **********Mr. Brill said the deal would have allowed Brill's Content or ''Dateline NBC'' to veto an article if either side  did not agree with its content. He also said that if his magazine proposed an article critical of NBC News and ''Dateline'' blocked it, he would have been free to make public NBC's resistance and offer the piece to other news programs. **********''We had a veto over everything produced,'' he said. ''These were people I have worked with at Court TV and I liked them and trusted them.'' **********Mr. Brill said that he had been in informal discussions with ''Dateline NBC'' since last fall and that part of the arrangement would have been a payment from NBC to Mr. Brill's magazine for having the first option to televise its articles. Mr. Brill would not say how large the payment would have been, but said it represented no more than 1 percent of the magazine's budget. **********Kassie Canter, a spokeswoman for NBC News, said ''Dateline'' was still interested in the arrangement. ''We think there is merit to this idea,'' she said. ''We're happy to revisit it when Steve Brill feels the timing is appropriate.'' **********After news of the arrangement was first reported by USA Today on Wednesday, Mr. Brill sent a memo to employees explaining it. He said two or three of the magazine's roughly 40 employees questioned the arrangement. A staff member at Brill's Content who spoke on condition of anonymity said that the arrangement had not caused a large uproar at the magazine, but that its cancellation was probably a good idea. **********''We have to prove ourselves first,'' the staff member said. ''There is a perception problem. If we have a year under our belts and show that we don't play favorites, there may be a way to do it.'' **********Howard Kurtz, the media reporter for The Washington Post who plans to contribute to Brill's Content, said  Mr. Brill could have pulled off the ''Dateline'' arrangement without compromising standards. **********''I don't have any doubt that Steve Brill could have hooked up with NBC and still kicked the network in the shins,'' Mr. Kurtz said. ''But I understand the appearance problem for a magazine devoted to being tough on the press.'' **********Although several magazines that critiqued the media have failed in the past, Mr. Brill said he was confident his would not. And another foray into cable television, he said, was not completely out of the picture. **********''If I do anything,'' he said, ''it might be down the road by starting another cable channel around this subject.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/02/news/.main_headline: Government to Ask for Donations of Gold Jewelry : Self-Help Glitters in Thailand
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/02/news/.print_headline: Government to Ask for Donations of Gold Jewelry : Self-Help Glitters in Thailand
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/02/news/.body_text: **********BANGKOK—                     Faced with the cold reality that foreign investors will not return anytime soon, the Thai government will ask Thais next week to hand in their gold jewelry to help bail out their nation, according to the country's finance minister. **********The official, Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda, said that he had devised the plan to allow the country to help itself out of economic crisis. **********Mr. Tarrin said in an interview that he would announce the move next week, and that the armed forces would fan out across the country within two to three weeks to collect gold jewelry in exchange for interest-paying government bonds or treasury bills. **********He said the action would be the first part of an official policy of "Chuay Thai" — or "Thais help Thais." **********Since Thailand can no longer count on an export-led recovery, Mr. Tarrin said, the country must emphasize self-reliance. The gold contributions, he said, would be used to bolster the country's dwindling foreign currency reserves. **********Thais, like many Asians, have traditionally held a large portion of their savings in gold in case of hard times. Purchases of gold have jumped in Thailand during the current economic crisis, officials say. Mr. Tarrin did not estimate how much gold Thais now hold or say how much the government hoped to collect. **********In South Korea, a state-run television station has started a program under which people are donating gold to help their country repay a $60 billion rescue package led by the International Monetary Fund. The station reported last week that South Koreans were believed to hold about 2,000 tons of gold, worth $20 billion **********"We have lost our ability to trade our way out because of competitive devaluation in the region," Mr. Tarrin said, "and the possibility of a quick inflow of investment is gone because of the loss of confidence in the whole continent. So I want to send out a very strong message: We will help ourselves first." **********There have been several individual initiatives to bolster the Thai economy, including the campaign of a monk who is raising funds to help pay back the country's $17.2 billion IMF-led bailout and a senator who urged people to curse speculators who benefited from the fall of the currency. **********"I hope the international marketplace would believe in us and in what we are trying to do," he said, outlining the government's strategy for economic reform. **********The first area of focus will be strengthening the financial system by installing better management and increasing the capital of commercial banks. **********"We are talking comprehensively. It is much more than just Bangkok Metropolitan Bank," Mr. Tarrin said, referring to a bank that purged its board of directors on New Year's Eve. (Page 15). He added that Thai banks would require at least 70 billion baht ($1.49 billion) in increased capital in the first quarter. **********To help weaker banks raise capital, Mr. Tarrin said, the government was willing to write down debts owed to the central bank in exchange for a share of ownership, an effective bailout of the finance sector. **********"If write-downs are appropriate, we shall write down," he said. **********Even the country's largest banks will take part in the capital increase, Mr. Tarrin said, adding that he expected an announcement of capital-increase plans from Thai Farmer's Bank and Bangkok Bank early next week. **********"They are heeding the call to take a leadership role in the financial system," Mr. Tarrin said. **********The second point of focus will be stabilizing Thailand's external financial issues, Mr. Tarrin said, including negotiations for the continuation of $92.9 billion in debt to foreign banks. **********Initiatives will include pressing Japanese banks to convert their dollar-denominated loans to yen. Japan, Thailand's largest lender, has been facing a credit crunch in its own financial system. **********The conversion of dollar loans to yen would take pressure off both Japanese banks and their Thai debtors, the finance minister said. **********"Each and every one of the major banks we have spoken to feel this flexibility will enhance their ability to support Thailand," Mr. Tarrin said. **********Terms for Thailand's first yen-denominated loan from Japan, worth $500 million to $600 million, will be negotiated when a team from the Japanese Export-Import Bank comes to Bangkok this month, he said. **********"Over the long term this may start a trend for yen loans around the region," Mr. Tarrin said. **********"Japan initially exhibited reluctance about the internationalization of the yen," he said. "Not any more." **********The third area of concentration will be on fiscal prudence, Mr. Tarrin said, emphasizing that Thailand would strictly adhere to the agreement with the International Monetary Fund. **********Analysts have expressed strong doubts that Thailand will be able to comply with requirements for the rescue set forth before the Thai baht went into a free fall. **********"As a matter of principle the IMF program is not a rigid one," Mr. Tarrin said. "There are reviews every three months, so to that extent we are both being flexible." **********The strengthening of Thailand's exports on a "massive scale" through a soon-to-be announced comprehensive government initiative will be the fourth area of focus, Mr. Tarrin said. **********"The program will include encouraging technological input, developing human resources, improving marketing and trade negotiations," he said. **********Unemployment and other social issues will be the fifth sector of focus, with Thailand looking for international assistance since it is constrained in spending, Mr. Tarrin said.

Esterline said that it had already acquired about two-thirds of Kirkhill's stock outstanding, representing shares held by the Kirkhill Employee Stock Ownership and Savings Plan. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/23/busin.main_headline: CYBERSCAPE : Microsoft and Oracle Battle for Database Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/23/busin.print_headline: CYBERSCAPE : Microsoft and Oracle Battle for Database Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/23/busin.body_text: **********They seem like unlikely lances in the jousts between Microsoft Corp. and Oracle Corp. over the future of computing, but databases were the weapon chosen last week for the latest round in the running battle between the rival software makers. **********Behind some jargon-laden product announcements at the Comdex autumn trade show was the larger dispute between the software companies: whether most computing should take place on big centralized servers or on smaller machines located near their users. **********Microsoft supports the idea of many small servers, which gives users control over what is on their computers but requires them to maintain their systems. **********Oracle, which is trying to break what it perceives as Microsoft's monopoly over computing, wants fewer, larger servers, placing control in the hands of the people who manage the big machines and simplifying the work of the end users, who would be freed from such chores as upgrades. **********Lawrence Ellison, Oracle's chairman, began speaking about network computing in 1995. In his original concept, there would be computers without disk drives that would largely be used to access networks — including the Internet. Such machines would cost about $600, less than half the price of standard desktop units at the time. **********But as prices for full-fledged computers have fallen below $1,000, the attraction of network computers has diminished, though even smaller handheld devices are being used to access the Internet, and electronic commerce is growing at a phenomenal rate. **********So Mr. Ellison was correct in his view that interest in network computing would grow. When people use Internet services through personal computers or other devices, they are essentially allowing the processing to be done by network servers, where Oracle's products are likely to be found. The company says that the 10 most popular consumer Web sites and nine of the top 10 business-to-business sites are built atop its databases. **********Databases are programs that contain information that can be searched according to various criteria. **********Companies use databases for a variety of reasons, but one key area besides the Internet is as a base for enterprise software: huge integrated programs that run many facets of large businesses, from ordering supplies to scheduling workers. About a quarter of databases sold are used to support these enterprise resource planning programs, which are principally supplied by SAP AG, PeopleSoft Inc. and Baan Co. **********Microsoft is trying to increase its share of the market for database products that run on its Windows operating systems. Databases from Oracle and other competitors can run on Windows, Unix or other operating systems. **********At Comdex, Microsoft carried the battle to Oracle's home turf by choosing the show as a venue to introduce the newest version of its database program, SQL (called sequel) Server 7.0. **********Oracle, which had just announced an upgrade to its database, called Oracle 8i, was not about to let its rival make an unchallenged splash in its home market. **********"We were delighted but surprised by their naïveté at the show," said Mark Jarvis, Oracle's senior vice president for marketing. "Did they really think we were going to let them come here and make a database announcement?" **********While Microsoft is the larger company, Oracle is a far bigger player in the database market. It accounted for 39.3 percent of the $6.6 billion relational-database market last year, according to figures from Gartner Group/Dataquest. International Business Machines Corp. followed with 26.8 percent, while Microsoft had 7.4 percent. **********After Microsoft scheduled its announcements, Oracle responded by returning to Comdex following an absence of several years, and Mr. Ellison arranged to give a speech last Monday night, a day after Bill Gates, the Microsoft chairman, opened the show with a presentation and just hours after Microsoft announced SQL Server 7.0. Mr. Ellison spoke about Raw Iron, Oracle's latest attack on Microsoft's Windows juggernaut. **********For Oracle 8i, Mr. Ellison contended, the operating system is largely superfluous. Except for communicating with the computer's memory and network, he said, the Oracle database handles most of its operations autonomously, and the existence of a full-fledge operating system slows it down. So Big Iron is supposed to be a refrigerator-sized computer with just the few elements of an operating system necessary to support Oracle's database. **********Of course, a Big Iron computer could not run anything outside the Oracle database, but Mr. Ellison said that half the users of Oracle databases run them on dedicated servers anyway. Oracle 8i can support applications itself, including Web browsers and word processors. Indeed, so many programs could run inside Oracle 8i that you could look at it as an operating system, though Mr. Ellison was careful to say that Oracle was not getting into the operating-system business. **********Oracle is negotiating with several manufacturers to make Big Iron. The cost of the systems would be comparable to current servers with Oracle 8i. **********Mr. Ellison also used the occasion to trumpet what he saw as Oracle 8i's advantages over SQL Server. He offered $1 million to anybody who could make a specific research query on SQL run more than 1/100th the speed of the same process on Oracle 8i, which he said had run faster than its Microsoft competitor in every benchmark test ever done, an assertion that depends on your definition of what was being tested. **********He was particularly proud of a function that allowed Microsoft documents to be easily transferred into an Oracle database, where they could then be searched by different criteria. **********It is difficult to define which program is better. "Both databases are good, depending on what you want to use them for," said Carolyn DiCenzo, principal analyst at Gartner Group/Dataquest. **********Oracle executives seemed surprised that Microsoft had not made concessions to network computing; Microsoft seemed surprised they were surprised. "They missed the significance of the Internet," Mr. Jarvis said of Microsoft. "All of their actions are distancing themselves away from the trends in the industry." **********Mr. Demas of Microsoft saw the opposite. "Our belief is that PC servers running on Windows NT will be the way companies decide to go." **********Although Oracle executives gleefully predict that the Internet and the model of networking it inspires will make computer users around the world eager to abandon the tasks of server administration, the reality may be more complex. **********Patrick McGovern, chairman of the researcher and financial publisher International Data Group., said that many corporate departments would want to have control over their servers and their data. He predicted that about 65 percent of users would opt to retain the client/server architecture, while the rest would opt for the megaserver concept. **********"The megaserver fights against the idea of autonomy," he said. **********Mr. Jarvis agreed with that. "The only people who want control of the data are the users," he said. **********Not a populist, however, Mr. Jarvis said that chief executives and their top technology officers would want to control the information themselves, and that it made sense to centralize the power in a corporation with its leaders. **********- **********E-mail address: CyberScape@iht.com **********Recent technology articles: **********www.iht.com/IHT/TECH/

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/05/busin.snippet: Karel van Miert, top European regulator reviewing Worldcom Inc's proposed $37 billion acquisition of MCI Communications Corp, says MCI's proposed sale of its wholesale Internet unit to Cable and Wireless PLC might not allay his antitrust concerns;...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/05/busin.main_headline: Europe Official Cites Concern On Worldcom-MCI Merger
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/05/busin.print_headline: Europe Official Cites Concern On Worldcom-MCI Merger
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/05/busin.body_text: **********The top European regulator reviewing Worldcom Inc.'s proposed $37 billion acquisition of the MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that MCI's proposed sale of part of its Internet business might not allay his antitrust concerns. **********MCI announced last week that it had agreed to sell its wholesale Internet unit to Cable and Wireless P.L.C. for $625 million in cash. European regulators and the Justice Department had made clear to MCI and Worldcom a concern that the combined company could unfairly dominate the Internet and that the regulators would require the companies to sell off some cyberspace assets. **********Foes of the deal, led by the GTE Corporation, which lost in its attempt to acquire MCI, have been pushing Worldcom to sell its Uunet unit, the leading Internet service company. **********But Worldcom has refused. Instead, MCI agreed to sell part of its Internet unit to Cable and Wireless. MCI told Justice Department officials about the Cable and Wireless deal more than a week before it was publicly announced, in the hope of winning the department's blessing. **********But the department refused to assure MCI that the Cable and Wireless deal would be sufficient to remove its concerns. **********Yesterday, Karel van Miert, the European Union's competition commissioner, also refused to give such an assurance. **********''I'm not sure that what has been offered will be good enough,'' Mr. van Miert told a news conference in Washington. **********Mr. van Miert said he had notified each affected company of his concerns and said the companies would each have a chance to make additional suggestions. **********GTE welcomed Mr. van Miert's comments, saying they'' clearly indicate that MCI's recent attempt to create the appearance of a divestiture through partial sale of some minor Internet assets are not going to fool the E.C.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/16/news/.main_headline: Note to Readers: IHT Begins Printing A Joint-Venture Supplement in Italy
