https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/16/news/.body_text: **********Beginning today, a four-page supplement of Italian news in English will be included with all copies the International Herald Tribune distributes in Italy. **********The daily supplement, called Italy Daily, is a joint venture of the IHT and the Italian publishing group Rizzoli-Corriere della Sera Editori. It will be printed with the IHT in Bologna for early distribution and will contain political and economic news of Italy, plus commentary, TV and cultural listings and lifestyle features. **********The supplement is the third such local-section joint venture by the IHT, which launched similar supplements in Israel with Ha'aretz in September 1997 and with Kathimerini in Greece in March. **********Italy Daily's editor is Claudio Gatti. The managing editor is Gabriel Kahn.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/29/busin.snippet: Three humorous commercials for Nike Inc by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco win Grand Prix at International Advertising Festival, Cannes, France (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/29/busin.main_headline: Three Ads for Nike Win the Grand Prix
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/29/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Three Ads for Nike Win the Grand Prix
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/29/busin.body_text: **********Three humorous commercials for Nike Inc. by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco took top honors in the competition for television and cinema work, winning the Grand Prix, at the 45th annual International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France. **********The spots, aimed at young skateboarders, present vignettes in which athletes pursuing mainstream sports like golf, tennis and running are harassed and heckled -- treated, in other words, as skateboarders often complain they are. **********Goodby, Silverstein, part of Omnicom Group, is one of two lead agencies for Nike along with Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore. The timing of the honor was interesting because it came after Advertising Age and Adweek published articles about the tug-of-war between the two agencies for Nike's favor. **********Of the 23 gold awards, called Lions, presented in Cannes on Saturday, American agencies won 12. Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis won three for three commercials for Miller Lite beer, sold by the Miller Brewing Company unit of the Philip Morris Companies. The Venice, Calif., office of TBWA Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of Omnicom, won two: one for a commercial for the Weather Channel, owned by Landmark Communications, and the other for a commercial for the Play Station National Hockey League game sold by Sony Computer Entertainment. **********Renzo Rosso, chairman of Diesel S.p.A., the Italian clothing company whose tongue-in-cheek campaign won the Grand Prix in 1997 for television and cinema spots, accepted the award for advertiser of the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/14/world.snippet: Japan freezes new new grants to India as punishment for nuclear tests; weighs cutting some of its much bigger loan programs; Germany suspends some of its aid; other major trading partners rule out sanctions; France scores United States sanctions (...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/14/world.main_headline: Japan Freezes Some Grants; Other Nations Seem Doubtful
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/14/world.print_headline: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE ALLIES; Japan Freezes Some Grants; Other Nations Seem Doubtful
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/14/world.body_text: **********The Japanese Government today froze new grants to India as punishment for the nuclear tests, and said it would consider cutting some of its much bigger loan programs. Germany also suspended some of its aid, but other major trading partners ruled out sanctions. **********Japan said that it was canceling $30 million in grants. Since 1992, Japan has extended $1 billion in aid annually, mostly in the form of loans. **********While the sanctions were not tough, they underscored the anger here at the Indian tests, for Japan has seen its role -- as the only country to suffer nuclear attack -- as a leader in efforts to halt the spread of nuclear weapons. **********Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto called it ''grave'' that India had gone ahead with a second round of tests today, at a time when many countries have condemned the three nuclear tests conducted on Monday. He said he would call upon the Group of Seven leading industrial nations meeting in England this weekend to condemn India for the tests. **********The Japanese Government said it would consider halting part of its lending program, but that is a delicate issue because Japanese businesses are often involved in these lending projects, and freezing loans could have serious effects on the Indian economy. **********Among other nations that give aid to India, Germany called off talks scheduled for next week in Bonn, said the German Minister for Economic Cooperation, Carl-Dieter Spranger. A portion of new development aid for India worth $168 million was put on hold, and no talks will take place anytime soon. **********France criticized American sanctions against India. A Government spokesman, Daniel Vaillant, said, ''the French Government does not encourage the Americans to pursue sanctions,'' asserting that ''this is not the way'' to discourage India. **********When asked if Britain would suspend aid, which averages about $200 million a year, Derek Fatchett, Minister of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs, said no. ''It would be wrong to do that,'' he told the BBC, because it would be ''punishing the poorest and the ordinary people of India for a decision taken by their Government.'' **********The European Union also stopped short of threatening penalties. **********India has access to easy loans and other assistance from the European Union of about $100 million a year, according to the European Commission, but individual members, such as Britain, have additional forms of aid negotiated separately. **********Sweden cut short a three-year aid agreement with India worth $118 million that began in 1997, but said it would renegotiate a new agreement after six months. Denmark froze its $28 million in aid to India. **********Japan currently provides more than $1 billion in assistance to India. In 1996, Japan imposed sanctions on China for testing nuclear weapons, but such measures were focused only on freezing grants. **********A spokesman for the presidency of the European Union, currently held by Britain, said today in a telephone interview that unlike the United States the union has no provisions for automatic sanctions in case of nuclear testing. The spokesman said it was ''improbable'' that the European Union would take such measures, even after Foreign Ministers discuss the matter at a meeting on May 25.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/26/busin.snippet: America's Research Group predicts that 40 percent of consumers will spend more this year on holiday shopping; John Konarski, director of research for International Council of Shopping Centers, says there is nothing to suggest the holiday is going ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/26/busin.body_text: **********Conspicuous consumption may be off a little this year, much like many a Wall Street bonus, but a bit of luxury and indulgence is definitely still in style. And for those on smaller budgets, the appearance of luxury -- in, say, fake fur trims and gold-  and silver-colored candles, handbags and champagne flutes -- works just as well. **********America's Research Group predicts that 40 percent of consumers will spend more this year. With forecasts like that and consumer confidence on an upswing, ''there's nothing to suggest the holiday is going to be a bust,'' said John Konarski, director of research for the International Council of Shopping Centers, which tracks shopping trends. Whatever the budget, when it comes to holiday shopping, emotion takes over. **********In the luxury corner, white gold, platinum and silver are popular, turning up in everything from cross pendants to Edwardian and Victorian designs inspired by the movie ''Titanic.'' Watches, long a gift staple, feature dials with colors like gunmetal gray, salmon or mother-of-pearl, and bracelet versions. **********Exotic travel locales, though, might bring to mind Indiana Jones more than James Bond. **********''People are looking for experiences,'' said Arnold Brown, chairman of Weiner, Edrich, Brown Inc., a New York firm that helps business analyze change. **********Holiday vacations this year, he says, are as likely to focus on the self-indulgent luxury of a spa or cruise as on an educational trip such as an ecology tour or whale watching. **********Low-end computers, priced under $1,000, will make their way into the homes of many shoppers, from retirees and other first-time buyers to families adding a model exclusively for the children. Recent price cuts are also expected to help computer and video games and cell phones disappear from store shelves, along with hand-held computer devices. **********The trend in apparel leans toward the casual. Fleece pullovers, the brighter the better, are flying off the shelves, said Thomas J. Burns, senior vice president at the Doneger Group, retail consultants based in New York. **********In women's clothing, cashmere is generally expected to sell well, with some sweaters offered as low as $40. But analysts expect consumers to balk at the lowest-priced, thinnest versions. Velvet and suede are also popular choices to add a hint of luxury. **********Then there are the gifts you can never go wrong with: books. But move over, Martha Stewart; Oprah Winfrey reigns here. Though cookbooks have long been a gift staple, this year mystery, suspense and self-improvement are hot. And anything Ms. Winfrey picks for her television book club is an instant best seller. **********''If you go into a Barnes & Noble, they have a section that says 'Oprah's Picks,' '' Mr. Konarski said. People believe that ''if Oprah says it's good, it must be good.'' **********And whether shoppers want them or not, scented soap and candles will be inescapable. These days, few stores fail to carry them, in all shapes, sizes and colors. **********Candles also offer a New Age twist. As 1999 brings the eve of a millennium, a religious or mystical influence will be felt everywhere from candles to jewelry, books to music. **********Convenience is gaining converts as Internet shopping continues to grow, lifted by a broadening array of products available by computer. **********''For the last 15 years, I've done all my shopping from my chair,'' whether by catalogue or Internet, Mr. Brown acknowledged. ''You have the list of all the people you're shopping for, and bang, bang, bang, you do all the shopping.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/10/techn.snippet: IMS Health, which tallies United States sales of all prescription drugs, offers comprehensive World Wide Web site for data on pharmaceutical industry; is particularly useful in identifying most popular drug for almost any condition; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/10/techn.main_headline: Comprehensive Information That Can Be Hard to Find
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/10/techn.print_headline: LIBRARY/PRESCRIPTION DRUG SITES; Comprehensive Information That Can Be Hard to Find
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/10/techn.body_text: **********WWW.IMS-HEALTH.COM **********THIS is one of the most comprehensive sites for information on the pharmaceutical industry. The A. C. Nielsen Corporation of the drug business, IMS Health, regularly tallies sales of all prescription drugs in the United States. Wall Street analysts and drug company executives regularly use the site for sales information, but there appears to be plenty of helpful material for others as well -- hard as it might be to find it. **********The site is particularly useful in identifying the most popular drug for almost any condition. It also has information on treatment trends for certain conditions, including H.I.V. and high cholesterol levels, and on the factors that influence a doctor in prescribing certain medications. **********But searching through IMS is akin to strolling through a large pharmacy with confusing aisle signs. The site map is intimidating. For example, the section called Over the Counter, which has news tidbits on nonprescription drugs like Tylenol, has 29 other icons, including Strategic Technologies and Erisco, which is IMS's information systems subsidiary. **********If you are looking for prescription drug sales, logic suggests clicking on Product News. But that quickly becomes an adventure in frustration. Type the word Prozac, Eli Lilly's ubiquitous antidepressant, into the search field and you will get zero responses. That is especially odd, given that Prozac was the second best-selling drug in the United States last year. **********O.K., maybe this site was not designed for a computer neophyte. I tried again, typing Glaxo, short for Glaxo Wellcome, into the search field under the category Company News.  Again, a complete bust. That was even more annoying. Glaxo Wellcome is the second-largest pharmaceutical company on the planet. **********An IMS executive said the company's main site was being tuned up. The information about prescription drugs was hidden in the site map in a section called IMS America. But after moving there, then clicking on Pharmaceutical Division and News or Trends, I was able to find the best-selling drug in the United States last year: Prilosec, Astra-Merck's anti-ulcer medication, with sales of $2.28 billion. The nation's top drug seller: Merck? Nope. Try Bristol-Myers Squibb, with sales of $5.69 billion. **********The IMS site is updated weekly, with news items added as they occur.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/04/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; SARA LEE TO SELL THREE FACTORIES IN EUROPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/04/busin.body_text: **********The Sara Lee Corporation said yesterday that it would sell three factories in Europe, generating $200 million in cash, as part of a plan announced last September to reduce its manufacturing base and focus on managing brands. The maker of clothing, packaged foods and body care products said it was selling two soap and lotion plants in Italy to Cover SRL, a packaging company. It will also sell an aerosol factory in Belgium to Trost Group International, one of Europe's top five aerosol-can makers. The Chicago company, which also makes Hanes underwear and Sara Lee baked goods, said it would use the proceeds to buy back shares. Its shares rose $1.9375, to $52.0625.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/21/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Stocks Up in Japan, Helped by Wall Street's Gain
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/21/busin.body_text: **********Japanese stocks rose today for a sixth day, helped by Wall Street's gains and the possibility of additional measures to invigorate the domestic economy. **********Elsewhere in Asia, South Korean stocks fell sharply. Other Asian markets were mixed. **********Japan's benchmark Nikkei average of 225 issues closed up 317.89 points, or 1.94 percent, to 16,684.42. **********Traders attributed the gain partly to a carry-over effect from the advances on Tuesday on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.5 percent and broader stock averages also strengthened. **********Further helping the Japanese market were more hints the Government might issue another economic stimulus package. **********Koichi Kato, secretary general of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, said on Tuesday that efforts to reduce the Government budget deficit should be delayed if the economy remained stagnant, the Nihon Keizai newspaper reported. He also said there was room to increase spending on public works. **********In Seoul, stocks dropped 5.1 percent on profit-taking from the market's recent gains and the uncertainty regarding efforts to renegotiate the nation's short-term debt. A South Korean delegation was conferring with international bank representatives in New York today. **********By late afternoon, the South Korean market's main index was down 27.40 points, to 506.15. **********In other Asian markets, Indonesia's composite stock index rose 4.4 percent, largely on demand for shares of PT Telkom, which was viewed as an increasingly attractive investment because of the diminished value of the rupiah currency. **********Stocks fell 2.64 percent in Hong Kong by midday, 1.42 percent in Singapore and 1.05 percent in the Philippines but were slightly higher in Thailand.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/02/busin.snippet: A majority of business students in Germany consider a master of business administration degree from a prestigious American university to be the most desirable educational credential they could have..But many large German companies say graduates of...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/02/busin.main_headline: Students Prize U.S. Degrees; Firms Disagree : Europe's MBA Discord
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/02/busin.print_headline: Students Prize U.S. Degrees; Firms Disagree : Europe's MBA Discord
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/02/busin.body_text: **********A majority of business students in Germany consider a master of business administration degree from a prestigious American university to be the most desirable educational credential they could have. **********But many large German companies say graduates of top-ranking European schools have educations that are more relevant to their needs. **********These, at any rate, are among the findings of a recent study of European holders of MBA degrees carried out for the German magazine Audimax. **********The study attempted to rank European business schools by how well they corresponded to the detailed preferences of more than 200 students on such subjects as the structure of the programs, curricula, location, admissions standards and teaching methods. **********The French business school Insead received the highest ranking, followed by the London Business School and IMD in Switzerland. **********William Cox, head of Cox Communications Consultants, which carried out the survey, stressed that the ranking was not a guide to the quality of the schools. The participants, he said, had not been asked to evaluate actual MBA programs, only to answer a detailed questionnaire on the attributes of 100 MBA programs available in Europe, about one-third of the total. No American schools figured on the survey. **********The answers were then matched against the programs as assessed from information supplied by the schools themselves or from their brochures. **********The result, Mr. Cox said, was a profile of courses that students thought most relevant to their needs, judged from the publicly available information about them. Thus the list contained schools in Spain, Italy and Finland, even though few Germans study at them. **********Intangible factors such as the value of networking with other students were not taken into account in the survey, although Mr. Cox said this was important when it came to choosing a school. Even if students declared that they were interested in high admission and academic standards, "what they really want to do is to make more money," Mr. Cox said. "That's 90 percent of the motivation." **********The students also were asked to award ratings of from zero to three points to various countries, reflecting their preferences for places to receive a business education. The United States received 541 points, with 160 students giving it the maximum score of three points. **********The next most popular country was Britain, with 395 points; the least popular region was the Nordic area, with only 10 points. Nevertheless, the Helsinki School of Economics made it onto the list in 20th place because its programs were closely matched to students' requirements. **********Mr. Cox said the responses showed a distinct lack of enthusiasm for studying in Japan or the rest of Asia. **********The popularity of universities in the United States and Britain was linked to the importance of English as a world business language, he said. He said American teachers were much in demand at European business schools, and at some, such as Helsinki, English was the language of instruction. **********Mr. Cox said, however, that European companies, particularly medium-sized ones, viewed a European degree as more valuable than an American one. The European qualifications were deemed more relevant to local needs, he said. **********Companies did not want MBA courses lasting longer than one year, particularly if they were paying for them, because such courses took students out of the "real world" for too long. **********"Two-year MBAs are going out of style," Mr. Cox said. **********He said European programs had "grown in maturity against their older American counterparts" and were "substantially more innovative and international." **********The students said they thought an ideal business education should feature the following: a program lasting one year; practical projects in corporations; a final project or thesis; the ability to specialize in such areas as managing medium-sized companies; classroom instruction; opportunities to spend part of the program in the United States or another foreign country; faculty members with both academic and business backgrounds and with experience teaching in foreign schools, and tough admission standards. **********The students said that schools should also practice what they preach by managing themselves like corporations. **********Mr. Cox said German students were particularly interested in having practical experience rather than academic or theoretical training. **********"They associate academic with theoretical, poorly funded programs in state universities with 300 or 400 students listening to a lecturer and say they don't want any more of that," he said. **********In addition, a business education is considered good protection against the high unemployment rate in Germany.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/05/world.snippet: United Nations Commission on Human Rights investigator Fatma-Zohra Ksentini report names US, Germany, Australia, Britain and Netherlands as biggest toxic-waste exporters, and says masses of toxic waste are still being sent to Africa; Ksentini says...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/05/world.main_headline: West Hinders Inquiry on Dumping as Rights Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/05/world.print_headline: West Hinders Inquiry on Dumping as Rights Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/05/world.body_text: **********Can dumping toxic waste violate human rights? **********In 1995, a group of mostly African countries turned to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights here to address how to stem the huge flow of dangerous substances to their continent. The commission agreed to look into whether dumping toxic products and wastes threatened the basic rights of life and good health. **********The idea was that an investigator would find evidence of unlawful dumping and produce an annual list of wrongdoers. But that was not what the investigator, Fatma-Zohra Ksentini of Algeria, was able to do, given her limited resources and little cooperation from developed countries or corporations. Only 18 of the 185 members of the United Nations replied to her requests for information; most were nonindustrial countries. She made some site visits, but had to rely mainly on information from United Nations bodies and nongovernmental groups. **********The United States did not give her any information. The United States' position is that such issues marginalize the significance of human rights, said Craig Kuehl, an American official who monitors the commission. **********''The question of illicit movement and dumping of toxic products and waste is a serious problem,'' he said, ''but the Commission on Human Rights is not the correct international forum.'' **********There is no doubt in Mrs. Ksentini's mind that dumping is a human rights violation. She said information she gathered shows ''serious violations of the right to life and health'' that in some cases ''had led to sickness, disorders, physical or mental disabilty and even death.'' **********Her report was a bit embarrassing: She named the United States, Germany, Australia, Britain and the Netherlands as the biggest toxic-waste exporters, and said masses of toxic waste are still being sent to Africa, while the bulk of European waste goes to the Baltic countries and to Eastern and Central Europe. Half of the United States exports went to Latin America; British exports go largely to Asia. **********Despite her lack of progress, developing countries are seeking to extend Mrs. Ksentini's mandate for three years. American officials have already prepared a recommendation limiting her to one more year. A vote on the extension is scheduled for next week.

The Los Angeles-based recruiter will seek to sell 12.5 million shares for $13 to $15 apiece, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. While Korn/Ferry initially filed for an initial offering in August, the filing did not give details of the planned offering. https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/19/world.snippet: war of words: the administration, its critics and questions of moral right**Excerpts from public meeting on Iraq at Ohio State University with Defense Sec William S Cohen, State Sec Madeleine K Albright and national security adviser Samuel R Berge...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/19/world.main_headline: War of Words: The Administration, Its Critics and Questions of Moral Right
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/19/world.print_headline: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ; War of Words: The Administration, Its Critics and Questions of Moral Right
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/19/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from the meeting on Iraq yesterday at Ohio State University with Defense Secretary William S. Cohen, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, responding to questions from the studio audience and from CNN viewers. The text was provided by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company: **********Q:  The American Administration has the might and the means to attack the Iraqi state, but does it have the moral right to attack the Iraqi nation? [Cheers, applause.] **********MR. COHEN:  The question is also, does Saddam Hussein have the moral right to use weapons of mass destruction -- [Shouts from hecklers.] -- against his own people.  The United Nations has determined that he should not possess chemical or biological or nuclear weapons, and what we have is the obligation to carry out the U.N. declaration to make sure he doesn't pose a threat of the immoral magnitude to his neighbors has he has done in the past. [Applause.] **********Q:  This Administration has raised concerns about Iraq's threats to its neighbors, yet none of these neighbors seem to threatened. . . . Furthermore, the international community has been opposed to the bombings. If nobody's asking us for their help, how can you justify further U.S. aggression in the region? [Applause, shouts.] **********MS. ALBRIGHT:  It is very clear that the problem here is one to the region. Saddam Hussein has invaded another country before, he continues to try to develop weapons of mass destruction [Shouts from hecklers.] and I have been to the region. I have talked to the neighbors. They are concerned about what is going on there. They have made it very clear that they are worried about what Saddam Hussein is doing, and we are going to be a part of a coalition helping them to resolve this problem. . . . **********Q:  If push comes to shove and Saddam will not back down, will not allow or keep his word, are we ready and willing to send the troops in? [Cheers, applause.] **********MR. COHEN:  . . . I just returned from visiting our troops on the U.S.S. George Washington.  I visited our troops on the U.S.S. Independence. Each and every one of those young men and women who are out there are prepared to do whatever is necessary in order to contain the threat. **********What we are seeking to do is not to topple Saddam Hussein, not to destroy his country, but to do what the United Nations has said in its declarations. And we want to insist that it's not only words, but deeds. We want the enforcement of the U.N. declarations. And these young men and women are prepared to carry out that mission. We do not see the need to carry out a large land campaign in order to try to topple Saddam Hussein. Our mission is to get the inspectors back; if they can't get back, to make sure that he can't constitute or reconstitute this threat. **********Q:  President Carter . . . was quoted yesterday as saying that up to 100,000 innocent Iraqi civilians could be killed. Is that something, Secretary Albright, [Shouts, applause.] that you think is a realistic possibility? **********MS. ALBRIGHT:  First of all, let me just say the following thing: I am willing to make a bet to anyone here that we care more about the Iraqi people than Saddam Hussein does.  [Applause.] He has, for the last seven years since the gulf war, he has starved his people.  We have provided food. There is no limit on the amount of humanitarian assistance that can go in. . . . So the point here is that he does not care a fig about his people, and if he does the totally uncivilized thing of putting women and children to guard his regime, then the fault is his. **********Q: Why do you think the other members of the Security Council have been reluctant to support the military action, other than Great Britain? **********MS. ALBRIGHT:  Let me first of all say that what is very important to know, that every Security Council resolution has been supported by members of the Security Council, which is to get full implementation of these resolutions that call on Saddam Hussein to allow the inspection and verification to make sure that these weapons of mass destruction are gone. **********We have great support from members of the United Nations and the Security Council.  They, as we, would prefer a peaceful solution to this, as we have said. And we are supporting and we've said that we agree that Kofi Annan should go on this trip to Baghdad. And I believe that we do have the support for what we need to do because we are fulfilling the Security Council resolutions. **********Q:  I would like to ask Mr. Secretary (Cohen) if he thinks that the ultimate goal of this particular action, which the United States may or may not take, should be the ultimate removal of Saddam Hussein from Government, because it is obvious that, as Secretary Albright has mentioned, he is a repeat offender. . . . **********MR. COHEN:  Thank you for the question. I think the difference is -- that exists between what is desirable and what is do-able. I think everyone in that region as well as the world community would welcome Saddam Hussein's removal from power. We would welcome the opportunity, as Secretary Albright has said, to deal with another regime and, hopefully, have a much more positive and productive relationship. **********But what is do-able remains another question all together, as Mr. Berger pointed out.  This would require, in our judgment, a rather massive force of land forces, and we don't think that it's necessary in order to contain him. We think that we can contain him, as we have for the past seven years, and allow the Iraqi people at some point in time to determine for themselves whether they want another seven years of deprivation. **********Q:  Assuming that the United States does do air strikes on Iraq, I was wondering what the United States is prepared to do if Iraq decides to retaliate by attacking its neighbors. **********MR. COHEN:  We have, obviously, taken that into account. We have planned for virtually every contingency. Should Saddam Hussein seek to strike out against his neighbors, we have prepared defensive measures. . . . And we would respond rather swiftly also should he attack his neighbors. So we have been coordinating very closely with all of the countries in the region. **********Q:  Since we are unsure where Iraq's weapons are, how can we direct a bombing strike against them? **********MR. COHEN:  We have carefully selected the targets that will be necessary in order to reduce his ability to threaten his neighbors or to deliver weapons of mass destruction.  We have reasonably, I would say, very good evidence in terms of intelligence where these systems are, in fact, produced as far as the delivery systems. We have a good set of options available for us should it become necessary. So we are confident that we will be able to diminish his capacity to reconstitute these systems and to deliver them, and that will be our goal. **********Q: There are news media reports that Iraq has moved much of their weapon industry to other countries. Would we consider targeting them in other countries? **********MS. ALBRIGHT:  First of all, . . . we have no indication that this is taking place. What we are concerned about is Saddam Hussein, who has a record of using weapons of mass destruction against his neighbors as well as against his own people. And a brutal dictator who is terrifying his people and threatening the region. And our policy is to contain him; that is what we are trying to do. **********Q: Why bomb Iraq, when other countries have committed similar violations? . . . For example, Turkey has bombed Kurdish citizens. Saudi Arabia has tortured political and religious dissidents. Why does the U.S. apply different standards of justice to these countries? [Cheers, applause.] **********MS. ALBRIGHT:  Let me say that when there are problems such as you have described, we point them out and make very clear our opposition to them. But there is no one that has done to his people or to his neighbors what Saddam Hussein has done . . . [Hecklers shouting.] **********Q.  What about Indonesia? Well, you've turned my microphone off. **********MS. ALBRIGHT:  I think that the record will show that Saddam Hussein has produced weapons of mass destruction, which he's clearly not collecting for his own personal pleasure but in order to use. [Hecklers shouting.] And therefore, he is qualitatively and quantitatively different from every brutal dictator that has appeared recently. And we are very concerned about him specifically and what his plans might be. **********Q: What I am saying is that there needs to be consistent application of U.S. foreign policy.  [Applause, cheers.] We cannot support people who are committing the same violations because they are political allies. That is not acceptable. We cannot violate U.N. resolutions when it is convenient to us. **********MS. ALBRIGHT:  We do not. . . .- **********Q. You're not answering my question, Madame Albright. [Cheers, applause.] **********MS. ALBRIGHT:  I suggest, sir, that you study carefully what American foreign policy is, what we have said exactly about the cases that you have mentioned. Every one of them have been pointed out. Every one of them we have clearly stated our policy on. [Shouting begins again.] And if you would like, as a former professor, I would be delighted to spend 50 minutes with you describing exactly what we are doing on those subjects. [Applause.] **********Q:  There are many countries that have these biological and chemical weapons -- six countries in the Middle East alone. You've stated why Saddam Hussein should be singled out, but it is puzzling to people to wonder why it's O.K. for these other countries to have biological and chemical weapons. [Applause.] **********MS. ALBRIGHT:  I think that is clear that other countries have weapons of mass destruction. It is a question of whether there is a proclivity to use them. [Scattered applause.] And Saddam Hussein is a repeat offender. And I think it is very important for us to make clear that the United States and the civilized world cannot deal with somebody who is willing to use those weapons of mass destruction on his own people, not to speak of his neighbors. [Applause, heckling.] **********Q:  Missiles landed in Israel during the gulf war, yet at America's request Israel restrained itself from - was restrained from defending itself. What will our country's posture be this time, and how will Israel be expected to protect its citizens in the face of potential Iraqi aggression? [Applause.] **********MS. ALBRIGHT:  I have recently been to Israel, and there have been, obviously, discussions about this. Every country has a right to make its own decisions about how to protect itself, and we are consulting very closely with Israel. **********MR. COHEN:  I also have met with the Defense Minister, and we are satisfied that full cooperation will accommodate Israel's defensive needs as well. **********Q:  How do we convince the Russians that it's in their vital interest to support an international coalition against Saddam if push comes to shove? **********MS. ALBRIGHT:  Well, let me say, I have spent a great deal of time with my counterpart, Foreign Minister Primakov. He fully agrees with the fact that Saddam Hussein has to fulfill his obligations under the Security Council resolutions, and he has been working with all of us to try to get a peaceful solution. They are concerned about Saddam's weapons of mass destruction, and I believe that we should all be working on a peaceful solution. But if we can't, I am sure that we will all be together in the end. **********Q:  The U.S. has put a lot of time and effort into peace talks between Israel and Palestinian and the Middle Eastern countries. If we go into Iraq, how will this impact those peace talks, and do you perceive any type of backing away from the table if that happens? **********MS. ALBRIGHT:  . . . 1997 was not a great year for the peace talks. But we are determined to continue, and these are two very separate issues that need to be resolved. And we will spend the time that's necessary. I've been in touch with both the leaders there and others in recent days and weeks. And we will continue to press that, because that's an issue of great importance to the United States. **********Q:  Why doesn't the United States give military support to the democratic opposition in Iraq? And this brings up the whole question of why doesn't the United States give -- perhaps release frozen -- the Iraqis' billions of dollars in frozen assets and make it available to the democratic opposition in Iraq? **********MR. BERGER:  I think as Secretary Cohen has said, we have and we will continue to support the democratic opposition in Iraq. I think one has to be very careful, though.  This actually relates to the point that the previous caller was making. If you encourage and almost incite people to rise up against their government, you incur a moral obligation [Hecklers shouting.] to come to their defense at a moment of peril. And we have had experiences in this country, in the Bay of Pigs, in Hungary in 1956 and in Iraq in 1991, where perhaps our rhetoric has gone ahead of what we are prepared to do. And we've been very careful not to let that happen again. **********Q:  If there is no peaceful resolution to the problem and war is inevitable, and we end up damaging their country even further, are we, the American people, the tax-paying people, going to be responsible for making financial reparations to the country? [Hecklers shouting.] **********MR. BERGER:  You know, if I could just answer that, Saddam sits on enormous storehouses of oil. And as Secretary Albright said before, it's the United States since 1991 that has been trying to say to -- to give him the right to sell that oil, take that money, buy food and medicine for his people and distribute it under U.N. auspices so we make sure that it goes to people and not to tanks. For five years, he refused even to have such a regime. We finally got such a regime in place. He delayed it another six months.  We're now prepared to expand that regime.  We would like to see him sell more oil so that more food and medicine can get to the Iraqi people; and, believe it or not, he is resisting that. So I think it is -- our quarrel is certainly not with the Iraqi people. We would like to help them get the food, the medicine, the other things that they need for their daily lives. **********There's one obstacle standing in the way of that, and I think all of you know who that is. **********Q:  How can these people sleep at night? We are not going to be able to stop Saddam Hussein. We are not going to be able to eliminate his weapons of mass destruction -- all of them. President Clinton admitted it.  All he wants to do, Clinton said, was send a message to Saddam Hussein. If he wants to send a message, we, the people of Columbus and central Ohio and all over America will not send messages with the blood of Iraqi men, women, and children! If we want to deal with Saddam, we deal with Saddam, not the Iraqi people! [Cheers, applause, shouting.] **********MS. ALBRIGHT:  . . . Let me say that what we are doing is so that all of you can sleep night, because we are facing. [Applause, cheers] We are in a very different kind of a world [heckler continues shouting] where we are facing the danger of the spread of the weapons of mass destruction. We had an initial example of this, as Secretary Cohen said, in Tokyo, and we need to really put a stop to dictators who have weapons of mass destruction and threaten to use them against their people. . . . **********MR. BERGER:  Part of what we fight for as a country is the freedom to argue. And I appreciate all of you coming. I appreciate most of you listening. We have certainly -- we have certainly listened to you -- at least those who we could understand. [Laughter.] And I think the fundamental point that I want to make here is two-fold; number one, we want to resolve this peacefully. But number two, there are some things worth fighting for and those include fighting aggression, fighting people who threaten their neighbors, and fighting to make this world a safer and more secure place for my children and for yours. [Applause, shouts from hecklers.] Thank you. **********MR. COHEN:  If I could just indicate to the audience this really is a tremendous example of what democracy is all about, the people who are here expressing opposition and criticism would not be allowed to do that in a number of countries, including Iraq.  [Cheers, applause.] . . . **********Let me say, as Secretary of Defense, it is my obligation not only to try and identify those problems that confront us today, but those challenges of tomorrow. Most of you here have children and will be building families in the future, and we have a choice to make. There's an old expression that you can pay me now or pay me later. With respect to Saddam Hussein, we can deal with him now, or our children and grandchildren will have to deal with the spread of chemical and biological weapons later.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/04/busin.snippet: Government is becoming increasingly dependent on Microsoft software, even as it steps up its antitrust pursuit of company that produces it; industry analysts estimate that in current fiscal year, Microsoft's Government sales will be about $380 mil...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/04/busin.main_headline: As U.S. Spars With Microsoft, Federal Offices Use Its Systems
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/04/busin.print_headline: As U.S. Spars With Microsoft, Federal Offices Use Its Systems
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/04/busin.body_text: **********Even as it steps up its antitrust pursuit of the Microsoft Corporation, the Government is becoming increasingly dependent on the company's software. **********The United States Army, Navy, Social Security Administration, Health and Human Services Department, Defense Logistics Agency, Postal Service, Coast Guard and, yes, the Justice Department, Microsoft's antitrust antagonist, have all started programs to use Microsoft software on tens of thousands of desktop computers. **********Part of the push toward Microsoft involves the company's office productivity and communications programs like its Word for word processing and its Excel spreadsheet, which in many Federal offices are replacing software from Wordperfect and Lotus. But the biggest move involves sales of Microsoft's industrial-strength operating system, Windows NT, which is becoming more and more popular in corporate America. **********''Microsoft and especially Windows NT are just taking over the desktop in the Federal Government,'' said Robert Dornan, senior vice president of Federal Sources Inc., a research firm in McLean, Va. ''And I don't see anything on the horizon that would undermine its success.'' **********To be sure, the spectacle of Washington's beating Microsoft with one hand while buying from it with the other is not as glaringly contradictory as it might seem. The antitrust confrontation with Microsoft, the Justice Department insists, is not intended to hobble the company but to protect competition and innovation in the software industry. **********The focus of the investigation, as the department considers filing a major antitrust case against Microsoft, is on accusations that the company is using its near-monopoly in the market for personal computer operating-system software to gain an unfair advantage in the new markets of Internet software, new media and on-line commerce. **********But if Microsoft succeeds not through unfair advantages but by offering the best product for the best price, then modern antitrust policy is working as it should. ''That's right,'' a senior Justice Department official said on condition that he not be identified by name, because ''I certainly don't want to throw them a bouquet.'' **********Feeling embattled these days, Microsoft is uncharacteristically touchy about the success of its Government business. An executive in its Washington office observed, ''Now remember, we lose sales, too'' -- not exactly the take-no-prisoners ethos long espoused by William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, or Steven Ballmer, the executive vice president in charge of sales. **********Microsoft started its Government business in 1986 with a one-person office in Washington. Today, the company has 120 people in its Federal systems unit, about 20 more than a year ago. Given the Justice Department's antitrust investigation, and all the resulting public attention, the Microsoft staff refers jokingly to the Washington office as ''ground zero.'' **********Still, the Washington business is thriving. The company does not disclose its Government sales. But industry analysts estimate that in the current fiscal year, ending in June, its Government sales will be about $380 million, up nearly 40 percent from the previous year. **********The far higher sales will probably come over the next several years as large installations of Microsoft software gain momentum -- especially for Windows NT, which is typically used for big networks of PC work stations. **********The Social Security Administration, for example, began a program last year to install 70,000 Windows NT work stations, running off 5,000 Windows NT network server computers, by 2003. **********And the United States Postal Service is replacing its 80,000 point-of-sale terminals nationwide with Windows NT work stations. **********''These Government customers are very big, so when they make a decision, the rollouts can be huge,'' said Pete Hayes, general manager of Microsoft's Federal systems business. **********To the Government, the appeal of Microsoft products is the potential cost saving and the ease of using its industry-standard programs. In many cases, Windows NT systems are replacing systems that use the Unix operating system, initially developed for scientific and research purposes. With the steady improvement in PC performance, personal computers can match the performance of Unix work stations at perhaps half the price or less, by some estimates. **********Once a technology laggard, the Government ''is leading the charge on NT in some ways, pushing it into more advanced uses that you see in most corporations,'' said Mathew Mahoney, an analyst for IDC Government, a research service in Falls Church, Va. **********The Air Force is an example of that. In a pilot program, it is beginning to experiment with moving some of its vital command-and-control operations -- which range from mapping battlefields to spotting enemy fighter jets -- away from bigger, more costly computers onto personal computers running Windows NT. **********''People in the industry say that Windows NT can take over these applications at far less cost,'' said Col. Richard Picanso, director of the command-and-control computer systems at Hanscom Air Force Base in Bedford, Mass. ''We want to see how much of that is marketing hype and how much of that is real.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/08/world.snippet: Brian Alexander article on battle between San Diego and Los Angeles over San Diego's effort to buy water from Imperial Irrigation District, largest user of Colorado River; map (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/08/world.main_headline: Between Two West Coast Cities, a Duel to the Last Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/08/world.print_headline: Between Two West Coast Cities, a Duel to the Last Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/08/world.body_text: **********IF Pirandello had written a play about water, he might have set it in a place where the London Bridge looms in one of the driest deserts on earth, where a $250-million water plant was built to desalt a supposedly freshwater river, and where huge pipes, like giant silver straws, rush water to gleaming cities hundreds of miles away. **********In other words, Pirandello might have set his play near the Colorado River, where fights over water have provided a real-life theater of the absurd for years. States, cities and agricultural districts are trapped in this world through a Byzantine set of agreements, court decisions and legislation known as the law of the river, which has been hammered out, sometimes after guns were drawn, over the last 75 years. Today, it is difficult to find anyone in the seven states governed by the law who thinks it is fair or that it reflects late-20th-century reality. At the same time, no one is willing to toss it out and start over. **********''I do not think it is the work of our generation to try to revisit this river constitution'' is how Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbitt puts it. **********Rather than changing the water rights outlined by the law of the river, Mr. Babbitt favors allowing those areas with water rights to sell, lease or trade them to those that want or need more. Such markets, his argument goes, will help water, which is often artificially cheap, find its true price and will encourage conservation. **********The Secretary may be right, but when the city of San Diego put that notion to the test, a nasty, two-year feud with Los Angeles ensued. It is a quarrel that could serve as an object lesson in the kind of paranoia, civic posturing and heated rhetoric that frequently accompanies water disputes in this part of the country. **********The feud began as a straightforward deal. San Diego wanted water -- more precisely, it wanted control of its source of water. The Imperial Irrigation District in the Imperial Valley, the largest user of the Colorado River, had so much water that it was apparently wasting it. So, in 1996, the two agreed that San Diego would buy water from Imperial, and Imperial would spend the money on conservation measures. It looked like a win-win arrangement -- but when it comes to Colorado River water, there is no such thing as win-win. **********San Diego has long felt it has lived in the shadow of the larger metropolis to the north, Los Angeles. When it comes to water, that perception is accurate. Though San Diego considered taking its own supply of Colorado River water over the mountains years ago, fate interceded in 1941 when the Los Angeles-based Metropolitan Water District of Southern California finished its aqueduct, which is about 240 miles from the river. **********At the instigation of the United States Navy, which was anchoring a major part of its fleet here, San Diego joined Metropolitan as a member in 1946. Today, with 27 members, the state-chartered Metropolitan is the largest supplier of water in the United States, serving about 16 million people in six Southern California counties. San Diego, which imports up to 95 percent of its water, is by far the biggest customer. **********This has not made allies of the two cities. For one, votes on Metropolitan's board are weighted in favor of Los Angeles, which has an independent water supply from the Owens Valley in the Sierra Nevada foothills hundreds of miles north of the city, and does not use its full allocation of Metropolitan water. Therefore, Metropolitan has been able to sell the water to other users, which has kept the district's coffers full and has expanded both its system and its power. San Diegans, whose city has grown on borrowed water, have known that in the event of a shortage, Los Angeles could cut the flow. **********''In the chamber of commerce in Los Angeles, they would tell C.E.O.'s looking to locate in Southern California that even though San Diego is a nice place, they do not have any water,'' said Joseph Parker, the incoming chairman of the San Diego County Water Authority. (He starts on Jan. 1.) **********The Los Angeles chamber of commerce denies this, and representatives of the Metropolitan District point out that the agency has never cut off San Diego's supply. David S. Freeman, the general manager of the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, calls San Diego's concern ''a red herring to rally the troops around.'' **********In 1991, however, which was a drought year, Metropolitan came very close to causing a virtual shutdown of San Diego's economy when it announced that the city's water supply would be cut in half. Fortunately for San Diego, a series of rains ended the threat. **********But after that, San Diego sought a source of water it could control and found it on the desert farms of the Imperial Valley, in the southeast corner of California. The Imperial district agreed to sell water to San Diego for $233 an acre-foot (about 360,000 gallons, or enough to cover one acre to a depth of one foot), not a bad markup on water for which Imperial pays the Federal Government an administration fee of 25 cents an acre-foot. It was also a good deal for San Diego, which pays Metropolitan $349 an acre-foot. **********The agreement was applauded by the seven Colorado River states (besides California, these are Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, Nevada, Utah and Wyoming) and by Mr. Babbitt's office. But Metropolitan was furious. Along with the other desert irrigation districts that tap the Colorado, its board thought it had a right to any water saved by Imperial. And if San Diego stopped buying so much water from Metropolitan, it would mean a loss of income. **********So, Metropolitan unleashed a legal and public relations blitz. It advised local black civic leaders that Mr. Parker, who is African-American and was then the vice-chairman, was being passed over for the chairmanship of the San Diego authority. Metropolitan, which regarded Mr. Parker as more conciliatory than Christine Frahm, the outgoing San Diego water chairwoman, ''wanted to make a big racial issue out of it,'' Mr. Parker said. **********Metropolitan also had a more direct card to play, since the water was not going to be physically shipped from the Imperial Valley to San Diego, but instead would be flowing from the Colorado -- through Metropolitan's pipes. So the agency tried to impose a charge for transporting the water to San  Diego that would turn the deal into a money loser. A state court judge threw out the plan. **********Such tactics led to an investigation -- still going on -- by the state legislature. Metropolitan's chief of operations, Jay Malinowski, said that while ''some cheap shots were taken at Metropolitan, it is undeniable the district's reputation was damaged'' by its strategy. On Aug. 12, it agreed to deliver the Imperial water to San Diego. **********Mr. Babbitt calls the San Diego-Imperial arrangement a major achievement, but cautions that the deal is not done. The Coachella Irrigation District, next to Imperial, has threatened to sue to stop it, arguing that it should receive water that Imperial does not use. And Patricia Mulroy, the general manager of the Southern Nevada Water District, says that a provision allowing Metropolitan to continue to take more river water than it is entitled to is ''a choker'' for the other Colorado user states. **********''Everything relates to everything else,'' Mr. Babbitt said wearily, referring to his own negotiations to settle disputes within California over the Sacramento River delta, the state's water hub. **********''The delta process affects entitlements to Southern California,'' he said, ''which in turn relates to their demands for Colorado River water, which in turn relates to river regulation, which in turn relates to river issues in Colorado and Wyoming.'' **********Mr. Babbitt said that feuds like the one between San Diego and Los Angeles ''are about history, political concepts, a lack of flexibility in institutions and local pride, rather than reality.'' **********''With so much water in the system,'' he said, ''if we move in a rational and coordinated way, there will be no serious long-term economic impacts.'' **********But he admits that he has not seen much rationality or coordination so far. **********''We are getting there,'' he said with a sigh, ''but it is trench warfare.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/07/news/.main_headline: Manpower Inc. Is Shaken Up in Power Struggle
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/07/news/.print_headline: Manpower Inc. Is Shaken Up in Power Struggle
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/07/news/.body_text: **********ROME—                     A power struggle has triggered a global management shake-up at Manpower Inc., the temporary employment service that is by some measures the world's largest employer, sources inside and outside the company said Monday. **********The Brussels-based chairman of Manpower's European and Asian operations, who is also the company's chief financial officer, resigned Monday, and a handful of top executives in Europe are also expected to leave. **********The divisions began at the heart of Manpower's most important market, Europe, and follow declining group earnings and speculation on Wall Street that the company might be a takeover target. **********Company insiders and industry sources said that the Brussels-based chairman, Jon Chait, had fallen out with Mitchell Fromstein, 70, chairman of the Milwaukee-based company. **********The issues that divided the chairman and Mr. Chait, who was seen by some industry analysts as his heir apparent, included whether or not to expand the business through acquisitions and how to market temporary employment services across Europe. **********Mr. Fromstein, in a telephone interview Monday, agreed that he and Mr. Chait had differed on these issues, but contended that "what we are putting into place is a reorganization of our senior management structure that is designed to shorten lines of communication between country managers and headquarters." **********Manpower last year brokered 1.4 million temporary jobs through its 2,800 offices in 48 countries around the world. **********At the same time, the company embarked on an aggressive campaign to penetrate key European markets such as France, Germany and Italy. It had 1997 group revenues of $7.2 billion. **********About 60 percent of its business is in Europe, more than half of that in France. **********But the profit margins of the French business have been squeezed because of attempts to keep prices down to compete with its two main rivals, the Swiss-based Adecco and the Dutch staffing service Vedior, analysts said. **********The problems in France were so serious that when Manpower last month announced that its second-quarter earnings would probably slump to 32 cents from 49 cents a year ago. **********Mr. Fromstein cited the French margin decline, blaming it on the costs of French social security, the national health insurance program. **********Last month's announcement caused Manpower's stock price to drop 30 percent in three weeks, from $39.50 to $27.75 in late trading Monday. **********That stock price, according to Adam Waldo, an analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York, "makes the company a fairly compelling target for a financial or strategic buyer." **********Mr. Fromstein, the chairman in Milwaukee, said he doubted that any takeover bid would succeed, and he predicted that Manpower's "strength" would be shown "in the next few months." **********In a telephone interview Monday, Mr. Chait said he was leaving Manpower because of differences with Mr. Fromstein over his responsibilities. **********"My job," he said, "had included responsibility for France as well as for the rest of Europe and Asia, and in the new reorganization, I would have lost responsibility for France, and that was a step backwards." **********"If you asked me if I might go to work for a competitor," he added, "I would say that I am studying my options at present." **********Mr. Waldo of Morgan Stanley said that the departure of Mr. Chait meant "that Fromstein is clearly trying to reassert his control over European operations." **********Mr. Fromstein said Monday he would give responsibility for Europe to Jeff Joerres, a Milwaukee-based executive in charge of marketing for North America. **********He said Mr. Chait's Asian responsibilities would be given to Terry Heuneke, an executive vice president who is also in charge of North and South America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/world.main_headline: C.I.A. Reportedly Ignored Charges of Contra Drug Dealing in '80's
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/world.print_headline: C.I.A. Reportedly Ignored Charges of Contra Drug Dealing in '80's
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/10/world.body_text: **********Despite requests for information from Congress, the Central Intelligence Agency repeatedly ignored or failed to investigate allegations of drug trafficking by the anti-Sandinista rebels of Nicaragua in the 1980's, according to a newly declassified report. **********In a blunt and often critical report, the C.I.A.'s inspector general determined that the agency ''did not inform Congress of all allegations or information it received indicating that contra-related organizations or individuals were involved in drug trafficking.'' **********Beginning in 1986, the subject of contra drug trafficking became a focus for critics of the Reagan Administration's policy toward Nicaragua, who charged that the C.I.A. was shielding drug smugglers to protect its anti-Communist covert action program in Nicaragua. **********That year Congress imposed a fund cutoff for any contra group that had members involved in drug trafficking. Despite that ban, the C.I.A. failed to tell Congress about allegations it had received against at least eight individuals with contra ties. **********During the time the ban on funds was in effect, the C.I.A. informed Congress about drug charges against only two other contra-related people. **********In addition, the agency failed to tell other executive branch agencies, including the Justice Department, about allegations against 11 contra-related individuals or entities. **********The report quotes many active and retired C.I.A. officers who served in Central America as saying they either did not hear or did not believe allegations of drug trafficking involving the contra rebels, with whom they worked closely. It also makes clear that the agency did little or nothing to investigate most of the drug allegations that it heard about the contras and their supporters. **********In April 1987, the Director of Central Intelligence, Robert M. Gates, wrote in a memorandum that it was ''absolutely imperative that this agency and our operations in Central America avoid any kind of involvement with individuals or companies that are even suspected of involvement in narcotics trafficking.'' **********The C.I.A. investigation that began almost a decade later, however, found no evidence that the memorandum was distributed to anyone other than Mr. Gates's deputy for operations, Clair George. **********The new study is the second volume of the C.I.A.'s internal investigation prompted by a 1996 series of articles in The San Jose Mercury-News, which claimed that a ''dark alliance'' between the C.I.A., the contras and drug traffickers had helped finance the contra war with millions of dollars in profits from drug smuggling. The series also alleged that this network was the first to introduce crack cocaine into South Central Los Angeles. The first volume of the C.I.A. inspector general's report, issued in January, dealt primarily with the specific allegations raised by the Mercury-News series and dismissed its central findings. **********The second volume is the result of a broader inquiry into long-unresolved questions about the contra program and drug trafficking. **********In all, the report found that the C.I.A. received allegations of drug involvement by 58 contras or others linked to the contra program, including 14 pilots and two others tied to the contra program's C.I.A.-backed air transportation operations. **********The report indicates that information linking the contras to drugs began to emerge almost as soon as the contras came into existence, and before it became publicly known that the C.I.A. was supporting their effort to overthrow the Marxist-led Government in Managua.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/techn.snippet: Letter by Alan Acton, chief executive of Acton Web Export, says those wanting to do international business on the Internet will need to consider their approach to language issues raised in June 18 article
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/25/techn.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********The article ''The Web Reflects a Wider World'' (June 18) has many implications. Those wanting to do international business on the Internet will need to consider their approach to the language issues you raise, as some are already doing. **********It is clear that many non-native English speakers browse the Web in English, at least some of the time. These people make up a huge market, and very few are fully bilingual. Owners of English-language Web sites who want to address this market should make sure that the English they use is clear, simple and international. **********And clear, simple English will be easier to translate to other languages when the time comes -- if it hasn't already. **********ALAN ACTON **********London, June 23, 1998 **********The author is the chief executive of Acton Web Export (www.actonwebexport.com), which translates Web sites.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/25/busin.body_text: **********CS First Boston is suing P.T. Polysindo Eka Perkasa for repayment of $235 million of bonds issued by the troubled Indonesian polyester maker. **********CS First Boston, a unit of Switzerland's Credit Suisse Group, filed its suit yesterday in United States District Court in New York. The bank contends that it was entitled to immediate repayment on its $235 million of Polysindo bonds because the company skipped interest payments. It is also asking the court to prohibit Polysindo from doing anything to avoid paying back the bonds, plus interest. **********Polysindo is being battered by Indonesia's first recession in 30 years and a decline of as much as 80 percent in the rupiah's value against the United States dollar. The rupiah's collapse makes it difficult for Indonesian companies to repay their foreign-currency debts, as the cost of repayment in rupiah terms has surged more than three-fold.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/23/busin.snippet: Consumer Federation of America begins campaign against consumer product manufacturers and Internet services that heavily promote products but fail to divulge prices; experts comment on reasons for such stragegies; drawing (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/23/busin.main_headline: Information Age? Maybe Not, When It Comes to Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/23/busin.print_headline: SPENDING IT; Information Age? Maybe Not, When It Comes to Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/23/busin.body_text: **********EVEN as the Internet has given consumers a powerful tool for learning what things cost, sizable chunks of American business seem determined to make price comparisons hard, sometimes frustratingly so. **********Consider the Oreck Corporation, which boasts that its compact XL vacuum cleaner has been embraced by luxury hotels and that the XL's four-pound supplementary vacuum is so powerful that it can pick up a 16-pound bowling ball. Oreck promotes these products heavily on radio and television, on fliers accompanying credit-card bills and in such mass-market publications as Parade magazine. **********But the prices of these marvels are not divulged: The potential buyer must mail or phone a request for an ''information kit'' to learn them. **********A consumer may also be frustrated when banks post or orally quote mortgage rates but refuse to actually make agreements on these terms until he plunks down cash to ''lock in,'' typically hundreds of dollars. **********''This sure discourages comparison-shopping,'' contended Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America, which has mounted a campaign against the practice. **********Then there is America Online, which was luring new subscribers with offers of free time but without specifying the costs at the end of the trial period. The company agreed this spring to explain its charges more clearly as part of a broad settlement with 44 state attorneys general. **********Except in financial services, there are few laws or regulations requiring sellers to disclose prices to prospective buyers, whether the item in question is a house or car -- both usually subject to negotiation anyway -- a box of cereal or even the product widely considered to serve as the economy's most visible barometer, a gallon of gasoline. For the most part, the Government just polices advertising to keep it from being false or misleading. **********''Our interest gets piqued if it's a way to restrain competition or if there's consumer deception involved,'' said Willard K. Tom, deputy director of the Bureau of Competition of the Federal Trade Commission. (In a recently settled case over competition issues, the F.T.C. had contended that a group of farm-equipment dealers in Kentucky and Indiana had withheld advertisements from an industry journal after it published ads by other dealers featuring prices lower than those offered by the group members. The F.T.C. had also contended that the journal later agreed to stop accepting ads that included prices.) **********One obvious reason that consumers are often left to guess at prices is that manufacturers and retailers know that general American prosperity has reduced the need for many people to watch how they spend each nickel and dime. **********But there is more to it than that, marketing and advertising specialists say. Generally speaking, marketers say they are finding an emphasis on price to be a poor, often self-defeating strategy. It tends to erode consumer perceptions of product quality, and also eventually loses impact even with shoppers whose primary consideration is price. That's because the bargain-hunters wait to buy only during the inevitable sales. **********The notion of buying goods at sale prices ''becomes an entitlement,'' said Tom Lawson, managing partner at Arnold Communications, an advertising agency in Boston. **********Just as important, others say, is a desire not to unnecessarily intensify competition. **********''Marketers aren't pushing prices because they don't want to get into wars,'' said Audrey Guskey, professor of marketing at Duquesne University in Pittsburgh. And manufacturers see little to gain by parading before Wall Street their current inability to raise prices in a minimum-inflation climate. **********Asked about his strategy of deferred price disclosure, David Oreck, the chief executive of the vacuum cleaner company, said it was a matter of practicality. ''We have several different models and there's just so much you can say in an ad,'' he said. **********Perhaps, the specialists suggested, the Oreck strategy is to concentrate on prospects who are motivated enough to request price information, at the risk of losing some potential customers who assume that Oreck cleaners are priced beyond their means. The products, which Mr. Oreck calls ''kind of mid-range,'' average $300 to $400. **********It is clear, though, that the rapid proliferation of Internet technology has complicated marketing strategies. ''A whole new source has emerged for price information that wasn't there before,'' said Joseph Plummer, director of brand strategy at McCann-Erickson Worldwide. **********Some sellers, though, avoid electronic commerce ''for fear that people would go on the Internet and comparison-shop,'' perhaps unfairly penalizing goods that should command premium prices, said Frank Torres, a spokesman for Consumers Union. **********YET according to a study by researchers at Pennsylvania State University's Smeal College of Business, consumer sensitivity to price ''tends to be lower on line'' than in stores, particularly when the sales pitch describes a product's other attributes, like nutritional value of a food product. **********In some cases, of course, the lack of a price tag is pure snob appeal, its absence intended to suggest that the product ''is for the kind of people who don't have to worry about the price,'' said Diane Cook-Tench, director of the Adcenter at Virginia Commonwealth University. **********Or, as has been said about yachts, if you have to ask what one costs, you can't afford it.
