https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/16/world.snippet: Ramadan tradition of firing cannon to mark end of day's fast is carried out in Jerusalem, but with modern twist; fireworks are now set off by Rajal Sandouka, who says his family has been entrusted with duty for 80 years; Sandouka charges Israelis,...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/16/world.main_headline: Jerusalem Journal; Lost Thunder of Ramadan Echoes in the Old City
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/16/world.print_headline: Jerusalem Journal; Lost Thunder of Ramadan Echoes in the Old City
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/16/world.body_text: **********As dusk fell over East Jerusalem this evening and people hurried home to break the daylong fast of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, Rajai Sandouka trudged up the path of a graveyard overlooking the walled Old City. **********Near a rusty Jordanian Army cannon at the top of the cemetery, Mr. Sandouka loaded fireworks into a launcher. Consulting a Muslim prayer schedule and a digital watch, he held a cigarette lighter to the fuse at precisely 5:04 P.M., the time of the sunset prayer. **********The rocket shot into the sky and burst with a thunderous boom over the city, signaling the end of the daytime fast. The Muslim call to prayer began echoing from minarets as families sat down to their festive meal after sundown. **********For nearly 80 years, Mr. Sandouka says, his family has fired the cannon on Ramadan in Jerusalem, following a longstanding Muslim custom. **********But on this Ramadan as well as the last, the Jerusalem gun has fallen silent, replaced by fireworks in another twist of the conflict here between Arab and Jew. **********Mr. Sandouka says the Israeli authorities, jittery after a string of suicide bombings by Muslim militants in the Jewish side of Jerusalem, have denied him the gunpowder needed to fire the cannon. **********Israeli officials assert that Mr. Sandouka has only himself to blame, because he has failed to obtain the gunpowder he needs. **********''For the people of Jerusalem, the cannon is a historical tradition,'' Mr. Sandouka said. ''Now the heritage of the cannon has been lost.'' **********A 36-year-old actor and puppeteer who is not religiously observant, Mr. Sandouka takes his daily firing ritual seriously, shooting twice more at dawn to signal the start of the daylight fast. The dawn-to-dusk ban on eating, drinking and smoking lasts the entire holy month, which began on Dec. 30 and ends on Jan. 28. **********''This is a religious responsibility,'' Mr. Sandouka said of his task, noting that neither rain nor snow have kept him from his appointed rounds. On Monday, when a rare snowstorm struck Jerusalem, he showed up like clockwork at the cemetery, braving the elements to send off the morning shots. **********But his work has been severely restricted over the years by Israeli security requirements. When he used gunpowder -- packing it in to the gun-barrel with old rags and a pole as he had been taught by his father -- the use of the explosives was strictly monitored by the Israelis. **********A special permit was required to transport the gunpowder from a factory in the West Bank town of Ramallah, along a predetermined route to the East Jerusalem cemetery. Police officers would arrive at the graveyard periodically to check the amount of explosives and to make sure they were used entirely for the cannon. On one surprise visit the officers hid, phantom-like, among the graves, Mr. Sandouka recalled. **********Now the Jerusalem Municipality pays for fireworks provided by an Israeli supplier, and Mr. Sandouka sets them off with a permit from the authorities. He must call the Jerusalem police daily to serve notice when he plans to shoot. **********The Israeli Ministry of Labor, which issues permits for civilian use of explosives, says Mr. Sandouka is free to use gunpowder again, with a permit, if he finds a supplier. The Ramallah gunpowder factory closed down about two years ago. **********Mr. Sandouka asserts that as a law-abiding Palestinian with a clean security record, he has no alternative source of explosives, and that it is up to the Israelis to provide him with gunpowder he can use. **********Yitzhak Lisinger, the Labor Ministry's regional supervisor in Jerusalem, said that he didn't see the difference between shooting fireworks and firing the cannon. ''It's the same result: noise,'' he said. ''The effect is the same.'' **********But for Palestinians in East Jerusalem, the Ramadan gun has become a symbol of the holy month, and fireworks are only a faint echo of the real thing. **********''It was better in the old days,'' said Azmi Muslih, a toy-shop owner who times his family's evening meal to the sound of the explosion. ''The children don't start eating until they hear the shot.'' **********Mr. Sandouka, who gets a symbolic fee of $4.30 a day from the municipality for his troubles, says that although the fireworks are a ''Western-style celebration'' quite different from the traditional Ramadan gun, he still feels the burden of public service on his shoulders. **********''It's our responsibility,'' he said of his family's duty. ''If I fail to do it once, people stop me in the street the next day and ask, 'Why didn't you fire the cannon?' People break their fast when they hear the gun.'' **********As he prepared to set off the fireworks this evening, Mr. Sandouka stared at his digital watch, which was synchronized to an Arabic radio broadcast that announced the moment of sunset prayer. **********''O fasters, the sun is now setting in the skies of Jerusalem,'' the radio announcer said. ''We say to the prayer-caller, send out your call!'' **********As the rocket burst overhead, the wailing calls to prayer began: ''God is great!''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/12/busin.snippet: US says it will ban import of all Chinese goods shipped in raw wood packing material in effort to halt invasion of voracious Asian long-borned beetle; officials say wooden crates and pallets used to ship goods to North America sometimes harbor bee...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/12/busin.main_headline: A Bug Turns Up in U.S.-China Trade Relations
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/12/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; A Bug Turns Up in U.S.-China Trade Relations
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/12/busin.body_text: **********To halt the invasion of a devastating insect pest, the United States said today that it would ban the import of all Chinese goods shipped in raw wood packing material, a move that is likely to strain China's economy -- as well as United States-China relations. **********Officials said wooden crates and pallets used to ship Chinese goods to North America sometimes harbor the comely but voracious Asian long-horned beetle, which has emerged from the packing material after it arrived in warehouses to kill trees in five locations around New York and Chicago in the last two years. **********The ban is likely to result in delays or higher costs for a third to half of China's $62 billion in exports to the United States -- at a time when China has already seen its export growth slowed by weak economies in other Asian countries. **********United States officials acknowledged during a news conference conducted by video hookup in Beijing that the restrictions, scheduled to take effect in 90 days, would cause pain for Chinese business -- and for American importers as well. But they said that when Agriculture Department inspectors found the beetles boring through maple trees in suburban Chicago neighborhoods this summer, they felt compelled to act. **********''We are very concerned,'' Dr. Isi A. Siddiqui, Deputy Assistant Agriculture Secretary, said during the news conference. ''These new regulations are based on sound science and a real threat to U.S. environmental resources.'' **********Government studies estimated $138 billion of damage to the United States economy if the beetles, which have no natural enemies in the United States and cannot be eradicated with pesticides, move to United States forests. **********Dan Glickman, the Agriculture Secretary, said the action should not be seen as a trade sanction, adding that trade between the United States and China had grown to $80 billion this year from $5 billion 15 years ago. **********''Our intention here is not to disrupt trade, but to lock out an unwanted guest that poses a serious economic and environmental threat,'' Mr. Glickman told an audience in Chicago. **********The new regulations require that goods from China be packed in non-wood packing material or wood that has been treated with heat or fumigation to kill the insects. It was not clear whether Chinese exporters would be able to adopt new practices in the next 90 days or how much their costs would rise. **********Although the Chinese Government had no official comment on the ban, Chinese officials have been aware of the looming possibility for weeks and were hoping to avert it. **********''If the ban is imposed, China's exports will suffer, because a considerable amount of our export trade is packed in raw wood,'' one Agriculture Ministry official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. **********The Chinese Government has recently issued billions of dollars in Treasury bonds in an effort to stimulate the economy and insulate it against a slowdown caused by economic crises elsewhere in Asia or the summer's devastating floods in China. Although China's exports are still growing, the rate of growth has slowed this year, and a reduction of its thriving export sales to the United States would be hard to bear. **********Dr. Siddiqui said the United States Government had been discussing the problem with China's quarantine agency for many months, ever since the beetles were discovered in warehouses. He stressed that the United States hoped to cooperate with the Chinese to minimize disruption to trade. **********''Look, this is not an action we wanted to take, but this bug is eating trees in people's back yards and their front yards,'' said one United States official in Beijing. ''Inspectors from the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service are knocking on doors and saying, 'We have to cut down all the trees around your home.' '' **********In the United States, the beetles have so far been detected in wood packing from China in warehouses in 14 states. They have been found free in the environment in and around Chicago as well as in Brooklyn and Amityville, N.Y. **********The beetle was identified as the Asian long-horned beetle by a Cornell University entomologist, Richard Hoebeke, after Brooklyn residents noticed mysterious half-inch holes in their trees. The beetle's larvae drill through trees' bark into the wood, where they undergo metamorphosis into large black beetles with bright white spots and long elegant antennas. **********In Brooklyn, as in three subsequent infestations, inspectors had to order the destruction of all affected trees, since there is currently no other way to control the pests. **********United States officials disagreed somewhat over just how much of China's exports were packed in untreated wood, with estimates ranging from 25 percent to more than 90 percent, and on how difficult it would be for Chinese to adjust to the new requirements. **********Ma Zhongmei, an official at the export department of the North China Air Transportation Company in Beijing, said about one-third of her company's customers packed goods in raw wood. She added that this sort of packing was most commonly used for high-value items, like large machines and factory equipment. **********''These customers could have used plywood, but they chose raw wood to reduce cost,'' she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/19/busin.snippet: Analysis of Justice Department's carefully honed antitrust suit against Microsoft Corp, which is likely to be watershed in setting ground rules of competition in digital age and guidelines for Government intervention in high-technology economy; Go...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/19/busin.print_headline: U.S. V. MICROSOFT: THE CASE; Where Fine Lines Blur
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/19/busin.body_text: **********The Government explained its landmark antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation today as a principled defense of the time-tested, bedrock values of capitalism, protecting consumer choice and economic competition from the predatory assault of a modern monopolist. **********Standing before a battery of television cameras and lights, Joel I. Klein, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division, described the case at times in business-as-usual terms. The principles, he insisted, were clear-cut; the remedies asked of the court were limited, and the theories behind the case were standard antitrust doctrine. **********The Government's suit is aggressive in that it seeks to apply the Sherman Antitrust Act, enacted before the turn of the century, to millennium technologies. Even so, said Carl Shapiro, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley and a former senior Justice Department official, it asks the court to take more of a next step than a giant leap in jurisprudence. ''The suit is carefully crafted to push the law a little perhaps,'' Mr. Shapiro said, ''but not so much that a court is being asked to embrace sweeping new theories about how antitrust applies to the software industry.'' **********Though carefully honed, the Microsoft case -- whatever the outcome -- seems certain to be a watershed in setting the ground rules of competition in the digital age as well as the guidelines for Government intervention in a high-technology economy. **********The Government sees the Microsoft case as a crucial test of how antitrust enforcement can be applied swiftly and ''surgically,'' in Mr. Klein's words, to protect innovation and competition in the fast-paced business of computer software. **********The Microsoft camp replies not only that it is innocent, but that the Government fundamentally misunderstands the facts of economic life in its industry -- and thus is running a grave risk of hobbling a dynamic part of the economy. **********Yes, the company says, competitors may suffer from its business practices, such as bundling software for browsing the Internet into its Windows operating system, but those practices also result in improved products that benefit consumers. **********The Government, Microsoft insists, is mistakenly bringing an industrial-era mind-set to a fluid, fast-moving field of the future. Microsoft's operating system, the central nervous system of a computer, has changed dramatically, adding dozens of new features over the years to make computers easier to use. All Windows' features, from point-and-click icons to software for sending faxes from a personal computer, were once sold as separate products. **********The line between what is in the operating system and what is a separate product, says William H. Gates, Microsoft's founder and chairman, changes every couple of years, and the borderline is elusive because it is all merely a collection of the electronic 1's and 0's of computer code. The software industry, Mr. Gates believes, is different. **********''This is a war between two competing philosophies,'' said Robert Litan, a former senior Justice Department official and the director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution. ''It's very difficult to predict which philosophy is going to win.'' **********The legal battle, analysts predict, will more likely be blitzkrieg than the slow trench warfare of the last big antitrust case the Government brought in the computer industry -- the 13-year suit against I.B.M., which the Justice Department abandoned as technologically irrelevant in 1982. **********The Government's suit does not try to block the shipment of Microsoft's next-generation operating system, Windows 98, which the company released to computer manufacturers today and which is to reach store shelves in June. **********But to try to level the current competitive field, while it pursues its antitrust suit, the Government filed a request for a preliminary injunction. **********In seeking the injunction, the Justice Department is asking a United States district judge to require Microsoft to either remove its Internet Explorer browser from Windows, or include the browser of its main rival, the Netscape Communications Corporation. (The states' suit asks that Microsoft be forced to include a third Web browser of its choice unless Internet Explorer is removed.) **********The proposed injunction also seeks new freedom for personal computer makers by giving them the right to install their own main screen that consumers see first when they turn on their computers. Today, Microsoft has control over the main screen -- which is important because it is viewed as a gateway from which people gain access to Internet shopping, news and entertainment. **********Tactically, legal experts say, the preliminary-injunction phase of the confrontation may well decide the Microsoft case. A ruling on the Justice Department's request for an injunction will likely be made in six weeks or so. If the Government wins, it is not expected to require a product recall of Windows 98, since the remedies involve allowing PC makers to remove or alter its software. **********Whichever side wins, the other side is sure to appeal -- with an appellate verdict likely to come within six months. At that point, experts say, the fast-moving nature of the software industry will surely shape the legal strategy, since six months is almost a product lifetime in software. Any forced product changes would be all but permanent, and if the Government is losing, the high  technology marketplace may have left its suit in the dust. **********''If Justice loses the preliminary injunction, time is on Microsoft's side,'' Mr. Litan of Brookings said. ''If Microsoft loses, the Government has the upper hand.'' **********The Justice Department's case, built around Mr. Klein's theory of a limited if essential role for antitrust intervention, inevitably raises the question of whether it goes far enough. Even if the Government wins its case, skeptics argue, a victory may well be toothless, doing little to loosen Microsoft's tight grip on computing. Indeed, some analysts say that anything short of a trust-busting-style breakup of Microsoft would likely have little effect. **********''The political support isn't there in this round, but if the Government is really going to create a competitive environment, it is eventually going to have to split up Microsoft as it did with Standard Oil,'' said Gary Reback, a Silicon Valley lawyer who has worked for Microsoft rivals. **********When asked if he might consider more drastic measures in the future, Mr. Klein ruled nothing out. Yet he emphasized that the goal of the Government's actions was not to insure the success of Microsoft's competitors. The Government, Mr. Klein said, is merely trying to open the door to some innovative company that might become the next Microsoft, rather than hobble the incumbent. **********''Nothing we are doing here will or should prevent Microsoft from innovating or competing on the merits,'' Mr. Klein said. ''What cannot be tolerated -- and what antitrust laws forbid -- is the barrage of illegal, anticompetitive practices that Microsoft uses to destroy its rivals and to avoid competition.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/07/world.snippet: British Government gives permission for a Protestant parade past Catholic area in Belfast one day after banning another group from marching through a Catholic area of Portadown; says further ban would have inflamed passions among pro-British Prote...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/07/world.main_headline: British to Allow March, This One in Belfast
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/07/world.print_headline: British to Allow March, This One in Belfast
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/07/world.body_text: **********A day after a Protestant Orange Order parade was blocked from marching through a Catholic neighborhood, the British Parades Commission reversed two earlier decisions today and gave permission for another Protestant march to parade past a Catholic area. **********The commission chairman, Alistair Graham, said that allowing the order to march past the Lower Ormeau Road in Belfast next Monday should not be seen as a tradeoff to help balance the decision banning the march Sunday in the Drumcree area of Portadown. **********A further ban, he said, would have risked inflaming passions among pro-British Protestant loyalists who already feel aggrieved at what they see as the authorities' eagerness to placate the Catholics. **********''We cannot ignore the importance of perceptions in Northern Ireland,'' Mr. Graham said at a news conference, ''and there is now a clear emerging sense of deep hurt amongst loyalists, which arises from our decisions to reroute.'' **********''This is in danger of spilling over into a serious law-and-order situation which is harmful to both communities,'' he added. **********After two nights of sporadic violence over the Drumcree ban, however, many people here considered the decision an attempt to mollify the Protestants and a bid to head off possible new protests. **********Officials and experts said the decision was a weak, if not disingenuous, attempt to make the Government appear evenhanded, alternating permissions and denials to weaken opposition. In Ulster, pleasing one side usually outrages the other. **********The decison against the Drumcree Protestants produced Protestant violence; the decision in favor of the Protestants next Monday is also expected to produce demonstrations, this time by Catholics. **********A spokesman for residents of the Ormeau Road, John Gormley, said the Catholic community would challenge the commission's ruling in court, arguing that it had not met the legal guidelines set down for the Orange marches. **********The experts said the decision was unlikely to defuse the sitation at Drumcree, or end the fear that the violence endangers the peace effort. Many feel that the most optimistic scenario is that the inevitable public disorder in the next week will fade, permitting the new Northern Ireland Assembly to resume its work when it reconvenes in September. The least optimistic would be Protestant unionist members' resignation from the new assembly, which would vitiate the institution and raise the likelihood of resumed sectarian killing. **********The Belfast march, which has twice been banned by the commission in the last year, will be one of about 500 parades to celebrate the victory of the Protestant William of Orange over his Catholic father-in-law, King James II, at the Battle of the Boyne in 1690. **********Most Catholics find the parades offensive and triumphalist. Protestants say they are a matter of freedom of assembly, a basic right. **********The province was calm today, but tonight Protestants in Belfast continued their violent reaction, the police said. Most of the incidents involved rioters throwing gasoline bombs at the police. There were no injuries. A police spokesman said at midnight, ''It's not as bad as last night, but the night is young.'' **********People worried about the effects of sustained violence on the peace effort, which nevertheless appeared to be moving ahead last week with the start of work by the new assembly. It is to enact the peace agreement approved in a referendum in May. **********''I'm afraid the violence will break up the whole thing,'' said Pauline Hegney, a Catholic mother of four, whose husband was shot dead seven years ago by Protestant paramilitary forces. ''I don't understand it,'' she added. ''Why should people want to march down streets where they have no supporters?'' Referring to a Protestant thoroughfare in West Belfast, she added, ''I wouldn't want to march down the Shankill.'' **********But Andy Wood, a political consultant and former information director for the British Government here, said of the violence: ''I don't think it puts the peace process in crisis. They are separate matters. But it shows just how deep the fault line runs in parts of Northern Ireland society.'' **********Police and political leaders appealed today for restraint, and for an end to the disorders caused by Protestants angry at the British Government's decision to deploy hundreds of combat-ready British troops and armed policemen to block the 191-year-old annual parade down a street in Drumcree, Portadown, 35 miles west of here. **********Several hundred Orangemen camped out overnight in Drumcree, sleeping in tents decorated with Union Jacks and vowing to stay until they received permission for their march. They said that they would remain peaceful, that the violent demonstrators were not Orangemen and that Orangemen were not provoking the violence. **********On Sunday night the Orangemen were regaled by the Rev. Ian Paisley, the hard-line Protestant leader known for his open anti-Catholicism and opposition to the peace effort and the assembly, which is to give Catholics more power. He did not advocate violence, but he promised the campers they would win. **********Their mood this morning was jovial as they posed for photographers and cameramen and answered reporters' questions. Two years ago, in a similar dispute at Drumcree, Protestants rioted for four days after the British Government banned the march. The riots forced the Government to reverse its decision and allow the march. The reversal in turn provoked Catholic rioting. **********Today the Drumcree Orangemen were saying that they would stay in the field until they got permission to march. **********Earlier, the protesters blocked dozens of roads, hijacked and burned cars and fought several batttles with the police. **********Rioters in a neighborhood near the Belfast city center threw flaming gasoline bombs at the police, who pushed the attackers back by firing plastic bullets. There was only one serious injury in the provincewide disturbances. An inspector's skull was fractured with a brickbat in Londonderry. **********But the Protestants stayed largely in their own neighborhoods; there were no serious clashes with Catholics. The police said the level of violence on Sunday night was much lower than it had been two years ago, during the last Drumcree crisis. **********Mr. Wood, the political consultant, said ''What we need is four or five days of the world's cheapest policeman -- rain.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/27/busin.snippet: Furby, animated stuffed animal with an attitude, is hot toy of this Christmas season, generating out-of-the door lines at any store that has any left in stock; Michael Glazer, chief executive of Kay-Bee Toys, retail chain, says his stores are sell...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/27/busin.main_headline: Stuffed Animals With Attitude May Spur Modest Rise in Toy Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/27/busin.print_headline: Stuffed Animals With Attitude May Spur Modest Rise in Toy Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/27/busin.body_text: **********Furby? Fuhgeddaboutit. **********A stuffed animal with attitude, Furby has already been turned by marketing buzz and a media blitz into the hot toy of the Christmas season. It is generating out-the-door lines at any store bold enough to admit it has a few in stock. And most parents trying to satisfy the demands of a teary-eyed 9-year-old are going away disappointed. **********''We've never had Furby in our stores for more than 15 minutes,'' said Michael Glazer, chief executive of Kay-Bee Toys, the mall-based retail chain owned by the Consolidated Stores Corporation. The Furby frenzy even has him taking calls from lots of old friends trying to get their hands on the toy. ''I'm hearing from people that I haven't heard from in years,'' he said. **********Furby is one of the few sure-fire hits in what promises to be a good, but probably not great, toy shopping period from now through the end of the year. **********The expected blockbusters include Mattel's talking Bounce Around Tigger, whose chief redeeming social value is that it gyrates uncontrollably. Toys based on the television shows ''Blue's Clues'' and ''Teletubbies'' as well as those tied to the ''Rugrats'' show on Nickelodeon, with its movie tie-in this year, are also expected to be exceptionally popular. **********A product from the Lego Group that melds technology and tradition is in the mix of potential hot sellers. Lego is rushing to raise output of Lego Mindstorms, the next generation of its classic toy, which combines robotics with building blocks. **********And, of course, Barbie still rules. **********But Furby appears to be in a special class. Tiger Electronics, the unit of Hasbro that makes Furby, said it was on target to sell more than a million of the animated stuffed animals this year, double the number it had expected. The supply, however, is far less than the demand. **********Part of the appeal seems to be that, at $30, Furby is a relatively affordable product that is both snuggly and smart, said Roger Shiffman, president of Tiger. Furby has bug eyes, big ears and an annoying need for attention. It speaks an imaginary language called Furbish but eventually learns English. That is when it begins to act like an antsy 4-year-old, laughing when tickled, singing jingles and even sneezing in your face. ''It's a lot of toy for the money,'' Mr. Shiffman said. **********But can the short supply of Furbys and other popular playthings really be because children are all making out the same wish lists? Or could it be that toy makers are deliberately not making enough to stir up an even greater frenzy? **********The manufacturers say unexpected consumer interest, whipped up by the media and advertising, is to blame. It is not that different from what happened in the early 1980's with Cabbage Patch dolls and with Tickle Me Elmo two years ago after Rosie O'Donnell plugged it on her television talk show. **********Unlike those shortages, though, consumers willing to spend a lot more have an alternative this year: an on-line auction site, Ebay (www.ebay.com), has been selling Furbys for as much as triple the retail price. **********Still, for all the interest in a few hot products, toy companies are only expecting modest gains in sales this season. **********Toys ''R'' Us, the nation's largest toy retailer, has the most on the line. The company is struggling to remake itself after turning in consistently dismal financial results for much of the year. The problem? Shoppers have increasingly become frustrated with the mammoth and often chaotic stores. And many have simply driven past Toys ''R'' Us stores to do one-stop-shopping at Wal-Mart or Dayton Hudson's Target. **********To fight back, Toys ''R'' Us has cut costs, in part by paring inventory, which has meant smaller orders to manufacturers. Another problem across the industry is that many of the most promising items have been slow to hit the market this year. **********A decade ago, about 70 percent of the industry's revenues came from holiday selling. And while half of the business still comes in the critical fourth quarter, the industry has been aggressively trying to get people to buy more playthings during other times of the year. **********In the last couple of years the strategy has worked well, as companies sold Tickle Me Elmo, virtual pets, Beanie Babies and other top-selling toys all year long. Keeping consumers interested in toys in the summer and spring enables companies to more accurately gauge how their year is shaping up before heading into the holiday. That, in turn, allows them to adjust promotions and supplies at crunch time. **********But this year, perhaps because of difficulties among Asian suppliers suffering from financial stress, production has been slow, which has once again tightened the selling period. So that kink, along with some product shortages, may make for spotty industrywide sales. ''Up to this point we're really kind of break even,'' said Terri Bartlett, a spokeswoman for Toy Manufacturers of America, a trade group. ''With the holiday season, we are expecting it to kind of pull us through.'' **********The industry expects to turn in a modest 2 percent sales gain over last year's revenue of $22.5 billion, according to the toy group. ''I think the season is going to end up looking good,'' Ms. Bartlett said. ''I don't know that it's going to surmount what we had to face from the rest of the year.'' **********The range of nifty products certainly helps. And the industry should benefit not only from the healthy economy but also from the fact that companies are increasingly coming out with toys that appeal to a wider age range and both genders. Typically toys grab the attention of boys or girls, but not both, and appeal to youngsters in a narrow age range. **********That is still mostly the case. The wildly popular dolls based on the ''Blue's Clues'' and ''Teletubbies'' television programs still appeal almost exclusively to very young children. And Mattel's timeless toy, G.I. Joe, is still mainly a boy's toy while its Barbie doll is still a girl's best friend. **********But many more toys are bridging the gaps, which lets toy companies draw from a larger group. Beanie Babies, still much in demand, appeal to girls from kindergarten to junior high school. Even their parents are sometimes shelling out as much as $1,000 to collect ''retired'' characters. And Lego says fathers are buying its updated building blocks for themselves as well as their children of both sexes. **********The new version also expands the appeal to older children, particularly boys, the company said. Lego Mindstorms allow users to build robots and vehicles that will move and follow commands programmed into a hand-held electronic brain. **********''Adding this technology to the product maintains its core value but makes the product more relevant for older kids,'' said John Dion, a spokesman for Lego. The appeal for adults? ''A lot of guys grew up loving Legos and now they are really into computers and this combines both their interests,'' Mr. Dion said. **********There are some drawbacks to this product, however. Some potential buyers may get sticker shock at the $200 price tag. It also requires a computer to program the nerve center that brings the toys to life. **********While product appeal may be changing as toys develop brains, purchasing patterns are also evolving. More people are shopping at discount stores these days, and those chains are expected once again to set off fierce price wars to lure even more parents away from traditional toy retailers. **********Wal-Mart, Kmart and Target ''are using toys to get people in their stores and these stores get so much traffic to begin with that Toys ''R'' Us is finding that hard to combat,'' said Gene Gilligan, executive editor of Playthings magazine, a toy industry publication. **********On-line toy sellers are trying to broaden their appeal as well, playing up the ease of point-and-click shopping. Etoys (www.etoys.com), an on-line toy seller, has taken a hit at large retail competitors with a new television advertising campaign that pokes fun at the frustrations of shopping in stores. **********''The first thing the commercials do is remind people that stores are not fun and then it reminds them that there is an alternative,'' said Toby Lenk, chief executive of Etoys, a unit of Idealab. **********Etoys also says it has an edge over traditional stores because in addition to the widely known toys, it offers specialty items that the big retailers do not bother to stock. This year, for example, Etoys has had a run on a brew-your-own root beer kit from a tiny company called Copernicus. Special items like this are ''selling neck and neck with the big guys,'' said Jane Saltzman, vice president of merchandising at Etoys. **********Some categories that remain flat are board games and action figures. And some of last year's hot sellers are also beginning to lose their luster. Virtual pets are a bit of a yawn this year, and youngsters finally seem to have grown weary of some of those wiggle-and-giggle toys. **********Enjoy the respite. It won't last.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/30/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS; Most Borrowers in U.S. Can Expect to Benefit
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/30/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve's decision yesterday to lower interest rates for the first time since January 1996 should translate into lower borrowing rates on many consumer loans and keep mortgage rates for home purchases and refinancings below 7 percent at least through the end of the year, economists said. **********The reduction of a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.25 percent, in the target for the Federal funds rate was smaller than had been widely anticipated. But the impact is enough to keep 30-year fixed-rate mortgages below 7 percent in 1998 and possibly through 1999, said Robert Barr, a senior economist at Fannie Mae, the Congressionally chartered private company that helps finance mortgages. **********The Mortgage Bankers Association of America, a trade group, has an even more optimistic forecast, estimating that rates could drop as low as 6.25 percent before the year ends. **********Mortgage rates are at their lowest levels in a generation but have not fallen as much as yields on Treasury securities, the benchmarks for calculating rate trends. **********One reason is that strong investor demand for Treasuries as a safe haven from turbulent markets has pushed those yields lower. **********The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was about 6.64 percent in the week ended Sept. 25, the 15th consecutive week of rates below 7 percent, according to Freddie Mac, the mortgage company. That level was 2.07 percentage points higher than the 4.57 percent yield on 10-year Treasury securities. On average, 30-year fixed mortgage rates are usually about 1.5 percentage points higher than the yield on 10-year Treasury notes. **********That gap could narrow as Treasury rates stabilize near historic lows and mortgage rates slip, Mr. Barr said. **********This year, new mortgages for home purchases and refinancings are expected to hit a record $1.4 trillion, said Brian Carey, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association. **********After the Fed's move yesterday, Norwest Bank in Minneapolis cut its prime lending rate, and others were expected to follow. The prime rate is a benchmark for other consumer and corporate loans, like credit cards, auto loans and small-business loans. The prime rate, 8.5 percent at most banks, should fall by at least a quarter-point, analysts estimate. Banks may also cut the interest rates they pay on savings accounts and certificates of deposit. **********On average, savings accounts paid interest of about 2.17 percent in April, according to Bank Rate Monitor, a research firm in North Palm Beach, Fla., that reports savings account rates twice a year. One-year certificates of deposit at banks paid an average rate of 4.69 percent as of Monday. **********Consumers with such loans as adjustable-rate mortgages and home equity lines of credit tied to the prime rate could see the impact of lower rates within the next few months, said Keith Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a financial research firm in Butler, N.J.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/04/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; FORT JAMES TO CUT 2,500 JOBS IN STREAMLINING
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/04/busin.body_text: **********The Fort James Corporation, the paper and consumer-products maker, said yesterday that it would eliminate 2,500 positions, or 8 percent of its work force, in an effort to streamline its operations in North America and Europe. The company said it would take a charge of $1.53 a diluted share, which would cause it to post a fourth-quarter loss of $1.46 a share. Severance costs connected with the layoffs will total more than $100 million. Last month, Fort James, based in Richmond, said it would close two tissue mills and eliminate about 520 jobs because of high operating costs. The company said production from the mills, which are in Carthage, N.Y., and Ashland, Wis., would be transferred to more modern plants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/13/busin.main_headline: The Neighborhood Business; Geocities' Cyberworld is Vibrant, but Can It Make Money?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/13/busin.print_headline: The Neighborhood Business; Geocities' Cyberworld is Vibrant, but Can It Make Money?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/13/busin.body_text: **********Rick Brown did not set out to be anyone's hero. Simply wanting to learn a little more about the Internet, he signed on two years ago with Geocities, a service that gives people free space to publish their own pages on the World Wide Web. **********Some people use their Geocities sites to show the world their children, their poetry or their model train collection. Mr. Brown built a tribute to Monty Python, the British television comedy troupe. **********His Web site started slowly, but Mr. Brown, 34, a grocery store merchandiser who lives in Bridgeport, Conn., kept adding Python memorabilia, sound clips, scripts and pictures. Soon the site took on a life of its own, and Geocities began promoting it as one its ''landmark'' pages. **********By June, when he had a falling-out with the service over a promotion effort, his site had attracted more than 100,000 visitors. **********Mr. Brown's experience exemplifies the paradox of Geocities: The service is attracting an impressive and growing number of members and visitors, yet as it moves toward a public stock offering, it is struggling to formulate a credible image as a viable business. **********The founder of Geocities, David Bohnett, says that the sheer scale of the service's operation and popularity would have been unimaginable when he  started experimenting with the Internet in 1994. As of June, more than two million members had created personal Web sites consisting of more than 15 million pages about nearly every imaginable topic. **********Organized into 40 virtual ''neighborhoods'' at www.geocities.com, these sites add up to the third-most-visited domain on the Web, attracting 14 million viewers in April, the most recent month for which figures are available. **********The audience for Geocities has been growing at twice the speed of the average Web site, according to Media Metrix, which measures traffic on the Internet. **********Now the company, based in Santa Monica, Calif., is going public. The investment bankers promoting the initial public offering hope investors will be drawn to the potential of Geocities' vast audience and to the low overhead of publishing a site created by millions of volunteers. **********They also hope that investors will not be discouraged by financial statements that suggest only the weakest vital signs of a going concern. **********Of course, as the company begins its road show over the next few weeks, it will probably talk of many plans to build its audience, to sell more advertising and to extract fees from at least some members for certain services. **********But it is not clear whether the service can build its business without alienating its members. For example, it was a promotional effort known as a watermark that set off the feud with Mr. Brown. **********The watermark is a translucent image of the Geocities logo that hovers in the lower right hand corner of the pages of its members, like the  ''ghost'' logos that identify television channels. The watermark's purpose is to encourage people entering one Geocities site to try other sites on the service. **********But many Geocities members complained that the watermark made their pages load more slowly on visitors' browsers, cluttered their screens and obfuscated links. **********So using the very tools that Geocities had given them to build their Web sites, some members created anti-watermark pages, chat rooms and mailing lists. When Mr. Brown turned the front page of his Monty Python site black in protest, Geocities stopped featuring his page. Other members got wind of this and  turned his case into a rallying point for the anti-watermark campaign. **********The whole situation, Mr. Brown said, reminds him of Monty Python's infamous sketch in which a pet store patron tries to return a dead parrot. ''The customer has a valid complaint, and the management uses every trick available to avoid facing that fact,'' Mr. Brown said. **********Such are the promise and the peril that come with trying to build a business by giving a megaphone to millions of people. Geocities is one of a growing number of ''on-line communities'' -- sites or services that allow people to publish Web pages and communicate with one another by chatting, sending E-mail and so forth. Such community sites now make up 6 of the 20 most-popular sites on the Web. Geocities is the largest, followed in descending popularity by Tripod, Anglefire, Hotmail, Switchboard and Xoom. **********Some advertisers are wary of placing their product next to chat that as likely as not will turn sexual -- or on a page that today is an affable tribute to Monty Python and tomorrow is a diatribe against the host service. **********''What gives us a nervous twitch is the fear that if a user has a bad experience they will think negatively on our clients,'' said Jonathan Adams, a media buyer for Ogilvy One, the on-line agency for Ogilvy & Mather. ''Even if 99.9 percent of the sites are squeaky clean, it's that tenth of 1 percent that will wind up in the C.E.O.'s lap.'' **********Mr. Bohnett, who has championed the right to free expression of minorities as a board member of the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, says that playing censor in chief for two million people weighs heavily on him. **********''A lot of what I'm doing has to do with being gay and part of a minority that has not had an equal voice in society,'' Mr. Bohnett said in an interview in March. ''But we have to balance freedom of expression with commercial viability. Otherwise all of this will go away.'' **********Mr. Bohnett has declined to comment on the watermark or any other matter recently because Geocities is in a required ''quiet period'' related to its planned stock offering. In May, Mr. Bohnett hired Thomas R. Evans, the publisher of U.S. News & World Report, to be Geocities' chief executive. Mr. Bohnett remains chairman. **********The impulse that created Geocities was more expressive than commercial. In the spring of 1994, Mr. Bohnett took a break from a career in software marketing after his longtime companion died of AIDS. Intrigued by the Internet, Mr. Bohnett and a friend, John Renzer, bought a $5,000 computer powerful enough to serve up Web pages and published a little site with a live picture of the Intersection of Hollywood and Vine and a few other locales. **********Within a year, they seized on the idea of giving users free home pages and organizing them into ''virtual'' cities, arranged loosely by topic. Thus, when a new ''homesteader,'' in Geocities' lingo, wants to set up a page, he or she selects a lot in a particular city. Those who are interested in cars move into Motor City; jazz fans choose Bourbon Street. **********The most heavily populated of the 40 cities are Silicon Valley, about computers, and South Beach, a vast spring break-style party. But the most popular destination among visiting Web surfers is Hollywood, the home of most of the fan pages, including Mr. Brown's Monty Python page. **********Most of the sites are simple, even hokey affairs, offering photos of pets, love poems, pie recipes and other matter that lived between the refrigerator and a magnet in the past. But some are much more elaborate. **********''If you're a bank clerk by day and a Smashing Pumpkins fan by night, this gives you an opportunity to express yourself,'' Mr. Bohnett said. **********Once they expose themselves to the world, Geocities members closely watch the count of how many visitors their sites attract, and they express glee at receiving an E-mail from a far-off place. **********''I was a ham radio operator in high school,'' Mr. Bohnett said. ''It was exciting to collect postcards from people you talked to around the world. That is a lot of what the Web is about.'' **********Even more surprising, people started sending E-mail to their virtual neighbors to comment on their sites and offer help. **********Mr. Rezner, now the company's chief technical officer, said, ''People actually go out of their way to become block captains, to join welcome wagons and to monitor chat rooms so they can have a neighborhood that is safe and clean.'' **********Indeed, Geocities now has 1,500 volunteer community leaders who help other members and watch out for offensive behavior. **********''The community leader program is the perfect environment for folks with a 'helper complex,' '' said Sherri Kaufmann, a housewife in rural Minnesota. She originally joined Geocities to show off pictures of her 10 children. Now she spends an hour a day on the computer in her kitchen watching over her corner of the ''Picket Fence'' neighborhood. **********''We truly are a community of neighbors who help each other out,'' Ms. Kaufmann said. ''I have made many friends here. Recently, my father became ill, and I was overwhelmed by the letters from the friends I have made at Geocities.'' **********But even more powerful than the common human urge to help a neighbor, however virtual, is the sexual urge. Much of the time of the volunteers and of Geocities' small staff is spent rooting out pornography that sprouts constantly on members' pages, as well as other illegal or objectionable material. **********''We've gone through seemingly endless debates about content guidelines,'' Mr. Bohnett said. **********And, still, its rules are uncomfortable compromises: Political opinion is O.K.; hate speech is not. You can have a page about sex but no pictures of naked people, unless they are classic artworks or on pages about nudism as a life style. Most members can criticize Geocities on their pages somewhat, but community leaders cannot. **********Similarly, Geocities has been in a constant battle with its members about how much of their pages it controls for advertising and promotion. Other protests arose when the service began superimposing advertisements over members' pages. **********Geocities has not been able to fill the ad space that it does have. Last year, the company had only six advertisers. Now, after a reorganization of its sales force, it says it has more than 100. But its members' pages are only about 25 percent sold. **********Now, with a new management team drawn from larger media companies, Geocities is trying to find ways to turn its audience into cash. It has tinkered with the design of the site to create more places for ads and to keep surfers longer at Geocities, especially on those pages that attract ad rates with a high cost for every thousand visitors, like pages about cars and other expensive items. **********And it is coming up with other sources of revenue. There are deals with on-line merchants like Amazon.com, which will sell books recommended on member pages, paying commissions to both the member and Geocities. There are services that for a fee let the most dedicated members build more ambitious and complex sites. And for those who want to set up business in cyberspace, it has started a program called Geoshops to display on-line storefronts for which it charges monthly fees starting at $25 a month. **********Taken together, Geocities hopes all these initiatives will quadruple its revenue from $4.6 million last year to a range of $20 million to $25 million this year, Mr. Bohnett said in March. Stephen L. Hansen, the company's chief financial officer, said in March that he expected Geocities to break even next year. **********But this rush to make money is leaving some members behind. **********''Right now, I feel they are pushing commercialism a little too much with all the home pages inundated with ads and links to ads,'' said Sharyn Gleaves, who has built an elaborate site devoted to drumming around campfires. **********Indeed, Mr. Brown says he is about to move his Monty Python site to another service. **********Yet Mr. Rezner, the co-founder, argues that making money is just another aspect of Geocities' virtual vision. **********''Everything in the real world should be mirrored in Geocities,'' he said. ''What do you do? You go to bars. You talk to people. You find a date. But you also go shopping, and you have a job.'' **********And, for that matter, there are virtual protests, boycotts and heroes as well.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/11/busin.snippet: Article on bargains that can be found among emerging-market closed-end mutual funds (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/11/busin.main_headline: In Closed-End Funds, a Fire Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/11/busin.print_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; In Closed-End Funds, a Fire Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/11/busin.body_text: **********WITH the embers still smoldering from the financial-market firebombings of the third quarter, prospective investors in closed-end funds might want to borrow a few lessons from junkyard dogs and other naturally skilled scavengers: Venture forth, sniff around and, perhaps, bite. **********The adventurous will inevitably be drawn to what appears to be the wasteland of emerging-market closed-end funds, which endured some of the worst of the destruction. Many have fallen by more than half from what were already low levels; some are trading for a few dollars or less a share. **********For anyone who bought these funds years ago, when prices were high and Wall Street gushed about the coming boom in Asia, Russia and Latin America, buying may seem less tempting now that the economies there have fallen so steeply. But if you missed the peak, opportunity may be staring at you. **********''This is where I think the most money will be made over the next 12 months -- the most money in the closed-end fund universe, anyway,'' said Thomas J. Herzfeld, chairman  of an investment advisory firm in Miami that tracks closed-end funds. ''They've just been pummeled. Fifty, 60 and 70 percent losses are not unusual.'' **********These funds, which issue a fixed number of shares that are traded like those of ordinary companies, have often fallen much further than the underlying values of their holdings have. This divergence is especially wide in Latin America, where stock prices as measured by the Morgan Stanley Capital International index for the region have fallen 45 percent this year -- most of that in the third quarter. **********But the gap helps create a new opportunity, Mr. Herzfeld and others say. Eventually, the shares and net asset values should converge. **********Buying shares of a fund that is trading at a 25 percent discount to its net asset value, for example, is like buying a $100 stock for $75. Many of these funds, however, are trading at even greater discounts. **********Closed-end funds can trade at discounts for various reasons -- shaky  economic fundamentals, bad management, poor performance. But the severe declines in stocks have contributed to some of the widest discounts in years, especially among Latin American equity funds. **********Mr. Herzfeld cited the Latin American Discovery fund, whose discount grew from 2 percent in March to 21.7 percent at the end of September. The Latin American Equity fund behaved similarly; its discount widened from 15 percent in February to 29.9 percent at the end of September. **********One reason for the selloff is that many investors panicked after Russia defaulted on its debts in August. Sensing a spreading malaise, they dumped shares no matter where their funds were invested. **********''No one really knows where the bottom is, but there's no question that discounts have gotten pretty deep,'' said Gregg Wolper, international funds editor at Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago. ''That's why more of the bargains are in Latin America.'' **********Others say funds invested in central Europe were also unfairly pummeled. Douglas Beck, an emerging-markets strategist at Merrill Lynch, is looking at funds with stakes in Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, which he saw as likely to recover even if Russia kept foundering: ''I think it's time for investors to dip their toes back into certain markets. What we're telling clients is,  regardless of what discounts do, we're making the assumption that discounts are close to an extreme. If you're looking to gain exposure now, the ability to purchase a diverse pool at a 20 to 25 percent discount is a tremendous opportunity.'' **********He said he was looking at two funds that do not have exposure to Russia: Central European Equity, which is 30 percent invested in Germany, and Central European Value, heavily invested in the Czech Republic. Both are trading at discounts of substantially more than 20 percent. **********OF course, many people doubt that the worst is over. Some closed-end fund strategists say they remain extremely wary about Latin America partly because it is unclear whether countries like Brazil, Venezuela and Mexico will need to devalue their currencies or require International Monetary Fund bailouts. **********''There's good reason to feel the contagion has seeped into Latin America,'' said Michael T. Porter, a closed-end fund analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. ''If you feel it's a question of when, not if, the currencies come under great pressure, then a 30 percent discount in closed-end funds today may not look so big.'' **********Mr. Porter said he was looking at emerging-market bond funds; although the shares of these funds are not trading at steep discounts -- some are even trading at premiums -- their yields are relatively high. **********''In a slow-growth global environment, I might want to take bond funds relative to equities,'' he said. **********As examples of possible buying opportunities, he offered the Morgan Stanley Emerging Markets Debt fund, which was yielding nearly 15 percent at the end of September, and Templeton Emerging Markets Income, yielding 13.6 percent. The Morgan Stanley fund has a discount of 23.2 percent, and the Templeton fund has a premium of 1.4 percent. **********Mr. Porter argued that even if countries represented in these funds devalued their currencies, the damage would be minimal because much of the debt held by the funds is denominated in dollars. But stocks in equity funds are denominated in local currencies and can tumble in value if there is a devaluation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/23/busin.snippet: Rich compensation package for three top executives of Computer Associates International Inc has hurt company's second-quarter earnings and contributed to large selloff; on volume of more than 25 million shares, stock lost more than 30 percent of i...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/23/busin.main_headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; At Computer Associates, Stock Option Plan Comes Home to Roost
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/23/busin.print_headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; At Computer Associates, Stock Option Plan Comes Home to Roost
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/23/busin.body_text: **********An avalanche of selling hit the stock of Computer Associates International Inc. yesterday, after the company announced late Tuesday that unexpected tremors from the Asian economic crisis had reduced its sales expectations. **********On extremely heavy volume of more than 25 million shares, the company's stock lost more than 30 percent of its market value, closing at $39.50, down $17.50. That represented a loss of $9.56 billion for investors in the company, which is based in Islandia, N.Y. **********Computer Associates derives only about 5 percent of its revenues from customers in Asia, so news of Asia-related sales weak ness clearly caught Wall Street by surprise. But the reaction may have been exacerbated because the bad news came just two months after Charles B. Wang, the chairman and chief executive, and two other top executives received a remarkable $1.1 billion stock grant that wound up costing the company about $675 million. **********''It left a bitter taste in the mouth,'' James C. Mendelson, managing director of Soundview Financial Group, in Stamford, Conn., said. ''Clearly, some portion of the selloff is an emotional reaction.'' **********The company included the warning about its sales prospects for the next six months in an announcement of its financial results for three months ended June 30. The report was released after the market closed on Tuesday, after which senior executives participated in a conference call with analysts. During that call, the executives explained that many of their big multinational customers seemed to be expecting slower growth in their own businesses primarily because of the problems in Asia. Those customers, who also have to deal with the Year 2000 adjustments, seemed to be holding back on major software purchases, the executives said. The analysts swiftly scaled back their expectations for Computer Associates' full-year earnings by about 7 percent. **********That bad news swamped the good news that the company's basic income had been slightly above expectations in the most recent quarter. With analysts expecting earnings of 33 cents a share, the company reported operating profits of 34 cents a share, or $194.2 million, up almost 25 percent from the $155.8 million the company earned in the comparable period last year. **********However, those respectable quarterly results were buried by the effects of the $675 million write-off necessary to finance the stock grants to Mr. Wang and to Sanjay Kumar, the president, and Russell M. Artzt, the executive vice president. Because of the write-off, the company reported a loss of $480.8 million, or 87 cents a share, for the quarter. **********The compensation plan, approved by shareholders in 1995, entitled the three executives to collect substantial grants of stock as soon as the company's shares had traded above a set price, $53.33 a share, for 60 trading days -- a milestone that was reached on May 21. **********As a result, Mr. Wang was awarded 12.15 million shares, which at the time were worth $669.8 million; Mr. Kumar received 6.075 million shares, which were worth $334.9 million, and Mr. Artzt received 2.025 million shares, which were worth $111.6 million. The total package was valued at $1.1 billion before taxes, but the executives essentially returned some shares to satisfy income tax obligations, reducing the package to $675 million. **********Restrictions on selling the shares will expire gradually over the next seven years, so the three executives actually suffered as much or more damage yesterday as their fellow shareholders. Mr. Wang, for example, saw the value of his recent stock grant fall by more than $200 million yesterday. **********Graef Crystal, an executive compensation specialist and editor of The Crystal Report, had been extremely critical of Mr. Wang's generous compensation packages even before the recent stock grants were awarded.  Yesterday's news did nothing to soften his opinion, even though the selloff reduced the current value of the stock grants to Mr. Wang. **********''He limped across the finish line, collected his huge stock award, and then suddenly they have just discovered this Asia problem,'' Mr. Crystal said. ''I think we will see lots of lawsuits. This will be like dropping 3,000 pounds of chum into a shark tank.'' **********But even Mr. Crystal said he was surprised at how deeply the stock declined yesterday, and wondered aloud whether Wall Street analysts had simply forgotten about the potential impact of the stock awards on the company's earnings. **********Joseph Farley, a stock analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, dismissed that speculation. ''The compensation plan was well known,'' Mr. Farley said. ''There was no surprise today from people just finding out about the earnings impact.'' **********There may have been some lingering resentment, Mr. Mendelson said. ''There is some bitterness being expressed,'' he said. But Mr. Mendelson defended the company's decision to share its worries about the future with its stockholders. **********''I think it reflects their desire to be as straight with the investment community as they can be,'' he said. With the company's annual stockholders meeting scheduled for Aug. 12, he added: ''It must have been a temptation to say, 'If we postpone the report a few weeks, we won't have to face our shareholders until next year.' But they did not say that.'' **********Mr. Farley remains wary, however. ''Is the selloff overdone? I think we've all got about 5 percent of the information we need to answer that question,'' he said. ''We have a company that has had a long period of very strong revenue momentum and predictability of earnings, and suddenly you are facing some vague, uncertain developments and we don't really know what happened.'' **********The Computer Associates announcement came in tandem with a similar warning from the Hewlett-Packard Company, reinforcing in several analysts' minds the need to look more closely at how vulnerable technology companies are to such secondary effects of the Asian crisis. **********Mr. Crystal pointed out that Institutional Shareholder Services, a company in Bethesda, Md., that advises investors on how to vote on proxy issues, had recommended against approval of the stock-grant plan when it was proposed in 1995. ''But it was approved by investors anyway,'' he said. ''So I guess you could say, stockholders got their comeuppance today.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/22/busin.snippet: Phelps Dodge Corp will eliminate about 680 jobs as it closes two copper mines, in New Mexico and Chile, because of continued low copper prices (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/22/busin.main_headline: PHELPS DODGE TO CLOSE 2 COPPER MINES AND CUT 680 JOBS
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/22/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; PHELPS DODGE TO CLOSE 2 COPPER MINES AND CUT 680 JOBS
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/22/busin.body_text: **********The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the largest United States copper producer, said yesterday that it would eliminate about 680 jobs as it closes two mines, in New Mexico and Chile, because of continued low copper prices. The Phoenix-based company will cut 500 jobs in southwestern New Mexico. It will also immediately close its underground mine in northern Chile, eliminating 180 jobs. The company will have about 7,000 mining employees after the cuts. The cuts will result in a fourth-quarter pretax charge of about $10 million. Shares of Phelps Dodge fell $1.125, to $56.375.
