https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/18/busin.snippet: Interview with Toyota Motor Corp president Hiroshi Okuda, who has black belt in judo and has taken aggressive stance to revitalize company; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/18/busin.main_headline: Black Belt in Market Share Becomes the Goal at Toyota
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/18/busin.print_headline: FIVE QUESTIONS WITH: HIROSHI OKUDA; Black Belt in Market Share Becomes the Goal at Toyota
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/18/busin.body_text: **********IN the three years he has been president of the Toyota Motor Corporation, Hiroshi Okuda has become known as much for his black belt in judo as for his outspoken views and aggressive moves to revitalize the once very conservative automobile maker that the stock market values as Japan's largest publicly traded company. **********His efforts come at an especially trying time for Toyota. The Japanese domestic market, which it dominates, is mired in a long downturn, and the company's most important overseas market, the United States, is showing signs of stalling. **********Interviewed in New York last week, Mr. Okuda sidestepped direct comment on the troubles of the Japanese economy or Government efforts to jump-start it, saying Toyota would pursue its goals regardless. But he said the prospect of tough times ahead has left him open to the idea of a strategic hook-up with an American partner.   SHARON R. KING **********Q. In light of Japan's economic problems, have you rethought your goal of achieving a 40 percent share of the auto market there? **********A. Regardless of the size of the market, our plan to get to a 40 percent domestic market share hasn't changed. Our current share is 39 percent, and for the past two years we have almost gotten there. I still think we can reach 40 percent. But it is going to be difficult. It is best to set a target that you can very likely achieve, but is still difficult to achieve. **********We can solve the problem by introducing new cars. We are probably introducing 12 to 13 different types of cars or vehicles a year. And at the same time, we are also scrapping the older, less successful models. **********To do so will take a large investment of people and resources, but I think the company has the strength of resources to do it. **********In the global market, we are making progress on our original goal of 10 percent, and we now have set a new goal of 15 percent by the year 2010. **********Q. The automobile industry is consolidating in much of the world. Will we see further  penetration of foreign ownership in the Japanese auto industry? Could a whole company be acquired? **********A. That's something that I've been thinking about very much. I think that's quite possible, especially as other currencies strengthen. Although the yen has been strong recently, it has been weak for a long time, and, generally speaking, the stock prices of Japanese automobile companies are low. Therefore, it is possible that an American or other foreign company could acquire one of the weaker Japanese companies. I think that's something that the Japanese auto makers are concerned about, including Toyota. **********Q. For Toyota, could you envision a partnership with an American company, or an American company buying Toyota? **********A. I think there can be two different ways that could work. The first would be an equity acquisition. The second would be in the area of localized technical cooperation. In the manufacture of engines and transmissions, and to develop environmental technologies, we have to make huge capital investments, so cooperation and joint efforts would make sense. Toyota could either provide or procure technology. **********Q. Your company also has an interest in being known as environmentally friendly. Does that goal correlate with some of the larger, less fuel-efficient vehicles that you now produce, like the Lexus line? **********A. First, today's situation is transitional, as new technology replaces old. Second, we must still respond to regional customer tastes as much as possible. For example, in the United States, larger vehicles are more popular. So we work to make our products as clean and efficient as possible, regardless of size. **********Q. In a country where executives are fairly conservative, you stand out. Do you see yourself as a role model? **********A. I don't think so. Everyone is different. But what I can say about Toyota is that before I became president, the company was considered to be very conservative, so I have tried to make us more aggressive. I think our example will be followed by other companies. Companies are being less conservative and that means even more competition, so the more conservative executives might not be around in the future.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/03/busin.snippet: Richard Allen Lester, economist who specialized in wage and labor issues, and dean of faculty emeritus at Princeton University, dies at 89; photo (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/03/busin.main_headline: Prof. Richard Allen Lester, 89, Expert in Wage and Labor Issues
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/03/busin.print_headline: Prof. Richard Allen Lester, 89, Expert in Wage and Labor Issues
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/03/busin.body_text: **********Richard Allen Lester, an economist who specialized in wage and labor issues, and a dean of the faculty, emeritus, at Princeton University, died on Tuesday at his home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 89. **********Professor Lester is known for his basic research in wage determination and minimum wages in the 1940's. One early theory, called the ''range theory of wages,'' offered an alternative to the prevailing view that workers in similar jobs were paid the same wages. Professor Lester said that one implication of his theory was that because wages were indeterminate an increase in the minimum wage would not necessarily result in reduced employment. **********Professor Lester also studied the labor movement, unemployment and employment discrimination. His textbooks include the ''Economics of Labor'' (1941) and ''Labor and Industrial Relations'' (1951). **********During World War II, Professor Lester served on the National War Labor Board and the War Manpower Commission and in the Office of the Secretary of War. His role as Government adviser and mediator continued throughout his career. He was an arbitrator, under the Railway Labor Act, of labor disputes involving the locomotive engineers' union in 1954 and 1961. **********Professor Lester advised the Kennedy Administration on employment, wage and labor issues, and served on several Federal and state advisory boards. **********Professor Lester earned a bachelor's degree at Yale University in 1929 and his Ph.D. in economics in 1936 at Princeton University. He taught at the University of Washington and Duke University before returning to Princeton in 1945. Starting in 1948, he served several terms as chairman of the economics department; from 1966 to 1968, he was an associate dean and the director of the graduate program at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton. **********In 1969, he became dean of the faculty, where he worked to attract women and minority candidates to the faculty. He retired in 1974, when he was named dean emeritus. **********Professor Lester is survived by his wife, Doris N., of Hightstown; two daughters, Margaret L. Wing of Mendham, N.J. and Harriet L. Tarver of Atlanta; a son, Robert A., of Charlottesville, Va.; a brother, John W., of Hamburg, N.Y., and six grandchildren.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/23/world.snippet: Tens of thousands of people in Northern Ireland and Irish Republic observe minute of silence, week after terrorist bomb exploded in Omagh, killing 28 people and wounding 220; blast is commemorated in public assemblies in dozens of cities and towns...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/23/world.main_headline: Irish North and South Mourn Terror Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/23/world.print_headline: Irish North and South Mourn Terror Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/23/world.body_text: **********Tens of thousands of people here in Northern Ireland and in the Irish Republic to the south observed a painful minute of silence at 3:10 this afternoon, the exact time a week ago today that a terrorist bomb killed 28 people in the center of this small market town. **********The bomb, which left 220 wounded, 75 of whom are still in hospitals, was the deadliest terrorist atrocity in 29 years of sectarian violence in this mostly Protestant British province. **********A Roman Catholic splinter guerrilla group, the Real I.R.A., claimed responsibility for the attack. The police are questioning two men, but no  one has been charged with the crime. **********''They wanted a united Ireland,'' said Amanda Heffernan, a clerk, speaking of the Real I.R.A., which wants the Republic to take over the North. ''Now we're united in grief.''  The blast was commemorated in public assemblies in dozens of cities and towns here and in the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republic. The Irish President, Mary McAleese, spoke briefly. Her father's pub near the border with the Irish Republic was blown up by Protestant terrorists 25 years ago. **********The Irish Prime Minister, Bertie Ahern, who has advanced harsh legal measures to combat terrorism, attended the ceremony at the courthouse in Omagh, a few hundred yards from where the bomb went off. Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott represented the British Government. **********The Real I.R.A., which split from the Irish Republican Army this year, has announced a cease-fire. And today, another Republican splinter group, the Irish National Liberation Army, followed suit. This means that all major paramilitary groups, Catholic and Protestant, are now observing cease-fires, a development officials say should enhance the peace agreement approved in referendums here and in the Irish Republic. **********The Irish National Liberation Army's last admitted attack was on June 25, when a car bomb destroyed part of the border town of Newtownhamilton, wounding 11 people. **********The group's statement -- announced at the west Belfast headquarters of its political representatives, the Irish Republican Socialist Party -- means that only one anti-British organization in Northern Ireland, the Continuity I.R.A., a relatively small group, has yet to call a truce. **********''We recognize that the political situation has changed since the formation of I.N.L.A.,'' the statement said. ''We recognize that armed struggle can never be the only option for revolutionaries.'' **********Noting that the people of the whole island of Ireland ''have spoken clearly as to their wishes,'' it acknowledged ''faults and grievous errors in our prosecution of the war.'' **********''Innocent people were killed and injured, and at times our actions as a liberation army fell far short of what they should have been,'' it said. ''For this we as republicans, as socialists and as revolutionaries do offer a sincere, heartfelt and genuine apology.'' **********But today in Omagh, a mostly Catholic city of 20,000 set in the cow-studded hills of bucolic central Ulster, the people in the town center and in nearby parking lots with loudspeakers listened to the prayers of Protestant and Catholic clergymen. Many wept, and many more seemed to be fighting back tears. A few directed anger at the Real I.R.A. **********When the minute of silence began, Kathleen Heffernan, picked up her granddaughter, Tara, 4, hugging and nuzzling her. Half of the dead in the  blast were children. **********Ms. Heffernan talked about her niece, Stephanie Colton, 16, who was seriously wounded in the blast. **********''She had a piece of the car, the car-bomb car, stuck on her chest,'' she said. ''She nearly lost a foot. On Tuesday they are going to try to take the stones out from around her eyes, the gravel that the bomb blew at her.'' **********Ms. Heffernan said her niece recalled that, seconds before the blast, as police officers alerted to a bomb mistakenly led crowds toward the explosion, not away from it, an older woman had turned to her and her friends and said, ''This is the real thing, this time, girls.'' **********''The girls began to laugh at the woman,'' Ms. Heffernan said. ''Then the blast hit them.'' **********Raymond Cunliffe, 68, a retired truck driver and a native Englishman, said: ''It is disgusting to see what one human being can do to another. If it was mad dogs, you  would put them down.'' **********''I hope this means the end of the war,'' said Joseph Harley, owner of a construction equipment company, recalling his shock at watching the Omagh explosion on television. **********''Yes,'' said his wife, Veronica. ''But too late for Omagh.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/23/world.snippet: India's general election progresses through second of three crucial days, with 200 million voters going to polls, but with results still clouded because of political turmoil in Uttar Pradesh, country's largest and most populous state with biggest ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/23/world.main_headline: Turmoil in India's Largest State Clouds Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/23/world.print_headline: Turmoil in India's Largest State Clouds Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/23/world.body_text: **********India's system of staggered voting moved through the second of three crucial days today with 200 million voters going to the polls in a general election, but with an overall result still at least 10 days away the probable outcome became murkier than ever. **********Opinion polls that Indian election law allowed to be published up to the first day of voting last Monday mostly forecast a close contest. Those polls predicted no outright winner, with two possible outcomes: either a coalition government led by a Hindu nationalist group, the Bharatiya Janata Party, or a rival coalition of so-called secular parties opposed to Hindu nationalism. In the latter case, the coalition leader would probably be the Congress Party, which has governed India for more than 44 of the 50 years since independence in 1947. **********But political turmoil in the past 48 hours in Uttar Pradesh, the country's most populous state and biggest electoral prize, has brought new uncertainty. Many Indian political commentators had already described it as one of the most confused since Indira Gandhi called an election in 1977, after a 20-month period of emergency rule, and contrary to most predictions lost in a landslide. **********Since the 1970's, election forecasts have become more perilous because of the larger number of political parties that have joined the fray -- more than 600 in the current election -- and the number of those parties, about 30, that are likely to win seats. **********The events in Uttar Pradesh, a banana-shaped state of 140-million people that lies along the banks of the Ganges River on India's impoverished northern plain, showed just how volatile the coalition politics forced on this nation of 980 million people by the multiplication of parties can be. **********A state government formed five months ago by Bharatiya Janata collapsed on Saturday night when defectors from two other parties, including Congress, switched sides and pledged their support to a coalition government formed by a cluster of parties, including Congress, that have little in common but opposition to Hindu nationalism. **********By all accounts, the defections that brought down the Hindu party's most important state government were organized by its opponents to cause a loss of face on the eve of voting in the state in the national election. **********Apart from presenting the Hindu party as a loser in a state that it has to win by a large margin to have any hope of triumphing in the national vote, the purpose of the exercise appeared to be to strike at the power that its government, like all state governments in India, had to influence voting patterns through its control of the local administration. **********The strategy's impact on the voting in Uttar Pradesh was questionable, coming as it did only hours before the polls opened in the state -- and too late for 52 of the state's 85 electoral districts, where voting already took place last Monday. In any case, it was far from certain whether the new coalition sworn into power on Saturday night in Lucknow, the state capital, would last. **********An emergency session today of the High Court in Lucknow delayed until at least Monday a decision on a challenge by the Hindu party to the legality of the state government's ouster. The party contended that the Congress-appointed state governor allowed the takeover without allowing the administration to test its support in the state legislature. **********While this left Uttar Pradesh in a political limbo, opinions were divided as to the likely impact on the general election, in which there was voting today in 9 of India's 25 states. **********Some commentators thought that the blow to the Bharatiya Janata's  prestige could be costly in the third round of voting next Sunday, when another 150 million of the 600 million voters will go to the polls in an array of states. Next Sunday's voting includes a band of territory in southern India where the Hindu party and allied groups need a breakthrough to get to the number of seats, at least 215 by most estimates, that they need to have any prospect of forming a government coalition. **********Another view was that the turmoil in Lucknow could play to the party's  advantage by allowing its leaders to claim that its ascent to power in New Delhi over recent years has faced a ''conspiracy'' from Congress and other parties. **********A hint that the Hindu party's leaders inclined toward a pessimistic view came when Atal Bihari Vajpayee, its candidate for Prime Minister, announced he would begin a ''fast unto death'' in his Lucknow residence to protest the unseating of the Uttar Pradesh government. **********Mr. Vajpayee, 71, has generally been regarded as the most publicly acceptable face of the Hindu nationalists. He won a reputation as a safe pair of hands as Foreign Minister in a non-Congress Government in the late 1970's, and in the current campaign, he has almost completely shunned the disguised anti-Muslim rhetoric that has been a staple of Hindu nationalism. **********Mr. Vajpayee described the events in Lucknow as ''a deep-rooted conspiracy'' aimed at denying the Hindu party power in New Delhi, and added: ''To oppose it is my moral responsibility.'' **********Mr. Vajpayee's main rival for mass support in the election, Sonia Gandhi -- the Italian-born widow of Rajiv Gandhi, the former Congress Party leader and Prime Minister who was assassinated while campaigning in 1991 -- continued her own campaign today despite the upheaval in Uttar Pradesh, still drawing large crowds. **********Most polls have shown that Mrs. Gandhi's efforts have checked Congress' long downhill slide and could cause as many as 5 percent of the voters to shift back to Congress -- enough to make a Congress-led coalition government possible. **********With today's voting, only next Sunday's balloting remains before vote-counting begins, on March 2. Although voting in three electoral districts in the Muslim-majority state of Jammu and Kashmir will take place later, the counting that begins on March 2 is expected to provide results by March 3 in most of the 540 electoral districts up for election in the rest of the country. **********Two other seats are reserved for representatives of the ''the Anglo-Indian'' community, meaning people of mixed Indian and British descent, and they are filled by nomination after the new Parliament sits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/27/busin.body_text: **********Forecast for Windows 98: Slow Start, Steady Growth **********Government officials are racing to determine what antitrust action, if any, they should take against Microsoft before it ships Windows 98 to PC makers in May. But while the personal computer industry has been gearing up for Windows 98 for far longer than the antitrust authorities, the software's early impact in the marketplace is expected to be slight, compared with that of Windows 95. **********Still, even with a sluggish start -- initial sales projected at less than half those of Windows 95 -- Windows 98 seems likely to set the next industry standard. [Page D6.] **********Microsoft has long had a reputation within the PC industry as a bully. But recent public scrutiny has propelled the company's swaggering image into the mainstream. Meanwhile, predicting the software giant's demise has become a national parlor game. Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce. [D5.] **********Microsoft Exits Network Project **********Microsoft has withdrawn from a controversial $300 million project to help the California State University system build a high-speed computer network linking 22 campuses. With G.M.'s Hughes Electronics unit already gone, GTE and Fujitsu are now the sole remaining private partners in the plan. [D6.] **********Search Is on at Netscape **********Netscape Communications is laying the groundwork for an Internet search engine to be offered as part of the Web browser company's ambitious new World Wide Web site. Lycos, Infoseek and Cnet's Snap are among the second-tier search businesses that are negotiating with Netscape. [D4.] **********Film Distributors Spread Risk **********Movie distributors are eager to market American films abroad. But economies of scale do not always apply in dealing with hundreds of different cultures, and the vagaries of national economic fortunes and currency exchange rates can make the international distribution business as risky as producing the movie itself. [D10.] **********Bodice Rippers on Television **********Fistfights, foul language and generalized voyeurism -- not to mention lots of talk about lurid sex -- have all helped to make television's Jerry Springer the political-cultural football of the moment. Critics of the show, produced by USA Networks Studios, call it tasteless; Springer and his fans dismiss the critics as elitists who are out of touch. [D10.] **********Authors Attack Publishing Union **********Calling the proposed combination of Random House and Bantam Doubleday Dell a ''colossus'' that threatens readers' choices at bookstores, the Authors Guild appealed to Federal regulators to block the union, which the association contends could command more than 36 percent of the domestic market for consumer trade books. [D12.] **********Buyout Firms Looking at Publisher **********Simon & Schuster is for sale and several leveraged buyout firms may be interested in the publisher. Among those mentioned are Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Knowledge Universe, controlled by Michael R. Milken and Lawrence J. Ellison. Book companies that may play a part are Harcourt General and Pearson. Publishing. [D10.] **********Zapata Buying On-Line Magazines **********Two popular on-line magazines shut down by their parent company last month are being revived by an unlikely buyer. Zapata, a food processing business based in Houston, will announce today that it is acquiring Word and Charged magazines from Icon CMT, as a first step in what Zapata's chief executive called a ''radical transformation.'' [D4.]

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/12/busin.snippet: Apple Computer names Timothy D Cook, executive at Compaq Computer Corp, as its senior vice president for worldwide manufacturing operations (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/12/busin.body_text: **********Apple Computer said today that it had named Timothy D. Cook, the No. 2 manufacturing executive at the Compaq Computer Corporation, as its senior vice president for worldwide manufacturing operations. **********Mr. Cook was vice president for corporate materials at Compaq and previously worked at I.B.M. for more than a decade, most recently in charge of manufacturing and distribution for I.B.M.'s Personal Computer Company in North and Latin America. **********''This completes the executive team of senior vice presidents at Apple,'' said Steven P. Jobs, founder of Apple and its acting chief executive. ''The fact that Apple could attract someone as senior and as high caliber as Tim says something about where we are going.'' **********Mr. Jobs has long had a special commitment to manufacturing. He put great emphasis on designing advanced manufacturing systems both for Apple's original Macintosh computer and at Next, the company he founded after he left Apple in 1985. **********He said he was continuing to push Apple's manufacturing effort in the direction of built-to-order systems, which are increasingly being used by personal computer manufacturers to lower inventories and to make it possible to be more flexible in strategic decision making.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/27/busin.snippet: Combination of flexibility and dogged determination has enabled Singapore to steer remarkably steady course through Asian economic crisis; economists and analysts say Singapore's strategy of cutting wages, allowing currency to adjust downward and ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/27/busin.main_headline: Some Role Reversal in East Asia; Singapore Freewheels While Hong Kong Curbs
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/27/busin.print_headline: Some Role Reversal in East Asia; Singapore Freewheels While Hong Kong Curbs
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/27/busin.body_text: **********When Lee Kuan Yew, the father of modern Singapore, wanted to transform this spit-and-polish outpost into a global financial center, he urged people here to mimic the freewheeling ways of Hong Kong. **********Never mind that under Mr. Lee's strict rule, Singapore had made a virtue of being everything Hong Kong was not: clean, orderly, buttoned-down -- an oasis of Asian values worlds away from the Western permissiveness of Hong Kong. **********Yet in a series of speeches over the last year, Mr. Lee, the Senior Minister, and his son, Lee Hsien Loong, the Deputy Prime Minister, have called on regulators to use a lighter hand on Singapore's markets. In this tightly run Asian citadel, the Lee family's crusade quickly became official policy. **********''It's very difficult to decide to change policies when they are working,'' said Lee Hsien Loong, 46, a brisk former Army general who also runs the powerful Monetary Authority and is expected to be the next Prime Minister. ''But we got feedback from bankers and others that if you want to take the next stage up, then really you have to shift gears and allow more free play.'' **********Few places on earth would set out to become more freewheeling as methodically as Singapore would. But experts in Asia are not about to poke fun: They say that this combination of flexibility and dogged determination has enabled Singapore to steer a remarkably steady course through the Asian economic typhoon. **********Although Singapore's economy finally slid into negative territory in the third quarter, it had held out longer than that of most of its neighbors. And several economists and analysts said that Singapore's strategy of cutting wages, allowing the currency to adjust downward and liberalizing the financial markets could mean that Singapore will be in healthier shape after the crisis than the normally resilient Hong Kong. **********While Hong Kong still has many advantages, Singapore is about to give it a run for its money. Singapore has introduced a futures contract based on the Hong Kong stock market that traders say is the most serious challenge yet to Hong Kong's status as the financial hub of East Asia. **********''Singapore has been more streetwise than Hong Kong,'' said J. Mark Mobius, the president of the Templeton Emerging Markets Fund, which moved its headquarters from Hong Kong to Singapore because of its lower tax rates. ''They've exhibited a better understanding of the crisis and sounder policy.'' **********William H. Overholt, the director of Asia strategy at Nomura International in Hong Kong, added: ''Singapore has been much more willing to bite the bullet than Hong Kong. That's a big change.'' **********While Singapore has thrown off old regulations and taken a knife to its high costs, Hong Kong has moved in the opposite direction -- intervening to prop up its stock market, imposing a raft of new restrictions on trading and suspending Government sales of land to stem the decline in real estate prices. **********''We're seeing Hong Kong become more like the Singapore of the past, and Singapore become more like the Hong Kong of the past,'' said Mac Overton, a portfolio manager at MBF Unit Trust in Hong Kong. **********For now at least, Hong Kong has geography on its side. While Hong Kong is the doorstep of China, a vast and still-growing economy, Singapore is sandwiched between two of Asia's sickest countries, Indonesia and Malaysia. Relations in the neighborhood are fragile in the best of times and have frayed badly under the pressure of the downturn. **********Indeed, officials here said Singapore's precarious geography has helped solidify popular support for the Government's painful recovery package, which seeks to carve $6.5 billion in costs out of the economy, mostly through a reduction of 5 percent to 8 percent in wages and even deeper cuts in pension benefits. **********''One reason Singapore has been so cohesive for so long is because of the economic and political stress we went through in the 1960's and 1970's,'' said the younger Mr. Lee, who introduced the package in Parliament. **********''When you are very small and you have to struggle for your living, if you don't hang together, you hang separately,'' he said. **********In Singapore, of course, it is often hard to separate active support from pliant acquiescence. The Lee family still dominates political discourse in this city-state of 3.4 million people. Its governing People's Action Party holds 81 of the 83 elected seats in the Parliament (10 members are appointed) and brooks little dissent from opposition leaders, labor unions or the media. **********About the only public grousing over economic policy has come from citizens' groups that say that Singapore's civil servants, among the world's best paid, should bear more of the wage cuts. **********''You're not going to see people marching in the streets or even a lot of letters in the papers,'' said Simon Tay, who is one of the 10 appointed members of Parliament. ''But the Government listens to the public and reacts.'' **********Chia Yew Boon has the glass-is-half-full outlook that is typical of Singaporeans. Mr. Chia was laid off recently when his employer, a foreign bank, retrenched in Asia. But he is considering several job offers and keeping things in perspective. **********''We're so much better off than the rest of Asia,'' Mr. Chia said over a lunch of Malay-Chinese food in one of Singapore's traditional Chinese neighborhoods. ''We're not seeing famine or riots in the streets.'' **********Considering its heavy dependence on trade with Indonesia and Malaysia, it is a minor miracle that Singapore's economy kept growing as long as it did. Output fell by 1.5 percent in the third quarter, the first quarter of reduced output in Singapore since 1986. Most economists think the city-state can still eke out positive economic numbers for the full year. **********The trouble is, at least 20 percent of Singapore's exports go to its two neighbors, both of which are in an economic free fall. Because economists predict that the two countries will continue to contract in 1999, it will be tough for Singapore to return to sustained growth before the millennium. **********The troubles of Singapore's neighbors have especially hurt in tourism and export services. Visitor arrivals are down 14.5 percent so far in 1998, and many of those who now come are fleeing riots in Jakarta rather than spending for getaway weekends at Singapore's swank hotels. **********Similarly, Singapore's lucrative export service business has collapsed, as financially troubled Indonesian and Malaysian companies can no longer afford to buy advertising, accounting and other services in Singapore. **********Malaysia has hurt Singapore in another highly visible way. When it imposed capital controls on its markets on Sept. 1, the country also prohibited shares of Malaysian companies from being traded in Singapore. **********Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, accused investors of using Singapore as a staging ground to speculate against Malaysia's currency. But the immediate effect of his action was to kill off a thriving market -- and deprive Singapore of an arrow in its quiver as a global financial center. **********Beyond these headaches, people in Singapore worry about the long-term stability of Southeast Asia, particularly Indonesia. With 214 million people, deepening social strife and islands that lie just across the harbor from Singapore, an unstable Indonesia could pose an acute economic and security threat. **********''If these 200 million people are never again going to be a market for us, that will be a big problem,'' said Tan Kong Yam, head of the business policy department at the National University of Singapore. **********By drastically reducing costs, Singapore hopes to make its exports more competitive to those of the rest of the world. Although Asia accounts for half of its trade, Singapore is a leading exporter of electronics, petrochemicals and other products to the United States and Europe. **********Unlike Hong Kong, Singapore has allowed its currency to drift downward, though not as much as other regional currencies. In August, the Monetary Authority adopted a more flexible exchange-rate policy, and the Singapore dollar has since risen along with Asia's other resurgent currencies. **********Years before the current crisis, Singapore was eager to stake its claim as Asia's financial mecca. It exploited its convenient time zone to become the world's fourth-largest foreign-exchange market, after London, New York and Tokyo. But it trails Hong Kong in stock trading and asset management. **********Now, Singapore sees a chance to close the gap. It has opened its Government bond market, eased restrictions on foreign brokerage firms and tried to attract asset funds like Templeton by promising low or zero tax rates. **********Lee Kuan Yew, who inspired the moves, said in a written response to questions that he was influenced by Hong Kong's success, by discussions with leading bankers and by his membership on the international advisory board of J. P. Morgan & Company, where he witnessed the changing world of global finance. **********The Singapore International Monetary Exchange, or Simex, has begun selling index futures contracts that track Hong Kong's benchmark index, the Hang Seng. Simex hopes to steal business by offering lower margin requirements for its contracts than the Hong Kong Futures Exchange, which raised its margin requirements in September to thwart speculators. **********Investors have welcomed Singapore's foray, and many are considering whether to move their business southward. ''For the big players, Hong Kong's costs have become punitive,'' said Bill Kaye, the senior managing director of the Pacific Group, an asset management fund in Hong Kong. **********Hong Kong gave itself even more of a black eye when it threatened to deprive Simex of the real-time data that traders need to calculate the value of the Hang Seng index. Investors were able to get the data on a Web site maintained by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. **********Now, officials in Hong Kong say they plan to cut prices to fend off the threat from Singapore. **********''Our objective is to maintain Hong Kong as the Manhattan of China,'' said Randy Gilmore, the chief executive of the futures exchange. **********For all of Singapore's moxie, Hong Kong will most likely cling to that mantle for some time. The difference, according to experts, is that Hong Kong's next-door neighbor, mainland China, is stable, growing, and friendly, while Singapore's neighbors are shaky, shrinking and potentially hostile. **********Indonesia's President, B. J. Habibie, fueled Singapore's anxieties earlier this year when he dismissed the city-state as a ''red dot'' on the map. Singapore has also recently squabbled over its border crossings with Malaysia, with which it has a tangled history of close ties and bruised feelings. **********In building Singapore, Lee Kuan Yew frequently warned of disaster around the corner as a way to mobilize his people. His son said the current tribulations could have a bracing effect on a population lulled by peace and ever-growing prosperity. **********''It's been quite helpful for Singaporeans to have heard this remark about the 'little red dot' because that's what we have been telling them, too,'' the younger Mr. Lee said with a wry laugh. ''So it's a timely reminder.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/15/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel ended a second round of talks this evening without achieving a breakthrough on reviving stalled Middle East peace negotiations. **********But senior American and Israeli officials said lower-level aides from each side would continue working on the issues on Friday and over the weekend. **********While ''we do have sufficient reason to continue serious work,'' the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said, ''it's hard to be optimistic, given the history of this process and our concern over growing violence among the Palestinians.'' **********A senior American official said Ms. Albright was not ready to report to President Clinton on whether the Israelis could soon agree to a deal that would allow them to start final peace talks with the Palestinians in a ceremony here. **********After the meeting today, senior Israeli officials said that progress was being made, ''but this is a slow-motion thing, slow but steady.'' **********The American Middle East envoy, Dennis B. Ross, will meet two Israeli officials, Danny Naveh and Yitzhak Molcho, on Friday morning, before Mr. Netanyahu travels to New York to meet with Kofi Annan, the United Nations Secretary General in the afternoon. **********Ms. Albright will travel to London on Saturday to join Mr. Clinton for meetings with European leaders that start on Monday. Mr. Ross is expected to meet again with Israeli officials here on Sunday and again with Mr. Netanyahu when he returns to Washington, also on Sunday. **********The United States has been pressing Mr. Netanyahu to accept an American proposal that would require a 13 percent withdrawal from the West Bank. The withdrawal would have to to be phased in over 12 weeks in parallel with specific Palestinian steps to fulfill their obligations to fight terrorism. **********Officials said the main problems remained the size of the withdrawal -- with Mr. Netanyahu's still resisting different formulas to reach 13 percent, and how to agree on the size and manner of a last interim withdrawal, which is due by Sept. 1. **********Mr. Netanyahu, who spent the bulk of the day making speeches to Jewish groups and talking to supportive legislators on Capitol Hill, met Ms. Albright for 90 minutes at his hotel. **********Senior Israeli officials said Mr. Netanyahu would follow Ms. Albright's tone in her speech on Tuesday and seek to calm relations with Washington while he is here, not worsen them. **********''He's sensed a boiling environment, and a lot of people wouldn't mind if he didn't have a more challenging relationship with Washington, but he's decided not to do that,'' one official said. **********In a nonetheless rousing breakfast speech to the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, Mr. Netanyahu repeated his mantra that peace emerges from security, not the reverse. **********''The only peace that can endure is a peace that can be defended,'' Mr. Netanyahu said. The normalization that peace brings may be reversed by any change of government or by the whim of undemocratic Arab leaders, he said, arguing that Israel's only security came from its military strength. He said Egypt and Jordan made peace with Israel only after they had realized they could not defeat it. **********In a formal statement earlier in the day, the State Department deplored the death of eight Palestinians in clashes in the West Bank and Gaza Strip and said that the violence underscored the urgency of putting the peace effort back on track. **********In a form of rebuttal to Mr. Netanyahu, Mr. Rubin said, ''Clearly this outbreak reflects a deterioration in relations between Israelis and Palestinians and underscores for all to see the need to break the impasse in peace negotiations.'' **********He asked for Israeli decisions on redeployment ''as soon as possible.'' **********''We deeply regret the deaths that occurred,'' Mr. Rubin said. **********Ms. Albright also telephoned Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, to express her condolences over the dead and wounded while counseling restraint, American officials said. **********Mr. Netanyahu, by contrast, expressed no regrets. He simply said the Palestinian demonstrations hurt their case. ''People ask themselves what kind of peace this is,'' he said. ''Israel will not accept and will not countenance these outbreaks of violence that are aimed at doing damage to Israel.'' **********Neither American nor Israeli officials were eager to discuss the details of the negotiations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/01/busin.snippet: Article on airline alliance proposed between Northwest and Continental focuses on how alliance will affect flight operations and service; photo (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/01/busin.main_headline: Whither the Customer In an Airline Alliance?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/01/busin.print_headline: SPENDING IT; Whither the Customer In an Airline Alliance?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/01/busin.body_text: **********THE airline alliance proposed last week between Northwest and Continental drew praise from Wall Street analysts, yet the deal -- in which Northwest has agreed to buy control of Continental for about $311 million in cash and $208 million worth of stock -- leaves a number of unresolved questions for consumers. **********For example, how will the alliance affect flight operations and service? **********Continental promotes its leadership for two consecutive years in the J. D. Power & Associates customer satisfaction survey for flights of more than 500 miles. It also has one of the best on-time records. Some industry observers say this reputation might erode through affiliation with Northwest, which has been beset recently by customer complaints and poor on-time performance. **********Indeed, last year Northwest fell sharply in the Power survey, placing ''below the industry average,'' according to a Power spokesman, in both long and short flights. In 1996, the carrier placed second to Continental on long flights, and was first in short flights. **********''Continental could be the big loser in this alliance, if Northwest begins imposing its standards,'' said Joe Brancatelli, who is a columnist for Trip.com (www.thetrip.com), a World Wide Web site for business travelers. In a recent column, Mr. Brancatelli excoriated Northwest's customer service and vowed not to fly the carrier again. **********Others say such a situation is unlikely. ''Northwest's outlay is a little over $311 million, less than a quarter of their liquidity,'' said Samuel C. Buttrick, an airline analyst with Paine Webber. ''So it's hard to see how a 25 percent reduction in their cash position could remotely affect service standards.'' **********Joseph Berman, an analyst with Avmark, an airline consulting company in Arlington, Va., said that contrary to Northwest's low standing in Department of Transportation rankings, which are based on customer complaints, the airline has gotten ''a bum rap'' -- especially since hiring a new head of customer service less than a year ago. **********Continental does not appear worried. ''We think we understand the formula for achieving customer satisfaction,'' said David Messing, a spokesman for Continental. ''We think Northwest also understands the formula, and they're working very hard to achieve it.'' **********Northwest said it, too, was committed to providing excellent customer service. ''We made a significant investment to address these issues,'' Kathy Peach, a spokeswoman, said. ''The difference in the ratings among airlines is very small.'' **********The carriers' frequent-flier programs are expected to be linked by June 1. While many details are still to be worked out, the prospects seem to benefit the consumer. **********''This alliance offers frequent-flier members a lot more choices than in their individual programs, especially since there's so little overlap in their routes,'' said David S. Stempler, president of the Air Travelers Association in Washington. Adding KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, Northwest's partner, extends that frequent-flier reach even further, he said. **********Continental's program is considered among the industry's most generous: its elite level -- which confers  upgrades and other benefits -- is  reached at 20,000 miles flown, and accrued miles face no time limits on their use. With some exceptions, Northwest's program requires 25,000 miles flown for similar perks; miles expire after three years. **********Mr. Messing said the two programs would probably function ''the way our program with America West does.'' Travelers enrolled with either Continental or America West can redeem miles earned flying on the other airline. **********Signals of an airline's service quality range from the condition of airplane interiors to in-flight food. But Mr. Stempler said the surest indication was the number of flights canceled for reasons other than weather. **********''Carriers with reliable service usually spend a lot of money having mechanics and spare parts available at airports away from their hubs,'' he said. ''That way they can fix minor mechanical problems there on the spot, even if it causes delays.'' Airlines that cut back, he said, must cancel flights to take planes back to their maintenance bases. **********Another sign might be any sharp change in top staff. ''This transaction does represent a change of control that will result in the immediate vesting of all management stock options at Continental,'' Mr. Buttrick said. ''In effect, the golden handcuffs come off, so management of Continental Airlines will be freer to pursue other opportunities.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/13/world.snippet: Financial experts say NATO forces in Bosnia and Croatia are needlessly paying millions of dollars in rent that is winding up in coffers of the political parties, that are often principal obstacles to peace; even though 1995 Dayton accord required ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/13/world.main_headline: Political Parties Opposed to Bosnia Peace Get Millions in Rent From NATO
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/13/world.print_headline: Political Parties Opposed to Bosnia Peace Get Millions in Rent From NATO
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/13/world.body_text: **********NATO forces in Bosnia and Croatia are needlessly paying millions of dollars in rent that is winding up in the coffers of the governing political parties, say financial experts who have studied the two governments. And diplomats say those parties are often the principal obstacles to peace. **********The 1995 Dayton accord, which ended the war in Bosnia and authorized NATO's presence, required Bosnia and Croatia to provide buildings and land to NATO troops without charge. **********But the United States, Britain, France, Germany and other countries may be spending as much as $40 million a year in rent for their bases in Bosnia and Croatia, a senior NATO financial officer said. **********The exact figures could not be determined, because many of the armies involved refused to disclose how much they were paying. In addition, NATO financial officers said their records were in disarray. **********Defending the payments, NATO officers said they went to private companies for use of their property. But while many of the companies receiving the rent portray themselves as privately owned, they appear to be Government-owned and controlled by political parties. **********Interviews with company and local government officials, as well as financial experts working for Western governments in Bosnia and Croatia, indicate that much of the money is going to the Bosnian and Croatian Governments, which funnel it to political parties. Foreign diplomats suggested that in Bosnia, the money effectively buys good relations between NATO forces and local and national leaders. **********Almost three years after fighting ended, Bosnia continues to be governed by ethnic-based parties that effectively dominate three mini states. Croatia is governed by a nationalist party that virtually controls the parts of Bosnia held by ethnic Croats. Foreign diplomats say they blame those parties for blocking the Western goal of a unified and stable country with an effective national Government. **********On being told about the payments, the chief international civilian official in Bosnia, Carlos Westendorp, said they undermined Western efforts. ''How can they pay money to these people when we are supposed to be here promoting democracy?'' he asked. **********Each foreign military force in Bosnia pays the costs of maintaining its soldiers here, while NATO pays the costs of the large headquarters that directs the operation. The British Army says it will spend about $16.5 million this year to rent its eight bases in Bosnia and Croatia. **********The United States Army says it pays rent only for bases on private land. A spokesman said the Army had spent ''several million dollars'' for rent in the last three years, including about $1.5 million a year for a single base in Croatia, but he could not detail all rents paid. **********The United States Army insists that great efforts are made to insure that it pays no rent to Government-controlled companies. But at many places where the United States has or had troops, it is not clear that the Army has always succeeded. **********A pattern emerged in interviews with local officials and with managers of companies whose property is being used by American troops and other NATO forces. It was clear that payments were being made to companies that managers admitted were Government-owned. **********For example, the Bosnian company that received the most rent from the United States, according to Army records, was paid $1.4 million to allow soldiers to put a base at its coal processing plant for nine months. **********The company's director, Pasaga Muratovic, said the company had always been wholly owned by the Bosnian Government. **********Another coal mine operation used for an American camp was paid about $744,000, the Army reported. But Sakib Dizdarevic, the mine's director, said that it, too, was owned by the Bosnian Government, and that the payment was nearly three times that amount. **********For most of 1996, the Army base named Pat lay on farmland controlled by the most radical Bosnian Serb political party, whose founder, the former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic, has been indicted on war crimes charges. **********Army records show no rental payment for the camp, a spokesman said. But the Mayor of the nearest town, Sekovici, said his office was paid more than $26,000 a month by the Army. The money is used for Bosnian Serb government expenses, he said. Local farmers said that although the land belonged to them, they received none of the rent. **********The headquarters of the British Army in Bosnia is in a large, unused sheet metal factory near the Bosnian Serb-controlled town of Banja Luka. The financial director of the factory, Milo Milovanovic, said that to qualify for rent, company officials had told British officers that the factory was privately owned. **********But in an interview, he conceded that the factory was controlled by Bosnian Serb officials. All of the company's directors, he said, were appointed by Government officials. Mr. Milovanovic said the money received for rent was turned over to the Government for what he described as taxes and insurance. **********In the town of Sipovo, the Deputy Mayor, Mile Bosnjak, said earlier this year that all the rent paid by British forces for an abandoned textile factory was transferred directly from the factory's bank account to the Bosnian Serb government. **********Germany and France also pay rent. A spokesman for the French Army refused to provide details, while records kept by the German Army showed that it paid $2.5 million last year to rent warehouses from a Bosnian Government company in Sarajevo. **********Rent money from government-controlled businesses goes to the political party in control in the area, said foreign financial experts studying the Bosnian economy. **********''Every important manager of these companies is appointed by the political parties,'' said Didier Fau, chief of the Economic Department at Mr. Westendorp's office. ''They do what they are told. **********Most of the NATO rent appears to have been paid to the huge state- controlled holding companies that dominated the Bosnian economy under Communism. Managers of the companies often say they have been transformed into private concerns, but the law that would allow privatization of Government enterprises was not passed until July and has yet to take effect. NATO forces have been paying rent since December 1995. **********Officials of the International Finance Corporation, an arm of the World Bank, say the number of privatized companies is ''infinitesimal.'' **********''It is closer to zero percent, than one percent,'' said Richard Rutherford, the principal investment officer for the International Finance Corporation in Europe. **********Even so, Lieut. Col. James Kerrick, speaking for the American Army in Bosnia, said the ownership of properties where the Army paid rent was thoroughly investigated to make sure that it was truly private.
