https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/12/your-.main_headline: You Should Live to Be 100 — and You Just Might
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/12/your-.print_headline: You Should Live to Be 100 — and You Just Might
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/12/your-.body_text: **********"WE ALWAYS thought that at 65 we would retire, then play golf," says Jeremy Rifkin. "For a lot of people now, that is just over midlife." Mr. Rifkin author, lecturer and diviner of scientific and economic trends — thinks that a lot more of us, not long from now, will have to rethink our notions of old age and retirement as advances in genetic research and treatment reset the upper limit of the life span. **********"No one knows for sure," he cautioned, "but if you have a very sophisticated approach to keeping people well through diet and exercise, it seems not unlikely to have the average life span at 100 to 110 for people who are here now, people who are 2 to 3 years old. **********"I'm being very conservative now. There is no reason in the next 20 years why we couldn't have a life span of 100 or a little more. For those folks who are middle-aged now, advances over the next 20 years will put years on people's lives. Depending on how fast the technology moves into the marketplace, it's not unlikely to extend the life span five to 10 years for many people." **********This is the advent of the "biotech revolution," Mr. Rifkin said, citing some of the initial skirmishes that have been occurring with astounding frequency: sheep cloning; genetic mapping and screening; manufacture and regeneration of human body parts; the creation of interspecies hybrid cells. **********Research being done now, he said, will bring changes in all facets of life — including how long it lasts. **********"This is not a marginal evolution, but a core revolution of the 21st century," said Mr. Rifkin, who founded the Foundation on Economic Trends in Washington and is an adviser to governments and a fellow at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business. He is the author of "The Biotech Century: Harnessing the Gene and Remaking the World." **********He prefers a revolution along the "soft path," with genetic screens used to devise the best programs of nutrition and exercise to maximize each person's life span. People found through screens at birth to face a risk of developing colon cancer, for instance, could be started on a high-fiber diet at the appropriate time. **********"Over 95 percent of longevity is accounted for by better nutrition, hygiene and sanitation," he said. "The way to use this science is to have a sophisticated 21st-century preventive health regime in the commercial marketplace." **********This approach, apart from being practical, would eliminate the ethical and social concerns of such "hard-path" procedures as gene-replacement therapy and, perhaps, the development of made-to-order genes. **********"They are based on totally different approaches, with a totally different frame of reference and value system, and with different results for society," he said. Among his misgivings is that the quantity and quality of life could be held for ransom by a handful of multinational pharmaceutical companies owning patents on all 100,000 human genes. **********Life-science companies are looking for "ways to control genetic instructions to extend age," he said. "The hope is to turn the human stem cell into a living factory that they can control to turn on switches to produce those parts of the body they need to regenerate." **********The stem cell is what embryos are made of before cells become differentiated into the building blocks of the various systems of the body: blood, nerves, muscles and so forth. **********"That's a big problem on commercial and philosophical grounds," he said. "The public might be quite shocked at the prospect of global life-science companies having patents on the human blueprint. **********"Whoever controls the genes controls the 21st century," he said. "It will be as critical in the next century and controlling materials and fuels was in the industrial era." **********The hard-path approach, he contended, "raises serious questions of eugenics." Genetic screens are already being used to influence decisions on employment, education and health insurance. It is not far-fetched to think of a two-tiered society in which the "haves" are born with the right genes, or have the money to buy them, and the "have-nots" must get by with Brand X genes. Another result could be "gene wars" between northern countries, which have the money and scientific expertise, and southern countries, which are rich in genetic diversity. **********"There's a broader ethical issue here," he said. "Does life have intrinsic value, or is it just intellectual property with commercial utility in the market? I think we'll see in a few years a genetic-rights movement." **********Mr. Rifkin dismisses the hard-path types as simplistic reductionists. He notes that their philosophy has been used to suggest that someday the contents of human brains might be stored on computer disks and placed in new receptacles to produce a sort of immortality. **********If the hard-path approach wins the day, he said, old age may be spent unpleasantly, repeatedly replacing body parts and cells that have gone on the fritz. If the path to extended life is as soft as he hopes, then those added years will be spent in good health. **********Mr. Rifkin has a few ideas about how people will be spending that extra time: "As people get older, what we're going to begin to see are new opportunities beyond the marketplace and beyond government," he predicted. These will occur in a "third sector" of cultural, religious, civic and fraternal organizations. **********"Why not begin to have spirited debate in every country on the possibility of creating separate vocations — paid, full or part-time?" he said. **********"We have to think from an early age about a vocation, and we have to plan financially much more carefully. If we live to 100, what's going to happen to Social Security? We have to understand that increased longevity brings with it added responsibilities. This notion of retirement should be eliminated altogether." **********- **********For further information: **********- **********THE BIOTECH CENTURY: Harnessing the Gene and Remaking the World. By Jeremy Rifkin. Published in May 1998 by Putnam/Tarcher. $24.95. ISBN: 0-87-477909

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/16/techn.snippet: Intel Corp plans to broadcast live performances of 300 bands on line and call adventure 'music festival'; home users with best chance of enjoying peformances are those with newer equipment; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/16/techn.main_headline: Bumps in the Road With Netcasts
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/16/techn.print_headline: USER'S GUIDE; Bumps in the Road With Netcasts
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/16/techn.body_text: **********I AM still trying to repress memories of my own aborted attempt to use the Internet as a broadcast medium. Back in 1996, I was the host of a weekly on-line show called ''Web Whirl,'' the goal of which was to take the audience along on a tour of a dozen or so Web sites. **********The show didn't work because most home users were at the wrong end of an information bottleneck. Relying on fickle modem connections, their on-line forays resembled uneasy games of Russian roulette. Would they connect on the first try? Or even the second? Would their connections fail in the middle of downloading a Web page? After a few months, the show was canceled. **********So when I heard that the Intel Corporation was planning to broadcast the live performances of 300 bands on line this week and call the adventure a ''music festival,'' my first reaction was skepticism. After all, not much has changed in the past two years to erase the obstacles that doomed ''Web Whirl.'' Today, with most home users still relying on finicky modems, will the so-called streaming video clip from a concert arrive instead as herky-jerky niblets of image? **********I hoped not. But my first glance at the Web page for the festival (which began last night and will run through Saturday) did not reassure me. The broadcast site at www.intelfest.com instructed me to download the software tool Real Player from Real Networks so I could hear and see the on-line performances. But my first two attempts failed because somewhere between the computer where Real Player was archived and my own desktop, the connection failed. **********With 300 bands playing live in 20 New York City clubs for the four-day period, Intel faces an even greater technical challenge. For each band, the club sets up a microphone to capture vocals and the softer instruments like flutes and violins, mixing those sounds at a main sound desk. Another microphone supplied by Intel picks up other instruments, like drums and guitars. Then the feeds from both microphones are mixed and prepared for on-line broadcast on a personal computer that encodes the sound and translates it into digital bits. Intel broadcasts the digital transmission through two dual-Pentium II 333-megahertz servers, which in turn distribute the signals over the Internet. Performances at five clubs are also being broadcast in a simultaneous video feed. **********The home users with the best chance of enjoying the performances are those with newer equipment. While you might technically be able to connect to the festival's Web site on a poky old 486 machine, I doubt that you could enjoy the experience with anything less than a microprocessor that runs at 166 megahertz and employs MMX technology to enhance audio and video. As for modem speed? Well, frankly, there is no dial-up modem that pushes sound and video across the Net reliably enough -- or fast enough -- to satisfy me. **********''So why bother?'' the curmudgeon in me wondered. The whole venture sounded like a flashback to the early days of radio or TV, with the broadcasters relying on an uneasy combination of prayer, spit and willpower to overcome inevitably choppy transmissions. But then, those early broadcasts, imperfect though they may have been, were exciting partly because of the unknown limits of raw technology. The roughness was fraught with endless possibility. **********So maybe I was being unfair to the Internet -- and to Intel -- by expecting too much too soon from this nascent medium. Why not give everyone points for trying? During a similar festival that Intel sponsored last year, 125,000 computer users tuned in, er, connected -- five times as many as attended the live performances. Weren't those numbers an indication that the experiment was at least somewhat successful in increasing people's access to music? **********A closer look at the schedule on the festival Web site also swayed me. The musicians in that eclectic group of 300 bands, whose sounds include  rock, punk, rap, jazz and folk -- would surely not have agreed to participate in this endeavor if they felt that the medium failed to convey their message. There must be benefits from playing to an on-line audience that would outweigh the apparent lack of intimacy between performer and listener. **********I decided to ask a singer, Victoria Williams, who was scheduled to perform in the festival live (and on line) at the Bowery Ballroom last night. **********A few days before the performance, I spoke on the phone to Ms. Williams to tell her that I had just been listening to the folky, lyrical stories she sang on ''This Moment in Toronto With Victoria Williams,'' recorded live in 1995. ''Do you think that you will interact differently with an on-line audience?'' I asked. **********There was a moment of silence on the phone that lasted just long enough to make me wonder if the connection had failed. ''I had no idea that this is an on-line concert that I'm doing,'' Ms. Williams said. ''I thought it was a live concert.'' **********I explained about the computers that would transmit her performance across the Net. **********''You mean that people are going to be able to watch it on their computers, but it will sound kind of broken up, with herky-jerky video?'' she asked. **********I told her I wasn't sure whether the Bowery Ballroom was one of the five clubs that would transmit simultaneous video. (I quickly tried to check the Web site for her, but my connection stalled.) **********But Ms. Williams sounded so unhappy about the possibility that I felt bad for her. ''Maybe it will all work fine,'' I said, trying to sound as if I had not lived through the broadcast disappointment of ''Web Whirl.'' **********After all, I went on, here was a medium that might have the power to propel her music to a whole new audience -- to millions of people around the world who could not physically attend her concert. Maybe the Internet would prove to be as potent a broadcast tool as television had been in 1964 when Ed Sullivan introduced the Beatles to 73 million viewers. **********''Wouldn't that be great?'' I said cheerily. **********''I've just never seen it like that, but it would be incredible,'' Ms. Williams agreed. She paused again. ''Or maybe the band and I could just walk kind of herky-jerky in the club, and shuffle our feet a bit, to give the live audience the Internet experience.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/10/busin.snippet: Hispanic Business magazine says advertisers spent $1.4 billion last year trying to reach Spanish-speaking and bilingual Hispanic consumers; figure is more than double $628.2 million spent in 1990 and four times $333.5 million of 1985; experts say ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/10/busin.main_headline: Spanish-speaking consumers are the object of a growing number of marketers' desires.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/10/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Spanish-speaking consumers are the object of a growing number of marketers' desires.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/10/busin.body_text: **********ILINGUAL education may be under attack in the public schools, but American businesses do speak Spanish. **********Advertisers spent $1.4 billion last year trying to reach Spanish-speaking and bilingual Hispanic consumers, according to Hispanic Business magazine in Santa Barbara, Calif. That was more than double the $628.2 million spent in 1990 and four times the $333.5 million of 1985, based on the magazine's numbers. **********While still less than 1 percent of the $186.8 billion spent on all advertising here in 1997, according to McCann-Erickson Worldwide, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, experts say the Hispanic number will keep growing rapidly. **********''People are beginning to recognize that the Hispanic population is very large,'' said Dolores Kunda, director of Hispanic marketing at Leo Burnett U.S.A., part of the Leo Burnett Company and a board member of the Association of Hispanic Advertising Agencies. ''The Hispanic population is as large as the population of Canada,'' she said, referring to the perhaps 30 million people of Hispanic descent now living in the nation. **********The most recent census estimates for 1995 show the Hispanic population at 26.9 million, or just under 10 percent of the total population. The Census Bureau predicts that will rise to more than 11 percent in 2000 and to 13.8 percent in 2010, with the Hispanic population nudging out blacks to become the largest minority. **********In response, mainstream publications like Newsweek and People have come out with Spanish editions, Ms. Kunda said, and bilingual magazines like Latina are cropping up. **********The number of Hispanic radio stations has grown to more than 400, according to SRDS Hispanic Media and Market Source. **********And, while mainstream networks struggle to hold onto viewers in a world full of cable channels, Univision Communications Inc., the largest of two Hispanic networks, has grown to 2.8 million prime-time viewers today from 1.3 million in 1993, according to Anne Corley, vice president for public relations. It added more viewers in the coveted 18-  to 49-year-old segment than any other network, including NBC, between 1993 and 1997, she said. **********The ability to deliver a block of viewers has made Hispanic television so popular in places like Miami and Los Angeles that Spanish-language programming now leads in some time slots, said Ernest Bromley, chief executive of Bromley, Aguilar & Associates, a Hispanic advertising agency in San Antonio that is part of the D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles unit of the MacManus Group. **********In the 1980's, Mr. Bromley said,  most advertisers were attracted to the Hispanic market for political reasons. ''Now, it's for marketing reasons,'' he said. ''They can see sales from the work that they do.'' **********While Hispanic Business tracks only those ads designed for the Hispanic, mostly Spanish-speaking media, Maria Zate, senior editor there, said a new breed of Hispanic ad has been cropping up over the last two or three years. These ads are in English and appear in mainstream media, she said, but are clearly aimed at  Hispanic consumers. **********She cites two examples, both for the McDonald's Corporation, one of the 10 largest advertisers to Hispanic consumers. One, she said, features a father and daughter in a McDonald's restaurant, discussing the girl's coming 15th-birthday gala. **********The other shows a toddler looking at McDonald's french fries, as his eager father tries to prod him to speak. When the child utters his first word, ''Papa,'' English-speaking viewers understand but only Spanish speakers get the joke that the word also means potato, Ms. Zate said. **********Just how much is being spent on such crossover advertising is tough to measure, she said, because determining whether the ad is aimed at Hispanic consumers can be subjective. **********Ads in English for Hispanic people might become more common because they now tend to be bilingual, she said. Figures from the 1990 census show that nine million of the 17.3 million Americans who spoke Spanish at home reported they also spoke English ''very well.'' Another 3.8 million reported speaking it ''well.'' **********But, she added, ''There's a lot of controversy there,'' because making Hispanic ads in English could undercut agencies that deal in Spanish-language ads. **********Bromley, Aguilar makes 85 to 90 percent of its ads in Spanish, Mr. Bromley said. The percentage of the Hispanic population who speak Spanish most of the time is going up,  not down, he maintained. ''We're seeing people who are English-dominant who are becoming more Hispanic,'' he said. ''They're reclaiming their language, renewed pride.'' **********''Are people going to increase their knowledge of English? Of course they are,'' Ms. Kunda said. ''Are they going to give up what makes them Hispanic, what is important to them?  I don't think so.'' **********Advertising tries to reach consumers on an emotional level, she said, and for the Hispanic population, ''Spanish is the language of the soul.'' **********Hispanic agencies will be needed for English ads as well, she added, because of the cultural nuances. **********Alex Nogales, chairman of the National Hispanic Media Coalition, agrees that the Hispanic population will continue to have a distinctive culture best appealed to with the aid of Hispanic agencies. But he said the day when English ads for them outnumber those in Spanish could be only 20 years away. **********''The move is going from Spanish to English very fast,'' he said. Of advertisers, he said, ''The population is moving from one to another much faster than they perceive so they're getting left behind.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/busin.snippet: United Healthcare Corp, one of nation's largest health insurers, agrees to acquire Humana Inc for $5.5 billion, further shrinking number of competitors in industry and narrowing choices of managed-care plans for consumers; chart (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/busin.main_headline: United Health To Acquire Humana Inc.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/busin.print_headline: United Health To Acquire Humana Inc.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/29/busin.body_text: **********The United Healthcare Corporation, one of the nation's largest health insurers, agreed yesterday to buy Humana Inc. for $5.5 billion, further shrinking the number of competitors in the industry and narrowing the choices of managed-care plans for consumers. **********The combination of the health plans, with more than 10 million members across the country, would dominate the South Florida market. It would be the strongest insurer in Chicago and some other Midwestern cities. **********Both companies said the agreement would strengthen their ability to offer services that patients want and provide nationwide coverage for big employers. But some health-benefits consultants called such a combination part of a consolidation trend that was unsettling for many Americans in managed-care arrangements. **********''Humana was a very aggressive player,'' said John Erb, a consultant in Boca Raton, Fla., with Arthur J. Gallagher & Company. ''They gave the Blue Cross and United a run for their money. Now, that competition will dry up. There will be diminished choices for employers and consumers.'' **********Both United and Humana recently reported strong financial results, after their success in raising this year's premiums. But like other health insurers, they are under more pressure to produce profits as consumers demand fewer restrictive rules, governments propose tighter regulations, and hospitals and physicians balk at some economizing. **********Managed-care companies also face a squeeze on Government payments for Medicare for the elderly and disabled, and Medicaid for low-income people. United Healthcare, based in Minnetonka, Minn., outside Minneapolis, and Humana, of Louisville, Ky., have a combined 902,000 Medicare members and 1.2 million Medicaid members. **********Under the terms of the all-stock deal announced yesterday, United Healthcare would exchange one of its shares for two shares of Humana and assume $850 million of Humana's debt. On the basis of United's closing share price Wednesday of $64.125, before the deal was announced, the value of the stock swap is $5.5 billion. **********United Healthcare shares fell $1.625 yesterday, to $62.50, while Humana's jumped $3.625, to $29.875. **********The agreement is the latest in a series of huge-scale mergers and acquisitions in the health insurance industry. In March, Aetna Inc., which bought U.S. Healthcare for $8.8 billion in 1996, agreed to add the Nylcare health care unit of the New York Life Insurance Company in a $1.35 billion deal. **********Both United and Humana have grown through acquisitions, notably the 1995 purchase by United of Metra Health, itself a combination of units of Metropolitan Life and the Travelers Insurance Company. **********David Jones, a Kentucky entrepreneur, founded Humana with a partner in 1961. They owned nursing homes and later, hospitals. Humana spun off the hospitals in 1993 as a separate company, Galen Health Care Inc., which was later acquired by the chain that became the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation. **********Mr. Jones, chairman of Humana, and Dr. William W. McGuire, chairman of United, said the combined company would promote United's ''open access'' health plans, which permit members to consult any specialist from a list approved by United, without approval in advance by their primary doctor. **********Mr. Jones said it would have cost ''hundreds of millions of dollars'' for Humana to duplicate the computerized information systems that United has developed, which make it possible to allow more flexible choices of doctors for consumers while keeping track of physicians' activity, an important cost-control device for managed-care plans. **********Doctors whose costs for patients are deemed excessive ''can be identified and counseled,'' Mr. Jones said. **********Dr. McGuire said profit margins were narrow in health insurance, while the demand for more capital was increasing. ''You've got to have strong organizations,'' he said. **********The two companies combined would have 602,000 members in health maintenance organizations in Miami, or 48 percent of that market, according to Interstudy, a nonprofit managed-care research center in Minneapolis. Dr. McGuire said United and Humana would have 1.4 million customers in all types of health care in Florida, or less than 10 percent of the state's estimated 14.7 million people. **********In the Chicago market for health maintenance organizations, United and Humana would have a 28 percent share, ahead of H.M.O. Illinois, the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Plan, with 24 percent, Interstudy said. **********Under the deal, Mr. Jones would have 4.5 million shares of United Healthcare and a seat on the United board. No new positions were immediately announced for Gregory H. Wolf, chief executive of Humana, or other Humana executives. **********Security analysts said the lesser role for Humana officials could mean less of the clash of cultures that has hampered many deals. ''The track record for mergers in this sector is less than stellar,'' said Rob Maines, an analyst with Advest Inc. Analysts said it had taken a year to 18 months for several health care companies to get back on their feet after big merger deals. **********Dr. McGuire said the Humana acquisition would bring eventual savings of $100 million to $250 million by eliminating overlapping administrative costs and ''a couple hundred million'' through efficiencies in medical care, including $100 million from lower payments to hospitals. **********The combined company, with headquarters near Minneapolis, would start with 50,000 employees before shedding an unspecified number. **********In the transaction, Goldman, Sachs & Company and the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell advised United Healthcare. Humana was advised by Lehman Brothers and Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/10/world.snippet: Italian authorities listen to tape recordings between crew of NATO-based American plane that clipped ski cables in northern Italy and air traffic controllers; hope tapes will help them answer fundamental questions about plane's altitude, speed and...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/10/world.main_headline: Inquiry Hears Audio Tapes Of Jet That Hit Ski Lift Cable
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/10/world.print_headline: Inquiry Hears Audio Tapes Of Jet That Hit Ski Lift Cable
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/10/world.body_text: **********The Italian authorities said today that tape recordings of conversations between the crew of the American jet that clipped ski lift cables in northern Italy last week and air traffic controllers will help them to answer ''fundamental questions'' about the jet's altitude, air speed and flight path. **********But the recordings, which were analyzed on Sunday by a team of experts investigating the tragedy, may have limited value because they are likely to contain information as reported to air traffic controllers by crew members, regardless of whether it was accurate or not. So far it is unclear whether the crew had accurate maps and altitude information when it struck the cable. **********The accident happened last Tuesday, when an EA-6B Prowler, a Marine Corps electronic surveillance plane, sliced ski lift cables near Cavalese in the Dolomite Mountains. All 20 passengers in a ski lift car were killed when the gondola fell to the ground. **********The plane's pilot, Capt. Richard J. Ashby of the Marines, told defense lawyers that the plane's altitude measurement equipment appeared to be malfunctioning. But experts said such equipment would have been of little use at very low altitudes, meaning that the crew would have had to rely on the human eye to spot the cable. **********Until today, the focus of the investigation into the accident was the jet's mission recorder, which keeps track of speed, altitude and route. United States Air Force officials said today that software experts from the recorder's American manufacturer were on their way to Italy after investigators were unable to retrieve all of the recorder's coded data. **********But Francantonio Granero, an Italian prosecutor following the investigation, said the mission recorder's importance receded after the audio tapes were examined. While investigators would not reveal the contents of the tapes, Mr. Granero, speaking by phone from Trento, the capital of the Cavalese region, said experts informed him that ''they now have all the elements necessary to answer the fundamental questions'' about the flight. Such questions might include the jet's precise altitude at the time of the accident and the crew's knowledge of its exact location. **********The tower-to-cockpit tapes contain conversations between the crew and air traffic controllers at Aviano air base and two civilian air fields in northern Italy. Both the plane and the crew returned safely to the Aviano base after cutting the cables. **********The jets from Aviano patrol over Bosnia, but use the mountainous areas of northern Italy as a training ground for low-level flying. The purpose of the exercise when the accident occurred was to practice flying low enough to avoid detection by radar. The four-member crew of the Prowler had been stationed in Aviano since August, and the crew had done at least one previous six-month tour of duty there in 1996. But it remains unclear whether they had ever flown over the area of Cavalese on previous training flights.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/busin.snippet: David A Coulter, who has resigned as BankAmerica Corp president after huge losses, is guaranteed pension equal to 95 percent of his combined 1997 salary until his death; also gets $5.24 million bonus (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/busin.print_headline: PRIVATE SECTOR; What About His Dental Plan?
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/busin.body_text: **********When David A. Coulter resigned last week as president of the BankAmerica Corporation after huge losses there, he said the decision was ''extremely difficult for me, both personally and professionally.'' **********But was it difficult financially? Because of an unusual arrangement, Mr. Coulter, 51, is guaranteed a pension equal to 95 percent of his combined salary and bonus last year of $5.24 million, meaning he gets $4.98 million a year until his death. (Pensions of 50 percent to 60 percent are more common for senior executives approaching a more traditional retirement age.)  Mr. Coulter may have resigned to show he is willing to fall on his sword. ''But what they didn't tell you,'' said Graef Crystal, the compensation expert, ''was that there were 100 pillows between him and the sword.'' **********ADAM BRYANT
